text: Little bigger than I expected, and looks really well made. They even include a regular wrist strap for use when you're not in the water. Would buy again.
Fell apart the very first time I wore it. That's in contrast to a Peora chain I've worn every day & night for the past 3 years. Nice looking though.

Half the reason I want a case is to make the phone more grippable. This case is slippery polycarbonate plastic on the sides. It does seem like it would provide a little bit of shock guard if the phone were dropped on its edge or face. The charging and headphone cutouts are on the small side and I could not fit my Monoprice charging cable into the port while the case was on. I used a dremel tool to enlarge the charging port. Overall, decent for a couple bucks but still looking for a better case.

Yes, this fan is super quiet, but it is ridiculously expensive. I didn't find anything else that came close to the quiet noise level for a through-wall fan, and so I bought this. I'm happy with the performance, but still irked at the high cost.
Great style, but runs much larger than the size stated. Had to return.

Great looking--looks more like furniture than a filing cabinet. It is close to the brown-black bedroom furniture from Ikea--not identical but close enough that it blends. The box arrived pretty beat up, but there was no damages to any of the pieces. Quality is typical for this type of particle-board/MDF furniture. All of the holes lined up except for one, and that one was only slightly off so it required just a bit of widening with a screwdriver.I wanted something sturdy and relatively permanent, so I took the time to add construction adhesive to all the joints and connection points. I plan to put a flat screen TV on top, and it will support the weight with no problem.The mechanism to allow only one drawer at a time to open is pretty simple, and it works. It would not stand up to a lot of force, but that's not its purpose.There's no detente when the drawers are closed, and they do seem to have a tendency to come open. That's probably more an issue with my floors being level rather than an issue with the cabinet. I expect a couple of small shims under the front of the cabinet will remedy this.The handles are shiny plastic and pretty awful, but I bought solid brushed nickel ones at Home Depot for $4 each. It was well worth the trouble to replace them because it makes a big difference.  Cabinet handles come in different widths; purchase the ones that are 96 MM (4 3/4 inches) between screws. I did have to add a few washers to the inside of the drawer because the screws with the new handles were a little long, Spend an extra buck and get a few washers just in case.The bottoms of the drawers are fiberboard and won't hold a lot of weight. However, that's okay because the cabinet is intended for hanging files, so the weight is distributed on the rails at the top of the drawers.  Legal files fit laterally from side to side.  There are also bars to hang two rows of letter size files front-to-back. All rails are plastic, but they seem like they are strong enough.I do wish the cabinet had a lock, but I knew it did not have before I purchased.

Works great and comes with everything needed for an easy install.  The protector does not go to the edge of the phone--in fact it barely covers the viewable area. It should have been about 1/8 inch wider and taller. The "wet" wipe had dried out, but that was not enough of a problem to deduct another star.Update:  A few weeks after I installed this, I dropped my phone face down on the asphalt.  There were 2 large pits in the front, but I was not worried because it was just the cheap screen protector that was chipped and not the phone.  I replaced the screen protector with the same brand and the phone looks like new again.  Moral of the story--get a screen protector.
This is a must-have device for anyone who uses VPN.
Little pricey for what they are but they work great.
Great quality a lot of bags. Will last me forever.

The heat cycle works just fine, but the cool cycle only cools the yogurt to 80 degrees F which is pretty weak since the temperature in my house is 75 degrees F.I put the batch in at about 4 PM with the default 8 hour cycle. I expected to wake up the next morning (11 hours later) to chilled yogurt, but instead found room temperature yogurt. The yogurt tasted okay, but it's pretty hard to screw up yogurt and I've had success with a fairly wide variety of temperature & time combinations. I believe I could have gotten the same result by simply using a heating pad with a simple timer, or using my oven bread proof mode with its timer.Since the only function this provides for the expensive purchase price seems to be a small heater with timer, I can only give 1 star because there are much cheaper products and other mechanisms that accomplish the exact same thing with very little cost.Called Cuisinart and they recommended exchanging. I'm sending back but will probably not get a replacement.

Some genuinely entertaining moments in the spirit of Christopher Moore or Terry Pratchett, but overall a mediocre book.  The ending was especially abrupt--very much in the style of "I have to finish this in a couple days for the publishing deadline, so let's put a simple happily ever after on all the plot lines and tie it up in a bow."  If the price is right, it's worth a vacation read if nothing better presents itself, but not recommended otherwise.
Just as advertised--works great.

I've used the Lutron version before, and those are becoming harder to find and slightly more expensive so I ordered this one.  The Thomas & Betts version has an indicator lamp which is the only plus.  The build quality of Thomas & Betts feels inferior to Lutron.  The big problem is that the switch operation is not smooth--there is a detent in the off position (similar to Lutron, which is good) but there is also a detent at the full on position which makes the switch operation far from smooth.  In my application I want accurate and fine control, so I will go back to using the Lutron version.
Very solid construction. Seals tight and easy to install/use.
This is great--strongest hairspray I've ever used.

I tried these after using the 360 version.  These regular dusters are very thin and not worth the money. They do work, but I have to use 2 or 3 of them. The 360 version picks up much more dust and even though the 360s are more expensive, I think they are cheaper because they work better than this version.

This works great, though I wish that it came in satin nickel and was metal instead of plastic.  I wanted this to switch out a couple of different hand-held shower heads. I researched for quite a while online and this is the only product that seems to provide a quick change option for a reasonable price. I installed in about 5 minutes. No teflon plumber's tape is required because the seal is made using a couple of gaskets on the face of the adjoining fixtures. I did notice that in one case I needed to use a thicker gasket than came with this coupler, but I took the thicker gasket from the existing hand-held shower and that worked fine. This coupler is made of plastic with a chrome finish and seems about as well made as plastic can be and I expect it will hold up under occasional use. It does not leak, and if it does start to leak, I expect that I can get replacement gaskets & o-rings at the local hardware store. Even though it is chrome finished and the rest of my bathroom is brushed nickel, it's really not that noticeable a difference.  I am planning to buy a second one because it's a reasonably inexpensive part and just in case the plastic does happen to break and I can't find anything else similar.

I do not understand why there are raves about this machine's keyboard. On a regular keyboard I type about 90 wpm. I have an older laptop with chiclet keys that I can type about the same speed on.  This keyboard is too stiff for fast typing and I find myself making mistakes and my hands fatiguing because the keys require more force to press than I'm comfortable with.

Disappointed with build quality. Bought two of these about a year ago and have used them fairly lightly only during occasional travel.  One of them is now failing to reliably charge my iPhone--I get the dreaded "Accessory not supported" message. I know this issue is due to the cable deteriorating since one cable still works with the same charger/phone.  But--I am very frustrated that Apple chose to engineer their products to ensure that non-Apple chargers won't charge at all. Apparently their idea of ensuring a good user experience means that NO charging is better than SLOW charging.  I won't make the mistake of buying an Apple product again.

I'm getting to that age where I appreciate the finer things in life, such as fine companionship, fine wine, fine food, and being able to read a damn menu in a fine dining establishment. Apparently, to qualify as "fine dining", a restaurant must be lit by no more then 3 candles strategically placed on non-adjacent tables so that there is no direct light whatsoever hitting my menu. Enter the rimless tube readers. These things are TINY and fit into a case that's not much bigger than a pencil, but in a pinch allow me read menus and playbills. They even fit in the pockets of those tight leather pants I should have stopped wearing at the end of the Reagan era. They're not intended for long-term use if you're doing serious reading, but the compact size ensures that they can always be on hand if you need them when out & about. I have a couple pairs of drugstore reading glasses of the same power and even though the lenses on these are smaller, the optical quality is obviously much higher.  I expect I will be a long time customer because I I think I will always have a couple pairs of these onhand in my computer & messenger bags. Buy a pair...you won't regret it.

These are a great size for always carrying in a pocket or handbag. The reason I don't give 5 stars is because the case is plastic and I suspect it will break at some point. I'm going to put these in my computer bag and the case will receive quite a bit of abuse.  I would really prefer an aluminum case.

I really like this. My usage is on a space heater in the bathroom because I want to make sure that I don't forget and leave it turned on.  Why not 5 stars?  Because pressing the button once, sets the device to be permanently on.  The reason that I want this is to ensure that the heater turns off, so I wish there were no permanent-on function. I do understand this adds flexibility to the timer/switch, but I've seen others make the same comment so I don't think I'm alone.  I'd pay probably twice the price if I could find one that had NO permanent on function.
Always had good luck with ProCell in all sizes.
Very nicely weighted and sharp. Great for some light log splitting work for the occasional fire. Lizzie Borden would love this.
CAFFEINE. WOW.  WOO-HOO.  I'M AWAKE...It's just caffeine. The only thing I don't like is that it's hard to break the pills in half, which is usually what I do.
useful for carrying wood short distances. a little kludgy to use sometimes, but better than tracking wood chips and dust into the house.
Great for starting fires.
Wish it had elastic straps that went around the head. The over the ear loops are workable, but the mask works loose and is not always effective.
Used this a lot for checking for winter drafts and general temperature sensing.
Great book on breadmaking.
Great snacks. Wish they had a little less sugar though.
This is indispensible for telecommuters working on VPN.
These are great clips. Threw away a bunch of grocery store clips as they fell apart and replaced with these.
These are indispensible
Worked perfectly for a wiring closet.

This works to crimp RJ45 and RJ11 connectors.  It cuts cable very well.  It does not strip cat 5e cable--I tried many times to use the stripping function and found that it always cut some of the wires. This may possibly work for stranded cables, but did not work well for solid core cable.
Love these single use tubes--I always keep a bunch on hand.
Just what I needed for some gas piping.
The glue bonds, just like all superglue does. I found I did not like the gel consistency for my application. YMMV

The Take is an intense crime tale with intrigue, betrayal, murder, and great dramatic build-up.John Leguizamo plays Felix de la Pena, a security truck driver caught in a complex robbery scheme where the ruthless villain – played very coldly by Tyrese Gibson – has a series of moving parts to cover his tracks and potentially implicate de la Pena.  The deceit and twists are portrayed well enough to leave some doubt as to who exactly is involved in the crime, and to what lengths each will go to preserve their freedom.  Agent Perelli (Cannavale), the lead detective on the case, is an even-tempered man who, despite mounting evidence, has a difficult time finding Leguizamo's character guilty.  Add in the hellish world being married to Rosie Perez must be, and it is easy to see why a man could potentially commit a crime that may ruin his life.The ending, while a little anti-climactic, is gritty and realistic.  No heroes.  No masterful revenge.  No regular Joe turning into Charles Bronson.  Just an awaiting, inevitable ending.

Steal a meth-head drug dealer’s toothbrush?  No big deal; it’s not like he’s using it.  Take his money, however, and there will certainly be problems.A Swollen Red Sun sets up this common theme of stolen drug money with realism and believability.  Fully develop characters present the evils of the methamphetamine world and those who suffer as a result.  The main tweaker, James Dean Skaggs, is realistic enough, even if a bit of the details of the world painted by Matthew McBride feel a little over the top.The comparisons to the complexities of Justified’s Harlan County are apt.  The wickedness and diversity of the drug world’s scum is very entertaining.  The storyline is a bit predictable, but entrancing enough to make this a quick and enjoyable read.

The foot, ankle, and calf compression feels great during exercise.  Post-run I still had a nice squeeze.  Whether or not the science behind it is legit is something above me medical knowledge, but what I do know is that these compression socks make my legs - particularly my calves - feel good.  The fit and contour is excellent, provided the socks are put on the correct feet.The only negative I have for this product is the moisture wicking aspect.  While my feet don't slide in the socks, and the sweat is expelled fairly well, my feet slide in the shoes when on longer runs.  That caused a dilemma, a choice between sliding or very tight shoes (which causes its own issues while running).Overall I like these socks very much, and would highly recommend them to the average, recreational runner.

I laughed twice in the introduction.  The first few lists felt like someone invading my personal life.This is a great book of lists about everything parenthood.  It's a guidebook, a warning pamphlet, a safety guide, and a ton of humor.  For anyone who is a parent, particularly if the children are still young, this book will resonate deeply.  If the kids are grown it's a source of nostalgia.I enjoyed the book immensely, and it really made me think about, and appreciate, that my kids still eat hot dogs like corn on the cob.

I don't have specific times or dates for my test, but I put these bad boys in a child's toy that my daughter would take anywhere and everywhere, and they have lasted for much longer than the average battery I've used before.  When toys have motion and sound, they seem to wear out quicker than those with just a single component, but I've not had any problems with battery life.  The police could be having a shoot-out in my cul-de-sac while a tornado goes through, and I'd still here that addictive, annoying jingle from her favorite singing toy.  So,  in retrospect, good and bad for me.Very solid battery that will last a long time, and apparently has a shelf-life that will survive cockroaches in the next apocalypse.

The color and design is gender-neutral and unassuming.  I like that.  The changing pad is a perfect size, folds up easy, and fits in the bag just fine.  The extra pocket can be used for a few things, but not much.  Size-wise, the entire kit is easy to lug around without being burdened by my wife's diaper bag that would get charged over-weight fees on commercial airliners.  It fits enough diapers that I don't have to worry about anything if I'm gone for a few hours...even if there is a blowout involved.The only downside I see to this kit, and it's sort of nit-picking, is that there isn't suitable room for a wipes case.  Sure, there's room for a ziplock baggy of a few, or a portable case of a few, but to get "down and dirty" - you know what I'm talking about - running out of wipes is a disaster.  I had to sacrifice a diaper or two in order to get a sufficient wipes case in there.

After the great War of Chicago, there are Transformer parts and carcasses lying about like nuts and bolts at the bottom of a toolbox.  Those not destroyed have gone deep undercover, remaining the barely noticeable sentient robots that can turn into cars, jets, etc., who fear humanity’s reprisal.  To maximize concealment, a post-war Optimus Prime parks inside an old theater in disrepair.  You know, to be inconspicuous with the rest of the trucks at the movie theater.  Oh wait.  It’s just him?  Scratch that then.  Good thing nobody noticed him.  Nevermind…a wannabe American Picker named Cade Yeager (Wahlberg) “stumbles” upon the scene, and the elephant in the room is almost literal, except replace elephant with alien, shape-shifting, bullet-riddled, rocket-filled semi in a movie theater.After a quick tow home to his nearly repossessed farm where is super-hot daughter Tessa (Nicola Peltz) is lamenting the fact that her father can’t pay the bills, Cade hooks the rig up to a battery and TADA!, Optimus Prime is shape-shifting, dropping parts like a robot leper, and waxing philosophic about the comrades he has lost.  The bad news for both Yeager and Prime is that a CIA agent named Harold Attinger (Kelsey Grammer) has teamed up with the intergalactic version of Dog the Bounty Hunter – thankfully without Beth – to capture/destroy all remaining Transformers.  Some level of government deceit is present, as many involved believe on the Decepticons are being targeted, but that does not compute to Optimus Prime.  The rest of the movie is a battle of survival against the government, the Decepticons, Dog the Bounty Hunter, and the film’s run-time.Speaking of run-time…165 minutes.  Really?  One wouldn’t think a movie filled with Michael Bay ejaculate (i.e. explosions) every other minute would be boring, but the film drags on.  Considering the various unnecessary subplots involving TJ Miller as nothing more than a Star Trek redshirt, Bingbing Li as a complete throwaway character, the tired “over-protective father won’t let his hot daughter date”-angle, the inclusion of a pointless boyfriend and associated romance, and a bomb/seed that helps Transformer-terraform a world, there really is some serious editing that could have been done.  Considering the lengthy and expensive FX, much of which becomes pretty repetitive towards the end, I’m sure viewers wouldn’t miss an explosion here or there.  You know it’s bad when the Dinobots make an appearance and I’m too drained to care much.Wahlberg is a huge improvement over Labeouf.  In every way possible.  To be quite honest, I even preferred Peltz to Megan Fox, but purely for the change of scenery and the super-short shorts Peltz painted on for most of the scenes.  The FX and sound are obviously outstanding, maybe the best I’ve ever seen/heard.Great for Transformer diehards and teenage boys, OK for cinephiles and anyone looking for a mindless explosion festival, rentable for most others.

I'm always uncertain about how all the cleaning products work.  Sure, I could read about how the oxygen molecules react quickly to get the uh, cranberry juice, I mean, cran-apple, out of my Cerruti sheets.  Lord knows the mouthy lady at the cleaners could use some Oxy Stain Remover.  She wanted to use bleach!  Unacceptable!!  Or maybe someone could break down the science of how this stuff can get the large pools of blood out of my white carpets and the beige sheets I lined my furniture with when Paul Allen stopped by for a drink.  Thank goodness I had a Clear rubber rain coat on to protect my Valentino suit.Put simply, this stuff works great!  Just ask my real estate agent about how clean she got my uptown apartment before the showing.

The trend - maybe it's always been this way - is to find neutral colors, add in a splash here and there, and try not to be ostentatious.  This curtain is exactly what the doctor ordered.  Beige?  Check.  Simple butterflies, simple foliage, and script provide just enough decoration and color without being too busy.  Check.  This curtain goes perfectly with the Stainmaster TruSoft Luxurious Bath Rug.Notes:-Standard 70x72-PVC-free PEVA (added bonus once I discovered the benefits)-Minor smell upon unpackaging

While this book has many positives, I'd like to start this review by briefly focusing on the negatives.The cons of the book are clear.  Children can cheer and clap at chronicles containing comedy, characters, and simple concepts - child's play.  Confronting children with challenging concepts of conservation, conversely, could conceivably confuse children if alliteration considerations are anything above circumstantial or carefully calculated.  I think I've made my point.  One other issue I have is the unevenness of the pictures and wording.  Instead of paragraphs, which are often difficult for children to listen to, pictures in children's books should flow with the words.  The pictures should tell the story along with the words.  Easier for young minds to remember and enjoy.  I don't believe this book accomplishes the harmony required for its target audience.Having said all that, I thought the illustrations were easy to grasp.  My daughter immediately started pointing at pictures and telling me what each item was.  Some new items (like the dropper) stumped her, but I enjoyed the blend of common and uncommon.  Additionally, the colors are bright, vibrant, and easy on the eyes.  Some of the wording, particularly from the dropper (i.e. "drop, drop, drop"), are fun to play around with.  I ad-libbed some hand movements and a tickle game into that portion of the book.  The size and thickness of the pages points to this being better for an older audience (5-8 is good).  The various scientific concepts are a great way of introducing complex concepts in a simple manner - my favorite is the chalk circles around the puddles.Overall this is an above average book that serves as a springboard for inquisitive minds.

The key to food storage is tensile strength.  On the bag itself and also on the seal.These quart food storage bags pass with flying colors in each area.  I've put meat, veggies, liquids, just about everything in these bags.  They do not stretch or flex.  The color-combo (yellow+blue=green) lets me know when things are questionably sealed.  That's a major need for marinating meats.It's pretty hard to top this product, and it's no wonder they've dominated the market.  Highly recommended.

I love movies.  I love popcorn.  This seemed like the perfect product for me.  For the most part it is.The flavor is a salty hint of cheddar that amps up popcorn just a little bit.  The holes in the shaker are pretty wide, so the product comes out quickly.  Very quickly.  On popcorn, it doesn't seem like too much.  Get a bag, pour, shake the bag, pour one more time and it's just about right.  What's more, it completely regenerated some semi-stale popcorn I had from the last movie outing.  I'd guess one container would last 25-30 big, movie popcorn buckets.Word for the warning, however, it is not good on anything else.  I tried it on pizza, chicken, and some potatoes.  Bad on all.  Not bad on wheat thins though.  Tread carefully when experimenting with this product.

I enjoy tea much less than the average southerner.  If I'm drinking it, however, I pretty much have to feel like it's got a bucket of sugar in it in order to enjoy it.  Which makes this product surprising to me.One squirt provides a watered down tea taste, like a big glass with lots of ice that's been sitting on the deck in a hot sun.But two ample squirts and the flavor was a pleasant, mild tea with a subtle honey flavor.  Very nice.I'm not sure how many drinks this will last, but I've had several glasses of "tea" afterwards and it still feels pretty full.  Very comparable to Mio products if you've used them.

For many, Phil Klay's "Redeployment" will read as nothing more than choppy sentences, questionable grammar, and indecipherable military acronyms.  Others, however, those like me, having been in or around the military every day of my life, it reads like a hilariously accurate, day-by-day account of military life in some respects, and a completely heart-wrenching detail of what war does to our military in others.  The camaraderie, the ball-busting, the brothers in arms.  The death, the carnage, the psychological damage.  This collection of stories is every bit the Iraq war counterpart to O'Brien's "The Things They Carried."For some it could be a tough read - esoteric source material & jargon - but it's an absolute bullseye for the target audience.

This Arnold flick is a combination of several other movies, covering minimal ground, providing extremely predictable entertainment and action, very enthusiastic gun-play, and classic Arnold one-liners.Prisoner transfer under heavy surveillance goes horribly wrong – S.W.A.T.A vehicle being chased by multiple police units gets snatched up by a crane – Operation SwordfishBad guys have a secret way of crossing the border from the U.S. to Mexico – Fast & FuriousSmall town cop gets pressed into duty against superior bad-guy army – pick a movieSmall town cop deputizes Johnny Knoxville – Walking TallSmall town cop and motley crew hold off superior forces – Rio Bravo, etc.Throw in a cartel boss who also happens to be a professional race car driver, and the movie writes itself.  I didn’t hate it or love it, hence the 3-stars, but I was really hoping Arnold’s return would have more oomph.

Jarra Townsend plays Sam, an emotionally distant woman overcoming her recent relationship issues.  To overcome this issue she attends a party where her smeared-lipstick, drunken whore of a friend (Alice Macdonald as Alice) gets her smashed enough that she accepts a drink from a stranger named BJ (Simon Barrett) and later has intercourse with him in an uncomfortable location (get your mind out of the gutter!  I’m talking about the backseat of a car.)She awakens the following day with what appear to be relatively minor issues, cold, having headaches, too much eye makeup, questionable henna tattoos.  Things go from bad to worse in a hurry, and the premise of this movie (i.e. Patient Zero) takes shape.  In a completely different way than most other similar films, it’s actually quite terrifying.In some ways this movie felt like an extension from Kids to various zombie du jour films of today.  Very nice change of pace from the norm.

What happens when a U.S. President's kids get killed by internationally-connected and funded drug cartels?  Basically Operation Swordfish with drones, as Troy Pearce, CEO of Pearce Systems, is called upon to unleash hell via a squadron of drones.The topic’s timeliness is fairly current, with drone technology becoming more pervasive in American warfare.  Similarly, the tech aspects and military jargon is legit, and no so deep as to be off-putting.  The plot itself – a U.S. President utilizing spec-ops folks to conduct a secret mission to take out individual adversaries – is realistic enough that it has been successfully accomplished in recent memory.  I have worked with the government sector, aviation in particular, enough to have shaken a hand or two that might be called on to perform such a real-world action.  Having said that, any situation where there is a potential war between the US and Mexico has to be discounted somewhat.  The conclusion would be the U.S. taking a huge dump on Mexico, resulting in what would be a 51st state named “Texas’s Diaper.”  I felt the inclusion of the Russians and Iranians was supposed to smooth out that rough edge, but it’s just not very realistic in my opinion.I mostly enjoyed the blend of characters, and while reading could see the script come to life through specific actors.  The primary players represents a wide variety of people, and could easily be an Ocean’s Eleven cast.  Speaking of that, the one small issue I had with the novel is the fact that it just felt like too much was going on.  Too many moving pieces.  It felt like a Soderbergh script and I had to revert back to the character list a time or two to clear things up.

Revolving around protagonist Air Force Major Nick Baron and his Triple Seven Chase spec-ops team, the novel Shadow Catcher delivers a good blend of military reconnaissance, espionage, sabotage, and warfare.  Originally on a mission to recover a lost stealth bomber on the sea-bed, Nick and his team encounter harpoon-wielding enemies intent on stealing the high-tech booty.  Meanwhile, a long lost MIA/POW places a distress call to which Triple Seven has to respond.Shadow Catcher has a good blend of personal and professional.  The character development and interweaving relationships are both handled very well, with just enough mix to make it enjoyable without turning into a parody of military novel character building.  Similarly, the military jargon and details avoid the esoteric, making it perfect for the average POG.  Detail-oriented and well-researched, but not to the extent of someone like Neal Stephenson, the novel is fast-paced, enjoyable, and a quick read.

In terms of simplicity and comfort, this is a top-notch product.  It's as simple as fitting the loop over the dog's head, and attaching one buckle.  I am very pleased with this aspect.  There appears to be enough padding to avoid any sort of chafing, and even if there weren't, the seams are far enough back that they don't rub the underarm area.The one issue I have is with the fact that most dogs, being stubborn with new things, won't like being pulled along by this product.  I suppose they don't like the traditional neck-collar either, but this one definitely takes some getting used to.  Once my doberman realized what it was, things were fine.  The very few times she pulls it works out perfect.  I even prefer it to the neck collar because I can lift her with minimal issues when situations arise.  She just didn't want to budge at first and she was less responsive to the pulling.Good product.

Presumably someone buys this because they own a larger dog that would benefit from easier access bowls.  The height is fine.  The stability is also very good, with a wide enough base that the entire set doesn't topple, and rubber grips that keep the bowls relatively still.  The one flaw, however, is the bowl volume.  If my dog is big enough to need elevated bowls, then my dog also requires increased food quantity.  This bowl requires more often filling than our previous bowls.If it's a matter of my minor inconvenience versus the dog's strained neck, it's an easy choice.  I just wish the bowls were a little bigger.

The quality in construction is great.  Perfect size and thick pages for little hands.  Vibrant photos and background colors fill the 26 pages.  It's just enough to occupy my daughter (<2 y/o) without boring her.  In other words, we don't dwell on the pages too long.The only thing I don't like - something pointed out In other reviews - is the fact that the books about puppies bad kittens aren't really learning books.  Well, there are words there, but the words are just random names for the animals.  An easy solution would be to include simple adjectives: "Bubbles is playful," or "Sunny is playful."Overall, however, a quality product perfect for bedtime reading.

I have reviewed both films separately, and both earned high praise for good reason."In Hell" feature JCVD in a corrupt Russian prison that pits inmates against one another for the amusement of the guards and upper staff.  It's kill or be killed, with weaklings served to conquering champions like so many scraps of meat.  This is one of JCVD's more nuanced performances, where he takes a small step away from the typical splits, jump kicks, and slow-motion fight scenes.  It's a gritty, brutal display of combat, despair, and perhaps even a slight bit of psychosis.  Overall the movie has a ton of action, and acceptable plot, and is severely underappreciated."Wake of Death" is perhaps JCVD's Magnum Opus.  In a movie where he must reach his darkest moment, JCVD manages to balance the attributes all his fans love (e.g. high flying kicks) with a violent action movie rivaling the concept behind so many revenge flicks (think Death Wish).  I can't express enough how exciting the action is in this movie.  Including what I contend is one of the 5 best car chase scenes in cinema history, there is not a single pause in the film.  From beginning to end there is something exploding, a kick breaking someone's face, or blood splatter flying against a wall.This is just about as good as it gets in terms of a JCVD-DVD combo package.  Highly rewatchable.

First, the boring stuff.  The packaging is cute.  It's a blue box that can be ripped open to act as tray and storage.  Put it on the bottom shelf in the pantry and watch the kiddo feed herself.  It's kind of like a 12-pack of soda, how opening one end makes the box suddenly functional.  Now, let's get down to brass tacks.My daughter (20 months) inhales this stuff.  It's liquid crack.  She learned the word "pouch" VERY quickly.  We unscrew the cap (great design/implementation for reseal/reuse) and hand the pouch to her.  A few seconds later and she's either asking for help or more.  Help because she can't get the stuff at the bottom, and she can feel the difference in the bag.  More because she obviously needs her fix.  We'll probably need to detox her later on.  She eats regular table food (demolishes cucumbers and pizza), but she absolutely loves these.  Works great when we're on the go or when she's being a picky eater.To be thorough I gave one a small taste.  They are pretty bitter to the adult palate; well, they are bitter to me.  Out of the three fruits listed, I'd say blueberry won the battle by a wide margin.  Very tasty, but strong.We've tried several other brands of fruit/veggie puree, and I'd have to say she likes this one the best.  For whatever that's worth.Great product.  Happy Dad.

This is probably not the book for dividend growth investors or buy-and-hold types.  The description points to universality, but it’s probably a step above a Dummies book, and definitely isn’t targeted to a typical investor.  Make no mistake, investing is not trading.  This book is for those who want to trade stocks.  Buy low, sell high, get in and get out with a profit.Some of the financial tech stuff is a bit esoteric, but I guess that’s the point.  In order to truly understand and trade, one must have a semi-firm grasp on financial statements, market trends, complex analysis, etc.  With that said, however, this book is probably just right for the would-be trader.  The investor who wants more, who wants to learn trend and day trading basics.  Take it to the next step.I’d say overall this book is a nice blend for most, but certainly a bit advanced for the typical “Dummy” reader who wants to start something from scratch.

Stifler from American Pie.Crudeness of Super Bad.Harold and Kumar's Dad, and med. interview.Partying from Project X.A little bit of Weekend at Bernie's.One thing from Revenge of the Nerds.Even some of the great Game of Death.Stew it all in urine, feces, vomit, and a ton of alcohol, and the results are both predictable and hilarious.  If you're into that sort of thing.  I laughed quite a bit.  Coming from the creators of Hangover, it should come as no surprise it got a little tedious towards the end (like Hangover 3), but I'm not disappointed I watched it.

After countless cramps and difficulties with marathon distance runs, I’ve looked high and low for the answers.  As such, one of my searches took me towards yoga and increased flexibility, not to mention core strength and improved breathing.  Which is interesting, because author Christine Felstead goes into great details in the beginning stages of her book to impress upon readers why yoga is so beneficial to runners. From injuries to breathing, Felstead’s quite thorough.Subsequently, the book has a detailed look at 88 poses focusing on the various muscle groups and how they relate to running.  What I like most about this part is that it’s not simply an explanation of how to do the pose, but also what to do to avoid injury.  As a yoga novice, I can attest to the fact that yoga is difficult and can hurt if done too strenuously or incorrectly.As if the book were intended specifically for me, there is even a section called “Yoga Off the Mat,” which is focused on poses that can be done at work, behind the desk.  Pretty great stuff for those of us who don’t waste half the day on “smoke breaks.”I intend to fully implement this at the work place in the very near future.  With any luck it will be just one more thing in my runner’s arsenal with which I can attack the next hill, marathon, or if I’m lucky, ultra.

The pack of four works perfect for multiple rooms and has a variety of wonderful aspects.Size-wise it's very unobtrusive.  About the height/width of a credit card, and it's only an inch or so deep.  The light itself is mellow, not too bright or dark.  It provides a glow that spreads throughout a room like a soft moon glow illuminating through a window.  The final positive is the night light auto-sensor feature. It turns on/off automatically based on the light in the room, which works great for a little one who wakes before sunrise (lucky me).Highly recommended.

Author Kilian Jornet (Burgada) takes us from childhood through current accomplishments, providing a few details about a variety of running philosophies, psychologies, and training plans along the way.  As an accomplished ski mountaineer and mountain runner, his accomplishments are quite esoteric, but they are nonetheless impressive.  It's just that the stories themselves are terribly interesting or exciting.The major strength of this memoir is that he really does let us inside his mind and his psyche.  I related to the story about a song getting stuck in his head, because I've often lost a mile or two before realizing I was thinking about a song, or a sport, or bacon during that period of time.  Very useful strategy.  My take on Kilian is that he's equal part physically gifted, driven, and psychologically strong.  The lattermost item being the most important, he's able to self-motivate when necessary and distract when not.  That's an incredibly useful tool for a long distance runner or ultra-athlete.Nonetheless, the title of my review is kind of my take on the book.  If you've seen the movie Dodgeball, you'll get the reference in the title.  A lot of this book just seems repetitive; others have hinted at it being a translation issue.  It's just not a terribly organized or interesting book.  Those looking for a good Ultra book should read Dean Karnazes instead.  Those interested in a motivating running book, try Meb Keflezighi's work.

What I want in a hand sanitizer is simple:Foam + Clean Feeling - Scent - WetnessThis product fits the bill.I never get sick.  My daughter is impeccably healthy.  My wife and I clean pretty regularly, but don't go overboard.  She probably uses this more than I do.  Heck, I don't wash my hands all that regularly (they get washed in the shower).  Admittedly, I'm probably the wrong father for this product.  It seems the more over-sanitized and medicated we become, the worse we are.  Just yesterday I let my daughter eat something off the floor.  On purpose.  The more I expose her to, the better.  But when presented with a small way to potentially improve health, I decided to give this product a try.  When I happen to think about it, I use this hand sanitizer, but it's not a habit by any means.What I like about this product is the foam.  It's pleasant on the hands, doesn't dry skin out, and dissipates very quickly.  Absolutely zero smell.  And when I use it my hands feel clean.Does it work?  I think so.  Is it safe?  Other reviewers - some no doubt followers of Jenny McCarthy and lots of late nights searching "my baby coughed" on WebMD - are going crazy about a chemical I've never heard of, but thus far nobody in my circle of family/friends has had an issue.  It seems the most contentious ingredient is benzalkonium chloride, and after a bit of research, it appears to be a chemical so ubiquitous that if you were to avoid it here you'll almost certainly run into it elsewhere.  The others?  Meh.Solid product.  If forced to buy hand sanitizer I'd probably buy the cheapest product, but I'd take this as a gift in a heartbeat.

Like his character cracks skulls and leathery-faced smiles, Gunnar Hansen, the original Leatherface, cracks the spine of his old note-ridden manuscripts to serve as diarist/historian for Tobe Hooper’s legendary The Texas Chain Saw Massacre.  Revealing previously unknown details and personal anecdotes, Hansen dispatches rumors and stories like unwanted intruders, providing the kind of behind-the-scenes information all commentary tracks should envy.For any Chainsaw fan, this is an absolute must have.  Genre fans as well.  It’s a step by step understanding of the actors, cinematography, directing, production staff, and all other details/difficulties that went in to making the horror epic.  I consider myself a big horror fan, and knew I would love the book going in.  But what I didn’t know was that I would learn so much.  The numerous details are like so many blood splatter on a wall: too many to count.Absolutely awesome in every way, and something I’ll refer to when watching the film again.

What most kids' toys require are vibrant colors, responsive controls, and loud noises.  This toy lacks all three.The screen is the first issue.  It's small.  And dark.  Real dark.  On top if that, it's very old looking technology that will not interest a kid who has seen the world of iPhones and computers.  For the computer folks like me, think less Java and more BASIC.The controls are rudimentary at best.  Lots of options aren't necessarily better than the fewer good options.  I could probably wash windows with a gallon of toilet water, but I'm gonna go with Windex instead.  It's not really worth mentioning the numerous options - there are plenty - because only one or two will hold a child's attention long enough to give Daddy time to catch a breather.The volume is poor, and it's not a big shocker.  With loud enough music maaaaaybe it's distracting enough to ignore the the generally disappointing overall product.I can't recommend this product at all.  In the 50s this might have garnered a child's attention, but it's far from compelling.  The only thing my daughter ever wants to do with it is close the lid and throw it.  Expensive doorstop, that's it.

The 8 Maxims alluded to in the title are as follows:1.  Don't Rush into Buying, and Avoid Further Bleeding2.  Profit from One Chosen Industry or a Selected Few Industries3.  Reference External Inputs but Stay Focused4.  Trust but Verify5.  Manage and Accept Portfolio Risks6.  Profit from Policies and Trends7.  Emotions and Investments Don't Mix8.  Maintain Health and WealthOf course, that is somewhat common sense.  Where this book succeeds is in the supporting details, the evidence, the facts, and the statistics.  From rudimentary to esoteric, there is something for everyone.  I learned a few technical details, a website I didn't know, and generally reinforced my investing beliefs.  It's nice to read the reinforcement.Anyway, it's not the best book out there, but it's a quick read with plenty of information for what it's worth.  I enjoyed it, and may go through it more closely in the future with a highlighter to pick out the real gems.

After replacing pretty much my entire toilet, I was left with one small issue: leaky flapper.  That sounds like a personal issue of some sort, but I'm talking about the toilet.This product's positives are easy to produce:1) No reliance on old flapper that is independent of the overflow tube.2) No mounting ears required3) Fit my toilet like a charm, and I suspect it would fit nearly all toilets.4) Zero leaking, and a very tight seal5) The "caulking compound" (it's putty) was malleable and easy to install.  Everything fit and sealed the very first time.6) Ample chain to attach to the handleThe basics of this product are a putty ring, a two piece flapper with a hinge, and a chain/hook.  Apply the putty ring, ensure a tight fit, push down on the flapper ring component for a second tight fit, and then attach the chain.  Easy.  The putty ring is ample, will certainly last quite some time.  There is even a replacement valve in case the one attached to the flapper fails.My toilet is not leaking, which makes me a happy camper.  Great product.

My toilet kept running, and since I’m not a fast guy I decided to fix it before it got away.  Pun aside, that’s why I bought the Fluidmaster 400A Anti-Siphon Toilet Tank Fill Valve.  I’m moderately pleased, and a little disappointed.First off, the issue with my toilet was multi-faceted.  One, the flapper wasn’t sealing correctly.  Two, the float ball was not functioning properly on my older model; it was bobbing. No matter the adjustment, it sunk to the overflow tube because of a faulty valve in the refill valve assembly.  I wanted to get away from the float ball conundrum, so this was a good purchase.The installation was easy enough, with one catch.  The tubing to the water connection – all four listed types – do not match up with the enclosed parts.  The cone washer and coupling nut that connect the tubing to the lock nut on the threaded shank won’t go over the top of the typical tubing.  Hence, no connection.  Of the four (Metal/Copper Flared, Metal Flanged, Metal Spiral, Vinyl/Braided) I had the Metal Flanged Tubing, with its existing coupling nut and plastic cone washer.  Once installed, it’s not a good idea to reuse that because the threading slice made into the plastic cone washer might not seal properly.  As a result, I planned on using the cone washer and the coupling nut provided in the installation kit.  Well, that’s impossible because every tubing piece sold by Home Depot and Lowe’s literally doesn’t fit the enclosed coupling nut and/or cone washer.  Luckily these pieces are pretty universal, and I bought a cheap vinyl/braided connector.  It doesn’t, however, solve the “leftover parts”-dilemma that plagues everyone at the end of plumbing installation.The only other sketchy part of this installation is the 1/8th counterclockwise rotation required for the valve top.  My system is working right now, but the point if this isn’t clear and it felt very breakable.  I’m guessing the lugs are very fragile.So, minor installation and leftover parts issues aside, I think it works thus far.  Now on to the flapper.

Bought it for my wife and people constantly ask her about it.  They comment about the retro nature, the old school.  Not only does it look cool, but it's functional.The cover is rubber that will absolutely not let the phone slide.  It's also somewhat flexible, which makes it easy to remove if necessary.  This could be a negative.  The only real negative, however, is the fact that there is no hole for the charging cable.  Huh?!  It's not like that was a big mystery addition.  The phone has to charge, and removing it every time is just unacceptable.

I should have read reviews.  This product is complete garbage.  Junk.  I did not treat it rough.  I simply added a single card at a time to see what would fit.  It broke within ten minutes of receiving.  Maybe five.  The problem is that the wallet hinges on its hinge.  Which is nothing more than a small, fragile, plastic piece that catches on another.  Guess what broke?  And now, within mere minutes, it's borderline useless since it won't close.This is literally the worst productive I have ever purchased, and I have bought food that gave me "explosive, wrap myself in a shower curtain"-food poisoning.  At least that tasted good going down.

I don't have the same problems others have mentioned.  My ticket stubs from sports, movies, concerts, plays, and various events (Chicken and Egg Festival, various BBQ festivals) all fit just fine.  I'm not really sure what would have been preferred.  Maybe a book that allows a user to adjust specific holding areas?  Spit-balling is all.  For what it is, it's a pretty decent product.

Really cool.  Some older stuff you've probably never heard of.  I got several that I actually recognized, however.  They are an absolutely perfect conversation-piece.  And to top it all off, they do the job perfectly!  There is no condensation stickage that attached the coaster to the cup when picking the cup up.  So far ours haven't worn out.  And if someone needs one across the room?  Perfect little frisbees.  (only recommended for adults with good hand-eye coordination and athletic ability)  I've even used mine, when I was too lazy to get up, to cut some blocked cheddar cheese.  Don't judge me.

This is perfect as a supplement to normal feeding.  Most toddlers are peculiar about eating.  We call my daughter a grazer.  She grazes and grabs a cucumber slice.  Then a cracker.  Then nothing.  All she wants is candy, cookie, etc.  (Amazing how quickly they learn those words, huh?)  So we are very lucky she really likes the formula.  Some days it’s all she wants, running into the room whining, telling me she wants “mek-mek,” which sometimes sounds like “meh-meh” and I ask her why she’s so blasé about everything.  Toddlers with rumbling tummies don’t understand Daddy humor.Anyway, our secret concoction is one scoop of this vanilla flavored stuff, one scoop of the regular one, and some whole milk to top things off.  She loves it.  Of course, she’d probably always choose a Capri-Sun or a small sip of Daddy’s soda, but 99 times out of a 100 she’s extremely happy to get her “mek.”

Getting a toddler to happily and properly brush teeth is like putting a dog in a bathtub.  Good luck with that.  The Gund Brush Your Teeth Bear is an attempt to make it more tolerable.  How?First, generate excitement like it's something fun to do:"Ooohhh, Goody!"  I'm so excited to brush my teeth with you!"Then sing an enjoyable song (to the tune of "Wheels on the Bus"):"Brush your teeth in the front.  Brush up and down.  Up and down.  Up and down."The animation is great.  The bear rocks back and forth to the beat while the left hand makes a continuous brushing motion up and down.  The entire song/dance/brushing lasts about 2 minutes, has further encouragement, instruction for each area of the mouth (front, side, back, tongue), and finishes off with sparkling teeth.The Gund Bear is adorable, sturdy, instructional, and relevant.  The only flaw we've experienced is that the brushing arm can be misaligned if picked up during brushing, and it's difficult to move higher.  It ends up looking like the bear is brushing it's torso if you can't get the arm just right.  A minor concern if you pay attention to your little one when they are brushing and grabbing the bear.  And to be honest, if I can get my little one to associate hugs with brushing teeth, then I'm fine if she grabs it while it's in motion.

We tried every diaper there is.  Even cloth, reusable.  The Pampers line, particularly the Cruisers, are the best diapers out there.  Even with the redesign.As the product description mentions, the snug fit adapts to the waist, legs, and bottom.  What that means is, the waist has two elastic straps that attach pretty easily.  Although, I must admit the redesign seemingly has worse adhesive than before.  Sometimes I have to put the tabs on one another and give them a quick rub or two to secure things.  My little one doesn't mind the extra attention.  The gussets are stretchy and capable, holding all leaks in without being so tight as to cause constriction.  Again, the redesign seems to be a little worse than before, with a small tearing issue when the gussets are pulled outwardly (kind of a necessity for them to work properly).  Once more, not a big deal.We have had no leak issues for quite some time, and my little cruiser twists more in her sleep than a crocodile snagging a feisty gazelle.  Zero chafing.  Long story short, the redesign may have more absorbency, but there is also minor downside.  Still the best diaper out there in my opinion.

This toy looks great, sounds great, and is borderline perfection in theory.  In practice, however, there is a big problem.The motor/blower is activated by pushing the red button the elephant's yellow arm.  This causes balls put into the purple ears to shoot through the elephant's trunk.  After that, the balls are supposed to recycle through to the ears again, where they can go one of two ways.  The first is back through the blower and the trunk, and the second is into the ball reservoir on the elephant's stomach.  If only it were that perfect.  Instead, what you get is a ball that comes out of the trunk, bounces on the plastic ears, and only recycles about 1 in 5 times.  Of that 20%, less than one-half actually goes back to the ear leading to the trunk.  The trunk rotates to help alleviate some of this issue, but it's only partially successful.  After reading multiple reviews, I'm guessing it has to do with the battery or blower power.It's a great idea, and looks really fun.  The problem is, to keep the child's attention, the balls need to stay with the toy.  With ours, my daughter liked it for a bit, then the balls flew everywhere, then she lost interest.  Occasionally, however, I'll return to the toy and find out she has used it...to stuff something into the trunk.  Not a big deal when the item in question is other than circular.  But when the item is circular, particularly when it's a slightly larger, more rigid ball from a different toy, a parent - read: me - might have the unenviable task of disassembly.  Either that or you figure out to extract from the trunk.  I've done both, the latter with a coat hanger to puncture the lodged ball.

What's not to love?  The taste of blueberry muffins always makes me reminisce a little, thinking about days as a child when my mother and aunt would cook breakfast together while the children played.  The muffins were always my favorite.  Warm, filling, with a great aroma that often overpowered the rest of the meal, I wanted them more than anything else.  And while this product doesn't quite live up to the memories, it's a pretty good substitute when I'm lazy.The muffins are nearly circular, so saying they are about 2.5-3" in diameter is not inaccurate.  They are perfect poppers, straight to the molars.  The spongy texture isn't quite the deliciousness of a baked muffin with golden brown edges, but it's not bad for what it's worth.  Blueberries aren't ample, but they are sufficient enough that the taste is always present.  And with at least three sugar-related ingredients, the taste is sweet without being acrid.Health-wise, it's run of the mill.  180 calories per serving (i.e. 4 muffins), 70 of which come from fat.  Over half of the carbohydrates are simple (i.e. sugar), and there is 130mg of sodium per serving.  Speaking of the serving...This product suffers from what I like to call "The Frito-Lay Deception."  I know that sounds like a The Big Bang Theory episode title, but it's essentially when a bag looks much bigger than the contents.  In other words, tons of air, not much product.  Each bag says "4 Muffins per pouch" on the front, but it's still a surprise every time.  It leaves you wanting more for both hunger and psychological fulfillment purposes.Good for a side snack next to your meal, or when you're in a hurry.

I got this book for my wife while she was entering the first few weeks of her second pregnancy.  What we were looking for was a straight-forward approach that takes an expectant mother from conception to postpartum, providing details about health, exercise, nutrition, without delving too much into baby development and straying off course.  In that endeavor, this book is successful.  Chapters on conception, each trimester, labor, delivery, and postpartum walk a mother through each step of the way, focusing on how exercise and a healthy lifestyle affect everything from fertility to one's mental state.Kristina Pinto has provided a cautious, easy to read primer with great illustrations that solves common issues, answers common questions, provides an easy-to-follow path towards a healthy pregnancy, and a speedy, postpartum recovery.  The only minor negative is what others have noted: this isn't targeted towards the everyday Mommy to be.  It's targeted to pregnant mothers who were already in very good shape and who were already athletes.  A minor issue when coupled with the overall strength of the book.

Military novels are a dime a dozen.  Culling out the unique perspective is what's difficult.  In that endeavor, I believe Andrei Gelasimov has succeeded.  War delivered through the eyes of a child - more aggressive but similar in ways to J. G. Ballard's Empire of the Sun - Gods of Steppe tells the story of a Russian boy named Petka living during WWII, who wishes he could aid his countrymen in the Red Army by fighting along the Russian-Chinese border.  Given that unreality, instead he gets into all sorts of mischief and eventually comes to the realization everything is not what he once believed.What I enjoyed about the novel was the realistic portrayal and description of war, as well as Petka's transformation.  His transformation is two-fold.  First, he's "the bastard" to everyone.  His mother had him at an early age, and his family life is disheveled in ways that include war, despair, and substance abuse.  But his interactions with the troops and camp guards is reinvigorating.  Similarly, after initially being nave and capricious, some harsh experiences altered his war-time perceptions.  Enemies and allies sometimes swap.  Family isn't always trustworthy.  Safety and danger are often illusions.  His interactions with the Japanese POW reminded me initial stages of the tragic friendship formed in Boyne's The Boy in the Striped Pajamas.The negative of this novel is the delivery.  At times it feels disjointed.  It's not terribly difficult to follow, particularly for someone engrossed in the tale, but I could see it causing issues for some readers.

My daughter loves Sophia the First.  I've been forced to watch the cartoon so much that I can sing the song and know all the characters.  I figured I would get a game that she'd love when of the appropriate age.  I have to say I'm quite disappointed.First and foremost, the number of pieces to lose is ridiculous.  Forty four cardboard castle cutouts, sixteen cards, twelve little windows, eight trinkets, seven big windows, six skinny windows, three staircase pieces, two medium windows, one bracelet, one spinning arrow, ♫ ♫and a partridge in a pear tree ♫ ♫.  BTW - Recommended age is 3 and up. (HA!)  Yeah, good luck keeping all of those pieces after a game or two.As for the rules, it's a two player game, so I already know my daughter is going to be Sophia and I'll be the "Hider."  There is no debating this.  From what I gather - and the instructions are somewhat convoluted for a 3 and up game - the Hider flips over a card, follows the instructions, and after all the cards are flipped over the number of trinkets ("charms") on Sophia's bracelet determine her score.  After the players replace the trinkets, flip over the cards, and switch roles (haha, that ain't happening), the game is repeated.  Whoever has the most trinkets while being Sophia wins.I'm sure this game could be fun with an imaginative and interactive parent, but the complexity doesn't really jibe with a 3-year old.  Aside from that, Sophia the character is only present on the back of the flip-cards.  She's the selling point, right?  And good luck having your daughter be the Hider.  Hey Disney and Wonder Forge game, would it have killed you to even consider making the "Hider" someone else in the game?  You know, like Cedric the Magician?  After all, he's about the only consistent antagonist on the entire cartoon.  And, he's always trying to get Sophia's amulet.  Jeez.  A little imagination please.Overall, the theme song for Sophia the First does a good job of summing up the problems with this game:"Now I gotta figure out how to do it right,So much to learn and see"Maybe a bit too much figuring out, and bit too much to learn and see.

I am not even going to mention the ingredients or health-related aspects of this product.  They are FUDGE STRIPE COOKIES.  You weren't trying to watch your waistline when you bought these, so why pretend?Each cookie is about the size of a nickel.  Each one more delicious than the previous.  By cookie five my eyes began to glaze over.  By cookie ten I was searching online for a reorder.  The next thing I knew the entire package was gone.  If anything, the 3oz serving is a blessing and a curse, because I would have eaten more.  Oh, so much more.Good crunch.  Great flavor.  Very chocolatey.  Great little container for a brown-bag work snack or a little kid you're trying to turn into Hansel or Gretel (not the movie version, because that sucked).

With a bunch of loose ties from previous books to be resolved, there was a lot to accomplish with the Witch Wraith.  The trilogy started with a weakening Ellcrys allowing demons into the Four Lands, necessitating a quest by Arlingfant Elessedil to find the Bloodfire.  Meanwhile, the Ohmsford family reads like a soap opera, with one long lost relative being hunted down, another in deep trouble, and one caught somewhere in between.  Throw in a combination of impossible to remember character names meandering through a battle with a Federation intent on war - also on muddying the variety of subplots - and it's a difficult series.  It's even more difficult when other Shannara books have been read and a lot of this book's details feel like regurgitation of previous plot points and characters.  It's even worse when some of the plot devices get a complete 360 reboot (e.g. Druids, Ellcrys).This reads like most of Brooks' other work.  Pretty decent character development, usage of old bloodlines, coming-of-age youths (usually in aforementioned families) , descriptiveness that borders at times on fluff, increased inspiration during major confrontations/battles (or when describing the magic/supernatural), supporting characters dying like so many red shirts on Star Trek, and an ending that feels somewhat rushed.  If you've read the first two parts of the trilogy or are a big Brooks fan it's worth the read.  For the average reader, however, it's a bit disappointing.
1:06 MinsVery good product.  Easy to use.  Virtually no installation, just a screw in the wall and some batteries.  A little flimsy, but should be OK if kept out of a child's hands.

David Gordon writes a stylish, suspenseful, sublime crime/comedy (cromedy?) novel about struggling writer Sam Kornberg, his new gumshoe gig, and the struggling marriage to his wife LaLa in L.A.  When Sam's wife drops the "we need to talk"-bomb on him, he finds an assistant detective job working for a bizarre agoraphobic Solar Lansky.  Think Ignatius J. Reilly with added weight and lessened sloth.  During his stakeouts, Sam finds himself increasingly drawn to the target, a beautiful woman that ultimately led to his employment.The majority of the book reads like a combination on the bizarro world stuff Tim Dorsey has made a career, and the list-centric, shocking stylings of Chuck Palahnuik. In fact, the copious references to literature and cinema are almost certainly the vibe Palahnuik was attempting in his disappointing Tell-All.  Which is to say, Gordon is a very gifted story-teller, a man capable of blending the seemingly incompatible into an enjoyable tale that refuses to be restrained or pigeonholed.  Where else will you read a single page that contains Nazis, taxidermy, a meteor shower, an orgasm, and the internet?!After reading The Serialist and being very impressed, I am now a firm believer.  Gordon has a gift, and he's on my short-list of contemporary authors.  I eagerly await his next book.

Make 'Em Laugh:Short Term Memories Of Longtime Friends by Debbie Reynolds was released in 2015. What a great read! I enjoyed it all, the stories about her friends like Wayland Flowers were very touching. He was a comic genius. If you love Debbie Reynolds, you'll love this book. I have met Debbie and she is very nice to her fans. Hers show is so good I have seen her three times. Fans of Debbie Reynolds will like this the most.

Dancing In The Street:Confessions Of A Motown Diva  by Martha Reeves is a good read ! Tells the tale of a girl born in Alabama and raised in Detroit. With her group The Van Dellas she had lots of hits for Motown. Jimmy Mack, Heat wave, and Nowhere To Run among many. Friendship with Dusty Springfield got the Motown sound  broken in England. Lots of details of her personal life too. Fans of Martha Reeves will like this the most.

Playing The Field by Mamie Van Doren was originally released in 1987. A great Hollywood tell all with lots of names she knew, Great photographs, and a filmography of her movies. I have met Mamie, and she is so nice to her fans. I appreciate her stand on women's and gay rights. A Living legend and one of the last stars of the Golden Age of Hollywood.

Been There, Done That: by Eddie Fisher is a sad book. Too much kiss and tell. His lasting notority  is only because of his former famous Hollywood wives,Debbie Reynolds, Elizabeth Taylor, and Connie Stevens. He savaged them in this book. On the level of the Enquirer. Too many other women he slept with also, I mean he tells all the details of his sex life. If you enjoy Hollywood tell alls you might, I repeat might enjoy this trash. For lovers of the lowest level of Hollywood gossip, who will like this the most.

Crazy For You by Jennifer Cruise was released in 1999. Quinn and Nick have a long way to go before they get together. The villain is truly vile. I was pretty upset that Katie the dog was ill  treated. Fans pf Jennifer Cruise will like this the most.

Full Blast by Janet Evanovich and Charlotte Hughes was released in 2004. It is a fast moving  suspense novel. Jamie and Max are two people who make you care for them as the story evolves.fans of Janet Evanovich and Charlotte Hughes will like this the most.

the Hourglass by Barbara Metzger was released in 2007. A different type of Regency novel tells the tale of Genie and Coryn who meet, marry, and then learn to build a life together. Fans of Barbara Metzger will like this the most.

Sweet Revenge by Fern Michaels was released in 2006. A suspense filled read about a vile woman taken down by the group of women vigilantes who right wrongs. Fans of Fern Michaels will like this the most.

The Pajama Game was released in 1957 and starred Doris Day and John Raitt in a fine musical. Barbara Nichols provides  good support. Favorite songs are Hey There, and Steam Heat. Fans of Doris day will like this the most.
It's My House by Diana Ross was released in 1979 and charted #27 r&b. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
Sorry Doesn't Always Make It Right by Diana Ross was released in 1975 and charted #17 adult contemporary. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
No One Gets The Prize by Diana  Ross was released in 1979 and did not chart. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
Last Time I Saw Him by Diana Ross was released in 1974 and charted #14 pop. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
Mirror Mirror by Diana Ross ws released in 1982 and charted #8 pop. Fans of Diana ross will like this the most.
Swept Away by Diana Ross was released in 1984 and charted #19 pop. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
One More Chance by Diana Ross was released in 1981 and charted #79 pop. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
Can Never Light That Ol Flame Again by Diana Ross was released by Diana Ross in 1982 and didnt chart. Motown released it after she left the label. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
The Boss by Diana Ross was released in 1979 and charted #19 pop. One of my favorite songs. Fans of Diana Ross will like this he most.
I Thought It Took A Little Time by Diana Ross was released in 1976 and charted #47 pop. Fans of Diana Ross will like this the most.
Chain Reaction by Diana Ross was released in 1985 and charted #95 pop.Fans of Diana Ross wil like this the most.

For folks interested in the noise level: It's quiet when not under load (obviously); when under full load there's a soft whine. About half as loud as one of the 3-fan 280X cards. The stock cooler is doing a great job at keeping the card cool. The room it's in is 25C and the card maintains 61C while under full load.For those interested in its mining capabilities: Believe it or not, from the angle of hash to watts, this is better than 280X or 290X cards. For days now I've been using this to hash at a stable 492kh, pulling only 175watts. Here's the breakdown:Engine / Memory / KH / Temp / Watt (all @ 24000 threadconcurrency)1030 / 1500 / 445 / 60C / 163w1080 / 1500 / 467 / 61C / 168w1115 / 1500 / 480 / 61C / 172w1130 / 1500 / 485 / 61C / 174w1145 / 1500 / 492 / 61C / 175wTest Setup:ASRock 970-Ex4, Sempron 145, 2GB DDR3BAMT 1.2, cgminer 3.7.2 (have used 3.4.3 as well)

For those interested in the cooler: The stock cooler on this is very nice, and does a much better job than any previous 79xx series card. At 100% it doesn't get as noisy as they used to, but it's still noisy. The MSI R9 280X has a nearly silent cooler which does a slightly better job at cooling. For both, I use an aftermarket cooler anyhow: Prolimatech MK 26, which is completely silent and cools better than stock.For those using it for mining:This is the most stable of the various brands of R9 280X series I've tried. It's also providing the most output. I get a stable 800kh+. I've tested it in cgminer 3.4.x and 3.7.x, runs flawlessly.800kh+ Settings:TC: 24000Engine: 1160Memory: 1800Intensity/Powertune: 20750+:TC: 24000Engine: 1050 or 1080 (some cards vary)Memory: 1500Intensity/Powertune: 20There is a tweaked cgminer scrypt kernel for the Tahiti chips out there which will net you 15-30kh more than usual in some cases, and I use this to help achieve extra speeds. Can't post the link, but if you're on bitcointalk talk to a guy named vesperwillow, he can link you.

This is a crazy awesome fan. I use these as well as its related cousin, the Blue Vortex 14, to cool a bunch of GPUs. These, like its cousin, are silent. Standing next to them you'd have to strain to hear them running--and that's in an otherwise silent room. They push almost 100CFM each too!These are "half height", and use 120mm thread holes, so keep that in mind. They WILL fit the Prolimatech Mk 26 coolers, you just need to bend the metal clips a little bit to get them to catch.

I use these on my Prolimatech Mk 26 VGA coolers. They're astounding! Even standing next to them you can't hear them running, and with that cooler, my GPU's stay plenty cool under overclocked load. So far, unbeatable value.The only one which is slightly faster than this (yet just as silent) is its cousin, the Prolimatech Ultra Sleek Vortex--mainly because it pushes more CFM, but at twice the price.

Having spent a lot of time researching GPU cooling, including talking to folks' who make it their hobby to try every single cooling option out there, and seeing the superb performance the Prolimatech Mk-26 gives.. I can, without a doubt, pronounce this one of the most amazing cooling solutions ever. I have the black and silver models and both perform equally. If you want to see my before/after results, skip down to the bottom.It's the most efficient GPU cooler you will find, and in 2 particular independant tests, performed better than off-the-shelf liquid cooling (Accelero Hybrid).As long as you have the physical space for this card (3 card slots without fans, 4 with, plus 2" of clearance on top the card), this is truly a must have--for the enthusiast, the extreme overclocker (myself), or even the casual gamer.By design, it supports passive cooling for almost every GPU it can mount to, but it really shines when you add 2 140mm fans. The fact it's universal (fitting almost every current and future single-die graphics card) makes it even more valuable. My suggestion is to couple this card with two 140mm fans (I suggest the Prolimatech Blue Vortex 14, as it's the quietest of all 140mm fans I could find, while still providing the same airflow).So far I've installed 12 of these, and I have many more to install. I'm ordering these units by the crate where possible, and as they're available (from Amazon and other websites). They're really awesome!For those curious, installation time took me about an hour for the first card (went slow to figure out how best to do many of them), but the next 11 took about 2 hours, give or take. I did each step all at once which helped. Shouldn't take more than an hour for just one card for the average user.PROS:* Nearly universal - fits a wide assortment of GPUs, and will fit many in the future* It's a simple "bolt-on" solution - if you've changed GPU coolers in the past, it's not really any different* Superior cooling/thermal capacity - blows away the competition* Passive & Active design - You can use it with/without fans. Using the suggested fans, it's nearly silent* Includes everything you need, with plenty of thermal paste (I was able to use 1 tube for 3 GPUs)CONS:* This cooler is amazing because of its physical size - the card sticks about 2" above the card. Without fans it sticks about 2.5" beyond the side of the card, and another inch with fans. You will need a unique case, or open case or open air design to hold the cooler.* The instructions included aren't as detailed as they could be - the website includes very high quality/very detailed photos of general installation. Use the website and the included instructions together. For someone who has done this before, you probably will only need the paper instructions to tell you which GPU die adapter to use, the rest is self explanetory.NOTES:* Some folks noted installation difficulties, even multiple hours per change -- anyone experienced with cooler swapping shouldn't have many issues, but it will depend on the card design. I saved time (probably more than half an hour) by NOT removing the stock thermal plate from my GPU's, instead I added extra heatsinks on top of it. Remember, the more metal there is to soak up the heat, the better--just make sure you add heatsinks and the fan can blow on them to dissipate the heat.* With the fans, most of the hot air will be blown past the card (ie, away from the back of the card) instead of toward the rear or front of the card. So keep this in mind with your design.BACKSTORY:I run a small GPU farm and wanted to ensure longevity with my MSI 7950's by keeping temps low, and make it easier to cool them during summer. As a bonus, I wanted to lower the fan noise level as well. I spent a month researching and talking to people, narrowing my results to the Prolimatech MK 26 and the Accelero Hybrid. I had also considered making my own closed-loop cooler (like the Accelero Hybrid), but I wanted more of a bolt-on solution than having to take time to get the water block mounted to the GPU. Especially considering I'm doing racks of these conversions, and not just one or two cards.In the end, what sold me on the Prolimatech over the Accelero was it's future-usability (being nearly universal), and the fact there were fewer parts to fail. If the fans on the Prolimatech failed, the GPU would still be cooled (just not as well). If the Accelero pump failed, my GPU was dead. Also, as mentioned above, in several tests the Prolimatech and Accelero Hybrid were a dead-even match in noise level and cooling capability--in 2 particular tests the Prolimatech was quieter by 2 decibals.MY SETUP:* Multiple Racks of MSI TwinFrozr III 7950 GPU's, slightly overclocked. Each rack has 12 GPU's. Each GPU is scrypt-mining over 700kh/each. Each rack = 8,400mh/s* Running the TwinFrozr coolers at max RPM would keep the cards between 78-85*C with ambient air of 20-28*C* Noise level of each rack (12 cards) was equivalent to a 20" box fan running on highMY RESULTS - With the Prolimatech MK 26 & two 140mm Prolimatech Vortex 14 fans @ 1,000rpm:* With ambient air of 20-28*C, the cards average in the mid 50*C range, with some in the mid to low 40's, and some in the low 60's. This variance is due to where the GPU is in the rack (near the floor, or near the ceiling)* I did a summer "burn" test by shutting off the air cooling system and letting the GPU's heat the room up. With ambient temperatures over 45*C, the GPU's remained between 55-65*C. Amazing!* Noise level for each rack is literally a whisper. I have to stand next to the rack and put my ear toward a fan just to hear it running. I would say, it's no louder than a desktop PSU fan. Astounding.

This isn't modular, the cable bundle comes right out of the PSU. This is powering 2 GPUs without issue, on an MSI AMD mainboard. Running quiet and cool. Cable bundle is jacketed in black sleeve, it's very nice.
I love the warranty, I like the brand ,and the price was great. They also offer 2gb for half the cost of this, just look for it if you need it. This is running great in an older system.
Needed this to replace an aging card in an older machine. This worked like a charm. I simply dropped it in, and XP SP4 picked it up without hesitation.
This seems quieter than the stock cooling fan which came with the AMD CPU. It does keep the chip a smidge cooler. It's kindof wide compared to the stock cooler, but it still fits without issue.
Got this for an HTC One-X. Not much to say about it except that it works and it's a great value. Definitely consider this when looking for a charger which will fit the One X or a Galaxy S3.

This is one of the 'chair' style floats I recently purchased to try out. I'll definitely be keeping this, it's really enjoyable.PROS:Easy setup, simply inflate the 4 different tubes (the 3 main ones, and the rectangular back support), and adjust the straps to suit your preference. The nylon seems tougher than some other products I've used in the past. I weigh around 250lbs, and this had no problem keeping me afloat similar to the product photos. I was able to use it in a reclining position and as a 'chair'. This can be deflated quickly and is very portable.Value:Overall this is a good value, but I can't say it's an amazing value. The product itself is awesome, but I believe it would be an even better value if it cost a little less, maybe low 20's or high teens.Other thoughts:If someone is having issues with this keeping their body afloat in the water, make sure your understanding of how it works is correct.
