The 3 main tubes will keep your body afloat. Don't expect to be sitting "on top" of the water surface. If you're pretty  much almost wholly sunk, I would advise ensuring the floats are fully inflated. At around 250, I was happily floating mid-waterline.

I haven't had a good tube in years, a decade even, and when I saw this tube on prime for the cost of just 3 large coffee drinks, I couldn't pass it up--considering the numerous high ratings, and the clear quality of the product. I weigh around 250, and this has no problem keeping me up. I'm sure it could keep 2 of me up.PROS:The vinyl is thick feeling, and the design is top of the line. The 'back rest' portion inflates separately from the tube, allowing you the option of using it or not. The handles are in just the right spot and easy to grab, and it offers 2 average size cup holders which do a great job. The mesh netting is sturdy, and the inner hole is 'just the right size' for adults. You can easily paddle with your arms, or kick-off using your feet. The inflation orifice is a high quality screw-down device, guaranteed to not accidentally popoff.Other notes: The inflation orifice is about 5/8" in diameter (eying it), and is meant for the 'hand' or 'foot' pump units, or anything with one of the larger inflation hoses. I didn't know this when I got it. I use the air system in my shop to inflate things like these, so I simply used a piece of vinyl tubing inserted into the orifice and connected to my air system, to inflate it quickly.

--Review has been updated, see below for details--Overall I am very pleased. The device will hold total water usage until you reset it. Keep note there is a 999 limit on the screen, at which point you have to reset it. It was spot-on accurate for garden hose usage, and within +/- 1% accuracy for large volumes (1,400+ gallons at once). It is water resistant, though I would not let the device get rained on.[Original Review:]I've seen some mixed reviews on this product, but I needed a quick way to measure how much water I'm using on my pool top-offs. The instructions are good enough. Basically you remove the cardboard 'tag' inserted in the meter, which activates the battery, and it should be good to go.I grabbed a 5 gallon bucket where the 5gal mark was clearly marked, and hooked this up to my hose. I ran it several times, and each time the water hit the 5gal mark, the meter read precisely 5.0. Each time the water level was the same, which shows consistency.The instructions mention a +/-10% error rate, which should be fine for most applications. For large volume, such as thousands of gallons on my pool, I'll also be using some volume calculations on the pool itself using a measure of fill height to see just how close the meter is to my manual math.I will post up my results after.Regarding waterproofness, I saw some folks say it conked out when it got wet. The battery compartment has a rubber oring to prevent corrosion, and the display appears to have one as well. Once I'm done with the item, I will disassemble it to determine actual weatherability, and report back.[2013/05/13 Updates:]As promised I'm providing more feedback on this product. I used this to keep track of the gallons used for my frequent pool top-off, and to see how accurate it is, I also used some math based on the inches of water added to the pool, to provide a volume calculation for gallons added. I also opened the device up to see what waterproofing methods were in use, if any, as some had mentioned theirs died when it got too wet.Regarding Accuracy:The instructions mention the device is accurate to within +/- 10%. As mentioned previously, I found it spot-on accurate when testing with 5 gallon buckets. For my pool, I was pleased with the accuracy level as well.As I found out on accident, the device only counts up to 999.9 gallons, and when it reaches this point it stops counting. This happened while filling the pool. I had been checking on it frequently and kept track of the time elapsed and the total count, every 20 minutes, but at some point forgot to check and I came back to see it reading 999. Quickly hit the reset button and it continued counting up once again. I was getting about 7.5 gallons per minute of flow into my pool, so that point where it hit its limit could have only been at most about 150gallons unmeasured. So I noted this.After the pool was finished filling, the meter had registered 1360 gallons. This is up to 150gallons shy of what may have gone in, due to me not realizing it had hit 999 and stopped counting. Knowing the area of the pool I was able to then measure the fill height in inches, and derive a volumetric total of gallons added, which came to 1490 gallons.So the math shows 1490, the meter showed ~ 1510 (1360 on the meter plus about 150 unaccounted for). This is certainly within 10% accuracy mentioned on the instructions, it's actually about 1%.I would say this is an accurate unit, and am pleased with the price paid.Regarding Waterproofness:I took the device apart and have added a photo of what I found to the product images. I outlined a rectangle in pink to highlight the epoxy being used to seal the electronics portion of the device. You can see some moisture in the casing which is to be expected, but the epoxy is very well done.I didn't take it apart further as I didn't want to disturb the epoxy. My theory is if the device is dying due to getting soaked, the LCD cover may not be wholly waterproof, allowing water to seep in and mess things up. I wouldn't use this device in the rain, nor leave it uncovered in the elements, but I wouldn't feel bad about some moisture getting on it every now and then.I definitely wouldn't connect it to a garden sprayer as they show in the instructions, as they sometimes drip a lot.

I have 2 of these installed on Viair compressors for automotive use. I wanted a flexible reliable hose to connect my shop's upright air compressor to the air system, so I went with this because I've had good experience with them before.The swivel fittings provide extra 'give' which is great as well. 1/4" NPT standard male fitting on both ends.My application will be 10 Bar / 145 psi, as has been in the past.

I know some folks complained that theirs didn't fit right, but mine fit perfect.Some video cards have power ports which don't follow the PCIE standards, so it makes me wonder if that's the situation with some of the times when people can't get them to fit right--where a 'round' plug should be square, or vice-versa.

Not much else to say about the cable. The price, quality and fast shipping were all perfect. Definitely keep in mind if you need this type of cable.On a technical note, remember that the max length of a DVI cable is dependant upon the equipment providing the signal. Expect at least 15' as a guarantee for most electronics, though some provide a strong enough signal for up to 30'-50'. The same goes for HDMI, the maximum length is dictated by signal attenuation and the gauge of the wiring, but expect at least 15' for sure.DVI doesn't support audio, so don't expect audio to work through the cable.

I was out of USB3 headers on my motherboard but still had a USB3 front port which I wanted to plug in somewhere, so after some searching I saw this and jumped on it for the price (under 20 at the time of this review). This board includes a USB3 header as well as the 2 external rear USB3 ports.The short of the story is this board solved my need and installation was a snap, drivers only took a minute to install. This is an awesome value, and it's a low profile card which is awesome. It also includes a small/short profile rear backplane cover in case you're putting this in a tiny/short ITX box.Installation was a breeze. I didn't install the drivers beforehand, I installed the board and booted the system up. My XP Pro install recognized the card but had an older driver for it, so it came up in System Hardware as unable to start. I checked their website and looked at the available drivers. Strangely enough the drivers available to download were older than the ones included on the CD you find in the box--that's rare. I used the drivers from the CD, simply running the setup program.After that I deleted the reference to the hardware (a Jmicro/Jmicron device) from System Devices and rebooted the system. I did this particular step because sometimes XP won't pick up a new driver despite being told so, and this will force it to rescan available drivers.Sure enough once I rebooted, it picked the new driver up and the board worked immediately.

This is an affordable high quality reader, super easy to install. I was up and running within moments! I suggest people look up 'militarycac' online, they will find a very useful website which will guide you step by step through setting these up and getting these to work with your government cac card--if that's the style you use. Even if it isn't, it still guides you through the driver and software process which is a huge benefit to anyone using smart cards.

I needed to mount a 19" Dell LCD to the side of a workbench, allowing me to swivel the monitor, swing the arm in/out, and some amount of tilting upward/downward. This was the perfect solution.The Dell was not a VESA-mount compliant monitor, so I had to do some drilling to make it fit, but that was expected and has nothing to do with the mount, I just have an old monitor.I didn't use the lag bolts included so I can't comment on other's experiences of it being difficult to use them, as I used some bolts to secure the mount to the workbench.Once everything was mounted up, I used the included small wrench to adjust how tight the arms and pivot joint were, to my liking. Everything is working like a charm.The tilting up/down works well, but didn't provide as much tilt as I had imagined. It still works perfectly for my needs however.

I unscrewed my old filter. I took this one, filled it up with water as the instructions said, and carefully screwed it into place. There was no need to shut off the fridge or water supply or anything.I ran it through a gallon of water as the instructions suggested, and the water came out tasting great!

I use these in cars and around the house, wherever 194 style bulbs are used. These are bright (in some cases a hair brighter than stock, at worst they are equal brightness), pure "white" light.I did have one batch look a hair "bluer" (6500k for example) than another batch (which seemed closer to 5000k). So if you need to have a bunch which all match in temperature, order them all at once.

I needed a BackUPS solution for a router/modem stack, and this was perfect. The size is great, and the right-angle power plug helps fit in tight spaces.There's 2 sockets which are spaced off from the other ones to allow for "brick" adapters. I let the battery charge up as the instructions said to, and it was ready to go.
Not much to say about USB extensions. The cables came quickly, and at a great price. All of them worked. Quality construction, comparable to any other high end cable I've ever used.

I needed a bar-styel USB hub which was compact, it needed to be inexpensive, and allow for external power--and this was the one for me. It doesn't require an external power adapter, but for my purposes I needed one (several USB devices requiring more power to be plugged into this). It didn't include a 5v power adapter, but I had one which fit perfectly.I don't have the power port measurements offhand, but it was the super thin style, instead of the classic "M" plug.The switches enable/disable their respective USB port, so you could have a device plugged into the port but the computer can't use it unless you turn the switch 'on'. If the switch is on, the blue led lights up. The light works regardless of external power or not.Be advised, you cannot use high-power USB devices (such as external drives), or a bunch of the ports all at once, without the external power. Most USB ports do not provide more than 500ma of current, and that will be split across all 7 of these ports equally (500 / 7 = 71ma). It's fine for mice or memory sticks, but yuo will need a power adapter for anything else.

I've used these several times over, and they work great. I use them on modified routers and computer/RAM chips. They absob heat much better than aluminum (since they are copper), and dissipate the thermal energy into the air efficiently. They never fall off, despite being mounted sideways and upside-down.I clean the surface area with alcohol, and then wipe it dry. I then press them on firmly and hold them for about 10 seconds. They're on there solid at that point.

Not much to say about wire, but I can say I recommend this product to others looking for 100' of 18ga wiring. I didn't use this for speaker wire, I needed 18ga wire to make some DC power connections, and this was perfect. The white outer sleeve keeps it discrete, and the inner conductors are clearly marked red/black, for easy identification. Awesome!
I use jumper wires for all sorts of projects. Breadboarding, computer repair, etc. For the price, this is a great value. The wires are quality, and are what you'd expect.

The fan can be flipped around by popping the case-piece off and putting it back on a different way, if need be. It moves a decent amount of air given how quiet it is. I can't measure the output of the fan, but I'm doubtful that it flows *as much* CFM as it claims, perhaps it gets close though. I have similar fans of same rating and they appear to move more air.I would definitely recommend this product.

I've reviewed many of their products, I use them several times a month. I've been playing the sport for almost 20 years, in very rough conditions. I can attest to the usability and durability of this product when properly cared-for and used. It's awesome!

I had a 3 hole faucet installation which I needed to convert to one, and this did the trick. The hole is about 1.25" in diameter. There's a neck line beneath the hole which doesn't quite reach the same depth as the outer edge, this is why some people have issues when they tighten their faucet. Don't over tighten, it will work fine!

I bought this product, but not through Amazon. I wanted to get the product "just for the heck of it", but due to the mixed reviews I didn't want to spend what it  was listed for here. I found it elsewhere for about 30% less. You'll see in my photos it's the same product.OVERALL:* Rating: 3.5 / 5 - "I like it, but it has some quirks, namely the noise"* Installation Time: ~30 minutes by yourself* Difficulty: Low* Quality: 3.5 / 5* Value: 4 / 5 for what I paid, 3 / 5 if I had to pay moreThis was a purchase for the whizz-bang factor. I have a dual sink in the master bathroom, one side is 'hers' one side is mine. The sink has really nice, expensive faucets, but just for the heck of it I decided I wanted something different. I looked around for something cheap, and found this. The mixed reviews made me cautious enough to want to find it cheaper elsewhere, so if it was a total loss I wasn't out so much. This is clearly a "made in a China factory in bulk with recylced metal" product, but it does function nicely and is definitely worth keeping.My installation instructions/sugggestions are at the very bottom. The next few paragraphs describe the contents of the box and the quality of the materials and the couple of quirks I found. I cover topics such as the leaky hoses and the noisey faucet, so please read.Here's what the colors of the faucet mean:Blue - Cold: anywhere from freezing cold to just plain coldGreen - Warm: lukewarm to very comfortably warmRed - Hot: this is what most people consider to be the high end of comfortable 'hot' waterFlashing Red - Super Hot: hot enough to where you can only keep your hand under the water for 2 seconds, on up to scalding hotA side benefit to something like this is you could teach kids not to use the water if it's Red. Red = hot = pain.INSIDE THE BOX:The faucet was wrapped safely in protective wrapping material. It included the hoses, mounting hardware (2 studs, 2 nuts, a mounting plate, some gaskets), the battery box and batteries. It also included instructions. Here's the first quirk: The instructions were for a completely different faucet. This didn't bother me because I wasn't going to use them anyhow, this is a straightforward faucet install.The faucet and its contents were secured nicely, there was no visible damage at all. 5/5 for packaging.THE HOSES:Some people expressed issues with their hoses. Either the oring gaskets were the wrong size, or they didn't fit the existing plumbing, or there were leaks. I examined my hoses closely, and the oring was the proper size for the hose and the faucet. I inspected the ports in the faucet where the hoses go. The faucet is made out of copper, plated in a nice chrome finish. The ports are just raw copper.The copper threaded ports where the hoses go were pretty clean, but I did wipe them out just to be safe. However, where the oring mates and compresses for a watertight seal, didn't seem perfectly round. I wonder if this is why some people had issues. You could put thicker orings on the hose to overcome this, but what I did was wrap the hose threads 3x with teflon tape, to help provide additional sealing. You can see this in my pictures.The other end of the hose, which goes to your plumbing, was the "new" American standard pipe size, and the hoses included the built-in rubber sealing gasket. I say new because some older homes may have a different size, which is why some people need an adapter or a different valve. My plumbing was newer, so the hoses fit without issue.The hoses felt like I could crush them with my fingers, which at one point I did on accident. I wouldn't advise using much force when handling these. For overall hose design and quality, I would say 4/5.THE FAUCET QUALITY:You know this came from a China factory, made in bulk. The chrome plating is perfect, but the bottom of the faucet where you install the hoses and the mounting hardware, is pretty rough. You can't see this rough, so don't worry. The threads for the mounting studs were threaded slightly at an angle, almost as if by hand instead of a machine. The base plate is thin enough where you could bend it to correct if you wanted to, but I left well enough alone. The handle looks really sharp, as does the neck of the faucet. The looks of the faucet are outstanding.I will point out a couple of things which bother "detail oriented" folks like myself. The handle was mounted "slightly" crooked in relation to the glass of the faucet. It's about 1-2 degrees of a difference. I didn't want to try and correct it and accidentally break some water seal, so I left well enough alone, but it does appear you could fix it if you needed to.The other thing to point out is the quality of the cut on the glass. 3 layers of glass are laminated together to make the faucet, and a machine cuts the glass to make the water channel. The cut is very rough and not polished. All other portions of the glass *are* polished, as you can see in my photos, just not the edges of the water channel. This will only bother you if you stare closely at it. Functionally it still works, but it will cause some of the water to "favor" the outer edges of the flow channel.Overall, 3.5 for the faucet itself. I take away half a star due to the 2 oddities I mention.INSTALLATION HARDWARE:The 2 studs and nuts are fine, that's fortunate. The gaskets were entirely useless to me, with the exception of the large round one. It looks like it will fit the bottom of the faucet, but it doesn't. At least, mine didn't. I did use it, however, to go beneath the hole cover. This way water around the sink can't leak into the hole under the plate. It also helps prevent the plate from bending too much when you tighten the faucet down.2/5 for this.FAUCET FUNCTIONALITY AND NOISE:I did not have any leaks with the hoses or any connections. 24 hours later, still no leaks, so for now I'm calling it "good". The faucet functions beautifully, it doesn't leak or anything. For all intents and purposes, it's great.The only catch is.. the faucet *does* make some noise. If you turn it on so it's just slowly coming out, it's about the same noise level as a usual faucet. If you turn it on all the way, it's about the same noise level as any other faucet which is on all the way.Anything between "on full blast" and "slow gentle stream", you'll be left with a faucet which is louder than most. I would say, twice as loud, as I perceive it. It's not enough that you can't hold a conversation in the bathroom, but it is loud enough that it makes you think your garden  hose is set to "jet blast away".3/5 for the sound.INSTALLATION AND SUGGESTIONS:Tool-wise all I needed was an adjustable wrench, the small kind. For added watertight sealing, I also used some Teflon tape and a synthetic grease. Here's a quick breakdown of what I did:* I put teflon tape on the hose threads. I did this by wrapping it 3x, and using a razor to cut the excess so the tape was only on the threads.* I put a thin film of synthetic grease (any will work, synthetic will prevent the orings from drying out/cracking or being damaged) on the orings, so they slide into place without any friction, keeping them from damage* I saw the hole of my sink was *just* slightly too small to accomodate the hoses and mounting hardware. My hole was 1.25" in diameter. As you can see in my picture, I used a dremel to provide some extra room at the "corners" of the hole. I used a plastic cup to catch the material as I grinded it away. Use a breathing mask btw.* I installed the hoses into the faucet. I tightened them by hand until they were snug, gripping the hoses at their base (not the hose itself). Then I snugged them a little firmer by hand. You can use pliers or a wrench for this, but don't over tighten--the orings provide the water seal, it's not a matter of how hard you tighten the hose.* I installed the hole cover plate (LightInTheBox Bathroom Vessel Vanity Sink Faucet 4" Hole Cover Deck Plate) onto the faucet. It took a little wiggling to get over the hoses, but it worked. Once the plate was on, I screwed the studs into place. I checked the fit with the metal mounting plate and all was well, see my picture.* I set the faucet into place, and used the mounting plate and 1 nut to loosely hold the faucet in place while I installed the hoses* I installed the hoses to my plumbing. Remember, with the faucet facing you, the hose on the left is the "hot", so attach it accordingly to your plumbing.* When tightening the hose to your plumbing, first do it by hand as much as you can, and then use a wrench to "firmly snug" the connection. The rubber gasket provides the seal, you don't need to use brute force. Too much force will cut the gasket.* I turned the water valves on to check for leaks. First, I let it sit for a few minutes to check leaks at the valves, all along the hoses, and up to the faucet. There were none. I then cycled the faucet several times, and checked for more leaks. I let it sit for about 5 minutes and checked again. You want to check for leaks like this before mounting and tightening the faucet down all the way.* I installed the battery pack and mounted it. For me, I have it mounted to the drain pipe, it's out of the way of any potential leaks, but still easy to reach.  If you mount it with the screws facing down, away from any potential leaks, there's no way water can get in the compartment. With the batteries installed, I ensured the LEDs light up, and they did.* Once I determined it was leak free, I lined the faucet and plate up, and fully mounted it in place. I used a wrench to "snug" the nuts, I did not make them "firm", just a smidge more than hand snug. Enough so the faucet won't move out of place, but not so much that it crushes anything.* I checked for more leaks later on, and there were none. I considered the project complete.

I needed to mount a center channel to my wall, and wanted a subtle mount which wasn't very apparent to the eyes. I thought about making one myself since it is a simple task, but I ran across this mount and decided to try it out. I've been really pleased with this over the past couple of months, it's solid as a rock with the wall anchors I bought locally (not the ones included).Short and sweet, the PROS:* Price - it was right where I was comfortable spending for the product* Looks - it's subtle, a soft black, and the design keeps it mostly out of sight* Simplicity - A couple of screws for each leg, and you're doneCONS:* The included wall anchors are larger than the norm, but not what I'd want to use for the job. They won't clamp well on older or crumbly dry wall. Many products these days have this issue, it's usually not the fault of the manufacturer, because they can't foresee every style of wall their product is being used on. I usually end up buying heavy duty wall anchors for all of my wall-related projects, because my drywall is very crumbly. I reccommend a nice wall anchor in my comments below.Other notes:* Because of the design, the legs of the mount angle downward slightly--ever so slightly. I haven't measured it yet, but I'd say less than 10* just by eyeing it. Heavier speakers will increase that effect, and it will be a bit more pronounced if you extend the legs.* Make sure to have a level handy, it makes life easierREGARDING ANCHORING:First, for this or any product which needs a wall anchor, and you need to make SURE it is a solid anchor, grab some of these: Toggle Anchors (available from Amazon and most hardware stores) - http://www.amazon.com/Toggler-Toggle-FF-B-588-D-Specifications-Threads/dp/B00AH28GMA/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1354565777&sr=8-1&keywords=drywall+snap+anchorIt uses a nice piece of steel to lock securely against the inside of the wall, and they're rated for high loads. Super easy to install! I used them on this wall mount. Unlike many wall anchors which simply rely on pressure from installation, or a small plastic nipple on the inside of the wall, these things really lock into place!A couple of reviewers apparently had issues with their speaker mount--either they got a bad unit from the manufacturer, or they misunderstand how these items work--as some "came out of the wall" or "broke" from putting weight on them. Although every person will have varying experiences with a product, something to note is that a speaker mount like this is only meant for a certain amount of weight, and how well it is anchored to the wall is even more important than the weight rating. If it is poorly or inadequately anchored, it will fail as a result of the anchor.Even if anchored properly, one shouldn't lean their body on the speaker mount.

Like many reviews for cables, it's hard to say a lot, but what's important is they work perfectly and the price is right!PROS:* Nice, thick insulation - don't worry about kinking or hurting these cables* Gold plated connectors - ensure the best possible connection/corrosion resistance* Firm clamping - they stick firmly onto the RCA terminalsThe price was awesome on these, and the quality is spot-on. More value than you'd imagine.

The wood finish looks sharp, matches many billiard table accessories. The clamps are plastic, and don't seem to marr the sticks at all. I use this to hold 7 cue sticks and a bridge.Easy to install, it includes screws and standard wall anchors which will work for most plaster/drywall. Using a drill, screwdriver and a level, I had this up in about 5 minutes. For the price, I love it.

I needed to couple two DVI-I cables together, and this worked like a charm! I convert an HDMI signal to DVI, and then onto a screen. Excellent video quality, gold plated connectors for high quality. Don't pass this up if you need one.

I purchased a few of these in order to plug some stereo cables into the wall, to pass some digital signals back/forth to an audio system. These worked really well. You have to push firmly on the cable to get it to fully "seat" the last 1/32nd of an inch, but either way the cable is secure and passes audio without a hitch.Selling points:* Price* Simple to use* Great quality compared to similar units* Gold plated connectors for best signal and lack of corrosionNotes: You'll probably have to push the connector in firmly the last millimeter or so, in order to fully seat and lock the cable in place.

USAGE:I'm part of a group of about 30 people who all use these, typically all on the same channel. At times we're spread throughout the woods, usually in varying terrain (hills/mountains/thick woods/brush), and sometimes flat-lands.. areas as large as 120 acres. We've been using these radios for over a year now with scarcely an issue with being able to hear each-other loud and clear.They are secure, reliable, and easy to use!I'll keep my review short, because there's lots of folks who've exhaustingly posted up about these radios. I'd give these a 10 if I could, instead I can only give a 5/5!PROS:* Too many good things to mention!* Outperforms standard FRS systems - Our group uses them in mixed terrain, flatlands to mountains to trenches, heavy woods.. 50..70..120 acres, no issue* Secure, unlike standard FRS--even secure against the same model radio, thanks to encryption* Private and Public channels, IE you can address everyone on the same line, or you can address a specific radio* You can tx/rx text messages if you like, to all, a group, or individuals* The kit includes everything you need to get started, including some basic headsets* The radios will accept higher-end headsets!* Can use alkaline batteries, excellent for when the rechargables die* There is a cloning feature built into the radios, so you can clone the settings and the addressbook, or just the settings. This is great if you have particular settings/channels you need to program into say, 50 radios at once, like our group! Set one radio up, and clone the rest off of it!* You won't find a better deal on license-free radios, for this price range, ANYWHERE. We have folks in our group who deal in the radio business, and at wholesale pricing, and for the under $80 range for a whole setup, you can't beat these* Amazon Prime has had the best price on these for awhile, I got mine for $67 shipped. That's less than $38 per radio, including headset and batteryCONS:* If I had to list a con, I'd say some folks don't like the included headset because it pinches their ears* Some folks don't like the rechargable batteries because they don't last a solid 8 hours* NOT WATERPROOF BY ANY STRETCH, not even water-resistant! That's one thing most of my other FRS radios can claim: being water proof. These are not. I've had to take a couple apart to get grease and other stuff out from under the keypad. So ensure you keep these in a pouch of some sort, or under your clothing!SYNCH ISSUES:A few years back, this model radio had re-synch issues.. no longer!BATTERIES:Half of us use the rechargable batteries, the rest of us use alkalines. The rechargables will work for about 4-6 hours of constant use, depending on weather variables. Alkaline batteries tend to last a full 8 hours.You'll know when your stuff is dying, because the incoming transmissions seem to go into slow-motion.

Needed to extend the distance between a television and the sound equipment, and these worked great!What sold me:* Price - These were a steal for what I paid* Thick Outer Shield - Thicker means you're less likely to kink/snap the fiber inside* Good reviews - Always a plusTech notes:* Keep in mind that when you're going such a long distance, you may need some sort of signal booster in some situations. SP/DIF-TOSLINK stuff is rated for about 26-30' before signal is lost beyond usability.* Gold plating on the connectors doesn't serve any purpose for the signal going through the cable, it's more of a gimmick, but hey it looks cool.

The price is outstanding, it has a "cool" blue anodized body on the connectors, and the cable is nice and thick, won't easily kink. Gold plated connectors provide the highest quality connection and lowest possible attenuation of signal. This will last you for years.Don't pass this deal up.

Every now and then I need a short 3.5mm patch cable, be it for computer, home theater or personal audio reasons. I frequently come back to these cables, and love them. You can't find cables like these in store for anything close to what you pay on here.In short, an excellent value. Take a look at these the next time you need a patch.
Needed to extend some USB ports, and these worked like a charm. Nice snug fit so the cables won't simply slide out. Better price than any local store, and same quality. Awesome product!

I've purchased several of these this year and last year, and keep coming back for more. They're simple, inexpensive, and work wonders. The design is thinner than some other cables, which has its own special benefits.With a much thinner design, you can more easily bend the cable, or allow it to fit into tight spaces, without too much worry. For instance, I have other brands of fiber cable, some of them 2-3x thicker, and they were not able to fit behind a TV of a recent install I did, without putting too much stress on the neck of the cable going into the port.These thinner ones were perfect, they fit right in, and don't have any issues with a tighter bend. For anyone curious, the ends of the fiber are not polished.PROS:* Inexpensive, great value!* Thinner protective insulation than other brands, which can be beneficial* Signal quality is great, as I would expect

If you need a compact, high quality HDMI right angle adapter, then look no further. I grabbed a bunch of these for some installations lately, and have been thoroughly pleased.There's not much to say since it's just a simple adapter, but I can say the fit is nice and snug (no worry about the cable falling out), and it's compact which allows for a nice tight angled fit behind TVs and equipment on the wall.PROS:* Gold plated* Snug fit, no worries of cables getting loose* Compact, great for behind equipmentANGLE NOTES:This is a 270* right angle adapter, which is a right angle but opposite direction of a 90* adapter. What this means: Picture an HDMI outlet on a wall. The smaller side of the connection is the bottom side. A normal 90* right angle adapter will cause the outlet to face downward to the floor. A 270* right angle will cause the outlet to face upward at the ceiling.Look closely at the product photo and you'll see what I mean. Make sure that 270* is what you need for your project. If not, go with a 90* adapter such as HDMI Right Angle Male to Female AdapterIn many cases, including wall outlets such as keystone slots, you can always flip the HDMI outlet around to fit the adapter.

I wanted to get a new modem to replace one which was about 4 years old. Spent some time looking, and after comparing some similar units, I went with this one.My primary concern was fitting under a certain price range, followed by good reviews. This model has good reviews across the board from various sources on the internet.Since installing, network latency (browsing, ping times, etc) have been much more favorable. Browsing has been snappier, and this was noticed on several devices on the network. Ping times also dropped overall.For me, I just wanted something a bit newer, and in doing so this product gave me a little bit of a performance boost. Really liking it.PROS:* Cisco has a great reputation* The modem supports the latest technologies, including gigabit* Includes USB connectivity if you need it* Setup was a breeze (see below)* Compact size, no frilly case, it's very straightforward* Includes an "online" LED indicator, unlike some modems which just show transmission of data or being connected to a cableSETUP:Not everyone's setup will be the same, as it varies by provider and personal computer network. My experience was pretty straightforward. My provider is COX Communications. Setting this modem up was pretty much an almost hands-off process with them.I unplugged my old modem, and my router, and left them both off for 10 minutes, which is about how long it took to clean a spot in my closet for the new modem.I plugged the modem and router together with the network cable, and then plugged the modem power in first, followed up a few moments later with the router power.After a few moments of the new modem synchornizing with the COX network, the "online" LED lit up. I then tried browsing, and it brought me to the COX "activation" page. From there I just tell it I'm installing a new modem, and within minutes the system does the rest.I was completely back online within 15 minutes from start to finish.

Needed some professor/nerdy looking theatrical glasses, the ones with basically clear plastic lenses with no prescription. Saw these and decided to give them a try.They came sealed in plastic, wrapped safely in bubble wrap, inside a bubble wrap envelope. I opened them up, gently took off the 'made in wherever' sticker, and put them on.Awesome! They gave the look I was looking for, and the plastic lenses were so clear you couldn't even tell you were wearing glasses.If you need some fake glasses, check these out.

Sometimes you need to run coax at a sharp angle, and bending the cable just don't do. It won't look good, and sometimes it's not enough. That's where this product comes into play.It's a compact right-angle coax adapter, and it fit the ticket for me with some recent coax runs. I ordered a bunch of these, and have used them all.Product is of excellent quality, nothing but kudos from my perspective. If you need to turn coax sharply, this is what you need.

Needed some more chalk, the old stuff was running out. Master chalk has a great reputation in halls across the country, so it was a no brainer for purchase.Sure enough, I'm loving it in my private collection just as I expected! Chalk came in a ziplock, which was then wrapped in a lot of bubble wrap, inside of a bubble wrap envelope. Plenty of protection.

I had a couple of tight spots with hard to reach TOSLINK connections. Rather than bend the cable too much (which has proven disastrous to me in the past), I went looking for a good right angle adapter.This particular model has a swivel piece which allows the input side to swivel a full 360, which is great not only for fitting odd angles, but helps reduce stress on the cable.I ordered several, and they all worked like a charm! I posted a photo of the adapter, and included the dimensions of the body in the picture notes.PROS:* Great price* 360 swivel for use at any angle, reduces cable stress* Doesn't diminish/attenuate the signal noticably (I have 2 of these being used with 30' of TOSLINK without issue)* The fiber end is polished* Compact size allows for placement in tight spots

I needed a short stick for tight places, and for younger folks who wanted to play occasionally. I saw this and for the price, I couldn't pass it up, I had to try it. When I got it, I was surprised at the quality.Solid wood, and it rolls mostly straight. Definitely a must have for any cue collection, just in case, you never know..PROS:* Low price* Short, lightweight* Straight
I've dropped my S5 in the hot tub a number of times,  and love the fact that I don't need a bulky case to water proof it.  Function over Form comparing the S6.
My tablet did not recognize the card, but after reading reviews I formatted it in my galaxy s5 and then it could see it. I reformatted it my tablet and everything was fine.
Yes this works, but be careful not to overuse. My dentist says it can make your teeth sensitive if overused. My teeth was white after first use.
These are nice, my candle refill came from the Dollar Tree. It has it's own glass holder so if you ever actually lite, stays clean.
I would but this again.
Seems good, but until I wear it for six hours in a row I really can't say about comfort. But the price is there. And the quality seems good.  I'm a ski instructor so it will get the test next season.

I have a Galaxy S5, and all my problems with it were related to the Amazon Music Player.  It swallowed up my internal memory and really messed with the phone operation.  So heres the deal, it by itself does not function on a phone at all, because thats the only place it works inside your Internal Memory.  It's like they adapted a less sophisticated software to rush it to the market and went with it.  They fixed the problem by making you discover through phone failure by reading reviews or by another means that they recognized the problem and really want to just sell you another app and download Amazon Apps.  You will need to download their Amazon MP3 Mover in order to move songs to your SD Card.  But it doesn't always work.  It leaves off artist names and titles often so it has a lot of bugs.  While the Amazon Player will not see the titles that it moves, the Android Music player will, so go figure.  I really liked Amazon Music Player until I realized what it does not do.  So one star, because Amazon knows the problems and can't seem to get it right.  Really who can store all their music in Internal Memory.  Take you mind off drone delivery which will never fly, and deliver your music.....

I have had the S5 for a year now, I bought very fast not knowing the differences.  First of all I have compared this phone to everything out there, but I didn't know to compare it to the S5 models that are available.  Here is the reason for two stars, It would be Five Stars if it had more than 16GB internal memory.  I only have a few apps, I bought a 64 GB mini SD Card for music and photo storage not realizing it will take up 128 GB card.  Go ahead and get the 128 mini SD card (External Memory).  The phone wants to update software (internal Memory) as it needs to, but it says not enough space on internal memory.  So I started checking out the problem because again I don't have that many apps., what I discovered was I should have bought or held out for the 32 or 64 GB internal memory model that some carriers don't carry yet. Search it out, the phone is awesome, but is really memory starved.Having said all this, it's the best phone I ever had.  Never has froze up and runs fast still.
This is it, the best.
They should do a YouTube instructional video on getting them attached, otherwise nice

This is one of only two serials that I follow, but I love L.j. Charles writing enough that I am willing to wait a short time between the three parts of the story, I am too excited about her books to wait until all three parts are out! When a friend of Caitlin's disappears, she and her boss Hannah are concerned enough to investigate before the requisite 24 hours have passed. Starting with three sets of tarot cards that someone sent anonymously the witches use their special gifts to try to uncover a reason that Alaina might have runaway. Everly helps with touch visions that show the situation as even more dire than the feeling they get from the card readings.

Although the other books in the series have given us a good introduction to Pandora, in Paws and Effect most of the tale is told through her eyes. As a cat still on her first life, she has a lot to learn but that doesn't keep her from doing her duty as one of the guardians of Mystic Notch. I loved that in this book we discover that someone other than Willa can see and communicates with ghosts!A ghost cat warns Pandora that the contents of a metal box that turned up during groundbreaking ceremony could be dangerous to the whole town if it gets in the wrong hands.  Pandora and the other cats of Mystic Notch must try to figure out whose hands are the wrong one and figure a way to stop disaster from striking those they are supposed to protect.

Tori Scott's magic is back with her newest series, Carter Country starts with a Cade, a heart-melting small town feel with Texas sized romance! The struggle to overcome guilt and the destructive forces of nature provide a solid background to our discovery of an awesome group of people.  I loved the novel Cade, and the character Cade, and look forward to the rest of the books in the series with excitement! I appreciate that Ms. Scott leaves the details of their lovemaking to my imagination.  What we see is enough to get my thoughts going as far as I want them to go.

I love Breaking Boundaries! This warm, hopeful, and hot novel of survival, hope, and growth is as outstanding as any of the Heartbreaker books. Teresa Reasor is amazingly gifted at drawing the reader into the hearts of her characters and at creating an edgy plot that keeps the reader glued to the page.I was especially delighted to discover that not only is Doc's sister Kathleen our heroine,the hero, Cal, has not one but two earlier connection connections to the team.

It is a Brenda Novak contemporary romance.  That says, I Love It, without any other words being  needed.  The book is a novella, but it felt like a full novel to me. The characters are so well developed that I wanted to shake Olivia's mother, of course everyone wanted to shake Kyle but we all also felt for him. He made a big mistake but he is a good guy and he knows he will not be the only one to pay for it.

The Fatal books by Marie Force are consistently outstanding.  I loved Fatal Scandal just as much as I have loved every book in the series. The relationship between Sam and Nick is as hot and beautiful as ever.  The homicide investigation focuses on clearing Gonzo of a possible murder charge. That plot would draw me in even if I didn't already love Sam and Nick.  In addition another romance faces complications.  The way Ms. Force allows members of Sam's team to share the limelight is one of the many strengths of this series.

Awesome.  In Her Sanctuary, we met SAC Marshall Hayes and observed his interaction with the Josephine Maxwell artist friend of an agent who has gone on the run from the mafia in fear for her life. Josie's life has never been easy even before she was sliced by a madman at age 14. After the terror, she withdrew into her own world with few friends and art as her salvation. Now the villain is back ready to close the circle, a circle of death and Josie is the beginning and end of that circle.I read Her Last Chance in the collection Her which includes Her Sanctuary, Her Last Chance, and the novella Her Risk to Take.

I have loved most of the Danger Cove books so far and this one is no exception.  While it is not my favorite, it is a winner.  From the all together too detailed statue swinging from the window of the old bordello that Cassidi inherited from her uncle along with the styling salon (in the all-together) to her friends and coworkers at the salon, humor abounds in this cozy mystery inspite of the murders and a serious mystery that Cassidi and her compatriots must help solve if there is any chance of the salon succeeding.

Toni Anderson books always have me chasing the twists and turns, but this one outdid itself in complexity of plot.  This outstanding novel displays all of Ms. Anderson's talent a both plotting and character creation.

I must admit that I was much more impressed with this book than I expected to be.  I loved it!  I was sure it would be pleasant but it was really, really good.  The characters were well crafted, the development of the relationship flowed well, and the story was fun.  Oh, yes, and it was Christmas.  It would be a good quick read for any time of the year, but I love Christmas stories so that is a plus for me.I will be checking out more of the Holiday Brides Series.

The sixth of the Jade Calhoun novels is great.  Jade and Kane are spending the beginning of their marriage walking between the shadows with Jade answering the the Angel's Council and Kane under the Brotherhood but is not offered the full respect of that position.  Neither role is great for this awesome duo but they have no choice.  When something that feels of Kane is walking the Shadows and trying to destroy angels, the team must battle a being that is to come after them too.  With only the support of friends on her witches council, Jade and Kane aren't sure if they have enough power to battle the evil they face, clear Kane's reputation, and protect their human friends from being destroyed. Note as the title hints, there is quite bit more sex in Incubus of Bourbon Street than in the earlier novels of the series.

I am a Debra Burroughs fan, but I believe that The Lake House Secrets is the best book I have read so far. The plot is intriguing, the pace is fast, and the people feel real. The way the Jenessa manipulates works some of her investigation bothers me but that is because it shows the press works almost any way they can to get information on an investigation.  Other than that I liked her and her friends and family. This is the first book in the Jenessa Jones series and I look forward to she where the series takes my new friends.

This second Kate Diamond Adventure is totally old-style adventure with a new style smart mouthed heroine and her battle counterpart.  The humor is in the interaction between characters but the action flows throughout the novel.PS, Spoiler ahead:  The snakes are really there, but they do not dominate the action; I could stomach them.

Karen Rose Smith always does it right, so it seems appropriate that one of her earliest series that I have read was Finding Mr. Right. Kit and Kisses is the first book of this early series and it is just as great as the books she writes today.Kit is working to recover emotionally and financially from falling to the wiles of a con man. Now she has to learn to trust and the man who is making her want to reach that goal is the local hardware store hottie who needs her expertise to build his business up in this day of big box stores.  Gray has trust issues based on his dating past to, but anyone he comes to trust must face the root of those issues along with him.

Gemini Rising was a good but the series title led me to expect more overt humor and a greater role from the dog in question.  I was not disappointed, but I do want to make sure that others feel that they got what they were expecting.  The series, Mischievous Malamute, is in fact the name of the protagonist business but that business IS named after Arianna's Malamute, Nicoh who is more than willing to get into mischief.Arianna never expected a forgotten bag of garbage to lead to death and danger, and a cute detective and when she discovered the battered body of a young woman she has no clue how closely she will become involved in discovering the person who could treat a woman that way or the reason behind the beating and subsequent death.I am definitely interested in following this series.

Witch Is the New Black is another delightful and sometimes tense novel in Dakota Cassidy's fun Paris, Texas Romances series.In this third fun but touching novel in the series, the witch in question isn't learning a lesson about abusing her powers, she is discovering that she HAS powers which explains why so many freaky things have happened to her since she turned 14.  One of the mysteries of the book is the question of why her parents didn't tell her she was a witch and prepare her for living in a human world with the powers of a witch. There is of course an evil one, a hot one, and many many wonderful people in Paris, Texas who are more than ready to help her once they understand what she need.

I have been a fan of LS Sygnet since I read the first of the Eriksson books and Hindsight is as good as the all of the others. I don't know how any author maintains this quality of writing through 14 books, but Ms. Sygnet has what it takes.Helen and her family and friends have traveled to celebrate the wedding of her brother Crevan and his love Alex when the hurricane that never hits Hawaii arrived to prove that nature does not play by rules.  During the devastating storm a murder occurs at the resort and some of the Darkwater crew who have stayed for a vacation are pulled into the investigation.  The darkness that has always haunted Helen's soul arises once more to complicate the situation

Bug is a delightful novel of romance and personal strengths, weaknesses and discovery.  Cheri Lewis is so talented at guiding the reader through the protagonist's struggle to understand relationships that are important to her and to understand her own strengths and weaknesses.  And while the author is leading us to discover the wonderful main characters, she blends real life components and great supporting characters throughout the plot to build a fascinating tale for our enjoyment.  This novel is a stand alone but intersects, in a small way, with the novel, Loves Lies Lost.  The story is much lighter than LLL although there are tough issues for both Maisie and Kellum to deal with.  Needless to say, I Loved It!

Doing the One Think To Make Reality Count is strong spiritual testament that reads like a conversation with the author. Brian K. Amos describes how God led him to the right path even when the author deviated the from plan when he was young. He makes the concept that God has a path for those willing to work towards is easily understandable and relates each concept to his own journey to athletic success. The book has few grammatical or structural errors which is an important issue for most of the readers that I know.

The best of a series I love. Lexi's newest case has her rethinking working on her own as a private investigator. The case she has taken on is so complex that she is taking the victim's word that she is being stalked; no one else believes it. Calling on all her resources, even her dad, Lexi is determined to prove that Juliet has a stalker who is so subtle and intelligent that even Juliet doubts her sanity some times. It turns out that she is not the only one interested in the case even though she is the only one who is trying to help Juliet; Solomon has been hired to determine is Juliet has violated laws covering illegal trading. My heart went out to Juliet and her fiancee because the situation seemed so impossible but I had faith that Lexi would find a way to get to the bottom of the problem.

I adore this series and this book was delightful!  That may sound funny considering that the main character gets shot and the relationship between her and her super hot fiancee is strained but there is so much humor that it keeps the balance of mystery, danger, and heat from totally boiling over.  Natasha is a trouble magnet providing much of the action and humor and Striker is always ready for action weather protecting Natasha or getting her steamed up in the bedroom or in her temper.

A Tainted Mind is an outstanding, fast-paced suspense novel with a wonderful romantic element. While the plot is solid and complex, it is the quality of characters that make the story great.  I am glad that this is a series because even the secondary character grabbed my interest and absolutely loved the main characters who are both extremely strong intelligent characters who have faced almost more than they can handle.  This one will having you begging for me just as it does me.

I loved Sweets Forgotten. Samantha Sweet books always draw me in and every book seems to get better.  I think that is because the characters have become so real to me.  Connie Shelton knows how to create a compelling plot while building a daily life for her characters that make me feel part of their lives. I adore Samantha and have such a crush on her now husband!  The touches of love the we see make their romance beautiful without crossing any lines. This is a series that I can reread to visit old friends and still enjoy the twists of the mysteries.

Lizbeth Selvig is an amazing author. Rescued by a Stranger is the fourth of her books I have read since discovering her recently, and I have loved everyone of them. One of the things that I enjoy way the fact that she weaves realistic community issues into each book, keeping us tied to the rich characters of the town as well as fascinated by our magnificent main characters.  Magnificent they are, however, they are not perfect. It is their weaknesses as well as their strengths that let us really see the characters as well as providing interesting background for conflicts in the relationships.Jill Carpenter is attend vet school during the year and works as a riding instructor/veterinary assistant in the summer and training as an Olympic hopeful.  Trust is her big issue but when Chance Preston sweeps into town rescuing her from minor disaster, it would be really easy to fall for the white knight on a vintage motorcycle.  Chance has lost faith in himself, so he is taking time off to escape memories and heal.

I love this series and A Mew to Kill was awesome.  The slight paranormal feel to the stories just adds to the depth of these cozy mysteries.  The story line surrounding the kitten was especially great.

I enjoyed Moving is Murder, but the story is a bit busy, and as I often do with cozy mysteries, I find that the protagonists goes beyond common sense, especially as she has a new baby.  I enjoy the real life feel that Ms. Rosett brings to the book and would never have guessed who the murder was. I chose this book because I love another series by the author, so I will probably try again. I especially enjoyed the relationship between Ellie and her husband and between Ellie and her best friend.

The Fourth of July celebration brings more than fireworks to the island. Death, fire, and explosions plague the island and the inhabitants of the McCarthy. This series is delightful and the characters are awesome. As disaster narrows in on the people she loves, Allie realizes just how much she cares for the man in her life.

Harper always felt that she fell short in meeting everyone's expectations, especially those of her father.  Now just when her professional life to take a major leap forward, the man she thought would live forever has died of a heart attack, and she has returned to the family ranch that she loves for his funeral. Mired in the pain of his loss and knowing that she will never have another chance to earn his respect, she is bowled over to discover that the family is close to losing the ranch.  The only warmth that she can feel is her reaction to her lifelong friend Cole, but she can't turn to him the way she has always wanted to because he had a long time relationship with her sister, and sisters don't date each other's exes, a philosophy that Cole refuses to understand or accept.  As disaster after disaster strikes, Harper is pulled by her love of the ranch on one hand and her need to succeed in her career as an artist on the other.Without Ms Selvig's amazing finesse in creating her character, Harper could easily have turned into a narrow, petty, or obsessed character, instead the reader is compelled to admire, enjoy, and just plain like the young artist.

I love the prequel to the Lexi Carmichael series. I adore the Zimmerman twins and this is the tale of when they first met worked together. I am not a big fan of prequels but I had to try this one and was so glad I did. I do wonder when Lexi is gong to realize that a certain computer nerd is crazy about her.In typical Lexi fashion, a trip to the beach, a nightmare in her world, gets even more complicated than she would ever imagine when she is literally left holding the bag. a bag of money that is.

I have adored Nick since I first met him in the Gotcha Detective series.  This book takes us back to early in his career when a case really hits him and helps make him the outstanding detective that he is.A stop for a quick bite at a cafe turns into a murder call that leads him into the world of runaways and teen prostitution. Although he is on patrol at this point he can't let the case go especially since the detectives on the case are caught up in something "more important". Short but well developed and touching, this story makes me love Nick more than ever.

Pros:- Needs no power cable- Works with Windows XP- Small, light and silent- A Terabyte for $50Cons:- Short proprietary cable- Cluttered root with Toshiba filesThese small drives have progressed a great deal. My past drives either needed a wall wart or two USB cables. I used this on two old Windows XP PC's, including a laptop, using a single USB 2 port, no problems. I transferred ~60 GB having thousands of folders and files in about an hour. Not fast by USB 3 standards but I was very pleased.The root of drive was cluttered with Toshiba files, I transferred all of them to a new folder (Toshiba). Toshiba should have shipped the drive like this. I dislike any files at the root, only folders.The drive cable end is unlike any I've ever seen before, don't lose the supplied cable, highly unlikely you'll ever find another like it. It's only 2-feet long and a bit stiff too.

The cloth backing is super tough, lasts at least 10-times longer than paper. Used this to clean my log deck rails and balusters prior to staining. The 80-grit makes quick work of the old stain and mildew.
Should have replaced this years ago. Two Phillips screws and done.
Cant tell it apart from the OEM taillight on the passenger side. Fast install with 3-10mm bolts.

Replaced the OEM sway bar on my 2000 Tundra 4WD because two snapped on me due to a defect (like a saw had cut 1/3 through). Unquestionably stronger and stiffer than the OEM bar but now the next weakest link fails. I do a lot of off-roading and this super stiff bar punishes the sway bar links and end grommets. I've broken maybe a half-dozen links. Some cheap ones from eBay only lasted 20-miles off road. The ACDelco links go about a year. I just installed a Moog link, definitely stouter but only time will tell if it'll last longer. As to the grommets, cheap OEM ones last a month or two, then they just disappear. Just installed a polyurethane set, I'm hopeful.Installing the sway bar required me to enlarge several holes in the frame for the included bolts. This thing is heavy, best to have a friend hold it until the threads are started.

Far and away the best mouse trap I've ever owned. Frequently catch multiple mice. Most I've caught in one evening is 4 mice. Bit hard to get them out when they get under the hinged door, but well worth the effort.The key is location and against a wall. I have mine against a log tail with no space between the log and trap, they follow the log, turn the corner and walk right in.I'm sure I've caught no less than 50 mice, likely double that. The downside of a log home . . . mice.

My review is limited to topo maps, with over 1000 road reviews there's nothing I can add.I'm upgrading from a 6YO Nuvi 205W, it lacks almost all of the bells and whistles of the 2757, but it did a good job displaying topo maps. Reading these reviews I was lead to believe that only road maps work in the 2757. Took my microSD with Above the Timber topos of CO & UT. Inserted the card into the slot. Turned on the 2757, browsed to the MyMaps page and it showed City Navigator, CO, & UT. Turned CN off, it'll display over topos, and moved from Chicago to UT using the base map. Zoomed in and viola, 24K topo maps.I've uploaded a screenshot of Arches NP. You can clearly see the road, hiking trail, selected arches and 40-foot contours. That my friends is the essence of a topo map.I won't take the 2757 in the field, too big. However that 7" screen will be a delight to preview a hike in my camper the evening before.Update June `15:Took the 2757 to Utah arch hunting. Drove 70+ miles on dirt and 4WD roads, the 2757 was mounted to the windshield using the supplied Garmin suction mount. That mount was so good the GPS never budged or vibrated the entire trip. I could see arch icons at the 1.2 mile scale giving me 10-miles of map to view. That allowed me to plan my stops for the closest starting point for each hike based on the contour lines . . . awesome. The main dirt road was on the CN maps and the spur 4WD roads were on the topo maps so navigation was a breeze.Puzzled by the battery charging. The mini-USB into the mount block will not charge the battery, it would only charge via the micro-USB port into the body. Why then does the mini-USB port exist?Update Sept `15:The 2757 supports AnyName.img in addition to gmapsupp.img for map files. Now you can break your topo maps into logical units instead of having one giant gmapsupp.img file. This is the first Nuvi I've encountered that supported AnyName.img, all handheld Garmin's have done so for many years.
Nothing but sugar. Normally eat P&B's cold, even heated this was dreadful.
Works like new.
Use these on my wrist BP monitors. Easily get 60-days of readings. Feeding them alkalines makes no sense.

Pros:- Half the price of TT basic- Opens MUCH faster than TT, and starts at your tax file- All the Forms- Data entry straight forward- Linked data from all forms to 1040- Forms button on top bar- PDF import- Modest learning curve- All files on my HDDCons:- Wanted to load at C:\ not C:\Program Files\- Had to register to open the software- State nag each time I opened the programLike all TT users I was appalled at Intuits money grab for 2014. For 30 years I'd been a TT user buying the basic version because it had all the forms I needed (1040, B, C & E), roughly $80 now on TT. I never use the Q&A format, simply wanted the forms and the internal links from each form to appropriate 1040 lines. At the end I run the audit check and file my paper return. I always have to pay, so I include the check with the return.TaxAct has all the features of TT, just slightly different and a bit of a learning curve. The most notable difference was the form(s) for expanded data for a single entry. TT tended to have custom sub-forms whereas TA used a single generic form for all entries.The PDF import was straight forward, with 20-20 hindsight I might have imported the massive form set instead of just the return to file. There were no import errors, just a few missing pieces. The alert review found missing data, so no big deal. Both TT & TA start in brain dead Q&A mode but in TA the Forms button was right at the top, TT required you to drill down.The C: load was contrary to any software in the last 10-years, even had a nag discouraging using Program Files, I did anyway, works fine. Never had a piece of software that I had to register before I could run it. The state nag was a noticeable bother, should have had a "Don't show this again" field.
Got a box of five on a Free Friday promotion at my local Kroger affiliate. Very tasty, but at $1 per 1 oz bar, good luck!

I bought a loop of this as a backup for my OEM chain on my Husky 455 Rancher. Once I used this, I realized how superior it was to the OEM safety chain. It like adding a couple of horsepower to the motor, it cuts so much easier. I've since ditched the OEM chain and got two more loops of this chain so I can change in the field. I sharpen them with a cheap HF grinder.This is not a "safety" chain but I've never had any unusual behavior, just smooth cutting. I just pay attention to the tip of the bar, illustrated in your manual.

This type of universal transformer has a noticeable delay, couple of seconds, as it sorts out the input voltage. There must be a relay and simple logic to switch the primary windings to either 120V or 220V. So while the LEDs are instant on, this transformer is not instant. If you don't mind the delay, works well.

Put these on a Tundra battery and so far so good after 18-months. I hate top terminal batteries, never had one that didn't corrode. Conversely, I have a 23 YO Chevy S10 with a side terminal battery, never had any terminal corrosion.

So far caught one mouse with no empty trips. These are substantially different from the classic wood base Victor Easy Set Mouse Trap 4 Pack M033 and more modern Snap-E SNAP-E MOUSETRAP set 6 traps. I have all three types and they all work.These have only three plastic pieces all held together with the coil spring, very simple design. Initially thought that the spring was to weak, but perhaps the molded teeth make the difference. Very easy to bait, set and release so you never have to touch the jaws or prey.
The plastic clip snapped off and the rubber grip is sticky. Would never purchase these again.

Sure enough, keeps the pleated filter from clogging, BUT you'll brush off this pre-filter 10-times as often. Very easy to clean this verses the pleated filter, but if you don't clean it frequently your vacuum will refuse to suck and sucking is what you want.I used some large rubber bands to hold this is place, worked well.

Not the same as the OEM heads. MUCH better!!!I kept purchasing new shavers on sale because they were cheaper than replacement heads. Little did I realize that the HQ8 combs are made differently than the OEM combs on the 7310 shaver. If you look closely at the photo, you'll see that the HQ8 combs have both standard slots AND small holes. The comb is keyed to the frame such that all the holes are in the interior with the slots on the outside. The OEM combs were all slots, no small holes.Bottom line, these HQ8 heads shave twice as close in half the time as the OEM heads. Can't say if the small holes are the reason or if the HQ8 heads are simply better, but they are a vast improvement over the OEM heads.
Have to clean the microwave 1/10th as often. This guy cleans in the dishwasher along with the glass turntable.

Having used the large loop with five small hooks to take the slack out of tire chains, a pair of these 9" straps is both better/stronger and easier to attach. These are 9" eye-to-eye and can stretch to 14". The steel hooks add several inches.

Needed to mark some white fabric care tags with small text info on a number of shirts, my old Rub-A-Dub pen was just too fat. After many washings the text is still clear and legible from this "thin" pen.

Pros:Cuts a 2x6, noticeable effort requiredAfter cutting ~100" of 2x6, blade still sharpCons:Hard to follow a straight cut line, too much dustI needed to make 2-dozen stepped 9-12 pitch gutter blocks. Didn't own nor want to purchase a table or radial arm saw for the job. I first tried the coarse tooth blade in a variety pack of blades, couldn't get even an inch with great effort . . . hopeless. Got these because of the incredible reviews for the Bosch shank version: Bosch T234X Progressor Wood Blade (5-Pack), I needed U-shank blades for a Skil jigsaw. Found the Bosch P/N on HD then used that P/N to search Amazon to order, Amazon searches are always a bit hit or miss.Because the blade tended to wander, I fabricated a 9-12 pitch guide which I clamped to the 2x6, I pressed the jigsaw shoe against the guide. I used my thumb on the back of the jigsaw to force the blade into the wood. Took about 2-min for each 4" cut. The wander likely means this blade is good for scroll cutting.If you ever used a SAK saw, then you know that the blade has no kerf/set, rather all the blade detail is within the blade thickness. Each tooth is intricately shaped and razor sharp, with right and left alternating teeth, not at all apparent from the product illustration. Not surprisingly, these blades were Made in Switzerland.
Works well and yes I used it outside. Powered a high current Skil saw with no problems. Price is right.

The back flange is very tight, I assume this was intentional so you could install the bracket on the gutter while on the ground and not have it fall off. Installing the bracket while on the roof is a bit difficult, but easy to open the flange with a small screwdriver.I installed my brackets every 18", the recommended is 24", should snow in a few days, that will be the test. After the snow, the gutter filled to the top with solid ice, no noticeable gutter sag. :)

Appears identical to the T25 Torx bit included with this box of screws The Hillman Group 47850 Star Drive 1000 Hour Deck Screw, 9 x 3-Inch, except:- That bit was marked T-25, these are marked HD S2???- The drawing says 60mm long whereas the specs say 50mm, the T-25 bit was 50mm long.

Got this rolling seat to sand and stain the log rails of my deck. Expect to spend many hours sanding and staining. A back and/or knee saver!!!It rolls so easy that the wind will push it across the deck!

The DCD771 is a detuned version of the classic Dewalt 2-speed, 1/2" chuck, VSR drill. Bigger, heavier, slower, less power, lower capacity batteries, slower charger, soft case, no belt or bit holder. Built to a price point of $99 on sale. Great for the once a month DIYer, not an everyday contractor tool.The closest contractor grade version of this drill kit is the DEWALT DCD780C2 20-Volt Max Li-Ion Compact 1.5 Ah Drill/Driver Kit which is $200+ shipped. Potentially double the price if you can find the 771 on sale.More detailed comparison of DCD771 and DCD780:- Lot longer (8.7″ vs. 7.5″)- Heavier (3.6 lbs vs 3.4 lbs)- Less powerful (300 UWO vs. 350 UWO)- Slower (0-450/0-1500 RPM vs. 0-600/0-2000 RPM)- Two 1.3Ah vs. 1.5Ah batteries- Slower non-temperature compensating charger (60 mins vs. 30 mins)- Contractor bag instead of a hard plastic case- No belt clip, bit holder or bit, but a place for both- Drill, battery & charger Made in China vs Assembled in USA from International partsBATTERIES & CHARGER:The Li-Ion 20V batteries have multiple cells which can individually drift, the charger can correct for this drift under known conditions: temperature. The 771 charger can only accurately charge the batteries when both the battery and charger are between 65 and 75 F. Whereas the included charger for the 780 has a cold/hot delay to compensate for cold/hot batteries. Charging outside the 65-75 temperature window will shorten the battery life, by how much?, that's the $64K question. For a homeowner, the 65-75 restriction is no big deal, for a contractor time is money. The 771 charger has two keyed holes on 4" centers to hang it on a wall. Cord appears to be 6-foot long.DRILL PERFORMANCE:The 771 arrived 12-2, charged the battery until the charger stopped flashing. Chucked a Torx T-30 bit and it took 50-sec to drive and remove a 5/16 x 4" Lag Screw into a pine log three times, color me impressed. My 30 YO B&D 3/8" 120V VSR drill managed to get the same screw halfway in before it stalled. In fairness to the B&D drill, shifting the 771 to high and it also stalled. It was almost dark and the LED light was almost blinding. Stayed on for a least 10-sec after the switch was released.The bag is spacious, was able to get both drills inside. The drill is very stout, you can tell there is steel inside. The entire back and handle is grippy rubber, the black. This may be a low dollar Dewalt, but it definitely isn't cheap.

A quality screwdriver has a ball on the end that presses into your palm to apply downward force to the screw, just like the product picture shows. That not what you get!!! Instead the end is simply rounded and the flutes cut into your palm when you press down. Add to that is the fluted plastic has a small diameter, so it's hard to apply torque to the screw.They work but only in a pinch would I use these. Best use: Opening the tabs of a 5-gal steel paint bucket.

A Torx deck screw is as significant an improvement over Phillips as Phillips was over slotted screws. I just finished installing custom 9-12 pitch gutter blocks using these screws and compared to the same size Phillips head screws the lack of frustration and increased drive torque was priceless. The drive bit slipped once when trying to drive at an odd angle, moved the ladder, squared the drill and buried the screw in the wood.I got the 1-pound box from my local hardware store for $7.29 + Tax. The box was labeled "Power Pro", Hillman appeared in small type on the bottom of the box. They had perhaps 30 different flavors, size and length, all Torx drive. I'll never buy another Phillips head screw if I can find the same screw in Torx.
Purchased in July, opened in November, DEAD!!!!Couldn't get the yellow to flow.Did not come in a box, only the foil pouch. Don't purchase from this sub-vendor.

Better than a Phillips/Flat combo bit. I rarely use the flat bit and the Phillips bit is good for about 100 deck screws before they're tossed, so twice as many screws per bit.I'll put these on my cordless drills in place of the Phillips/Flat.

Nicely made with a thick acrylic pile lining at an excellent price but definitely NOT extra-large. I wanted a size large winter glove and that's exactly what these are. I also ordered a pair of B.A.G.G. LEATHER & Canvas Reinforced INSULATED Work Glove - 2" Cuff - LARGE, both gloves are the same size. The product photo makes the cuffed glove look longer, it isn't. These are the better value being all leather.

Nicely made with a thick acrylic pile lining at an excellent price but the all leather B.A.G.G. LEATHER Insulated Fingered Work GLOVE - EXTRA LARGE is the same size and the same price, so it makes more sense.Both gloves are the same length and the leather on the back of the hand and cuff will offer more protection than the cotton of this glove. For a cuffed glove, the cuff is 2" shorter than the non-insulated Custom Leathercraft 2048L Work Gloves with Leather Palm and 4.5-Inch Safety Cuff, LargeI've been using these extensively hand splitting firewood blocks, moving aluminum ladders, snow raking my roof, feel real good. Warm but not waterproof. Good gloves.

Pros:- Holds 22 fluid ounces- Easy dishwasher clean- Great for hot soup heated in the microwaveCons:- Each cup weighs 23 ouncesThe weight is both a blessing and a curse. If you heat food in the cup, like in a microwave, then the cup will be the same temperature as the food and keep your food warm longer. However, if you pour hot food into the cup, that same mass will suck the heat out of the liquid quickly turning it tepid.In a prefect world I'd prefer a thinner, lighter cup.

Pros:- Better than a radio in weak signal areas- Retain old factory radio with new radio features- Short learning curve to figure out the remote- Sound is surprisingly goodCons:- Have to remember to eject and turn off "cassette" battery, no visible light- Doesn't eject smoothly on my Jeep- No apparent way to fast forwardAllows me to retain the OEM radio look and have MP3 audio. Wish the battery light was visible on the edge of the cassette as a reminder to eject and turn off the battery. I primarily listen to sports talk radio, frequently need to fast forward this content, I haven't found a way using the remote.

The DVR 612 is my third Dish DVR going back over 10-years. First had the original 501 which went 9-years and I got a letter from Dish saying it was obsolete. Dish replaced it with a used DVR 512, which had a squeaky fan that I replaced. It lasted 2-years before the HDD failed. Got the VIP 612 on ebay for ~$70 as a refurbished unit still in a sealed anti-static bag. The 612 pros and cons compared to the 512:Pros:- HDMI output to an HDTV- 20.1 remote with a Format button with four aspect ratio options- USB output option to external HDD- No fan noise after the first minute of power on- Bigger HDD so more recording hours- Big bright record (red) and on (green) lights, could barely see 512 LEDsCons:- Power hog, 38 watts just plugged into the wall- Skip forward audio anomaly- Slow to acquire satellitesAll three Dish DVRs are power hogs, the 612 is the worst, roughly 25% more than the 512. The 612 uses 38 watts plugged into the wall, 39 watts turned on and 40 watts recording, shame on Dish, that's more daily electricity than a refrigerator. I'm solar electric so I have an inline switch to save my batteries. But the satellite acquisition time is 3 times as long as the 512 or I'll get unviewable recordings if I don't power-on at least 15-min before the record time.
