The 512 could be powered on at anytime and it would start the record as soon as the satellites were aquired with no record defects.The audio anomaly happens after skipping forward on recorded programs, takes the audio ~2 sec to settle after the last skip, neither the 501 or 512 had this "feature".The Format button on the 20.1 remote is particularly useful. Some broadcasters send SD in standard 4:3 format, whereas others use 16:9. The 4-options on the remote allow a screen filling view without clipping. The same button on the HD TV remote either didn't fill the screen or clipped some of the image. Both stretch SD content, but clipping is a bigger issue. I haven't upgraded my antenna yet to receive the HD satellite, so still dealing with SD.

Pros:- Has USB so no manual transfer to a spreadsheet- Software sets clock via USB- Software on CD, no download- Works with NiMH AAA batteries- Bargain price- One button for Start and Off- Set H/L rangesCons:- Usual weird Asian software- Would need a tool (paper clip) to manually set clockI got this for $20 shipped from an obscure music store via a Google search. USB wrist BP monitors are very rare or very expensive. I'm comparing it to a Prevention USB BPM I got from Woot some years ago. I measure my BP using both units and get similar results, not identical. The Ion tends to give a little lower readings.With the Ion and the Prevention I can get 2-months of daily readings before recharging the AAA batteries.Overall the Ion software is easier to use, more intuitive than the Prevention software, but so far the BP graph is less dramatic. You can set High/Low ranges and the software will report the number/percentage of events in/out of range. My doctor was particularly pleased with this report, more so than the graphs.The Prevention BPM has long been off the market and I predict the same fate for the Ion brand when these sell through.Five stars for the price, if $50-$100 for a USB BPM then 3-stars.

Pros:- True to Size- Incredible Comfort- Shed dirt and water- Peatmoss, a dull dark green- Slender Cut- Wide belt loops, over 2"Cons:- Velcro rear pocket closures- Columbia name stitched onto the rear hip in whiteI took a fly on a pair of these from STP because of the low cost (~$25) and the Columbia name. From the moment I first put them on, I was blown away by the perfect fit and the fabric feel and weight. The fabric has a light stretch vertically. In the crotch, the stretch is horizontal.Went on a backpack with them and they looked as new at the end as at the start. Then I did a trail maintenance trip where I was down on my knees and splattered by mud, looked like new after a quick hand brushing.I quickly ordered 3 more pair, 2 for me and one in a different size for a friend. I got out my seam ripper and removed the Velcro from the right-rear pocket from all three.I wouldn't hesitate to wear these in a business environment, except for the stitched name, they are that stylish.

Pros:- Removes ash powder from glass- No foul smellCons:- Very expensive for what is does- Will NOT remove the translucent white filmI bought a bottle of this 15 years ago when I got my first wood stove. I had no clue how to run a wood stove. After a few weeks it became clear, run her hot. Initially I'd try to throttle the damper, that only produced black soot everywhere. I run my stove a minimum of 200 days per year and the damper now has only two positions: wide open or closed when cold. I usually clean the glass every time I empty the ashes, about once a week.Over the years a persistent translucent white film has developed and I've tried toothpaste, ash paste, and this product. All make a dent but none removes it completely. I followed the directions and used a Teflon kitchen sponge with heavy pressure. The film is so thin and well bonded it has a rainbow near the edges.For weekly cleaning, Windex and a paper towel removes the white ash powder as well as anything.FWIW, the active ingredient is Sodium Hydroxide.If anyone knows how to remove the translucent white film, please post a comment.

Pros:- Four simple, large LCD timers- High contrast LCD, they keep getting better- H:M or M:S not H:M:s- No clock, just complicates things- Loud alarms- Only 4 buttons to control everything- Buttons accept a single increment- Metal magnets on back, not magnetic tape- Pen has an eraser and magnet, need not use pen clip- Master reset, press 3 of 4 buttons (product photo is out-of-date)- Remembers last setting, Press Start/Stop to recall- Stop and Restart timer, essentially pause- Audible alarm stops after 10-min, counter continuesCons:- AAA batteries, prefer AA- No support under buttons, rocks slightly pressing buttonsI bought this to replace a Polder 891-90 Triple Kitchen 20-Hour Timer/Clock/Stopwatch which had two basic flaws: 1 You couldn't increment the setting one digit, it would often jump 2-5 digits with a press; 2 It wasn't splash proof, it's supposed to be a kitchen timer where water/liquids are common.Now used this Taylor for a couple of months, pretty brain-dead simple to use with everything I need. Whoever thought to marry a timer with a whiteboard deserves a raise, expect many copycats.

I loved this mouse until it had a flat tire!Intermittently I would experience so much drag on the scroll wheel that it would barely turn. This usually happened in the morning after extended hours of non use. Today I was having troubles and the entire rubber outer rim had pulled away from the wheel. It was like the rubber rim was several millimeters larger than the wheel. How could this happen???Today I ordered a new Logitech mouse, I'll limp along until it arrives.Edit Nov 2013: FIXED FLAT TIRETook the mouse apart, need a Torx T-6, and gently removed the snap in wheel assembly, broke the three tiny plastic welds, and using a small round file created a number of concave pockets on the outer rim of the wheel. Went to the hardware store, bought a small o-ring ($0.40) and stretched it over the wheel rim. Cemented the plastic wheel cover and re-assembled into the mouse.The mouse wheel looks a little odd, but works very well. I now have the magnify tool which is unique to Microsoft mice and not available on Logitech mice.I'll leave the two star rating, I shouldn't have to repair a mouse wheel.

Pros:- Breathable upper fabric- Light weight- Rubber boot strap, not a cord- Elastic calf shock cord with retained spring clamp- Price for all black ~$8 less than the colorsCons:- Would not stay up on calf- Zipper starts at the bottom- Black- When cold/wet the boot strap slips out of the ladder buckle- Which is right/left?I put these on at the house, drove 25-miles to the trail, hiked 4-hours in 2-6" of snow and they were never hot, either in the car or while hiking. That and  the cuffs of my cotton denims weren't even damp, that's impressive.I'm 6'-1" with a 34" inseam but the calf shock cord would not hold up the size large gaiters, seems they needed to be a couple inches taller.  They did not droop to my ankles because the front zipper and Velcro is so stiff, it propped up the fabric.My last pair of gaiters had the zipper start at the top, I'm convinced that's a much better solution. In almost every other respect these are far superior.The rubber boot strap threads through a ladder buckle for retention and adjustment, this works very well when dry and at room temperatures. Not so well when wet and cold. Several times I've had the strap come loose and be flapping. I solved this by putting a small safety pin through the strap.The product photo is so small and dark both on Amazon and Outdoor Designs, I was in the "dark" as to the features of these gaiter. However, the many positive reviews swayed me. I posted a photo with notes to help others.

I removed the white plastic part, must be used in some other vehicle that this fits. I now have a 4-speed fan instead of high only.I've seen these priced as high as $60, so the Amazon price was refreshing.

Pros:- Thick, one piece leather uppers- Solid bonding of sole to upper- Comfortable, No Break-in needed- Color = Dirt- Good traction in snow, rock and gravel- Laces that stay tight- True to size- Nice padded collar- Price, about the same as a resole- Metal, not plastic, lace hooksCons:- No steel foot-bed, too flexible- One tongue not centered- Soft rubber sole collects cactus- Not waterproofSince I received these in late July I've put over 200-miles on them in 4-12 mile day hikes. Most hikes have been on trails, but a few off trail on steep side slopes and talus. Both off trail uses highlight the weakness of these boots. The lack of a steel foot-bed makes the sole too flexible for comfortable off trail hiking on steep terrain.The cactus con was a surprise. For miles around my house small prickly pear are common and with leather uppers and Vibram soles I just ignored the cactus. My first hike with these and the soles were filled with a combination of needles and crushed cactus pedals. Basically the sole rubber is too soft to reject the needles, unlike a hard rubber Vibram sole.The Timberland website claims waterproof, not what I experienced. Took a 4-mile,4-hour hike in 2" of snow where the boot toes were frequently dusted with snow, when I got home my socks were damp. Never experienced that with my Gore-Tex boots.I'm only mildly disappointed with these boots, they have limitations and I'll need to use them where they are best suited.

Pros:- Fits my 1991 Chevy S10 Pickup, passenger door- Amazon price if you're willing to wait a few more daysCons:- The plastic rod retainer was inserted backwards causing confusion- Supplied metal post retainers would have been difficult to installInstalling this is quite a marathon. The biggest challenge was reinstalling the push-rod which goes from this handle to the latch mechanism. That push-rod isn't retained by the latch, so once removed finding its proper hole is entirely by braille. Then the plastic retainer was inserted backward into the new handle lever, it wasn't until I examined the old handle that I realized the problem. The supplied push-on post retainers weren't as easy to install as the old spin on nuts, so I used the old ones.All 9 door panel clips snapped removing the panel. Got 20 clips from China, took a couple of weeks.

Pros:- Holds the tanks securelyCons:- The heavy steel strap fatigues and breaks at the spot weld- Hard to compress and engage the cinch boltI have this same rack in my RV, until it failed it held the tank securely. The heavy gauge loop strap (~1/16") is just mild steel, not spring steel. The ends need to be spread apart about one foot to get the tank inside the loop. Doing so causes the steel to bend, not flex, at the spot weld. After so many bend cycles it fatigues and breaks.This same bending makes getting the bolt through the two ends very difficult, especially starting the nut while holding the two ends together.Perhaps this rack was designed to have the tank inserted vertically, not possible in my RV.

Pros:- Adjustment for latch position- Gentle lead in for the spring boltCons:- One supplied wood screw snapped off at the head- The adjustment plate sticks out- Not the same screw centers as the old plateYou'll need a hammer and wood chisel in addition to a Phillips screw driver to install this strike, the holes are a good bit wider. One of the supplied wood screws snapped off ~1/4" from the head just as I was tightening the screw. The screws need to be very tight for the adjusting teeth to hold.Bottom line: My entry door is tight against the weather seal with the ability to make it firmer if need be.

Replaced the Denso OEM plugs in my Tundra after ~84,000 miles, they were working fine. Checked the gaps from one bank, all were between 0.047-0.050", about 50% over spec.These Russian made Bosch plugs reeked quality. Hard to get excited about a spark plug, but everything about these said well made. Plating, ceramic, fit and finish were top notch.The gap spec is 0.032" and I checked all of them. In all cases a 0.030" wire passed through and a 0.032" wire just entered the gap. Close enough since the ground strap was 50% thicker then the Denso plug and I would not have been able to bend it.The engine fired right up with no misfire. So far driven 500+ miles and the most surprising thing was vastly improved AM radio reception. I drive exclusively in the mountains and FM is only good to ~25 miles. The AM station I listen to is well over 100-miles away. The old plugs had severe static, whereas these are almost static free.

Fairly straight forward replacement once I figured how the groove in the pads mated with the carrier. The carrier accepts the braking force, not the caliper. The pads were made in India, that's different.The new pads had copper threads in the matrix, in a ceramic pad??? Did a search, to be expected. Okay :)The braking performance was excellent after the new pads and rear brake adjustment.Some tips:- Put a container under the master cylinder, then use a C-clamp to compress the caliper piston.- If you're replacing the front pads, then for sure your rear brake shoes are out of adjustment, may be worn too. Remove the drum and turn the star wheel until the drum just fits. Will make a huge difference in the brake pedal feel.

Pros:- Nicely made 3/8 drive, 5/8" 6 pt impact socket- Very readable size markingsCons:- Spark plug falls out when held vertical- The display gadget broke off inside the 3/8 squareA spark plug socket MUST hold a spark plug in any position or it fails. The product had an elastomer deep inside the socket so an attempt was made, but the first plug I inserted fell into my lap. Better there than the engine bay.To display on a peg board it had a 3/8 plastic square molding inserted into the socket. When I tried to remove it, the gizmo snapped off, leaving the square socket full of plastic. Had the socket retained a spark plug I would have been only a bit perturbed and drilled out the plastic.So if you're looking for an extra long 5/8" x 3/8 drive impact socket, this may be it. Just not a spark plug socket.Back to Amazon it goes.

My only real complaint about this saw is that a simple wing-nut is an insufficient clamp to prevent blade rotation on the push stroke. Even though all folding saws are only intended to cut on the pull stroke, some drag will occur on the push stroke. Particularly when cutting green wood.I used this saw cutting three 4" Dia logs the other day during trail clearing. Two were dry and even pithy and even on those I experienced some slippage/rotation at the wing nut clamp. The third was more than a year down, so semi-dry, and the drag in the kerf was so severe that every push stroke caused blade rotation.My solution! Drill a hole in the blade, add another 10-24 x 1-1/4 carriage bolt and wing nut to prevent rotation. See photo.You may think that removing that screw from its storage location and inserting it through the blade is a lot of extra work, but given the effort to saw a log, it will be time well spent. Besides, the way I have it configured, you need not use the second screw unless/until the blade starts rotating.Basically, Flexrake needs to incorporate this or another solid anti-rotation solution to make this a finished product.

Pros:- 2" Capacity- Light Weight- Reasonable Cost- Compound Cutter, Less Effort- Easily SharpenedCons:- Compound Cutter, More Distance to Open- No Rubber StopI bought this lopper exclusively for trail maintenance a few times per year. That maintenance consists of 90% willows with the balance conifer limbs and Potentilla. Willows grow as a multi-stem cone from knee high to over head high and quickly obscure a trail if not pruned back periodically. The goal is to cut the willow within 6" of the root. To do that a long reach is needed and the compound mechanism reduces the force required.The AL 4110 is the least expensive of the ~40 lopper models that Corona makes. However it is not cheaply made, just design compromises to reduce cost. All the steel parts: cutter, hook, link bar were heavy gauge steel stampings with nice tight joints.I used this lopper for 8-hours over two days cutting 1000's of willows from 1/8" up to 1-1/2" Dia. If I could get the cutter/hook around the willow stem, then the cutting effort required was always trivial. By comparison, I have an old single pivot lopper, cutting the largest stems required every ounce of strength I had.If a cut wasn't clean, a small uncut ribbon, then sharpening was required. I sharpened the cutter perhaps a half-dozen times in the two days using one of these Corona Clipper AC 8300 Sharpening Tool, fast and easy. The same compound mechanism that makes cutting so easy puts a lot of stress on the cutting edge, causing the edge to dull.Even though the AL 4110 lacks a rubber stop, I never felt a jarring close. Perhaps because willows cut so easily or it is just inherent in the compound mechanism?I considered one of the highly rated Fiskars PowerGear loppers, but if you watch their video, they need to be opened 180, that's best suited for waist high cutting. For willows, the best cutting position is sitting on  the dry ground. For that position, the 90-120° opening of the AL 4110 is a better fit, see attached photos.1 Year Update:I've now trimmed over 10,000 willow and spruce branches, no I didn't count. Occasionally, the tool will bind from grit getting between the cutter and hook. Disassembly (4 identical 1/2" nuts) and simple cleaning and works like new. After all that use, held it to a bright light, no gap between the cutter and hook.Was on a backpack into a NM wilderness, met a USFS trail crew with a 5-foot long 2-man handsaw, they had this same lopper as part of their kit.The combination of light weight, long reach and powerful cutting action makes this lopper an ideal trail trimmer.

Pros:- Very heavy suede leather- No weak stitches- Very long cuff- PriceCons:- Hot to wearIn my experience work gloves fail at the seams before the leather wears through. I used a pair of these for trail maintenance, clearing willows with a lopper and using a pick to divert water off the trail. Used them for 8-hours over 2-days and they showed no signs of seam failure. I had no blister or other sores so the gloves did their job of protecting my city hands.I was working in 60-70° temps and after an hour I couldn't wait to get these gloves off to allow my hands to cool and dry off. This bodes well for low temperature use.

If you're looking for a powerful fine mist showerhead, look no further. You don't realize how important a showerhead is to the shower experience until you used a couple of duds then find THE ONE.This is not a water saving showerhead and the whole phrase is an oxymoron. I want a pleasant shower and saving water is never a thought.Amazon only allows 5 stars, but to me this is a 10 star product.

I like to hike and backpack between 10 and 13,000 feet in Colorado. Also I'd rather not wear a hat. My preference is alcohol based quick drying sunscreens for my thinning top and face. This product meets all my sun protection needs, EXCEPT the smell. An hour after application I'm still overwhelmed by a sweet citrus odor that limits where I can apply the sunscreen.Previously I had used a similar Bullfrog product that offered identical protection with no odor.

I had no idea what I was getting when I ordered this hair trimmer/cutter. Basically ordered it for the low price and the Norelco name. As typical of so many products on the internet, the descriptions don't begin to show what a product does or how.I didn't know that the simple cutter is adjustable both in height and that it rotates 90 degrees to either side. Both of those adjustment are critical to the function and a marvel of clever engineering.Except for smooth shaving your face, this trimmer can remove/lower any hair anywhere on your body over a range from 1/4" to 1" in small increments. As an example, today I decided to prune my bushy eyebrows, fast, simple, painless. I could give more examples, but suffice to say, any hair anywhere on your body!

Pros:- Blade Locks Open & Closed- Large Rubber Grip- Low Cost- Knuckle GuardCons:- Heavy and Large- No set to the teethI got this as a packable saw for trail work to use instead of my 14" non-folding hand saw. Its 30% heavier but the blade fits inside the knuckle guard when closed.The saw is 4.5 x 11.5 inches closed, weighs 13.2 oz and the blade is 9.5" long. Everything you see in red is a rubber material for a slip free grip. The blade is quite thick and the teeth have no set.I've done two trail clearing projects since receiving the saw, this is what I've learned. The lack of set to the teeth is a major problem for dry wood over 4" Dia and green wood over 3" Dia. When cutting larger wood, the chips fail to clear the center teeth during each back/forth stroke. Then the saw binds in the cut and it no longer moves. To continue, you have to fully remove the blade from the cut with each pull stroke, not very efficient.When I ordered, the same saw was offered by several Amazon vendors, I choose the cheapest, BuyDBest at $8.23. Amazon has a huge selection of folding saws, wade in.

Pros:- Thermometer- Three independent burners- Tool Storage- Easy propane tank attachment- Price- Excellent customer serviceCons:- Structurally deficient, see photo- Cosmetic damage- Defective Ignitor, not true see edit *I started looking for a new gas grill late summer 2011. I had problems with ground squirrels getting into my grill and tools. All I could find at various big boxes were monster contraptions costing many 100's of $$$. So when the 463722311, catchy model name, showed up on one of the bargain sites for $94 shipped, I jumped on it.THE GRILL:Fundamentally this is a very solid gas grill with flaws in design of the support frame and numerous quality issues getting a perfect product to the customer. The basic gas grill was preassembled and it slid into the frame you assembled from the many parts using a well-illustrated manual. Both the top and bottom of the firebox were heavy gauge steel shells. The burners, tent flame shields, upper wire shelf and grill racks are then inserted inside the shells, all exhibiting a been there - done that before professionalism. All the steel pieces were coated in porcelain, easy to clean and durable. I've yet to fully master all the subtleties of grilling on the 463722311, but I'm convinced that with the thermometer and 3-burners it won't take me long.* Since I started using the 463722311 2-months ago I've grilled steaks, chicken, brats and burgers at least twice each and the combination of the three independent burners and the thermometer allows  repeatable control. Some things just need fast grilling whereas other need baking. I always grill in the center with a single grate, this allows me to move the grilled item over the flame tent, away from direct flame. I then adjust the outer burners for the interior temperature. Easier to do than explain.BBQ** Before I got this grill I was clueless how to BBQ, I only grilled. BBQ is grilling first, then baking to finish. For BBQ three burners and a thermometer are crucial, I cook in the center and leave that burner off for baking, use the other two burners for temp control. BBQ has tripled my menu options and I now use the grill ~100 times per year. Surprisingly easy on propane, maybe three bottles per year.STRUCTURE:The frame that supports the firebox lacked basic structural elements to prevent parallelogram collapse on the right side. A simple triangular brace is all that would be required. Instead, Char-Broil wasted three pieces of wire to exclude a propane tank from being placed under the firebox. Any of those three wires could have braced the frame from collapse. I added a steel strap, crude but functional, see photo.DAMAGE:The grill had numerous dents, dings and bends in many of the thin gauge steel parts. The worst dent was in the upper firebox shell. It had a large dent from the inside out. It's as if someone took a ball peen hammer with full force struck the shell. The dent fractured the porcelain coating inside and out. In addition, the control panel was heavily scuffed in the right corner leaving a thumb size area with the paint removed. Everything was well packaged in cardboard and/or Styrofoam. The outer carton had almost no damage when it arrived. None of the packaging material showed any damage. All this leads me to believe that the damage occurred prior to shipment and were packaged that way by Char-Broil.IGNITOR:The piezo crystal push button ignitor didn't work. I saw one blue spark in one hundred attempts. I used the interactive PDF ignition questionnaire and ended up at the 800 number. I called customer service and except for the accessory up selling the process was smooth and painless. New ignitor should arrive in a week. Installing it into the tight space above the gas manifold will be non-trivial.* After receiving the replacement ignitor which also didn't work, I figured out the problem. I assumed that the ignitor had two parallel circuits for the side and main burners . . . wrong. The two electrodes are in series. By not installing the side burner, I defeated the ignitor function, I should have grounded the side burner wire to the frame.MORE:While the 463722311 has no designed in tool storage, I had no need for a side burner, so I converted that compartment into tool storage, see photo. I purchased a 1/8" pipe plug to block the gas port for the side burner. The propane tank has a hook and v-notch attachment over the axle, quick and simple.I deducted 2 stars for the defective ignitor, weak structure and all the damage. The 463722311 could have easily earned 5 stars except for those problems. My spell checker likes igniter, but Char-Broil spells it ignitor in their manual?*Edit 2-15-12 I bumped my rating one star.**Edit 7-8-14 Added BBQ paragraph

Pros:- Price, I paid $399- My Dish remote did basic controls (On/Off, Volume, Mute)- Vibrant LCD colors and contrast- Color presets or individually adjustable settings- Matte screen- Low power (74 watts)- Easily attached external speakers- Useful manual- Great image via HDMI from Bluray, DVD or Xbox- Good composite image from my DVR- Power brickCons:- Terrible speakers- Slow start up, ~5-10 seconds- No auto recognition of aspect ratio- Power brickI got this from my local Small Box a couple of days before BF, so I've had it about 5-weeks. I had been considering the LG 47" 3D bundle, but virtually no 3D content and half the price from a local store and I bit on this in spite of the many low reviews.At first I had weird color patterns, orange bands in the green grass, watching football. The manual's troubleshooting section suggested it was a composite cable problem. Checked the cable, too much strain causing the connector to be skewed, fixed that and not seen the problem in 4-weeks.The power brick is a double edge sword, another block to deal with, but OTOH possible to have no cables attached to the TV when moving, not even a power cord. Speaking of power, I measured 74 watts when on, less than 1 watt off. That's about as good as it gets with any 42" LED LCD TV.As to speakers, instead of a $100+ sound bar, I opted for a pair of computer speakers, I had 3-pair laying around. One problem, computer speakers have a single 1/8" (3.5mm) plug whereas all TV's have RCA jacks. To quickly convert you need this inexpensive part from Amazon: "2 x RCA Male / 1 x 3.5mm Stereo Female, Y-Cable, 6 inch". Radio Shack does not carry an equivalent part, bah humbug. I ordered two and give the second to my local Radio Shack.One other step in the speaker situation, you need to disconnect the TV's internal speakers, else their terrible distorted sound will add to whatever external speaker you select. If you simply turn off the internal speakers with the menu command, you no longer have volume control with your remote. You'll need an A/V receiver or some other solution. To disconnect the internal speakers, I disassembled the TV cabinet and posted photos.I have this sitting in a corner next to and almost touching two large windows, the matte screen and LCD image combine to make for a very viewable picture in the middle of the day.This TV does not auto recognize the aspect ratio of TV content, don't know if this is possible, sure would be nice. Perhaps if I get a HDMI DVR then this will be a non-issue. Currently I scroll through 4 settings on the remote to select the best aspect ratio for the content I'm viewing. In the grand scheme of things not a big issue.Overall I'm very pleased and if it dies in a year I'll only be out $400, OTOH if it lives 5-years it'll be a great bargain. Time will tell.

Pros:- Records two SD programs at once and allows me to watch any prerecorded program while recording, including either of the two being recorded.- Improved menus and overall operation vs the DVR 501- Essentially faultless recording in the 4-months I've had it.Cons:- Power hog, 33-35 watts just plugged into the wall, on, off or recording- The 4" HDD fan squealed, I replaced it with a computer case fan- Very old, full of dust, the 200GB HDD was made by Maxtor (they've been gone for years)- No HDMI socket for HDTV- Can't handle Daylight Savings Time, all programing is an hour off, delete and reprogramI've been a DVR junkie for almost 10-years, I time shift 95% of everything I watch. My DVR 501 had been acting up for 6-months and then I got a letter from Dish saying it was obsolete and would need to be replaced in the next year. I called Dish the next day and asked why wait, they said how about tomorrow.The only bad part was I now incur a $6/mo DVR fee which starts in one year.

1:24 MinsI've not done any video editing in about 10 years, so I was starting from scratch. Other than understand a timeline, I had no clue how VSPX4 worked. It took me about 4 hours to create the attached video. That included loading VSPX4 (20 min), and finding several still photos and crop them to 640x480, the same as my base avi file.I started with a 10-min avi video and used it multiple times with different start and end points. Then I added numerous text elements which were added to the parallel text timeline. I did numerous previews to see how all the elements interacted. The attached video is composed of the avi file plus three jpeg photos for a total of 84 seconds. I did all this without ever opening the manual, just hovered over the tools to read the tool tips.The only hard part was figuring out the output format. Tried a avi 640x480, took 20 min to render and it was lousy. Then tried wmv at 320x240, took 1 min and it is the attached file.I did not find a help link in the main menu, surprising for a Corel product. My only real complaint is that the text timeline did not stay attached to the video timeline. So if you insert and/or change the length of video clip, all the downstream text elements no longer relate to the correct clip. Quite possibly I need to learn by reading the manual. ;)So by my standards, this is easy to learn and I'm looking forward to adding to my skill set with more projects.

Pros:- Dark as AdvertisedCons:- Lacking any hint of chocolate flavorI'm comparing this product to two store brands by Kroger and Walmart. Both of which have a distinct bitter-sweet chocolate flavor. This syrup has no hint of chocolate flavor, in fact no flavor at all. This is simply dark goo with nothing to excite my taste buds.Hershey . . . back to the kitchen!!!

I got these to mail slim DVD cases, but a standard thickness DVD case fits also. I cut off the bottom of a plain paper invoice for the address label and attach it with clear packaging tape, seems to hold as well as on kraft.The light weight film is easy to wrap over the DVD case to create an adjustable length envelope. The adhesive flap is also better than the wet to seal of a kraft envelope.Lighter, easier, cheaper!!!

I'm a newbie to the world of high cocoa chocolate bars. I got one of these at my local grocery for $2, amazed they'd carry such a high end product, it's a very small store. My only previous purchase was a box of Chocolove 77% bars from Amazon. I've consumed one of a dozen bars.In comparing the two products, the only significant difference is the noticeable aftertaste of the Lindt bar which was not present with the Chocolove product. I'm talking several hours later after I'd brushed my teeth and gone to bed, still an aftertaste.Otherwise, both were very smooth with a rich chocolate taste. I chased the Lindt bar with a couple of dark Hershey kisses, amazing how sweet a Hershey kiss is after eating some high cocoa chocolate.Two other observations:1- A 3.5 ounce bar is huge. One bar is good for at least three servings for me. YMMV.2- The Lindt bar had a sealed foil wrapper, whereas the Chocolove bar had a folded paper and foil cover with no real seal.

Pros:- Good Sunlight Readability- Dynamic Distance and Bearing- Works with Above the Timber Topos- Very Accurate Position & Altitude- High Resolution Display- Ability to Color and Save Tracks- Touchscreen Interface- Easy Text Entry- AA Batteries- User Text Block at Start up- User Background- Many ways to Display Trip Info- Create a Screenshot of Anything- 0 or 2 or 4 Semi-transparent Data Fields on top of the map- Custom Profiles to Retain Unique Settings- Excellent GeoTagging integration with BaseCampCons:- Odometer Inaccurate, Greatly Improved w/ 3.90- Low Battery Life- Imprecise Touch Position- Most Elevation Fields not displayed on Trip ScreenThis is my fourth Garmin GPS (it's a disease) and for my outdoor hiking interest this is so far the best. For my needs no GPS is worth a pinch of salt except for the internal maps, knowing my coordinate location on planet earth is of no value. However, having an accurate map inside gives that location context and in doing so exceeds the sum of its parts. As I move, the GPS instantly centers the map around my position and I can quickly zoom in/out for more detail or area.Of secondary interest are the GPS' whistles & bells such as various time, distance, elevation and waypoint fields. I like and use all of these as it satisfies my inner geek. Unfortunately, you cannot put all possible fields on a single screen. The max/min elevation values can only be displayed on the elevation profile screen, not the main trip screen. Also, a date field is not available on either of the two data screens, hence you cannot create a single screen to record relevant data with the trip date. I record a screenshot of the trip data and a date field would make it a complete trip snapshot.Since I've gotten the 450 in mid-Sept., I've taken 4 hikes from 4 - 11 miles, in all case the trip odometer has been off from 20-50% low relative to the same trip distance as recorded by the track log. I also compared the odometer to a Garmin Colorado and its odometer was within 2% of the track log. I'm running the latest firmware 3.80, doing my odometer comparison. Update, Garmin's latest firmware release 3.90, greatly improves the odometer accuracy to where it is low about 2%.A feature of the 450, common to most Garmin handhelds, but missing from the Colorado, is Dynamic Distance & Bearing. With DD&B you can place a marker anywhere on the map and the GPS will instantly calculate the distance and bearing from your current position. It's dynamic because as you move those two values are always updated. That marker also becomes the center of reference for subsequent zooming actions. Problematic with this is using the touchscreen to place the marker accurately, be prepared for some frustration.Sunlight screen visibility is a key criteria of any outdoor GPS unit. Unlike a Nuvi where the screen is almost useless in direct sun, the 450's screen visibility is improved by direct sun . . . the brighter the better. While not as bright as the same resolution Colo screen and certainly less snappy than an eTrex, the 450's screen is none the less very readable in the field.My favorite 24K Topo maps are published by Above the Timber and they work faultlessly in the 450. You can read my map comparison in another review.Started doing GeoTagging of photos using BaseCamp, awesome! A icon for each photo appears on the map in BaseCamp, clicking any icon brings up a photo viewer. You can then click through the photos and the map will stay in sync. It gets better, transfer those same photos back to the Oregon 450, and view them in map context inside the Oregon. Kudos Garmin. BTW, you must record a track log while taking your photos.Users can open a file (startup.txt) on the 450 in a text editor (Notepad) and add up to 5 lines x 30 char each to identify ownership. This text will display at startup. In a similar fashion, user backgrounds can be created/saved as JPEGs to display behind most of the data screens. I went with mostly white to enhance overall visibility.I'm getting roughly 10-hours from a pair of Eneloops, below my expectations. The good news, the 450 beeped, it displayed a low battery screen, I stopped, opened the case and inserted my spare AA's. Easy!!! The battery life can be greatly increased (~75%) by having the display time out after 30 sec.A leading reviewer dismissed the accuracy of the altimeter, not my experience. I find I need to calibrate the altimeter at start of a trip/hike, a simple procedure of grabbing the nearest contour value and inputting into the calibrate field. That gives the barometric altimeter a reference. From that point forward the GPS altimeter continually updates the elevation in its auto calibrate mode. I'm rarely off more +/- 20 feet from known elevations, an order of magnitude better than any watch/handheld altimeter.

Pros:- Much less Heal Pain- Cost less the $10- Easy InstallCons:- None YetFor the last year I've been experiencing heal pain after long hikes (greater than 5 miles). I've tried softer socks and a different brand of gel insoles. Better but still some pain the next day. I selected these at a walk up display at a local big box because they were on sale.The night before a long hike I got out my hiking boots and adjusted the insoles and put these on top. Just a little scissor work to shorten for my boots. The next morning I left for what would be an 11-mile hike with 2700-feet of elevation gain and decent. On past hikes a 10-min rest would have my heals so sore I could barely walk, didn't happen. The next morning I had no significant pain when walking.It is my belief that the waffle pattern is as much responsible as is the gel material. What ever the reason, I'll soon be buying another pair for my other hiking boots.

Pros:* Amazing value* Single sheet feeder* Brain dead easy setup* Large finger recesses, bottom center, for lifting the big fella* Sharp text* ToolboxFX Utility* Compact footprint* USB & Ethernet* Nice organic shapeCons:* Dreadful case color choices, gray & black* Small paper tray, ~100 sheets* No custom paper size* Unreadable displayI got this to replace my 15-YO HP LasetJet 4P (Parallel Port) which was still performing like new. The 1518 was a re-certified unit for $125 delivered, amazing value! The 1518 is a little faster than the 4P for the first page, much faster for all subsequent pages. I'd been using a HP PhotoSmart AIO for my color printing, I'll still use it for CD printing. However, text printing on the 1518 is so much crisper that I can't go back. Still adjusting to the color difference, the ToolboxFX utility easily adjusts CMYK colors, but knowing which way to adjust is a work in progress for me. I tried the M -2, Y -1, as one reviewer suggested, it was not an improvement over the default. I ended up at M +1, Y -1 for the maps I print.The high cost per page for toner is a non-issue for me, but the priority single sheet feeder was a must, I print ~100 UPS adhesive labels per year. Having this caliber of printer for $125, more than justifies the high cost toner. HP has to make a profit somehow. Besides, Amazon has good deals on toner.The case colors make the 1518 look like death warmed over compared to the PhotoSmart's mostly beige case with the same gray. My LJ 4P held 1/2 ream of paper, so surprised at such a small tray on the 1518, particularly for a network printer. The good news, the paper tray is a breeze to remove and add paper.In addition to the adhesive UPS labels, I print my bank deposit slips on a 3.5 x 8.5" sheet of paper from an Excel spreadsheet. The 1518 does not have a custom paper size option and because it center feeds odd sizes, I could not just print on the left side of a letter sheet like I did on the LJ 4P. I ended up selecting a #10 envelope and marking the case for the position of the centering wings of the single sheet slot.The 1518 has a small 2-line alphanumeric LCD display that is all but unreadable for me. I have the printer sitting on a small table 6" off the floor slid part way under the modesty panel of my desk. The combination of the display glare and lack of backlight makes the display worthless. I can only read it if I bend over with my head below the desktop, then it always says: Language - English. The good news, trouble messages pop-up on the PC monitor, so not sure that LCD has any value for anything?

Pros:- Made in the USA- They work- Great price- Mix of AA and AAACons:- Took forever- Package split open (in shipment?)These are not Kodak brand batteries, rather the package says Made for Kodak, whatever that means. It'll be months before I know if they're any good. Here's hoping.

Pros:- ATX PSU while still low and narrow- Light weight and still rigid- Possible 3-3.5" HDD's, 4 w/ a 5.25 converter- Subtle power on and HDD lights- 120mm 3-pin fan, very quiet- Desktop drive bay orientation- Removable front logo- No sharp edges, I gave no blood- Low priceCons:- Bigger than my mATX case in all dimensions- The adhesive feet stick to the table better than the caseThe main attraction for me was the ATX PSU mount, most mATX cases fit mATX PSU and they're almost universally dogs, very inefficient. It was cheaper for me to buy this case and use an existing ATX 80+ PSU than to get a 80+ mATX PSU. One reviewer mentioned getting a modular PSU, I'd have to agree, the Antec Earthwatts I used has long cables and they fill the case.Bit of chicken and egg mounting the PSU and connecting the cables, the PSU wires quickly obscure the front panel connectors on the MB, but you have to have the front off to mount the PSU.The FDD clips barely connected to my short card reader, so I drilled out the clip and used a screw to attach each clip to the reader.I mounted a 3.5 to 2.5 HDD adapter into the front cable port, the ribbon cables had no problem fitting through the gaps but it blocked the power cable, so I rerouted the power cable, see photo. Perfect screw alignment for a 3.5" HDD if you're inclined.The adhesive feet are very grippy opposite the adhesive, so much so that as I slid the case under the coffee table, all four feet pulled loose from the case. I had to lift and drop to position the case.

Pros:Feels comfortable to hold/useAggressive teethCons:Aggressive teethWorthless folded paper scabbardSo far I've only cut some dry wood with the saw and the aggressive teeth are hard to start and it jumps all over. I suspect a 4" green limb will be just the opposite. Also the thin blade flexes a bit too easy on the push stroke, partly because the teeth bite so hard. Again, me thinks all it faults will disappear on a green limb.Sure wish it had an included plastic scabbard to protect me from those aggressive teeth.

Pros:Thinner better plastic "box"Cons:NoneThe plastic box is the main reason I buy bulk microSD cards. Retail packaging has gone to blister packs, which are throw aways. I need a professional package for my uses.Previously the plastic box was a modified Compact Flash box with molded risers for the adapter and microSD. This new box is a little smaller and much thinner due to a SD card being thinner than CF. It's easier to open, is clearer and is just better.Thank you Digital Media Source.

Pros:Full length, full height PCI slotsBoth the ODD and card reader/floppy hide behind cosmetic doors, this may be a con?Ample length for all the front panel wires, will reach any MBHuge collection of extra screws and misc hardware, including rubber feetFront is attached via 4 friction pins and is easily removedTwo removable 3.5" HDD TraysThe ODD/Floppy bay is easily removed from the case, I used Position 3 for the ODD and 2 for the card readerCons:Terrible PSU efficiency, 9W just to run itselfThe 10" power on light bar is a bit much, however easy to disconnectThe power switch has no click to it, only the power bar light to confirm pressNo SATA power connectors, only MolexThe extra MB standoffs used a different screw than the attached standoffs, duh?Poor cooling options for a high power rig, 2-60mm included, room for 1-80mm fan, however  the 80mm location has almost no external vent holes.Comments:I selected this case to go on the bottom shelf of a coffee table. Not many cases in this class accept full height PCI cards. Because I'm doing a low power Clarkdale build, the lack of cooling was not a problem for me. I gave blood once while checking out the 80mm fan housing, so not totally free of sharp edges.The Athenatech website has some excellent product photos to help understand all the features. While the product photo shows this case on end, I'm at a loss how you could use a tray load ODD in that position.  Theirs a weird spring loaded "door" on the left side of the front, not clear its exact purpose? I mounted a 3.5 to 2 X 2.5-Inch Bay Converter into one of the HDD trays so I could use a notebook HDD.I'd paid $20 more for this case if it would of included a 200W, 80+ PSU. I hooked up a 380W 80+ Earth Watts PSU as an experiment. It drew 33W at idle whereas the included 200W PSU needed 45W, I was flabbergasted.This is a slick versatile case if the cons don't matter to you.

Pros:No Salt or Oil, just PopcornNo BPA? Teflon? ?? lined microwave bagsA fraction of the unpopped kernels verses microwave popcornAmazingly inexpensive applianceOne-tenth the cost of microwave popcorn per servingServing size controlChild's play to use, but it does get HOT!!!Cons:No switch, have to plug it in and pull the plug for offThe exploded husks tend to litter the counterNo bowl or box for the popped cornBig dude taking up counter space.Seems to take longer that a microwave bag, but I haven't timed itNot quite as convenient as a microwave bagComments:Prior to the Poplite, the only salt-free and "butter"-free microwave popcorn I could find was Newman's at $3+ for a box of three. For half that I purchased a 2-pound bag of bulk popcorn which pops lighter and larger. Finding a plastic container that was the equivalent of a microwave bag was a bit of a challenge. I settled on a 1-gallon Sterilite pitcher (73149-04900), it's a flattened oval and fits the mouth of the Poplite near perfectly. I'd guess it to be twice the volume of a microwave bag, you'll need the space.

This is a great case not only for the chainsaw, but lots of extras. I have a Husqvarna 455 Rancher with a 20" bar. In addition to the saw, it can easily store a combo face shield and ear muffs, plus chain file and bar wrench, roll of paper towels and more. Their are molded recesses for holding many of the tools, even a spark plug holder.The bar shield is molded such that it locks to the side with a tongue and groove and when the drop down front cover is closed, it pinches the shield firmly in place. The drop down front has a locking groove it snaps into when closed. Very clever design.I particularly like the square shape vs. the form fitted cases. It fits perfectly behind the left wheel well of my S10 long bed, with the bar next to the wheel. When I'm done cutting I'll box up the saw and place the box behind the wheel well. The loaded wood them keeps everything snug. The case is strong enough to have loaded wood on top and pressing the sides.The only minor quibble I have is with the Velcro saw retainer strap, bit of a hassle to strap and unstrap. However, I've not figured out a better way. This case not only protects your chainsaw, it also protects you from the sharp chain and dusty chainsaw. Well worth the money.

Pros:Very close and comfortable shaveExcellent sideburn trimmerGood battery lifeCharge completed flashing LED'sPrice is right if . . .Cons:No battery status indication, none expectedTacky colorsI've been shaving for over forty years, mostly electric and mostly Norelco. For 3-months I had a Remington R450, see my review, huge dissapointment. Every couple of years Norelco tries to come up with a new gimmick to get us to purchase the latest and greatest. Thing is that Norelco got it right 30-years ago. The cutters and combs in the 7310 are the essence of that technology and if you can spin the cutters you'll have a close shave. All the other Whistles & Bells are just fluff.Norelco claims 10 days of cordless shaving on a 8-hour charge. The charge full indicator started flashing at 2-hours, done. I went 9-days and wondered how much longer, on the tenth day the motor started slowing down and it quit halfway through the eleventh day. By stretching the battery after the first charge/discharge I was able to get 12-days, well actually 11.9-days, could have used another minute of shaving. I stretch a NiCd by running the battery dead with the cutters flipped open for the lowest motor load. Pretty impressive for a single AA NiCd battery.People claim this is a good/great budget shaver. Nonsense, this is a excellent cordless shaver that can be had at a budget price. I got mine from the big W for thirty-one to my PO Box. It came in the full retail blister pack. By the time I got it to my house, 8500-feet, I thought it was going to explode. I saw at least two retailers have it for a bit less on Black Friday. Makes you wonder what the models that cost 4-5 times as much have to offer?So why is it ugly? Well of course beauty is in the eye of the beholder and this old eye doesn't do black and white on a shaver, all black . . sure, all white . . probably not, all silver like my deceased 7865XL's . . YES!!! I still gave the 7310 5-stars, I don't see the colors while shaving. BTW, I do like the white power switch.If you look at the photos I posted, you'll see that the 7310 consists of a small waterproof power module encased in four cosmetic shells. It's these shells that allow Norelco to play the silly color games at no additional cost. The sides even have rubber bonded to the shell. Turns out I shave with my thumb between the power switch and head and my fingers over the trimmer, so I don't even feel the "slip proof" rubber. Where are your fingers?So if the feature set meets your needs, don't hesitate to get the 7310, it will deliver a comfortable close shave. As to the colors, only you can decide.

Pros:Toss the drill and keep the caseVariable speed, reversing, cordlessAmazing variety of bits and drillsBoth Pozi and Phillips bits in two lengthsBroad selection of Torx bitsIncluded masonry drillsCase to hold everything in logical orderCase is light gray, not blackSingle #2 Phillips & Flat bit snaps to the drill bodyCons:Gutless, Not enough torque to bury a single #9 x 3" Deck ScrewTools are brittle or weakCase won't close properly, battery too wideNo hex or square drive bits1/4" Drive Hex sockets won't fully seat onto drive adapterMissing one Torx (T20) bit, extra T151/8" shank grinding bits seem misplaced on a 550 RPM tool, they need to spin at 20,000 RPMAll the small bits randomly inserted into the case, when I arranged them I found the missing T20Removing and inserting the bits from the case requires a tool, none providedI got this drill set from a local retailer on Black Friday for thirty, so hard to go wrong. I was expecting high torque from a 19.2V drill, not to be. I tried driving some 1/4" X 6" lag bolts into pine and they barely moved. In fairness, my 30-YO B&D corded 3/8" VSR Drill was none to thrilled with the lag bolts either, but it did drive them all the way. The All Power did drill many holes in the same pine with a 7/8" spade bit.All the Torx bits are a huge bonus for me inasmuch as large deck screws are now Torx drive. I'd much rather drive a screw than pound a nail for most any project.The is in no way a professional tool nor was I expecting great things. I'll use it once a month and be happy that it's all in one case. I dinged the rating one star because of the cons, none major but in total one star.Edit Nov, 2013, after using a number of the tools, they are weak or brittle. Example: the included phillips/flat bit snapped off after a few uses. The second long #2 phillips got through 10 screws before the flutes rounded and it was useless. Almost no torque, I couldn't bury a single The Hillman Group 47850 Star Drive 1000 Hour Deck Screw, 9 x 3-Inch in a soft pine 2x4. I have a 15-YO 12V drill that had no problems driving multiple of the same screw. Both had freshly charged batteries.

Pros:PriceClose shaveNose hair trimmerCons:High pitched whineUnder-poweredTwin button head releaseCrappy On/Off buttonNo charge indicatorLow Run TimeMarginal Sideburn TrimmerI've been a Norelco user most of the last forty years, I've watched as they progressed from solid functional razors to expensive gimmicky razors. Those expensive gimmicks caused me to try this Remington knockoff of a basic Norelco design. The R450 was cheaper than a set of new Norelco replacement cutters.Two things struck me about the R450 from the get-go,1) the sharp whine of the motor vs the purr of a Norelco and2) the motor was under-powered, it would noticeably slow when all three cutters were engaged on the side of my face. Then I came home from a backpack with a 3-day growth and the motor literally stopped while shaving under my chin, ouch! Never had a Norelco stop if it were charged.The 2-button release latch is another pain, theirs no spring to pop open the head and pushing both buttons and hooking a fingernail under the head all at the same time is difficult at best. A Norelco uses a single button opposite the hinge and it has a spring, simplicity!!!The on/off button is surprisingly difficult to find/press lacking just the most basic raised area to locate, you have to visually find the spot and press. A charge remaining indicator is a nice basic shaver feature, not on the R450.After ~16 hours of charging I got 8-days of shaves before it pooped out, significantly below my expectations and their claims. The sideburn trimmer was marginal, seeming to jam when I tried to define a straight bottom.The single AA powered nose hair trimmer was an unexpected bonus, seems to work too.After using this product for 3-months I came to dread my morning shave and ordered a Norelco 7310, only 20% more expensive but an order-of-magnitude better shaver. The slowness, motor stalls and the feel of the combs against my face all contributed to my dread. Yes the R450 is capable of giving a close shave, but getting there was not pleasant for me.

Pros:Route-able Roads and Trails24K Topo DetailCons:Dark Colors and Poor ContrastMissing TrailsTrails aren't namedNo BLM or State LandsMy comments are limited to Colorado and I'm comparing the Garmin maps to another 24K topo set by Above the Timber. On a recent 3-day backpack I used the Above the Timber maps 95% of the time, Garmin 5%, readability was the key. The good news, both map sets reside inside my Garmin GPS and switching is a breeze.In my opinion a 24K Topo is a back country map used for foot, horse or other slow travel. This map set combines the excellent route-able Navteq highways and also route-able trails, that's slick. However due to an overly dark set of color choices, it's very difficult to see the trails to make an intelligent trip and/or route selection. Having the routing engine choose your route based on time or distance misses the human dynamic of most scenic. Not seen a routing engine that knows my scenic values . . . it'll happen someday.The Garmin maps do not show BLM or state lands, a very big deal in Colorado. Also the trails lack either names and/or numbers, kind of like having a highway map w/o names or numbers, huh? Names and/or numbers give you valuable clues as to where you're going, which you verify with occasional sign posts.To understand my colors and contrast comment, you'll have to view the attached Nuvi screenshots. They're fuzzy, the Amazon import did that and I'm not sure why.

Pros:Incredibly handy hydrationHigh quality materials and workmanshipCons:Mild chemical (plastic) tasteFabric cover attached to bladder not removableNo bite valve coverI got one of these to put in my older backpack which didn't have a hydration pocket. I put it closest to my back and I opened a seam to get the hose to the front. Unless your going to attach this outside the pack, all the fabric and buckles are unnecessary added weight.I have two Camelbak bladders, both have a mild chemical taste which I'd as soon live without. I emailed Camelbak, they replied in an hour (Wow) with a canned cleaning message, but the taste was day one to two years later. Turns out a teaspoon of lemon juice will kill the plastic taste w/o adding a lemon taste.I consider this to be very well made, but I wish Camelbak had included the bite valve cover as a standard feature. Otherwise, the valve drags in the dirt each time I take my pack off.Can't imagine using a water bottle ever again.

Complimentary copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.Kennedy has suffered a lifetime of abuse, either at the hands of her biological parents or her husband; she’s finally had enough. When she runs into Corbin, an MMA fighter she had a crush on in high school, she begins to realize that she is stronger than she ever gave herself credit for. With the help of Corbin and her “adoptive parents” (her best friend’s parents whom took her in, saving her from further abuse), she finally leaves the man that has made her and her young daughter’s lives hell. But as she gets closer and closer to Corbin, she has to come to terms with her past, to find herself before she’s able to give herself to someone yet again.Corbin has his own issues. Dealing with the death of childhood friend in his formative years has left him with a sense of guilt he’s carried into adulthood. For years he has medicated himself with meaningless flings, so when Kennedy, the girl he secretly harbored a crush on in high school comes back into his life, he realizes he needs to tackle his own demons before he can give himself to someone else.As you might expect with two broken characters, their relationship is a bit of a rollercoaster. Add into it the complication of Kennedy’s daughter and the obvious love Corbin has for the both of them, they need to tread lightly, to make sure that there are no expectations of a happily ever after until they know they dedicate themselves fully.The absolute highlight of the book was Kennedy’s daughter Ashlynn. The interaction between her and Corbin was downright heartwarming, making it easy to root for the young family in the making. The relationship between Kennedy and Corbin was sweet with a side of steamy, a coupling fans of contemporary romance will easily embrace. The first person, dual POV gives readers a chance to see inside the thoughts and fears of each of the characters.While the book started out strong, by about the halfway point it started to fall. Unfortunately the author attempted to incorporate too many dramatic elements that were not resolved in any sort of meaningful way. Abuse, both spousal and parental, MMA fighter hero, second chance love, reunion with an estranged parent, allegations of cheating were all represented, but not with any significant depth to really make an impact on the story as a whole. The heroine’s ex-husband just kind of gives up and disappears, as does her abusive father. Perhaps if the author had explored just one or two of those tropes in depth, the book would have felt more cohesive than it did.In the acknowledgements section of the book there is a reference to both an editor and a proofreader, however I’m not sure if the arc I received had been seen by either of them, as there were numerous errors and plot holes. As a first time author Taylor holds a lot of promise, and I hope that my comments are accepted as constructive criticism, but the way that the book in its current incarnation is tough read.

Complimentary copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.Adam has reached a level of desperation for money that he has decided to audition as a fitness model, a job that sometimes requires him to expose a little more of himself than he’s comfortable with. Originally from Nebraska, he is in L.A. with his mom and aunt as his mom fights her battle against cancer, which has depleted the family’s funds completely. In danger of losing her place in the treatment facility of their choice, Adam has decided he’ll do whatever it takes in order to keep her there in order to reclaim her health. But when Adam shows up on set, looking out of place and easily intimidated by the agency’s panel, he has to prove that he’s right for the job. After convincing them he’s the right choice, his career takes off, but not without the help of Solo, the photographer’s assistant and all-around badass.Solo, the product of two gay dads with a Han Solo obsession, has worked for Teeg models since the age of eighteen, assisting with shoots, wardrobe and marketing. She lives on the same grounds as the models, however not in the same house, leading to a close-knit relationship with all of the guys. After a failed relationship with a model, she has sworn them all off, not wanting to get burned again once they hit it big. But when geeky Adam signs with the agency, she falls and falls hard. Their mutual love of Star Wars and all things geek quickly proves that they just may have been made for one another, but Solo’s lack of faith coupled with the walls she’s constructed around her heart may be the undoing of their relationship before they even have a chance.“How long is your penis?”Was she for real? When did how long is your penis and how many times do you work out become casual questions in a job interview?“I-I’m not sure,” I answered honestly. “I never measured him before.”“A smile spread across her face. “Ahh, you call your penis a him.”“Well, he’s not a girl, if that’s what you’re implying.”“Does he have a name?”The minions all looked up and waited on the edge of their seats for my answer. Did I want this job that bad that I should continue to answer these questions?Yeah, I needed money…badly, so I swallowed my pride and mumbled out his name so it was barely audible to my own ears.“I’m sorry, I didn’t hear that, what’s his name?”My hands ran down my face and I said, “Just-In Beaver.”The room rang silent.Adam’s naiveté makes for some spectacularly hilarious moments, but also makes him completely loveable. He’s the kind of guy that finds a girl in Wonder Woman Underoos just as hot as the girl in the skimpiest of lingerie. And Solo, it’s so nice to encounter a character that isn’t ditzy, isn’t caught up in the fact that she’s constantly surrounded by scantily clad men, and can hold her own around the guys. She’s the antithesis of her best friend and co-worker Nolly, who regularly hooks up with the models and gives them the reigns in the relationship.“Is that some kind of reference to a woman’s lady garden?” Thaddeus asked, as he tried to understand the reference. “I believe that call it a muff? Am I right Bashty?”“Oh my God.” Solo said into her hands, after she set her doughnut down. “Dad, please don’t say muff.""I think a muff is referring to a lady garden that hasn’t been properly landscaped,” Sebastian offered.“Oh, dear,” Thaddeus said, looking over at Solo. “Honey, please don’t tell me you have a muff.”One of the biggest highlights of the book is the relationship between Solo and her dads. They are over the top hilarious, yet the love they have for their daughter is obvious. Quinn has created characters that are easy to fall in love with, and you just can’t help to root for underdog Solo in the vapid world that can be modeling.“Don’t worry, honey, we’re not old biddies; we know you have youngins have overactive libidos,” my mom assured.Nodding her head, Solo looked at me and said, “Well did he at least tell you that when he jumped off the bed in shock from seeing my dads barge in, instead of shaking hands, he curtsied as if the Queen of England was standing in front of him, and when he got up, he cut wind louder than a freaking blow horn?”If Adam weren’t hot enough simply because of the way he interacts with Solo, then his relationship with his mom and aunt will make you fall in love. He’s the All-American boy next door, and the lengths that he’ll go to for him family feel genuine and downright swoonworthy.Quinn has crafted a laugh out loud story with heart, something we’ve come to expect from her. The book is written in a first person, dual POV, giving the reader great insight into the thoughts and motivations of each of the characters. It is well written, if not a little a little predictable, but all of the hilarious elements that make Solo’s life in particular completely overshadow that. The relationship between Solo and Adam is equal parts sweet and sizzling, and you’ll be sucked in from the very first page. If you need a quick pick me up, something to put a smile on your face that will last for a long while, check this one out. You’ll be happy you did.

Complimentary copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.Callie and Madison are best friends yet their marriages couldn’t be different from each other if they tried. Callie is married to her soul mate whereas Madison is married to her baby’s daddy, staying in a loveless marriage for the sake of their child. So when events begin to unravel leading to the demise of Madison’s marriage, Callie must not only help Madison get through the emotional upheaval, but reevaluate her own marriage, especially when some of her own husband’s actions become questionable.The story is told in both the past and the present and for the most part it is effective. It helps to get inside the head of the characters and see how those experiences shaped them. There were some twists that I didn’t see coming that I appreciated, but I did have some trouble connecting with the characters on any kind of meaningful level. I couldn’t help but feel that both of the women were a little on the doormat side and the relationship between Callie and her husband didn’t feel as strong as the author would make you believe it was.The basis for a great story is there, no doubt about it; but in it’s current state it is in dire need of an editor. There are numerous plot holes and inconsistencies, awkward word choices, changes of tense within the same paragraph, all things that detract from the story itself.  The storyline itself is intriguing and original, but as it stands now, it falls a bit flat in the grand scheme of things.

Complimentary copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.The One Addicted, the second book in The One Trilogy, picks up immediately where the first book leaves off. Lucia and Sebastian are on the outs after a woman claiming to be Sebastian’s girlfriend shows up, however it soon becomes apparent that there is more to the story than at first glance. Seems Toni is up to her old tricks in an attempt to break up the couple. But the pair prove that years of friendship and their budding romance mean far more to them than anything their past can throw at them and proceed to grow closer and closer.Much of the book is spent exploring Lucia and Sebastian’s relationship, both emotionally and physically. There is a bit more angst than in the first book with a lot of time back and forth wondering how they fit into each other’s lives and making assumptions of how committed they are to each other, assuming the other is on board for just the “friends with benefits” relationship they had agreed to. Once they finally get their feelings out of the way, they can pursue the type of relationship they had always hoped to.This volume though really starts to become intriguing in regards to the stranger that is stalking Lucia, and just how bold he is becoming. She is starting to pick up on clues that the stranger is leaving behind; as he gets bolder, he is getting sloppier. The book was already a great blend of sexy and hope for a lasting relationship, the added suspense makes it one that will keep you on the edge of your seat.Friends-to-lovers is one of my favorite tropes and I am very excited to see how it ends for Lucia and Sebastian (and Finn, I LOVE the dynamic of the three of them together). Due to the angst and waffling of the main characters (ugh! Just communicate already!) this one wasn’t quite up to par with the first, but I have no doubt that North plans for this series to go out with a bang!This book is NOT a standalone. You will need to have read book one, The One Awakened before starting this one. Trust me, you’ll want to anyway, Sebastian Silver is all sorts of worth it!

Complimentary copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.I’m still not sure I forgive Fallowfield for her last installment of The Domville, a story that felt like it left me gutted and gasping for air, but in this volume, she certainly made up for it. The events of this volume coincide with the events of the last volume, and while each of the books can be read independently, I HIGHLY suggest reading volume two before reading this one for full effect.Mandy is gearing up to be maid of honor at her older sister Lisa’s wedding. The night before the wedding the two are sharing an exclusive signature suite, where everything they could ever want or need is provided for them. After parting ways in the hotel’s lounge, Mandy heads off for a quickie with the bar’s piano man. But throughout their hot, quick encounter in the hotel’s pool, she can’t get thoughts of “Rampant” Roger out of her head, the manwhore of a best friend to Lisa’s fiancé, Brady.Mandy and Roger had hooked up previously at a wedding rehearsal and neither can get the other out of their mind. That’s not to say they haven’t tried, hooking up with others any chance they get (not unusual for either of them). But for some reason, their encounter just felt “different”. They antagonize each other, via witty banter, creating a sexual tension that is palpable. But can two people that make no assertions of being relationship material even think about having a relationship…together?Unlike the Shakespearian tragedy vibe of the last installment, Mandy and Roger’s story is one of hope. Don’t get me wrong, it is HOT as hell, but while Lisa and Brady’s story was about a relationship in crisis, Mandy and Roger’s story is about possibility. We also get a little more of a glimpse into Lisa and Brady’s story as well, which I appreciated, considering how I felt at the end of their story! Again Fallowfield has crafted another thoroughly engaging story with characters that are easy to care about.Again, this is a series of standalones, but I implore you to at least read the second volume before this one! You won’t be sorry!

Becs has spent the major part of her life in the foster care system and at the age of eighteen is working a job and trying to better herself. If her constant worries about money weren’t bad enough, she feels obligated to look after her older foster brother that is heavily involved in drugs. When she loses her job for reasons she’s not entirely clear, she takes her complain to Bray Spencer, the owner of the building that houses the coffee shop she worked for.Bray Spencer is a billionaire recluse that refuses to get involved with the opposite sex due to the unhealthy relationship of his parents. But over the course of a couple of months he becomes enamored with Becs, the colorful pixie, as he calls her. When she storms into his office demanding answers about her job, Bray finally has the opportunity to insert himself into her life.Bray takes her on his live in housekeeper/cook/assistant and eventually his lover. As their relationship gets out, it seems there are forces working from all sides in order to break them up. Will Bray end up just like his father and destroy the one thing he loves most? Will Becs ever be able to trust anyone? Or feel like she won’t be left behind, yet again?Maybe it’s my age, maybe it’s the volume of books I read but I’m finding it harder and harder to suspend disbelief. In the Romance genre there definitely needs to be some bending of timelines, belief, etc., but this book was way over the top. The man is in his mid-30s and is a virgin, who quickly becomes a sex god. He’s obsessed with an eighteen year old in a way that makes Christian Grey look like the best boyfriend in the world (like desperately wanting her to get pregnant so she can’t leave). He’s an investor that has paparazzi stalking him. There is just so much going on in the story without any real storyline, other than once they get it on, they do it a lot.I had picked this one up because the synopsis looked good and there was a lot of chatter about it in the book world, but it just didn’t do it for me. I didn’t connect with the characters and the storyline was kind of all over. This was my first book by this author but I would still check out some of her other work. If you’re looking for a hot, fast paced read, this one might be for you.

Complimentary copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review.When Lex Easton’s new line is, well…on the line, she must travel to Italy in order to meet with the Prince Massimo Tittoni, the owner of the Girasoli Garment Company, who is holding the fabrics for her new line hostage, due to non-payment. Easton Essentials, the company Lex built from the ground up, is teetering on the edge of failure and without the superior Girasoli fabrics to create her signature line, she will find herself flat broke with nothing to show for it for the second time in her life. Her goal is to convince the playboy prince to release her fabrics, but when Massimo propositions her, will Lex do what it takes in order to save not only her company but her employees as well?Massimo is fodder for the tabloids and when Lex first makes his acquaintance it’s obvious his reputation is well earned. But could there be more to the prince than she originally though? What are Massimo’s reasons for shielding his heart? More importantly, is his proposal to Lex more personal or business? Can the two work together?Things move lightning fast between the two and as you might expect, the tabloids find some major dirt in order to smear not only the relationship between Lex and Massimo, but also Lex the rising star in the fashion world. Just how far out of each of their comfort zones are they willing to come in order to make it work. Told in the third person with I guess, for lack of a better way to describe it, first person interjections throughout, you get a look into the minds of each of the characters.Aster has certainly created an animated cast of characters and has set them up nicely for subsequent books in the series. It is obvious that there is a great deal of affection between them given their history and it made their interactions feel genuine. One of the things that really started to grate on me though as the book progressed was the constant name-dropping. I understand that it is a book about fashion, but at some point it becomes tedious knowing that everything a certain character is wearing is of a certain label, vintage, or price.The book was fun and definitely hot and would make great reading for the beach or poolside, but it just seems that there were so many opportunities wasted to give it a little more substance. Lex’s troubled relationship with her parents is the catalyst in decisions she’s made and the way she chooses to live her life both publicly and privately, yet Aster does very little to touch on Lex’s history. Yes, there is a prequel series that was released after the fact, yet I’m still not sure how it would give any more insight into WHO Lex really is.The lack of depth, coupled with the over the top sex scenes and insta-love (marriage proposals within days) made this one a challenge for me and I’m not sure how invested I am in the characters or storyline. That’s not to say that there aren’t plenty out there that will enjoy the series immensely, I just don’t think this is the one for me.

Complimentary copy provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.Titus has been an integral part of the Welcome To the Point saga thus far. As the half-brother to Bax and cop that often has to deal with the gray area between right and wrong for the sake of the greater good, we’ve gotten to know the man that he is. Only this time, we get a more in depth look into why he makes the choices he does. Loyal to a fault, Titus needs to decide where his priorities lie, especially when it comes to matters of the heart.Reeve is the dark haired beauty that is persona non grata in The Point after not only setting up the abduction of Dovie, but then going into WITSEC in order to testify against crime boss Novak’s crew. When the Marshall tasked to protect her turns out to be a bad cop obsessed with her, Reeve risks it all by heading back to The Point with evidence in hand, looking for one man and one man only…Titus King.Even when the two were adversaries before she disappeared into WITSEC, there was no denying the attraction between the two, so when she turns up at the police station, desperate and afraid for her life, Titus’s protective instincts take over, fanning the flames of the attraction once again. What results is a tale of steamy suspense that will keep you on the edge of your seat.Following the fall of Novak’s empire, there has been an increase in crime as new organizations look to take a foothold in The Point. But things aren’t quite as they seem with the new bad guy in town. Turns out there is a whole lot more history there than either Titus or Bax know about and neither them, nor anyone they love, is safe until the threat is neutralized. But just how many more people will die in the meantime?As Titus and Reeve face down their adversaries, they get closer; they find that they are able to provide each other with what they’re missing. Titus is the man who takes care of everyone, yet doesn’t have anyone to take care of him. Reeve is the girl who is good at her core, yet has had to make hard choices in order to survive. Together they are a perfect storm, but only time will tell if they’ll both make it out alive.I love this series. It’s the right amount of steamy that is chock full of action and drama that keeps the story moving quickly and keeps you riveted. Titus is probably one of my favorite characters and I loved getting further into his head. The storyline in this volume also sets up the scene perfectly for the next installment as well where we get Nassir’s story.My only complaint with the book is the ending. For the amount of drama and the depth of the relationship forged between Titus and Reeve I would have expected an ending that felt more “complete”, for lack of a better word. It felt a little rushed and I would have liked to see a little bit more resolution, especially when it came to Reeve’s relationships with those that she had previously wronged, but hopefully we won’t see the last of her as the story continues. That’s why this one isn’t quite a five star, but it’s pretty damned close.In order to fully appreciate the series you definitely need to start with the first book. You won’t be sorry. If you’re a fan of sizzling suspense, this is the series for you!
