Smith and George Beccaloni, Oxford University Press, 2008, 510 ffAn in-depth look at the oft-neglected discoverer of evolutionWhen we talk about evolution, we usually think in terms of the work of Charles Darwin. But there was another scientist thinking along the same lines at the same time as Darwin and that was the Welsh-born biologist Alfred Russel Wallace. Furthermore, Darwin and Wallace were not even the first to address the problem as, half a century earlier, Charles’ grandfather Erasmus Darwin and the French biologist Jean Baptiste Lamarck produced their own theories of how life on Earth developed.This volume has contributions from twenty-three specialists in their fields, as well as the two editors, to recount the work of Wallace, not only as a biologist but also as a passionate socialist and investigator of spiritualism. As historian of science Peter Bowler comments in his Foreword, Wallace not only made major contributions to evolutionary biology but also, in both his biology and spiritualism, showed his opposition to the materialism of mainstream Victorian culture.Although Darwin trained to be a priest in the Anglican Church, his approach to evolution was essentially materialistic with no mention of any possible divine intervention in the process. Wallace on the other hand did not exclude the possibility of some non-material agency in shaping the course of evolution.In this book, Normal Johnson tells us something about Wallace’s concept of reinforcement as he saw it operating in the natural world. Tim Caro and colleagues writes on the colours of animals. Bernard Michaux gives a good account of Wallace’s biogeographical studies in the Far East that produced what came to be called the Wallace Line in Indonesia. And some of what are now regarded as misdirections in Wallace’s work are also covered – like his campaign against vaccination (by Martin Fichman), and his equivocal view of Francis Galton’s advocacy of eugenics.There is not a lot written here on Wallace’s interest in spiritualism – of importance to the man himself in his lifetime and in the early years of the 20th century but probably of much less significance in comparison with his evolutionary studies and conclusions. Overall, this is a book for the reader who wants to have a serious grounding in what the life and work of this great man was all about. The book ends with a 40-page list of References and a useful Index.Howard Jones is the author of Evolution of Consciousness

Alfred Russel Wallace: a rediscovered life by Michael A. Flannery, Discovery Institute Press, Seattle, Washington, 2011, 166 ff.Michael Flannery is Professor and Associate Director for Historical Collections at the Lister Hill Library of the Health Sciences, University of Alabama, Birmingham, Alabama in the U.S.A. He has written here a most readable and accessible introduction to the life and work of a great naturalist , whose work has tended to be overlooked by the general public in favour of Wallace’s contemporary, friend and rival, Charles Darwin. The arguments go on as to whether Darwin or Wallace should be credited with creating the theory of evolution; but the documents of scientific history show us that both men were proposing similar – but far from identical – views about the origin of species at the same time and it seems obvious that each developed ideas from the work of the other.It is often said that Wallace has been relatively neglected in the story of scientific developments because in later years he took an interest in spiritualism, long derided as fantasy and fiction by much of the scientific establishment. But, as Flannery has so eloquently shown, the processes of evolution as described by Darwin and by Wallace differ in a fundamental and significant way. Although Darwin trained to be an Anglican priest in his early years, his description of evolution envisages a thoroughgoing materialism in the process. Wallace on the other hand adopted a more teleological approach. Darwin had the advantages of a full schooling and study at two eminent universities, Edinburgh and Cambridge, while Wallace had only eight years of formal schooling and was largely self-taught. Darwin’s family were financially secure while Wallace had to be withdrawn from school because of the family’s financial hardship.Flannery sets out the backgrounds of the two men and explains in this short book how their views of evolution differ. Without any religious hyperbole about Wallace’s ideas on ‘intelligent evolution’, Flannery interprets Wallace’s writings in a very measured way and shows their significance for readers interested as much as anything in the human side of the story and without any detail of the biology for non-scientists. He compares Wallace’s approach not only with Darwin’s but also in the context of the current so-called ‘intelligent design’ movement. There are three useful Appendixes of key writings by Wallace, nearly 300 references of sources, and a detailed Index. I would unhesitatingly recommend this book as a balanced view of the work of Alfred Russel Wallace and its interpretation.Howard Jones is the author of The World as Spirit and other books.

Quantum Jumps: an extraordinary science of happiness and prosperity, by Cynthia Sue Larson, 2013, 286 ff.The opening paragraph of Larson’s book presents us with a profound truism – one that an increasing number of people are embracing but also one that so many people either ignore or are too apprehensive to acknowledge: ‘A new Quantum Age is upon us . . . In this new Quantum Age, our experience of reality is transformed when we acknowledge that we are all connected – and that at any given moment, there exists an infinite number of possibilities’. There is in science an idea that there might exist ‘many worlds’ – a whole galaxy of universes. I have long believed that these ‘many worlds’ are virtual, that is, they consist of the realm of all the possibilities of thoughts and actions that humankind had available to them though human history – a kind of cosmic akashic field or, to put it another way, an assemblage in fact of ‘quantum jumps’. This is the author’s message here. At the outset Cynthia, who has a degree in physics from the University of California at Berkeley, describes a similar picture using two of the fundamental principles of quantum physics – potentiality and interconnection. The opening chapters of the book explain in completely non-technical language the relevance and application of these ideas from quantum physics in our everyday lives – we don’t have to be quantum physicists or working in a laboratory to see and feel these ideas in practice. Technical ideas like coherence, tunnelling, entanglement and superposition are all explained with their everyday relevance to us. We can begin to improve our health instantaneously by focussing our minds – what medics describe as the placebo effect. Spiritual healers do not have to be at the bedside of their patients but are able to transmit their beneficent thoughts to their patients remotely – just as the interactions of the subatomic entities of matter are able to transgress the restrictions of space and time. To the creative writer or composer – or scientist or mathematician – the ‘quantum jump’ is that moment of inspiration when the subconscious mind tunes in to the cosmic energy and a great new book, poem, symphony or theory comes into physical existence. After the simplified scientific stuff, the author goes on to suggest ways these ideas can be used to change the present and future of our lives. Larson echoes the importance of the power of intention that several other authors have written about in the last two decades. Each chapter of the book describes a number of exercises that readers can carry out by applying the principles of what has just been described. I have read many technical papers and popular books about quantum physics. Unfortunately, as Larry Dossey has pointed out, the word ‘quantum’ has become hackneyed because in recent years it has been overused by ‘New Age’ gurus who clearly had no real understanding of its significance. But here, we have a book that is precisely about quantum jumps in our everyday lives – but it has taken a physicist to use the term in its entirely proper context. That she is also blessed with a spiritual outlook makes the book doubly valuable.Howard Jones is the author of Evolution of Consciousness, and other books

Seeding of clouds with dry ice or silver iodide has been used for many years to produce rainfall artificially. This sci-fi film is about an experiment to use 2000 drones to create the clouds themselves, seed them with silver iodide and then have the drones recharge themselves automatically by drawing in atmospheric carbon dioxide and freezing it to dry ice. The drones drift in the upper atmosphere to a new location and then start the process all over again. Unfortunately, they are a little too successful and start producing mini ice tornados in one location after another in north-western USA. Frank (Robert Moloney) is the coordinating bureaucrat behind the project and the guy who puts up the money. Once the experiment is underway they find its effects are dramatic and fatal but the scientists in the field are powerless to moderate it. Meanwhile former scientist turned sci-fi author Charlie Price (whose has just had a signing locally for his latest novel) gets drawn in to the impending disaster. It's not a great movie but the special effects are quite good and it's an entertaining enough film using a piece of nearly believable science when actual highly damaging hailstorms with tennis-ball sized hailstones have become a reality of our present-day weather.

Emilie Janzen (Deedee Pfeiffer) is a normal housewife separated from her husband Richard (Matthew Harrison) but living with their two children - Lori (Tegan Moss) and Kevin (Brett Dier). Emilie is normal - but has quite useful psychic flashes periodically. Lori, like any gorgeous, attractive 17-year-old, has boys in school who have crushes on her; Lori's favourite at the moment is Curt (Jared Keeso). When Lori goes to a party at a girlfriend's house and doesn't come home after having had an argument with her mother earlier in the evening, Emilie starts to get worried. She quizzes Curt and his father, but Curt denies knowing anything about what has happened to Lori, though he admits that he and Lori had a fight. Emilie decides to go to the police who, at first, are dismissive, regarding Lori's behaviour as typical teenage rebellion. It emerges that Lori's disappearance is a lot more serious than anyone at first thought and how they manage to track her down makes for an intriguing story.

Passionate abolitionist and philosophy professor David Gale (Kevin Spacey) is on death row in a Texas prison awaiting execution for the rape and murder of a fellow DeathWatch activist, Constance Harraway (Laura Linney). Gale had previously been accused of the rape of a former student, Berlin (Rhona Mitra), although he was subsequently cleared. Gale secures a huge fee from a magazine to give a series of three two-hour interviews on the last three days of his life with one of their successful investigative journalists, Bitsey Bloom (Kate Winslet). The story is therefore told retrospectively and Bloom uncovers increasing amounts of evidence to suggest that Gale is innocent. But there are other individuals involved who support or oppose the death penalty. This is an exciting story directed by Alan Parker and we don't know until the very end whether or not Gale is innocent.

The Sense of Being Stared At, and other aspects of the extended mind, by Rupert Sheldrake, Hutchinson, 2003, 384 ffIn this book, author Rupert Sheldrake makes the case for regarding phenomena such as telepathy and premonition as perfectly normal human faculties rather than paranormal or supernatural events. He suggests that minds - and the human mind especially - may extend far beyond the confines of the brain. Sheldrake was formerly a Professor of Biology at the University of Cambridge and is now a Fellow of the Institute of Noetic Sciences in California.He begins his discussion here by showing how science continually develops with new discoveries and new ideas. He describes what is often called extrasensory perception (ESP) as the seventh sense, maintaining that the ability to detect electromagnetic fields by animals should be called the `sixth sense'. He also regards personal experiences as valid evidence for the existence of these phenomena - after all, readings of ammeters and spectrophotometers have also to be made and recorded by human observations, and the fields of law and medicine rely heavily on personal accounts. Darwin's evidence for the law of evolution came largely from personal anecdotes. Sheldrake has done for `seventh sense' observations what marine biologist Alister Hardy did for spiritual experiences. The mind may be centred in the brain, but it is not confined to it.So much for the Introduction: in the opening chapters of Part I Sheldrake gives many examples of telepathy, often between family members or, he suggests, between those playing team sports. He reviews some of the early work on psychic experiences by scientists in the 19th century. Of course, telepathic interaction with animals is included in this section. Entomologist William Morton Wheeler suggested a similar explanation for communication within communities of social insects, schools of fish or flocks of birds. This is discussed in a later chapter in this section, though Wheeler's name is not mentioned. This phenomenon leads Sheldrake to conclude that `the psyche is not confined to the body during life'.In Part II, The Power of Attention, we begin with a chapter on `The Sense of Being Stared At'. While many of the accounts are anecdotal, there are results given also of statistically significant organized surveys, and a refutation of standard arguments against significance that such `feelings' are examples of paranoia, arise from reasons other than visual focus, such as movement in the subject, or are statistically insignificant in comparison with the number of occasions when no such awareness arises. This kind of sensitivity is clearly important for animals for self-preservation, and for humans in wild territory inhabited by predatory animals, and Sheldrake covers these situations in one of the following chapters, including research by himself and others. As with other forms of telepathy, the results are most convincing when subject and starer have some kind of emotional rapport.An accurate interpretation of the nature of vision has been a challenge to philosophers and physiologists for over 2000 years: Sheldrake reviews the evidence and provides a theory of his own of `the extended mind'. This leads us on to Part III on Remote Viewing and the experiences that some people have of events occurring at a different (past or future) time or in a different place. Part of Sheldrake's evidence for this lies in the senses that many species of animals have of catastrophic natural events, like earthquakes, tsunami or volcanic eruptions, but there are several accounts of human premonitions of disaster too. This leads on to Part IV which explores possible rationally coherent explanations of how the `seventh sense' might work. There are copious Notes, a Bibliography of further reading and a good Index to complete the book.Howard Jones is the author of Evolution of ConsciousnessThe Presence of the Past: Morphic Resonance and the Memory of NatureThe Science Delusion

Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg) is on an illicit mission in Ethiopia with a fellow sniper, but as the US military are not supposed to be there, their military support is withdrawn leaving them to their own devices. Swagger's comrade is killed in action but he escapes - to retire from the U.S. Marines to live in peace in the country. He's then approached by Colonel Isaac Johnson (Danny Glover) to plan an assassination attempt on the president, on the pretext that they want to know how a real assassin would set about it. In reality, Johnson and his corrupt colleagues, under the control of Senator Charles F. Meachum (Ned Beatty), want to assassinate an archbishop from Ethiopia, appearing on the platform with the president, because the archbishop is in America to expose atrocities by the U.S. military in his country.  With an all-too-familiar conspiracy plot, Swagger is made the fall-guy for the archbishop's assassination and is hunted down by Johnson. But an FBI agent, Nick Memphis (Michael Peña) who becomes suspicious of the frame-up joins sides with Swagger and the two of them see that justice prevails. As part of the conspirators plot, they also capture Swagger's girl-friend, Sarah Fenn (Kate Mara), who has also to be rescued by Swagger and Memphis. A really thrilling, action-packed conspiracy movie.

This is a gripping adventure story set in the US Scientific Exploration base in Antarctica. Mayhem breaks out on a Russian cargo plane when one of the crew assassinates all the other passengers and pilots and forces the plane to crash in Antarctica. Fifty years later, a US Geological Survey team stumbles on the wreckage, and pays for their discovery with their lives. Clearly there is a villain in their midst, but who is it? With the cast wearing full snow gear much of the time, it's difficult to sort out the good guys from the evil-doers. Tom Skerritt as the camp doctor, Dr. John Fury, Gabriel Macht as U.N. Investigator Robert Pryce, and Kate Beckinsale as the star heroine, U.S. Marshal Carrie Stetko are all excellent with a quality supporting cast. The filming in Province of Quebec as Antarctica, complete with the Aurora, is quite spectacular. The director was Dominic Sena and the soundtrack arranged by Eugene Raskin and Michael Nazaretz adds to the atmosphere. `Whiteout' refers to an extreme Antarctic storm with high winds and heavy snowfall.

Music & Silence by Rose Tremain, Chatto and Windus, 1999, 462 ffThe story is that of the court of King Christian IV of Denmark in the 17th century. Christian's reign lasted nearly sixty years, from 1588 (when he was only 11, though he was not crowned until he was 19) until his death in 1648. He had his court musicians housed in his cellar so that they were heard but not seen. The structural order of the music provided by his orchestra - and most notably by the handsome lutenist Peter Claire - is a metaphor for the order Christian would like to see in his household and in Danish society in general. The Court as a whole is a picture of the harmony and discord reflected in the music.Another main character in the story is the King's consort Kirsten with her amorous adventures: Kirsten hates music and the pleasure it gives her husband - she would undoubtedly prefer silence. Kirsten is a selfish, malicious and spiteful woman who hates to see others deriving any pleasure from life. The story is peppered with real characters of the time, such as English composer John Dowland who served at the Danish court as composer-lutenist for eight years from 1598; and Tycho Brahe the famous contemporary astronomer who served also as augur, as was customary in those days. These references and other details add to the authentic atmosphere of this story of historical fiction. The first half of the story moves along quite slowly in segments devoted to each of the principal characters but is infused with quite a lot of humour; then the tale gathers momentum and becomes more engrossing. I certainly felt immersed in this aristocratic world of the time and Tremain is an entertaining writer.

Here we have a CD featuring the gloriously pure voice of the Welsh soprano Elin Manahan Thomas, born in the town of Gorseinon, near Swansea in South Wales. There are 16 tracks on the disc of arias from operas, cantatas or oratorios. Some of the melodies are very well-known - like Handel's `Where'er you walk' and `Ombra mai fu' and Purcell's `When I am laid in earth' from `Dido and Aeneas'. Other tracks were new to me when I bought the CD but I have come to know and love them since. All the pieces are from the medieval or Baroque periods - Bach, Handel, Purcell, Dowland, Arne, Vivaldi and reaching back to Hildegard von Bingen. Thomas is known both as a soloist and for her singing as part of The Sixteen, directed by Harry Christophers, who conducts The Orchestra Of The Age of Enlightenment here.

This is the first of 3 CDs released by Naxos in which John Lenehan plays the piano music of John Ireland. They are all attractive and easy-to-listen-to music recorded at St. George's Church, Brandon Hill, Bristol - a location often chosen for recordings because of the warm acoustic. This disc contains the two pieces in the set `In Those Days', the three pieces that comprise `Sarnia' (the Roman name for Guernsey), the less often heard Prelude in E Flat', the four `London Pieces', `Ballade' and `Columbine'. `Merry Andrew' and `The Towing Path' are on Vol.2. `Green Ways', which includes The Cherry Tree, Cypress and The Palm and May are featured on the third CD. Overall this is a very enjoyable three hours of music.

Mort Rainey (Johnny Depp) is an author suffering from writers' block after discovering his wife Amy (Maria Bello) in bed with another man at a motel. He retreats to their cabin in the woods in search of inspiration when a mysterious stranger, John Shooter (John Turturro), turns up and accuses Rainey of plagiarism. Shooter leaves a copy of his short story `Sowing Season' with Rainey who is surprised to find it does indeed strongly resemble a story of his own, `Secret Window'. The title refers to a window in their cabin beneath which his wife was to have planted a flower bed so that she could look out on it. Rainey then finds his dog has been killed (obviously suspecting Shooter) so reports this to the local sheriff, Dave Newsome (Len Cariou), who isn't really interested. So Rainey decides to visit the home he shared with Amy to recover the original MS. Unfortunately, the house is burnt down and Raney's original MS is lost in the flames. Raney suspects that all these incidents have been caused by Amy's new boyfriend, Ted Milner (Timothy Hutton). So he hires an old friend of his, Ken Karsch (Charles S. Dutton) to investigate. When Rainey gets back to the cabin he finds Ken and the only witness that Shooter even exists killed. The story is a bit involved but it's quite a gripping plot, extremely well-acted by Johnny Depp and the rest of the cast, based on a book by Stephen King, and with the movie directed by David Koepp.

Everyone is Right: A new look at comparative religion and its relation to science by Roland Peterson, DeVorss Publications, 1986, 320 ff.The author is an electrical engineer who has served in senior management positions of several American companies. In this book he develops a world-view drawn from studies in physics and psychology on the one hand, and from the insight of esotericism on the other.Part 1, occupying more than one-half of the book, gives us A Comparison of Religious Thinking, which comprises a survey of some of the main features of the religions of East and West. This is an impressive section: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Taoism and Confucianism are all explored. The material is displayed mostly in a two-column comparative format and the whole is interspersed with quotations from the Bible, Koran, Upanishads and the works of many poets. This is one of the most accessible presentations of comparisons of these religions that I have come across and, considering its relative brevity, contains a great deal of readily accessible information. Also in this section there are 20 pages devoted to religious views of reincarnation and immortality.Part 2 of the book deals with Science and Religion and includes a 14-page section on astrology, but it opens with a short chapter on `Differences and their Resolution'. The resolution Peterson proposes is indicated by the title of the book - that all religions of both East and West have a degree of truth within them but that the scriptures have to be interpreted allegorically and not literally if they are to be compatible with current scientific thought. There is a survey of modern physics, discussion of spiritual healing and other psychic phenomena, a dozen pages on psychology, and even a short section on astrology. Overall, I think the way Peterson has blended in the work of Capra with Jung, LeShan with Erich Fromm, and the New Testament with Hindu scriptures is masterly.There is a short Summary constituting Part 3, and a Bibliography to end the book. This is unquestionably one of the best books I have read to really inter-relate science and scripture, so for those interested in this field I would have no problem recommending it.Howard Jones is the author of Evolution of Consciousness

Not as well-known as his Welsh namesake, Dylan, R.S. Thomas wrote wonderful poetry often encapsulating the spirit of his homeland. Born in my home town of Cardiff in Wales, Thomas was known in his lifetime as much as an eloquent and passionate preacher as he was as a poet. Although all these poems are in English, Thomas was a great advocate of all aspects of Welshness, though he did not learn the language until he was an adult. There is no Commentary in this collection on the man or his work, but it provides a comprehensive overview of Thomas' poetry with over four hundred examples, steeped in the Wales he knew all of his life. I cannot compare his poetic style with anyone, for it is unique. This is a collection for those who wish to know something of the atmosphere of life in Wales during the twentieth century.

Considering how much computers are in our lives these days, I have seen relatively few movies about computer programmers. Angela Bennett (Sandra Bullock), who is a systems analyst living in California, is sent a disk with some secret information on that Angela can make nothing of except that it says it's secret. A pi symbol on the corner of the screen of this program lets her access a whole lot of secret files. Her colleague, Dale Hessman (Ray McKinnon), who sent it to her is killed in his light aircraft as he flies down to meet her. Bennett was on the point of going on vacation, so she continues on down to Mexico where she learns of Hessman's death. Meanwhile, she gets picked up on the beach by Jack Devlin (Jeremy Northam) who takes her out on his boat, seduces her and then tries to kill her. One of the first difficulties that Bennett encounters is that she has her identity stolen and a new `Angela Bennett' installed in the firm for which she works. She has to assume a new identity of 'Ruth Marx' even to get back into the U.S. from Mexico. The rest of the film is then about Bennett trying to get her own identity back and get crucial information to the FBI while Devlin tries to stop her. The perpetrator of this scheme is the head of an organization that is supposed to be protecting hacking of secret government files. This is a very exciting, nail-biting thriller

This is another cracking good thriller, directed by Sydney Pollack, from a cracking good book by John Grisham. Mitch McDeere (Tom Cruise) joins a relatively small but quite prestigious law firm in Memphis, headed by Oliver Lambert (Hal Holbrook) even though he hasn't yet passed his final bar exam. The firm offer him very attractive terms and make it clear that they want him a part of the team. He and his wife Abby (Jeanne Tripplehorn) settle in and McDeere makes a good impression on his mentor in the firm, Avery Tolar (Gene Hackman). Eight weeks into his time with the firm, McDeere learns that two associates of the firm have been killed in a boating accident. Then a couple of guys from the FBI start taking an interest in him and McDeere learns that two others met with a similar fate a few years ago. This creates disquiet for the McDeeres. The FBI then make McDeere an offer that leaves him between a rock and a hard place. They want him to be a mole and report what goes on in the office, but if he decides to work with the FBI, his career is finished and he will have to relocate under the witness protection program. If Mitch doesn't cooperate with the FBI, then when they take down the firm, he will be indicted and serve a long prison sentence.McDeere decides to hire a P.I. Eddie Lomax (Gary Busey) to investigate the deaths of the associates, but before he can even get started, he is killed - which deepens McDeere's fears about the firm. McDeere's brother Ray (David Strathairn) is in jail but coming up for a parole hearing. So Mitch makes a deal with the FBI to get Ray out of jail in return for the incriminating files. From then on it's a race against time for Mitch to get hold of the files and Ray to get away before the firm's hoodlums catch up with him.  An excellent, tense and exciting story.

Of the 20th century Romantic piano concertos, that by John Ireland, composed in 1930 is not often heard in public performance or on record. This is a pity because it is a fine work with a unique beauty of sound in its melodies and harmonies. The concerto was written for the young pianist Helen Perkin, who gave the first performance, also in 1930. If there are any parallels to be made in the sound world of the work it would surely be with the G Major Piano Concerto of Ravel. The soloist is a pianist well-known for his association with the piano works of English composers - Eric Parkin.The concerto takes up nearly half the playing time of this Chandos CD and the other half is divided between two orchestral tone poems by Ireland: Legend for Piano and Orchestra and the Symphonic Rhapsody, Mai-Dun. In 1906 Ireland had met the Welsh writer Arthur Machen and this meeting inspired Ireland to explore the scenery and literature of Wales. The Legend is dedicated to Machen, though its composition was inspired by the scenery of the Sussex Downs, where Ireland lived for some time, and in part by Machen's short story, `The Happy Children'. The title Mai-Dun is taken from Thomas Hardy for a medieval hill-fort near Dorchester that Hardy described in `The Mayor of Casterbridge'. The atmospheric orchestral playing on this CD is provided by the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Bryden Thomson.

With all the glossy, bloody war films in full Technicolor, made in the past couple of decades, it's good to be able to see again some of the gritty black-and-white war films. As with many Hitchcock thrillers, war films in b/w seem to have that extra realism. This is one of several that John Wayne starred in and there are plenty of authentic looking battle action scenes mixed with a dash of personal psychology and love interest. This movie, made in 1949, directed by Allan Dwan is set in the Pacific theatre. If you are a fan of war films, this is a good one to watch.

Eve Pretson (Emmanuelle Vaugier) is a TV reporter from KQAP who seeks out eccentrics to make fun of them on her show for `entertainment'. She goes out with her cameraman to interview retired MIT research scientist, Ned Larfield (Michel Perron), who has invented a new kind of solar-powered automobile. He doesn't know that the patent officer handling his claim is corrupt and has shredded his application, deleting all records from the computer. Horrified bosses of an energy supply firm are determined to stop his invention being patented at all costs. Their hit men run Eve and her cameraman off the road and Eve is thrown clear but loses her memory. They then go back to Larfield's home, kill him and destroy his invention. Eve finds in her pocket a business card with the time for an interview for her next subject exposé - a self-styled motivational psychiatrist, Dr. Harry Griggs (Anthony Lemke). She keeps her appointment with him at a local hotel, though she has no idea who she is, having suffered memory loss at the accident. Now the hit men are after both of them, and the chase makes for quite an exciting story, though the direction by Philippe Gagnon was loose and sloppy. Considering Eve is out to do a hatchet job on Griggs' professional reputation, he is surprisingly easy to win over, even with Vaugier looking as gorgeous as she does. I didn't find the energy company's determination to eliminate the competition at all implausible, though I would have thought they would have found it more profitable to buy up the patent.

This seems to be a remake of the film made in the 1950s with Spencer Tracy starring called Bad Day at Black Rock. William Macpherson (Val Kilmer), a disabled veteran, has had enough of killing as a marine in Iraq and, after the war, goes back to the States and tries to look up his old Mexican buddy, Miguel Silva. The ranch in Arizona where he was living is now a building site run by a bunch of white supremacists, headed by John Rhodes (Gary Cole) who are intent on ridding America of `foreign' immigrants. Macpherson soon meets up with Rhodes' girl Joanna (Jennifer Esposito) and it's made clear to him that he's not wanted in town. First they ask him nicely to leave - but then things get a bit more heated and he has to take on all of Rhodes' cronies nearly single-handed. An exciting action-packed film but little in the way of plot development.

This is one of a number of recordings that the late Sir Colin Davis made with the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus and a quite splendid array of principal soloists. The two- disc opens with tenor Giuseppe Sabbatini singing a short aria as Faust. The orchestra make a fine job of the Hungarian March that concludes Part I. The bass Michele Pertusi is sufficiently menacing as Mephistopheles, who plays a significant role in Part II. Marguerite (mezzo Enkelejda Shkosa) appears in the Part III on disc 2. I have heard more captivating Margueritas but tonally the singing is fine. And the final soloist is the student Brander, also sung here by a bass, David Wilson-Johnson. Overall, I found this to be a fairly satisfying performance, though it never came alive for me; it was released in 2002 on the LSO's own record label.

Leap of Perception by Penney Peirce, Atria Books, New York, 2013, 350 ff.This is a self-help book. The author's idea is to encourage readers to tune in to a more intuitive and spiritual way of living. The quotations throughout the book that one reviewer found so irritating are in fact valuable milestones along the path that Peirce is trying to lead us down - inspired sayings by acknowledged masters of the spiritual, like Carl Jung, Fr. Bede Griffiths, and Fr. Pierre Teilhard de Cardin, who was both a mystical priest and a scientist.This book by Peirce is the last in an `unexpected' trilogy - a trio of books that the author set about writing without knowing at the outset where the story would take her. This is the first book of hers I have read; perhaps it would have been an advantage to have read parts 1 and 2 of the trilogy, `The Intuitive Way' and `Frequency', first but I settled easily enough into the story even starting here. But then she herself says: `I've occasionally woven together bits of explanation from the two previous books', so perhaps reading them first is not essential.The message of this book is, by now, a familiar one: there have very many books written over the past two or three decades that encouraged or reported a fundamental shift in the consciousness of humankind towards a more spiritual and less materialistic attitude to our lives with greater concern for the environment of the Earth of which we are a part. Some of these books have been rational and scientific (Rachel Carson; Thom Hartmann, Lester R. Brown) warning us of the dire consequences if we continue to desecrate our environment. Others have been more spiritual in their approach (Aldous Huxley; Teilhard de Chardin; Willis Harman). But the `bottom line' is always essentially the same - that our future is in our hands and it is up to us to adopt the mind-set that secures our future.So this is what this book is about - encouraging and guiding us down a path of greater spiritual involvement with one another and with our earthly environment. The message is expressed in terms of the higher vibrational frequencies of energy that living spiritually demands. This is achieved by focussing on the moment (as recommended by Eckhart Tolle and eastern mystical philosophy) and making your conscious mind aware of your environment - living in what Peirce calls the `being' state of the soul. There are mind-training exercises and a short summary with each chapter. I didn't personally relate to the `spherical-holographic' metaphor in Peirce - it reminded me too much of Ken Wilber's `Four Quadrants' concept, making the simple unnecessarily complicated. But overall this is an excellent book with a very important message for the wellbeing of humankind. The book concludes with a brief set of notes, and a glossary of terms, but no index - not that one is really needed here.Howard Jones is the author of Evolution of ConsciousnessCosmic ConsciousnessGlobal Mind Change: The Promise of the 21st CenturyThe Phenomenon of ManThe Perennial Philosophy: An Interpretation of the Great Mystics, East and West (P.S.)

This is an atmospheric thriller set in 19th century Vienna, as spiritualism was beginning to take hold. Young Eisenheim and Sophie are childhood sweethearts, but are separated as their parents part to lead their respective lives. Years later, Eisenheim becomes a respected stage illusionist (now played by Edward Norton) with Josef Fisher (Eddie Marsan) as his manager, while Sophie (now played by Jessica Biel) becomes a countess. As such, she is betrothed to Crown Prince Leopold (Rufus Sewell), but, when she meets up with Eisenheim again, she yearns to be with him. But Leopold apparently kills her to prevent her joining Eisenheim. Inspector Uhl (Paul Giamatti) threatens to arrest Eisenheim for fomenting dissent against the monarchy but when he confronts Leopold over Sophie's murder, the Crown Prince shoots himself. But the story is far from over and we do not know till the end how much is real and how much is illusion. The movie is well directed by Neil Burger.

Based on real-life events, this movie gives an account of the impact on the personal lives of those involved of the WMD episode in the Bush administration. President Bush Jr. was so obsessed with invading Iraq to finish the war that his father had started that he fabricated the story that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. CIA operative Valerie Plame (Naomi Watts) is sent to Iraq under cover to find out the truth. She persuades several of the Iraqi physicists involved in the program to defect to America. She makes it clear back home however that there are no WMD. Her partner, Joe Wilson (Sean Penn), writes a newspaper article about the fiasco but in return the administration discloses Valerie's identity and the nature of her mission. The Iraqi physicists are abandoned to their fate in Iraq and they are rounded up and executed. The chief `hawk' in the administration is Scooter Libby (David Andrews) who subsequently stands trial for his part in the fabrication, and is sentenced, but has his sentence revoked by the president. The movie is an exciting dramatization of events, directed by Doug Liman. This deplorable story has been told in print by those concerned: `Fair Game' by Valerie Plame Wilson and `the Politics of Truth' by Joe Wilson.

I guess this Aussie thriller would count as a film noir. Bored husband Raymond Yale (David Roberts) has an affair with the wife Carla Smith (Claire van der Bloom) of one of his neighbours. Inevitably, their relationship is discovered and along the way Yale is blackmailed. But one of those who threaten him accidentally gets killed and Yale is forced to bury the body - in `the square': this is a patch of land that is about to be filled with concrete as part of a building project, but the Australian rainy season comes early and concreting is delayed. This is only the first of the unexpected twists in the story and there are several more. Overall a good exciting thriller - well acted and directed by Nash Edgerton.

Celtic Mythology and Religion by Alexander Macbain, Sterling Eneas Mackay, 1917, 256 ffThough this book is nearly a century old, the subject matter does not itself undergo changes like so many facets of our present-day world. There is more up-to-date research it is true, but a Celt steeped in these traditions himself, as is the author, is an excellent place to start any reading in the subject. Gaelic was the author's first language and he is regarded as one of the greatest Scottish Celtic scholars, specialising in philology. He qualified with a Master's Degree in philosophy and a Doctorate in Laws from Aberdeen University.After an introductory chapter by the Aberdeen and Oxford scholar Professor William J. Watson that puts Macbain into his academic background, the book begins with an exploration of the nature, cause and spread of myth. The author goes on to record and discuss what is known about the place of myth within the religions of the Aryan Nation, Celts, the Gauls and the Druids. This is an eminently readable little book and, as I too spoke only Welsh as a child before I went to an English-speaking school, and my father was a scholar of medieval Welsh poetry, the book was of a great personal interest. The author makes the stories come alive and the presentation is not at all dry and academic, though not lacking in academic rigour.Howard Jones is the author of The World as Spirit

Dogs that know when their owners are coming home, and other unexplained powers of animals, by Rupert Sheldrake, Arrow, 2000, 320 ffThe title of this book may be rather unwieldy but it tells the reader exactly what to expect. Whether you are an `intelligent dog owner' or just an `open-minded scientist' this book is packed with observations and experiments (during which no creatures were harmed!) that confirm and put onto a rational statistical basis what every pet owner, animal trainer or animal homeopath already knows - that animals are capable of feelings and senses that cannot be explained or dismissed on the basis of human behaviour. It has already been found often that cats and dogs taken from one home to another, or abandoned in the wilderness, find their way back home. It has also long been part of popular folk-lore that animals, both terrestrial and aerial, can sense when there are about to be earthquakes, tsunami or forest fires. Sadly, despite being forewarned, they may not always be able to escape the danger.In this book, anecdotes (unpublished observations) of animal lovers are turned into statistically analysed case histories (accounts written down and interpreted by scientists, namely, Professor Sheldrake and his colleagues). As well as being fascinating reading, it provides a most valuable piece of scientific research.After a brief historical survey of the domestication of wild animals, Sheldrake deals first with human bonding with dogs and cats but moves swiftly on to parrots, chickens, geese - and an owl. The author has found no cases of bonding with reptiles or fish. But cases have been found of humans, using precognition or telepathy, anticipating the arrival of a friend or relative. This phenomenon has been studied in Norway by Professor Georg Hygen in Oslo who reported individuals sensing a `warning soul' or vardger relaying messages to them spiritually: as Sheldrake says `In non-Western civilizations, such as India, such forms of perceptiveness are still widely taken for granted'. Similar animal or human empathy over owners who are ill or who have died are also recorded here.As might be expected, Sheldrake attributes this animal-to-human bonding to communication through the morphic field and suggests that a similar mechanism is in operation for social animals and insects: the mechanism has even been endorsed by that arch-materialist Edward O. Wilson. Communication amongst social insects like ants has been intensively studied by William Morton Wheeler. Sheldrake also reports on the incredible experiments with chicks conducted by the French researcher René Peoc'h, where conditioned chicks were able to seemingly affect the random path of a robot. There is also a short section giving a preview of a later book, The Sense of Being Stared At. This is a wonderful book, concluded with Notes, References and an Index. If only the sceptical scientists could be persuaded to read, learn and experiment for themselves!Howard Jones is the author of Evolution of Consciousness

This is an entertaining but fairly predictable western directed by Howard Hawkes. Gunslinger Cole Thornton (John Wayne) rides into town to meet with rancher Bart Jason (Edward Asner). On the way he meets up with an old friend of his, J.P. Harrah (Robert Mitchum) who is now sheriff of El Dorado. Harrah tells Thornton that Jason is trying to drive another rancher, Kevin Macdonald (R.G. Armstrong), off his ranch so that he can get hold of more land. Thornton decides not to work for Jason but accidentally kills one of Macdonald's sons. In return, Macdonald's daughter, Josephine (Michele Carey), shoots Thornton and leaves him with a debilitating injury. Some months later, Thornton meets up with another man, Mississippi (James Caan), who is also intent up avenging the death of his friend. Jason has hired another gunslinger, Nelse McLeod (Christopher George), to fight his battles. There are various twists and turns in the story which goes pretty much to plan, but it's good entertainment if you like westerns.

This movie was based on the first of five novels (`the Ripliad'!) written about the (fortunately fictional) psychopath Tom Ripley by Patricia Highsmith. Like the movie of her first novel, Strangers on a Train, it probes the psychology of her characters. Ripley (Matt Damon) is a talented piano player who earns money as a con-man. He is asked by shipping magnate Herbert Greenleaf (James Rebhorn) to go to Italy to persuade his wastrel playboy son Dickie (Jude Law) to come home. Actually, Ripley soon finds he enjoys the life-style too much, especially the company of Dickie's girl-friend Marge (Gwyneth Paltrow), and joins in with Dickie's activities. The smooth flowing of his new persona is disrupted by his meeting with a real heiress at the airport, Meredith Logue (Cate Blanchett), and a real friend of Dickie's from Princeton, Freddie Miles (Philip Seymour Hoffman). To Meredith, Ripley has already passed himself off as Dickie Greenleaf. Then a local girl that Dickie has made pregnant drowns herself. For the rest of the movie Damon has sometimes to be `Dickie Greenleaf' for Meredith and others, and at other times himself, Tom Ripley, for Marge and Dickie. Eventually Ripley and Dickie fall out and Dickie is killed: Ripley tells Marge that he has simply gone off to other parts of Italy, but Marge never really believes him. This is an intriguing characterful thriller and, though long, is really entertaining. The director was Anthony Minghella.

The Greek Myths: Gods, monsters, heroes and the origins of storytelling, by Stephen P. Kershaw, Robinson, London, 2007, 544 ff.This is a collection of tales from ancient Greek mythology that many of us will have encountered, however fleetingly, in our school days and wished we had known the full story. The popular tales of Jason and the Argonauts with their search for the Golden Fleece, of Theseus and the Minotaur, and of the wooden horse and the fall of Troy are recounted here. Many of these were made into the basic stories of movies in the 20th century. Extracts from the classical works of Hesiod's `Works and Days', and the Iliad and Odyssey compiled by the poet Homer are given here in everyday language that allows them to be read like a contemporary set of short stories. The account here of the origins of Plato's story of the `lost continent of Atlantis' should put an end to the nonsense of New Age followers claiming to have had distant relatives from Atlantis - but then myths even more fantastic than this still endure. The author here completed his doctoral thesis under the direction of Richard Buxton, one of the world's great authorities on Greek mythology. This is a fascinating compendium with detailed additional Notes for each chapter, a few pages of further reading, and a good detailed Index. I would unhesitatingly recommend this as a source book for anyone interested in reading the symbolic stories of Greek mythology.The Oxford Dictionary of Classical Myth and Religion

These do wonders on my curly hair. I love that both sides are silk. I tend to either wrap my hair or braid it and it doesn't cause it to become frizzy or mess it up to the point i need to redo it all together.  I enjoy that both sides are silk because i do sleep on my stomach and tend to flip my pillow throught the night.The fresh cold silk on my face is so amazing and I'm able to get back to sleep fast. I did get this item for review and as always my thoughts are always my own.

I really like these and so does my daughter. I don't find the smell offensive or over powering like some others we have used. My daughter has pretty sensitive skin and said they don't irritate or burn her skin. We both thought they did a fabulous job on removing our makeup, prior to face washing. They are great for the lazy days when you literally don't have energy. Great for gym bags, purses, and lockers at school. I was able to get these at a discount for review however my thought are always my own.

I really like how soft and comfortable these are. They came really neatly packaged and undamaged. I got my set in a Queen size and i have a pretty thick mattress and the pockets on the sheets were still a touch large. Im not sure how they would fit on a thinner or regular mattress. They are so comfortable. I did wash prior to first use however after a couple nights on them i found that their were small like lints rolling on the sheets. Im a person who CANNOT stand any crumbs or ANYTHING in my bed. That is the only thing i didnt like about these, i plan on washing them this week and hopefully they go away with a few more washes. I did receive these at a discount for review.
this has really helped mine and my husbands sensitive skin! it soothes on contact and within a couple of minutes redness is gone! i did get this at a discount for my honest review

Omgosh! These are SOO cute! my daughter lit up when she saw these. I think it would make a wonderful gift for the little glamour girl in your family! It comes with a cosmetic bag, brushes, powder, lipgloss, eyeshadow, and blush (all fake). It looks so real i thought it was but thankfully i don't have to deal with the mess. This will keep them busy for quite some time. Its even fun for me because when i get ready she can also (get ready) and we can spend sometime doing something else we enjoy together. I did get this for review however my thoughts are always my very own

Im the type of person who LOVES wearing false lashes. A good pair can last several uses as long as you take care of them properly. I can't get enough of these lashes. They are so beautiful on! Very easy to apply and i really like that. I love how natural they look on, very full also. The band is easy to manipulate to fit to your eyes easier. I highly recommend theses to anyone l looking for a great pair. I also recommend these to beginners, experts and anyone in between. I do like this however i didnt see much of a change with the cellulite. I love it for post workout though! It feels so good if you have over worked a group of muscles. Why oh why didn’t I get this folding stool, years ago? I’ve only had it less than two hours and it’s already been put to good use. The top of my fridge is now dust free. I can use kitchen cabinets I couldn’t reach before.This Rubbermaid folding stool is the kind of product that once you have it you wonder how you did without it…or why… when it costs only $17.99.I think of all the times I struggled to reach something. This is going to make my life a bit easier.The stool folds and opens easily and doesn’t take up much room. It has 1” storage depth.  You can store it under a kitchen sink. There’s a non-slip thread where you stand. It is very light. You can carry it with one hand. It has a 1 year limited warranty.I am glad I have this. What a deal!

The Proactiv skin revitalizing pad is the most unique skin care product I have used.It comes in a box with three dark glass bottles (that contain retinol as an ingredient) and a jar with pads. There are an additional 60 other pads wrapped in plastic.You’re supposed to shake the bottle then pour the contents over the pads that are in the jar.You wipe your face with a saturated pad.It feels kind of mysterious and kind of fun.The directions say to use in the evening but I figured my skin didn’t know what time it was so I applied the lotion as soon as I got it. It had had a faint and pleasant scent. It did not burn or irritate my skin.I think Proactiv will last a long time. I see no reason not to reuse the pads though the product comes with plenty. The box states that the saturated pads should be used within 30 days from the date the pads were saturated. At $64.95 I can’t imagine tossing out any of the saturated pads that are left after 30 days.Does it work? I can honestly say that I am not sure. It didn’t seem to soothe away imperfections or give me a younger looking completion. Maybe my eyes are going. Maybe it’s because I didn’t follow up with the Proactiv + Three Step regimen. Perhaps I need to use it longer to see results.I will report back if I see definite results in a month.This is expensive at $64.95. If you have that kind of money to spend on skin care you may enjoy this product.

Phyto 5 Phyto-Peel has natural AHA. It comes in a 2.5 tube. It has a pleasant, faintly medicinal scent. A little goes along way. I squeezed out a blob the size of a dime and messaged it in circular motion, according to directions. My face feels as clean and soft as a newborn’s behind.Phyto-Peel boasts of ‘gene expression,’  ‘pro collagen’ and of clearing pigmentation spots. I admit I do not know what this means.There’s an ingredients list that covers three fourths of the side of the box.Because I received the $73.00 Phyto-Peel in exchange for a review I felt it only fair to do some research on facial peels and scrubs which start in price from $3.00 so that I can help you decide which products to purchase. I was curious what makes a low cost vs. an expensive product. I never found out.At a cursory glance online, I did learn there are more than 19 facial scrubs and peels. I also learned that many of these products could help you survive if you’re ever stuck on an island or in a desert without food. Their ingredients are a veritable salad bar.Phyto-Peel contains mango and banana. Other facial scrubs contain: grapefruit, pineapple, walnuts, rice, grains, oatmeal, apricot, oat and almond flour, green tea, strawberry seeds, cranberry, papaya, raspberry enzymes, sea salt, citrus, tea, tree oil and honey almond.There's a brand of scrub called 'Triumph and Diaster Rock and Roll Suicide.'You can also find a recipe online to make your own scrub…for pennies.I wind up purchasing many of the products I have received for review from Amazon Vine.Not this one. It is nice, but not $73.00 worth of nice.

I am grateful for the copy of this book I received in exchange for a review. I am also grateful I have glasses to read the book with; fingers that work to turn the pages and I am grateful that I am grateful for the second hand sofa I am sitting on and for the roof over my head.I’m making a disclaimer:  I am probably the worst kind of reader to review this book. As a psychotherapist for 30+ years I have learned that those with the least and those who carry the most pain and experience the greatest losses are also those who are most grateful.A parent with a dying child is grateful for another day; a homeless person is grateful for a roof over their head. Sitting in an oncologist’s waiting room you will find gratitude for a good test result; a good prognosis; alleviation of pain; gratitude for more time or for the simple and powerful gift of hope.Life is not fair, but sometimes life has a funny way of evening things out. What you’re not grateful for today you might not have tomorrow. So for starters; be grateful you could plunk down the $19.76 for a copy of this book instead of for medicine or for two weeks worth of food or for the cheap pair of shoes which is all you can afford.I think the author has good intentions.Studies have shown that attention to circumstances and things we should be grateful for improves mood and outlook. So this book is a good idea and will be helpful for some.For me, the book had as much substance and fluff as cotton candy. It was written towards a fourth grade reading level.I wonder how credible a woman is who appears to have everything to be grateful for, and who NEEDED to learn how to be grateful; can write a book on gratitude? She comes off to me as spoiled and self indulgent.I question the credibility of an author who cites numerous studies yet provides no references. She also cites the opinions of family therapists and other mental health providers; that without studies to back them up are only their personal opinions.This is a watered down version of many philosophies and studies.Consider that if you cannot feel gratitude you may be clinically depressed or physically ill or be in a situation that needs resolution and change.Meaning brings gratitude to our lives. Read ‘Man’s Search for Meaning” which suggests you not ask what the meaning of your life is but recognize what questions your life is asking of you.Victor Frankel writes. “In some ways suffering ceases to be suffering at the moment it finds a meaning.I hope this book helps some readers to find ways to be grateful.I also hope that at least one person will be grateful that they saved $19.75.

Sarah Hepola had me at the first page. By the last page, I felt like we were friends.Blackout is a sharply written, brave and thoughtful account of author, Sarah Hepola’s journey through shame, self degradation and self destruction during dark and muddled years when she drank to the point of oblivion: blackouts.Blackouts occur when alcohol prevents the brain from recording new memories. Blackouts are not a loss of memory; blackouts occur when there is no memory recorded.  It is like the save button in your computer doesn’t save. There is a gap. There is nothing. This is the story of the life of an alcoholic woman. Hepola could not imagine a sober life.  She said she knew what she wanted. She didn’t want to face a day without alcohol and she wanted to not have to face the consequences of having it in her life.She tells about her first sip of stolen beer when she was seven; getting drunk in the sixth grade; her squirm and cringe-worthy (and familiar) adolescent awkwardness; her college years and her first success as a writer. She takes us from Dallas, Texas through college in Austin to New York City: drinking all the way.She gains success as a writer. She has friends: women friends; men friends; boyfriends and she has fun. Alcohol helps her through her shyness. It allows her to do and say outrageous things she’d never do if sober.  Hepola knows she needs alcohol to succeed and be someone other than the self that wasn’t good enough.  “Drinking saved me…it gave me escape…it gave me power…it gave me courage…it gave me the path…when I triumphed it celebrated with me…when I cried it comforted me…and in the end…it gave me oblivion.”Blackouts prevented Hepola from remembering the embarrassing and shameful behavior. that shamed her sober self. The blackouts weren’t intentional; they were the consequence of drinking to excess. Once Hepola started drinking, she could not stop.Reading her story feels like the nauseating realization seconds after you trip at the top of a staircase and know you’re going to be tumbling down, banging against the steps as you claw all the way to the bottom.And she does fall down; down flights of stairs, and she falls face first on floors, and off curbs. She wakes up with bruises. She loses time. She has sex with strangers. She writes about having sex with a man she’s never seen before and she describes it so vividly that her waking up on top of this stranger may make you squirm.Sarah Hepola dedicates this powerful story “For anyone who needs it.”The author shares her agonizing and fearful attempts at sobriety. She shares her fears; her insights; her struggles and her successes. Mainly, she shares her experiences and through them; she shares her heart and soul.You may see yourself in these pages. If you do, you’ll feel less alone and lost.Sarah Hepola is more than an author.She is a friend.

Itay Talgam is an Israeli conductor who has also become an advisor to business leaders; a ‘conductor of people;’ a TED lecturer, and now, an author.  He believes working for an organization is like working in an orchestra which requires individual excellence in a culture where people listen to each other. He encourages leaders not to impose their ideas on their followers but to encourage individual creativity and to allow for the possibility that others may have better ideas.Talgam expands his own ideas about conducting and conductors and advises leaders of the importance of allowing others to create meaning and to shine in open spaces and ‘gaps’ This book is not so much about ignorance as it is about open mindedness and the book could aptly be entitled “The Open Minded Leader.”Good leadership Talgam believes frees the power of the performers who are usually told what to do.Talgam describes the leadership styles of 7 great conductors’ and gives examples of each in separate chapters. He illustrates their individual styles from one conductor who is rigid and controlling; another who is detached, and the best one of all who is nurturing and encouraging.This is an idealistic work for a perfect world where leaders are willing to relinquish their egos and power and their drive to control others. Unfortunately, experience too often teaches that an environment where leaders do not suppress and oppress talented subordinates and where quotas do not take precedence over quality is very rare; especially in a shaky economy.Some leaders become leaders because they want to control and even oppress others.You can add depth and dimension to your appreciation and understanding of this book by downloading Itay Talgam's TED talk, online.English is a second language for Talgam and I found the writing to be vague at times.

Oh these wild berry and tropical flavor Skittles are so beautiful in colors of mauve, orange, green,  blue, yellow, and maroon that they’re almost too pretty to eat. But eat, I did!The colors are mixed so I couldn’t tell the difference between the wild berry and tropical flavors but it didn’t matter. Each color burst with wild fruity flavor all the way down to the chewy center.  These are better than many candies, like gum drops that only have a flavor shell. These stay packed with flavor to the final melt.They call them “flavor mash ups” but I found them to be happy and fun “flavor perk ups”. They’re delicious.They come in a 9 ounce resealable bag.Skittles are a great take-along-guilt free candy; 160 calories for six of them. You really don’t need more to satisfy a sweet tooth. And for those who don’t eat candy, they make a pretty decoration in candy dishes or glass bowls.

Justin Gifford, PhD spent more than a decade researching Iceberg Slim (born Robert Lee Moppins Jr., AKA Robert Beck) accessing paperback pulp novels, prison records; FBI files, interviews, newspaper articles, unpublished fiction and letters.Gifford states that Robert Beck’s “Pimp: The Story of My Life” and Beck’s other works have transformed African American literature and culture, and have influenced…and maybe been the genesis of street literature, blaxploitation, hip hop and gansta rap. Gifford writes that “Pimp” became one of the most influential works of anti-establishment literature of the twentieth century.Beck’s account of black underworlds and of his years as a pimp sold millions of copies and he was once the most popular black author in America. By 1971 Beck had sold two million books.Gifford traces Beck’s beginnings, his influences, his adolescence (he was arrested 8 times between 14 and 17); his attendance at Tuskegee Institute; his imprisonments, his love/hate relationship with his mother and his obsession with being a “professional pimp.”This is also a sociological and historical study of effects of the Great Black Migration on America’s cities and the segregation, exploitation and disintegration of black communities.  Gifford captures the history of Chicago’s Southside; Milwaukee; Detroit’s Paradise Valley, and Black Bottom; Cleveland’s Central District and South Central L.A.: the jook joints, heroin and cocaine, playing dozens, the pimp book, the hustles and the cons.A central theme is Beck’s long suffering mother and Beck’s displaced hatred of her.This is a hard book to read because Beck could probably be diagnosed as having Narcissistic and Antisocial Personality Disorders.  He is cruel. He is violent. He spends a lifetime exploiting people and situations for his own personal gain.  His brutality and disrespect towards women …especially black women… is stomach turning. He blames his mother. He blames early childhood sexual abuse.This book is a walk on the wild side written by an author who knows and loves his subject to the point of adoration.Gifford blames much of the inner city crime on urban renewal, unemployment and the white establishment. He writes of the slums and poor living conditions but also about the harm urban renewal creates when the slums are cleared.  In Gifford’s view, the African American is blameless and Beck is a hero. That is my only criticism of this well researched and sharply written book.I have worked in Chicago and other cities with sex workers, heroin and crack addicts,alcoholics and assorted cons and gangsters and I felt I needed to shower after reading about the life of Iceberg Slim.Gritty.

This works better than anything to soothe pain and relieve stiffnessI've tried other brands but these seem to work the best.Triple Flex isn't cheap, but for me, it is well worth the price.I am back walking miles a day.Sometimes I forget I have arthritis. After taking Triple Flex my 87 year old mother said she was able to raise her arm over her head for the first time in years.I just advised my friend's mother to try Triple Flex. I've ordered two 170 cap bottles. I compared prices and found the best prices on Amazon.

Wow! I ordered this from Atharva, one of Amazon's sellers and it arrived THREE DAYS EARLY. Not only that; there was no delivery charge.As far as the scent: I am in a dream. It is gorgeously, sultry and sexy. This sent reminds me of hidden mysterious rooms where you do or dream of doing things that you'd never tell even your closest friend.This is dangerous stuff; subtle, yet packs a strong message. This, and direct eye contact could bring someone to their knees.The small bottle has a roll top. A little goes a long way.Take it easy.Let the dream begin.

Author, Kyle Dickman was a former Hotshot who spent five years fighting wildfires in California. He has poured his heart and soul into this account of the June 2013, Yarnell Hill fire that burned 19 Hotshots to death. His reporting was nominated for a National Magazine Award.This book is so powerfully written I had to wait a day to process it before attempting to write a review. It’s the kind of story that creeps into your consciousness and pulls you into a world you never imagined. This is more than just a report of the tragic fire; Dickman presents a history and an education of, and about wild fires: and the culture and lifestyles of Hotshots. He profiles salt-of- the- earth men who exemplify character, integrity, guts, and grit, usually portrayed in movies by the likes of Clint Eastwood or Jeff Bridges.Hotshots are dedicated to the job and loyal to their co-workers whom they see as brothers.  They each have their own assignments that contribute to the whole. “There was elegance in the way the team moved.”Most Hotshots don’t consider their jobs high risk. “The flames were a sense of awe-not fear.”In fact, according to Dickman, the job is lower risk than logging, commercial fishing, roofing or driving a taxi. Fire fighting is a good way to make good pay in a short time.We learn of the hierarchy and the progressive steps of the job, from rookie scrapes to swampers to sawyers and beyond, to supervision.  We are introduced to positions like weather analyst, incident commanders and fire behavior analyst.  Being involved in fire fighting, and especially being a Hotshot is a source of pride. It gets into the blood and is easy to become addicted to. “At its best, the job is the greatest adventure of many Hotshots’ lives.”The training and preparation is brutal: six mile runs, hike three, do 60 pull-ups: 390 sit-ups and 240 push-ups.  Each man’s pack that he carries into a fire weighs forty-five pounds.That tragic day when 19 Hotshots are burned to death is described in detail so fine, we can almost smell the smoke and feel the Hotshot’s boots as they slip over rocks on their final and lethal route; from the first lightening strike and a fire, so small the incident commander determined a Hotshot team wasn’t needed, to the final moments when the Hotshots are trapped and surrounded by flames and they crawl into portable aluminum shelters.The author makes an argument for prevention, forest management and explains the serious consequences of early suppression of fires, saying that,” Naturally and regularly occurring fires played a crucial role… and removing flames changed the self regulating system.”Kyle Dickman documents the main sources used in each chapter.Maps will be provided for clarity. (This is a review of uncorrected proof and had no illustrations or maps.)This book is informative and exciting and absolutely heartbreaking.

I usually purchase drug store brand batteries when they’re on sale. I do this often because I regularly forget to turn off my battery operated radio when I fall asleep during boring talk radio shows. I come back the next night to find the battery dead.This did not happen with Fusion by Rayovac which purports to last “35% longer than Energizer Max in digital cameras.” So I got a chance to test these batteries. It wasn’t a scientific test but I can verify that they do seem to last longer and with crisper sound than the ones I usually buy. This makes them a good deal. Cheap batteries don’t last.Fusion batteries have a 10 year guarantee to stay fresh in storage. (This means I can store them in my camera’s pouch or in a drawer without worry.)These batteries are mercury free.They are made in Fennimore Wisconsin and there’s a real telephone number you can call.Rayovac has a video about them on their colorful website.Rayovac also makes flashlights and flashlight bulbs. The company seems to have been around forever…which is how long I have been alive.The package says these advanced alkaline Fusion batteries are Rayovac’s longest lasting batteries.That’s good. I hope I last as long as they do.

The first thing you may notice about Josie Natori Body cream is the weight, 6.8 oz., and the large size of the jar. This will last a long time. The top of the jar has an interesting design: black and white squares with red flowers creeping up the side. The border of the lid is black and the jar is transparent, with the pale, powdery peach color of the cream, visible.Natori body cream is light. Its absorbency time is average. It leaves the skin feeling soft and moisturized.The scent lingers. For me, Natori has the unmistakable scent of menthol combined with other scents, perhaps a light baby powder, perhaps sandalwood, but for me, menthol was predominant.Others have characterized the scent as exotic and sultry.It reminded me of being a child with a cold when my mother rubbed a vapor rub on my chest.The ingredient list on the black and white box is extensive.UPDATE and ADVISEMENT: Scent was still strong after six hours with only a scant application. You may want to apply your usual scent more moderately as this body cream seems to act like a cream perfume. Some will love this, but some will not.I felt it was important to include this information in my review.Natori Body cream costs $58.00. Perhaps someone more sophisticated than me can tell me why.

Aveeno is weird in a wonderful way.Seconds after it glides on, it feels like light power (How do they do this?) and it will make your skin feel as soft as velvet.There’s no greasiness or oiliness. Aveeno feels pure and clean.It is fragrance free and ingredients include soothing oatmeal. It is recommended by dermatologists.My thought is that this will be refreshing in summer and add needed moisturizer in the winter.Aveeno comes in a 12 fl.oz. pump plastic bottle.I love this stuff.

This is an excruciating, horror filled and nightmarish account of author Clark Elliott, Ph.D’s experiences of brain damage from a concussion he received in a car accident. He writes of his symptoms from the smallest detail to the global effects they have on his life and of his struggles and frustrations in his attempts to get help.Elliott writes, “The book is intended for those who have suffered from a brain injury and know it…for those who will not know it until they recognize aspects of their lives in these pages… for those who have family members or friends who have suffered a brain injury.”Clark Elliot describes debilitation so extreme and so pervasive that his efforts and ability to carry on with his life as a professor and father reach the level of heroic.He goes to a hospital two times. His experiences there are horrific. (One time he returns home with a needle lodged in his arm and does not know it. When he returns to the hospital, the nurses find it amusing.) He has appointments with two leading neurologists. He goes through tests at a nationally known rehabilitation center; He attends a balance clinic; a neurotherapy clinic; a homeopath, various physicians and a psychiatrist; treatments with an elecrostimulation therapist, an orthopedic physical therapist who specializes in brain injuries, standard and Atlas-specialty chiropractors, an herbalist and an acupuncturist and a sports medicine specialist.Elliot states that virtually every expert he has seen had shown little interest in his condition and even less understanding.He’s been treated with suspicion, as if he was a scam artist, a trouble maker or a malingerer.After eight years, he comes to the realization that if something doesn’t change he’ll have to resign from his job as a professor…lose his home…lose his ability to support his family...lose everybody’s medical insurance…Then, when he is at the end of his rope, he finds a cognitive restructuring specialist and an optometrist who emphasizes neuro-optometric rehabilitation. They work together to change his life.The author kept detailed notes from the day of the accident through his recovery. This book has pages and pages of his almost unbelievable symptoms and struggles. This is written from inside out by someone with TBI. He gives us a vision of a waking nightmare.This was a copy of an Advance Uncorrected Proof. There will be suggestions at the end of the published book for further reading.This important book may be a life saver for those with TBI and their loved ones.

Since being offered to try 100% organic Cocozia I learned about the benefits of coconut water.This coconut water comes in a heavy cardboard container and has a unique cap that locks into place to prevent spilling.That’s the good news.When the16.9 fl.oz.  container arrived I shook it up and took a gulp.Big mistake. It tasted bland and was reminiscent of stinky feet.I figured it was supposed to be drunk cold.I refrigerated it, shook it up and took a sip.It was still bland and now, reminiscent of COLD, stinky feet.I tried. I really did.But for $4.50 I can buy a whole bottle of wine.I can also buy a coconut. I can buy coconut milk and make a smoothie and still have enough left over to do it again…and again.Many seem to love this.Maybe there’s something wrong with my tongue.

This is a love story.This memoir is so personal and intimate that you can feel author, Jonathan Kozol’s angst and indecision;  see lines and shadows crisscross his father’s face; feel the light of his beloved smile, the twinkle in his eye, and you can almost touch his father’s strong but trembling hands. The Theft of Memory reads like a diary. We see Kozol’s father fade through the lens of Kozol’s eyes.We can feel the love. We can see the struggle to hold on. We can sense the loss. The book’s pages seem to have absorbed each worry and tear and every small and significant lucid moment in this recollection by a son of a father slowly consumed by Alzheimer’s disease.  The fading memory and physical deterioration of the author’s father are recounted in years and months and weeks and days and final minutes.  And when we read that Kozol’s hospitalized father is deteriorating quickly, it feels personal, almost like we’ve shared the journey with them and we know them.Kozol writes that he felt he was on a journey with his father beginning with his father’s diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease when his father was 88 years old. He recalls when his Harvard trained; neurologist father first tells him about ‘neurological spells’ and lays out his symptoms for his son in graphic terms.We watch the decline of a brilliant mind even as letters come asking for his opinion on academic papers or observations on a research study while Kozol tries to hold on to his father at home, then in a nursing home; then back in his father’s apartment and through the, hospitalizations even keeping a subscription to a newspaper his father can no longer read or understand.This is also story of a marriage—Kozol’s mother figures prominently throughout this account.Family secrets are revealed. Good and bad times are recalled.There’s also a discussion about the value of a life and how it seemed “A ninety-eight neurologist who suffers from dementia has no further value to the economic order.” There is an incident at a hospital of blatant disrespect as the author pleads for help because his father has a urinary infection and is sick, and the receptionist says, “How do you know? He can’t talk.”There’s another incident that will set your hair on end as Kozol’s father endures an extremely, dangerous and painful procedure that sends him into shock.Award winning author, Jonathan Kozol calls him Daddy.This account of the decline of a brilliant clinician to a baby-like state is heart wrenching and unforgettable. Keep tissues nearby.

You don’t have to look further after you read all the reviews. These Clipperton shower rings are the top of the line. They’re easy to attach to the shower curtain and rod. They slide, effortlessly without tugging on the shower curtain. They are made of high grade stainless steel and they are built to last.Just read what the company says about their product and you can almost feel their pride.A True Story:I’ve moved a lot and putting up shower curtains has been one of the worst—most pain-in-the-neck things about all my moves. It is something I have dreaded.I always have to find the hole in the shower curtain and liner and then put the shower ring through them both—with one or the other hole slipping out of the ring.
