Then there’s forcing the rigid plastic rings around the pole. This is a major effort because my hands are not very strong.  Locking the rings was arduous and painful. The rings didn’t stay locked. In places, my shower curtain would sag.I finally gave up after trying different brands of shower curtain rings.Some were too rigid. Some cracked. Some didn’t stay locked.A constant hassle.Until these came, my shower curtains were held up by ribbons. Because frankly, I stopped giving a damn.This is the solution.Clipperton shower rings are easy to put on and lock in place. They are pretty. They are efficient. They are well made.Shower curtain rings are not a major purchase, but if Clipperton shower curtain rings can make life a little bit easier. .. that’s a lot. It was for me.

This is a hilarious and bitter-sweet account of growing up horny and Orthodox. Author Eytan Bayme, offers a brave and often pain filled peek into his prepubescent obsession with sex reminiscent of the style of a Jerry Seinfeld and Woody Allen.This book is a situation comedy. A better title; and less embarrassing one to read on the subway would be: A Boy and His Schmeckle: A Love Story; or for the more intellectually inclined, A Boy and His Genitalia: A Love Story. The fun begins with Eytan as a whinny, spoiled six year old brat who for pleasure, ‘presses’ himself on everything, everywhere including under a glass dining room table at this parents’ friends house where the diners have a “front row seat for the show.”His own painfully patient, understanding, lenient, intellectual and bewildered Jewish Orthodox parents call it “rocking.”They’re almost as funny as he is.Later we see Eytan’s machinations to get his hands on, and hide porn magazines.  He hides one behind the air conditioner outside his bedroom.  Of course it is found.  Of course this draws a crowd The discovery had me laughing out loud. Eytan hides other porn magazines behind his bed and under the bathroom sink. The maid finds his copy of “60 Plus” magazine about sex with older women and tells his mother who says he has to apologize to the maid. When he tells the maid he is sorry, she says she thought this was “A nice home and a nice family, until I met you.” He’s barely a preteen.Eytan’s friends are funny too. One friend, during prayer services asks God for certain baseball cards. Eytan also prays to God, “Please get me a girl.”Eytan is an outsider who is a slow learner in a slow-track class. He sees a psychiatrist, has weekly tutorial sessions with a child psychologist and sees a child psychiatrist every two months for medication. He feels like a loser.There' s a chocolate milk scene that will twist your heart even as you choke on your own laughter.In a heart wrenching part of the book Eytan, believing his highly influential father can pull strings, tells all his friends he’s been accepted at a prestigious Manhattan High School.Eytan’s sheltered innocence is charming and tender.Eytan takes us into his adolescence; his first cigarette, non-Kosher pizza, coffee, weed, Nine inch Nails concert, and his trying on new identities to look and act cool, (“Aside from my mom I didn’t know anyone who drank coffee and the cup that (his friend) held …made him look older than his years.”). We cringe while laughing at his adventures and small successes, big failures, embarrassing moments and girls. The more you read the funnier it gets.The ending will make you want to stand and cheer.

What David Brooks heard on an old Command Performance variety Radio Show broadcast after V-J Day on August 15, 1945 set off a chain of thoughts. He writes that he noticed the tone of the era’s biggest celebrities was one of self effacement, humility and modesty. There was no self celebration. He contrasted the subdued and modest tone of this broadcast with watching on the same night, the self puffery and the victory dance of a defensive football player who had just made a tackle.Brooks discusses the shift from humility to narcissism.It occurred to David Brooks that the shift might symbolize a change in culture from one that says, “Nobody’s better than me but I’m no better than anyone else”, to a culture of self promotion that says, Recognize my accomplishments. I am special.”Brooks credits Rabbi Joseph Soliveitchik’s 1965 book, “Lonely Man of Faith” in which the rabbi notes there are two accounts of creation in Genesis that represent two opposing sides of our nature: Adam I and Adam II.  Author, Brooks expounds on this idea and he defines what he believes are the contemporary examples of these two opposing forces: Adam I:  The career oriented individual who wants to build, create and produce, have high status and win victories, and Adam II: The person who wants a serene character, a quiet sense of right and wrong; a desire to sacrifice and serve in the service of others and who renounces worldly success and status for the sake of a sacred purpose.“Adam I wants to conquer the world and Adam II wants to obey a calling to serve the world.”External vs. Internal. Success driven vs. Self sacrifice for one’s own inner moral imperative to serve.Brooks talks about Resume Virtues:  The skills we bring to the job markets that contribute to our success, and Ecology Virtues: The kinds of virtues that are at the core of our being and will get talked about at our funeral.Brooks profiles notable people in biographical essays whom he beliefs exemplify the Adam II Character with exhibiting humility and by challenging and overcoming their own moral weaknesses.  He cites a reoccurring pattern: “They (all) had to go down to go up. They had to descend into the valley if humility to climb to the heights of their character.”Davis Brooks admits to having a naturally shallow disposition, and who is paid to be a narcissistic blowhard and be more confident about his opinions, and be smarter than he says he really is. He has lived the life and achieved the external success of Adam I and now seeks to examine how others have trodden the road to Character.This book presents ideas we probably should stop in our mad dashes to think about. Brooks brings up questions and holds up a mirror to us. He clarifies and explains the humble hard worker shift to the narcissistic ‘BIG ME’ shift in our society. Much of the book is beautifully written. The Road to Character offers introspection and inspiration with a thread of religiosity.  This book, an ADVANCE UNCORRECTED PROOF is also uneven and verbose at times and often waivers from the pedantic to unfocused rambling.I question his character profile choices. Dwight Eisenhower, one of the people profiled achieves the highest job in the land (Adam I), cheats on his wife and coldly dumps his mistress.And of course the idea of the book itself exemplifies Adam I and contradicts Adam II.  Most people will read this book because of David Brooks’ success. How many of us would read this if it were written by a self effacing Shirley Sebranski or Thomas W. Jones? Would the book even be published?The Road to Character is well worth reading. The ideas in this book are going to be widely discussed.

The chocolate colored contents of Jergens Natural Glow Instant Sun pumped out like whipped cream or a dessert mousse. It spread thinly and evenly and was absorbed instantly into my skin.The faint flagrance was pleasant and unobtrusive.I was a little disappointed that the warning said not to apply to face since that’s where I wanted the sun tan look most. So I tested this product by applying it to my lower arm. It dried in seconds and did not run off on my white knit sweater.Instant Sun worked beautifully to ‘naturally’ tan my skin. I have the 6 fl oz Deep Bronze color and liked the idea that it took 3 applications to turn my pale skin a light brown. This means to me that it is hard to make a mistake because the color gradually intensifies with layering.This does feel a bit tacky and sticky after it dries. You need to be careful when depressing top because a lot of product comes out. I think the average adult female may need two cans to do a complete job on arms and legs.I give this a C.

If Fekkai Technician Color Care Mask came in a bigger jar, I’d use it as my conditioner, but 1.69 oz seems almost microscopic. With medium length hair I figure it’s enough for around five applications.The pink cream hair color mask has a scent lovely enough for a perfume. It’s sort of exotic, sort of sweet and gentle and sort of musky.It smoothed my unruly hair but did nothing to add to the shine.I give a 5 for the scent: a 2 for the size of the jar, a 3 for manageability and a 1 for the shine.

Cetaphil Ultra Moisturizing Baby Wash is unremarkable. It is like a thin and mild lotion with no suds or bubbles. It has a faint scent.The bottle opening is upside down which I think is counter intuitive. If one is holding on to baby with one hand, the bottle is difficult to close or put down. Contents can leak. The top will be a minor challenge to close.There’s nothing special here. But maybe there doesn’t need to be.

Laura Biagiotti Essenza Di Roma Eau de Toilette is soft and gentle and reminds me of baby powder but with a hint of muskiness. Other reviewers have said it is bold and woodsy which only shows that body chemistry and noses and tastes are different for each of us.What most of us can agree on is the pretty slanted, gold topped and ribbed, frosted glass bottle with a wider glass pedestal at the bottom.I imagine this Eau de Toilette would be fine for any age because it ‘feels’ innocent.

I am impressed by many convenient and smart features of the stout and sturdy Travel Pro Crew 10, 22 inch expandable 7.7 lb. suitcase.The first thing I noticed, when removing it from the box was a grab indentation in the bottom  for gripping so it’s easy to pick up if you need to lift the suitcase or shove it in an overhead storage bin.  There are top and side handles.This suitcase has three main compartments: outside the main case there’s a zippered compartment for odds and ends. Behind this compartment is another zippered storage for a laptop. The main case unzips and has one plastic and one mesh pocket along the side and unique adjustable straps that slide up and down to hold clothing secure.Flip the side out and there’s an expandable suiter with a removable zippered extension panel and a padded roll bar to keep longer items wrinkle free.The ‘patented contour grip’ handle with cushioned touch points really is more comfortable than my other suitcases. I recall switching hands during long hauls across airports or hotels because my pulling hand got sore and tired. The handle also extends with a standard stop at 38” and extends to 42.5”without a wobble. I am 5’6” so it extends to below my rib case. This added extension is important for anyone who wants to be able to freely extend their arm while wheeling this suitcaseThe suitcase has a stability system that prevents tipping and spinner wheels that turn in all directions.Travel Pro is touted as the choice of flight crews and frequent travelers.You can find two helpful on line videos that explain all the benefits of Travel Pro Suitcases.

This book is a kind of love story. This book is an act of love, redemption and resurrection by a daughter who finally and fully came to know her father when she was 75 years old.Mimi Baird was six years old in 1944 when her esteemed, highly educated, Harvard trained physician father disappeared. She was told by her mother that her father was `ill'.  When Baird asked questions, they went unanswered; she was told her father was `away'. There were fleeting comments about her father suffering from manic depression, but he was rarely mentioned and he was effectively erased from the author's life when Baird's mother divorced him and remarried within the year. Baird saw her father one more time, in 1959, shortly before he died in a low rent boarding house and drowned in his bathtub after a seizure, common in those who have had a frontal lobotomy. He was 55 years old.Years later, in 1991, during a casual conversation with a physician, Baird learned that the physician had known her father. When she mentioned this coincidence to another doctor, he did some research at Harvard Medical School Library and found a cache of her father's old letters.This was like the first tangible evidence that her father was really real. Baird visited the Harvard Library and found more correspondence. This emboldened her further. She called her estranged father's brother and learned her father had written a book that had been sitting in an old briefcase in her cousin's garage.This is the book from that manuscript her father began in 1944. It was published in 2013; twenty years after Baird inherited her father's papers.This book is Dr. Perry Baird's heart breaking story of his personal waking nightmare of the horrors of mania from the inside out, locked up in state institutions, tied up in strait jackets, packed in ice packs and subjected to nothing less than medieval torture: the only treatments doctors knew in those days before medication.Dr Baird's cogent controlled writing is supplemented by medical records which describe behavior such as: destroying several hospital beds, breaking panels from door to his room, breaking sashes from the window, threatening staff, smashing light fixtures, breaking a transom with his hand, smashing furniture and using pieces of it as weapons and `tearing the place to pieces," and having to be restrained....over and over again.Yet he was brilliant enough to be one of the first to be convinced that Bipolar Dosorder is caused by a chemical imbalance; he conducted research; got an article published entitled, "Biochemical Component of the Manic-Depressive Psychosis" in the Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease." But it was too late for him.His illness caused his medical license to be removed. It cost him his family, his dignity, his friends and his life. He wanted the moon but would have gladly settled for sanity.This book could share a place on a bookshelf with Kay Redfield Jamison's, Touched by Fire, An Unquiet Mind and William Styron's, Darkness Visible.Shattering.

Maybe these stories by Jonathan Lethem are an acquired taste, like anchovy pineapple pizza.Maybe I am dense and lack insight.I did not like any of these stories. None of them touched me. None were memorable. I kept reading the stories and finishing them and wondering, what was the point? I reread a few of them like "Traveler Home" and tried hard to glean something meaningful. To me, the story read like it was written by someone for whom English was a second language...and learned poorly.I'm going to take the rap. It is me and not the author who deserves criticism.I found nothing here.Maybe I am blind.Or dumb.

Empire of the Senses is a story of an assimilated German Jew who is married to a beautiful but frigid German woman. The novel spans the years of 1914-1953, and tells us about Lev, the main character who joins the German army in WWI to prove to his wife, her family and himself that he is not a coward. We learn about his experiences on the Russian front during the war and the characters he meets, including a woman he falls in love with and idolizes throughout the rest of the story.This novel flows along at a comfortable pace as the author describes Lev's desertion from the German army when Germany loses the war, and continues with Lev's daily mundane life with his wife and their two children in pre WWII Berlin.The wife is a self involved social climber who is concerned with appearances. The teen aged daughter is a typical superficial and frivolous teen and the gay son struggles with shame for his gayness and Jewishness. Lev, the main character is in love with a Jewish woman he met during the war.This is a story about the falling apart beneath the surface of what looks like a `typical family' and their comfortable lives in a Berlin in pre Nazi Germany. This is also a story about hiding who you are and what you love and the costs it involves when you lose your identity and your way. How Berlin is depicted in this book, while knowing what's coming adds a chill to the narrative.On the cusp of Nazism in the later part of the book things start falling apart. The tension as the book builds towards a climax to will have you breathing fast and quickly flipping through pages.And as you turn the last page, you may let out a sigh.I was perplexed by the title, "Empire of the Senses." Perhaps the author is saying that when we deny our sense of who we are, it consumes us and becomes our entire world.This 474 page book (advance Reader Copy) is well worth your time. The book is more comfortable than exciting which makes this story feel true to life.

This Home Essentials tote made of woven paper feels like it is made of heavy canvas. It looks `beachy" with horizontal black stripes over a beige background and reminds me of a tote that people would bring to a beach. It has two woven handles to make it easy to carry.This tote may be commandeered by your cat as a nice place to snuggle up in. You could use this tote for papers; for knitting materials, magazines, an under bed storage for sweaters or other clothes. Your imagination will fill this tote fast.This is the kind of item you don't know you need until you have one, and then wonder how you managed without it.

Good Grips can and bottle opener is the easiest and prettiest (Robin’s Egg Blue) openers I have ever used.Good Grips pierced my can of veggies effortlessly and fast and the knob (is that what you call it?) turned smoothly around the can. No strength was needed.The bottle opener is on the side…very cute…very efficient and very neat.I think this opener would be perfect for anyone whose manual dexterity is compromised.Arthritis sufferers would probably really appreciate the ease of use and a handle large enough to grip comfortably.I imagine this opener would be good for camping trips or for any place an electric opener can’t go.I think this is a great product.

This autobiography feels like it comes from a desperate place.Kevin Sessums, whose methamphetamine addiction cost him a career that many writers would sell their souls for ends this autobiography living in a 120 square foot apartment with his two dogs, his clothing in garbage bags, no oven, sleeping on a worn out mattress on the floor, $1.23 in the bank and $5.00 in cash, HIV positive and clutching an eight month sobriety that seems so tenuous that I wonder if the next thing we hear of him will be his obituary. After a brief career as an actor, Sessums became a celebrity interviewer. He was executive editor working for Andy Warhol at Interview, and contributing editor at Allure and worked for Tina Brown at Vanity Fair; he had a New York Times Best Seller;  hung around with the New York cool people whose names(Madonna, Courtney Love, Keith Ledger) we all know, and all the while he felt detached,  "...like, I'm just visiting my own life." He writes that he always felt alone...different. He was gay, "My wrists were wrong. This was not the way a boy should run...I could not mimic what I saw...I began to cry." He felt like an outsider even in a loving home.He is seven when his father dies in a car crash and orphaned when his mother dies a year later.Throughout this book it appears that his grief, loneliness and his self pity cloud his vision and perception like a caul. Then he discovers methamphetamine.He was a super star with a six figures income; he lived in a 2000 square foot loft in New York's TriBeCa and he interviewed and socialized with celebrities until it all fell apart and he found himself jobless, homeless, and addicted and living on food stamps and methamphetamine.This is the story of Sessum's rise and fall and his spiritual quest to find answers and sobriety. He climbs to the top of Mount Kilimanjaro. He shares his experience as he walks the Camino de Santiago. He tells us of marvelous occurrences in the real world and then describes, the universe-embracing, life- (death)affirming hallucinations he loves, cherishes and craves while on his methamphetamine binges, and he admits they surpasses everything... even his life...especially his life. "I only know it was the most blissful, most peaceful, most astonishing experience I've ever had in this life because it wasn't of this life."Sessums is honest and he is naked and courageous and he strips himself to the bone and soul and he adds graphic sex scenes and details about anonymous sex partners and it's like he's turning himself inside out.But he can be funny. There's a hilarious  part when Kevin is caught, by his parents literally in  the closet with his mother's dress falling on top of him and his feet in her high heels.We see family moments where there's tenderness and love. Shortly after His father dies we read of Kevin visiting his mother in the hospital and watching her in pain as she lay dying. We see Kevin, the little boy in his loneliness and his longing for his mother and father who loved him so.  We see him sitting alone in front of a flickering TV.The writing is a bit uneven; the beginning of the book seems to hum along with minor digressions and detours but the rest of the book feels like being thrown off a ledge.Kevin Sessum's  I Left it on the Mountain makes you want to root for Kevin.Desperately.

There’s nothing wrong with Beachblond Sea Eaves Sea Salt Spray by John Frieda if you don’t mind smelling like you got in a fight with an angry coconut… and lost.  This has a strong (chemical) coconut scent which may remind some of sun tan oil. It also does contain sea salt. So?I find scrunching my usual leave-in conditioner works better at making and keeping curls than this. I saw no evidence that this was superior at increasing a ‘ropey ripple effect.’ And for that ‘care free beachy style’ I just tumble out of bed and don’t comb my hair.This comes in a blue (reminiscent of water?) 5 fl.oz bottle with a pump that mists the contents.There are instructions on the bottle for long and shorter hair.All hair is different. There’s nothing wrong with this mist if you don’t mind smelling like a coconut.

This works better for me and relieves my stiffness and minor arthritic pain than the more expensive glucosamine and chondroitin.I received a sample of New Chapter Turmeric Force, did some research to determine safety, and I began taking this Turmeric less than two weeks ago. I immediately noticed the difference. Placebo effect? If it is I’m okay with that because my stiffness is gone.I highly suggest you try this. You have nothing to lose. It is not expensive and even if it was, it would be worth the price just to feel so much better.I won't be without this ever again.

The scent is lovely and the conditioner works as well as or maybe a little better than the other named brand conditioner I’ve been using. I experienced fewer frizzes after using this Vidal Sassoon conditioner but still enough for me to need leave in conditioner. I didn’t notice an extraordinary shine or notable manageability.I give an A for the scent and a C for the conditioning.All hair is different. Maybe this will be the perfect conditioner for you.

Of course this smells so heavenly; there should be a label that warns against drinking it.  Shampooing with Sassoon Cherry Almond Shampoo is a totally sensual experience.This is a great way to start or end a busy day.The added benefit and the REAL reason we use shampoo is by what it does and doesn’t do.This does treat hair gently; even colored hair.  The bottle states it is also suitable for colored hair.This does lather up bubbily and creamily. (And yes I added an ‘I’ to make up those two words because nothing describes shampooing with Sassoon better.) This leaves hair shinny. This does not leave hair feeling stripped and dry.Simple. Sassoon shampoo is a small and inexpensive way to be good to yourself.

What's at fault for my being bored and not enjoying this book was my expectation of a book that presented `fast food' and easily digestible, dangerous and alarming flash points and not a leisurely five course meal.  I learned a lot about European history which is necessary to evaluate the present, but it comprised more of the book than I expected. For me, this was not light or exciting reading. Other readers will dive in and enjoy discussing this book and Friedman's point of view, for hoursIn the book's beginning, I found the author's own family history in Europe and their surviving Nazism and their escape from Hungary, fascinating. It was the most exciting part of the book.Author George Friedman states in the preface to Flash Points that "the most important question in the world is whether or not conflict and war have actually been banished or whether this is merely an interlude, a seductive illusion." He writes at the end of the book that the reason he wrote the book was to answer the question of whether or not Europe will return to its historical ways. To answer this question he raises two questions:  How did Europe achieve global domination, and what was the flaw between 1924 and 1945 that that caused it to throw away this domination. This is the focus of the book.He ominously writes that he thinks that Europe's history of conflict is far from over.This book is dense and detailed and focuses on history. The author painstakingly explains why the border between Germany and Russia is a flashpoint; why the Caucasus remains a flashpoint, and how and why Turkey is surrounded by flashpoints. The massive movement of the population from North Africa and Turkey into Europe is a flashpoint. There's a rise in Europe's right wing parties from Hungry to France.This treatment in this book may be too slow and too complicated be for a casual reader like me who is more interested in breaking news stories of Flash Points that have flashed and exploded like the recent events in Paris.This book is not for everyone.

This is a second order and this time I doubled the order. This is the ONLY thing that works.I have tried everything and finally found relief with this.Pleasant scent. Easy to use.Like a miracle. Worth it's weight in gold.

This Dove moisturizing bar combines the exotic scents of mandarin and tiare flower. Tiare flower is a type of gardenia from Tahiti. The scent is subtle and lovely. I put the empty soap box in my lingerie drawer.This soap has a rich lather that feels luxurious. It made my skin feel silky.What I liked immediately was the cool touch of the bar when it slid from the box. When I held it, it fit like it was custom designed to fit in my palm.Trying this new (new for me) Dove was like meeting an old trusted friend who introduces you to something wonderful and new.This was a relaxing and lovely experience that lingers.Lovely.

I thought from the title, "So You've Been Publicly Shamed" that this book would be about readers' experiences with being shammed, the consequences of their being shamed and some advice or solutions from author. Instead, Jon Ronson writes that the book's journey began with his own identity being hijacked by a spambot and a group using his twitter name.This is a book about others being shamed. All were `outed' and shamed for different reasons, like the writer who made up quotes for a magazine article, or for the simple (only human type) stupidly like a thoughtless joke on twitter or a thoughtless picture on Facebook. I was disappointed. And also, around halfway through the book, I was bored. The book seemed directionless, and left me wondering what the point was.But I was amused at the beginning.  Some paragraphs were kind of funny. Ronson tells us all the places he went to interview people. He tells us how he found these people and how he got some of them to talk. Those he writes about include a disgraced former governor, a writer who lied about the research he supposedly conducted, and a man accused of engaging in a "sick Nazi orgy."He writes about attending a porn scene being filmed and participating in a group called "Radical Honesty" which helps clients eradicate feelings of being exposed or judged as not being good enough.I shamefully admit that I'd never heard of most of the people in Ronson's book. There were no Stars of Shame like Monica Lewinsky or the Clintons or Martha Stewart or James Frey or Jayson Blair (New York Times), or Janet Cooke (Washington Post).This is a fun book and a book about nasty people who destroy other people's livelihoods and lives, (some do it to themselves) and a book where we see people suffer and read of some of them committing suicide and a book about "society's intensifying eagerness to publicly shame people..." And it doesn't gel with the author's lighthearted humor and fun.This was a superficial treatment of a serious problem.Ronson "gets it." He ends the book with the line, "We are defining the boundaries of normality by tearing apart the people outside of it."I wish he'd started the book with this line and written with more depth about consequences of being shamed, and not just for the characters he writes about, but for the rest of us. One careless twitter comment or Facebook faux pas and we're all at risk.

This is a compassionate book written from a personal perspective, and includes extensive research, interviews and historical data. The author explores the personal, psychological, social, cultural and political aspects of what we know as PTSD. David J. Morris is a former marine infantry officer and a journalist who was almost killed by a roadside bomb in Baghdad. He writes about his own struggles with PTSD. He says he wrote this book for selfish reasons as an attempt to answer basic questions: Why does the world seem different since he got back from Iraq? Why does he feel out of place? What does one do with the knowledge gleaned from a near death experience?The Evil Hours: A Biography of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorders really is a biography of PTSD that goes wide and deep into the history, symptoms, treatments, and the valiant fight by group of Viet Nam Vets to have PTSD included as a mental Illness Diagnosis in the DSM III. Morris writes of Shell Shock, Combat Neurosis, Traumatic Neurosis, Combat Fatigue, VietNam Syndrome all being different names for what we call PTSD today. He writes about the trauma of the soldiers in WWI and WWII and VietNam and the trauma of rape and natural and man-made traumas, as well as his own difficulties with PTSD. He includes interviews though out the book.Morris writes about his own treatments (he dropped out of one) and other treatments: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy-Cognitive Processing Therapy, Psychodynamic Therapy, Prolonged Exposure, Flooding, the drug propranolol and even Yoga. He cites the ineffectiveness and dangers and controversies of some of the therapies and the dropout rates of 54% of therapies with most empirical support. The chapters on therapies and psychologist and psychiatrist infighting is informative and is reason enough to recommend this book.Author David J. Morris writes that historian and philosopher, Will Durant "calculated that there have been only twenty-nine years in all of human history when there wasn't a war going on somewhere in the world."Morris writes in the final chapter about suffering and growth from suffering and he quotes psychologist Richard Tedescho who says his research has shown that post-traumatic growth is far more common than post- traumatic stress. Research continues.This beautifully written factual and philosophical book is rich on many levels. Morris delivers information about PTSD within a broad history of war and social, political and cultural movements and shows us the influences that shape who we are today and who we will be tomorrow.

Absolutely horrible- unless you want to stay in one place while holding your phone completely still. So very disappointed. I bought these after a brand just stopped working. However, the worked for two years so I went back to them and ordered another pair. GOgroove AirBAND Bluetooth Stereo Headphones...

2:24 MinsOh how I love wine, and wine loves me! So, when the opportunity arose for me to try this product, I was excited. I did order this product at a discount in exchange of my honest review.When the blizetec wine chiller arrived I was pleasantly surprised to see how small it was. I had no issues opening the package or did I need to grab scissors or an axe just to get into it, which is a nice change. Once I had it out of the package it was only two pieces that easily screwed together. The stainless steel rod and the pourer which has a built in aerator.Per the instructions I placed it in the freezer for about 2 hours. It was nice and frosted when I took it out. Then you have to make a little room in the bottle for the rod, insert and wait 5 minutes. I was really surprised that after only 5 minutes my bottle of wine was chilled to a perfect temperature!We have a great outdoor space that we love to eat dinner on. Unfortunately, I find myself running back and forth to the refrigerator to refill my glass of wine. Well, no more of that! This kept my wine nice and chilled throughout our 2+ hour dinner.Now what could be better than what I have stated above? I just about completed my Christmas shopping, this is the perfect gift for anyone that drinks wine!Also, this is very simple to clean with just a quick run under the faucet.I would most certainly recommend this product! What an ingenious concept!

I have always dreamed of having beautiful long lashes. I always felt that when I wore false eyelashes people would notice and they always felt heavy. I started using a prescription formula to help grow my lashes with no success. I just received this today and whipped it out and I can't believe the results. This is my first time applying it,so I'm sure I'll get better over time. My eyes do not feel heavy and they are not irritated. Thank God for whomever thought of this genius idea.

I literally laughed when I saw these and thought to myself " Are we really getting that lazy?" Well, I am eating my words now. I ordered them and now I do not have to fight with my husband to come outside to help with all the groceries. I can but so many bags on these! What would usually take me 4 or 5 trips is now 3 max. Almost wishing I would have invented them.

Eh- I wanted so badly for this to work. I did as other reviewers said and let it sit in hot water. I just couldn't get a great lather out of it. I also felt it left a slime behind. The smell is not great either, nothing overpowering I just didn't feel clean. I also didn't see any improvement of my dermatitis​, which is what I purchased it for.
These are great! I use them to pack my lunch. I can make a salad or take leftovers from the night before. They are washable but suggest they go on the top rack. You can also microwave them!

This might be one of the best purchases I have ever made. It's adorable looking- everyone compliments me on it. It holds my license, 3 credit cards and then receipts and insurance cards in the pocket behind the card slots. Even when you have all that stuff in it, it still closes which I love. It's magnetic, instead of trying to slip a tab into something. Very durable, I have dropped it a few times. You can also use it as a stand while watching videos, movies etc.

Great if you are looking for something that is pratical but not overly concerned with appearance. These are plastic and look cheap. However, the do the job. I have them in a closet hanging so no one see's them. If you are looking for something that will  be seen you might want to go for a more expensive option.

One of the best bubble bars I have had. I have gone through many of the blue ones that have to be so careful with as they will snap with the slightest touch. This is great because you can bend it to suit your needs. It produces just the right amount of small bubbles. 6 months and still going strong! I have had no issues with it clogging.

I was so impressed with this plant. It really looks great in my tank. I have a 40 gallon. I had to trim it down a bit because of the height but that was a simple fix. My fish love it. The little guys will sit on the leaves and just hang out. It is very realistic looking as it waves back and forth in the tank. If I had a bigger tank I would have more than one.

Very professional looking notebook. I needed this for meetings with upper management. The front is sleek in design. There is a table of contents. On the front of it you can detail the project you are working on. My husband saw it and immediately ordered one. I will be ordering more.
Liter

I was so excited when this arrived. It turned out to be a nightmare. After over 30 minutes of trying to get it on the back of the tank it had creases in it that could be seen. I would like to say this could be the result of user error but I have 3 fish tanks and have all my life. This was the hardest one I have ever tried to apply.

I love these! They are great for so many things. I usually buy in bulk, so I might have a bottle of 500 pills. This way I can place the huge bottle in our storage closet and have this smaller vial in the medicine cabinet. Just be sure to label them. They are not child proof in anyway so keep that in mind. I can mix spices in it, dissolve my dogs medication in them. There are so many different uses.

I had always heard such great things about this product so I decided to give it a try. It was so incredibly greasy. I had to wash and wash my face to get it off. Even after that I still felt that it was on my face. I have sensitive skin so I don't want to use anything that would clog my pores. I feel this product would indeed do that.

Looks awesome in my tank. It matches the rest of my house decor. You do need to rinse it. The best way is to punch a bunch of holes in the bag with a knife. Then cut open the bag and set in the bathtub and let water run through until clear. Color has stayed in tact for the 6 months I've had it.
I really really wanted to like these. I have a corgi and she would have looked adorable. Unfortunately they don't stay. The clips are not strong enough. One slight shake and they were out.
Love how this looks in my tank! Adds a very expensive look.

I was thankfully blessed with a pretty face. In return for that I was handed the ugliest feet ever! I have tried everything. I stopped going to get pedicures because it was so embarrassing. No sandals and I live in Florida. NOT ANYMORE. I received this gem and opened it right away. I can't believe I'm going to do this, but I'm posting before and after pictures. I am amazed! These results after one use.
This is absolutely the best thing ever! I LOVE LOVE LOVE it! HOWEVER- you can buy this at walmart for $3.99.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.I received a copy to facilitate my  review. The opinions expressed here are my own. This new author has a grasp on what it takes to be a great writer. Her characters are well drawn. Simon the main character is one you cheer on from the beginning. His best friend Derek is one I found myself going back and forth. between loving and hating. In my opinion, anytime a writer can make you love a character that you want to hate for their actions. they are successful.  The action scenes are just that, full of action. The reader goes from one conflict to the next. The tension is kept tight from beginning to end. I had to keep reading once I began it because I needed to know how Simon was going to handle situations. Would he be able to stay strong? Would he be able to keep friendships intact?  What happens when you have to make those tough life decisions?  I have to say I've known the author for several years. I knew this book was within her.  I knew she had talent.  I could never have imagined just how gifted a writer she is until I read this book.

I received this item in exchange for my honest review.  This is a fantastic gadget.  It is great not only for strawberries, but also for tomatoes. It very simple to use. Push the green plunger down place it in the top of the strawberry or tomato, release plunger and I twisted it as I pulled it out.  I do recommend you use firm strawberries as the ones I used it on were not quite as firm.  I love this took and I'm sure I'll find other uses for it.

From the moment I began reading this book I had several thoughts go through my head. The first was howsorry I felt for James.  As a teacher I've actually heard parents tell their kids they hated them and wished they'd never been born. I've heard them blame the father's. This book immediately resonated with me as I am sure it will with so many of my students. The author has commented that his ideas came from several places, especially his favorite book, "The Phantom Tollbooth".  I can see how the worlds resemble each other.  I loved this world. It is a world I was very familiar with.  My students have a difficult time believing there was a time I didn't believe in myself. I considered myself no one special. I would try on occasion to better myself, only to have someone say something that made me feel like I was only average. James is whisked away to the land of Average where he is to be tested to see if he is to be their next king.  I thought it funny that he wanted to excel at being average because he thought that was the best he could hope for. His journey to find out what happened to the last king will change his life in ways he never saw coming.  I think this should be required reading in every class, in every school.  There are so many people out there like James who need the message in this book.  The funny thing is, at age 57, there were lessons I could still learn. Learning to step above seeing yourself as just average or not worth anything for some of us in some situations is an on-going process.  I will definitely recommend this book to my fellow teachers and readers, and parents.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Like the author, I grew up reading mysteries. It has always been my favorite genre. When I was first approached about reading and reviewing this book I was surprise to learn I had so much in common with the author My husband has done some stained glass work  and he turns pens. We've both be involved in some of the same things. Then we learned she lives just north of us and her story takes place in St. Petersburg, FL, less than an hour north of us.  I loved the way she gives so much information about working with glass. Books like this often lead people to learn more about things like working with glass.  My favorite thing about the book is that Savannah must try to unravel the clues left by her father.  She has created characters that you come to care about including Suzy, the service dog.  It is brought to a satisfying conclusion and gets you ready for the sequel "Shards of Murder" which will be out sometime next year.  I have to say that I really enjoyed this and will recommend it to all those who love mysteries. This is an author you want to keep your eye on.

When it comes to authors who write about nutrition, Shir Guez is my favorite. This is not your common picture book. This is a book for parents to read to their older children or for them to read on their own. I loved this book because it teaches about different fruits and their importace to our bodies. One of the reasons I love her books is I always learn something new. This book was no different. She spoke about the Lychee fruit.  I actually found some in an Amish market a couple of months back and loved them. Since I have put more fruit in my daily diet it is great to know how these fruits help my body.  An excellent book I will recommend to all of my friends.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.This is a great story to tell your young children when they ask where they came from. It doesn't answer the physical question, but it does let them know that a lot of thoughts, love and planning went into making them. I really enjoyed this book.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Story 25 finds Oliver with his owl friend Ollie. Ollie Owl was the wisest creature in the forest. He would sit on Oliver's porch and creatures from the forest would come to him for advice. When Oliver's ring goes missing Ollie tells him how to figure out where his ring is.Story 26 Oliver receives a note his sister has had kittens. She would like him to visit. This means he and his friends will need to travel across a desert. Read to find out what happens to them on their trip.Story 27 Oliver visits a local castle just to explore it. On this trip he meets a lonely ghost who lives in the castle. He plays cards with him and several others who live there. He agrees to return if they agree to help him with Trick-or-Treat. Is this a good idea?  Read to find out.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Story 22 finds Oliver and his friends on a train ride adventure. They are taken through many fantastic lands and find themselves on a rollercoaster.Story 23 finds Oliver with a case of the hiccups. The only way he can get rid of them is to climb a mountain where a special bird lives. Their babies are born with hiccups and need the nectar from a special flower. Follow Oliver on this adventure.Story 24 Oliver is spending time with Joey while his mom goes shopping. After eating breakfast they go out on a boat to go fishing. Follow them on this fishing adventure.

Ana Franco has created a story for all ages.  She has taken mythology and turned it on its head.For fans of the Percy Jackson series they will find a friend in this book.  You have two orphanages separated by gender.  When Kitty shows up at the girls orphanage and is accepted in, she learns a fantastic secret about the teens you will meet in this book.  Although they have everyday names like Andrew, Anna, Natalie and Thomas they are in reality gods and goddesses.  The author has combined several different myths to create this story. You have of course a couple of gods who are up to no good.  There were some liberties taken with the gods in her story.  I like that.  I hate having the same thing rehashed in different stories.  For those who are not familiar with the different myths some back story would have helped.  That would be my only suggestion.  Over all I really enjoyed the book and can say with all honesty that this is an author I will recommend to students and one I will be watching for more great books.I received a copyt to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.

I received a copy to facilitate my review, The opinions expressed here are my own.One of the hardest things for kids to understand is the concept of time. A young boy in a village keeps hearing phrases about time: "running out of time", "living on borrowed time". He believes if he can stop the hands of the church clock that everyone will have all the time they need. Read this wonderful book where this author addresses this issue and see what lesson young Anthony learns.I would definitely read more by this author.

I was intrigued by the premise of this book and was thrilled once I started it.  As a teacher I see kids kids like Alex, Roy and their friends every year.  I have always fought for those students who have been told over and over that they are stupid or a loser.  That might be why I start each year off reading a book with the class called "Loser" by Jerry Spinelli.  These kids need to know that they are not losers.  Alex and his friends have problems yet there is a part of them that are coping with the bullying and name calling.  A part of them realize they are not losers.Alex is in  a wheelchair because he has spina bifida.  He also has the ability to "spin" people. This means he can take their pain and heal them. Having dreamed about his parent's death the day before it happened and being pushed from one foster home after another because of his "strange ability", he finds himself in the worst foster home yet.  His foster mother is cruel and abusive and knows about his "gift".  She want to make money off of him. When Alex dreams about his teacher's death and it comes true he finds he is in the crosshairs of some very evil people.  They will do whatever it takes to get to him.  Along the way he learns a truth about his family. I don't want to give it away because I never saw it coming and want you to be just as surprised. Alex learns exactly what it means to have true friends.I read this book the last day of school since we had nothing for the students to do in the morning. My afternoon was mine as I'd already cleaned up my room.  This was a perfect way to end my school year by relaxing with a great book.  I read this in electronic form.  I will definitely purchase a copy for my shelves.  I will mark it as more mature because of the language used.  I could see this as a movie in my head.  The author is great with his descriptions.  I felt fear, I felt the pain some of them felt.  I will definitely check out more books by this author.

I received a copy to review. The opinions expressed here are my own.If you have ever had a desire to be an Air Force Pilot, then this is the book for you. It is full of wonderful information as well as great pictures. The author makes it clear you must meet certain requirements to be accepted as a pilot. As a teacher I really liked the fact he made it clear how important getting an education is. I never knew how much was involved in becoming a pilot of any type. I also had no idea there were so many types of Air Force aircraft.  This is sad because my brother retired from the Air Force. He was one who loaded cargo planes.  There is information on the types of guns and missiles each carry, and how fast they can go. The book tells you what each type of aircraft is used for.  This is a book I would be proud to give to kids. If it ever comes out in physical format it will be a welcome addition to my nonfiction shelf in my classroom. The author did a phenomenal job of gathering all of the information and putting it in a format that will entice anyone.

I received a copy to review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Alexander Pig, Mycroft Zebra and Pim Hedgehog live in the Littel Green Forest. The three friends decide they need to go on an adventure. They decide teh best place to go is camping at Dog-Rose Camp. There are no dogs there. They go home to pack. Mycroft and Pim wait at the train station for Alexander. Finally a taxi arrives and Alexander steps out in a fancy suit.  They get to the camp and set up the tent. While Mycroft is drinking a cup of tea, Pim goes to get firewood. Alexander takes out a lobster to eat. The lobster pinches him.  He keeps making up stories and when they finally go to bed he has a nightmare and sleepwalks.  What will happen to Alexander?

I received a copy to review. The opinions expressed here are my own.One day Pim the Hedgehog decides he needs to go grocery shopping. He leaves his house a mess.  Alexader the pig and Mycroft the Zebra decide they would like to go fishing and they go to Pim's house to invite him.  When they get there the house is unlocked. They see the mess, a story on the table about a kidnapped sheep and then they can't find Pim. They decide he must have been Hedgehog-napped.  What will they do to get their friend back?  A very cute book about friendship.

I received a copy to review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Jack is a very talented young boy. He plays multiple instruments. He plays the trombone, the piano and the guitar.  Everyone thinks he will be a star one day. He doesn't care about being a star. He writes his music for himself. It is what takes him to other places. They are his words. His father gets sick and ends up in the hospital.  He writes special music and brings it to his father and his father begins to get better faster. He starts to play music for others in the hospital. When they go home he decides to play for the people.  He has learned that his music is special and can do amazing things like help people heal both physically and mentally and can bring back wonderful memories.  This book is great at teaching how special music can be.

I received a copy to reviw. The opinions expressed here are my own.This is an absolutely wonderful book. Santa has been delivering toys for years.  He is disappointed that he no longer gets to meet with the boys and girls. One night when he is delivering his last gift to his last house he sees a young boy peeking around the corner.  They sit and talk for a long time. Ben gives Santa ideas on gifts.  The next year Santa not only meets Ben, but he wakes up a couple of children. He does this for years. Finally, Ben gives him the idea that he can meet more children if he goes into the stores around Christmas time.  He begins this but soon he and everyone at the North Pole are stretched to the max.  How will Santa solve this problem?  Will Ben be able to help him?  This is one of the most charming Christmas stories about Santa I have read in a long time. I will be recommending it to everyone I meet.  My all time favorite Children's Christmas Book is the "Polar Express". This book has now become my second favorite.  This is the type of book that I will buy for my children to read to their children. I can't recommend it high enough.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.I loved the extras that came with this coloring book. I'm ot into meditation, yet there is information about the connections between meditation and mandalas for those who are into meditation. Waht I found extremely interesting was a chart she had that is a color guide that goes into the meaning of colors.  I have always associated color with moods so this was just a great tool for me. The pictures go from the very simple that you could use crayons on, to the very complex that you will need colored pencils or very fine markers.  The thing that impressed me most about this coloring book was that it came in the form of an ebook. That means that I will be able to print pictures over and over and over, unlike physical coloring books that once you have colored all of the pages you are done.  I highly recommend this coloring book.

These two authors are firefighters in real life. They have written a story about a young boy and his mother who visit their uncle at the firestation where he works. His uncle lets him sit in the fire truck, turn on the lights and then has him help him with the hoses. He teaches him many things about the hoses and how difficult it is to learn to use it the first time. When he talked about hanging up the hoses to dry I asked my husband, a former firefighter about it. He said not all of them do. Some of them lay them out to dry. He said they need to wash the dirt and ash off and let them dry to make them last longer. I hope there are more stories about the life of a firefighter. These are perfect for young kids who think they would like to be a firefighter and for those like me who just like to learn new things.I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinion expressed here is my own.

I love this purse. This is the second one I have received from this company. The first was a canvas hobo bag. This one has an elegant look to it.  I was actually surprised by the amount of space inside. There were several pockets inside to carry all the things that I need.  There are two small pockets on one side of the inside of the purse. The other side of the inside has an open pocket and a zippered pocket.  The you have the entire opens space in the middle of the bag. There is a small zippered pocket on the back outside of the purse.  There was a very unique pocket on the front. If you look at the picture you will notice a real small zieer on each side of the front. The space actually goes from one zipper to the other inside. I decided I could carry pens or small items there and I would be able to unzip either pocket to to extricate what I needed. the metal detail on the front almost looks like rhinestones in it. There are none.  This is a very classy purse and one I am happy to carry. I have never had more than one purse at a time.  I find it amazing that through this company I have found two high quality purses that I really like, and that I get so many compliments on.I received this product in exchange for an honest review. The opinions expressed here are my own.

I received this product for review. The opinions expressed here are my own.I am not hte most tech savvy person so I really need to have explicit directions.  In this case I felt the directions could have been much better.  I actually needed the assistance of my son and son-in-law, who never even looked at the directions. Turning it on and navigating was not too difficult as there were pictures which helped this visual learner.  I was able to download music by dragging music from my computer to the folder that popped up when I used the cable that came with it to attach it to my computer.  It was no different than using my Kindle. The video was cute and funny. I still don't know how to add a video to it. I do know that the video was bright and vibrant. The sound quality was good, but that was using my own headphones. I have very tiny ears and had trouble getting the earphones that came with it to stay in. I next tried out the games.  There were 3 or 4 on there.  Don't know if you can add any more or not. Doesn't matter because I am just as bad with them on this device as I am on any other device. "A Dog's Tale" by Mark Twain was the book that was loaded.  Once again my complaint was that I didn't know how to download other books. I would not use that functio because the screen is so small that it caused the formatting to be off. With my vision issues the tiny screen made it difficult to read on this device. I will say that for the price they are charging and the size, shape and ease of carrying it and ability to download and listen to my music on the go that it is worth the price.  I would not give this to anyone that I know will not be gentle with it because I felt like it was a little bit flimsy. That may just be my impression, but it will work for me.

As I prepare for next school year I've once again gone to these wonderful prompts by Bryan Cohen.  One of my favorites of this set is his "Four Seasons of Creative Writing".  Out of these five books, this is the one that is one of the best for teachers to use with their students. You may be wondering why.  He has it set up by seasons, which is a plus for me as a teacher.  I can find just right prompts for each of the seasons.  I love his 'Five Senses' and 'Mixed Bag'.  I can take the prompt the way it is or I can tweak it.  Often the students will take one of the prompts I've given and make their own tweak to it to make it their own.  In my opinion any writing prompt that pushes a student to make the prompt their own is top notch. Need a topic for your blog?  Bryan has a book for that as well. I've found these useful in my own writing as well as in my classroom. It is for this reason I highly recommend these to anyone who does any type of writing.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Imagine growing up in a world where you can see God’s beauty all around you and follow your heart.  Now imagine that world is crushed by the death of a loved one.  Jessamine Brady lived in that world with her grandmother until the age of 10. When her grandmother died the Shaker community took her in.  This is where I really had to pay attention. I’d heard of the Shakers but really didn’t know anything about them.  I thought they were like the Amish.  Boy was I wrong.  I felt their beliefs were way out there, especially their belief about remaining celibate.  Men and women were equal in all ways.  They stayed separate.  They considered marriage  and procreation a sin.  I kept wondering how a people could get so messed up.  Jessamine remembers her life outside of the Shakers.  When she and her sister find a man in the woods and bring him back because he is injured, things change.  They are immediately drawn to each other. Tristan had lost his memory. When he gets it back he tells no one hoping to find out who tried to kill him.  However, the closer he and Jessamine get the more the Shakers are ready to send him packing.  That is exactly what happens and Jessamine goes with him. Tristin’s parents have made a marriage arrangement to save their finances.  Will Tristin and Jessamine stay together? If he leaves will she stay in this world or go back to the Shaker world?  If you want these answers you will definitely need to read the book for yourself.  It was definitely a different take on religion. The author did an excellent job of presenting the history of that time period.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The Opinions expressed here are my own.If you haven’t read the first two books in this series “The Thorn” and “The Judgment” I would suggest you do.Briefly you have Rose Kauffman who was taking care of her mother after a buggy accident.  You have her sister Hen and her five year old daughter Mattie Sue. Hen had married an Englisher and then gone back home during which time her husband began divorce proceeding that threatened her custody of her daughter. Then there was her husbands car accident.  Rosie and her boyfriend Silas have had an on again, off again relationship.  Then there is Nick, the bishops adopted son who came from the English world and seems to have left for it again after the bishop’s son Christian is killed in an accident. Does Rosie love Silas or does she love Nick? Does Silas love Rosie or does he love Rehbeka?  All of that drama and more happened in the first two books.In this third book in the series, Beverly Lewis has tied up all of the loose ends. Rosie’s mother is finally going to have the back surgery that will hopefully alleviate the terrible pain she has been in for years.  Rosie is still having relationship issues. She turns Silas loose, but now there is another guy in the picture named Isaac.  Then Nick returns. Because of all that went on with the Bishop’s sons, he has been “silenced”. I found it inspiring that it was the Bishop God used to reach Hen’s husband.  He had made it clear he wanted nothing to do with the Amish and their ways. After being temporarily blinded and having to stay in the Amish community, thing have changed.  So now you are wondering what exactly has changed yes?  Well this is where I tell you that once again Beverly Lewis has done an excellent job of storytelling and that you really must read the book to find out how all of these conflicts were fixed or not.  This is another highly recommended series by a great author.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.This is the second book in the “Season’s of Grace” series. Grace Byler is dealing with so much in her life.  Her mother mysteriously left and didn’t tell anyone why.  Something had been bothering her for quite some time.  Grace is trying to help her father and around the house.  Then there is Heather, a young English woman who finally confides in Grace.  He lost her adoptive mom to cancer and now she has cancer. Her father wants her to take chemo like her mother, but she prefers to try naturopathy. She learns she was adopted from an Amish family and would like to find more.Grace’s father is a quiet man and confused with his wife’s behavior. Their bishop is threatening to shun her if she doesn’t return soon.  One thing Grace’s father is pretty sure of is that his in-laws know something about why Lettie left, but won’t speak of it. Grace breaks up with Henry and finds she suddenly has the attention of another young man named Yonnie.  There is even a problem with this situation. Her best friends has eyes for Yonnie and is upset with Grace.In my opinion Grace was aptly named. She handles all of these situations with grace.  Nothing is resolved by the end of the book, yet you get a pretty good idea where this is heading and what some of the outcomes will be. Beverly Lewis has once again done an excellent job of creating a situation that will capture you and hold you until the end of the series.  I definitely recommend this book.

I loved this sequel to 84 Ribbons.  After her injury Marta returns home.  At first she just hangs out around the house, most days in her robe.  She still has an issue with diet pills.  Steve has been a big support throughout this whole thing.  He is still supportive when she makes a mistake that could ruin their relationship.  Marta’s biggest issue is trying to figure out what she wants to do with her life.  Before the accident she thought she had her whole life mapped out before her.  Now she is so confused.  What starts out as helping her mother at the dance studio, turns into so much more?  Will this be what it takes for her to straighten out her life?  When she meets the parent of one of her students she feels conflicted.  Will she still stay with Steve, or will her life take her down a different path?  At times I felt annoyed at her indecision.  I think I felt that way because I am a person who has a difficult time making decisions. Once I’ve made the decision the commitment is there 110%.  I know this is how Marta felt. I really enjoyed this book and would recommend it to those who love the world of dance or love to read about the world of dance.  This book didn’t focus on Marta’s dance so much as her dance with life changes. An excellent book.I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.

Abigail loved helping deliver babies. Since she could only go so far in school she was an unlicensed midwife who worked with the local doctor. Unfortunately the one night the doctor is needed most, he is unable to help.  Abigail goes to help a young mother deliver her baby.  She tries to get the mother to go to the hospital, but she refuses. Abigail delivers the baby, but loses the mother.When the authorities find out that Abigail was not licensed, she is arrested for practicing medicine without a license and several other things. To add to her pain, her father, a bishop won’t come to the jail to see her, she can’t make bail because the community won’t help.  At this point I probably would have felt betrayed by everyone.  Abigail spends her time reading her Bible and praying.  At home her sister has come to stay in her house to help Abigail’s husband with the children and the household duties.  While helping out she meets a young man who works on the farm.  Everyone thinks Isaiah is mentally not all there. In reality he is deaf and very smart.  Catherine is aware of this and attracted to him.This is a great story.  There are themes of love, forgiveness and finding God in the midst of your trials.  Lessons of learning that God accepts us just the way we are where we are.  Mary Ellis is great at creating such realistic stories that tug at the heartstrings yet have so many hidden messages and lessons that we all need to hear.  You could never say her stories are preachy because they are definitely not.  This is one Amish fiction author you really need to read.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.All is not harmonious in Harmony Main for the main characters in this story.  When Amy and Nora King lose their parents in a house fire, their younger siblings go to live with relatives and they go with Amy’s future husband to Harmony, Maine. John’s brother is the minister in Harmony.  He decides that Amy and John need to wait a while so that Amy can properly grieve her  parent’s death. Things are so different in Harmony.  They are a stricter community.  Amy is willing to try to fit in. Nora on the other hand has difficulty.  Their clothes are too bright so they must make new ones to fit in with the drab colors of their new community.  Where they would have had singings and buggy rides while courting, that is all banned in this community.  For Nora it mean no Rumspringa, which is also banned. I applaud Amy for trying so hard to fit in to her new community. I also applaud her trying to help Sally, the minister’s wife who doesn’t feel like she fits in with the other women.  Nora, I wanted to smack her for acting like a spoiled brat.  When John’s younger brother Elam, the rebellious one shows up, he takes Nora down that path as well.  Amy learns that she has an aunt who was shunned leaving nearby. She makes plans to meet with her and learns that is also forbidden.  Will she follow the rules or follow her heart? Will Nora ever settle down and stop causing so much trouble?  Will John and Amy finally get married? The answers to these questions are waiting for you  in the book.I have to say the only character I really had a hard time liking was John.  He came across as too strong and almost unforgiving in some of the things he did. However, like all of her other books, I really enjoyed this and would definitely recommend it to those who love reading Amish Fiction.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.Amish values is a book that should be read by any family that is looking to improve their family dynamics. The one thing I’ve always admired about the Amish is their sense of family and what is truly important.  One thing that really stood out is how much family means to them.  They love their children, but do not spoil them the way we who are not Amish do.  For this reason they don’t grow up feeling like we, the parents owe them everything they desire. They raise their family around their faith.  God is the center of the home. The author shows us through examples and stories of Amish families. This is not a book where the author spouts off, “do this or that  to get this or that”.I think one of the reasons I relish their lifestyle so much is because I pretty much grew up that way.  We are not and never were Amish. Yet, growing up on a farm with all of our duties were so similar to the Amish lifestyle.  I was never raised to expect anything except what God gave us. I worked hard as did all of my family.  It carried over to my own children, even though we left the farm behind many years ago.  My parents made sure that God was the center of our life. We started our morning with devotions and we ended our evening with devotions. I was well prepared for my day ahead.This book, with all of its examples and proverbs at the beginning of each chapter, shows that we can go back to a simpler life, yet not as structured as the Amish live, and still come out with some of the same great results.

Take a trip through rural India. Learn about it culture and especially its classical music. Meet Kalu, a young boy who lives on the streets. To survive he runs errands.  It was hard to imagine that there could be anyone worse off than he was. Kalu has a friend named Bal.  I was sickened to learn his family sold him.  He had even less than Kalu had. Kalu had a talent that helped him improve his life.  He was gifted at playing the flute.  This ability  gets him noticed. It also is what helps him get an education.  As he travels we are shown the sights and sounds of life in rural India.  The descriptions are so vivid you get the image in your head and it stays with you. Just because he is discovered doesn’t mean trust comes easily to him.  Hope is something he tries to hang onto, but it is difficult when there has been so much pain in a small life. A great book from many aspects, learning about India and its classical music, learning about the lives of those who are on the lost rung of the caste system. I’ve heard stories from some of my Indian students, but this book brought it so much clearer.  A great book to read and learn from.  I recommend you read the book to see just how his life was changed and who it was that helped bring about that change.

I received a copy to facilitate my review. The opinions expressed here are my own.When I was asked to review this book I jumped on it.  I am always looking for adult coloring pages to help me relax.  I have a folder of individual coloring sheets I have found online to download. When I clicked on the link to look at this book I was surprised to see it was an ebook.  My first concern was how I was supposed to color the book.  The end of the book has a link to download the PDF version. I did that and immediately picked out four pictures to color.  These pictures are fun and whimsical as you can see from the cover above. I printed a whimsical cat, owl, a fun beachy type picture and a picture with mushrooms and leaves that reminded me of something from the 70s.  I enjoyed coloring the pictures.  The other thing I like about this book is that at times my granddaughter wants to color pictures like this. She's never been one to color Disney type pictures.  I know that this is something she would want to color as well.  I definitely will recommend this book. If I have a favorite picture all I have to do is print it over again.

Wow, these are some heavy duty hex wrenches. They fit perfectly into their separate cases and have everything I will ever need and more. I decided since I have to use a hex now and then I might as well get a quality set. This is definitely above and beyond what I need, but I did want some high quality wrenches. The goldguard and chromium finishes look very elegant and pragmantic at the same time. A beautiful set here, machined from what I can see near perfectly. The special balldriver ends are a nice touch. Everything about this set is quality. Top notch tools.

Very nice snips that have no problems for me. They have the solid Irwin design and awesome grips I have come to know. Mine are the normal yellow and blue color. They lock up nicely and were well-oiled from the shop. Tried them out on some tin and everything went well. Nothing bad to say here. Sharp and decent snips for a good price.

These are my favorite tongs so far. They have a nice, solid weight to them, lock up easily, and for the most part are all metal. The rubber grips work well and seem sturdy enough for use. The grips themselves do well in gripping just about any type of meat product or grill food. The lock design works flawlessly for me. The tongs have a tiny space between them when fully locked. All in all nothing wrong these tongs at all. Good design.

These are hands down the best 8 knives you will get for 25 bucks. I haven't seen any better for even remotely this price. For me, my mother needed some steak knives to replace some horribly old Chicago ones from about the 90s. I didn't want to spend too much and I didn't want to buy junk. I was about to get the Henckel ones for 20 for 4 and then I came across these.... they do the job very well.They have a nice weight to them and come out of the box with sharpness and decent design. No, you will not mistake these for steak knives that are 20 dollars a piece or more, but they are a good imitation. Full tang, decent rivets, and a solid, sharp blade. They look a little cheaply made.... but except for that there is nothing in this price range that competes. Do not dishwash. They are marked with "Stainless Steel" on them.

So far I have zero problems with this scale. It is very elegant and well made and I cannot find anything truly wrong with it. Weight could be a pound or so off from I guess what you might call a perfect scale but that doesn't bother me much. This is a consistent scale. I can get on and off the scale and it does not register different weights like the claims of some reviewers here. At least for me. The blue LED is perfect. The scale requires no tapping and is a no-nonsense type of scale with a beautiful glass finish. It's decently heavy but thin and has some padded feet for hard surfaces. You can switch pounds out for kilograms if you need. I can't give it less than 5 stars because so far it has done nothing wrong. I'll update with battery life at some point.

Back in the heyday when Grisham was all the rage they were making some pretty good films from his populist novels. And here we get three of the better ones. It depends on how you look at it but A Time To Kill is probably the most powerful, though, The Client gives it a run for its money at times. Pelican Brief is also not a bad film just not quite on the same level. All three here have bluray transfers that are pretty decent for older catalogue titles.I cannot see anyone being truly disappointed with this budget release, though, some light DNR is evident most often in PB, probably the least important of the trio offered here. Softness is apparent at times from old masters and I take it lower bitrates. The Client has the only MPEG4 transfer with the others getting VC1 near the 20Mbps line.... Nothing that is going to rock your socks for sure but for 10 bucks or so it is a good deal. Recommended.

This is actually, probably, how a modern pop breakup album should sound. Local H keeps on trucking and to be honest their work is pretty solid. Certainly, this is probably not as good as a couple of the 90s albums but it's endearing in a way and never outstays its welcome. The songs are actually pretty catchy and this is basically what you get when a band that makes its best album in their earlier years stays relevant in the alternative genre or whatever the hell you want to label Local H. Unlike Weezer, as another reviewer pointed out, these guys actually still make decent music. I didn't find anything super great on here but most of it was above average and none of it stuck out as weak. It's good. poppy rock about heartbreak.

This is a very nice collection of guitar pieces tied together by the excellent title track. Ackerman here creates an original mood that never wavers or recedes in the wake of too much complexity or too little movement. Seattle is positively stunning! An upbeat and ambitious track that perfectly recreates the busy rhythms of the city, picking up the record right as it starts to wane after the expressive mellow Sunday Rain. The title track is poignant and nostalgic in all the right places and a true gem. I don't really have anything negative to say about the album. It's a new favorite. I recommend anyone into guitar in general to check it out. Just know what to expect here.

My rig was 4 years old and had a decent paste before, I cannot remember what was used as I didn't apply it, but things were getting a little too hot for my comfort on load after 4 years. This one seems about on target so far. Looks to be about 1-4 degrees difference on idle and more on load.I tested Prime 95 a little bit--I don't really need these types of stress tests as I never see these loads in reality--and things were not heating up to 80 degrees at all, or at least not in the time I used the program. I would bet my OC is a tiny bit unstable in Prime, but even for gaming it is just about perfect and the temps were reduced, telling me I probably should have done the thermal paste a bit sooner.The paste was a nice consistency and spread fairly easily. I used the spreader included with the package and tried not to put too much on the CPU heatsink. I probably used about a larger pea size. It seemed fine and as a plus this product is not reactive anyway and will not ruin your motherboard if you get a little bit of overspread after screwing in your cooler. All in all a solid purchase. Curing is mostly done at this point and the rig is definitely running slightly cooler than it was before.
