It was smart to dial in a lock position, assuming people use it, this is very helpful..... making the lock integrated with the legs would have been a nice safety feature to assure when the unit is closed down, it will lock....I think some people will struggle with the concept here.... as u set down the laser with its wobbly legs, u have this desire to make it level, but that is not required, as its self leveling (within  4 deg surface vs. level)  However, when you then spin the unit, u then have to wait for the plumb bob to settle, which takes some time... so pros n cons to this method...If there is one area I would like to see this product improved...its the ability to move the horizontal line up/down, without moving the unit up / down..this might be hard to accomplish at this price point...but u immediately desire this, unless u are only working with the vertical line.  Regardless, there is always work arounds, like measuring, story sticks, etc.Overall, clever product, fits a niche in the laser level market... I have higher quality levelers, which cost 5-10x what this cost...so I always try to review products for their "value", or price vs. performance...

this is an incredible replica of the early 1900's binocs... It requires a lot of precision optics and machining to make a product like this...only Nikon or Canon could make such a product and sell it for this low price point.  However, as a pair of useful Binocs, they are average at best... why?  A few reasons.... first, the light is folded through an extra prism to accommodate this design... which can slightly degrade the image quality.  Next, for this price, u don't get Zeiss like glass, so contrast is mediocre at best.  The exit pupil is 2.5mm, so it requires perfect alignment with your eye pupil in sunlight, when your pupil is stopped down to about 2-2.5mm.  So you get a lot of black-out effect, or vignetting whereas the exit pupil (light circle from binocs)  is missing your eye pupil opening...  The eye relief is very short, not good for eyeglass wearers.So, to be fair...if you want this for your coffee table as a conversation piece, I would give it 5 stars, as its truly an amazing replica for the price.  But if your looking for a good usable pair of 6x binocs, these will have inferior views to most binocs in this price range, or even much less.  U are paying for added prisms, and sophisticated metal machining....Also, since the light path does not extend outward like normal binocs of this size, i.e. two straight tube monoculars.... the point at which you hold the binocs is very close to your eyes, vs. further away from your body...this makes keeping them still very difficult.  The further out you hold the binocs, the less effect hand shake as on the image.  double the hold distance, u cut the shake effect in half, the relationship is linear.  Even at 6x, I have a horrible time holding the image still vs. tubular binocs at 6x.

What do I love about X8?  You own it!  No monthly subscription fee like Photoshop!  And Correll has come a long way in this game, I no longer consider PS Pro inferior to PHotoshop.... of course, for the consumer, or prosumer level... at the prof. level, PHotoshop surely has some benefits, but I no longer am a pro, so don't need every bell and whistle to edit photos anymore....Some good reviews here, so I won't repeat much of what has been written... I would consider x8's user interface very intuitive, better than most of Adobes products.  They have some unique features which is described above in the features section.  Loaded first try on Windows 7 machine... it might take me some time to really dig into the details of this...but overall, I like it enough where I might pull the plug on Lightroom and PS!  will try to update in a few weeks after I get some more mileage on it...

I am rating this product on not just the powder, but how it makes me feel.  These products are hard to rate based on purity, sourcing, etc. cause we know very little about those issues.I have a love hate relationship with MACA powder... at times, it really gives me a lift.  But I feel it builds up, and my body reacts with tolerance build up, then it becomes almost non effective, very similar to caff.  So now I have learned to use it "when needed" vs. every day... at least if you want the nrg boost benefits..  I am sure not everyone builds up tolerance to this, but, it something to pay attention to.  As for the other health benefits, I never noticed any, so hard to comment.The quality of this product seems acceptable to me, similar to other maca roots I have taken... they all have a slightly different smell...sometimes the same makers product smells different from batch to batch...its a natural product, so that is to be expected.. just like fruit, two pieces can look the same, one is delish, and the other taste rancid.  Mother nature does not have QC dept.  ;)Anyway, if you like to mix powders in your drinks, and u want a boost, or an alt. to caff, this is worth a try.

I use a lot of Vitamin World products... as well as Jarrows, and Thorne.  I like large national brands, they have more to loose if something goes wrong, so I suspect they have better quality controls.  I have been using this Curcumin for the past year, on and off, like most supplements, I get tired of taking them.  As many have read, this is suppose to be a miracle natural ingredient found in tumeric... there seems to be a mountain of evidence it reduces inflammation, and now, inflammation of the cells is new "cholesterol"... it makes sense, but as with all these buzz words, they often fade over time.  However, I tend to stick to the items whereas humans have been consuming them for thousands of years.... and although Tumeric has been consumed as a spice for all these years, its never been taken in massive quantities like we do with these supplements, i.e. where they extract a very small component of the tumeric and place it in a capsule....so humans could never consume this much Curcumin in the form of Tumeric as a spice.  Whether that has some negative effects, I guess science and trial and error will teach us.  Till then, like other posters have mentioned, I too am hedging my bet on this one.  I like the capsules... they are LARGE, but, its required to get the volume of Curcumin required...so if you have a small throat, beware... drink lots of water first, to wet the slide ;)

I have about 6 of these in my garage and office,  where I am always short on outlets.  I would say Woods makes one of the better units in the "consumer" market.  For even better office protection, Belkin units are even more robust and offer additional protection...expect to pay up to 2x more.  This is for outlets only, not phone, dsl, ethernet, etc.  If you need that protection as well, look for a multi use outlet.  For business use, there is even better units by GE, Belkin and others.One reviewer mentioned the outlets are too close together.... Considering there is 8 outlets on this model, I would say it was a fair compromise, as the last two outlets have large spacing, for larger transformers.  If they all had this much spacing, the unit would become too large.  they make short pigtail extenstions, like 15" that you can buy that solves this problem, so you take the extension, and plug in the transformers away from the 8-Outlet.  I think this is the right solution, so the outlets don't become over-sized for most peoples use.  Never had any problems with Woods units yet and plan on buying more as my office and garage keep expanding.  Woods IMO offers the most value for the dollar... u see their products in Home Depot, so that tells u the value they offer, as Home Depot buyers really scrutinize "value" of a product...

I am new to electric razors... Since they were on Vine, hard to resist trying to become a CONvert vs. my Gillette Fusion blades, which I love.  While the Philips is incredible with how well these products are designed, packaged... I only took 1 star away, cause, as good as this is, the best blades IMO still get a closer shave.  BUT, if that is NOT a big concern, I can see why these are gaining in popularity.  The fact u can shave without cream, is helpful and faster...  With the new Fusion blades, going against the grain provides a level of closeness that is tough to beat.The contour of the head is very nice...seems to fit everywhere nicely, very comfortable...ergnomics in the hand, surperb.  Cleans relatively easy, but I am sure after awhile, added stubble build up, the cleaning tank will be required.  The process seems a bit cumbersome for my limited attention span for things like this.  The sideburn attachment is very nice as well, lots of power, easy cutting.  A bit cumbersome to install though, so I would prob. not use it.  I have a small dedicated unit for $20, less fumbling around with changing heads.  Footprint is small.  Looks cool, thats for sure!There has been some issues with other Norelco users about reliability of the heads... I never used them enough to have this problem, as I always seem to resort back to blades.  But u would think, if they are unreliable, the cost of the new heads will make these electric shavers very costly to use.For me, the real benefit of this unit is a fast shave, without using cream... the downside is, not quite as close...but, sometimes that is not an issue for me.  So maybe that will be its place for me...

hard to imagine getting excited about a pencil sharpener...but, I did... mainly due to the cool factor... its fun watching the debris fly off the pencil.  Sharpens as well as any of my other 5 sharpeners ;)I think makers ran out of "what next" with pencil sharpeners, well, see-through case was the answer!  I only use standard Ticonderoga pencils, so not sure how it does with the non standard pencils... hopefully other reviewers will cover that....

While these are made for bottles, they can be used for anything that must take the rigors of abuse in the work place.  They are very strong and seem impervious to just about anything.  Tired of labels fading, tearing, wearing on items that gets lots of contact from people... so glad these were avail. on Vine, as I would have never thought to use them.  As with all Avery products, printing is a breeze... great web site too...

I have been using Flax seed oil since it was introduced over 25 years ago...some have very strong flavor... not usually tasty... but you consume Flax oil for Omega 3 health benefits..not flavor...I can NOT take fish oil supplements, so this is most Omega 3 I can consume, as its not abundant in many plant based foods.although maybe some find the Flax flavor tasty... most people would be happy if the taste of flax oil is tolerable...Alliga Flax oil is by far one of the least offensive ones I have used...and since its Organic and non gmo, I will switch over to this brand.  I am very surprised at the high heat rating.  Most Flax oils can not be heated as they de nature...I won't fry with it, unless on low heat, but will add it to soups...i often mix it with other oils, such as macadamia nut, for Omega 9.I do refrigerate my flax oil, as it seems flax oil spoils much faster than most other vegetable oils.Alligga charges a bit more, but the extra $ is well worth it considering they raised the max cooking temp, Organic and non GMO.. well done... Alligga has raised the bar on flax oil.

This is may first Swiss Legend Watch.  I do admit, I like collecting watches as they are my only form of Jewlery ;)As much as technology has marched forward, it seems analog watches are still as popular as ever, strange, huh... all those mechanicals never got replaced by high tech electronics.The packaging and storage case is superb, so are the instructions.  Although, I don't use a watch for much, other than glancing at it and telling time.  But if you like all the twist dials and small inner timers, this watch will not disappoint.  While a few other reviewers mentioned this watch is too large for most men... I would somewhat agree...while I prefer a large face dial, this one is adequate, but its the thickness makes it quite the beast on your wrist.  And it has some weight as well.... its noticeable.  So, for those sensitive to heavy watches or watches that "stand out" due to size, this is not a good fit for you.Time setting was a little different, but the instructions take you through it... I did try to experiment with the inner dials, and they are too small for me to see well... the date is small as well.  The blue tint in person, is NOT as strong as the picture suggests, it has a very slight blue tint, noticeable, but not overwhelming.... a nice touch IMO.When you look at this watch, at first glance to the average person who is not a watch enthusiast, it can be mistaken for a watch MUCH more expensive... as those watch enthusiasts know, similar looking watches can cost thousands.  The best switch watches today cost over 6 digits!  So, I would surely say it passes the bling test, if that is what you are after!  And at this price point, that says a lot.Overall, this is a nice watch for the price, IF, you like em big n heavy and a want bling on your wrist.  Its not for everyone for sure... but a LOT of watch for the dollar....

I used to print fine art prints using many different types of epson printers.  I think the company makes excellent products and always innnovating.  This product is no exception in the innovation area...they are getting ahead of the curve IMO.So, the marketplace finally tired of these constant small ink cartridge prices...with prices ranging from dirt cheap to very high for OEM.  Some printers had chips on the carts, so you could not use 3rd party.  Its the old, make money on the consumables concept.  Epsons response is large refillable ink jet printer.  Refilling is quite simple, if you can follow directions ;)  The print count is quite impressive, see above product description... now, whether this is reality, most people never check.  Regardless, its quite the convience vs. constantly changing carts which held very little ink.  The description states, equal to 20 carts... well, that is quite impressive.  I have not seen price of the ink bottles, but it has to be waaay more cost effeftive than carts.In return for not buying carts, the makers willl make less money on consumables....so I imagine Epson had to charge more for the printer as the consumable revenues would be way less... and I think this is the case, you get less features for the cost vs. "buy our cartridges" type machines.  Fair enough IMO.  For example, no LCD disiplay?  Build is solid, which is an Epson trademark vs. the low cost compeitors.  Did not set up Wifi, so can't comment on that....The scanner works EXCELLENT, both text and photos.... Epson knows scanners well, they make some nice dedicated photo and text scanners.  The printer works, well, like most ink jet printers, so nothing new there, prints look sharp and crisp.  Paper tray holds 100 sheets, a bit light IMO, but, then again, the footprint of the printer is small... which is a major factor these days in such crowded home offices.Overall, the unit performs very well.... is compact, quiet, and considering the low cost for ink over its life, surely offsets the small price premium you pay for the printer.  If you print a lot, the cost effectiveness alone would make the initial cost a non issue.

Wow!  First,  I weld as a hobby... I never owned a top notch helmet  like this, so its possible I am overwhelmed since I only have experience with lower cost masks.  This is my first auto darkening helmet as well, so what a treat.  I never knew this level of sophistication existed in welding Helmets.First, and most important is the ergononics... Once I got the adjustments right, it fit like a glove... no real pressure points, and most of all, the helmet is so light weight, I barely notice the weight vs. my other helmets.  I guess this really matters if you are welding all day...even my eye glasses I wear for my PC benefitted greatly by swtiching to Nikon lenses and ultra light frames, what a difference it makes on the bridge of your nose.  The mask can still get hot in the summer, so if you sweat a lot like me, you still need a head band to prevent the vewing area from getting wet.  Unless the helmet makers start installing AC systems,  this will always be a nuissance in hot weather.  Nothing unique to this maker.The auto darkening is quite the treat if you never experienced this before.  Damn, it darkens FAST!.  It is so much easier to work by not constantly flipping the mask, or filter, on and off to see when the welder is off.  The system does account for ambient light very well.  I have only used it in Weld mode, so I can't comment on the other modes.  I do appreciate how clear the viewing panel is... I imagine a lot of the cost of the helmet is in the viewing glass... to offer all these features and still be crystal clear is quite the engineering accomplishment.Excellent instructions, well written, nice to see this, so tired of illegible instructions.  Overall, very very impressed with the helmets performance!A friend of mine is a more serious welder, and he too was very impressed with the clarity, quick darkening, the modes of operation, and ergonomics.

What makes these chairs unique vs. all others I have used... is how FLAT they fold!  Less than 3", closer to 2.5"!  I am shocked the maker does not shine a spotlight on this feature, as in so many living quarters these days, space is at a serious premium.  4 of these together is 10-11".  The material is very nice plastic, has a slight granite appearance...and appears to wash easy, making them OK for outdoor use, vs. folding chairs with fabric on them.  The load capacity might be an issue if you are a big person, as the legs don't seem to thick... another reviewer mentioned 275lb load capacity, if so, that is impressive considering how lean the chairs are.  Will make great use of these folders... I have also used lots of Lifetime folding tables, and they have been very durable for indoor / outdoor use.

I owned one of the first versions of these when they came out 20 years ago....it still works today... was excited to see this updated version come up on Vine.  Well, its a bit better than the old version... faster steam times, love the foot on off pedal, nice size wheels for moving.  Very simple concept, steam removes wrinkles... but, lets get real here, not 100% of them like an iron will do.  So you pick and choose what to use it on.  Also, it is nearly always ready, assuming you have it in a place where its ready to use.Another reviewer struggled to get wrinkles out... I have a large board with fine carpet on the front, which you press the clothes against...without this, its much less effective.  It brings the action much closer to that of an iron, but will not make creases, of course.  Overall, a lot of value of the money, works great.  I always use distilled water too!

Love Avery labels... and while I am sure these would work great through a printer, my first task was to put them on large bins and mark whats in the bin... finally a BIG label!  I will have some great uses for these through my laser jet.....  amazing product line and support.  never been dissapointed with Avery products, been using them for 20+ years.

Just what the doctor ordered!  I wanted to turn a patio light on and off, and went through several photo cells, through time... bottom line, outside controls and devices, wear out from weather, sun, etc.  This little device is another innovation by Intermatic, who pioneered the mechanical time clock field.  It knows when to turn the lights on and off, as it has knowledge of when the sun sets and rises.  Finally, its put into a simple indoor device.  Brilliant...  its a bit deep vs. the switch, so cut any excess wire length from behind the switch.

Just love steam mops.  And Bissell often makes the best floor cleaning products...this mop is no exception.  Long cord, thank you Bissell.  Big tank enough to do my entire kitchen, dining and foyer.  Fast steam production.  2 pads, but u should buy extras.  With detachable steam tank and hose, u can clean / sterilize just about anything.  Very nicely design, snaps back in place very easily.  Very easy to assemble.  I use distilled water too keep sediments from building up and making the floor shine even more.  We have very hard water.  Can't think of anything to improve on this unit, the design engineers thought of everything!  Hoping its reliable, as its a keeper for sure.

This is my 3rd Defender case, previous on two phones.  If you mis handle your Ipad, this product is for you.  It will safe you from damage on most all drops.  Its that effective.  Installation is a breeze...having used them before, I know longer need to read instructions.  The unusual part of the Defender is the screen protector is integrated into the product, like a door, vs. a bleed on added screen, which always leaves bubbles.  U would think it would reduce the touch screen, but somehow, I have not noticed such...  I love how it doubles as a stand as well... excellent product, excellent design, great feel (not slippery)....If you are not clumsy, and do NOT drop your ipad often, this product might be overkill, as it is big and bulky.

Wahl seems to make the BEST electric clippers of any of the makers... I have been using these forever..  I love all the cutting length options this kit offers.  Awesome chord length, much appreciated vs. adding small extensions chords...  The cutting is prof. quality...super sharp blades, however, all blades dull over time, although it does say, self sharpening... regardless, u can prob. replace the blades if you use these enough...for home use on just a couple of people it could take years... blades typically dull very slowly.the benefit IMO of these clippers over the cordless type, is POWER....these clippers have a lot of power in them, which prob explains why they cut so much better the cordless type.  The cordless types also seem to die must faster.  Can't find any flaws of this product, specially at this price point... Kudos to Wahl...

I keep using and trying Thera products...what I like most about this mouthwash is... it has staying power!  Most mouthwashes, even the strong ones last for 15 minutes and seem to leave no trace...this one lasts almost an hour...i.e.  I can still feel the minty clean feeling... I think its the mix of xylitol and pepperment... they seem to compliment each other in a symbiotic way.  I like how it feels clean, but does NOT HURT your mouth, like the GOLD listerine type loaded with alcohol.  No harsh chemicals, and even though its mouthwash, which we spit out, there is obviously some residual that remains... great product, will continue using this... so happy it appeared on Vine for me to try!

Straight C (Absorbic Acid) kills my joints, I ache like crazy, been like this all of my life... I even avoid fruits high in C...its a condition called Fruit Acid Arthritis.  Remarkably this buffered version of Vit C does not bother my joints.. so I am a big fan, as Vit C is so critical for good health.  Thorne products are atop my list of vendors as they do NOT use magnesium Stearate in their caps... great company.

I have used the TheraBreath products for quite some time... mostly the mouthwashes... this is my first use of the toothpaste and I really like the way it feels.... it also has mostly natural ingredients... whether it helps with breath issues.. not really sure, I find all toothpastes help if I use them enough... i prefer to use products with less harmful ingredients...

I am an advid football "catch" player, granted, I am over the hills... but a football coming at u fast can hurt your hands ;)  While these are lineman gloves on Vine, I had to try a good pair of gloves and wow, no wonder all the NFL players wear these.. the quality of these gloves are amazing.  They almost feel like your own skin.  Well designed...  Now, I am curious how much different the receiving gloves are!

I love Avery labels, been using them for years....On my large shipments, I usually have printed on reg size paper and cut n clip to make a label.Then tape up the label with clear tape...While that system works fine...I really love how professional this label makes my shipments look... they are LARGE, so be sure it does not overwhelm your package.You can see through them a bit, which surprised me... not sure why Avery designed them this way.... not a major problem, just beware if you place label over high contrast background label... either tear off or use black marker when re using boxes... to save the planet!  ;)Avery web site is superb on tutuorials and downloads on how to use their labels...

Technology advances never cease to amaze me.  I assumed Monster would not dissapoint, they never do... I have been using their products for years!  The amazingness of this speaker is the combination of its ultra small size, AND, incredible size!  Now, lets get real... u can only turn the volume up so loud on a device this small, but considering its not much bigger than my NOTE4 phone, the volume is more than sufficient for such a portable device!  Prob. the best size to sound spearker on the market, but, I have not tested them all, i just can't imagine sound getting much better than this in a package this small...so just speculating.  Of course, any time u have a larger speaker, u have greater potential for high volume base.The packaging... it deserves a design award!  U would think the product cost $300 with such elegant packaging.  Also a nice carry and protective pouch and USB cable.  Splashproof too!  Pls don't drop in the pool, it would surely ruin it...BT worked on first try, whamo... I dig the announcement of BT connected!I can't find much wrong with this little powerhouse, specially for under $80.  If you do NOT want portability, of course there is better options on the market, even by Monster.  This will be my new carry along BT speaker... just remember, to keep it charged!

I installed this on girl friends HTC One... I already installed the Defender on my NOTE4, and loved it.  Previous to this, I installed a few defenders on previous phones.... bottom line, its not the best looking case in the world, it has a big footprint vs. other cases...but that is NOT why would buy a defender... us clumsy users who drop phones a lot love a case that can take a beating, and keep on tickin... the Defender does this better than any other cases I have tried... I rather live with the added bulk.  This paticular defender is one of the more stylish I have used... I think OtterBox is becoming more style concious in their designs, kudos to them.Buttons work well, mic flip is perfect, as well as charger flip area... excellent grip-ability factor.  Highly recommended if you drop your phone a lot !!!

I am a huge Hunter Fan customer.... the company has always stood behind their products.... great support, and friendly customer service, a rarity in the good ol USA anymore.  I had one fan with a pull chord, no remote, so was glad to see this product come up on Vine.  Now I have a remote control, as well as a cell phone BT control.First, I am a super techie guy... I have wired homes,. installed way too many ceiling fans and know electricity very well.  So as others have pointed your, your mileage may vary based on your expertise.  Installation was a breeze for me, instructions ultra clear as with most Hunter products.  Product worked on first try, no reason to call tech support.  As an added remote, its superb...but I wonder how many fans don't come with remote controls these days?  Not sure what market this product is targeted after.  Next, the BT control with the cell phone... worked first try, flawless... but, will I ever use it?  Prob. not... again, maybe there is some specific uses for this that I am not aware of... maybe just a couch potatoe who always has cell phone in hand?  Regardless, its a neat gadget, that alone makes it worth its while... overall, a great product for the right application.

When I found The Man in the Empty Suit by Sean Ferrell, I was surprised that the book isn't longer than it is.  My ebook version is a mere 225 pages. Having said that, after reading the book, I can say that it is long enough.The idea behind the story, a time traveler returns to the 100th anniversary of his birth each year to celebrate his birthday with other both younger and older versions of himself is, in itself, quite grabbing.  As others have pointed out, this creates several difficulties dealing with a time paradox.  If this weren't enough, the murder of one of the versions of the protagonist drives the action for the rest of the book and creates a paradox in it's own right.The Man in the Empty Suit has enough atmosphere to keep a 1940's black and white film noire movie fan happy for a long time.  Most of the action takes place in a rather run down hotel that becomes another character entirely.  Combine this with a wonderful cast of characters, and the book is a reading party unto itself.One of the touches I liked in Sean Ferrell's story is the way the various versions of the main character interact.  The Suit, the version at the center of the story, refers to other versions of himself as The Nose, The Screwdriver, Seventy, etc.  There isn't any level of affection between the versions either.  In fact, the reader gets the feeling that the versions really don't like each other even though there is only a few years between them in some cases.One of the distractions for me was the endless, and really pointless, chase between The Suit and the juvenile versions of himself.  What was the point?The setting of the annual party is in a crumbling hotel which provides the atmosphere.  The hotel, in post apocalyptic New York City is an additional factor which, again adds to that atmosphere.Though I enjoyed The Man in the Empty Suit, I just can't award more than four stars.  I thought the story, as written, it too long.  I had difficulty in getting through the central part of the story.  I was disappointed that some of the questions the reader is left with are never answered which adds to the level of dissatisfaction the reader is left with.Still, The Man in the Empty Suit is a worthwhile read.  A beach read.Peace to all.

Nothing Gold Can Stay by Ron Rash is another gripping collection of short stories.  The short story is Rash' preferred format and I think it is where he shines the most.  Having said that I enjoy the poetry as well as his novels.Of the fourteen stories included in Nothing Gold Can Stay, ten have appeared before in various publications.  The New Yorker, Shade, The Warwick Review, and Ecotone are among the periodicals where these stories have appeared.While all of these stories have power and the ability to grip your imagination, several were especially defining for me.  I acknowledge that other readers will be touched by different stories and this reflects the literary DNA we bring to the experience. "Those Who are Dead Are Only Now Forgiven" was especially memorable because it looks at how hope can turn to hopelessness before we even realize it has happened and how those we choose to love can direct our chosen path.Also worthy of special mention is The Trusty.  The way we interact with those who appear to be nave can often have surprising results even though that isn't obvious at first.....or even at the end.As I said, all of the stories are wonderful but these spoke most loudly to me.By his own admission, Ron Rash is a poet first, and novelist second.  That is evident on virtually every page he has published and is no less obvious in Nothing Gold Can Stay.  The best time was always right before dusk.  The water got quieter, more still, especially the deep pools.  Sometimes there'd be a mayfly hatch, and it looked like pebbles hitting the surface.  It was the trout feeding, but they wouldn't make splashes, just those tiny sips, as if they didn't want to break the stillness.  Donnie and me would break down our rods, knowing a spinner wouldn't work with a hatch going.  But we didn't go right home.  We'd sit on the bank a few minutes.  Donnie might smoke a cigarette but otherwise neither....  Nothing Gold Can Stay, p36Or,  The cow's abdomen relaxed and the round eyes calmed.  Somewhere in the loft a swallow stirred.  Then the barn was silent and the lantern's light seemed to soften.  The calf waited in its deeper darkness for Carson to birth it whole and alive or dead and in pieces.  Carson's hands suddenly felt heavy, shackled. He looked down at them, the liver spots and dark blue veins, knuckles puffy with arthritis.  He remembered another misaligned calf, not nearly as bad as this one.  He was just months into his practice and had torn the cow's uterine wall, killing both cow and calf.  Doris had been pregnant with their first child, and when she'd asked Carson if the calf and the cow were okay, Carson had lied.  Three A.M. and the Stars Were Out, p233Nothing Gold Can Stay is a pretty fast read, and a re-reading gives time feel the stories.  Ron Rash often tells dark stories that reflect the reality that is Appalachia.Still, there is hope in the place and in the people and in the story.I highly recommend.

19 Lessons on Tea:  A Guide by 27 Press is an impressive and very informative book.As a committed coffee drinker, I have long been tempted to explore the other side of the domestic non-alcoholic beverage world.  Unfortunately, my familiarity with tea is limited to the "bag" realm and the wonderful stuff served iced in the restaurants.Lessons are chapters.  At 95 just pages, plus space for notes on new tea sampling, 19 Lessons won't take much space on your bookshelf.  However, if this fact leads you to believe that this is a quick read you are mistaken.  I found myself flipping back to earlier lessons as I progressed through the book.  Add to this the fact that in many ways, 19 Lessons, is a reference book; a volume that you will want to refer to many times. Beside the lessons on tea types, I thought the most interesting Lesson (chapter) was number 15, Regions and Rituals.Lessons on Yellow Tea, Green Tea, White Tea, Oolong Tea, Black Tea are obviously needed.  But also included is a chapter on Iced Tea, Teapots, and Buying Tea.Tea is becoming an increasingly more popular drink.  19 Lessons is a great book if you're interested in gaining important information in this area, and doing so in a quick and efficient manner.I highly recommend.

I have to admit that The Gordonston Ladies Dog Walking Club by Duncan Whitehead is an interesting read.  Had I seen this short novel in a bookstore, the title and the cover art might have dissuaded me from even picking up the book let alone reading it.  However, I did read it, and I have to admit that it was an interesting read with a somewhat surprising read.The book's action takes place in Savannah, Georgia with a significant detour to Paris, France.  Gordonston is a mid to upper class neighborhood that serves as a bedroom community for Savannah.  Most of the primary characters are of retirement age but the community they live in does have younger families.  We know this because of the Girl Scout cabin in the center of the neighborhood park and the play area referred to a number of times.Cindy, Carla, Heidi, and Thelma are the dog-walking club.  Thelma we never really meet since she has an advanced case of cancer and is never a part of the story.  It is the interplay of these three older women that drives most of the story.  Tom and Kelly, a young couple that are relatively newly married and Doug and Veronica, also, a young couple, add to the set of characters.  Elliot, Thelma's husband, and Mr. Jackson, round out the cast.  Whitehead has a talent of developing interesting characters.  The entire novel is only 189 pages (my copy) and in that short space he has developed nine fully developed characters.As other reviewers have pointed out, there is a word for word repeat of an early chapter near the end of the story.  I'm not sure the reason this was allowed to happen.  I have seen movies that replay an early scene at the climax of the movie, which is what Whitehead has apparently done.  While effective in a movie realm, it only mystifies the reader and, at least in this case, caused a slight episode of frustration.I also found the novel very wordy in places.  It's apparent that additional editing would have helped the story along.  Again, at only 189 pages, there are many places that the story could have been effectively expanded had page count been a consideration.I suspect that we will see additional novels based in Gordonston.  This prediction is made because so many tidbits regarding the characters were introduced and then just left out on the floor.  Just a random thought!Given these two negative issues, I still consider that a worthwhile read.I recommend Gordonston Ladies Dog Walking Club, a pretty good beach read.( I was provided a free copy of this book but in no way influenced this review)

As a committed, albeit, minor book collector, I found A Gentle Madness: Bibliophiles, Bibliomanes, and the Eternal Passion for Books by Nicholas A. Basbanes to be a profoundly eye opening read.  I've always known that book collecting existed in a world of it's own, but I never dreamed of the passion driving most collectors.Additionally, it has come as a surprise that the passion for book collecting has existed as long as it has.  Having been collecting books since my Marine Corps days, I thought my feeling toward my books was unique.  However, I have learned that many others have loved their collections as well.  For example, Silvestre de Sacy, who said "Oh my darling books."  "A day will come when you will be laid out on the salesroom table, and others buy and possess you...."  It finally hit me that one day, someone else will own my signed and unsigned first editions of current literature.  My signed copy of The Reivers will be owned; possessed by another.  It was at this instant that I made a connection with the story (ies) that Basbanes had to tell.Virtually every named collector that Basbanes includes is new to me.  I am a babe in the woods in the world of book collecting, but therein lies the value of reading A Gentle Madness.  This book opened a completely new world to be, one that I somehow knew existed, but had no idea of the history of book collecting or the extent that collectors will go to build a collection.Basbanes does a marvelous job of illustrating the passion (s) that the collectors he includes in A Gentle Madness had for their avocation.  Whether it was personally perusing the book fares or Paris, or sending agents to the four corners of the planet to make purchases on their behalf, one is given a private glimpse into the mind of a bibliophile.  Well done Mr. Basbanes.Given the rise of the ebook, A Gentle Madness is a quietly re-assuring message that the physical book will continue to exist, even if it is only in private collections.  When you think about it, how big a deal will it be to collect an ebook?  How can you ask an author to sign an ebook?  Collections (libraries) of "books" will always be there.Finally, a private observation!  One of the great treasures of holding an antique book, collectible or not, is finding margin notes that some long past reader took time to put down.  Their reaction to the author, positive or negative, is a bonus to reading the book.  I'm not sure that's possible with ebooks.I highly recommend A Gentle Madness.

Keeper of the Dawn, a wonderful debut novel by J. B. Hickman is a sensitive story and somewhat of a "coming of age" foray into the life of Jacob Hawthorne.  Reading debut novels is always a treat but sometimes filled with disappointment.  Nothing could be further from the truth with Keeper of the Dawn.Haling from a dysfunctional family, Jacob is sent to Wellington Academy located on a small island off the coast of Rhode Island.  Jacob eventually sees that he is with other boys from families headed by fathers of stellar success but also lacking the bonds of family.  Both of Jacob's parents are pre-occupied with their lives.  His older brother has fled the family for the four winds.  In an interview, Hickman said that Keeper of the Dawn was a novel of denial and so it is, profoundly.Part of the beauty of Keeper of the Dawn is the wonderful characters that populate the story landscape.  Perhaps the strongest attachment that Jacob makes in the story is that with his grandfather.  Other characters, Sal, for example, and several of Jacob's teachers are also memorable.One additional comment about Hickman's style.  Very few authors have the ability to use prose in such a magical way.  Mr. Hickman, through his use of language transports the reader into the story.  Wonderful!I truly enjoyed this novel and can recommend it without reservation.Peace to all.

Over the years I've read perhaps a hundred books dealing with World War II, most I will admit have had to do with war at sea.  I can honestly state that I'd never heard of the incident between American 2nd Lt. Charles Brown and German 2nd Lt. Franz Stigler over the skies of Germany on one fateful day.  I'm not sure I would have believed it.  But, I've read the book and the story is true.A Higher Call by Adam Makos and Larry Alexander is perhaps the greatest book about WWII that I've read and that's going some.  A Higher Call is an emotional taffy machine.  It will influence your attitude about the German combatants that faced the allied soldiers.  Instead of all being the monsters we've learned to hate over the years, A High Call provides us with an intimate glimpse into the German ranks, admittedly on a limited basis.If you chose to read A Higher Call, hold on.  Use the chapter breaks to catch your breath.I highly recommend.Semper Fi.

Michelangelo's Last Painting: Its Chilling Revelation by Andrew Boemi is a pleasant surprise.  So many of these arty/suspenseful novels are over written and yes, over acted by the participants in the story and barely pass the Dan Brown smell test.  While Boemi's novel is a bit top heavy, it is a page-turner with an original take on Michelangelo and his work.  As I read the book I was hooked early.  I have a busy life and cannot read all the time.  When I was forced to put the book down I have to admit that I couldn't wait to get back to reading.  Only the fact that I had grandchildren visit for a week kept me from knocking out Michelangelo's Last Painting in near record time.The plot is grabbing even in its simplicity.  A painting of Christ on the Cross is created for Vittoria Colanna, Michelangelo's love interest.  However, certain elements of both the charcoal sketch and the actual oil painting are up setting to Colanna and are smudged out.  However, one of Michelangelo's assistants fails to follow instructions after the master's death and merely covers the painting with another art work.Spring forward 400 years and the original artwork is rediscovered and immediately develops a following among powerful interests who desire to possess the painting.  The world by the time this all takes place is a much different and more sinister place.  Technology has progressed to the point that wondrous military equipment is possible.  The geopolitical environment of Boemi's world is very scary with the distribution of power to rogue nations, city-states, and powerful individuals making for a very dangerous world.All this makes for a novel that is paced almost to the point that the reader is left breathless after just a few pages.  I can't remember any "dead spots" in the novel, which is surprising.Boemi has much to say in chapter 20 that is very insightful of our present predicament with both the economic and political environment in the United States.  I think he has a handle on what's going on in Washington today but this is not a distraction from the story; merely and explanation as to how the world in the novel came to be.  This is scary because it is plausible.If you're looking for a wonderful read I highly recommend Michelangelo's Last Painting.(I was provided an uncorrected proof by the publisher but this review is entirely my view point and is not influenced by anyone.)

I've purchased the Non Sequitur Day-to-Day Calendar for the last 9 years.  I look forward to ripping off yesterday's comic every morning.  Reading funny or thought provoking comic first thing in the morning and they only way to start the day.  From there it's on to the first Suduko of the day.  2013 looks promising.  One admission though.  I read the Danae panels, but generally am not a fan of hers.  Peace to all.

Flipping through this book, it becomes quite clear that the New Yorker is a time capsule of sorts.  Look through a copy of The Big New Yorker Book of Dogs and you'll see what I mean.Beyond that, who can't love cartoons about man's best friend?  Add to that great essays by some of the nation's best thinkers and you have a winner.I looked at this in a bookstore and read a great deal of it.  Wouldn't this make a great Christmas gift?  Hint! Hint! Hint!Peace to all.

According to Jon Gordon in The Positive Dog: A Story About the Power of Positivity we all have two dogs inside us.  One is negative and barks angrily.  The other is positive and is happy.  Given all else is equal, guess which one gets adopted and taken home?  Or, even more importantly, guess which one gets to stay home and not be taken to the pound.I often wonder why I didn't think of this way of making a point.  But, alas, I didn't.The story involves two dogs.  Matt, is the negative dog that is always barking and snapping.  Bubba, the positive dog takes Matt into his confidence and shows him how to add positivity to his life.We all know people who are negative.  If you've ever worked in a group setting, you've seen the person who shoots down any idea that is proposed.  That's a Matt and they're an impediment to progress.This book is a must in the college classroom and group training sessions.  It's a wonderful story, and best yet it's very short.  You can read it in a few hours.I highly recommend.Peace to all.

The Wind Through the Keyhole: A Dark Tower Story is Stephen King's latest addition to his Dark Tower opus.  It actually takes place between Dark Tower, Book 4, "The Wizard and Glass" and Dark Tower, Book 5 "The Wolves of Calla".Roland and his ka-tet are caught by a sudden winter storm while on the way to the Outer Baronies.  It is during this layover that Roland tells his cohort three tales.  The tales fit together nicely and the reader is (especially if you're a Dark Tower fan) treated to some of Roland's past.  First young Roland is sent to a small mining town to hunt down a shape shifter who has been terrorizing the community.  It is during this part of the tale that Roland comes across Bill Streeter, a young boy who is the sole survivor of the "skin-man's" latest killings.  In an effort to ease young Bill's mind Roland begins telling a story from the Magic Tales of Eld.  We are introduced to Tim Stoutheart's story.  When the tales are over Roland ka-tet, all of them are still there and we know they're bound for the adventures in the Wolves of Calla.Like another reviewer, the best thing about The Wind Through the Keyhole is that King does not change anything.  Stephen King is not averse to changing, expanding, or rewriting his stories as evidenced by the reissue of The Stand.  I for one would never tell Stephen King, of all people, how to handle his storytelling and to be honest I thought the expanded version of The Stand was better than the original issue.  Still, when I saw the announcement of The Wind Through the Keyhole I did get a bit nervous since I like the series the way it is.The Dark Tower series now stand a eight novels.  Beyond these, many of King's other novels touch on the series either directly or tangentially.  In any case, King is a master storyteller.  Like so many other great writers, it may be the next generation of professors and literary agents that finally recognize the fact.The Wind Through The Keyhole is a must read if you're a King fan.I highly recommend.Peace always.

Vegan Cooking for Carnivores: Over 125 Recipes So Tasty You Won't Miss the Meat by Roberto Martin is a life saver for me.  I've become a vegetarian over the last year (well, mostly a vegetarian) and building a library of recipes has been a real chore.  I'm not a fan of tofu so I'm really fighting a losing battle.  Martin's recipe for Spring Rolls and Dipping Sauce is wonderful as are most of his recipes for pasta and sauces.  I haven't tried more than a few of his concoctions (no disrespect intended) but will get to more soon.One of the special elements of Vegan Cooking for Carnivores is the fact that Martin includes recipes that you will recognize and might even be familiar with.  He shows you how to substitute any number of ingredients for meat including using beans and meat substitutes (textured protein).  In the end, following his tips, you'll find yourself pleasantly satisfied.I promise you that Vegan Cooking for Carnivores won't sit forgotten on you book shelf.I highly recommend.Peace to all!

Lincoln Child's latest book, The Third Gate, is a terrific read and filled with enough suspense, mystery, and drama to compete with the best of the 1940's film noire movies.  In fact, the book felt like an old black and white movie.  Mixing hard science, history, archaeology, and the occult The Third Gate is a page turner and sure to please a wide audience.The story largely takes place in the Sudd, a swampy area of the upper Nile at a research facility looking for the grave of Egypt's first pharaoh.  Jeremy Logan, a history professor, is recruited by the expedition's organizer and underwriter, Porter Stone.  However, Logan's training as a historian is not the expertise Stone is after.  In fact, Logan is what he terms an "enigmalogist".  Logan studies paranormal events and near death experiences (NDE).  Why is this particular specialty needed on an archaeological expedition in the middle of a swamp in the middle of the desert?  Well, that's why you might want to read the book.I would love to give The Third Gate five stars.  However, there are places where the story wears a little thin and some revelations are "telegraphed" in advance.  I would love to share them, but then this review would be a spoiler for you.  Still, there are enough twists and turns to keep you reading.  Certainly the story proper is lean and streamlined with no fluff.  Child is recognized as a writer who turns out tightly written stories and The Third Gate is no exception.Despite the one thin spot, The Third Gate is a very worthwhile read.  I finished the last hundred pages in a single sitting and couldn't put the book down until I'd finished.I highly recommend The Third Gate.Peace!

I have to give Winston Groom top marks for his book Shiloh, 1862.  While much has been written on all of the major battles of the Civil War, there always seems to be something new to say.  I believe that in most cases, new books covering these battles stem from an author who feels they have something to add to the literature.  It could also be that an author feels it is simply time to get the study of a battle in front of a new audience and rather than republishing an older, updated work, its just easier to write a new account.  Whatever the reason, I enjoy these works as they are published.  In this case, Winston Groom, an experienced Civil War author, does a great job with the first bloody battle of that conflict.Some authors have a knack at brevity in the books they publish.  Frankly, I prefer an author who is willing to fully explore the backgrounds of the major players and decision makers in a given study.  In this case, Groom provides a decent exploration of all of the major leaders involved in the Shiloh battle.  Better yet, I like that he took the time to provide updates on those he mentioned by name as he told the story, both general and private, both northern and southern.  That was an especially nice addition.Also, the maps covering the battle are first rate as are the notes included at the end of each chapter.Winston Groom loves the English language and proves it on each page of the book.  As one reads the book, it is easy to see the great amount of research under taken in preparation for the writing of Shiloh, 1862.  The many colorful details provided for the reader that adds so much detail, texture, and color had to be mined by countless hours reading letters, diaries, and official reports of the participants.  While some may feel that much of this information is of little importance and may even detract for the book, I feel that these details help clear the window and provide as realistic picture as possible.Well written and intended for a general audience, I highly recommend.Peace to all.

The Complete Peanuts, 1983-1984 (Vol. 17) is another installment on what will be the complete republication of all of the Peanuts comic panels.  On the one hand it seems hard to believe we're already to volume 17 and yet there seems so much more to go.The 1983-1984 edition continues some of the more established storylines.  Snoopy and his World War I flying ace, Charlie Browns continuing search of a Valentines card, Lucy's love affair Schroeder, Snoopy's brother Spike's adventures in the desert, as well as the Great Pumpkin and more are included.  Also, some interesting new elements.  Peppermint Patti's dismal progress in school results in failure to be promoted in school.  During the summer she tour's Europe with her father.  Spike's infatuation with a girl in a red pickup truck is also launched in this volume.I did notice that Charlie Brown avoids Lucy's trick of pulling the football away at the last minute which shows some real growth for this character.For confirmed Peanuts fans there is much here to read and cherish.  Again, I found myself thinking back to memories for these two years.  In this case, the birth of my youngest daughter on July 18, 1983 as I read the panel for that day.  Other memories surfaced as well.I highly recommend The Complete Peanuts, 1983-1984.

I'm sure that like many Americans, I was completely unaware of Madeleine Albright's background.  When she was selected to be Secretary of State by Bill Clinton, I just assumed (you know what that can do) that she was another sheltered and pampered intellectual; another product of an Ivey League education.  Well, it just goes to show you that one should never take at face value what one sees.Prague Winter: A Personal Story of Remembrance and War, 1937-1948 by Ms Albright opens the curtain on a historical event that is a lesson on appeasement.  Of course, the betrayal of Czechoslovakia is not new information.  Those of us that remember our second or third semester of Western Civilization have had this tale told to us.  However, reading Ms Albrights book places it on a very personal level and we are also provided with details that most of us were unaware of.  We are intimately shown what betrayal of this small central European country meant and it's cost to those who had to live under the events that were triggered by the actions of the western democracies, mainly France and Britain.Prague Winter is not an autobiography.  Albright's life is secondary to the history that she tells.  While she does tell us about herself growing up and how the various moves that her father, Josef's work required impacted on her, the main part of the book is reserved for what happened on the world stage.  Diplomacy and failed diplomacy.  Promises and the promises turned to lies.  Action and inaction.  The old saying that "the road to h___ is paved with good intentions" would serve as a good synopsis of Prague Winter.But the biggest lesson of Prague Winter isn't a new one.  Appeasement, whatever it is called simply doesn't work with mad men.  Dictators, as did Hitler, see the intention of others to avoid war as weakness.  Albright reveals several times that had Hitler thought the western democracies would have fought him over Czechoslovakia and then Poland, that he probably would not have proceeded with his plans.  We can only guess what would have happened but World War II might have been avoided with all of the tragedy, suffering, and death.Prague Winter is a gripping read.  Though the reader probably knows the outcome of the major events discussed, there is a power that draws the finger to turn the page.

It's always a pleasure to have the chance to read and ponder and then review a writer's debut novel.  There is only one first of anything.  Wiley Cash has written a sensitive, troubled, yet spiritual story set in the western mountains of North Carolina; Madison County specifically.A Land More Kind Than Home is an interesting title and accurately reflects the story and the characters held within its pages.  The story turns around three main characters.  Adelaide Lyle, an elderly single woman who narrates several key chapters and provides most of the back-story. Jess Hall, age 9, the central character who is a young boy growing up in Madison County along with his older brother Stump and his mother and father.  Clem Barefield, the county sheriff is central in several chapters and also provides some background as the story progresses.We are told that Stump, Jess' brother, is deaf and dumb.  It may be that he is autistic and though a minor point, would impact the story.  At any rate, Stump and Jess witness an event that begins to impact everyone's life and eventually spins out of control.  It is this singular happening that then triggers the most tragic part of the story.  It is interesting how Cash layers his story.  Each layer is interesting in and of itself, but then as more of the story is revealed you realize that what you read earlier is more interesting.  I hope that's not confusing.The reader is also treated to a glimpse into backwoods religion that includes speaking in tongues, and handling snakes.There are a host of other interesting characters that fill provide contour for the novel.  Jess' father and mother, Ben and Julie are also central to and play a significant role during the last two thirds of the book.  Carson Chambliss!  It is dangerous to say too much about him without throwing spoilers all over the floor.  Suffice it to say that Carson will live in your memory for a long time and is the poster child for what is wrong with organized religion.Full of wonderful description and introducing characters that are three dimensional and fully developed, A Land More Kind than Home is destined to make Wiley Cash' name familiar to many readers.I highly recommend A Land More Kind than Home.

William Boyd is a prolific writer.  His latest novel, Waiting for Sunrise, is a journey in the months just before World War I and the early years of the conflict.  The primary protagonist is Lysander Rief, an actor in the flower of his twenties.  The story opens with Lysander in Vienna seeking psychiatric treatment for a condition that is of some embarrassment to him.While in Vienna, Lysander meets a young artist named Hettie Bull and begins an affair.  In the end she becomes pregnant and in an effort to cover her betrayal of her full time lover, claims that Lysander raped her.  This forces Lysander to make his escape from Vienna with the help members of the British consulate.His escape puts him in debt to the British government, both figuratively and literally.  As a way to repay the debt, Lysander agrees to perform a mission behind what are now enemy lines.  It is through this experience that his life changes.  In fact, he discovers that he has the ability to be quite brutal in accomplishing his mission.  Once he completes this initial foray into the world of spies, it becomes easy for him to continue since he is able to bring to bear his talent as an actor.Waiting for Sunrise is a suspenseful story.  This first half of the book is tedious in places and moves rather slowly.  However, it is the first half that really sets up the suspense of the last half and allows Boyd to create the intense atmosphere that he is so good at.Waiting for Sunrise is an excellent period piece full of interesting characters and a clear eyed look at an earlier time; a time that proves that life then isn't as innocent as we think.I highly recommend.

Dr. Ben Carson's America the Beautiful: Rediscovering What Made this Country Great is perhaps one of the most significant books published in many years.  It is certainly the most profound book I've read this year.Dr. Ben Carson grew up in poverty.  His mother realized that the path out of poverty required a love of reading.  She required her son to read a book per week and write a book report and hand to her.  It took a few years, but eventually he discovered that his mother was illiterate and unable to read the book reports.  Still, she instilled upon him a love of reading that did lead him to a better life.Dr. Carson, as a black youth, experienced racial hatred and discrimination first hand.  He reacted as anyone would; with anger and aggression.  One incident he relates is attempting to use a knife on another youth.  Lunging at the boy, the knife hit his belt buckle and snapped.  Had the belt buckle not deflected and break the knifeblade, he might have killed the boy changing Ben's life forever a robbing us of a very talented surgeon.Dr. Carson realizes that the path to success lies in getting a good education.  The founding fathers also believed that the nation's health rested with an educated electorate.  He asked the question "what are we becoming" as we get away from our basic values; reliance of education is one of those values.Dr. Carson also believes, rightly, that physicians should be more involved with their communities in leadership roles.  He points out that four of the signers of the Declaration of Independence were physicians.Most who read the book will know that Dr. Carson is a neurosurgeon and tops in his field.  He is an excellent example of what it means to be successful today for all Americans, not just black Americans.America the Beautiful is a valuable read in a nation that seems to have lost itself.I highly recommend.

I'm not trained as a poet but I know good poetry when I read (hear it in the ear of the mind) and Robert Morgan's new volume of poems Terroir is a good collection.  By the way, not being trained in French, Mr. Morgan says that Terroir means Dirt in the French tongue.There are 78 poems in this collection and virtually all of them relate to home, country, family, and nature.  Morgan is a truly talented novelist and historian, but he is a poet first.  You can hear his love of language not only in his poetry but also in his fiction.  I find that writers who are poets first are much better writers in their ability to use language in a playful manner than those who are not.All of these poems are worthwhile but I have a few that are my favorites.  Snakes in the Attic, pg. 81, (having had that situation before) seems to touch me most directly.  Also, Flag on the Barn, pg. 90, speaks to love of country, family, and place.  Confederate Graves at Elmira deals with the tragedy that prisoners of the Union Army suffered and one lone black custodian  "who dedicated twenty years  to finding out the name for each  Confederate grave and then had etched  the proper words on fields of stones,  to honor those lost far from home,  because it was the decent thing,  he answered neighbors' questioning.I recommend all these poems highly, but my most favorite of all is The Years Ahead, pg. 57.I highly recommend Terroir by Robert Morgan.Peace to all.

As a man in his early 60's I have no problem identifying with Tony Webster the main character in Julian Barnes' The Sense of an Ending.  Given that the book is nominated for the Man Booker is enough said.  Even given the book's shortness, the story is captivating and worth reading.The first part of The Sense of an Ending deals with Tony Webster's formative years.  While some feel this isn't the strongest part of the book it is never the less, an important part because it sets up the last part of the book.  As another reviewer pointed out, the book is more character driven than plot driven though the plot is a strong one.In many ways The Sense of an Ending is a book about remembering; something that is becoming more important to me.  I identify with Tony Webster on so many levels.I recommend.Peace to all.

Robert Morgan is one of the premier authors writing today in the South.  Though many of his books have been fiction and poetry, his last two ventures, Boone, and his current release, Lions of the West: Heroes and Villains of the Westward Expansion are explorations into American history.  Boone dealt exclusively with the life of Daniel Boone, his place and times and that work was well received nationally.  Lions of the West, on the other hand looks at the lives of ten prominent Americans and their contributions to the American story and the settling of the west.  When I say prominent, I mean Americans who have contributed significantly to our development and success.  And, as the subtitle states, some of these people may have been villains, and others heroes and some have been both.  I guess each will have their own opinions.I believe that Morgan portrays these Americans in chronological order so Jefferson is the first personality that is explored.  Then follows Andrew Jackson, John Chapman (Johnny Appleseed), David Crocket, Sam Houston, James K. Polk, Winfield Scott, Kit Carson, Nicholas Trist, and finally John Quincy Adams.  The longest chapter is devoted to Winfield Scott and the shortest to John Chapman.  Which is the most interesting?  Again, everyone will have their own ideas.One of the joys of books of this type are the tid-bits of knowledge picked up by reading the chapters.  I'm always amazed when reading a book of history how the author develops the story he is going to tell.  Sometimes, as an author spins his tale I wonder why this information or that information was included.  In almost all cases, by reading on, all becomes clear.  Morgan also lets his tale of each person wander, but never does he include needless information. You might be wondering why James K. Polk was included in this group.  Most Americans couldn't tell you two things about Mr. Polk, one of the lesser known Presidents.  Morgan points out that Polk is the only President that did everything he said he would.  He promised he'd serve one term and he did.  He is the President that gained for the United States Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, California, Nevada, etc.  He gained for his country nearly the land area purchased by Mr. Jefferson.  And among historians everywhere regarded as one of our most successful Presidents. Then there is Sam Houston as another example.  Houston was anything but a good guy during this youth.  He was a drunkard, and a scraper, an fought more than he share of duels, winning most of them.  It was only after his move to Texas that the statesman and military leader that we're familiar with surfaced.  Read the book and you'll see why each man was included.One thought is that, as Morgan shows, some of these men have been both heroes and villains.  In many ways they reflect there country.  The United States, over its short history has proven that it has the capacity to do extraordinary good and has also filled the role of villain.I had an opportunity to have lunch with Robert Morgan and several others after he delivered a program on Daniel Boone at my library.  He mentioned then that as a result of the research for Boone that he had gained an appreciation on the settlement of the West.  It is pretty evident that Morgan likes doing the research for his books.Robert Morgan is a tremendous author.  I've enjoyed his fiction for years and became a stronger fan after reading Boone.  That appreciation has grown even stronger after finishing Lions of the West.I highly recommend.Peace always.

Waking, Ron Rash's first collection of poetry in ten years, is a unique collection of works.  Some of the poems relate to the Civil War (Shilo, Cold Mountain, The Belt).  Others spring from or relate to novels Rash has written.  Girl in the River (Saints at the River), and Good Friday, 2006: Shelton Laurel (The World Made Straight).  There may be other poems that relate to his other two novels, One Foot in Eden, or Serena, but I haven't made the connection.Rash is a fluid novelist, and his poetry is even more lyrical, the rhymes subtle, and the word play surprising sometimes.  He richly reflects the traditions of Applachia and gives voice to the people who have populated the region for generations.  The poem "Tobacco", for example, demonstrates the farmer's struggle to make a decent living and the tragedy of pursuing that cash crop.  "Dismal" explores the heartbreak of farming in the mountains: "though fog was worst, / how it settled / for days to snuff out light and sound, / rot barbed wire, fence posts and grain. / No gaze but inward in a world / gray and still as any gravestone."Waking contains 74 poems, most not longer than a page and many much shorter.Ron Rash is a significant author and poet who has found his voice.Peace to all.

Luce is content to live her life as she now has it.  She's a caretaker for an out of business bed and breakfast whose better days have come and gone.  Luce is happy to live in isolation, socially as desolate as she can get.  So attracted to the hermits creed is Luce that she has burned the boat that could take to town across the lake in just under half an hour.  By road that closest town is an hour away.  No matter, Luce is happy.  But this happy existence is doomed.So opens Charles Frazier's third novel Nightwoods.  Nightwoods is different in several ways from his previous novels:  Cold Mountain and then Thirteen Moons.  First, Nightwoods is set in the 20th Century.  More fundamentally, however, the current book is pared down and less affected by history.  The Civil War was the background for Cold Mountain and the removal of the Cherokee from the Southern Appalachians was the core event in Thirteen Moons.  Nightwoods is historically isolated in that respect, but that's okay.  Nightwoods does fine in its time and place.Luce's existence is set on it's ear when she learns that she must raise her sisters twins.  The social worker merely shows up and that is, as they say, that.  One boy and one girl!  However, these children aren't the cute and cuddly type.  These children are ruined, almost feral.  They're neither interested in talking or interacting in any other way for that matter. They even avoid eye contact.  That Luce must care for these children is even more interesting when we learn that she doesn't even like children.The state shrink thinks they're weird.  I mean, they make roosters disappear, set the house on fire and generally zone out.Then there is Bud, a backward thug who is convinced the twins know where money is located.  Luce has suspicions of her own regarding Bud but to say more might be a spoiler.Frazier has created a very interesting character in Luce but then Frazier is great in this regard.  Can anyone deny that Ruby is the most memorable character from Cold Mountain.Nightwoods might be the best book of the year for but, but there is still three months left.I highly recommend.Peace to all.

Matthew Pearl gives his readers another well constructed and well written story in The Technologists.  Centered in Boston in the post Civil War years, the story revolves around a group of MIT students trying to solve several technological disasters that have befallen the city.Pearl does a good job inter-weaving the real and the fictional in constructing his story.  For example, Professor Louis Agassiz was a real figure that did in fact teach at Harvard.  Whether he is accurately portrayed in the Technologists I can't say.  However, a quick Internet search will reveal all.  Pearl also did an enormous amount of research because he has seemingly nailed the depiction of the time period in which his story takes place.  Even the dialog of the characters rings true.  Many of you know that the Dicksonian period was extremely harsh in the social norms that were imposed on everyone.  Pearl deals with the period by including the lone woman student, Ellen Swallow, who must study in absolute isolation from her male counterparts.  Harsh even in fiction!Marcus Mansfield, is a student in the first class at the fledgling Massachusetts Institute of Technology.  Marcus is a Civil War veteran, a former prisoner of war, and a charity student.  While he comes from a humble background, Marcus is a sharp student in the sciences.  It is he and several of his classmates that decide to investigate the recent occurrences both in Boston Harbor and later the business district of the city.  We take for granted the gifts (or curses depending on one's point of view) of modern science and technology.  We forget that at an earlier time, technology and the science that bread the breakthroughs were viewed with mistrust as were those that practiced these "arts."  This feeling puts Marcus Mansfield and his cohorts at a distinct disadvantage which they must deal with.One of the things I like about some authors is when they refer to an earlier novel or short story in their most recent publication.  Stephen King does this routinely as do many others.  Pearl briefly refers to the Dante Club in The Technologists.  I don't know why I like this trait in some authors but I do.Finally, the author creates an atmosphere in the story that is similar to the work of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.  Very effective!I wouldn't necessarily call The Technologist a page turner, but it is certainly an above average mystery story.  Matthew Pearl is a gifted author; one that I will read again.I highly recommend.Peace to all.

My White Mountain Electric Ice Cream make arrived some time ago and we've been making ice cream.  This unit lives up to its name.  Anyone who has ever made ice cream using the hand crank type of make will love this machine.  We've made a good bit of ice cream and so far the motor and gear train has held up nicely.The box arrives with everything you need to get started.  The small instruction book is informative and contain recipes for about a dozen flavors of ice cream.  However, a quick search on the Internet will yield an almost unending supply of recipes.  My favorite is the basic chocolate, but blue berry is a close second.One tip.  Follow the instructions about washing the tub with baking soda.  There is a coating on the container that isn't tasty.Enjoy.Peace to all.

I was fully grown when I discovered Shel Silverstein.  My oldest daughter brought home Where the Sidewalk Ends from her school library.  I don't think she opened the book, but I did, and I've been a huge fan since.  My youngest daughter is also a fan.  When she was about 9 she made a point of memorizing several of her favorite Silverstein poems.  It is this ability to reach some children that makes Shel Silverstein such a unique artist.  His passing was a true loss for the country as a whole, but for children specifically.I've purchased and read Every Thing On It and will be sharing this volume with my granddaughter when she visits.  I may even read a poem or two to my now fully grown daughters.  So what if nobody came?  I have all the ice cream and tea,  And I'll laugh with myself,  And I'll dance with myself,  And I'll sing "Happy birthday to me!"Of course, when you read Silverstein's poems you experience the same lyrical wordplay that he is famous for.  These fresh poems continue his legacy of talking to children with respect and at the same time honoring their wonder at the world around them.I highly recommend Every Thing On It to children (of all ages) everywhere.Peace to all.

There is something reassuring about the steady arrival of these collections of the Peanuts gang.  Honestly, as I've said in virtually every volume that I've reviewed (not all of them) each book is a trip down memory lane as I recall what I was doing when these panels appeared.The 1981-1982 volume continues with the same members but with the introduction of Marbles, another of Snoopy's siblings.  We also see Spike drafted into the Army (Snoopy's imaginary WWI experiences).  Charlie Brown plays for Peppermint Patti's baseball team and ends up blowing a fantastic lead.  Charlie Brown's family also gets into farming, etc., etc.If you're a fan of the Peanuts neighborhood then you'll grab this 16th volume.  If you've missed one of the best retrospective publishing efforts of all time, it might be time to get on board and enjoy a new tradition.I highly, highly recommend.Peace to all.

It has been some time since I picked up a Temperance Brennan (Kathy Reichs)novel.  In fact, Grave Secrets, was the last one I read completely.  Something in the description for Flash and Bones led me to pick it up and read it and I'm glad I did.  As with another reviewer, I am struck also by the difference in Temperance Brennan in the books and on the television.  I'm pretty sure I prefer the book character hands down.Its NASCAR time in Carolina as the Coca Cola 600 at the Charlotte Motor Speedway becomes the mecca of the moment for race fans everywhere.  But then a barrel filled with black goo turns up with a body in it.  Temperance is called in both to investigate and identify the body, a victim of an apparent homicide and also to clear the way for the race to proceed......pronto.Wayne Gamble, an employee of the race track suspects that the body is either that of his sister Cindi or her boyfriend Cale both of whom disappeared twelve years earlier.  It seems that Cale had connections to a right-wing extremist group.  The investigation into his and Cindi's disappearance was dropped by the local police as well as the FBI at the time the couple went missing.  Tempe isn't buying that theory, however.  She thinks the body is that of, Ted Raines, a recently disappeared employee of the Center for Disease Control.  The FBI is taking no chances and swings in and takes the body.Given the absence of a body and any other leads Temperance is stymied, but not for long.  Not only is the investigation not going well, but Tempe must deal with her ex-husband's  issues.It is an understatement to say that Kathy Reichs is a gifted author and has a sure fire franchise in Temperance Brennan.  Flash and Bones is a gripping, well written novel by a mature author practicing her craft.  Having said that, the novel is realistic and doesn't fall off the "reality scale".

SmartKey is a great feature.  With so many family members and visitors who tend to lose keys, I can easily re-key all of my locks and feel safe.Kwikset finish is good for interior use, but doesn't hold up the harsh external elements.  After 2 years, the external side looks horrible compared to the internal side of the same door.I'm not too worried about those videos that claim to pick the lock in a few seconds.  It takes some skill and tools to do so.  It's easier for the crooks to smash the window to get in.If you live in an unsafe neighborhood or if you need higher quality finish that can withstand outdoor weather then go with Schlage.

The pin I received looks different than picture shown, which is what my lost pin used to look like.  Not to worry, as it still fits perfectly and comes with a little lanyard so that I wouldn't lose it again.
