The nut seems tighter as it's more like a lock nut that's harder to loosen.I like the combination of both the nut and the clip.  If somehow one comes undone, no disaster to my kid.

I've been using a whetstone to sharpen my blades.  It's a lot of work and takes some skill, but when done right, the result is a sharper blade than this sharpener. However, nobody else in my kitchen would even tough the whetstone, and a small mistake can damage the coating of my new set of Komachi knifes.The biggest difference is the angle.  Knifes that have been sharpened with whetstone tend to have a more acute angle and the edge is more like the tip of a heart shape than straight V shape.  I tried these knifes on this KitchenIQ sharpener and had to run through it 20 to 30 times to reshape the angle. I'm surprised to see a lot of metal metal shards falling out.  On the new Komachi knifes having the normal angle, it only took 4-5 times on each groove as instructed.The result is quite sharp, but I still miss the effortless feeling of a blade just sharpened with the whetstone where cutting everything feels like a hot knife through butter.  After a few days of use, both methods feel the same.  Oh well, convenience wins I guess.

The product description keeps on saying "Genuine Replacement Part" which fooled me into thinking this is an OEM part.  It's not.  It's softer and thinner than my Whirlpool original.  It still works fine but I'm concern about how long it would last.I managed to install without opening up the top and the front cover as instructed by YouTube videos, because there's not enough room in my laundry room to pull the whole thing out.  If you have room though, following the instructions will be easier because it's a tight squeeze to open the inner ring screw with a screw driver.
Broke after 4 uses.  The tip is slightly too sharp that cuts my child's ear when he wiggled around.

I waited a long time before I reviewed so that I had at least several uses on it.  There's no question how superior this is over the conventional plunger. One plunge is enough most of the time on my U shape bowl outlets.Pros:+ Sucks up a serious amount of water - for more thrust+ Soft rubber seals U shape bowl outlets better - no water splashing back upCons:- Doesn't come with a case/house
These balls last much longer than cheaper brands like EastPoint.  They play perfectly the way 3 star balls should.
Good for my purpose.  I stuck two of them to my power drill so that the drill holes are not slanted. Epoxy glue works much better than super glue for this purpose, because epoxy is thicker.

This Y adapter cable reduces the recycle time of my Godox Witstro AD360 from 5 seconds to about 3 seconds when used on full power.  That's not quite double as fast, but still good considering the low price.  It also adds to the length of the original flash cable which was kind of short when the flash is mounted on a boom/arm.Neewer DB-02 is the exact same cable, so buy whichever cheaper.

Watch out - The pointy tip of some screws stick out the back of the board even though I used the same screw size, because screw holes are not consistent.  This is dangerous if the kid can crawl to the back of the rock wall.Variations - I see about 5 different styles, which is great.  However, it can also be a bad thing. Some stones are only half the size of other stones.  For people who want a challenge, it could be great, but having 3-finger grip is tough. Some stones have deep enough grip even for an adult but others have very shallow grip.Rock like - good texture and hardnessInstallation mistake - At first I bought hex head screws and it turned out to be a mistake.  The screw holes are small not consistent, so my hex wrench socket couldn't fit in some holes. I recommend slot or phillips head instead, where a screwdriver can be used.

It's not the filament that amazed me, but rather the lack of a bulky unsightly base.  Where is it?The base is for a circuit and a transformer . The transformer is needed because LED chips can't work with 120V AC.  It must be converted to something like 4.5V DC The transformer emits heat, so the base casing also acts as a heat sink.  The case must be big enough to cover up the transformer as well as dissipate heat.With the filament technology, it appears that they put a large number (25) low-powered LED chips in a series in each filament, reducing the requirement of converting the voltage.  One tear-down video shows a tiny transformer, while another tear down shows no transformer at all.  Without the the transformer, there's less heat and the base is gone.  There's is still a circuit, but they managed to squeeze it within the threaded section.What I like:+ no bulky base+ filament looks like incandescent+ light can shine down because there's no big base blocking it.  This is particularly important for chandeliers having the bulb standing up to mimic candles+ color is more true to incandescent.  It's slightly more yellow than other "warm" LED bulbs and has no nauseating green mixed in+ globe is glass, not clear plastic+ instant on, no hummWhat I don't like:+ increased cost+ unproven technology.  I wonder how long it would last.  The transformer is usually the first thing that burns out, not the LED chip, so it bodes well to have a smaller transformer. However, first generation manufacturing and common lack of QC in chinese factories could play a bigger role here.

I turned on the self cleaning mode for my DSLR and it shook off most of the dust but left 4 dots still visible.  Then I used this blower and got rid of 3 more.  There's still one left in the corner that I couldn't blow off.  Luckily it's at the bottom of the image, which seldom shows, because the dust is more likely to be visible on the sky.  I'm scared of wet clean, so I'll just have to photo shop it out in the rare occasion it's visible.Tip: The sensor is upside-down.  If you see a dust spot at the top of your photo then blow the bottom of the sensor.

The product is well built, but the ease of closing it depends on installation.  The two sides need to align perfectly.  This is more tricky than it seems because the sliding window might not be flushed with the frame bar.  In such case, add a shim to make it flush.  Alignment issue is the reason why phillips screws are included in addition to the one-way tamper resistant screws.  It might seem unnecessary to use the phillips screw first only to be removed and replaced with the one-way screws.  But don't skip this important step because once the one-way screws go in, you can't remove them to adjust the alignment.If you made mistake in drilling, or if you're replacing an existing lock and the old screw holes are not at the exact same location, you can easily cover up the old holes with Bamboo Skewer and wood glue.  Then a new hole near can be drilled right next the old one without breaking up the wood.  Drilling pilot holes is strongly recommended because it's so easy to crack near the edge.The way the key works is slightly strange.  There's no need to turn the key.  Instead, just insert the key straight in, and then flip the latch open.There's another Prime-Line U 9933 that has a thinner left side. Check out how much room you have on the window before buying.

I award my 2nd grade child half an hour of TV time for each page she wrote about any topic.  In a few months, she already filled up nearly a half of the  book.  Her spelling and penmanship improved dramatically.  The lock was a curiosity in the beginning, but she didn't use it much because what she wrote wasn't any secret.  In fact she loved to show off and read it to me. The book held up well without any tears.

I used this on men's hair to soften the edge between hair clipper cut and scissors cut.  It worked very well.Build quality is solid and it's plenty sharp.The first time using it, I made a mistake of cutting everywhere, which thinned out the volume too much and the short hairs stick out.  Now I only use it within half an inch of the hair tip for feathering.  I'm not a hair stylist but the result is pretty professional looking.

I used it with a Kawasaki 4 1/2" angle grinder for cutting curves and holes in marble tiles.  It works well and is still plenty sharp after a job.  For straight cuts though, I prefer my wet tile saw machine because it's much faster, less dust and less noisy too.

Excellent.  Works on my 50D and lasts about the same as Canon's original.  Through the years, I had 2 Canon batteries that died on me, and also 2 generic batteries that died, so I doubt Canon's OEM is any better.
I threw this in my toolbox for the most important tool in the box: the pencil.  It doesn't get crushed like the plastic ones.

After mounted, I noticed that the screen was rotated to the right side, meaning the right side is about 2" lower than the left side.  I thought I did something wrong, but after careful inspection, I found it was welding problem on a small plate that connects to the arm.  I had to drill another hole on the wall and mount the bracket to the other side to compensate.  The problem is that the second hole is now off the wall stud, so it's not very strong.Other than that the mount is sufficiently sturdy.  I would still buy it again, but will check for possible alignment problem and return it for a better copy.

There's a reason why my Acura manual insists on using genuine Honda brake fluid, which is because other types allow moisture to seep in and cause rust.  The manual even stated that non-Honda fluid can be used temporarily as an emergency, but must be drained out and replaced with genuine Honda fluid later.My brake indicator light was on occasionally and surprisingly ABS and Traction indicator lights were also on with it.  Checking brake fluid shows that it was on the minimum level.  After I filled up the brake fluid to max level, all 3 lights are off permanently.I was a bit worried about shipping fluid in the mail, but the seller packed the item very well with extra tape on the cap to avoid leaking.  Kudos!

My knob is slightly more brown than what's shown on the picture.  That's perfect for my purpose.Installation is super easy.  Just hook the first link of the existing chain to it.Quality is good.  Knob wood looks rich and chain is sufficiently strong.

Shipped from China so it might take 2-3 weeks. I was a little worried about buying things from China, but this turned out to be a quality item.Made of aluminum, hollow tube, which is light weight but still sturdy.  It doesn't make squeaky sound because there's plastic cushion at the joint.Antique brass finish looks very good even upon close inspection.  When sunlight hits it, it looks shiny as shown in the photo.  Without direct light it looks slightly duller.Came wrapped in a cloth pouch inside a paper box, with a separate small plastic bag for mounting hardware.

Slim is in - I've had very cushy cases before, like the Ballistic case, but I really hate them now.  They are hard to pull out of jean pockets and teleported me back to the brick phone era. So now I prefer slim cases.The closest competitor for this Caseology is the Elago G5.  They are both slim and are nearly identical except:. The Elago is hard plastic, Caseology is flexible. When mounted on the phone, both of them feel hard. Hard plastic has better protection in case of a fall.. The Elago has no protection for the top and bottom of the phone.. The Elago is slimmer and exposes the aluminum rim around the Galaxy S3.  It makes the phone look prettier, albeit has slightly less protection for the screen.. The Elago hard plastic will eventually crack (after about 1 year). Both are glossy and slippery, which is good for slipping in jeans pocket, but hard to hand hold.No obvious winner here.Note that I'm using this Caseology on the Virgin Mobile version of the Samsung Galaxy S3.  It fits perfectly. The white case is slightly off-white and doesn't match the white color of the phone perfectly, but it was close enough to casual observers.

Why is this cheap?  Because it has no rechargeable battery inside.  The battery to support 40W power over hours would need to be huge. Just about any bluetooth speakers out there include a battery, so they have to use lower power amplifiers, resulting in tiny sound.  So if you have a place to plug in, then you'll get a lot more bang, or in this case thump, for your buck.Sound quality: flat + good by default or powerful + distorted when tweaked.  By default, the speaker generates high quality mid tone but lacks the high and low end.  If you don't need the thump then this would be your best setting.  When tweaked the settings, you can get a lot of bass and treble, but then distortion becomes a factor.  Increasing the volume makes distortion increasingly worse.  Regardless of settings you'll never get a solid kick or sparkling high like those of a quality car/home audio system (but that's an unfair comparison).  The settings include:. D-Bass. Base +1, +2, +3, +4. Treb +1, +2, +3, +4. Input Level +1, +2. Put the back near a wall will also greatly increase the bassBottom line: there is no miracle here, but it's hard to get better sound for under a hundred bucks.  The convenience of bluetooth and ease of operation usually triumphs utmost quality.  The guests visiting my home can play their own music via their own cell phones. My serious multi-thousand dollar audio system (Harman kardon amp / Paradigm tower speakers) get used less often, although I'm seriously considering adding a blue-tooth adapter to it.
Could be just my luck, but the two bulbs I used on an outdoor sensor light are still working after a year.

Great spiral design for mixing and solid quality.  I used it for mixing joint compound.It will fit any power drill with a chuck.  It's long enough for a 5 Gallon bucket and also works for a small pail that is slightly larger than a drinking cup.Cleaning afterward was a bit tough due to the crooks and crannies, but there's no need to clean it completely.

The LED light is nice and bright, but the LED driver is dead after just a couple of weeks.  First it got dimmer then it only turned on intermittently.  I bought another LED driver and now the light works perfectly.A LED driver is basically a transformer that outputs a contant current while leaving the voltage to vary.  Voltage needs to adapt to LED temperature so that it has the same brightness when first turned on (cold) and after warmed up.For this 3 Watt light, look for an LED driver that says 3x1W or 1x3W.  It should output about 300mA current and let the voltage varry between 6-10V.  At the max, 10 Volt x 300 mA = 3,000 mW = 3 Watt.NEC code.  If you're planning to install this into the ceiling or wall, then you should know that it doesn't meet the code without extra work.  The hardwired connection to household 110V needs to be in an electrical box.  That's why if you buy a recessed light can in the US, there's always a junction box attached to it.  In China there's no such law, so they didn't make the box.I had to install a junction box right next to the light for this  purpose.  Also, the LED driver needs to be in accessible place for replacement, because it would eventually burn out.  I put the LED driver in the junction box.  There's no light can to contain the heat, albeit a very small amount, so at least make sure insulation material is at least 3" from the back of the light.  Some cities also have the requirement that recessed ceiling lights need to be Air Tight for energy conservation, which this light is not.If you install it in a cabinet, then NEC code doesn't apply.

Lowes sell this item under the brand "Portfolio" for double the price.It's made out of hard plastic, but looks like plaster if left white.  I painted mine brown, which looks metallic, matching my light fixture.It covers up ceiling defects on my ceiling and also looks great for a traditional decor theme.There are no pre-drilled holes for mounting.  It can be squeezed between the fan/light canopy and the ceiling, or nailed/screwed/glued to the ceiling directly.
I play tennis and this keeps my sweaty palm from slipping.  I like the plastic bag outside of the rosin bag, as it keeps my shorts pocket clean.

The Snap closure doesn't fully seal the neck, so some hair got in and caused itch.  My kid kept on moving to scratch his neck, making it hard for me to cut his hair straight.  If I can buy again, I would choose something with Velcro closure to better seal the neck.The quality is decent and my kid loved the the angry bird pattern.  I'll keep it for now and will try to insert some napkins into the slack in the neck seal next time.

I had the 50 ball version of the Gamma ball hopper, which worked so well.  When I needed more capability, I stuck with Gamma.  However, the larger size doesn't work as well as the small one, because sheer weight of 110 balls is too much for the metal wires.  These wires are thicker than the 50 ball version, but are not strong enough.  Common problems include: it collapses often when stood up, the lid opens by itself when I laid the hopper horizontally in my car's trunk, the legs slip out and had to be popped back in.So I used pliers to bend the metal wires where the lid and legs snap in.  I also used a metal file to rough up the slippery wire surface at contact points.  Now it works well, also partially because I'm more aware of what actions can cause slipping.

When a screwdriver slips out at 100lbs+ torsion force, it can ..., well I'll leave that to your imagination.These rods look simple enough, but they are the key to avoid injuries.  First thing to do is use masking tape near the end to mark how deep these rods will go into the winding cone of the torsion spring.  Then every time inserting the rod, use the tape as an indicator that it's inserted fully.When done, you can use them as your chopsticks (if you're a giant).

Green color code on the spring means it supports 120lbs, or 240lbs if using double springs. Note that the picture is wrong, as it shows brown code on the spring.There's also a color code on the winding cone (not the spring)  Red cone = Right wind = counter clockwise = Left side  Black cone = Left wind = clockwise = Right sideYou can determine the correct spring either by weighing the garage door or measuring the existing spring.Weight: A double roll-up garage door is typically about 200-250lbs.  There's a tutorial on the web showing how to weight it with a bathroom scale.Measurement: need inside spring diameter, spring length and gauge.  To measure gauge, get the length of 10 coils together.  Ifit comes out to 2.5 inches exactly, then each coil is 0.25 inch.

The actual color of the glass shade is more like aged off-white.  When using warm color bulb, like incandescent, it becomes more yellow, but still doesn't have the magenta color cast as shown in the picture.The scrolled frame is metal but very thin.  It doesn't feel substantial on my hand.  I still like it as it looks good from a distance.  Up close, the finish is more like leopard skin than cracked bronze.  Zoom in the picture and you can see it.Overall, it's good for the price.

Venetian Bronze finish is crazy expensive, but I have to buy it because it matches my faucet.  Looks good.Proper installation is needed to make sure it remains sturdy through all the pulls.  Must screw it to the wall stud or use included anchors on dry wall.  If you need to drill through tiles or masonry, remember to buy a carbide drill bit or else you'd ruin the drill bit fast.  Drill bit is 1/4" if you use the screw anchors, or 1/16" if you screw into the stud. Even if you don't use the anchor, you'll still need to drill  pilot hole or else the screws won't go in straight.There are a couple of hex screws that attach the posts into the wall bracket.  A small hex driver is included.

After months of frustration with the Home Deepot fogger (from DIG Corp), I gave this a try.  The DIG Corp has a poorly designed mist head that either leaks or sprays only a tiny quirt instead of a fog.  It also fails often, because hard water eventually clogs up the tiny hole.In contrast, the hole on the Orbit is much bigger and thus harder to clog up.  It also sprays out farther and wider, like 3 feet long, so one sprayer can mist multiple hanging orchid baskets at once.  In windy condition, the wide mist coverage ensures some of the mist to touch the exposed orchid roots, rather than being blown away.  Of course, you can adjust the flow down all the way to a complete stop if you don't need a big spread. Turning it down will gradually make the mist thicker and more like a stream than a fog though.Tip: Unlike drippers, misters need a lot of water pressure.  While this mist sprayer connects to 1/4" tube, the small tube diameter doesn't allow a lot of pressure to be carried over a long distance.  Keep the small tube short, like within a few feet.  Use the larger 1/2" tube when you run more than 10 feet, and then connect the small tube to the big tube at the very end.

True, foam will save money on soap, but that wasn't my main intension.  With foam, the soap easily spreads all over your hands, rather than just where you pour it on.  Foam is also quicker to rinse off than thick soap. This is espetially true for kids, who are too lazy to thoroughly clean their hands.  When one kid in class gets sick, they all get sick.I loved the disposable foam soap bottle that I bought previously, and that was why I looked for this dispenser.  Compared to the disposable bottle, the foam dispenser works nearly the same, but not quite as great:. The foam is a little runny. After a day or two, the first pump gives out very little foam.  I would have to pump it twice.I'm still giving it 5 stars because the problems are more likely the soap than the dispenser.  I'm diluting from a hand soap refill.  Maybe the formulated foam solution is better than mixing regular soap myself.  I'll also try giving it less water next time.I wish there are more styles to choose from.  The modern style of this dispenser doesn't quite match my traditional home.-------------Update on 9/7/2015The white plastic gets dirty after several months of usage, perhaps from greasy hands trying to pump.  I tried many kinds of soap and chemicals to no avail.  Taking 1 star off for being so hard to clean.

This BLUE Sterilite is so frustrating to pop the ice out.  I threw it away and substitute with the WHITE Sterilite, where all the cubes fall out with a small twist.Bought mine at Target which is slightly cheaper.

The color is not as pictured.  It's really more like silver than bronze.  That's why they call it "Mystic Silver", rather than "Mystic bronze".The aging effect looks good and construction quality is solid.  Glass is thick. Comes with mounting hardware.

The power button on mine protrudes a little too far out of the end, making it hard for the flash to stand on its own on the floor/desk. I own a couple of similar looking flashlights that don't have this problem. I don't know who made that produding button, SODIAL brand or the seller HFHF INC.Other than that, the flash works fine.  It uses the same Cree LED and aluminum shell as all of the other brands.  The flash is very bright initially, but loses much of the luminance after about half an hour of usage.  After about an hour, it gets really warm to the touch, and the light is barely visible.  If I let it run all the way, then the flash would blink, indicating that the battery is out. Note that I use rechargeable NIMH AA battery.

This is a fun story that fans of Godzilla and other giant humanoid monster films (daikaiju) are sure to enjoy. But it isn't stereotyped into that category by any means. Those who never got into tales of large beasts destroying large cities are likely to appreciate the witty characters, compelling plot, frequent action, compelling mystery and underline thriller aspect of this tale. There's even a small element of romance, which never distracts or cheapens the story. It's like the author wrote this book to appeal to a wide audience, but without hindering the quality of the work whatsoever. Not to say there aren't any holes, but they are easy to overlook when getting pulled into the exciting and unfolding events. There's something for just about everyone. I'd rate this 4 and a half stars, but because there is no such option, I'm leaning more toward five.

These are closed back headphones, which is expected for studio style -- helps keep outside noises out. That said, I found they didn't block external noises as much as other headphones I've tested. This may or may not be good for your situation; if you need to talk to others while wearing them, it's good, if you need absolute quiet in a noisy environment, it's bad.The cord length is nice and long; easily reaches to my recording device. Plus the coil at the bottom can be stretched out for an even greater distance. This is good because the audio cable is NOT removable/replaceable; it is permanently attached to the left ear-cup. I prefer to have the option to remove it, but in my case, I find it is a good length. Should you wish for a shorter cord, you are best looking elsewhere.The leather ear pads are comfortable. I found I could wear them for hours without feeling uncomfortable. The ear cups didn't get in the way when wearing glasses -- never once did the headphones press the earpieces into my skin. They fit snugly without adding excess pressure against the skull.What impressed me most with these headphones is the sound quality. The bass is rich and thick and the high notes are clear and crisp. I've tested a lot of headphones, and these stand out toward the top on sound quality. Impressive considering the low price range.Overall, these are nice studio headphones. I use them in my home studio for doing voice-over acting and they fit the bill well. I would have liked a bit more noise cancellation, but the sound quality makes up for that in my case.

I am impressed with the quality of this watch. The build is very solid and sturdy. The negative of this is that the watch is very heavy. The metal band doesn't help with the weight. If you have thinner wrists like me, you can take some of the links out to lighten it a bit, but I still found it takes a while to get used to the weight. Speaking of thin wrists, I was impressed that the watch face fit me so well. Typically, with larger watches, they stick out and look silly on me. But this one forms really nicely.As far as style, this watch has an executive feel. More for suit and tie than blue-collar workers or outdoor enthusiasts. Great for me since I've been going on job interviews in the business industry; makes me look more valuable.If you are looking for practicality, look elsewhere. Not just because of the weight and style, but because of the need to wind it 25 to 30 times once a week. Not that this is a big deal, but it is something that one could easily forget to do.Overall, this is a fine quality watch that I recommend to people who are looking for something classy. I liken it to those who prefer fountain pens over ballpoint; not the most practical, but has an appeal for the right audience.Note: the box I received looks different from the red one pictured in the product images. Mine is a square, black box with "Swiss Legend" printed in red on the lid.

The headset is lightweight and surprisingly comfortable given the large size. The plastic build feels a little cheap, but that's part of what keeps the weight down. I found I could wear them for hours without feeling uncomfortable. They do feel a bit bulky when laying my head against a pillow, but didn't get in the way when wearing glasses -- never once did the headphones press the earpieces into my skin. They fit snugly without adding excess pressure against the skull.It's important to note that these are open back headphones; not designed for noise isolation. If you want to put these bad boys on and tune out the world, look elsewhere. Logically, SteelSeries made these open back with the PS4 in mind; designing them for people who want chat audio alone. This means you can put both earcups on and still hear the external audio (eg. game music and sound effects) put out by your TV or stereo speakers. Think of it as having chatting internal and gaming music/sound external. You can hear your buddy cursing in your ear after you got in a good headshot, but only have the sound of the sniper rifle available for outside ears. A good privacy feature without muting your 1000-watt sub-woofer (assuming you have one).That said, know that you can set them to pump in both chat AND game audio. This isn't set on the PS4 by default, however. You'll need to go into your settings and click on "Devices." From there, select "Audio Devices." Under "Output to Headphones" select "All Audio." Now you have full privacy with both chat and game audio, but keep in mind you will hear outside noises when the sound output is low.I found the audio cable to be a bit long for hooking into the PS4 controller. I'm a 6' man with pretty long arms, and there was still a fair amount of slack between my ears and my extended arms (where I hold the controller). This extra bit of slack in the cable was slightly annoying as it bunched up and got in the way. I'd have preferred the audio cable to be removable/replaceable so that I could swap it out with the exact length that suites me, but as it is the cable is permanently attached to the left ear-cup.I do have a PS3, but honestly didn't bother to set this headset up with it. Unlike the PS4 where you can plug the headset into the controller, you'll need to find a convenient way to plug them into your audio system. For most people this will require an audio extension cable. Which, to me, is kinda annoying and a bit outdated.In reality, this headset isn't limited to either the PS3 or PS4 gaming system. Any device with a standard audio jack can be hooked up. And since there's a mic, you can even use them with your smartphone for phone calls. I tested them on the PS4, Wii U, Laptop, Chromebook and smartphone (LG G4).The sound quality is actually pretty good as long as your device is setup with the right drivers. I had a laptop running Windows 10 and the audio it outputted was flat, but I fixed that by updating the drivers. There is deep bass (considering the open back) and somewhat crisp highs. I say somewhat crisp because I noticed a few notes that just don't hit it as clearly as Bose headphones I tried. That said, for the price range, the sound quality is quite good. I did notice some popping distortion on loud explosions when hooked to the Wii U, but not on the PS4.Overall, I like these headphones for the price range. I did noticed that sweat builds up in the earcups pretty fast, so I recommend avoiding any sort of physical activity while wearing them (or time spent out in the sun).

This is essentially the mini version of the Zing Air Storm Fire Tek Bow. Sized for younger kids (5+) with indoor play potential. It is also designed to be used in an office for those big kids who get bored of sitting in their cubicles (I am guilty of that). All joking aside, the box does say it is fun for: Home, Office and Outside. However, I find that it is less comfortable for adults and older kids because the hand hold is so small.One of the reasons the manufacturer says the bow is OK for indoor use is because the release isn't as powerful as the larger bow. Even with the string pulled fully back, the arrows traveled about a quarter of the distance (the box says up to 35ft whereas the Fire Tek Bow goes up to 125ft). This, of course, makes it less dangerous in the house as there is less power to cause heavy damage. That said, it can still knock over things such as vases. The first time my 6-year-old took aim at the closet doors, she somehow managed to fling a picture off the wall instead. Is this good for indoor play? I'd say it can be, but only under a controlled setting (such as an unfinished basement).Keep in mind that these arrows are of the suction cup variety, not the soft tip ones that whistle in the air and bounce a good distance when hitting the ground. I find that the suction cups don't travel as far since they are heavier and less aerodynamic, but they do stick on smooth, flat surfaces. I shot a few arrows against my car window and against a closet door. In both cases the arrows stuck, but only held for about 15 seconds. Not to mention I had to get the arrow lined up just right or it would bounce off the surface instead of stick.The light-up ability of the arrows is pretty cool. My daughter was thrilled when she saw them glowing in the dark. But this was inside the house with the lights off. I found I couldn't see the glow outside in the daytime. But it does work good at night and makes shot arrows easier to locate.Because this is a mini version of the Fire Bow, the build is more fragile. The arrow shaft and fletching (aka feathers) are very thin and can be damaged more easily. This makes outdoor play somewhat risky, as outdoor play is often rougher on toys.Overall, this bow is nice if you are looking for a smaller size and something geared more for indoor play. But I find that the larger, Fire Bow is better built and can still be used by younger children. If you don't need the smaller size, I recommend getting the bigger bow.

I let my facial hair grow out to about 0.5 centimeters (0.2") and gave it a full cut with the Remington PF7500. I did not perform any pre-shaving steps, just went right in to see how well the Remington would cut hair that long. It actually did a pretty good job. It cut really close to my skin making it look as smooth as if I had taken a traditional razorblade to it.There was a few places where the device tugged, causing me to flinch, but that was expected with hair at that length. Overall, the shaver was fast enough to keep up with cutting to avoid too much pain. I also came across a few places where the razor had trouble clipping the hairs, especially on my neck. The manual says to stretch the skin with your free hand so that the hairs stand upright, but I still came across a few rebels. Thankfully, the retractable trimmer made quick work of them, so this wasn't a problem.I like that the foils can be rinsed directly under running water, which makes cleaning a quick and painless task. It does recommend to soap them and do a more thorough cleaning once a month, but even that isn't too vigorous or time consuming.An advantage with this PF7500 over the PF7400 is that you can shave with the cord attached should the battery go dead before you finish. There is also a quick charge feature which promises one shave worth of power after a 5 min charge. That said, if you want to shave in the shower or with gels, you'll need to buy the PF7600 since both the PF7500 and PF7400 only support a dry shave.For those who had issues after using this device, keep in mind that the manufacturer recommends using it daily for three weeks to allow time for your hair and skin to become accustomed to the new shaving system. I also recommend keeping your original sales receipt as the limited two-year warranty requires it as proof of purchase. Of course, if you buy this online through Amazon, you can always print it off later.Overall, I'm happy with this shaver. It cuts well, holds a good charge and is easy to keep clean.

There isn’t much to this toy organizer -- a mesh bag and some suction cups -- but sometimes simple is better. I’ve been testing it for over a month now and have been happy with the results. The material has held together well and the suction cups continue to hold strong against the plastic surface of my shower.Because the bag that holds the toys are mesh, you can put the toys in it while they are still wet. The water will slowly drip out and into your tub (assuming you have it placed correctly). I did notice some slight discoloration on the mesh material where the water was heavier, but overall it still looks clean.The individual suction cups work well for holding bath scrunchies and have also stayed attached without falling. I recommend adding a little water to the suction cups before attaching just to be sure there’s enough moisture to aid in the gripping.Overall, this bath toy organizer works well for the purpose it was created.

This was definitely long enough for our outdoor umbrella, with some room to spare. The 100% woven polyester fabric feels sturdy even though it’s only one layer thick, and the stitching is well positioned with no apparent flaws. The drawstring hem cord doesn’t pull the bottom completely shut; there’s approximately a 5” gap (excluding the umbrella poll) at the tightest I could get it. That said, I was able to twist the fabric and use the loose part of the hem cord to wrap around and totally close off the opening (see the photos I uploaded).Overall, this cover does a good job of keeping rain and water off the umbrella as well as protects it from fading caused by prolonged exposure to sunlight.

The game, Jenga, has been around since the early 1970s and is appealing for its simplicity of rules and focus on physical concentration. Now, many years later, it's still sold in stores but has become a bit stale for some individuals. That's why adding the random and unexpected vibration (quake) gives this classic game another level of interest and enjoyment . . . and frustration? The quakes are intermittent and some last longer than others, but ultimately I find that none of them are massive enough to overly mess up your strategy.Overall, I enjoyed the extra feature, but I did find I missed having wooden blocks. The plastic ones that come with this game are hollow and light, almost a bit on the cheap side.

This review is for the Belkin FormFit Cover / Case for iPad Air (Lavender). Since there are several options, this review may not cover all the cases that are under this product page.One of the negative items I’ve seen under reviews for this product is people who’s iPad did not fit the case properly. With the case I’m reviewing, I do not have this problem. In fact, the case fits the iPad very tightly and I absolutely have no concerns with it falling out. All the cutouts perfectly match the position of the buttons, speakers, camera, volume, audio port and other items. If someone has a problem with this case fitting properly, I’d assume it’s because they are trying to get it to fit the iPad Air 2, not the iPad Air 1. Though the two different models are close in size, there are some differences such as the position of the camera and thickness of the body. These differences are enough to mess with the proportions of this case. This case is not for the Air 2, but the first generation.Another comment I’ve see is people not getting the cover to power the screen on and off. Like above, I do not have this issue with my version of the case. The magnets in the cover match my iPad Air perfectly so that when I open and close it, my screen turns off and on.The build quality is fairly good; thick enough to handle a drop but not too thick as to bulk up the device. The plastic seems solid and sturdy and all the materials are soft to the touch. This soft material does mean that there isn’t a lot of friction, so the chance of it slipping out of your hand and dropping to the ground is more likely. I haven’t done this, thankfully, so it hasn’t been a problem for me. The stitching is also well done and positioned well; no frayed areas or missing threads.The clip that keeps the cover shut could be a little better. It snaps to the plastic edge, but I can see this wearing out over time. I prefer ones that stretch from the back and hold the cover shut magnetically. Also, because the clip is attached to the cover, it gets in the way when you fold the cover back to hold the device vertically (like a book). It sticks outward and gets in the way of my fingers. This is my biggest gripe with the case; there’s no good way to get the cover out of the way to hold the iPad vertically. Not only is the clip in the way, but on the left side, the material bulges away from the back rather than lying flat against it. Since the majority of my use with my iPad is for reading, this is a huge negative for me.The case does a decent job as a folio case, meaning, standing the iPad on a surface in a horizontal position. This is good when I use it in my kitchen for recipes. The last case I had would slide and fall out of position, but this one has little divots on the inside of the cover that align with a plastic tab on the side of the case. As long as you line these two items up, the iPad stays upright. The only negative with this is if you want to lay down and have it on your stomach -- such as when you are in bed -- the angle of the iPad isn’t upright enough for me to see it properly in this position. Part of this is due to the soft and bendable section of the case. Why they made it this way I’m not sure, but basically, it leans back to the point where it is only effective on a desk while you are sitting in a chair or standing up on your feet. This means watching videos while laying down isn’t the best fit; because I still end up having to hold the iPad upright with my hand (or lean it against my bent legs).Overall, I think the build quality is pretty good with this case, but if you want a case that gets the cover out of the way so you can hold it while reading, you may want to look elsewhere.

In general, Hershey's is not known for high quality chocolate. It's a chocolate that appeals to children, particularly served around the firepit to create smores. However, that's not the case with this bag of Nuggets Milk Chocolate with Toffee and Almonds.Granted, it's milk chocolate, not dark. I've found that most adults prefer dark chocolate over milk chocolate. That said, taste is unique to the individual, and in the case of this chocolate I'd say the addition of the toffee and almonds help to appeal to an adult palate.In fact, my six-year-old took a bite and instantly thought this chocolate was yucky. My wife on the other hand couldn't get enough. It's addicting, and I found myself unwrapping more than I intended to eat.You are getting 3.75 Pounds of chocolate. I don't recommend this for keeping around the house because, if you are like me, you will eat too much. But it is a great option for parties, weddings, and bigger events. You can feel confident that your adult friends and family will like this; it goes against the grain of Hershey's being a kids chocolate.

My wife saw this in an infomercial. Unlike most infomercials, this product stood out to her as something she wanted to try. Why? Because she has super fine hair, and most products don't do much for adding body.When giving the InStyler a whirl, it was a little confusing at first. So I went to the InStyler website and watched a few videos. The most relevant one was the video named, "Fine or Thin Hair." The hair on the model used in the video had much thicker hair than my wife, so when I sat her down in a chair and followed the directions, I wasn't entirely surprised when we had no positive results.Next we took the InStyler to a friend's house and tried it on her. There were better results as this friend had thicker hair. However, the friend still preferred her Perfecter Fusion Styler over this one. So next I tried it on my mother.My mother has really thick, frizzy hair. Which is often out of control and hard to manage. When using the InStyler on her we were met with pretty amazing results. The frizzles vanished and was replaced with slick, silky hair. My 5-year-old daughter even commented on it saying, "Grandma, your hair looks really soft."Unfortunately, the InStyler proved to be ineffective on my wife's thin hair, but it did prove to be useful for thicker hair. It even did wonders for making a grandma look classy :-)Just be warned that the InStyler roller gets extremely hot. We're talking 225 - 430°F, so be careful and keep it out of the reach of children.

I was mainly interested in these glasses for motorcycle riding. I have a pair of eye-wear with sun protection that works well during the day, but are hard to see through at nighttime. Because these contained the amber lenses, they act as a type of blue blockers, which work good at night (and in rain). They are larger than I expected, which wasn't a problem, but because the shape of my face is narrow, the bottom portion is not sealed. Too much air flows under the eye lenses; the seal is not tight. I also tested these for construction projects around the house, but found the lack of a full seal to be limiting. For instance, sawdust gets in under the bottom and into my eyes. In reality, these glasses are best for those who have a more rounded face.The manual states that this eyewear is not intended to provide protection against sun glare. They are intended for indoor and outdoor use where no optical radiation hazards exist other than solar radiation. They are intended to provide adequate protection against sun glare and ultraviolet radiation from the sun. But as stated, on a limited basis.They are listed as impact-resistant, but I saw no mention of them being shatter proof. Which means a rock to the eye at high speeds on a motorcycle comes with some risk.I like that there is a strap for a tight fit, particularly useful when facing strong winds on a bike. But overall they were not the right solution for the shape of my face.

I have been sporting a goatee for several months and so I figured I'd give the Conair Flex Trimmer a try. The build feels a little cheap, but at the same time this makes the device light. It cuts quickly and sharply enough so that there are no snags or tugs. I did noticed that, even though there are 24 length settings, even on max (5.0mm) it cuts fairly short -- therefore this may not be a good device if you want to manage a longer beard. That said, if you are just trying to maintain stubble or a shorter length, I find the more precise settings to be fairly effective.Keep in mind that, with the low price comes some sacrifices. For instance, the blade does not self sharpen and you need to keep it oiled (for first use and then from time to time). Also, even though the trimmer boasts of being wireless, it requires 2 AAA batteries (not included, mind you) -- which means it is not rechargeable. For some people that would be an instant deal breaker; especially considering how standard it is for trimmers to come with charging ability in this day and age.The swiveling head is nice and the comb guide can be detach for easier cleaning (and detailing/shaping), but hair does get trapped under the blade and requires some wiggling and blowing to clean out. Keep in mind that you cannot clean the hair out with water like you can with other, higher-end trimmers. Not without detaching the blades from the unit itself (which you can, but if you do, be sure to oil them after), and you'll need to make sure they are dry before reattaching.Overall, you get what you pay for. A decent operating trimmer but with few bells and whistles.

The purifier works well with only a few negatives. There are three fan speeds, but the top setting isn't as strong as I'd like it to be. I have another unit that can clear a room quickly should our wood burning stove get backed up or something catch on fire when cooking. The Febreze HEPA-Type Tower Air Purifier doesn't have the power or the push to operate as efficiently. However, under normal (more mild) uses, it keeps up fairly well.The slow setting produces a really soft blow, which would be close to silent if it wasn't for the fan motor that produces a slight buzzing sound. When set to medium or high, the buzzing isn't noticeable, but on low it could become a bit annoying if you focus on it. If your intention is to use this unit for white noise -- such as when sleeping -- you'll want it set to medium or above.The Febreze scent cartridges only last for 30-days, and that's with minimal usage. It's possible to go through several per month if you have the scent intensity dial turned up. At approximately $5.00 each, it could get a bit costly. If the scent option is important to you, keep that in mind when calculating total cost. Thankfully, if you don't need the scent, you can operate the purifier without having a cartridge in it at all.The filters need to be replaced every four months or so. For the larger unit, you need two filters which puts the cost around $30. That's $90 a year, closer to $100 when calculating tax and [possibly] shipping. Keep in mind you may need to replace them sooner if you use the purifier more heavily. Note that the manufacturer states you cannot clean the filters to extend their life. Water will destroy them. However, I find that a vacuum hose with a soft brush attachment can be fairly effective at removing partial dust buildup.With scent and filter, you're looking at around $160 per year. More for heavy users. If those costs are fine with you, then this unit isn't a bad option, especially since the retail price of the unit itself is lower than others I have seen.

Has a nice, rich flavor. Not watered down or weak even with the added cream. I like black tea made in my Keurig Brewer over the traditional tea bag because the brewer makes it slightly frothy and takes the guesswork out of the seap time. The negative, of course, is the higher cost per unit. I've had other Earl Grey k-cups that cost less and have a similar enough flavor that I don't think I'd spend the extra on this one. But overall, it has a good taste IMHO.

My wife bought our godson the SodaStream Play Soda Maker years ago from Bed Bath & Beyond. As a heavy pop drinker myself, I admit to being a little jealous. That's why I was thrilled to have a chance to test out this KitchenAid adaption.As is typical with the KitchenAid brand, this device is very well built. Solid, sturdy. Much heavier than I expected; not plastic or cheap. I have no worries of it tipping over or getting knocked down. The quality blows away the one we got our godson.That said, there is one issue with it being such a grand device; it's big. Very big. From counter to the top of the handle it nearly measures 18". Because of this, I wasn't able to get the device to fit under my cabinets. Thankfully there was one spot on my counter that had no cabinets above, but keep this in mind for your situation.I like that there is no power cable to plug in and get in the way; just 3 AAA batteries that are included. The process of carbonating water is very quick and simple too: takes less than a minute. What surprised me the most was how good regular old water tasted when carbonated. In the past I tried sparkling waters, but their flavorings never appealed to my palate. With this device I'm able to make regular water, sparkly. And it's pretty good!There are quite a few Sodamix flavors out there too, and they are healthier than buying most pop -- if only because you can get them without the high-fructose corn syrup (google this and you will see how bad this stuff is). For around $6, you can get up to 12 liters worth of cola, Dr. Pete, root beer or whathaveyou. And if you don't mind voiding the warranty and risking gunking up the machine, search for the article "Hacking Home Soda-Making Machines" written on the NYTimes for other uses, such as making sparkling wine. I'm not yet courageous enough to try this for myself, but it's interesting to see what others have done.Replacing the CO2 carbonator is fairly simple. You can see a list of SodaStream authorized retailers on their website, but I find my local Bed Bath & Beyond is the best place to go. They will swap your old cartridge with a new one, which is cheaper than buying a full replacement.Overall I am very happy with this device. It has the highest quality build of any SodaStream beverage maker I have seen.

The Amped Wireless AC1750 was fairly easy to set up. It comes with an installation video on a CD that you can watch, or you can just follow through with the written instructions. I came across a slight problem in that this router is set to 192.168.3.1 by default, whereas most others I've tested are 192.168.0.1. This wouldn't be an issue except for the fact that I had two devices on my network with custom IP addresses assigned (e.g. 192.168.0.143). This meant that those systems didn't work automatically like they had in the past when switching routers, but it was a simple matter of changing the device settings from "0" to "3." (Note: I could also have set the router's IP address to 192.168.0.1, but figured I'd stick to the defaults for testing purposes.)The admin interface is easy to use, and you can adjust a fair amount of custom settings such as lowering the wireless coverage and blocking websites. Pretty standard stuff. A lot of the more advanced settings -- such as QoS Engine -- comes disabled by default, which is nice since those options can actually cause issues with certain devices (e.g. my iPad 2 hates QoS for some reason). I like that it gives basic users the minimum of what they need to get going, without forcing advanced options onto them. Yet more advanced users can still make their tweeks in the admin. Setting up forwarding was really simple too. Such as Remote Desktop and HTTP. No issues there whatsoever. Connecting to my company's VPN worked like a charm as well.You have the ability to plug in a USB hard drive to use as a network drive, good for storing music and video files that can be accessed by other devices. You can even have the router create an FTP that writes to that drive (however, I had some issues getting the FTP working, but haven't messed around with it long enough to figure out what the issue is).Some users complained of poor range and bad video streaming. Thankfully I didn't have a problem with either. Connected to a MOTOROLA SB6121 SURFboard Cable Modem and Comcast internet, my connection and performance is steady and consistent. I was able to have Netflix playing on an iPad and Smart TV simultaneously without a hiccup in the streaming. I also have it connected to a D-Link Wireless Day/Night Network Surveillance Camera without any issues -- it connects all the way from my basement to the outside of my garage.I like that there is a power button on the Amped Wireless AC1750; I can perform a power cycle without having to unplug it. Another nice feature -- and the first time I've seen this on any router -- is the ability to turn off the blinking activity lights. This makes my office feel less like an alien ship is trying to land in it. If you have this router in an active place, such as a living room, you may find it nice to disable those annoying flashing lights.I really don't have many negatives to speak of with the Amped Wireless AC1750, however I found that I like my D-Link Wireless AC1900 a bit better. Both have 5GHz and 2.4GHz channels and similar capabilities in other areas, but I found my D-Link had a bit more solid of a connection at greater distances (I was able to get full bars on the D-Link from across the street and into my neighbor's driveway, plus the outside camera ran a little smoother while on it). The D-Link is built more solid and has larger antennas. That said, both are fairly decent routers and I would be perfectly happy with either.

Wow!! I don't even know where to begin. I thought the first book, The Way of Kings, started out a bit slow but then got really good about halfway through. I was glad I stuck through all the character and world building. When finished, I gladly started reading Words of Radiance, the next in The Stormlight Archive. It. Was. Amazing!! Since I knew the majority of the characters and the environment, the story just took off and left me wishing for more and more and more. This book has made it to one of my top 10 of all time, and I eagerly await the release of the third book, Skybreaker!! Can't wait.

I have mixed feelings about this unit. The build quality is good, with a rubbery skin to help keep moisture out (amplifying the "beach" quality of the unit). The buttons up top are easy to access, even without looking directly at them since they stick out -- you can tell what they are by touch alone (which is nice if you are laying back and relaxing with your eyes closed).The stand works good and there's no jumping/bouncing of the unit even when the volume is maxed. Speaking of which, the volume goes fairly high and the sound can easily be heard outdoors.The multiple international adapters truly make this unit a great choice for the world traveler. As for myself, I only need the USA version, but it's nice to know I have other options in the future.For guys like myself, the carrying case feels awkwardly like a purse. In fact my wife got a good laugh out of me carrying it around. I've never been a murse kinda guy, so this didn't quite fit my style. That said, I can toss the speaker into a backpack and leave the case at home.Now, here's my more negative findings with the device. Firstly, when turning the device on, there's a steady flow of white noise coming from the speakers. It reminds me of the sound cassettes would make when playing a blank spot on the tape. It's not super loud, and mostly gets covered when music is playing, but if you are in a quiet room trying to get a peaceful rest with soft classical music playing, you may find that noise annoying.The speakers produce a fairly full midrange sound, but the bass is pretty weak. It's also a bit lacking in the crisp high pitches, but is better than other units I've tested. A lack of deep bass is to be expected in a device of this size, but I do feel as if it could be a little better.It's true that the international adapters are nice, but it also means the charging cable is specialized. Meaning, you can't just plug the speaker into the same standard micro USB adapter you use to charge your phone, tablet or headset. In fact, you can't charge the speaker through a USB adapter of any kind, which means [when traveling] you need to carry the specialized power cable around with you in addition to the speaker itself. I personally prefer to declutter cables and use something that works with multiple devices.Finally, and this is what I consider the biggest negative, is the limited range between the connecting device and the speaker. I used my Samsung Galaxy S5 to connect, which should produce a fairly strong signal, but when putting my phone in my pocket and walking to another room, the connection breaks in and out (the song stutters so to say). At first I questioned my phone, but then I connected to another bluetooth speaker (RND Ripple) and put my phone in my pocket and left the room, the connection didn't hesitate at all. Which means the NYNE is at fault.Overall, the NYNE is a decent device. I like how it is customized for portability and durability, but I'm a bit disappointed with the white noise, poor connectivity, and lack of deep bass. Personally I find I like my RND Ripple better, which is less expensive, smaller, connects better, can be charged by micro USB, and has better bass. But it lacks the waterproofing, higher pitch, raised buttons, "other device" charging, international adapters and carrying case of the NYNE. So they both have their positives and negatives.

Does not get every last drop as you do with the reamer style, but is a very nice product. I think it needs maybe another 3mm of travel to get all the juice. I guess if your lemons or limes have thicker rinds then it could get 100% of the juice...
Cute design, but gems received were very faint in color, nothing like the photo. If you are looking for something like a light lavender then this would work well.
Works as advertised. Waterproof and can still use touch screen / camera. I highly doubt it floats.

Very nice model to start with. Only purchase one with the CD content if you can, helpful reference and the book does require you to copy/paste from the files to your model (default data, libor data)...though not an absolute must, you could make it up and it would still work.There is a critical error in the PMT formula on the Cash Flow tab beginning in cell G7: =IF(J6<=G6,H7+E7,-PMT(F7*C7,OrgTerm1,AssetOrgBal1)). For a floating formula, you cannot reference the Asset's original balance to calculate the payment...must be previous ending balance.

I have a west facing patio in Southern California....my Weber Q cover had taken a beating and has held up like a champ. I wish they made patio furniture out of the same material. I've gone through 2 sofa covers (both nearly 5 stars here on amazon $39 for the strathwood sofas), in a shorter period than how long I've had this cover for. Very little, if any, signs of aging. Fantastic.Now please start manufacturing patio furniture covers.

The blade on this thing is about as sharp as a spoon. It literally smashes (note, not slices) its way through your bagel. What you are left with is two halves of a bagel smashed into the shape of a mangled triangle.I haven't run into a product this worthless in a while. It blows my mind that this made it past any sort of quality control checklist.

Bags are so so so thin that they fall apart if you look at them with a mean face...not too sure why they couldn't be made 2x as thick? I haven't been able to successfully use them. I put in some veggie choppings...lift up...and it bursts...I find it funny that other reviewers noted they don't compost in a 2 year amount of time...I cant even get mine to the compost bin without them breaking apart...soiling my carpet...Further...$19 for 100 bags...oh my.

Great jars...the seals are so good they keep salt from clumping. They look great and are a nice size.Cons (all very minor):1) stickers on the new jars are annoying...solved with soaking in vinegar2) some of the edges of the glass, i.e. biggest diameter point of the lid, can be sharp, needs smoothed out. The edges to the openings into the jar are fine.3) wish the seals were silicone4) jars are continuously tapering in, which makes labeling the sides a bit difficult. No flat point except the lid. We managed however, check out the uploaded photo.

I have a Pepper sport frame sunglasses as well, both great products at a fair price. The case that comes with this one is a bit annoying, though not low quality. It is annoying because there is a hole in the center and it just doesn't work as well as a normal case, you end up touching the lenses with your fingers to get them in the right spot.Regardless, excellent simple product. If you could care less about a known brand name, and simply don't want to pay for a name, but still want a nice product...here it is.FYI, you can view them in person at an REI...though they charge almost double what I found here on Amazon.

So you are here because you like the price, and the style is what you are looking for...I'm here to tell you that the product is indeed great. Lightweight, effective, and you don't look like a tool wearing them. You won't regret it.I used them hiking and biking, but wouldn't hesitate to use them driving or anything else just because they are "sport."

This book seemed to me to have a number of goals. Andrews' primary goal seemed to be to provide a careful delineation and defense of Nabokov's "aestheticism" and to distinguish it from the popular slogan of "art for art's sake". Andrews argues that, if we understand Nabokov's aestheticism correctly, it does not fall prey to the critiques that are often leveled at proponents of "art for art's sake". Andrews argues that "art for art's sake" is really a more specific form of aestheticism and "What makes 'art for art's sake' more specific than 'aestheticism' is that the former stipulates what 'art,' 'beauty,' and 'taste' are not while the latter stipulates nothing" (13) To be more specific, art for art's sake stipulates that art, beauty, and taste are radically distinct from questions relating to morality, truth, social consciousness, and other practical and pragmatic concerns. Whether something is beautiful is a radically different question from whether it is moral or true or socially responsible. Beauty becomes something radically divorced from experience and the concerns of everyday life.Aestheticism, on the other hand, does not stipulate what art, beauty, and taste are not. It merely argues that art's primary concern is to produce an aesthetic effect, whatever that may involve, and, in fact, Nabokov, in his famous afterword to Lolita, seems to suggest it involves curiosity, tenderness, kindness, and ecstasy. Andrews discusses some of the dangers of "art for art's sake": "the art-for-art's-sake aesthete may inadvertently create or fall under the influence of an immoral book; may isolate himself in an ivory tower, prioritizing art at the expense of human experience; may waste time on empty or overrefined stylization; and may pursue a vacuous notion of beauty through a self-indulgent distortion of Walter Pater's hedonism" (13) Andrews discussion of the dangers of art for art's sake in that passage seemed a bit abstract to me but Andrews makes the dangers more concrete in his discussion of Leni Riefenstahl's films. Riefenstahl's films were made for the Nazis, and served essentially as Nazi propaganda, but Riefenstahl always argued she was concerned only with beauty, and the films were defended at one time by Susan Sontag I believe, on the grounds that they were beautiful. The problem is that aesthetics becomes so divorced from the realities of the world that the supposed "aesthetic effect" of Nazi propaganda films becomes independent of their more nefarious and equally powerful effects as Nazi propaganda tools. Andrews spends the first part of the book arguing that Nabokov's aestheticism does not fall prey to these critiques and problems since, for Nabokov, the aesthetic effect is not entirely divorced from what we might call moral emotions - curiosity, tenderness, kindness - and is based upon an absolute respect for the uniqueness of reality.Andrews also attempts to define Nabokov's aesthetic in this book. Nabokov's aestheticism is "an ideology that emphasizes careful perception of all phases of worldly uniqueness" (40) The reason an artwork "cannot be reduced to its ideas" is "because its value is a function of its total uniqueness as a thing" (40) Nabokov's aesthetic is also an aesthetic based on balance between the imagination and the artist's "duty to create new and unique things" and the equal duty to "respect extant but equally unique things" (53) Imaginative invention should not be merely a mask for ignorance, i.e the artist should not say "I do not know, therefore, I will invent." Nabokov was very careful that the detail in his books was accurate. Nabokov has a beautiful phrase summarizing this aspect of his aesthetic, "Does there not exist a high ridge where the mountainside of 'scientific' knowledge joins the opposite slope of 'artistic imagination?" (53-54) As Brian Boyd argues in his book on Pale Fire, Nabokov sees a similarity between the aesthetic effect produced by a work of art and the wonder experienced by the scientist investigating reality. Both must respect reality and not substitute their own subjective feelings for that reality.While Nabokov's aesthetic emphasizes a careful attention to reality, it is not purely mimetic. The artist's objective is not "to represent a prior reality" (54) Nabokov uses the example of butterfly mimicry to illustrate the function of art. The butterfly must "pay attention" to reality in order to mimic it in its camouflage, but it does not merely copy reality. Nabokov follows nature's example since, "both art and nature rely on a mimetic technique that requires attention to prior realities. Consequently, Nabokov's creative process puts its main emphasis neither on being 'realistic nor on being 'naturalist' but rather on being 'real' and 'natural' - i.e. on being in tune with nature's creative processes" (55) Rather than copy a product of nature's creative process, Nabokov mimics nature's creative process itself, since both art and nature mimic in order to deceive. Andrews argues that Nabokov's aesthetic combines elements of the mimetic, formalist, and the expressionist aesthetics, but cannot be reduced to any of them in their traditional forms.Finally, Andrews provides a reading of Lolita in terms of Nabokov's aestheticism as defined in the first half of the book. I thought Andrews provided one of the more interesting readings of Lolita I have come across. For Andrews, Humbert represents a kind of parody of Nabokov's aesthetic ideas, which is why Nabokov and Humbert have often been simply identified, and Nabokov criticized for Humbert's lack of moral compass. Humbert represents an art-for-art's-sake aesthete who uses his aestheticism as a mask for his ruthless hedonism. There is a distinction between "Humbert-the-artist" who claims that his love for Lolita is "an appreciation for beauty" and "Humbert-the character's" hedonism which "leads him to treat the objects of his appreciation in a careless, generic, and utilitarian manner" (72) Andrews points out that Humbert is often "identified with apes and spiders, both of which prey on butterflies - the insects most often identified with Lolita" (74)Andrews makes an interesting point about John Ray's foreword as well. John Ray winds up justifying Lolita's destruction because it serves a moral purpose "for in this poignant story there lurks a general lesson" (Lolita, 5) This points to a similarity between Humbert and John Ray. Both are willing to sacrifice the individual - Dolores Haze - for a utilitarian aim. It makes little difference that Humbert's aim is purely personal - satisfaction and pleasure - and John Ray's is communal - the bettering of society. Both fail to respect Lolita's uniqueness. We can see why it is a mistake to accuse Nabokov's aesthetic of being "immoral". It is the didactic, moralistic novel that winds up being immoral because it uses individuals for its own purpose. Only art respects the uniqueness of the individual as an individual.Andrews also makes another very interesting point about the novel: Nabokov's words and Humbert's words are identical but their intentions are not the same. Humbert is trying to deceive the reader, influence the jury, and justify his behavior. Humbert's intention is self-serving. Nabokov's intention is more complex and will depend upon one's interpretation of the novel. It seems clear that, at the very least, Nabokov is attempting to produce curiosity, tenderness, kindness, and ecstasy in the reader, and to critique Humbert's version of aestheticism. Andrews argued earlier on in the book that Nabokov's aesthetic is expressionistic to the degree that Nabokov thought the artist's intention was important in interpreting a work of art. This means: the intention behind a work can influence whether it is a good or bad piece of art. If Humbert was the real writer of Lolita it would be a bad piece of art, for the same reason that Leni Riefenstahl's films are bad films, they were made with a bad intention. If a pedophile on trial for murder had written Lolita all the florid prose in the world would not save it from universal condemnation. We would sense the self-serving purpose behind the prose and feel sick when reading it. But a novelist can write the exact same novel and it can become a classic. The fact that Humbert is a creation of Nabokov, and the "internal filmmaker's aestheticism" is the object of critique "by the external filmmaker" makes Lolita great art (97) Humbert wishes to immortalize his own subjective perception of Lolita as a nymphet but Nabokov makes us pity the real but ultimately unknowable Lolita. This is why the aesthetic effect is different between the two works.Andrews also makes a good point in the conclusion relating to John Dewey's philosophy of art "Didactic artworks convey orthodox truths through orthodox structures, reinforcing prejudice rather than dispersing it" (129) In this book, Andrews makes his case that aestheticism and morality are not at odds by distinguishing between different brands of aestheticism but, I think, one might also distinguish between different brands of morality. There is a morality that is based on custom which is often severely immoral, and is often the object of critique of moralists and philosophers (Plato, Nietzsche, Faulkner all critiqued customary morality, but not in the name of "anything goes" immorality). There is also a morality that is more in line with Dewey's definition as "an activity, a process through which the individual sharpens his awareness" (129). Aestheticism and morality would only be in conflict if one is thinking of social morality. A work of art may offend the current social mores prevalent in society but, a good work of art is always in the service of the sharpening of our awareness, an increase of our understanding, and our pity for our fellow human beings. Art serves a higher form of morality without that purpose conflicting with its aesthetic purpose.All in all, I thought Andrews book raised a number of important issues, provided a decent summary of Nabokov's aesthetic, and provided a very interesting reading of Lolita. If I had to point to any flaws I would say that Andrews seemed to me to get a little too obsessed with all of his distinctions between different forms of "art-for-art's-sake" even resorting to subscripts to distinguish between all of them. I do not think that is where the real interest of this work lies. Andrews also sometimes dismisses, or at least attempts to attenuate, statements made by Nabokov that seem to contradict Andrews' theses by claiming that they are the result of Nabokov's "dogmatic moods" (38) He may be right, but it is always a bit dangerous to start cherry-picking which comments an author really meant to be taken literally, and which statements were merely the result of a "dogmatic mood". It becomes pretty easy to defend any thesis if you are willing to dismiss anything that does not align with it as the result of a momentary mood. Those flaws aside, the book is still worth reading for anyone interested in Nabokov, Lolita, or the general issue of aestheticism.

I was a bit skeptical about this book. I love reading literary criticism, which is one step removed from reading actual literature, but I gathered from the title that this volume would be a history of the criticism surrounding Lolita, which would be a step removed from reading actual literary criticism and a second step removed from reading actual literature, and I was worried that might be a step too far. Pretty soon I might be reading histories of the histories of the criticism surrounding Lolita and staring blankly at the sky. In reality, this volume presents excerpts from influential critical works on Lolita spanning five decades. Each chapter covers a decade, beginning with the 50s and ending with the 90s, and Christine Clegg has pulled excerpts from the most influential essays written on Lolita in each decade, interspersed with her own comments.After reading the book, I feel my fears were unfounded. This is literary criticism, plain and simple. Christine Clegg has compiled a ton of excerpts that approach Lolita from many different angles and it is the perfect way for someone interested in Lolita to get a sense of which avenues they would like to pursue in more depth. The reader of this volume will get excerpts from all of the most important essays written on Lolita in the past 50 years: from Lionel Trilling's famous essay, through Richard Rorty and his analysis of cruelty, and the feminist readings of the 80s and 90s.Lolita is a tough nut to crack. Personally, I do not feel that any of the authors in this volume fully cracked it, or answered all the lingering questions I still have about the novel. All of the authors excerpted in this volume have interesting insights to offer - insights into Nabokov's use of language, the relationship between morality and aesthetics, insights into the character of Lolita, etc. -  but I do not feel like anyone has presented a complete reading of the novel that I find entirely satisfying. However, this volume does succeed in raising a number of very interesting questions: To what degree should we trust Humbert's narrative? What is the relationship between the "real" Lolita and the Lolita that Humbert creates in his imagination and attempts to immortalize through art? What is the relationship between morality and aesthetics in the novel? and many more.These are the questions I will bring to my next reading of Nabokov's text as I search for that fully satisfying reading that may wind up being as much a figment of my imagination as Humbert's perfect nymphet. Reading is not a passive activity. The enjoyment we get from literary texts is often a function of the degree to which we participate by asking questions of the text. This text gives the reader of Lolita a mountain of questions with which to approach the text and will turn any potential reader into a literary detective combing through every detail in search of clues. Whether the reader solves the ultimate mystery or not that kind of attentiveness will certainly reveal many hidden gems. I heartily recommend this volume to anyone interested in Lolita.

Lehan provides a fairly satisfying reading of The Great Gatsby, its themes, and its language in this book. Lehan reads the novel as a movement from romantic possibilities to a corrupt reality: "The green breast of the new world...gives way to the valley of ashes; the dream of an idealized love gives way to adultery and death; and the idea of a just God gives way to blind eyes overlooking a physical wasteland and to characters who continually missee when they see at all" (124). Lehan provides a good analysis of all the major characters in the novel and also provides a good chronology that helps the reader grasp the symmetrical structure of the novel - centering around the central reunion between Gatsby and Daisy in chapter 5 - and provides insight into some of the recurring metaphors and tropes that structure the themes of the novel. Lehan makes the interesting point that the symbolic language in the novel "undercuts a strict literal and realistic reading" of the text. The symbolic relationships are more important than the literal chronology, i.e. the "movement from summer to winter, from youth to early adulthood, from romantic expectation to disillusionment, from life to death, from the pastoral to tragic, from the ideal to the grotesque, from the spiritual to the material" (132)Lehan also provides some very interesting quotes from Fitzgerald's correspondence. In one quote Fitzgerald wrote that, "The worst fault in [The Great Gatsby], I think is a big fault: I gave no account (and had no feeling about or knowledge of) the emotional relations between Gatsby and Daisy from the time of their reunion to the catastrophe. However, the lack is so astutely concealed by the retrospect of Gatsby's past and by the blankets of excellent prose that no one has noticed it - tho everyone has felt the lack and called it by another name" (125) I think this is an interesting quote because I think Fitzgerald does put his finger on a genuine flaw in the novel but it is one that - as Fitgzerald himself recognized - most people (including me) do not consciously notice until it is pointed out to them. Fitzgerald said he did not have a feel for how Daisy would react to someone like Gatsby and that does seem to be a real gap in the novel that I think I did feel on some level. It was like there was an expectation there that was waiting to be filled and never was.Lehan also discusses some of the real characters behind the novel and provides a little biographical detail.
