Fitzgerald apparently had his heart broken by a woman named Ginevra and that experience had a profound effect on his life and his work. Lehan explains the way that experience produced what I think is the dominant aesthetic of the novel, "When Fitzgerald lost Ginevra, he came to believe that such yearning was an end in itself; he believed in the need to preserve a romantic state of mind where the imagination and the will are arrested - in a state of suspension - by an idealized concept of beauty and love. The loss creates an eternal striving, and hope keeps the world beautifully alive" (72) The reason readers respond to this novel on such a deep level is because they can feel that aesthetic operating in the background. It was nice to have it stated so plainly.While Lehan's book increased my appreciation for Fitzgerald's novel I felt it suffered from a couple of flaws. Actually, there is really one main flaw. Lehan is constantly comparing the themes of The Great Gatsby to the themes of other Fitzgerald stories or other novels written by other authors. I think the idea was to highlight the themes of The Great Gatsby by comparing and contrasting them with the same themes as they appear in other works. However, I rarely found this very enlightening. I did not think it added much to the simple statement of the theme and the drawback was Lehan had to spend a fair amount of time summarizing the stories or novels he is comparing The Great Gatsby to since he cannot assume the reader has read those stories. So, he spends paragraphs summarizing Fitzgerald stories like "Winter Dreams" and "The Rich Boy", and paragraphs summarizing The Crying of Lot 49 by Thomas Pynchon, and A Lost Lady by Willa Cather. It felt a little bit like padding to me and I felt that, in a book that was supposed to be devoted to an analysis of The Great Gatsby, Lehan spent too much time summarizing and analyzing other novels and stories. So, that is my opinion, such as it is.

Consciousness has proved extremely elusive for science and for philosophy. Even as we have come to understand more and more about the brain the mystery of consciousness has remained one of the most puzzling enigmas of the universe. We are still a long ways away from understanding consciousness but there have been some very interesting developments in the last decade or so and Stanislas Dehaene's book is a great introduction to those developments for the lay person.Dehaene begins by outlining some of the new experimental evidence relating to the study of consciousness. One of the major stumbling blocks for consciousness research has been its seemingly "subjective" character. How can a science that aims to study phenomena "objectively" deal with phenomena that are fundamentally "subjective"? Many scientists believed this stumbling block was insurmountable and that consciousness research would always remain within the province of philosophers and mystics. However, scientists have proven resourceful in designing creative experiments that have allowed them to bridge - to some degree at least - that objective-subjective divide and Dehaene introduces the reader to these new experiments and their exciting findings.After providing a great deal of experimental evidence, Dehaene attempts to develop a new theory of consciousness. I am sure Dehaene would be the first to admit that we are still a long ways away from being able to work out a full fledged theory of consciousness that is fully capable of accounting for the phenomenon as a whole. However, Dehaene's theory is a good start and it is a testable theory that can help guide further consciousness research. In brief, Dehaene theorizes that consciousness is a phenomenon that takes place when a phenomenon reaches a critical threshold of importance in the brain and the messages reporting the various aspects of that phenomenon become synchronized and broadcast throughout the brain as a whole.Whether this theory is able to resolve the hard problem, or the explanatory gap, I will leave up to the reader to decide but, whatever the case may be, anyone who is looking for a good, accessible introduction to the current state of consciousness research could not find a better book than Dehaene's.

The Rainbow is an incredible novel. The novel inevitability overflows the bounds of any attempt to summarize it or encapsulate it. All of the characters in the novel are caught in a dialectic between the known - a circumscribed world of normal human relationships, stable egos, and matter of fact realities - and the unknown - a world of pre-personal desires with obscure and unknown objects and mysterious longings. The novel itself reaches into that unknown region so, any attempt to summarize the novel by pointing to what can be found "within" the limits of its pages, fails to capture what is so great and engaging about the novel, namely, the fact that it reaches into the dark and points beyond itself. It is a novel that can be read on many different levels and registers. In this review I will make a feeble effort explain why reading this novel is so rewarding and moving by highlighting three possible registers.The first register of the novel is the register of human relationship. The novel is a beautiful examination of human relationship. I am no expert in the English novel - I have never read Jane Austen, for example - but the stereotypical view of the English novel is that it is a novel of manners and courtship. Once the courtship is over, and the marriage is confirmed, the conflict is over, and the new couple can settle down into a comfortable life together. Lawrence portrays all the turmoil and conflict that arise after a marriage - when two people attempt to accommodate each other and make room for each other. Lawrence makes it clear that marriage is not easy, but he also makes it clear that, without the struggles of human relationship, we can never become the people that we truly are. It is only in those struggles, in our sometimes hellish attempts to accommodate another human being, and the demands of self-transformation that requires from us, that we become whole. At this level, the novel is about the search for self-fulfillment through relationship.The second register of the novel is the register of pre-personal desire. For Lawrence, our desires are bigger than our egos. Our desires often drive us beyond ourselves towards things that scare us. Our desires often feel threatening to our self-identity and what we take to be our fixed personalities. The hero for Lawrence is the person who is willing to follow their desires into the unknown as opposed to walling themselves up in a secure life. Our desires lead us to self-transformations that are often scary and painful and disillusioning but they provide the only path to a genuinely fulfilling life. There is a moral tradition dating back at least as far as Plato and moving all the way up to Freud that teaches us that desire is blind and needs to be restrained. The Id is limitless and will destroy civilization if it is not reigned in. Lawrence believes that desire is fundamentally religious. Desire is fundamentally a desire for the unknown and the transcendent. From Freud's perspective, the Id needs to be restrained because it has a tendency to make life for the ego very uncomfortable. Desire is the problem and the ego is the solution ("Where 'It' was, there 'I' shall be"). For Lawrence, it is the ego that is the problem. The ego is what chains us to our little selves and chains desire to the ego's own self-aggrandizing projects. The Rainbow is a celebration of desire as a liberating and religious force that is able to break down and free us from our egos.The third register of the novel is the metaphysical or religious register. Lawrence has a fully worked out metaphysics in this novel that is fundamentally religious. Every character in the novel is driven by a desire for the unknown. Some of the characters find fulfillment in another person. That person comes to represent the unknown - or, we might say, the infinite, for them. Other characters - like Ursula - are unable to find what they are looking for in another person and their search continues. There are at least two aspects to Lawrence's metaphysics. First, the fundamental drive that is driving human beings - and the Universe as a whole - is a religious drive, it is a drive that calls people towards self-transformation and self-realization. Lawrence actually has a fairly optimistic view of human nature. In Lawrence's universe something like evil would simply be a very confused and mistaken attempt at self-realization. The desire itself is good and wholesome but it is directed into a misguided channel. The second aspect of Lawrence's metaphysics is: the world exceeds what can be known of it. Our little islands of consciousness are surrounded by infinite darkness and our desires will never be satisfied with anything less than infinity.My description of the novel no doubt makes it sound much more abstract than it really is. This is definitely a philosophical novel, but it is a novel, not a philosophical treatise. The main interest lies in the characters, their emotional struggles, their conflicts with other characters, and their attempts to find a life that can satisfy the longings that define them. There are so many beautiful and poignant moments in the novel that will break the reader's heart. I was particularly moved by the scene with little Anna yelling at the geese, "My name is Anna, Anna Lensky, and I live here, because Mr. Brangwen's my father now. He is, yes he is. And I live here." There is a very interesting metaphysics behind the novel but it is ultimately a human story. I highly recommend it.

This is an excellent collection of critical essays on an excellent novel. I am going to try to provide brief summaries of the essays in this volume for the interested reader."Introduction" by Mark Kinkead-WeekesMark Kinkead-Weekes places Lawrence's novel in the context of Lawrence's own artistic development, the development of the novel, as well as its broader historical context, and highlights some of the major themes of the novel. In terms of Lawrence's development, the novel lies between the agonizing struggle that gave birth to Sons and Lovers and the apocalyptic post-war Women in Love. It is like a beautiful landscape or valley between two mountains.In terms of historical context, the novel deals with three major changes taking place in England between 1840 and the first years of the twentieth-century: the industrial revolution, a revolution in education leading to an increase in articulateness, knowledge, and self-awareness, and the decline of religious values (5) Lawrence avoids falling into simplistic extremes: either the ideology of triumphalism and infinite progress or the parochial nostalgia for a lost past. Lawrence sees the opportunities, the dangers, and the new challenges of the new historical developments.Lawrence is also part of the movement in literature from "behavior" to "consciousness". According to Kinkead-Weekes, Lawrence's challenge is to "discover new ways of showing the lines of force which operate" on his characters, "to make them reveal first one orientation, then another, according to the rhythm of the situation in which they find themselves, while remaining recognizably the same people" (8)"The Originality of The Rainbow" by Marvin MudrickMarvin Mudrick argues against those readers who would see the originality of Lawerence's novel in his rejection of the stable ego and his new form of characterization. Rather, what is original to Lawrence, and The Rainbow in particular, is that "it is the first English novel to record the normality and significance of physical passion; and it is the only English novel to record…the social revolution whereby Western man lost his sense of community…and men - more especially, women - learned…that there is no help any longer except in the individual and his capacity for a passional life" (17)"The First and Second Generation" by H.M. DaleskiH.M. Daleski analyzes the struggles in the marriages of Tom and Lydia and Will and Anna. Lydia represents the unknown for Tom which he both desires and fears and the conflict between them is only resolved when he finally stops trying to conquer the unknown and instead surrenders to it. There is a dialectic of losing and finding the self at work in their relationship. The relationship between Will and Anna is different. Will is dependent on Anna - he sacrifices his own creative self when he destroys his woodcarving - while Anna wants to remain independent.Daleski provides a very interesting analysis of the scene between Will and Anna in the Cathedral. It is tempting to view Will's rapturous ecstasy as positive and mystical but it is a oneness without difference, a return to the womb, to the lack of differentiation. Anna recognizes this when she clings to the "sly little faces" and gargoyles that "laughed in triumph of their own very littleness". There is a lot that is left out of the Cathedral: the individual in their freedom and littleness (54-55)"The Third Generation" by Keith SagarKeith Sagar analyzes Ursula's struggle. Ursula's struggle is different because her "struggle against the confines of her life" takes place before marriage rather than within marriage. She demands a lot from life, and she is consistently disillusioned, but this does not lead to cynicism or conformity. Rather, "If life seems to thwart her, it must be that she has sought the wrong things; rather than ask for less, she will ask even more of it" (58) She is searching for the unknown in her relationship with Skrebensky but she does not find it. Nor does she simply resign herself to its loss to settle down within the comfortable limits of a life with Skrebensky."The Rainbow and the Bible" by George H. FordFord argues that Lawrence - like Joyce - was dissatisfied with the "one-dimensional  level of naturalistic fiction" and combined modes: ironic, mythic, romantic, and epic. Ursula - like Leopold Bloom - is, on the prosaic level, a young woman living at a particular time in England, concerned about her future, love, career, historical change, but, on the mythic level, through the use of Biblical references Lawrence also portrays her as a prophetess who can lead us out of the wilderness to the Promised Land - just as Joyce portrays Bloom as another Ulysses (76)Anna Brangwen, her mother, beams a forerunner. She begins a journey into "unknown realities" but stops on "Pisgah mount, from whence she can see the rainbow, a symbol of promise" (76). She is no longer a "traveller surging forward" but she is devoted to her daughter who will continue the journey into the unknown. This mythic dimension of the novel adds a sense of timelessness to a novel that is very historically situated. Just like Joyce situating Ulysses on a specific day, but highlighting universal themes through the mythic parallels with The Odyssey, Ford argues Lawrence is doing the same thing by using the Bible."The Childhood of Ursula" by William WalshWalsh argues that Ursula's childhood is determined by Will's over-possessive love for her. There is some unfulfilled need in Will, and a need to be recognized and affirmed, which he turns to Ursula to fulfill. The roles between child and father are reversed because Will's love is dependent and Ursula's is protective (85) As a result "the relaxed rhythm of childhood is shattered, and the child…is jerked too early into a too sharpened awareness" (85)Another quality of Will's love is its exclusive character "which inspires in the child a corresponding jealousy and resentment for anyone outside the magic alliance who attempts to break into it" (86) This is an important element in Ursula's character and inspires in her a kind of instinctive fear of the "grudging power of the mob" since she is an exception. She always feigns to be less than she is "for fear that her undiscovered self should be seen, pounced upon, attacked by the brutish resentment of the commonplace, the average Self" (88)Walsh also examines the devastating effect that Will's unprovoked acts of cruelty have on Ursula and how they help to determine her future character. Walsh rightly praises Lawrence for his ability to portray a familiar domestic event "like a father's anger with his child" in a way that makes us feel "the vibrations of a deep and complex human disaster" (87)"Lawerence's 'Carbon'" by Laurence LernerLerner's essay is quite short, and it is quite clear it is part of a larger context which is left out, which makes it a little difficult to discern Lerner's point. Lerner argues that Lawrence is concerned with "carbon" but, unfortunately, what Lerner means by "carbon" must have been developed in a part of his book that was not included in this selection.Lerner praises Lawrence's ability to outdo the realists by conveying a realistic scene as well as the unconscious processes and tensions that are going on behind the scenes. This has something to do with what he means by "carbon" but I am not entirely sure what."The Marble and the Statue" by Mark Kinkead-WeekesKinkead-Weekes's essay opens with a number of great quotes from letters that Lawrence wrote describing his writing of The Rainbow. Here is one of my favorites:"The Laocoon writing and shrieking have gone from my new work, and I think there is a bit of stillness, like the wide, still, unseeing eyes of a Venus of Melos…There is something in the Greek sculpture that any soul is hungry for - something of the eternal stillness that lies under all movement, under all life, like a source, incorruptible and inexhaustible. It is deeper than all change, and struggling. So long I have acknowledged only the struggle, the stream, the change. And now I begin to feel something of the source, the great impersonal which never changes and out of which all change comes" (97-98)Kinkead-Weekes also examines early drafts of The Rainbow when it was still titled The Sisters or The Weddning Ring. He provides an analysis of Lawrence's study of Thomas Hardy and its theology based on the dialectic of Law and Love and Female and Male which Lawrence sees operating everywhere and, Kinkead-Weekes argues, is the true subject of the novel. Kinkead-Weeks provides an in depth analysis of three scenes from the novel - the cathedral scene with Anna and Will, the new relationship of pure lust between Anna and Will that results from Will's experience with the warehouse girl in Nottingham, and the scene of Ursula with the horses - in terms of the dialectic from the Hardy essay.

Richard H. Brodhead has collected a solid set of essays on Moby-Dick that succeeds in examining the novel from various perspectives and increasing the reader's appreciation for Melville's complex novel. I will attempt to provide brief summaries of each essay to give the reader some taste of what they will get from this volume."Trying All Things: An Introduction to Moby-Dick" by Richard H. BrodheadIn his introduction Brodhead argues that Melville identifies literature with "epic, quest narrative, and heroic tragedy" (2) Melville manages to combine these genres in the figure of Ahab who rises to epic and heroic proportions and manages to "sum up some fact of human potential" (2) but ultimately succumbs to a tragic fate. However, Melville does not stay strictly within the limits of traditional epic or tragedy - his writing embraces "the full form of writing's expressive potential", all the way from Elizabethan soliloquy, to scientific treatise, to Calvinist sermon, to legal brief (4)Brodhead makes a good point when he argues Melville sees the "most elemental human passion" not as "love, or ambition, or acquisitiveness, but something more like anxiety - anxiety, specifically, about the ground of our being, an anxiety that drives us…to keep worrying the question how the world is framed and governed" (4) This is ultimately the impelling force of the novel. Ahab and Ishmael are not driven by pure ambition or greed but by a desire to get to the bottom of the mystery of the world.Brodhead also discusses the critical history of Moby-Dick and makes the interesting point that the revival of interest in Moby-Dick came at a time "When qualities like discontinuous or fragmented form, symbolic structure, stylistic thickness, and antitraditional experiment were established as literary values" (18) This goes to show that aesthetic standards are not eternal. They are not set in stone. They change through the ages and, as they change, works become reevaluated, and people become capable of appreciating what appeared merely mysterious before."The Mariner's Multiple Quest" by James McIntoshMcIntosh highlights the "fluidity of consciousness" found in the novel. The novel never presents any settled opinions but is rather driven by an endless seeking and questioning of the universe, there is no settled mood that is not eventually disrupted by its opposite. The novel expresses moments of mystic calm followed by violence. The novel also flirts with relativistic nihilism in its presentation of the different perspectives on "The Doubloon" but even nihilism is only a temporary resting place that eventually gives rise to continued seeking.The novel is a Romantic quest narrative, where an external quest becomes the image of an internal quest, but, according to McIntosh, it is unique in being a "multiple, not a singular, quest" (29) Each character is on their own unique quest and the White Whale does not signify the same thing to everyone. McIntosh compares and contrasts Queequeg's quest with the quests of Pip, Ahab, Father Mapple, and Captain Bildad."Moby-Dick as Sacred Text" Lawrence BuellLawrence Buell points out that the "rise of the 'higher criticism' in biblical studies" around the time Melville was writing had two effects. Negatively, the higher criticism threatened to reduce the Bible to a "culture-bound, historical artifact subject to the same methods of interpretation and susceptible to the same errors…as any other ancient artifact" (55) Positively, "a less parochial and more creative understanding of the religious imagination…became possible, an affirmative reading of myth as the expression of spiritual archetypes informing not only the Bible but the scriptures of all cultures, and not only ancient texts but - at least potentially - the literature of one's own day as well" (56)This new understanding of religious literature, as more akin to poetry, made it possible to conceive of poets as prophets and "Literature and scripture become interchangeable categories" (57) Buell argues that Melville's novel is a religious novel that is a part of this new myth-making process.Buell argues there are two elements in Melville's novel that are in tension to some degree. There is often a comic note involved in Melville's religious imagery - for example, in Melville's description of the elephants praying by holding their trunks up to the sun - that undercuts the myth-making process with the possibility of solipsism, since, as Ishmael notes: "in gazing on such scenes, it is all in all what mood you are in" that determines how they are read (60) But, there is often high seriousness in Melville's myth-making and "the luminousness with which the mystery of Moby Dick has been invested" (61) It becomes possible to read Moby-Dick as a comic debunking of myth as fabrication or as a form of sacred scripture. Buell argues the latter reading is more persuasive "for dramatic reasons" (64)Buell summarizes briefly Paul Ricouer's analysis of different forms of revelation. Prophetic revelation is based on a double author of speech. The prophet is God's mouthpiece and the words spoken by the prophet are really the words of God. Moby-Dick is not revelation in that sense. Ishmael never claims that God is inspiring the words he writes. However, there is also narrative revelation. What is "essential to narrative revelation…is the emphasis on the founding event or events as the imprint, mark, or trace of God's acts. Confession takes place through narration…God's mark is in history before speech" (65) God is present in the events of Moby-Dick and Ishmael merely narrates them as a witness to the divine event."Call Me Ishmael, or How to Make Double-Talk Speak" by Carolyn PorterCarolyn Porter provides an excellent analysis of the role that Ishmael plays in Moby-Dick. Ishmael has to play many duel roles in the novel. Ishmael has to be both an outcast and a representative of human nature, he has to occupy the marginal space between the familiar and the unknown, and he has to speak "with the full authority of the culture whose authority he is out to subvert" (93) Melville has to walk a very fine line with Ishmael and it is a mark of his genius that he was so successful in creating a character that exists right on the line. If Ishmael veered too far in either direction the novel would become a very different novel.If Ishmael was not an outcast to some degree, if he represented our quotidian selves entirely, we would be presented with a farce. Ishmael would be totally lost and out of place at sea. Perhaps we would see him trying to stick to his morning breakfast routine while the rocking ship knocked the bowls and plates off his table to comic effect. If, on the other hand, Ishmael was totally foreign, he could not represent our own human nature, he would be above and beyond us, or outside of us - like Ahab. Ahab represents a possibility of human nature but he does not represent human nature in its universality, whereas, Ishmael makes the feeling for the ocean seem "fundamental to human nature itself" (74)Similarly, if Ishmael was not in some sense a representative of the culture whose authority he was out to subvert, our xenophobic defenses would go up, and Ishmael would seem aggressive, savage, and intolerant. Even though, as Porter argues, Ishmael "aims to undermine our most basic and fixed assumptions and beliefs" most readers find Ishmael to be "genial, tolerant, open-minded" (93-94) If Ishmael fell too far the other way, and simply represented our own culture, and not its subversion, then we would be presented with a novel about the strangeness and foreignness of other cultures in a way that would merely confirm us in the rightness of our own beliefs."Calvinist Earthquake: Moby-Dick and Religious Tradition by T. Walter Herbert, Jr.T. Walter Herbert, Jr. sees Moby-Dick as a response to a rift that opened up in the religious landscape in the Nineteenth-century between Orthodox Calvinism and the liberals. The contradiction arises from two claims, 1) That the world is governed by Providence, 2) That God is just and respects the moral integrity of human beings. According to Herbert, Melville "sets forth a Calvinistic analysis of Ahab's moral strife in order to form a drama in which Calvin's God appears morally odious on liberal principles, yet in which liberal principles lose their validity as a description of religious truth" (128)Ahab is the representative of this conflict. Ahab sees his injury at the hands of the White Whale as a punishment inflicted by God which he refuses to accept since, the doctrine of a God who punishes the entire human race for Adam's fall is a teaching that evokes "a divine monster ruthlessly violating the central principles of moral truth" (127) However, Ahab - and the entire novel - also undercut the liberal notion of a God who respects the moral integrity of humanity. The deist God of order is foreign to the revelation of Godhead - not as a "decorous city" but as the "ground on which the city stands, which reveals its strange hidden life when it moves" (113) - that underlies the novel."When is a Painting Most Like a Whale?: Ishmael, Moby-Dick, and the Sublime" by Bryan WolfBryan Wolf's essay analyzes the notion of the sublime that is at work in Emerson's essay on Nature, Melville's novel, and American landscape painting. Wolf argues that the sublime in all three is not, as is often assumed, a loss of self in the unity of nature but, rather, the absorption of nature within the solipsism of the self. This process takes place through language. However, Melville is very careful to point out the limits and dangers of the sublime in that sense. The sublime is easily disrupted - by a precipitous fall from a mast-head or when Queequeg intrudes - and the result can be death. Those who forget the outside - and forget that writing, or the attempt to recover the world in speech, relies on an outside that can never be fully absorbed - risk falling to their death in their moment of ecstasy.

I am going to do something I do not usually do in reviews and break this review into a list of what I consider to be its strengths and weaknesses. This list may be somewhat idiosyncratic but I will balance that by saying upfront: overall I thought this book did a very good job providing a basic introduction to the themes of Salinger's novel, the character of Holden Caulfield, and some of the debates that have surrounded the novel since its publication. In other words, the "weaknesses" I will list - which are colored by my own interests and subjective opinions about the novel - should not be taken as arguments against reading this book. I heartily recommend Pinsker's book to anyone who is looking for a deeper appreciation of Salinger's novel.Both the strengths and the weaknesses of the book revolve around Pinsker's analysis of the character of Holden Caulfield. This is hardly a surprise since the novel itself revolves around Holden Caulfield. If I had to summarize the strengths of the book in a sentence I would say: Pinsker often succeeds in presenting Holden as a much more complex character than most readers often assume. It frustrates me that the critical landscape around Salinger's novel seems divided between the "Holden lovers" - who think Holden is the most insightful genius who ever walked the earth - and "Holden haters" - who think Holden is just a spoiled brat, a pseudo-intellectual cynic with nothing positive to offer in the place of all he would like to destroy. I do not think that either camp has much appreciation for Holden as a character or the emotional struggles of a teenager drowning in despair. Instead, both sides focus on Holden's "philosophy" and miss the emotional core of the novel. The weakness of Pinsker's book is that he sometimes gets caught up in trying to figure out what we should think of Holden's "philosophy" as opposed to trying to understand him as a character. The strengths of Pinsker's analysis definitely outweigh the weaknesses, however, since any book that is able to increase the reader's appreciation for Holden as a complex character - and not simply the mouthpiece of teenage angst or a half-baked philosophy - is a definite step in the right direction.So, first the strengths. Pinsker does a good job getting at the existential core of Holden's struggles. People who read the novel often fail to see the existential problems that give rise to Holden's "philosophy". The "Holden haters" criticize Holden's philosophy without understanding the emotional turmoil that lies behind it which is the real subject of the book. Pinsker argues that The Catcher in the Rye is a death haunted novel. When Holden asks the cab driver what happens to the ducks during the winter Pinsker argues it is a "thinly veiled way of asking the question 'Who protects life?'" (38) Holden is at the age when he is becoming more aware of the world around him, and he has to face the fact that no one seems to be in charge of protecting the weak from the storms and fury of the world - no one is in charge of making sure the ducks survive the winter - and this effects Holden very deeply. Holden's attack on "phoniness" is a result of the force with which such existential questions assail him. Holden wants to be comforted and his disdain for people is often a result of their inability to offer him anything but cliches and platitudes. For example, Holden is critical of the undertaker who comes to his school and talks about Jesus being his "buddy". He knows that having Jesus as a "buddy" is not a solution to the deep existential problems that trouble his soul. This is what the "Holden haters" universally miss. They take Holden's philosophy, and his disdain for nearly everyone, at face value, and fail to see what lies behind it.Most readers are able to understand on a first read through of the book that Holden is fascinated by childhood and has a deep longing for the lost innocence of childhood. However, many readers miss Holden's equally powerful desire to become an adult. It is the conflicting desires that create the real difficulty of Holden's situation and Pinsker does a good job analyzing this. Holden's desire to be an adult shows up in the scene with the woman on the train where he attempts to act more adult and sophisticated than he really is. It is a simplification of Holden's existential dilemma to assume that he is simply fighting against the inevitability of growing up. If that were his problem he could simply remain infantile and hide from the adult world. There are people who choose that path in life and are able to avoid falling into the kind of existential struggles that Holden falls into. But that is not a solution for Holden because Holden's existential dilemma is a result of being pulled in two directions at once. That is what makes his experience so wrenching and difficult.Finally, to conclude my list of strengths, Pinsker recognizes that there is growth in Holden. This is something that I missed - and I think a lot of readers miss. Critics of the novel argue that Holden is critical of everything around him but has nothing positive to offer. I think that criticism is based on a fundamental misunderstanding of the novel - and, more importantly, a misunderstanding of life, as if the solutions to life's problems required the working out of some "positive philosophy". Most of the existential problems human beings struggle with are solved by living through them, outgrowing them and accepting them. We do not necessarily have to have some positive doctrine to offer at the end of the process. The solution to Holden's existential struggles does not lie in the elaboration of some grand metaphysical system capable of answering his question about the ducks in winter - or justifying the ways of God to man. Holden never offers us a theologically satisfying analysis of Providence to allay our existential worries about the fragility and precariousness of life. Nor does he bury his head in the sand of naive optimism and pretend that everything is okay with the world. Many of the people Holden meets attempt to offer him solutions along one or another of those lines but Holden recognizes the emptiness of any attempt to solve life's problems with a philosophy, a new car, a good career, or by becoming buddies with Jesus.Holden does grow up though. When Holden is watching his sister Phoebe go around the carousel at the end of the novel he has an almost epiphanic insight that is easy to miss. Phoebe and the other kids are all grasping for the gold ring on the carousel and it is dangerous. Holden would like to protect them but he recognizes he has to let go of his desire to be a "catcher in the rye", he has to let go of his desire to protect everyone from the cruelties of the world, and, as Pinsker argues, "Part of the sheer joy," Holden experiences in the final scene of the novel, "is a newly quiet acceptance (partly born of exhaustion, partly of relief) of the human condition as it is, and must be" (94) I think it would be a sin against this epiphanic insight to try to present it as a positive doctrine. If Holden were to attempt to present his new acceptance as a new philosophy of life it would falsify the experience. The world is still a cruel place, there is no one watching out for the ducks. People are still stupid and mean and trapped in meaningless pursuits that they hope will silence the anxiety and despair at the core of their being. All of that is still true about the world but Holden has a new perspective on it all. He even begins to miss Stradlater and Maurice. Perhaps, Holden realizes that everyone is caught up in the same drama and our stupidity is the result of our efforts to find some livable solution to the insecurity we feel. He might not be able to articulate that but that does not justify the criticism that Holden has nothing positive to offer.Now the only weakness of Pinsker's books is: Pinsker sometimes fails to treat Holden as the complex character that he is and starts to offer his own commentary on Holden's philosophy. For example, Pinsker is critical of Holden's views on artistic purity. Holden thinks anyone who works in the movies has sold their soul and he thinks that the piano player at the bar is just playing to the crowd by throwing in a bunch of cheap tricks. I do not necessarily disagree with Pinsker's "critiques", rather, I disagree with the whole approach. Salinger did not write a work of philosophy or aesthetics or cultural criticism. He wrote a novel. And the protagonist of the novel is a teenage kid. We would never think of criticizing The Sound and the Fury because Quentin's views about female sexuality are misguided. Rather, we praise Faulkner for creating an interesting and tortured character. Too much of the criticism surrounding The Catcher in the Rye is a result of abstracting Holden's philosophy and dealing with it in abstraction from the emotional core of the novel and the struggles of its central character. People treat Holden as if he were an unfiltered mouthpiece for Salinger's own philosophy and believe they are criticizing the novel when they are really criticizing what they take to be Salinger's philosophy.Pinsker never goes to that extreme, but he does, in places, seem to feel it is necessary to critique some of Holden's views. But the question of the literary critic is not: are the views elaborated by character X correct in some Platonic heaven of true ideas? Rather, the question is: are the ideas true to the character the novelist was trying to create? Does the author succeed in create a believable and full-blooded character with an understandable point of view? Does the novelist succeed in portraying the emotional and existential struggles of their main character in a powerful and compelling way? and other similar questions. Salinger, I think, does a great job portraying the existential struggles of a confused kid, and Salinger never pretends that Holden is anything other than a confused kid. If Salinger had wanted to portray Holden as a prophet with all the answers, he could have, but he did not. We turn Holden into something he was never meant to be when we start debating his ideas about "artistic purity" or "aesthetics" as if he were a professor who had just published a treatise on the subject. Holden's views on "artistic purity" are not meant to be a fully developed philosophy of art. They are the expression of Holden's longing for something true and genuine. In that sense, they express an emotional truth. Whether they are true in any other sense is irrelevant.

I usually take detailed notes when I read books and write really long reviews based on my detailed notes. However, I am getting lazy and I did not take any notes when I read this book. It felt like too much work. I think it is still worth writing a review because this is a really solid analysis of Moby-Dick and deserves at least one review. However, in contrast to most of my reviews, this one is going to be short and sweet. McSweeney does a great job analyzing the themes and characters of Moby-Dick. Moby-Dick is a difficult book. It is full of digressions, it gets deep into the intricacies of the whaling industry in the Nineteenth century and uses obscure nautical and whaling terms that most readers will be entirely unfamiliar with, it mixes genres, it can seem sloppy at times - adopting various narrative points of view - and the long middle section of the book is pretty short on plot and action. Many people find it a bit of a slog to get through. While I enjoyed most of Moby-Dick I admit that I found it a slog in places.McSweeney does a good job conveying why people continue to read Moby-Dick, and find it endlessly fascinating, despite its surface difficulty. McSweeney sees the primary theme of the book as the "quest for what Ishmael calls 'the ungraspable phantom of life', 'that demon phantom that, some time or other, swims before all human hearts' the predominant embodiment of which in the novel is Moby Dick itself…This quest involves profound explorations of fundamental epistemological, psychological, and metaphysical questions: what if anything can be known with certainty? can meaning or significance be found in the world outside the self or even in personal experience? do human beings have free will or free choice and if not who or what shapes human destiny? what is 'the secret of paternity' that makes us what we are? is there an afterlife or at least something beyond the visible world other than 'inscrutable malice' or a blank whiteness signifying only 'the heartless voids and immensities of the universe'? is there an abiding alternative to the suicidal impulses or self-destructive obsessions that come in the wake of 'the knowledge of the demonism of the world'? how adequate are Christian beliefs in the face of such knowledge and what is the status of the transporting but fragile experiences of friendship and love, and of oneness with the visible world?" (9)McSweeney really dives into the metaphysics of the novel. What I found most powerful in the novel was Melville's refusal to resolve the metaphysical questions raised by the novel. The unknown part of the world always exceeds the known part and it is our existential condition to be a tiny light encompassed by darkness. The whale symbolizes that in the novel. It is important to remember that, at the time Melville wrote the novel, most people had never seen a whale. Now we have nature shows on television so, even people who have never been to the ocean generally know what whales look like, and can get some idea of their size, and learn about their life. When Melville was writing people only had drawings and paintings to go by and Melville spends a chapter of Moby-Dick analyzing all the inaccuracies commonly found in depictions of whales in the Nineteenth-century. Even scientists knew very little about the subterranean life of whales so they were a perfect symbol for the vast reaches of the unknown. McSweeney does a great job highlighting this theme in the novel.McSweeney also does a great job analyzing the characters of the novel and their differing worldviews. He focuses in particular on Ishmael, Ahab, Starbuck, and Stubb. They each represent a particular relationship to life and the world. Stubb represents a kind of unthinking confidence in the world, Starbuck represents the standard Christian viewpoint, Ahab is the monomaniacal obsessive, and Ishmael - whose viewpoint is perhaps too complex to summarize in a sentence - represents the questing spirit, the search for the "ungraspable phantom of life", and a soul that is acquainted with the vast reaches of the unknown, and the sad and dark aspects of the world, that are left out of Stubb and Starbuck's worldviews. Ahab and Ishmael are similar in many ways but McSweeney does a good job highlighting their differences as well. McSweeney definitely increased my appreciation for the complexity of Ishmael as a character and narrator. In fact, it is the narrative voice of Ishmael that first drew me into the novel and my interest in Ishmael as a narrator, and a character - McSweeney is careful to distinguish between Ishmael the narrator, who looks back on his experiences, from Ishmael the character in the described action of the book - has only grown after reading McSweeney's book.There is much more in McSweeney's book than I have been able to summarize since I am basing this review purely on memory and my memory is not what it used to be. But hopefully this review will give potential readers some idea of what they will find in this book.

I have read a lot of the books in the Twayne Masterworks series. They are almost always of a very high quality and this is definitely one of the best I have read. It provides a fascinating analysis of Beckett's play Waiting for Godot and increased my appreciation for the play a great deal. This is going to be a long review, mainly because I want to summarize all the insights contained in this work for selfish reasons, so that I can return to this review and remind myself of Cousineau's insights whenever I want. I hope other people get something out of the review as well.All of the Twayne Masterworks start out with three chapters that analyze the historical context, the importance, and the critical reception of the work under review. In the chapter on historical context Thomas Cousineau reads Beckett's play in the context of the attempts to convey "moments of intense perception that free the self from its bondage to ordinary consciousness" made by Joyce and the Surrealists and also discusses Beckett's play in relation to Artaud's theory of the theater and his claim that the "concrete scenic language" of a play could convey meanings which addressed themselves directly to the prerational self without the mediation of language. This becomes a major theme of Cousineau's reading of Beckett. He does not merely analyze the words of the play but the stage directions as well which, Cousineau argues, often convey their own direct meaning which is in contrast to the nihilistic hopelessness that is expressed through the overt speech of the play.In the chapter on the importance of the work Cousineau discusses some of Beckett's innovations in the theater which include his "refusal to subscribe to the conventions of plot, his exploration of new structural principles, such as the use of repetition and difference, and his foregrounding verbal games and non sequitur rather than 'meaningful' dialogue" (7). Cousineau also argues that the play critiques "patriarchal society" which favors abstract perception over sensual perception. Freud, in Moses and Monotheism argues that this was a "great step forward…because it permitted those progressive achievements through which man was able to extend his mastery over the world." However, for Becket, it was also a move that alienated us from the "creative well-springs of life." Cousineau argues that the play dramatizes this conflict in the relationship between the text of the play - which expresses despair - and the concrete movements and gestures of the play - which convey humor and even joy.In the chapter on critical reception Cousineau argues that there are two main lines of interpretation. The first group of interpretations focus on theme, meaning and symbolism but, Cousineau argues, Becket himself warned against reading the play in terms of "meaning" and "symbolism" - reading "Godot" as "God" based on their linguistic similarity, for example, a connection that does not actually work in French which is the language the play was originally written in. Beckett claimed that the "key to the play was the literal relations among its surface features" (11). The second group of interpretations take Beckett's claim about the "literal relations among" the play's "surface features" seriously and focus on structural elements - repetition, etc. - choreography, and internal dynamics. I think Cousineau favors this second approach to the play but, readers who enjoy thematic and symbolic analyses - and I count myself among that group - will still find discussions of those aspects of the play in Cousineau's book.In the rest of my review I am just going to summarize some of the insights that I found most interesting in Cousineau's analysis of the play. If I had to sum up Cousineau's interpretation - and reveal the common thread that runs through all of these insights - it would be this: there is a tension in the play between the overt text, which expresses a message of meaninglessness and despair, and the concrete action of the play - which includes the verbal games that are freed from the dominance of meaning - which are humorous and express a kind of primal joy in life. That tension expresses the fact that the meanings we impose on the world, and our attempts to order the world in an effort to control the future, are imposed by the ego. We cling to those meanings, and we think life would be unlivable without those meanings but, in reality, those meanings are a burden that robs life of its spontaneous joy. In other words, I think Cousineau's analysis is based on the intimate relationship between the destruction of meaning and the release of instinctual joy.In the introduction Cousineau does a great job describing what I will call the subterranean effects of Beckett's play. This is not a term that Cosineau uses but I think it captures what he is getting at. Cousineau points out that Beckett takes Descartes's method of radical doubt to extremes undreamt of by Descartes himself. Everything falls under the negativity of doubt but "His negativity does not…leave us with feelings of desolation and abandonment…This is because we intuitively recognize that the beliefs and foundations undermined by Godot exact a heavy price in terms of instinctual renunciation" (22) Despite the overt despair that is expressed in the text of the play, one does not come away from the play feeling beat down. The play is quite humorous and "The fact that we enjoy being relieved of these inherited structures seems confirmed by the laughter that the play provokes" (22)Beckett destroys the beliefs that have sustained us but "after destroying every conceivable foundation, proposes alternative forms that have little connection with our conscious wishes. Our enjoyment of Godot, in spite of its discouraging portrayal of human aspiration, may imply the existence of potentialities that refuse the narrow structures of conscious desire and seek expression in the fulness of the present rather than in a perpetually deferred future" (24) It is possible that Beckett is critiquing a particular relation to time: waiting for something that never arrives. We are attached to our hope for the future but it also brings us agony. It is the boredom of waiting so, once we are relieved of that structure, we can find the "creative well-springs of life" in the present moment. I have always felt a real sense of relief whenever I see a Beckett play or read his novels and I think Cousineau does a good job explaining why.Cousineau argues that it is tempting to read the play in terms of its Christian symbolism - the tree, waiting expectantly, etc. - but the play could also be pointing out our "cultural inertia" and our tendency to interpret everything in terms of our own cultural inertia. Then the "pedagogical value" of the play would lie "not in its positive use of Christian myth as a means of interpreting the world but in its capacity for making us self-consciously critical of our own readiness to make interpretations in terms of inherited points of reference" (27) In other words, it would be pointing up the arbitrary nature of the meanings we impose on things. We see "waiting for Godot" as "waiting for God", not because of "objective evidence" within the play, but because we are looking for those meanings already, even if we are not Christian. But, perhaps, the whole conceptual framework - even if emptied of theological content - is arbitrary and meaningless.Cousineau argues that Beckett's fundamental insight is that "our relationship to the world is based on a misunderstanding…we assume that our individual selves are the center of the universe" but "the truth of the matter is that the universe, having no need of us whatsoever, acts in accordance with principles that are completely indifferent to our individual needs and aspirations" (27) Christianity obscures this truth because it puts man back at the center. It is often argued that without a goal - in the form of the Kingdom of God, or a meaning imposed on history by Providence - the world becomes meaningless. Our conscious minds might grasp at external meanings but I think there is a deeper level of ourselves that is actually relieved to be free of such meanings and free to find joy in the present moment that is not connected to some hazy future. It is a burden to be the center of the universe and I think we feel relief at a bodily level when we are freed from such notions. I think this is what Cousineau means when he says that our beliefs exact a heavy price in terms of instinctual renunciation.Cousineau makes these points when he argues that Vladimir and Estragon "live in a world that has been molded by the Christian hope of salvation" (28) It is a particular relation to time. Time is empty and meaningless now but it is going to be fulfilled and meaningful. It makes us ignore the present moment. This structure is deeper than Christian belief "Even if the foundations of Christianity were to be dealt a deathblow, its vision would assume transplanted form within some secular ideology because the promise of an outcome that ultimately justifies the accumulated frustrations of a lifetime is simply too seductive an illusion to give up" (29) The play dramatizes "the degradation that the Christian promise of salvation can encourage" (30)Cousineau returns to the theme of the subterranean effects of the play - the meaning that is conveyed to our body rather than our rational consciousness - when he discusses the use of language in the play. Cousineau points out that while the "words spoken by characters often fail to communicate thoughts, they do supply the raw material for a series of verbal games that we instinctively enjoy…Moreover, when language does fulfill its communicative function in Godot, it frequently serves as an instrument of oppression and alienation. The intelligibility of a statement is often directly proportional to its success in manipulating a character's behavior. The playful use of words, on the contrary, deprives language of its coercive power, transforming it into an expression not of authority but of liberated impulses" (43) If there is a continuing thread through Cosineau's analysis I think it is that meaning is often oppressive. Beckett celebrates a meaningless world but, far from being a depressing view of life, the freedom from meaning is really a celebration of the immediacy of life, sensuous experience, and play.The play, for Cousineau, is not structured by a traditional plot. In the beginning of the play Vladimir and Estragon are waiting for Godot, there is an interlude with Pozzo and Lucky, and then Vladimir and Estragon go back to waiting for Godot. The arrival of Pozzo and Lucky, and their departure, has no effect on what Vladimir and Estragon are doing (54-55). The play is structured by Vladimir and Estragon's enslavement to a very unreliable past. They do not remember clearly what they asked Godot or what he promised or what they are waiting for but they sacrifice the present moment to an unlikely future based on a very hazy memory. Vladimir and Estragon are enslaved to a dead mythology and the promise of a kingdom that never comes so they are unable to create new futures. Cousineaus makes the same point I made above - about meaning being oppressive - when he argues that this structure of memory and expectation and the ordering of the world in terms of cause and effect are impositions of the ego. They are ways the ego attempts to remain master of the world and its own experience - by predicting the future based upon the past. But, it is only "after the ego has been dethroned" that the "smothered divinity of unconscious experience" can awaken (65).Cousineau provides a beautiful analysis of Vladimir's speech, "Was I sleeping, while the others suffered?" Cosineau argues that, "The hypnotic quality of the speech, created by its poetic imagery and cadences, reinforces our sense that this is a moment of heightened awareness" (74). Anyone who sees, or even reads the play, can tell immediately that the rhythm of the language has changed and, as Cosineau says, this conveys in a very immediate way that Vladimir has reached new depths of himself - he has broken through the surface consciousness created by habit, which dulls our experience and "cuts us off from the deepest layers of feeling and revelation at the same time that it defends us against the suffering of others, who only too clearly perceive our sleep and self-deception" (74).Cousineau also provides an interesting analysis of the use of repetition and difference in the play as structuring elements. This is a different way of structuring our lived temporality. Expectation for the future is one way of living time but repeating difference is another. The first way of living time posits a goal that lies beyond the present moment in a future that never arrives but the second finds depth and fulfillment within the present. This reminds me of Gilles Deleuze's analysis of the eternal return which undermines any telos to time and instead connects us with the prerational depths of the present. The characters in Beckett's play are constantly weary because they live in the first kind of time where time is just waiting and boredom. I think this is what Beckett means when he says that the play is not symbolic. We do not need to equate Godot with God. The important thing is in the experience of waiting itself - as a way of living temporality - and that is all on the surface of the play.So, those are the insights in Cousineaus book I found most interesting. I highly recommend this work to anyone who would like to increase their appreciation and enjoyment of Beckett's play.

Nietzsche is a philosopher with many faces and he has been appropriated by interpreters with wildly different and often conflicting goals. For example, he has been enlisted by philosophers of a Romantic persuasion in their attacks on science. Such interpreters draw on Nietzsche's analysis of the "will to truth", his celebration of art and appearance, his perspectivism, and his ideas about the fictional nature of all posited unities - such as that of atoms. But he has also been enlisted by the scientifically minded in their attack on superstition, religion, and philosophical systems built on a priori premises. Nietzsche has been appropriated by both philosophers and non-philosophers who are looking for justifications for their amoral behavior, and find that justification in a particular interpretation of the will to power and Nietzsche's attacks on pity. Nietzsche has also been appropriated by those seeking a new, naturalistic ground for ethics and values. As evidenced by the reviews on this site, Nietzsche has been appropriated by harsh critics of liberalism and the values of liberalism - such as individualism - as well as staunch individualists and celebrators of "diversity".Every philosopher leaves some wiggle room for competing interpretations but this seems to be especially true of Nietzsche. The Nietzsche you get depends a great deal on the interpreter. As Alexander Nehamas points out in his Foreword to the new edition of Kaufmann's Nietzsche, "Kaufmann's book brought about a radical reversal of the popular image of Nietzsche as a ranting, totalitarian, anti-Semite and gradually made it possible for philosophers...to take him seriously once again" (v). This makes Kaufmann's book historically important. However, Kaufmann was so successful in destroying the image of Nietzsche as a "ranting anti-Semite" that one might ask: is Kaufmann's book still relevant? If all Kaufmann did was debunk the myth of Nietzsche as a proto-Nazi this book would be of merely historical interest. However, Kaufmann's interpretation of Nietzsche is both interesting and still cuts against the grain of many modern interpretations of Nietzsche.So, what picture of Nietzsche do we get from Kaufmann in this book? Kaufmann is particularly eager to debunk the myth of Nietzsche as a Dionysian reveler, a celebrator of chaos, a defender of the unbridled passions against anything - or anyone - that would seek to place a check on those passions. This view is still a very popular view of Nietzsche and is often espoused by philosophers who have been influenced by Deleuze's interpretation of Nietzsche. I happen to love Deleuze's interpretation of Nietzsche, and I think it is more subtle than what I have presented above, but there is no doubt that Deleuze celebrates the Dionysian side of Nietzsche. Kaufmann argues that Nietzsche had a more nuanced view of the Dionysian as early as The Birth of Tragedy - what he was really celebrating in that book was the union of the Apollonian and Dionysian in Greek tragedy, not the Dionysian in distinction from the Apollonian. Kaufmann also argues that the Dionysian eventually came to represent for Nietzsche the dialectical union between the Dionysian and the Apollonian, as opposed to only one term of the dialectic.Kaufmann is equally eager to debunk the notion of Nietzsche as an irrationalist Romantic. Kaufmann sees Nietzsche as an empirical/experimental philosopher and a rationalist. According to Kaufmann, Nietzsche attacked systems - and Christianity - mainly because they were based on first premises that were supposed to be a priori and beyond question - or based on unquestioned faith. Nietzsche wanted all premises to be subjected to experimental evaluation. Nothing was beyond question. Kant is an illuminating example. Nietzsche often attacked Kant and his notion of the categorical imperative. Readers of Nietzsche who are interested in giving free reign to their passions and selfish impulses often take Nietzsche's attack to be an attack on morality or law tout court. But, if we accept Kaufmann's reading, what Nietzsche was really attacking was Kant's failure to question the origin of the values he took for granted. He simply took the moral principles of his own time and culture as unquestioned and based them on the eternal nature of Reason. Nietzsche wanted to submit even our most cherished values to experiment and rational critique.Kaufmann's study is presented in chronological order. Kaufmann believes that many misinterpretations of Nietzsche result from the fact that interpreters pay too little attention to the development of Nietzsche's thought. So, Kaufmann begins with the early books - The Birth of Tragedy, Untimely Meditations, Human, All Too Human - and moves all the way through Ecce Homo and The Antichrist. This is an illuminating way to progress. We can see, for example, how the notion of the will to power grows out of Nietzsche's desire to provide a naturalistic ground for values and morality (at least in Kaufmann's interpretation). The metaphysics of The Birth of Tragedy was still dualistic, the Apollonian was viewed as a separate force from the Dionysian. The taming force of civilization was anti-naturalistic. The will to power solves this problem. It is a naturalistic force as well as being a fundamental drive towards self-overcoming. There is no need to introduce a second force since the fundamental drive of life itself is self-overcoming.Kaufmann interprets Nietzsche's famous doctrine of the Overman in terms of his interpretation of the will to power. The Overman "has overcome his animal nature, organized the chaos of his passions, sublimated his impulses and given style to his character" (316). We can see how far we are, in this interpretation, from the celebration of Nietzsche as the Dionysian reveler. For Deleuze, for example, the Overman is the one who affirms the eternal recurrence of difference by affirming chaos against all imposed identities - including the identity of the subject. For Kaufmann, the Overman is the opposite: he is an orderer of chaos, a person who is able to "become themselves" by giving shape to their own character. Kaufmann holds Goethe up as Nietzsche's primary example of the Overman in that sense.Alas, I do not have time - or the inclination - to summarize all of Kaufmann's book. Kaufmann does have some very interesting things to say on the Eternal Recurrence, Nietzsche's repudiation of Christ, and his admiration for Socrates, but I will let the interested reader discover that on their own. I do not always agree with Kaufmann's interpretations but he definitely presents an interesting perspective on Nietzsche. I also think it is still a necessary perspective since there are so many simplistic interpretations of Nietzsche floating around. There are very few people who still interpret Nietzsche as a proto-Nazi, but there are still people who interpret Nietzsche as an amoral celebrator of unbridled passion and the drive for power, or as a teenage angst-ridden attacker of "the herd", and as long as those people are around Kaufmann's book will serve as a necessary corrective.

John Haugeland's book begins with an hypothesis: human thought is at bottom "rational symbol manipulation." This is a contentious thesis but Haugeland does not present it dogmatically. Haugeland's book presents a narrative history of AI and the attempts that have been made to build realistic computers that are capable of mimicking human thought by manipulating symbols. The book is broken up into topics but Haugeland also manages to present a lot of the history and context which is good for neophytes like me.John Haugeland's book has a number of virtues that make it a good introduction to classical AI. First, its accessibility. I have a strong background in philosophy, but I have almost no background in philosophy of mind, computer science, or cognitive science. Even without that background I found the ideas presented in this book to be both lucid and powerful. The chapter that examines computer architecture was the most challenging but Haugeland still manages to present the ideas clearly.Second, Haugeland is honest about the serious difficulties that classical AI runs into when trying to produce realistic models of human thought. However, as I realized very quickly reading this book, even the failures of classical AI are illuminating. We learn a great deal about human thought by examining the ways in which computers fail to realistically mimic our thought. By seeing what computers are (at the present moment) incapable of doing we get some insight into what we are capable of doing. I think human thought progresses by following paths to their natural conclusion and, even when we reach dead ends, we have learned something about why that path was a dead end. So, I think it is great that there are people taking the basic hypthothesis that human thought is rational symbol manipulation as far as it will go. Even if the version of AI presented in this book turns out to be a dead end we will know more about why it is a dead end if we pursue it to the end. If we simply dismiss it on a priori grounds we gain nothing.Third, Haugeland himself is not dogmatic one way or the other, which is extremely refreshing. He clearly finds the prospect of AI exciting but he does not consider it inevitable. He sees the problems and challenges clearly and he does not hide them from the reader or adopt a defensive posture. It is easy to dismiss the idea of AI, but the easy dismissal of AI is generally based on our intuitive understanding of how our thought functions, and our intuitions are often wrong. One of the great things about AI research is that it often presents us with really startling, counter-intuitive hypotheses about how our minds function. And finally, Haugeland never pretends we know more than we do and he leaves the reader with lots of unsolved problems begging for thought and future research (which is a good thing).All in all, if you are looking for a good, accessible, exciting introduction to classical AI, Haugeland's book is a great place to start.

It causes me real pain to have to give this book three stars and in all honesty I was on the fence between three and four. There are lots of really beautiful and lyrical passages in this novel and the novel is certainly powerful. It is, I think, a novel about being sunk in our own karma. It is a meditation on death and the infinite aspirations we all carry trapped in the prison of our rotting mortality. I was often enthralled by McCarthy's prose and the images he creates - I was especially moved by the image of a helix of moths coiling up to a light only to fall burnt to the ground - and I have a great deal of sympathy for McCarthy's worldview (despite what my review may lead you to believe).However, I found reading this book quite tedious most of the time. I have a lot of complaints with the novel. Some of my complaints have to do with what I take to be McCarthy's "metaphysics" and some have to do with more technical aspects of the novel. This is going to be a long review because I want to be detailed about what I did not like about this book. I know a lot of McCarthy fans (and I consider myself a McCarthy fan) are going to disagree with my assessment of this novel but I hope at the end no one will wonder why I did not like this book more than I did.I will start with some of the technical aspects of the novel that made reading this book tedious. The main problem I had with the novel is that it seemed to me to be mostly atmosphere. McCarthy spends pages and pages "setting the scene", so to speak, but nothing much happens in the novel. To use an analogy, imagine a playwright who spent all of his time designing the set, getting the atmosphere just right, and then realized he did not have time to actually write a script, so he just let his characters wander around for awhile in the beautiful set, and called that a play. That is how this novel feels to me. McCarthy did a great job creating his set but then he just lets his characters wander through it for awhile and calls that a novel. He even has some interesting characters (more on that later) and he occasionally has them do interesting things (especially Harrogate) but the focus is not right.He makes what should be the background (the atmosphere) the foreground and what should be the foreground (the plot) the background. The plot seems incidental to McCarthy's real interest: the decay of the material world, which McCarthy never tires of describing. His  obsession with rot and decay eventually becomes monotonous and boring. Whether he is describing a field, the woods, the river, or the streets of Knoxville, McCarthy always picks out the same exact details: litter, ripped newspaper, weeds, rusting metal of some kind, feces, and usually an animal carcass, and all of his adjectives refer to decay or rot. The book reads in places like a long list of objects that McCarthy finds distasteful or like a list of evidence in a trial against God (Exhibit A: What about animal feces, your honor? Pretty disgusting, right? Well, it exists in the world YOU created, Lord! What do you have to say about that?).To make matters worse, what plot there is McCarthy manages to confuse in a number of ways. First, he has a whole host of characters with strange names (J-Bone, Cabbage, Hoghead), or sometimes he just refers to them as "junkman" or "blindman", but he does not do a good enough job introducing or individuating them, so the reader never has a very clear idea of who is who. Plus, when McCarthy has dialogue with his characters he often does not label who is speaking. He apparently does not want to clutter up the page but dialogue is one of the best ways to reveal  and individuate character. We often learn what people are like by the way they talk so, by not labeling the dialogue, it makes the characters even more shadowy and amorphous.There are only a few really clear characters in the book: Suttree, of course, Gene Harrogate (who is, by far, the most interesting character in the book), and Ab Jones (and a few others whose names are escaping me). The rest of the characters never really stand out well enough against the background. That can be a problem and detracts from the potential power of some of the scenes. For example, late in the book Suttree picks up a paper and reads that "Hoghead" is dead (403). This could potentially be a powerful scene if the reader can remember who Hoghead is. By that point in the novel I certainly did not remember who Hoghead was.Gene Harrogate is the one real success of the novel (other than the novel's lyricism). He is the most interesting character and he has the most interesting story arc, if you can call it that. He is simple in a lot of ways, our first sight of him involves the violation of watermelons, but he is quite clever in a lot of ways as well. He figures out a way to kill bats that inspires a doctor's admiration and he is always working on some get rich quick scheme. He is funny, interesting, and he has an interesting story. I wish he was in the book more. There are huge sections where he does not appear at all and the reader feels his absence. I kept wanting the story to get back to him.Suttree is not, in my opinion, a similar success as a character. McCarthy shares with Hemingway an aversion to the inner lives of his characters. He only portrays inner lives through outer action and it is partly for that reason that Suttree feels like a blank screen to me. He registers everything around him but it is not clear what he wants or what he is doing or feeling. We know that he has had some falling out with his family but we never really learn what it is. He goes and sees an aunt in an insane asylum late in the book and I kept thinking, "Alright, we are going to get some revelation" but, instead, we get a very convoluted genealogy crammed into a couple of paragraphs and that is it.Hemingway also had what he called an "iceberg theory". Hemingway believed you could leave anything out of a story, as long as the author knew it was there, and the reader would feel it. However, it was important that the author know what he was leaving out, otherwise, it was just an excuse to be lazy. McCarthy presents the reader with the tip of the iceberg: Suttree's uncle visits him early in the novel and they discuss his family in an oblique way, his mother visits him in prison, he is chased away from his son's funeral by his wife and their family, etc.. You know something else is there, but I don't think that even McCarthy knew what else was there, and the reader feels that. The reader can feel that there is no wizard behind the curtain.I also do not feel like I really felt the emotions of the characters in the novel. McCarthy does a good job conveying disgust in the reader, and the self-disgust of his characters, but he is not as good at conveying their sadness, or even their despair. When Suttree's son dies he is clearly very sad but the reader does not feel it. I had actual tears in my eyes when I read The Road. McCarthy was successful at conveying genuine sadness in that book but I did not feel it in this one.The same goes for the character's despair which feels too intellectual. Characters say they want to die and that they are tired of life, but again, I did not feel it. It felt like the kind of despair that arises when a philosopher contemplates the world (as a former philosophy student I know all about that). Chekhov wrote a story about a man imprisoned in an insane asylum (I might not have those details exactly right). The despair in Chekhov's story was so intense it made me want to jump out of my skin. It was crushing. I never felt that in this novel. I never felt the character's hopelessness. They often expressed it in words but I did not feel it.Now, I will say a word about the metaphysics of the novel. I think all of our aesthetic judgments are tied up with judgments about what we think is true. So, it is impossible to separate our aesthetic judgments from our judgments about what the world is at a fundamental level. I would never characterize myself as an optimist. There are times when I am afraid to reflect on the world because I feel myself pulled towards what the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche called an "incurable pessimism". I tend to be drawn toward writers who have a bleak view of life, I like to read authors whose work answers to the dark questionings that consume my own soul.However, McCarthy takes pessimism to a whole new level in this novel. I felt like I was being beat over the head with it. I felt like saying something I don't think I have ever said to another human being "Cheer up McCarthy! Things aren't so bad!"I think McCarthy has the sensibility of a lapsed Catholic. I am Catholic myself. At least, I was baptized Catholic. My own feelings about Catholicism are quite complicated and an amazon review is not the place to air them. However, I recognize a sensibility in McCarthy that I also recognize in myself. Catholics often have sort of a bleak view of the world and the pleasures of the flesh. This surfaces in McCarthy's views on the physical world (his most common adjectives refer to decay, rotting, etc.) and sex (McCarthy describes the activities in a brothel as "brief ruts spent...in the joyless dark").In that latter description, we see that, for McCarthy, there is no joy in human sexuality. It is compulsion. However, in the "full" Catholic view there is also the "good news" of Christ's redemption. In the light of Christ's redemption we can say, with the Catholic monk Thomas Merton (who I believe was quoting William Blake) "Everything that is, is holy." McCarthy keeps all the pessimism but without the good news. He even says explicitly in the novel "no news is good", and I take that to be a reference to Christianity.And just so I am not misunderstood, I am not attacking McCarthy for rejecting Christianity (I know nothing about McCarthy's actual religious views). I am simply pointing to a sensibility that I think pervades this book (and probably all of McCarthy's work): he has accepted all of the most depressing and pessimistic aspects of Christianity and discarded the rest, at least when he is constructing his novelistic world. He has rejected the notion of heaven as a vain illusion but he still believes in the existence of hell. All of his characters still strive for some kind of redemption but they are not allowed to believe in it or hope for it. At one point Suttree is standing in a lightning storm "It cracked and boomed about and he pointed out the darkened heart within him and cried for light."This is a character who is crying out for some kind of redemption but he never gets any kind of a vision of anything beyond his own miserable life. The closest he comes to a vision is when he is lying on his bed staring at "the light in the ceiling thirty feet above like some dim nebula viewed from the pit." In some novels, this might have been a vision of an "otherworldly beauty", perhaps unattainable, but still a promise of something beyond the world. But, in this case, he is simply staring at an artificial light in a run down building. There is nothing of promise in the description.SPOILER ALERT. The end of the book is, surprisingly, not utterly hopeless. There is an image of a white concrete highway that suggests something like a passage into an afterlife, though it curves into empty air with iron rods pointing into vectors of nowhere. But at least Suttree is leaving Knoxville. There is a sense that he is pulling himself out of the mire of his own karma (if, in fact, he is still alive, and I think there is some reason to doubt that). The hounds of hell have not managed to snatch him, at least.
