But the vision of the white highway is ultimately unconvincing and fails to convey a sense of otherworldly beauty or resolution (compare the scene to Honda's walk into the garden at the end of Mishima's The Decay of the Angel and you will see what I mean).I think McCarthy is also a bit of a Romantic, mourning the loss of a childlike vision that has not yet been introduced to the cruel realities of the world. There is a beautiful passage late in the novel that describes two ways of looking at a carnival, "Suttree wondered if she were ever a child at a fair dazed by the constellations of light and the hurdy-gurdy music of the merrygoround and the raucous call of the barkers. Who saw in all that shoddy world a vision that child's grace knows and never the sweat and the bad teeth and the nameless stains in the sawdust, the flies and the stale delirium and the vacant look of solitaries who go among these garish holdings seeking a thing they could not name" (408-409).This passage probably encapsulates everything I loved and hated about this novel so I will analyze it in a little detail and then bring this ridiculously long review to a close. First, I think it is a beautiful passage, and captures beautifully a certain vision of the world: as a carnival, full of vacant solitaries, who are seeking for something, but they don't know what. It is a beautiful little encapsulation of the human condition.However, there are lots of different ways of looking at a carnival, as this passage itself makes clear. Children see "constellations of light" and throngs of people having fun, celebrating life, while the pessimist sees nothing but bad teeth, nameless stains in the sawdust, and hopeless imbeciles striving toward some unachievable goal. If you were to ask a pessimist to describe a carnival they could no doubt give you a powerful description of the seedy underbelly of carnivals, the cheats, the broken promises, the dirt, the feces. That is essentially what Suttree is. A novel written by someone who looks at the carnival of the world and sees nothing but the dirt, the cheats, the feces, and the shattered hopes.McCarthy seems to think that is the only "true" way of looking at a carnival. He feels annihilated by the truth but he is unwilling to comfort himself with an illusion. But what he considers the "truth" is merely his thought about the truth. The death that McCarthy is so troubled by in this novel is really the thought of death. Not death itself. It is not nothingness that oppresses us but the thought of nothingness, and it is not death that makes us miserable - how could it? - but the thought that we must die (which, of course, is true). If we could stop clinging to our ideas of being and nothingness we might be able to see the carnival like a child again. But, I think, in this novel at least, McCarthy is too obsessed with his own thoughts about death. He sees the world through tired eyes and, not surprisingly, seeing the world through his eyes eventually becomes tiring.

There is a lot to appreciate in The Mayor of Casterbridge. The novel has an interesting plot full of twists and turns and fateful accidents. It is an interesting character study of a man who feels hounded by fate but is ultimately trapped in his own character. It can be viewed as a study in self-destruction, and I also think it is sort of a mournful cry of resignation in the face of an indifferent world, though that might be just my own subjective interpretation.The plot of the novel centers around Michael Henchard and a small cast of supporting characters. The novel opens with Henchard selling his wife and daughter at a fair. The next day he is repentant and swears off drink for twenty one years. A sober Henchard eventually becomes mayor of Casterbridge and his wife and daughter return. I am not going to follow all the twists and turns of the plot but Hardy makes a point to connect the events in the novel, and the unraveling of Henchard's fate, to his character (hence the title of my review)Henchard often feels as if there is a malevolent power operating in the world. There are lots of little accidents that continually undo his plans, but Hardy makes it clear that it is Henchard's decisions and character that rule his fate, and not some malevolent force. Henchard is a tragic character because he is sympathetic in many ways. He is not evil but he has some pretty serious "tragic flaws". He is impulsive and he has a temper. He is constantly moving from relative tenderness, to rage, to vengeance, to repentance before beginning the cycle all over again.The novel, I think, is about how hard it is to escape from ourselves. Henchard recognizes that his drinking has gotten him into trouble in the past and he manages to give that up (for awhile, at least) but he is unable to master his impulsiveness or his temper. The sadness of the novel comes from our sympathy for Henchard. When he is not in the clutches of his rage, he can be tender and loving. The occasional tenderness he shows Elizabeth-Jane is touching but it is punctuated by seemingly unprovoked cruelty. It can be frustrating for the reader because we can see Henchard sabotaging himself, and destroying what human sympathy he has, with his rash overreactions. It is like watching a family member self-destruct.It is always easy to look at someone's life from the outside and say "Well, why did you this, or this, or this? If you had just done this different things would have worked out." But we all know how hard it is to change our own characters. We follow them even to destruction. Hardy has a melancholy view of the world that is quite explicit, where happiness is "but the occasional episode in a general drama of pain", and I think the difficulty of changing our characters, even when we see they are causing us suffering, is at the heart of this melancholy view of the world.I appreciated the way that Hardy portrayed his characters as fluctuating, particularly Henchard. I recently read The Rainbow by D.H. Lawrence and I know one of D.H. Lawerence's innovations was the abandonment of the permanent ego. As human beings we are made up of competing impulses and we are always changing. Hardy portrays brilliantly the struggles of a conflicted character. Henchard is loving at one moment and cruel the next. Our characters are not consistent. They are not simple identities and do not obey the law of non-contradiction.I think Henchard's ultimate "tragic flaw" is his rage against fate. In Lawerence, our conflicts with ourselves lead to growth, and we are eventually able to break out of the prisons of our limited egos. Henchard never fully succeeds in breaking out of the prison of his ego but he begins to resign himself to his fate and to the world. He quits fighting against everything and it allows him more space to love the people around him. The image of Henchard carrying his bird cage to Elizabeth-Jane's wedding was quite poignant and sad.Ultimately, I think this is a novel about a very willful person crashing against the world and breaking, and I think the power of the novel comes from the fact that we all recognize ourselves in that description, to some degree at least.

This volume is a collection of critical essays on Flannery O'Connor's novel Wise Blood. The opening essays analyze the novel from a religious perspective, providing insights into O'Connor's theology and how it effects the world and the characters she creates in the novel. The middle set of essays analyze some of the humor in the book, some of the influences on O'Connor (including Kafka and Dostoevsky), and structural issues. The final set of essays (which, unfortunately, I did not have time to read) examine gender and cultural issues in the novel and discuss the film adaptation of the novel.I found Wise Blood to be somewhat opaque. I knew next to nothing about O'Connor before reading it. I knew she was a Catholic with a reputation for writing brutal books but other than that I knew very little about her theology or her worldview. When I finished the book I was not really sure what I was supposed to make of it. What were we, as readers, supposed to think about characters as strange as Haze and Enoch? Were we supposed to feel hopeful over Haze's "conversion"? Was it genuine? What about Enoch's "conversion"?This set of essays helped me get my bearings. I read a lot of literary criticism and the main reason I read it is because it helps me organize my thoughts about a book. Reading literary criticism is like looking for circling vultures in the sky. It lets you know where the meat is. The parts of a novel that critics circle around and debate are often (though, perhaps, not always) the most interesting parts. Even if you disagree with a particular author they they can still help guide you to the meat. Once you are there you can taste it and make up your own mind.I was not blown away by this volume but it definitely helped me find the meat in O'Connor's novel. I am not going to summarize every essay but I want to summarize a couple. The ones I found most interesting. Unfortunately, I got this book from the library and I have already returned it and I did not take the best notes. It is not always clear from my notes whether I was writing down what the author was saying in the essay or the thoughts I had in response to the essay but I will do my best to remain faithful to the authors's intentions in my summaries, and apologize in advance if I accidentally put words in someone's mouth."Flannery O'Connor and the Question of the Christian Novel" by Debra L. CumberlandDebra Cumberland attempts to determine "what kind of a depiction of Christianity and the Christian experience is actually conveyed in the novel" (5) Debra is ultimately somewhat critical of O'Connor's version of Christianity as portrayed in the novel. For one thing, it is too Manichaean. The material world is evil and the spiritual world is good. Haze draws away from the world into isolation while Enoch plunges into his animal self. There is no reconciliation of the animal and spiritual halves of man. They are split asunder. The material world is ultimately left out of Christ's act of redemption in the novel.This worldview infects the humor in the novel which is bitter, satiric, and full of sarcastic derision (15) It is not "redemptive humor".  Cumberland makes a good point "...'it is impossible to love God and to have contempt for the sins and weaknesses of other people at the same time.' Yet this is exactly what Haze does" (16) Haze's conversion does not come with a corresponding sense of compassion for the sins and errors of the world. Quite the opposite: it isolates him even further from the world. He has even more contempt for the world in the end than he did in the beginning (if that is possible).Cumberland concludes that Wise Blood does not present a Christian conversion or the act of grace or redemption but it still may be a Christian novel because it portrays a Christian vision of hell (18-19)"Virgil if Punched in the Gut: A Defense of Jansenist Interpretations of Wise Blood" by Andrew Peter AtkinsonAtkinson begins with a brief introduction to Jansenism as a theological doctrine. Briefly put, Jansenism posits a radical separation between nature and grace with a corresponding devaluation of nature. The novel is Jansenist in theological outlook because Haze does not cooperate with grace. In fact, he actively works against it. He does everything in his power to deny Christ and his redemptive grace but he fails. Grace conquers nature in the end.According to Atkinson, "What Wise Blood lacks are characters who love virtue for virtue's sake", i.e. the virtuous pagan (Virgil). If I may be allowed to add my own thought to this: I think this is one of the ways in which O'Connor stacks the deck. She drives the reader toward the necessity for an act of supernatural redemption, and to do so she begins with a description of the world without grace, but her description lacks everything we would recognize as human. It is a world without love, community, morality, friendship, or any other purely "human" virtue. She sucks the world dry, presents the shell, and then asks "Isn't something missing from your supposedly self-contained secular world?""The Dostoevskyan Structure of Flannery O'Connor's Wise Blood" by Lylas Dayton RommelRommel compares the worldview of O'Connor with that of Dostoevsky. Dostoevsky was Orthodox while O'Connor was, of course, Catholic. This led to differences in their world views. For example, O'Connor's worldview was rooted in the natural law of the Catholic Church. For O'Connor, without the Catholic Church and natural law as guarantees of order the political world descends into chaos. But, for Dostoevsky, "The idea of equality among individual people based simply on the humanity of each is sufficient to discover moral principles" (294). This does not require uniformity of belief while for O'Connor uniformity of belief is necessary to avoid chaos.Rommel also highlights the different uses of shame in the two authors. In Dostoevsky, shame "derives from isolation from human community", i.e. from a failure to admit your fundamental equality with your fellow human beings. For O'Connor, shames "derives from participation in a false political system." Rommel argues that "shame for a system that allows people to believe and behave however they want pervades the structure of Wise Blood" (295)Rommel ends with what I think is a great quote so I will present it in full, "The Christian response to the complexity of the modern world is to see the 'other' as Christ, not to blame him or her...The fear that modern moral choice is really an excuse for nihilism and relativism can be overcome by compassion for the human suffering of blind and limited persons trying to do the best they can under the difficult circumstances of modern life...respect for different perspectives preserves human freedom in ways that O'Connor's argument does not" (302)You will probably notice a common theme in the essays I chose to highlight. They are all somewhat critical of O'Connor's religious vision. This was, basically, my response to the novel as well. I actually really enjoyed the novel as a novel and I think it had a lot to recommend it. However, I have some fairly profound theological and ideological differences with O'Connor and her novel is saturated in her own theology. It is impossible, I think, to totally separate the novel, considered as a piece of art for aesthetic contemplation, and O'Connor's theology.Actually, I do not believe there is such a thing as "pure aesthetic contemplation" divorced from a concern with truth. The things we find beautiful are tied up with judgments about their truth. So, my own analysis of O'Connor's novel is tied up with my appraisal of the ideas contained in it. However, I will say that not all the essays in the book are critical of O'Connor so, if you love O'Connor, and are in general agreement with her theology, I would not let my review deter you from this volume. You will find plenty of food to enjoy and you can spit out the rest.

The Rainbow is one of my very favorite novels and Duane Edwards has written an excellent analysis of the novel. Edwards starts out with a very interesting examination of the historical context of the novel. The novel was written around the time of the Great War - a time of great pessimism and great cultural change. It was a time when society was transforming and it became necessary to discover new values. That is one of the great themes of the novel as succeeding generations of the Brangwens have to confront the modern world and create their own religions to sustain them.Edwards also analyzes Lawrence's personal biography and how it influences the novel. One of the most important themes of the novel is the need to grow and adjust in response to our relationships with other human beings - particularly marriage - and the often difficult struggle that ensues when trying to come to terms with another human being. Edwards relates this aspect of the novel to Lawrence's own relationship with Frieda.Edwards also discusses the revolutionary aspects of Lawrence's novel. Lawrence was really doing something very new with The Rainbow. He was discarding the permanent ego. Lawrence believed that our true selves lied in the unconscious, and were always becoming and changing, and he had to find a way to present the unconscious lives of his characters. How, for example, does a writer present the often non-verbal communications that take place, often below the threshold of consciousness, between a man and woman who are married? So much of our communication, and the rising and falling intensities of our lives, are non-verbal so, how does a writer present the non-verbal in a verbal medium?  This is one problem that confronted Lawrence in writing this novel.In the section on the critical reception of the work Edwards presents a really handy survey of the critical literature on D.H. Lawrence and The Rainbow. All of these Twayne series are organized in the same way, and I have read quite a few of them, and the section on critical reception is usually quite short and focuses mainly on the shifting opinions of a work throughout its history. What Edwards does is provide a list of the major works that have been written about Lawrence, summarizes them briefly, and shows how different critics have focused on different aspects of Lawrence's work, and how interpretations have shifted through time. Anyone who loves Lawrence will love this section because they will get to add a bunch of books to their "to read list".Edwards also presents some of the philosophical views that Lawrence held and that inform his fiction. For example, he briefly discusses Lawrence's study of Thomas Hardy, and his rejection of Hardy's pessimism, and Edwards makes the very interesting observation that, for Lawrence, the study of man's deepest motives "does not result in a denigration of man; rather, it reveals that man's deepest motives are religious or creative" (20). Most modern novels that explicitly - or implicitly - set out to probe the unconscious, and to get at the deep roots of human behavior, wind up taking a rather pessimistic view of human nature.It seems like most modern novelists assume that any dive into the unconscious is going to reveal all the worsts aspects of ourselves - all of our sexual obsessions and aggression that we usually hide behind carefully constructed masks. This is a very Freudian view (and probably a Christian view as well). The things that we repress are repressed because they are socially and morally unacceptable so, if we go exploring in the dark reaches of ourselves, we are bound to find monsters.Of course, it would be a hopelessly rosy view to deny that we do find these things in our unconscious but, for Lawrence anyways, when we probe all the way down, to the deepest roots of our lives, what we find is a fundamental urge for growth, a joy in creativity and in life, a search for fulfillment, and a desire to love and be loved (perhaps even a desire to worship?). I think this is actually a much more realistic view of human nature - we often assume for some reason that the more pessimistic view is the more realistic - and it is one of the things I love about Lawrence, so I was glad that Edwards highlighted it. If I may be permitted a final sidenote on this issue: even Freudian analysis, which in some ways has a fairly pessimistic view of human nature, relies on the creative urge towards health in order to be effective.The rest of Edwards book provides a detailed analysis of the novel through an analysis of the main characters and their relationships and desires. I will not provide a detailed summary of the rest of the book. I highly recommend that anyone who loves The Rainbow read Edwards's book for all of the insights scattered throughout the rest of the volume. I will just say this: Edwards sees the book as fundamentally about Ursula. Her story certainly takes up the largest portion of the book and, Edwards argues, the history of her family provides the context, all the shaping influences, that molded Ursula's character. It is a way of showing the dependence, but also the freedom, of Ursula in relation to her past.Because Edwards views the novel as fundamentally about Ursula he sees a progression in the book. The novel becomes a progression from "surety" to a loss of surety and the search for a resolution. The earlier couples in the novel still have surety. Tom and Lydia have a more successful relationship than Anna and Will precisely because they still have surety. The process of accommodation between Tom and Lydia becomes an open war with Anna and Will. It is up to Ursula to successfully solve the problem left unsolved by Anna and Will.I admit, when I first read the novel this is not how I read it. I read it as purposely repetitive rather than progressive. Each generation's struggle is the same as the last generation. Each generation must solve their problems for themselves and each couple comes to their own form of accommodation in the end. I still like my own reading but I was glad to have Edwards present another perspective on the novel that is probably closer to Lawrence's intentions. All in all, I thought this was a very thought-provoking and substantive look at one of the most beautiful novels written in the twentieth-century (or any century).

Beowulf is a medieval epic poem about a hero who comes from the land of the Geats (modern Sweden) to a Danish hall in order to kill the monster Grendel who has been wreaking havoc there. The poem follows Beowulf's exploits in killing Grendel and his mother, the celebrations in the halls of the Danes, a few old stories as digressions that give some of the history of the Danes, and Beowulf's death at the hands of a dragon.The poem is an heroic epic that celebrates the exploits of Beowulf, similar to the stories told about Achilles and the Greek heroes that eventually became The Iliad, but there is a melancholy atmosphere in Beowulf that, to me, contrasts sharply with the Greek heroic stories. There is always a sense of ultimate destruction looming in the future. For example, when the poet is describing the Danes hall in the very beginning of the poem his admiration is mixed with a forecast of the future, "The hall towered/its gables wide and high and awaiting/a barbarous burning" (lines 81-83).The sense of tragedy does not only lie in the future but the past as well. There is lengthy interlude regarding Hildeburh and a fight between the Danes and Jutes (I believe, correct me if I'm wrong) in which Hildeburh is tragically caught in the middle of a fight that claims the lives of her son and brother. The sense of melancholy in the poem is so strong that Tolkien categorizes the poem as an elegy rather than an epic poem.There has been a lot of argument over whether Beowulf is a Christian or pagan poem. There is no doubt that the poem takes place in pagan times. The characters in the poem are not Christian though they seem to be monotheists and the poet presents them as virtuous pagans to be admired. Thomas D. Hill argues, in his essay in this volume, that the poem is a "radical synthesis of pagan and Christian history" and that the poet imagines his pagan heroes as saved. When Beowulf's grandfather Hrethel dies the poet writes "Heartsore, wearied he turned away/from life's joys, chose God's light/and departed" (2468-69)The poet definitely seems to be suggesting that Hrethel has joined God in heaven. However, what I find most interesting about this passage, and the poem in its entirety, is that, even though there is definitely a strong Christian strain in it, the mood of the poem is not one of Christian hope, or the celebration of Christ's victory over death. Death is a melancholy absolute in the poem. Even in the line about Hrethel "choosing God's light" we feel more melancholy about his "turning away from life's joys" than we feel glad over the prospect of his blissful afterlife.It is possible I am projecting a purely subjective interpretation on the poem but, what I find interesting in the poem, is the dual sense that earthly life is a veil of tears - where the earthly powers of greed and avarice and violence and death hold sway (which is certainly Christian) - combined with this deep sense of sadness over having to leave the world and "life's joys"- even with a heavenly home awaiting. I think this is one reason the poem is still moving today. To sum it up in a very trite formula: life is difficult and painful from beginning to end but we very much hate to leave.Now just a brief word on the essays in this volume (I cannot really comment on Heaney's translation much since it is the only translation I have read and I cannot read Old English to compare it to the original). The essays are certainly interesting and many of them are quite helpful in providing insights into the themes of the poem, its meaning, its historical context, etc. However, many of the essays are really (I think) geared more towards scholars. Many of the essays, instead of explicating the poem for the new reader, pick a scholarly position and spend their time defending it, often without referencing the actual poem much at all.I realize that is what scholars do, especially with an historical poem like Beowulf, but for non-scholars like myself, who are really just looking for an increased appreciation of the poem, I would have preferred more essays that analyzed the poem and its themes rather than arguing a very specific thesis that I am too uninformed to form much of an opinion about. The stand out essays for me were Tolkien's essay "Beowulf: The Monsters and the Critics", John Leyerle's essay "The Interlace Structure of Beowulf", Jane Chance's essay "The Structural Unity of Beowulf: The Problem of Grendel's Mother", and "The Tomb of Beowulf" by Fred C. Robinson.

This is a really beautiful novella and I don't think there is any way I am going to be able to do it any kind of justice in a review. I am a philosophy student, and I tend to read a lot of philosophical novels, and then I sometimes write very long reviews (some might say too long) discussing the ideas that I find interesting in novels. I don't think there are a lot of ideas in this novel but there is a lot of heart and lyricism and sadness. It is the kind of novel that will stay with you long after you read it.The novel follows a man named Robert Grainier. He works as a logger off and on and he marries and tries to start a family. It is a simple story but it is told in beautiful prose. Johnson manages to be lyrical without being overly ornate or drawing too much attention to his large vocabulary. I consider that quite an accomplishment. The novel is full of genuinely poignant moments. Grainier traveling through the scorched earth after the forest fire, his relationship with his dog, and his penchant for howling.It is a very earthy novel. The characters are all very in touch with the earth. Some might call them simple but they are supremely human and Johnson portrays them with the utmost love and sympathy. Grainier himself does not have any real grand ambitions. He just wants the basics: food, shelter and love. He is also a bit superstitious (he believes the bad things that happen to him are the result of a curse placed upon him by a Chinese man he and a group of railroad workers tried to throw off a bridge).The novel is about a very specific place and time but it also manages to be a universal howling cry of sadness in the face of all the struggles we face as human beings (death, grief, labor, sexual desire, etc.). I am not sure what else I can say about the novel other than: I think you should probably read it. You will enjoy it more than this review. I promise (I know, I am not setting the bar real high there).

I watched this movie right after I finished reading the novel by Jim Thompson (when I say right after I mean minutes after). The movie is quite faithful to the book. I spotted very few deviations from the book and the movie actually helped to clarify a number of plot points I was vague about after reading the book. If you have read the book, and you enjoyed it, I recommend watching the movie. I think they did a good job adapting it for the screen and all the acting seemed excellent to me.The movie is quite disturbing (more disturbing than the book which I thought was lighter in tone). The book it is based on is a first person narration told from the point of view of a serial killer. The story follows a small town deputy sheriff who suffers from a sickness which we usually call sociopathy or psychopathy. He has kept it under control for years until a new prostitute shows up in town that awakes the demon. The narrator does not really have any redeeming moral qualities. People who think that books or movies - or art in general - should have a moral purpose or at least confirm our standard moral values will probably find this movie rather despicable.However, anyone looking to this movie for moral education is looking in the wrong place. Lou Ford is not being held up as a hero in this film or someone to emulate and it is quite clear that no one is endorsing the kind of behavior that is being portrayed in the film. I would also point out that, unlike most shoot em' up movies made today, the violence in this movie is actually hard to watch, which is what violence should be! I think more damage is done by movies that portray violence as "exciting" and "fun" than by movies like this that portray violence as genuinely horrifying.There are two really horrific scenes in this movie and they are shot as they should be: with very little embellishment. It is just bare. There is no fancy choreography, no crashing through windows, no flying kicks, no dramatic music (that I remember). There is nothing cool, slick, romantic or exciting about it. When you are watching Lou beat Joyce, or Amy lying twitching on the floor in a puddle of her own urine, you just want it to end. You get to see how sickening that kind of violence really is. Which is why I think some of the moral criticisms of this movie miss the mark. It is a brutal movie but it does not romanticize that brutality which I found refreshing.There were a few things I did not like about the movie. I thought the pacing seemed weird in some places but, all in all, I thought the filmmakers did a good job adapting a strange and disturbing novel into a strange and disturbing movie. Although you will definitely need to cleanse your palate afterwards. At least I did.

I am not a big genre fiction reader and this is really the first book of "noir" I have read. I am somewhat fascinated by the darker dimensions of the human psyche and there was something about a first person narrative told from the point of view of a serial killer that drew me in. There was a lot that I enjoyed, and even admired, about this book, but I cannot say that I was blown away by it. I am not rushing out to read more Jim Thompson.Thompson does a good job creating an interesting sociopath. The tone of the novel, despite its violent subject matter, is actually relatively lighthearted and even humorous in places. The narrator loves to torture the townspeople by spitting endless cliches at them (every cloud has a silver lining, its not the heat but the humidity, etc.) which I found rather humorous. Thompson does not portray the narrator as simply insane. He reasons, he produces rationalizations for his actions, and it is only in the end, when the narrator has a moment of insight into his true motivations, that we come to see that his reasonings were merely masks for his dark impulses.The plot unwinds in a satisfactory way. It is not overly simple or overly complex. There are a number of interlocking pieces that all come together in the end. A lot of the necessary background to the plot is revealed in dialogue which sometimes feels like it is just pure exposition dialogue put in for the benefit of the reader (like the first conversation between Lou and the union leader where Lou recounts his history and the death of his adopted brother). However, all in all it is a well constructed plot and I was especially pleased with the ending. I admit, I did not see the ending coming, but it seemed so obvious once it was revealed that I was amazed I had not seen it coming.I would not rate this book among the best I have ever read but I certainly have no regrets. If you are a fan of noir or are fascinated by the dark reaches of the human mind I recommend giving this book a try (although I am not really sure there is much insight into the psychology of serial killers in the book it still makes for an interesting novel).

I have what some might call a prejudice against short books. When I am really interested in a subject I usually want as much depth as possible so I generally gravitate towards long books. A thousand pages to me is an ideal length if the subject is interesting. Eliot Deutsch's book on Advaita Vedanta is definitely on the short side but it is a masterpiece of concision. Deutsch manages to pack the essentials of Advaita Vedanta into just a little over a hundred pages without it feeling dumbed down or overly simplified.Deutsch manages to provide an overview of Vedantan ontology (theory of being), epistemology (theories of knowledge), and ethics (theories of the good) in an accessible style without sacrificing philosophical depth.I first encountered this book years ago when I took a class on Eastern philosophy at community college. It was the first philosophy class I ever took. I eventually went on to get a Masters degree in philosophy (although I did not specialize in Eastern philosophy). I can say from personal experience that this book is great for all levels, no matter where you are in your philosophical education. It worked great as a basic introduction to Advaita Vedanta when I was just starting out in philosophy, before I even knew what terms like "epistemology" or "ontology" meant, and it has also been a great resource after years of studying philosophy.Lots of books claim to be great for "lay readers" and "scholars" alike but this book really delivers in that regard. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an introduction to Advaita Vedanta whatever level of philosophical sophistication you happen to be at.

This is an excellent collection of essays on William Faulkner's Sanctuary. Rather than provide a general summary I will just summarize the individual essays themselves to give the potential a reader a taste of what they will be getting with this volume. Warning: this is going to be a VERY long review. The essays were very thought provoking."Introduction" by J. Douglas CanfieldCanfield provides a good general introduction to Faulkner's novel as well as the various critical approaches and controversies surrounding the novel. Canfield discusses the major changes that Faulkner made between the first and final drafts of the novel, he points to some of the ambiguities of the novel that have led to critical debate and speculation (why does Temple perjure herself?), he draws attention to many of the major themes, including the theme of evil which we all tend to project outward but which, ultimately, exists in all of us, he examines some of the social themes raised by the novel (the proletariat - the bootleggers - and the bourgeoisie - the townspeople), and he concludes with an interesting discussion of Nietzsche's views on tragedy and the role of the Dionysian and Apollonian in the novel."Crime and Punishment: Sanctuary"  by Olga W. VickeryOlga Vickery provides a very interesting sociological analysis of the novel and makes a number of very interesting points. She argues that there are two societies in the novel with their own social codes. The bootleggers - out at the Old Frenchman place - live by one code, and the townspeople - including the university where Temple goes to school - live by another. There are different languages at work in each, signs have different meanings in the different contexts. Temple's flirtatiousness, for example, is a sign that is read a certain way at the university, among the college boys and town boys, but it is read very differently at the Old Frenchman place. At the Old Frenchman place it is read as an invitation and as license. The violence in the novel arises from the invasion of one society by the other.Vickery points out that both societies were getting along alright until the foreign element intruded. Lee keeps his home relatively violence free until Gowan and Temple introduce a foreign element into the situation.Vickery provides a very interesting analysis of Horace. She points out, correctly, that what "reduces Horace to a state of shock is the discovery not of evil but of the shoddy foundations of his vision of a moral and rational universe." Horace is not horrified at the mere existence of evil (Popeye) but the total failure of the institutions of "the church, the state, and the law" in the face of evil. They wind up participating in it. She also points out that Horace is concerned with abstractions rather than the realities of experience (his idealism is destroyed against the harsh rocks of the reality of experience). Vickery puts this very nicely, "He [Horace] offers Goodwin the protection of `law, justice, civilization' against the concrete menace of Popeye's gun" and when attempting to convince Temple to testify he stresses the importance of truth and justice while Miss Reba "cuts through the abstract verbiage" and reminds Temple that they are going to hang a human being and Ruby and the baby will be left on their own. Horace lives in an abstraction and he is horrified to learn that in the realities of experience "'good and evil' do not live in separate compartments."Vickery points out that both of the "societies" in the novel lack something. The "moral society" of the town lacks personal virtue. They are concerned with propriety but they are hypocrites who treat Ruby cruelly. The bootlegging society has "personal virtue" but they live outside the law. Being a philosophy student, I am reminded of Hegel's vision of moral society. For Hegel, having "personal virtue" is not enough (to live by private moral laws); those moral laws needed to have concrete form in society, they needed to be concrete by becoming the actual laws of an actual society. Hegel had a vision of a harmonious moral society. In contrast to Hegel's harmonious vision, Faulkner's vision seems torn between a tragic either/or. You can either give into society, as Narcissa does, and give up your absolute moral vision, or you can live tragically grasping towards an unrealizable ideal, as Horace does.Vickery also points out that Temple and Ruby are parallels of one another. Temple is the "respectable girl" who finds herself in the "underworld" while Ruby is the "harlot" who finds herself in "respectable society". Both are invasions and both lead to violence."William Faulkner's Sanctuary: An Analysis" by Lawrence S. KubieKubie argues that Faulkner's novel rests on "unconscious sources" of anxiety, and the primary unconscious source of anxiety structuring the novel is male anxiety about and fear of impotence in the face of instinctual forces. To give concrete form to this anxiety Kubie imagines a man tied down and forced to watch as his wife is raped. This theme is exemplified both in Popeye's literal impotence and Horace's more symbolic impotence.Kubie does a good job drawing out the nightmare quality of Temple's time at the Old Frenchman place. Kubie compares Temple's experience at the Old Frenchman place to the dreams we have where we run higher and higher but cannot escape a danger or we try to run but we cannot move. Temple is in the underworld or the unconscious at the Old Frenchman place.Kubie also sees the novel as a conflict between our blind instinctual forces and the equally blind vengefulness of an enraged conscience (the Id and Superego). Neither force is rational and the ego (Horace) is torn apart and disillusioned by their interminable struggle, worn out to the point of nihilism. Benbow is the "weak representative of the much battered `Ego,' that fragment of the personality which is so often ground to pieces in the battle.""Faulkner's Popeye: The `Other' as Self" by T.H. AdamowskiAdamowski provides an interesting Sartrean reading of the novel and of Popeye in particular. Adamowski points out that Popeye is often described in terms that make him out to be a representative of mechanical nature - he is described, for example, as "stamped tin" - but Adamowski argues that Popeye's seeming indifference is a show he puts on. Popeye is treated as a scientific object in his childhood - his mother is told that he will never be older than he already is - he is treated as a piece of being in-itself, fully transparent to the for-itself consciousness. Popeye is reacting against his past, and against being treated as a transparent object by effecting opacity.Popeye's opacity is an existential project in Sartre's sense. Popeye is not, therefore, the mere product of his environment or his disease. He lives his disease, and his past, in a certain way.Adamowski also points out that we do not have access to the inner life of Popeye (this is his opacity in contrast to the other characters in the book) but we do have access to his free subjectivity and spontaneity in another way: the fear that other characters have in relation to Popeye's unpredictability. We know there is a free subjectivity there because the other characters cannot predict what he will do (mechanical nature is nothing if not predictable). The other characters "recognize that they may fall prey to the whims of this hidden consciousness that seems organized for destruction.""Gothicism in Sanctuary:  The Black Pall and the Crap Table" by David L. FrazierFrazier starts out with what I think is an interesting idea: Faulkner's novel has two strains - the gothic element (the rundown mansion in the woods, the sense of darkness and danger and evil) and the modern/comic (the bootleggers) - and Frazier sees the scene at Red's wake as exemplifying both strains. The "black pall" of the funeral represents the Gothic and the "crap table" represents the modern. However, Frazier uses this motif to develop a moral reading of the novel that I found disgusting - to put it bluntly.Frazier ultimately sees the novel as a "general moral condemnation of modern youth." I suspect this has much more to do with Frazier's own worldview than it does with Faulkner's novel.I think Frazier's moral interpretation is entirely incorrect. For example, he sees Ruby as the "virtuous Gothic maiden" and claims that the "differences between Ruby and the matron are the effects of, and point up, the evils of modern society" while he sees Temple as "spiritually rotten." He essentially treats Ruby's view of Temple as if it were Faulkner's view. Ruby sees Temple as a "selfish hypocrite who gives nothing for all she receives." Frazier forgets that Ruby views Temple as a threat and this colors her view. He also forgets that Ruby's perspective is only one perspective in the novel. It is the perspective of a specific individual, from a specific class, on another individual from a different class.So far, I think Frazier is just wrong. However, eventually his interpretation becomes chauvinistic and disgusting. Frazier writes "Temple was a virgin before the crib, but only technically; she had no virginal attitudes and therefore no purity of mind as armor against evil as had the Gothic damsel. The evil which overcame Temple came in part from within her." Frazier is, of course, right that Temple does not have a virginal attitude, but he seems to be endorsing the view that women SHOULD have a virginal attitude (i.e. they should not have sexual desires of their own and, if they do, they are "evil", which makes women partly responsible for the sexual violence that is inflicted on them). This notion that women should have "virginal attitudes" and "purity of mind" is precisely the hypocritical view held by the townspeople in the novel and it is precisely the view that Faulkner is attacking!Frazier also claims that Temple was "not raped, but seduced." In other words, Temple wanted to be raped (the usual argument made by rapists themselves)! Frazier goes on to argue that "removed from her father and brothers, her inhibitors, her concupiscence, a result of the corrupting influence of modern society, begins to control her." Of course, Frazier ignores the fact that Temple was brutally raped and abducted and sees her later "concupiscence" as a natural flowering of her natural instincts once she is free from her father and brothers. This is the same male chauvinistic view - without men to protect women their own natural sexuality is liable to run amok - that leads Quentin to suicide in The Sound and the Fury.This leads to one of the most interesting double standards in the essay. Frazier views Popeye as a symbol of the death instinct (his impotence cuts him off from his desire, the sexual instincts and life drives, eros as opposed to thanatos). In ordinary Gothic literature the villain is good except for his evil sexual obsession but, with Popeye, he is evil except his sexual desire for Temple is a life instinct that leads to the ultimate suicide of the death instinct (love conquers death). In other words, Popeye's sexual desire for Temple (which leads him to rape her) is a positive "life-force" that ultimately leads to the inner collapse or suicide of the death instinct, but Temple's ordinary sexual desires are "evil" and are the effect of "the corrupting influence of modern society." What a joke!"William Faulkner's 'Temple of Innocence'" by Aubrey WilliamsWilliams argues that the "growth and fructification of the 'seed of sin' within all children is...the major area of human experience explored in the novel." Williams sees Temple as an exemplification of this truth: that "the maturing process is inevitably a process of learning about one's own involvement with evil." Williams also highlights Horace and Popeye's childlike qualities. Horace has lived "the protected life of a nursery" and it is in Little Belle that he begins to see the ubiquitous presence of evil even in the appearance of innocence. Popeye is a kind of perpetual child and is also a symbol of evil. As such, he stands for the evil that already dwells in all children. I do not entirely agree with these characterizations or interpretations but I agree that the general theme of the "seed of sin" within all human beings is certainly a theme of the novel.Williams also makes the good point that the novel sees man "as the victim not only of himself, but also as the victim of a world, and pattern of evil, for which he is not fully responsible: man is not only the crucifier, but the crucified." Williams argues that "the ultimate shock of the novel is not to be found in the single grotesque episode in which a young girl is raped with a corn-cob. It is to be found in the larger pattern of evil and injustice of which this episode is merely one instance." I think we could say that what Horace finds so demoralizing is that the rape of Temple is not some weird anomaly in the world. The world is in conspiracy with it just as nature is in conspiracy with Little Belle's sexual dalliances. There is a cosmic dimension to evil in the novel that I think Williams is right to emphasize."The Pattern of Nightmare in Sanctuary: Miss Reba's Dogs" by William RosskyRossky draws out the nightmare quality of the novel: the fear infused paralysis and stasis that characterize Temple's time at the Old Frenchman place (Temple is constantly running and getting nowhere, soundless screams, etc.). Rossky suggests that this nightmare quality of the novel can help explain some of the mysteries of the novel. Why doesn't Temple escape into the woods? Why doesn't Horace question Temple in the courtroom? It is because the novel is a kind of nightmare. Rossky believes the image of Miss Reba's dogs cowering beneath the bed is an image of man confronted by the "universal dream-horror of existence" which is the latent metaphysics of the novel."Sanctuary and Frazer's Slain Kings" by Thomas L. McHaneyMcHaney draws out all the parallels between the imagery of Sanctuary and the rituals described in Frazer's The Golden Bough. There are simply too many parallels to summarize them all in my review but after reading McHaney's essay I am convinced that the parallels were intentional and conscious on Faulkner's part. I will just give one example. In the Eleusinian mysteries described by Frazer there was a ritual of mock copulation. A man would intentionally make himself impotent with hemlock, he would descend to a cavern with a woman, they would engage in mock copulation, and when they returned to the surface the man would hold up an ear of corn which the woman supposedly gave birth to, and which was meant to represent nature's fertility.The parallels with Popeye's impotence, Popeye and Temple's "mock" copulation, and the ear of corn held up at the trial, are too striking to be coincidences (plus, we know Faulkner owned The Golden Bough, and there are lots more parallels). McHaney sees the events of the novel as a kind of profanation of the rituals described in The Golden Bough. This represents the death of the old gods and myths. The events of the novel do not symbolize new life and fertility but death."The Profaned Temple" by David WilliamsWilliams provides a Jungian reading of the novel that I found very interesting. Williams sees Horace as a rational idealist, a representative of masculine consciousness, who thinks in terms of conceptual dichotomies, and rejects life and fertility because life and fertility are inextricably mixed up with evil, and Horace needs to keep good and evil in separate boxes. He is, in Williams's words, a representative of the "unattainable desire of the male intellect" to be "beyond the female cycle" of life and death. It is the male principle of consciousness attempting to separate itself from its source in the feminine dark.In fact, all the male characters are representatives of this principle, while Temple is a representative of the "counter-balancing tendency" of the "feminine unconscious" that ultimately unleashes its retributive vengeance on all the male characters in the book (Horace, who collapses in despair; Popeye, who is hanged for a murder he did not commit; and Lee who is burned to death for a murder he did not commit). There is a kind of Dionysian force that rises to destroy the male principle when it "pursues too strongly its spiritual independence." Temple is the unconscious agent of this force in the novel. I am not sure if I entirely agree with identifying Temple with the destructive anima but Williams reading is very interesting.Ultimately, according to Williams, the novel concludes that "Ephemeral...as gnats and no more than insect-sized, the dependent world of masculine life is conceived as being at the mercy of the dominant and perhaps capricious goddess." Of course, this flies in the face of the most obvious reading of the novel: Temple is no longer merely the victim of male sexuality (although she is that too since it is the objectification of Temple, the moving of sexuality "to the head", that unleashes the counter-balancing tendency) she is also the agent of a kind of divine retribution."Sanctuary: Style as Vision" by Arthur F. KinneyI was really looking forward to reading Kinney's essay because I have been looking forward to reading his book: Faulkner's Narrative Poetics, for a long time, and the essay in this volume is an excerpt from that book, but I am not sure I really followed his essay all that well. Perhaps it makes more sense in the context of his book. I am wondering if perhaps they cut too much out of the essay to fit it into this volume (there are ellipses throughout).What I gathered is that Kinney is attempting to draw out structural patterns and parallels in the novel: between the locations in the novel (the Old Frenchman place, Memphis, nad Jefferson) and between the characters (Popeye and Horace, Popeye and Temple, Ruby and Temple, etc.). Seeing how these places and characters are similar and different allows us, as readers, "constitutive consciousnesses" to see meaning that is not accessible to the characters themselves in their "narrative consciousness." For example, seeing all three places together supplies us "with a sense of "unified corruptibility." We see the same evil everywhere we go.Kinney does make an interesting point about Horace that is not necessarily tied to his structural interpretations (which I do not entirely follow). The reason Horace is disturbed by Temple's narration of her experience is because he is confronted with his own naivete regarding women. He returns home and sees Little Belle's picture in a whole new way after hearing Temple's story. He no longer sees women as merely victims of male sexuality but as sexual beings in their own right."The Space Between: A Study of Faulkner's Sanctuary" by George TolesToles also makes some interesting points in his essay but, overall, I found his essay to be rather dense and elliptical. I am not even going to try to summarize the overall intent of the essay, because I am not sure I understand what it is, but I will highlight some of the interesting points Toles makes. Toles argues that the opening paragraphs of the novel employ various methods to both bring us into the scene and keep us at a distance, which is in line with the voyeurism scene of the novel. Faulkner withholds information about his characters which makes the scene and the motivations of his characters opaque. He also breaks up the time line in weird ways (something I thought might have just been bad writing when I first read the novel).Toles also analyzes Faulkner's use of metaphors. The descriptions we get of Popeye are full of tropes and metaphors that bring us closer to Popeye but also keep us at a distance. We do not get any direct sight of what Popeye looks like. We see Popeye through a "haze of metaphors." Toles argues that Faulkner is trying to cover the brutal and pulp fiction realities of his story with language and provides us with a reality that is "in excess of the immediate." I think this is actually part of the reason I did not like the novel all that well. The style did not seem to match the subject. I just finished reading Flannery O'Connor's Wise Blood and her style seemed to me to match the subject perfectly, but Sanctuary is telling a brutal pulp-fiction style story in Faulknerian prose, and it just seemed strange to me. I actually wish that Toles's essay had been less dense because he is discussing stylistic features of the novel that I am quite interested in.Toles also provides an interesting analysis of Faulkner's use of paradox. Faulkner loves paradoxical expressions. Not just in this novel but in all of his writing. Toles argues that these paradoxes point to the "excluded middle": the reality that can never be captured by our language and our dichotomous categories. This is the "space between" referenced in the title of Toles's essay."Precarious Sanctuaries: Protection and Exposure in Faulkner's Fiction" by Philip M. WeinsteinWeinstein's essay is one of the shortest in the book but I also think it is one of the best. Weinstein starts with a quote from Nietzsche regarding our ability to handle the truth. Nietzsche imagines that beings can be distinguished from one another in terms of how much truth they can bear. Weinstein believes that the notion of "sanctuary" functions in Faulkner as a kind of necessary illusion, or fiction, that human beings are forced to project onto the world in order to live, because, as Nietzsche says, they cannot bear too much truth, the chaotic nature of reality. Man escapes from Nature as unbridled energy (the Dionysian) into the ordered world of man-made categories (the Apollonian).What I especially appreciated about Weinstein's essay was his interpretation of Temple. Nearly all of the essays I have read on Faulkner's novel view Temple as corrupt in some way. She carries the evil that undoes her within herself. I do not view Temple in this way at all. It seems to me this reading relies on an equation between "natural sexuality" and "evil". Temple is sexual and vain. She enjoys attention from the opposite sex. She is frivolous. All of that is true, but that hardly makes her "evil" in a strong sense. She is an average teenage girl. Teenagers in general are more concerned about themselves than about others and I find it hard to believe that Faulkner intended Temple to be a critique of the "modern generation."Weinstein argues that "The disintegration of Temple Drake is the emotional center of the novel and the locus of its considerable power. In it Faulkner renders the damage that a psyche can undergo." I could not agree more! Every other reader of the novel seems to see Temple's transformation as the natural maturation or blooming of some latent evil that was always within her and that would have eventually developed even if she had not been brutally raped. Weinstein sees Temple's "disintegration" (rightly) as based on the vulnerability and fragility of the psyche. The psyche cannot handle too much disorder or too much trauma without breaking and disorganizing. It is amazing to me that so many readers see Temple's evolution as a natural flowering of evil, as if her brutal rape and abduction were just part of the normal course of nature. Weinstein argues that "The Temple Drake of the later chapters is not so much immoral as psychically damaged." Exactly! Weinstein's essay is a necessary corrective, in my opinion, for all of the weird interpretations of Temple's character that I have seen.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS. You have been warned. This movie has a lot of negative reviews and I have to admit, I was somewhat disappointed with the movie myself. I had very high expectations going in, as I think a lot of people did. Cormac McCarthy's first original screenplay certainly generated a lot of interest. I will be the first to admit: this movie failed to live up to the hype, fell far short of Cormac McCarthy's best novels, and it is simply impossible in this case to lay the blame on Hollywood or bad acting. Hollywood is notorious for diluting and ruining genuinely original writing but that is not what happened here. Nearly all of the problems with this movie are problems that can be traced to the script.All that having been said, I think this movie is a lot better than many critics are making it out to be. I think a lot of the complaints that people had with the movie arose from a confusion of genres. People are treating this movie as if it was meant to be a thriller. I saw it described in one review as a "drug-war" thriller and in another as "a meditation on capitalism in the form of a thriller about cocaine trading." Obviously, the plot of this movie revolves around a lawyer who gets caught up in the drug trafficking trade with disastrous results. But, is that what this movie is about?We learn very little about the specifics of the deal that the counselor (played by Michael Fassbender) has made. We know that he is involved with moving cocaine from Mexico to Chicago and that is about it. We also learn very little about the cartels themselves. We see some low level cartel members involved in the operation of transporting the cocaine in a sewage truck but there is only one scene where we get to see a high-ranking cartel member and he spends his time quoting the Spanish poet Antonio Machado, as opposed to talking about the drug-trade or money (he is most certainly NOT an image of unbridled capitalism; if anything he is an image of death and mortality).What the movie focuses on, and it seems to me nearly all the critics neglect this fact, are the relationships between the counselor and Laura (played by Penelope Cruz) and Reiner (played by Javier Bardem) and Malkina (played by Cameron Diaz). They are the central characters in the film. The plot involving the drug deal is ancillary in this sense: it is an external force that disrupts the relationships in the film. I also do not think the movie is about greed. Reiner makes it very clear that the counselor is not motivated by greed. He tried to appeal to his greed in the past and it did not work. There is only one character who I think is motivated purely by greed and that is Malkina.Ultimately, I think this movie is a movie about grief and the suddenness and inevitability of death. The most powerful scenes in the movie are: the scene where the counselor is talking to the high ranking drug cartel member and trying to make a deal to trade his life for Laura's, and the scene where the counselor receives a dvd from the cartel which, because of the set up by Westray (played by Brad Pitt) earlier in the film, we assume is a video of Laura's murder. The counselor's breakdown when he sees the dvd is extremely powerful and, in it, we are confronted by our own helplessness in the face of death.The theme of our helplessness is precisely why (I think) so many people are disappointed in this movie. They were expecting a "drug-war" thriller, a battle between good and evil, but, as Mr. Compson says in The Sound and the Fury (I am paraphrasing): when we wage war against the world and fate, we are not only destined to lose, there is never really even any fight, because there is no one to fight. We have all seen "drug-war" thrillers and we have certain expectations. This movie disappoints those expectations which, I think, is a good thing.For example, when Laura is kidnapped by the cartel. Here is the standard story that we have all seen a million times (that might be hyperbole): the cartel calls up the counselor and demands that he make reparations for the money he "stole" or his wife will die, they let him talk to his wife on the phone, the counselor vows to rescue her, puts together a scheme, meets some challenges on the way, but ultimately prevails (with lots of explosions, car chases and gun battles in between).Here is what we actually get: the counselor figures out that Laura has been kidnapped because she never shows up at their arranged meeting. No one from the cartel tries to contact him about it. No one from the cartel tries to make any kind of deal with him (the cartel is, in that sense, as inexorable as fate; you cannot negotiate or make bargains with death or god). The counselor reaches out to some friend of his, who puts him in touch with a high-ranking cartel member, they have one fairly short conversation on the phone, the counselor receives a dvd of his wife's murder, and he goes home. There is never even a shred of hope that the counselor might be able to get his wife back.The plot unfolds (or unravels) mechanically from the moment the drug deal goes wrong. It just disintegrates. I can understand why viewers who are used to taut, developing, spiraling plots would be disappointed with a decaying disintegrating plot but, personally, I found it a refreshing change of pace, and, I would have been far more disappointed if Cormac McCarthy had turned in a formulaic plot (one reviewer on Rotten Tomatoes, who I generally enjoy, was disappointed that the car chase scene "lacked suspense". I have two questions: first, would you really want to watch a lengthy car chase scene written by Cormac McCarthy? Is that the best use of his talents? And second, does anyone still get excited by car chase scenes?)There are also people who complained that the plot is "confusing". It is true, Cormac McCarthy does not waste time explaining things to his audience. He lets the audience figure things out for themselves. Personally, I think that is a good thing. I get very frustrated with "exposition dialogue" in movies and television, dialogue that states the obvious, or has no purpose other than filling the audience in. The plot of the movie is not really complicated enough to require that anyway. There are really only three moving pieces: the counselor (who is allied with Westray and Reiner), the drug cartel, and Malkina (who works for no one but herself).I give McCarthy credit for writing what I think is a well-crafted, non-formulaic plot, that is emotionally powerful. Still, this is certainly not a perfect movie. It suffers from a number of flaws that I think reviewers have nearly universally picked up on.The first and most obvious problem is the dialogue. The critics of this movie are describing the dialogue as "pretentious", "pompous", "pseudo-profound", and other similar descriptive terms. While I do not necessarily agree with those adjectives (the term "pretentious" is almost always misused, and terms like "pseudo-profound" are often used when people stare into a deep pool and are disappointed when all they see is their own reflection on the surface) but I agree with the general sentiment. There is some dialogue in this movie that might work in a novel (although I am not even sure about that) but seems very out of place on the screen ("the truth has no temperature"; "it is like being in love with easeful death" (a reference to Keats).There is also a lot of dialogue that I think is just wasted. For example, Westray spends a lot of time trying to convince the counselor that the drug cartels are seriously dangerous ("You might think there are things that they are incapable of but you'd be wrong"; "They will cut out your liver and feed it to their dogs."). I don't think, in this day and age, anyone but the hopelessly nave needs to be convinced that the drug cartels are dangerous and capable of horrific violence, and the counselor certainly seems worldly enough to grasp the risks of his venture ("Oh, you mean the drug cartel might actually kill me if things go wrong? I had never thought of that!"). It was necessary for Westray to tell the story of the snuff tape to set up the most devastating moment in the movie but all the other time he spends talking about how dangerous the cartel is seems wasted.The second problem I think has to do with the characters. None of them are all that likable, which is actually fine with me. I don't need to like characters but I need them to be interesting. There is one extremely interesting character in the movie: Malkina. The rest are sort of boring. We learn very little about the counselor or what makes him tick (Is he a good lawyer? An idealist? A scumbag who gets criminals out on technicalities?). We learn very little about Laura (Where did she meet the counselor? What does she do for a living? How does she feel about her fiance's involvement in the drug world?). We could say the same thing about all the other characters in the movie, except for Malkina.Malkina is quite a triumph, in my opinion. Cormac McCarthy is often criticized for the lack of female characters in his novels but, in this movie, the most interesting character is a woman. She is cruel, deceptive, cunning, and vicious. The scene where she goes to confession, just to mock the institution, along with the belief in God, is a brilliant little scene. Malkina clearly finds something disturbing about the fact that Laura is religious, it does not fit into her hedonistic, materialistic, nihilistic philosophy. She imagines that the priest must be getting off listening to the women talk about their sins (an attempt to fit religion into her own hedonistic philosophy) so she goes to test it out. Perhaps she imagines that she will be able to convert the priest to her own hedonism or perhaps she just wants her own disillusionment to be confirmed. There is, however, no doubt that without Malkina this movie would have been much less interesting.The movie has a lot of flaws. I do not think there are any living novelists who are better writers than Cormac McCarthy. There are probably some who are just as good, but none who are better. There are certainly lots of screenwriters who are better screenwriters than Cormac McCarthy but, then again, there are even more that are worse!

There are some spoilers in this review. You have been warned.I should begin by saying: I am a huge Faulkner fan. However, I have mixed feelings about this book. This book was Faulkner's most popular book for many years, largely because of its outward accessibility. On its surface, the book is much easier to follow than some of Faulkner's other (and I think, better) books. The book's critical reputation has fluctuated. For awhile, I think, it was considered an artistic failure but it has been rehabilitated somewhat. It is not a bad book but I do not think it can be ranked as high as some of Faulkner's other works (Light in August, The Sound and the Fury, Abaslom, Absalom!, As I Lay Dying). I will begin with what I liked about the book and then explain why I did not like it more than I did.Faulkner manages to create an interesting cast of characters. Popeye is quite terrifying and Faulkner deserves a great deal of credit for creating such a complex and terrifying character. It is not often that we see (in books or television or the movies) a truly terrifying character who is afraid of the dark. Horace is also quite complex. There is a lot to admire about Horace: his idealism and his disgust with the moral hypocrisy that surrounds him, but there is also a lot to criticize: his lust for his step daughter, his own hypocrisy, and his lack of moral courage. Clarence Snopes, as the corrupt politician, is also another great character.There are also characters that you love to hate: Gowan, the "gentleman" alcoholic who is responsible for Temple's kidnapping and rape, and Narcissa, Horace's hypocritical sister who is largely responsible for having an innocent man convicted of a crime he didn't commit in an effort to protect her own reputation.Faulkner has also created an interesting and fairly intricate plot. There are a number of individual plots that are all seamlessly interwoven: Horace leaving his wife and stepdaughter, Temple and Gowan's relationship, Temple's rape and kidnapping, Lee and Ruby's marriage, Lee's bootlegging operation, and, of course, Popeye's antics and shenanigans. At the beginning of the novel all of these characters are pursuing their own individual paths and, by the end, their fates are all intertwined. Faulkner does a great job building all of these individual stories to a crescendo so, when you reach the climax, when Temple enters the courtroom, and Horace realizes that his case is lost, you feel as devastated as Horace does.Finally, Faulkner explores a number of very interesting themes in the novel. Ultimately, I think the novel is an attack on the hypocrisies of "high society" and Christian morality. Popeye's rape of Temple is, of course, extremely brutal, but Temple is treated just as horribly by the court and the justice system. The district attorney claims that they are going to "right her wrong" for her, but they really just use her to turn social opinion against an innocent man, simply because he has sinned against public morality by living with his common law wife. Meanwhile, they let the person who is actually guilty of Temple's rape go free.I think one of the themes of the novel is: "high society" is guilty of all the same crimes as "low society"; they are just less honest about it. They cover it up. In "high society" sexuality becomes an elaborate ritual, which allows its members to hide their own impulses from themselves. For example, Temple feels very comfortable getting dressed up and going to a dance with the college boys, or going out on dates with the town boys, but she is terrified at the Old Frenchman place. In both arenas she is surrounded by seething male desire, but at the dances it is hidden behind propriety. Within society's rituals it becomes possible to pretend that we are "safe"; to pretend that the uncontrollable urges boiling beneath the surface are under our control.There is a kind of Freudian theme here. Civilization requires us to mask our own impulses even from ourselves. While Faulkner is clearly critical of society's hypocrisy, the novel is by no means a celebration of the unrestrained id. While the boys at the dance might be more hypocritical than the men at the Old Frenchman place, it is at the Old Frenchman place that Temple is actually raped. If given the choice, hypocrisy is certainly preferable to rape. However, the town's hypocrisy ultimately leads them to burn an innocent man alive and claim, in the same breath, that they are serving "justice". There has to be another way out of this dialectic between repression/hypocrisy and the unbridled id. Neither solution works on its own.So, the novel has interesting characters, an interesting storyline, and explores some interesting themes. The novel does, however, suffer from some flaws. I will merely highlight three. First, Faulkner uses some of his trademark language in this book. Some people find Faulkner's language annoying. I generally find it beautiful and it is one of the things I love about Faulkner. However, Faulkner mixes styles in this book in a way that I don't think works that well. I will use an analogy to describe what I mean. Sometimes I hear a song that I think is a kind of seamless web. All the parts fit together perfectly. It is integrated. I do not hear the guitar, the vocals, the drums and the keyboards all as separate pieces merely thrown together. I just hear one integrated song. Other songs are not integrated and I start to feel like the vocals are just floating on top of the guitar.This novel did not feel like a seamless web to me. The language is not integrated and seems to "float on the surface". Absalom, Absalom! has a lot of difficult language but the novel is told in long run on sentences that are meant to reflect the unconscious thought processes taking place in the characters. The novel takes place in the depths of consciousness where poetic language seems entirely appropriate. This novel takes place on the surface (for lack of a better term). It is a story that is based around plot - outward events - not the inner lives of its protagonists. Faulkner has sentences where he is describing very matter of fact things, but then he throws in one of his trademark words and it is jarring.For example: Horace and Narcissa are driving and Faulkner writes "Soon they had left the town and the stout rows of young cotton swung at either hand in parallel and diminishing retrograde." The word "retrograde" just seems out of place. It is not integrated. It is like a bulge on a piece of straight thread (whereas Faulkner's other novels are more like knitted sweaters: all the pieces contribute to the whole). Faulkner is trying to write a poetic crime novel or potboiler (almost) and it is jarring at times. There are beautiful passages in the book that I think really work, and fit in the novel (when Faulkner describes Temple looking at the clock face in Reba's house), but there are also lots of places where the language just seems out of place and almost sloppy. The novel does not feel like an integrated and aesthetic whole to me.Second, I found myself getting frustrated with Faulkner's indirectness. Some degree of indirectness is necessary. If, for example, Faulkner had described Temple's rape in brutal detail when it happened, then there would have been no shock in the courtroom. It is important that the reader learn exactly what happened at the same time as the jury and Horace and the rest of the town. There are places, though, where the indirectness just seems annoying and unnecessary. Faulkner often has his characters speak in half sentences, letting the reader infer what they were going to say. The novel is a book about rape, but I am not sure whether the word "rape" even appears in the book, it is always just hinted at, indirectly. While I generally prefer Faulkner to Hemingway, I do sometimes prefer Hemingway's directness to Faulkner's indirectness. There is something healthy about being able to say exactly what you mean and, in a way, Faulkner's prose mirrors the hypocrisy of the society he is criticizing; a society that is incapable of saying anything directly.Finally, there is some behavior in the novel that is hard to explain. For example, why doesn't Horace take Temple with him after he goes to visit her at Reba's? He must know she was kidnapped but he just leaves her there. Some people might argue that this adds to the mystery of the novel, or the complexity of the characters, and scholars have indeed spent a great deal of time speculating about Horace's motives. While it might provide food for the critics, I am not sure whether, artistically speaking, that is a good thing. I think the reason that critics have found it so hard to explain why Horace leaves her, and why there have been so many different and competing theories, is because there is not really any very good reason, so the ground is free to invent reasons.Faulkner, of course, needed to leave her there in order to have his great climactic moment in the courtroom, but it feels like he wound up stretching believability a bit in order to save his climactic moment. There are other examples of this in the novel as well. Ruby, at one point, asks Temple "If you are so afraid here, why don't you just leave?" (that is a paraphrase). Good question! The critics I have read speculate: Temple is used to being led by men, she is unable to take initiative on her own, etc. Maybe. Or maybe Faulkner just did not do a good enough job providing a reason for Temple to stay. Maybe that is a genuine flaw in Faulkner's design. I think it is. Other readers might disagree.So, that is my assessment of the book such as it is. Faulkner used to say that the artist should aim for "splendid failure"; meaning: the writer should take risks even if they wind up failing. I think what Faulkner was trying to do in this novel was very interesting and he made a worthy attempt. I am not convinced he was entirely successful.

Sanctuary is, on its surface, one of Faulkner's more accessible works. It was, for that reason, one of his most popular for a long time. It is relatively easy to follow the basic story so a line by line commentary might seem unnecessary. However, this book really increased my appreciation for Faulkner's book. The first time I read Sanctuary I was not actually all that impressed with it. I am a huge Faulkner fan but the novel seemed strange and not all that interesting to me. After reading this book I realized just how much I was missing.This book was helpful in two ways. First, it helps to illuminate all the little subtle things I was missing. For example, in a few places Faulkner shifts into a flashback without giving any indication to the reader that he is doing so (I am thinking of the scene where Horace is talking to Miss Jenny about Narcissa and Gowan in particular). There are also places where the dialogue is somewhat cryptic. The dialogue between the three town boys as they watch Temple at the dance with Gowan, for instance. This book was extremely helpful in shedding light on lots of little details that I missed. The basic story of Faulkner's novel is fairly easy to follow but I would be willing to bet that many of the details are lost on readers. At least, they were on me.Second, the book also sheds light on some of the larger themes of the novel. My lack of appreciation for the novel after a first read through was largely because I was missing some of the interesting themes that the novel explores.
