Mishima is also able to construct a novel that is both specific, it takes place at a particular time and place, and universal, the themes transcend that specific time and place. Sometimes love stories set in different times and places fail to reach the level of universality. They become bogged down in the specific etiquette and social customs of a particular time and place and fail to reach the universal human emotions that are present in all times and places. Mishima's novel does not suffer from such a failing. Mishima is also able to convey powerful emotions through restraint. The final meeting between Kiyoaki and Satoko is beautifully written and heart-breaking. It is a central scene in the novel and it is a scene that, I imagine, would be difficult to write. Mishima handled it perfectly. He was a true master. I am definitely looking forward to making my way through the rest of his oeuvre.

I have read this novel twice and, in all honesty, I did not enjoy it all that much either time. After reading it the second time I decided to read some criticism on the work to see what I was missing. I found two helpful collections of critical essays: The Sun Also Rises edited by Harold Bloom and The Sun Also Rises edited by Kelly Wand, and a short, book-length treatment of the novel: The Sun Also Rises: A Novel of the Twenties by Michael S. Reynolds. I would recommend all three to anyone wanting to dive a bit deeper into Hemingway's novel. I have also spent a great deal of time thinking and reflecting on the novel. I have been trying to figure out what I liked about the novel and why I did not like it more than I did. I have reached some tentative conclusions. I will try to share some of those conclusions in my review. I definitely think this novel is worth reading even if you do not enjoy it.SUMMARY OF THE BOOK AND SOME OF THE THEMESThe novel follows a group of American and British expatriates in Paris. Jake is the war wounded narrator, Brett is the woman that pretty much all the men are in love with, Mike is Brett's fiance, Robert Cohn is the Jewish boxer who tends to be the punching bag of the group, and Bill is an American writer. Jake takes a trip every year to the San Fermin festival in Pamplona to see the bullfights and he invites the rest of the gang to go along. The novel is really about the changing relationships between the characters. Anyone expecting a really dramatic story is going to be disappointed. Traditionally the novel has been viewed as a portrait of the so-called "lost generation". Virtually all the characters in the novel, with the possible exception of Cohn, have been wounded in some way by the war, and there is no doubt that the characters in the novel are all suffering from a lack of sustaining values. However, Hemingway himself, apparently, did not like the term "lost generation" even though he used Gertrude Stein's quote as one of the epigraphs for the book.There are really two central conflicts in the novel. The first is obvious and revolves around Robert Cohn's love for Brett. Robert Cohn is the only character who did not fight in the war and he is the only character who still believes wholeheartedly in Romantic love. He is the least cynical character in the book. He is, perhaps, a bit of a Don Quixote figure, still defending an outmoded value system. This gets him into trouble with Brett with whom he has a short affair. The relationship between Cohn and Brett highlights the dangers inherent in all relationships. If the two parties have different ideas about what the relationship is about, and different value systems in general, there is likely to be miscommunication, misunderstanding, and heart-break.Cohn's conflict is the obvious conflict but, as Michael S. Reynolds points out in his book, the central conflict really revolves around Jake. It is difficult for the reader to pick up on the central conflict (I missed its importance until I read Reynolds' book) because Jake tends to make himself invisible in his narration. Jake is also in love with Brett but because of an unfortunate war wound is incapable of physical love. Brett seems to love Jake as well but cannot settle for a non-physical relationship so Jake has to watch her sleep around with other men. Jake has a real love for bullfighting. He goes to the bullfights every year and he is the only American that the Spanish respect as possessing aficion, or passion, about the bullfights. Bullfighting gives Jake some sustaining values: courage, honor and artistry, among them. However, Jake is unable to say no to Brett, and winds up pimping her out (Cohn's words) to the bullfighter Pedro Romero. A Spanish hotel owner with whom Jake has had a relationship for a number of years sees this and by the end of the novel the two are no longer on speaking terms. This is, as Reynolds argues, the central tragedy of the book. Jake was given a moral test and he failed, and his trips to Pamplona, if he continues them, will never be the same.There are lots of interesting themes in the novel. There is, of course, the theme of emasculation. Jake is emasculated in the war and is further emasculated in his relationship to Brett. Despite Hemingway's reservations about the term "lost generation" the destruction of traditional values after the war is clearly another theme of the novel. Jake and his group do not really have a sustaining philosophy of life. At one point Jake claims that "Enjoying living was learning to get your money's worth" but claims that in five years that philosophy will "seem just as silly as all the other fine philosophies I've had" (148). Jake also claims "I did not care what it was all about. All I wanted to know was how to live in it" (148). Technically Jake is Catholic but we learn throughout the book that he does not have much religious feeling. That is, perhaps, another casualty of the war. So, throughout the novel, we see a group of people trying to figure out how to live, and not doing all that great a job at it.Another theme that I found very interesting is the return to more primitive, one might say pagan, value systems as a replacement for Christianity. This shows up in a number of places in the book. Jake and Bill go on a fishing trip in Burguete and meet a British man named Harris and they all go to visit a monastery. They all agree it is a remarkable place but, Bill asks, "It isn't the same as fishing though, is it?" The others agree that it is not. Clearly, there is an attempt to return to nature here, and nature is viewed as more reinvigorating than traditional religion. The only time the reader gets any sense of health reading this novel is in the descriptions of nature and in the characters' contact with nature. There is also an interesting mix between the Christian and the pagan in the San Fermin festival. It is, in name at least, a Christian festival in honor of a Christian saint, but the practice of bullfighting (sacrificing the bull) is a much more primitive religious practice, and it is clear that all of the characters, especially Jake, are much more moved by the bullfighting than they are by the Christian aspects of the festival. There is, it seems to me, an attempt in the novel to move back to a more primitive form of religion to find some sustaining values after the collapse of Christianity. There is a similarity here between Hemingway's novel and T.S. Eliot's poem The Waste Land (Norton Critical Editions).WHAT I LIKED ABOUT THE BOOK OR WHAT HEMINGWAY DID WELLNow, before I try to explain what I did not like about the novel I want to highlight a few things I liked about the novel. First, Hemingway does a great job portraying powerful emotions. There is an interesting exchange between William Faulkner and Ernest Hemingway that I think is relevant. William Faulkner criticized Hemingway by saying "He has never been known to use a word that might send a reader to the dictionary". Hemingway replied by saying "Poor Faulkner. Does he really think big emotions come from big words?" Personally, I much prefer Faulkner to Hemingway, but Hemingway definitely has a point here. Sometimes simple and direct is more powerful. There is a scene where Mike and Robert Cohn get into a fight. Mike calls Robert Cohn a steer because he is always "hanging about so". Hemingway (or Jake) simply writes "We were embarrassed". That is all that is necessary to convey the discomfort and the powerful emotions broiling beneath the surface of the scene. It is a very painful scene to read.There is another scene where Brett says "Oh darling...I'm so miserable" and Jake replies "You were happy a minute ago" and Brett replies again "It's all gone". To me, that is much more powerful than if Brett had tried to write an impromptu poem expressing her misery or provide some literary metaphor for her depression ("it is as wide and deep as the ocean" or something like that). Just saying "I'm so miserable" is more powerful than any literary trope which will tend to sound contrived. There is really an emotional hell just beneath all the quiet stoicism and ironic detachment of this novel and Hemingway does a great job conveying that in very few words. It is part of the reason reading the novel is not always all that pleasant of an experience. We can feel the misery and despair that is just beneath all the supposed gaiety. Hemingway also used to say that writers should portray how people actually feel rather than how they think they are supposed to feel. He definitely lives up to that. We have, I think, a lot of misconceptions about love. Love is a very complex emotion that is mixed up with a lot of other emotions and not all of them are positive. Pride and jealousy, for example, both play a huge role in the emotion we call love. Hemingway portrays the complexity of love, and the destructive ingredients of love, quite well.Another thing I appreciated about the novel was Hemingway's sparse style in his descriptions of nature. I have been reading Henry David Thoreau recently, and as much as I love Thoreau, and as great a naturalist as he was, Thoreau still gets caught up in some of the standard literary tropes when describing nature. It does not feel direct. It is mediated by literature. Hemingway describes nature directly. There is actually a place in the book where he writes "The trees were green" (94) and that is his entire description of the trees. There are no descriptions of Apollo driving his winged chariot across the sky, etc.. Hemingway cuts all that away. If I am honest with myself I really prefer a slightly more ornate style. I prefer Faulkner to Hemingway. However, I do think that Hemingway's sparse style was necessary. It was like a cleansing forest fire. It removed a bunch of sick and dead foliage and allowed new shoots to bloom in literature. For that I am very grateful to Hemingway.REASONS I DID NOT LIKE THE BOOK MORE THAN I DIDThe first thing to be said is: I am a philosophy student. I love ideas and I enjoy metaphysical speculation. Hemingway was not really a philosopher. He was clearly more interested in character and emotion. There is big emotion in this book but there are not really any big ideas in it (none that I have found anyways). I have a feeling that Hemingway would have considered metaphysical speculation unhealthy. While I can appreciate that standpoint to life it does not change the fact that I tend to prefer novels that have big ideas in them or helpful insights into life. There are not that many helpful insights into life in the novel. There is not a lot of wisdom to be found. The characters are all lost, trying to figure out how to live in the world, and while they are certain that the old ways of living in the world are no longer possible, they do not yet have much to offer in their place. The lack of big ideas and insights into life is one reason I did not like the novel more than I did.There is also a lack of sincerity in the novel. A number of critics really loved the fishing scene with Jake and Bill. They seemed to think it highlighted Bill's humor. To me, it highlighted Bill's incessant sarcasm and lack of sincerity. When they eat lunch they have kind of a mock saying of grace. I find this inability to be sincere to be a rather annoying trait. The characters are all very cynical and they clearly despise (at least at times) the one character who does not entirely share in their cynicism: Robert Cohn. To me, Robert Cohn and Brett Ashley were the most sympathetic characters in the book. Robert Cohn may be delusional but at least he believes in something and is willing to look foolish in defending what he believes. Brett Ashley may make emotional mincemeat out of most of the men in her life but she does not seem cruel to me. She is just wounded and desperate. From the criticism I read on the novel, however, it does not seem like most readers share my views. Most readers think that Cohn and Brett are very unsympathetic characters. If that is how Hemingway intended them it goes a long way towards explaining why I did not like the book more than I did. I think novelists should always try to understand their characters and genuine understanding always breeds sympathy. If a character is portrayed as extremely unsympathetic chances are they are a cardboard cutout character, with no real depth, enlightened by a merely superficial gaze.The novel is also quite depressing. It is, in my opinion, much more depressing than more openly nihilistic novels (Celine and Beckett, for example). The characters are all caught up in what the philosopher Soren Kierkegaard called the aesthetic existential sphere. There is despair beneath the surface of the aesthetic sphere but it is unconscious. Openly nihilistic novels are expressions of conscious despair. In The Sickness Unto Death Kierkegaard argues that unconscious despair is worse than conscious despair. At least the person who experiences conscious despair is aware that they are sick and searching for a cure. The characters in this novel are attempting to drown their despair in alcohol and sex rather than facing it directly. It gives the novel a very unhealthy feeling that made it difficult for me to read at times. Perhaps that is what Hemingway intended. If so, he definitely succeeded. It is definitely powerful. Still, it reduced my enjoyment of the novel somewhat. The despair in the novel is slightly contagious and I found myself getting sucked into it at times.One final observation and then I will bring this overly long review to a close. Part of my problem with the novel may be my own fault. It is possible I am reading the novel as if it were a nineteenth-century novel. I assume that Hemingway is trying to say something, that he wants the reader to adopt a particular position in relation to his characters, and that might not be the case. I may be assuming too much about the judgments that I think Hemingway wants me to make about his characters, and I tend to disagree with the judgments I think Hemingway wants me to make. For example, I assume that Hemingway approves of Jake's stoicism and disapproves of Cohn's lack of stoicism. Jake suffers silently while Cohn's primary sin seems to be that he is unwilling to suffer silently, to suck it up, so to speak. I do not agree with the values behind that judgment, so if that is the judgment that Hemingway wants the reader to make, it is another reason I did not enjoy the novel more than I did. However, it is possible that Hemingway is not expecting any particular judgments from the reader. Modern novels do not tell the reader what to think in the same way that older novels do. The reader is allowed to make up their own mind. Things happen, and those events effect different characters in particular ways, but there is no God's eye view from which to decide which reactions are "good" and which are "bad". So, if I could convince myself that Hemingway is simply holding a mirror up to a particular time and place, and leaving it up to the reader to form their own judgments, I would, I think, enjoy the novel much more than I did.

Michael Reynolds has written an accessible and insightful analysis of The Sun Also Rises. In the first chapter Reynolds presents some of the historical context. He draws attention to the effect that World War I had on the value systems of the "lost generation". It was no longer possible to believe in honor, glory, or country. Reynolds also draws attention to the conservative climate in America in the 20s. This is important to remember since we tend to have a vision of the 20s as being very fast and loose. There was, however, a very strong conservative strain: prohibition was in effect, the president William Jennings Bryan was opposed to the teaching of evolution in school, the Ku Klux Klan was having huge open rallies and had a real presence on college campuses, and there was a strong movement towards censorship. The Sun Also Rises would have confirmed these conservative views that the current generation was going to pot: awash in sex and alcohol.In the second chapter Reynolds draws attention to the historical importance of the work. Hemingway, along with a few other writers including F. Scott Fitzgerald, Sinclair Lewis, and John Dos Passos really defined American modernism "They defined what an American novel should look like, how it should be structured, and what its subject matter might be" (6). Hemingway's use of ironic understatement was also something radically new. The irony and the cynicism of Hemingway's novel have become common place now and no longer shock us but Reynolds points out that they would have been shocking to Hemingway's contemporaries.It is also important that Hemingway does not really tell us what we are supposed to think about these characters or how we are supposed to judge them. Are we supposed to approve of their free-wheeling life-style or is Hemingway presenting them to us as for moral censure? I think this is still difficult for some readers (including me) to deal with. Readers often want to be presented with the author's values in an unambiguous way, they want to be told what to think, and how they should react. It is one of the defining features of the modernist novel that the interpretation is left up to the reader just as it is in real life. For a generation who has lost faith in traditional religion there is no longer any magic book telling us how we are supposed to live. We have to think for ourselves which can be disconcerting.Another hallmark of the modernist novel is the fact that the heroes tend to be passive in relation to greater forces. The characters in Hemingway's novel "did not want war, did not choose the economic forces that rule their lives, did not choose their psychological problems" (7). This contrasts with older novels where heroes choose their battles and those battles test their courage, honor, strength, and other positive moral values. Marx and Freud have opened our eyes to the fact that we are often the puppets of hidden forces, economic or psychological, and the modern novel tends to portray its heroes as unwitting victims. Hemingway was one of the pioneers of the modern novel in all of these senses.The third chapter presents a brief history of the critical reception of the work. Many of the first reviewers of the novel were repulsed by the work, the "pervasive lack of sustaining values", the fact that there was no admirable hero, and the fact that vice was not punished (9). In some ways we have come a long way since Hemingway's time. Most readers nowadays do not demand that vice be punished. There are exceptions. Certain genres of fiction require that the bad guys get their comeuppance in the end but we have lost faith in the idea of a beneficent world order that rewards the good and punishes the evil. That seems a bit unrealistic to us. However, the fact that there is no admirable hero in the novel and the seeming lack of any sustaining values still turns some readers off. Reynolds also makes a very good point in this chapter when he says that there is no "correct" reading of the novel (15). This goes back to the point above: Hemingway does not tell us what to think. That means that the novel winds up being a mirror for our own values. Some people read the novel and admire the life-style depicted and others condemn it. Our reading tells us more about ourselves than it does about the novel itself.In the fourth chapter Reynolds focuses on Jake Barnes who is the narrator of the novel. Reynolds points out rightly that Jake is really the only one changed in the novel. Brett is going to continue having meaningless relationships, Robert Cohn will probably return to Frances or find someone else like her, Mike will continue to drink himself silly, Bill will continue doing what he does, Pedro Romero will continue to fight bulls. We tend to forget how central Jake is to the story because, as a narrator, he tends to withdraw in favor of what he is narrating. However, the central drama of the novel has to do with Jake. Jake is the one who is morally tested. Jake is the one who sells himself out by pimping Brett to Romero. Jake can never go back to Montoya's. He is no longer part of the inner circle of aficions. I really appreciated this insight from Reynolds because until I read it I tended to assume that Robert Cohn's story was the central drama of the novel. I am now convinced that Reynolds is right: the central drama has to do with Jake. The yearly trips to Pamplona meant a lot to him, he failed his moral test, and now his trips to Pamplona will never be the same for him. This is probably what Hemingway meant when he said that the novel was "a hell of a sad story". Reynolds also points out how good Hemingway is at clueing us in to Jake's ironic tone. We can often tell the tone of voice of Jake's comments based on the reaction of the other characters.In the fifth chapter Reynolds draws attention to changes that were made to the first draft of the novel that make it more difficult for the reader to pick up on the central conflict of the novel. Originally the novel was going to open with the scene in Pamplona where Jake is sitting in the bar with Brett and Romero and Montoya walks in. Montoya starts to smile at Jake but then sees that he is sitting between Romero, who has a glass of liquor in his hand, and Brett. The novel then flashes back to explain what led to this moment. This makes it clear what the central conflict of the novel is. Hemingway obviously changed the draft which makes it more difficult for the reader to pick out the central conflict. Reynolds also draws attention to the growing tension through the novel that finally explodes in Pamplona (34). This is one of the driving forces in the novel that give it structural unity. Mike, Bill, and Cohn are three bulls who are dangerous and Jake is the steer that calms them (36). However, he cannot contain the conflict forever and it eventually erupts. Reynolds also argues that Romero is not in the novel to present a "viable model for behavior" (38). We cannot all run out and become bullfighters. However, Romero has a set of values that sustain him in the face of death. Romero is there to highlight the absence of any set of sustaining values in the other characters.In the sixth chapter Reynolds highlights Hemingway's skills as a travel writer. This explains, I imagine, the appeal the novel has for a lot of people. Hemingway describes Paris, the cafes and the dance clubs, Burguete, the Spanish fishing town on the river, and Pamplona, and the festival of San Fermin, in a way that makes the reader want to visit those places. Even if the reader does not approve of the life-style of the characters in the novel they can still get value out of Hemingway's travel descriptions and advice. In elucidating the historical context Reynolds also points out that the anti-semitism in the book is historically accurate. Reynolds argues we should not shoot the messenger. Hemingway is merely holding a mirror up to his own times.In the seventh chapter Reynolds analyzes the values in the novel or the lack thereof. Reynolds connects the heavy drinking in the novel to the institution of prohibition. Americans went to Paris to drink because they could not drink legally at home. Hemingway is, again, just reflecting the times he lived in. Reynolds also points out that the war destroyed the values of honor and glory once the veterans realized that they were not really fighting to save Western civilization but were instead fighting to make sure the Morgan bank loans to the allies were safe (63). It would be hard not to become cynical if you had been lied to in such a way. Reynolds also highlights the fact that money, or the "simple exchange of values", is the only real value operative in the novel. Everyone tries to get their money's worth. Reynolds points out that "The Sun Also Rises is not a guide to reasonable behavior. It is not a song in praise of the so-called lost generation. It is a thorough moral examination of its time. If the results are offensive, we can not blame the doctor who conducted the exam" (64)In the eight chapter Reynolds draws attention to a number of signs that the attentive reader should pay attention to when reading the novel. Reynolds points out that signs change and there are a lot of signs in the novel that would have been understood to Hemingway's contemporaries that no longer make sense to a modern reader. Reynolds analyzes a number of signs: the importance of money, bathing, and time among them. In the final chapter, which is only a page long, Reynolds claims that "Despite its irony and its sadness, we walk away from The Sun Also Rises with a good feeling" (95). I am not as convinced of that as Reynolds seems to be. Reading the novel left me with sort of a sick feeling. However, Reynolds makes a good point when he claims that "So long as we do not approve of the 'simple exchange of values,' then we know higher standards of behavior exist". We might not know what those higher standards of behavior are, but our rejection of a morality based solely on money, is a sign that we are holding out for something better. That is something, I guess.

This book is a collection of critical essays on Ernest Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises. Like all essay collections some of the essays were more interesting than others. There is another collection of essays, edited by Harold Bloom, that makes a nice complement to this collection: The Sun Also Rises (Bloom's Modern Critical Interpretations). There are two overlaps between the volumes. I will provide a short summary of the essays I read for the interested reader."The Difference Between France and Spain" - Delbert E. Wylder. Wylder's main thesis is that there is a contrast operating in the novel between France, and its materialistic values, and Spain, and its more spiritual values, and Jake is caught in the middle between the two. He points out a number of places where this contrast operates: the tip that Brett gives Jake's concierge versus the tip that Jake attempts to give to a Spanish waitress, the owner of Madame Lecomte, who knows Bill but cannot get him a table, versus Montoya who saves rooms for his favorite guests, and the contrast between the national sports (bicycle racing versus bullfighting). Wylder argues that "Neither country provides an easy answer to the problem of living one's life" but Jake is clearly drawn towards the Spain side of the equation."Jake 'Wins' in Spain at the End of the Sun Also Rises" - Donald A. Daiker. Daiker's main thesis is that the final scene of the book, Jake and Brett in Madrid, represents Jake's final triumph over Brett. Daiker offers an interesting analysis of Jake's time in San Sebastien. He argues that Jake is in need of cleansing after he pimps Brett out to Romero and his trip to San Sebastien is a kind of moral purification. Jake diving with his eyes open is a symbol for his probing of the depths of his inner self (44). After Jake encounters the nurses, and the wounded soldier, the water is rougher, a symbol of his emotions which are more intense since the encounter reminds him of how he met Brett, but he is able to master his emotions through his swim. He is, therefore, prepared to face Brett, and achieve his independence. Daiker also offers a detailed analysis of the final scene and illustrates how Jake and Brett's positions have been systematically reversed from what they were at the beginning of the book."The Character of Robert Cohn" - Robert E. Meyerson. Meyerson argues that the other characters resent Cohn because of his remaining idealism, the fact that he was untouched by the war, and the fact that, as a Jew, he occupies the position of "sufferer" which is a position they want for themselves. One of the most interesting insights from this essay is Meyerson's insight that "attitudes towards Cohn rise and fall according to the health and welfare of those around him" (67). Cohn is sort of a moral barometer for the other characters. When they are feeling good, they treat him well, when they are feeling lousy, they start to treat him poorly, and they tend to lapse into anti-Semitism."In Defense of Brett" - Roger Whitlow. Whitlow attempts to defend Brett from the standard critical appraisals which tend to criticize Brett for not being "womanly" or for being a b****. Whitlow argues that one must take into consideration the milieu she existed in and points out that she is never cruel. She is also far more self-destructive than she is destructive of those around her. Also, Cohn, Jake, Mike, and Romero are all partly to blame for the destructive effect that she has on them. I was glad to see Brett defended. She was actually one of the only characters in the novel that I felt sympathetic towards. She seems more like a wounded soul than an uncaring destructive force to me. She is the kind of lost soul that men have a tendency to fall in love with in the hopes of saving. I do not think it is really her fault that she disappoints those hopes."Alcoholism in The Sun Also Rises" - Matts Dios. Dios argues that alcoholism turns all the characters in the novel into manipulative self-loathing wrecks incapable of love or friendship. Liquor also keeps their lives in a constant state of disorder and obscures their spiritual bankruptcy. Personally, I really enjoyed this essay. I have to admit, I did not actually enjoy reading The Sun Also Rises very much (I have read it twice and did not really enjoy it much either time), and I got these essays in the hopes that they might make a convert out of me. I think Dios' essay highlighted some of the reasons I did not like the book. Dios points out that the novel "is a portrait of a bankrupt value system that depends far too much on appearances and dramatics". I think part of the reason the novel did not work for me is because I do not think that Hemingway necessarily intended that. If he had intended to portray a bunch of codependent alcoholics who were spiritually bankrupt it could have been an interesting novel.I think Hemingway does see a bankruptcy of spiritual values in his characters but he does not see the connection with alcoholism. So, bullfighting becomes the big spiritual savior. Romero, the bullfighter, is independent and does not rely on women for his sense of self-worth. However, as Dios points out the "intense need for personal power" is itself a sign of alcoholism. In other words, it seems to me that Hemingway's "cure" for the spiritual bankruptcy of his characters is, ultimately, merely a symptom of the real disease operating in the novel. I think that is, perhaps, why I do not like the novel very much. It is sick all the way through. There is no sign of health in it. The one sign of health might be nature. The fishing trip is as close to genuine health as the novel gets but, even there, Jake and Bill are constantly drunk. If Hemingway had intended the novel to be a portrait of the lost generation I think I would like the novel more, but he consciously disavowed that reading of the novel. He believed it was a moral novel and many commentators agree. Dios, on the other hand, seems to see the "code" or the "moral backbone" of the novel as a mere symptom of alcoholism. That is probably a bit too simplistic but there is a lot of truth to it as well."Money in The Sun Also Rises" - Patrick D. Morrow. Morrow argues that where a character gets his or her money is a key to their moral character. Money is the moral dimension of the novel and money is circular since "more money ensures that the 'entertaining' circular movement of life without purpose can continue" (125). Morrow also highlights the various roles that money plays throughout the novel: it is a means to buy and control friendship (125), it is a measure of artistic success (125), and it is a way of making up for one's weaknesses (126-127)."Social Class in The Sun Also Rises" - Marc D. Baldwin. Baldwin attempts to analyze the class consciousness of the various characters in the novel. This is an interesting dimension to the novel that is definitely present. For example, Frances Clyne perceives Paris to be clean, while the prostitute Georgette finds it terribly dirty (136). This shows the different perceptions that arise from different class consciousnesses. Baldwin also points out that the characters with the most social class in the novel (Brett and Mike) are the biggest free-loaders (139). While I think there is a lot that could be done in analyzing the class consciousness in the novel, and I am sympathetic to Marxist criticism some of the time, I do not think that Baldwin's Marxist reading of The Sun Also Rises is all that convincing in many of its details."The 1920s and The Sun Also Rises" - Michael Reynolds. Reynolds argues that it is important to understand the historical context of the novel when interpreting it and he attempts to correct some misconceptions about the 20s. Reynolds points out that our standard views about the "roaring 20s" and the "Jazz Age" are somewhat misleading. The 20s were actually a very conservative time when many Americans were worried about new sexual mores, the spread of "black music", and the rising Jew. There was a lot of bigotry and racism. There was also a rise in rampant consumerism. Reynolds points out that people living in the 20s would read the novel very differently than we do today. Brett, and her promiscuity, for example, would have represented everything that the conservatives thought was wrong with the 20s, sexual freedom, the degeneration of society, the collapse of family values (sound familiar?). Reynolds also interestingly points out that in 1925 the exchange rate between the U.S. and France was 1:26 at a time when half a franc bought a mug of beer. That means that expatriates could live in Paris on the cheap. Americans started flooding into Paris and that shows up at a few points in the novel."Hemingway's Writer's in The Sun Also Rises" - Robert E. Fleming. Unfortunately, I did not take very good notes on this essay, but I know that Fleming argues that Cohn represents all that is wrong with the writer in Hemingway's mind (160-161). Hemingway believed that the writer should write what they truly felt rather than what they thought they were supposed to feel. It is hard to disagree with that. Cohn, however, "spends his time parroting the lessons he has been taught about how he should feel". I am not sure how Fleming knows that or reaches that conclusion but it is an interesting essay."The Art of Repetition in The Sun Also Rises" - E. Miller Budick. Budick argues that the novel is made of repetitions (with a difference) but they are bad repetitions based largely on Jake's lack of self-awareness. He gets himself into the same situations over and over with Brett because he does not understand himself and he represses that self-knowledge. Budick does believe that by the end of the novel Jake has gained in self-awareness and has altered his relationship with Brett. This essay reminds me of the philosopher Gilles Deleuze and his book Difference and Repetition. Deleuze argues that there are good repetitions, based on the affirmation of difference, and bad repetitions, based on repression. I think it could be said that Jake is trapped in bad repetitions when the novel begins but is able to free himself to some degree by the end when he repeats his drive with Brett. I actually think that all novels should be about growth in self-awareness and I think The Sun Also Rises fits that pattern."Narration in The Sun Also Rises" - Terrence Doody. This essay had a really interesting subject but I had a hard time following it in certain sections. Doody attempts to analyze the fact that The Sun Also Rises is written as first-person narration. Jake is the one speaking and he is not a purely objective observer. Jake changes as the novel progresses and Jake's style of narration changes. There is a tension, however, because, in order to maintain the immediacy of Hemingway's narrative style, Jake cannot be seen to purposely change his style, or see or narrate the changes in himself. If Jake were to "solicit an audience, or commit his perceptual experience and moral education to a formal mode" he would be "violating Hemingway's code". Doody seems to think that Hemingway did not adequately resolve this dilemma. Doody writes that "Hemingway does not realize what he is doing to Jake because he has not thought out the first person novel and its demands with enough care" (195). This is a really interesting subject but, like I said, I am not sure I totally followed the essay, and I am not even sure that my summary is entirely accurate to what Doody intended.There are also six essays in the book that I did not read (actually, one of them I read, Spilka's essay, but I read it when I read Bloom's collection, and the reader can find my thoughts about it under my review of that volume). The essays I did not read were "Paris and the Characters of The Sun Also Rises" by David Morgan Zehr, "Confused Chronology in The Sun Also Rises" by J.F. Kobler, "The Primitive Emotion That Drives Jake Barnes" by Ernest Lockridge, "Good Old Harris in The Sun Also Rises" by Jane E. Wilson, "The Death of Love in The Sun Also Rises" by Mark Spilka, and "Humor in The Sun Also Rises" by James Hinkle.

The first thing to be said is, if you are looking for Ernest Hemingway's novel, The Sun Also Rises, go here:The Sun Also Rises. This book is a collection of critical essays. There are five reviews here. Four of them are for the novel, and one of them is for Tennessee Williams' play A Streetcar Named Desire. In other words, none of the reviews on this page are reviews of the actual book, so the reader should be aware of what they are getting. Amazon has a tendency to mix up the listings a bit so I have a feeling that reviewers may have been confused by earlier listings. It is also quite confusing that Ernest Hemingway is listed as the editor for this volume. Hemingway had absolutely nothing to do with this volume other than the fact that he wrote the novel which is the subject of the critical essays. If you are at this page now, and you order this book, you are going to get a collection of critical essays, edited by Harold Bloom, about The Sun Also Rises, NOT the novel itself. I wanted to make that clear at the start so no one wastes money ordering a book they do not want.All in all, I thought there were some interesting essays in this book. The Bloom volumes in this series are hit and miss. Some are quite good, and some are quite bad. This one seems to me to be in the middle. I should be upfront and say that I do not actually like The Sun Also Rises very much. I read this collection of essays partly hoping that they would convert me. I thought perhaps I was missing the themes of the novel and that if I understood the novel better I might appreciate it more. The essays certainly highlighted a lot of things that I had missed but I cannot say that they succeeded in converting me into a Hemingway fan. In the rest of my review I will give a brief summary of the essays that I have read (all but two) for the interested reader. These summaries are really more "highlights" than actual summaries. I am a little too lazy to try to pick out the main thesis in each essay, explain it, present the evidence, etc., so I have simply highlighted what I think are the most important, or most interesting, themes highlighted in each essay."Introduction" by Harold Bloom - Bloom's introduction is short and, I have to admit, I do not really like Harold Bloom. Bloom tends to be obsessed with two things, 1) literary influence, and 2) ranking books in terms of their place in the literary pantheon. The question of literary influence can be interesting but Bloom's introductions to these volumes tend towards meaningless lists. Bloom claims that Hemingway's "peculiar excellence is closer to Whitman than to Twain, closer to Stevens than to Faulkner, and even closer to Eliot than to Fitzgerald" (2) (you get the feeling he put in the last one just to be a contrarian). That is the kind of statement, and analysis, that seems almost useless to me. The attempt to rank works in terms of the pantheon is, in my opinion, even more useless. The job of the critic should be to explain why a work is valuable or interesting. Whether it is the "best" or "one of the three best" is a useless question, and history will decide what works will survive and which will not. Most of Bloom's short introductory essay is related to these rather useless questions. However, he does have some interesting things to say about Hemingway's style "Hemingway evokes by parataxis...a way of utterance that plays at a withdrawal from all affect, while actually investing affect in the constancy of the withdrawal" (6). Bloom draws attention to Hemingway's use of understatement and points out that style is a "metaphor for a particular attitude towards reality" (6). Bloom should have left out all the ranking and influence stuff and focused on developing those insights a bit more."The Wastelanders" by Carlos Baker. Carlos Baker critiques the standard interpretation of the novel as a portrait of the "lost generation". People tend to focus on the first epigraph, a quote from Gertrude Stein, and ignore the second, a quote from Ecclesiastes. According to Baker readers have mistakenly supposed the quote from Stein to represent Hemingway's own views, but according to Hemingway himself, Stein's quote about the lost generation was "a piece of 'splendid bombast'" (13). For Baker there is a "sturdy moral backbone" to the novel represented by the trio Barnes-Bill-Romero. They contrast favorably with the sick trio Cohn-Brett-Mike. Baker sees the moral norm of the book as a "healthy and almost boyish innocence of spirit". It is hard for me to see that represented in Barnes or Bill. In fact, I think Cohn comes closer to representing "boyish innocence" than Barnes or Bill. He is the least cynical of the characters. Barnes himself claims that Cohn had a "nice, boyish sort of cheerfulness". In other words, I am not sure I buy Baker's analysis of the moral backbone of the novel. I think there probably is a moral backbone in the novel but I think it is probably related to two things, 1) closeness to nature (as in the fishing trip), and 2) bullfighting, which seems to represent Hemingway's own moral ideal."The Death of Love in The Sun Also Rises" - Mark Spilka. Spilka sees a stoic ethic operating in the novel (26). Anyone who "bears his sickness well" like Barnes is viewed in a positive light, while those who are unable to bear their suffering silently, like Cohn, are viewed in an unfavorable light. There does seem to be an ethic of self-control operating in the book. Romero comes closest to representing Hemingway's moral ideal and bullfighting seems to represent the ability to remain composed in the face of danger. Romero does not let the Romantic entanglements with Brett and Cohn get in the way of his performance in the bullfighting ring. That seems to be Hemingway's ideal. Barnes attempts to mimic that ideal with less success. He lets his misery spill out at times. Personally, this ethic of self-control is one of the things I do not like about the novel but I have no doubt it is there. Spilka also argues that Cohn is the "last defender of an outworn faith" in Romantic love. All the other characters have been disillusioned by their experiences in the war (a number of characters, including Brett, lost loved ones in the war). This is one reason the other characters seem to look down on Cohn."Implications of Form in The Sun Also Rises" - William L. Vance. Vance's essay is one of my two favorite essays in the book. Vance argues that the novel is a mix between a naturalistic and an Aristotelian narrative structure. The naturalistic structure is based on repetition while the Aristotelian is a linear plot driven by the conscious actions of the characters. All the characters except for Cohn, according to Vance, follow a repetitive pattern. They go out to dinner, get drunk, go to bed, and repeat. Brett has one love affair after another. Each love affair is an isolated episode without any greater meaning. Cohn, on the other hand, still believes in the standard love story arc. Cohn's story, therefore, has a beginning, middle, and end, and is set off against the repetitive background of the rest of the character's lives. Vance argues that Cohn's "view of life is at least worth considering as an option to theirs" (42). Vance recognizes, I think rightly, that Cohn is not merely an object of contempt. There are admirable qualities in Cohn. In modern terms we could say that Cohn still believes in the fairy tale ending while the rest of the characters can no longer believe in that. We might agree that Cohn's views are idealistic and unrealistic, however, far from presenting a positive alternative to Cohn's illusions, Vance argues that "The cynicism, bitterness, and self-pity of the point of view of those who have given up hardly recommend it to the reader either" (48). I think that is an important point. It seems to me that the novel represents a certain disillusionment but offers nothing positive in its place. The illusions of Romantic love might be over but I do not think that an ethic based on bullfighting can make up for the void left by the death of traditional values, meanings, narratives, etc.. Hemingway might have believed it could, but I think he was wrong if he did."Ernest Hemingway and the Rhetoric of Escape" - Robert O. Stephens. Stephens believes that there is a distinction operating in the novel between "the truly questing escapist and the pseudo-expatriate" (52). The true escapist is attempting to escape an intolerable situation "He escapes to another situation to find a more tolerable experience". The true escapists can no longer tolerate traditional values. They are pragmatists who are trying to figure out how best to live in the world, as Jake says "I did not care what it was all about. All I wanted to know was how to live in it". The true escapists are also aware of "nada" which is "the knowledge that social values" and "personal beliefs in immortality...have been seriously damaged by the war" (53). While all the true escapists are aware of nada, they cannot speak of it directly. This gives rise to a lot of the indirect forms of communication used in the novel. Stephens offers some interesting analyses of these indirect means of communication that makes the essay certainly worth reading."Meyer Wolfsheim and Robert Cohn: A Study of a Jewish Type and Stereotype" - Josephine Z. Knopf. This is one of the essays I did not read so I cannot summarize it."Hemingway's Morality of Compensation" - Scott Donaldson. Donaldson sees a moral economy operating in the novel similar to Emily Dickinson's "For each extatic instant/We must an anguish pay". Some characters, like Barnes, pay for their joys through hard work, others, like Cohn and Brett, receive inheritances they did not work for, or let other people pay their way, and wind up racking up a negative balance, which has to get payed for eventually in suffering. The world, apparently, does not give anything for free. Donaldson seems to see a kind of karmic metaphysics operating in the novel."The End of The Sun Also Rises: A New Beginning" - Carole Gottlieb Vopat. Vopat attempts to argue that there is real development in Jake. He is not the same person at the end of the novel as he was in the beginning. He is no longer willing to be a mere puppet in Brett's games. He has achieved a new status of independence and self-respect. She offers a nice little analysis of the scene where Jake comes to see Brett in her hotel room in Madrid at the end of the novel, and she claims, rightly, I think, that at the end of the novel, Jake and Brett "no longer feed off the same fantasies and illusions" (100). That is a nice way of putting it. She also draws meaning out of Jake's time in San Sebastien and claims that Jake is afraid to "become involved with life, with Brett, with emotions, as bullfighters can...He is afraid of drowning in the open sea, of facing the bull head-on rather than vicariously, of a love affair, of women, of his unconscious, of a life without limits" (96). Rather than a negative character trait, however, Vopat sees in this a humble recognition of his own limits. Perhaps that is another reason I do not like the novel very much. Cohn is the one who is willing to take a risk, and risk looking like a fool, while Jake seems more concerned with how he will look, than he is about pursuing what he wants. That, to me, is cowardly, not stoic. For me, Cohn is closer to having the right attitude, but most commentators tend to see Cohn as the object of Hemingway's critique. I think Hemingway and I have dramatically different values. Vopat's essay does do a good job analyzing the character of Jake and is worth reading."The Sun Also Rises: One Debt to Imagism" - Linda W. Wagner. Wagner argues that Hemingway took many of Ezra Pound's suggestions about good prose to heart. Present things directly, use words sparingly, avoid abstractions, etc.. Jake presents things directly with very little interpretation. The reader is left to interpret the emotions. For example, when Brett hangs her head during Mike and Robert's verbal repartee. Jake does not add "She hung her head in desperation, or sadness, etc." He just presents it directly and it highlights the changing relationships which, Wagner claims, are the real subject of the book. Not a lot happens in the novel in terms of plot but the relationships shift. These shifting relationships are often dramatized through subtle body language or changes in behavior (drinking more than usual, etc.). Hemingway also avoids abstraction "Love, hate, grief, religion, death, fear - these are the prime movers of the novel, yet the words scarcely appear" (111). Again, Hemingway presents love in concrete details. He does not present a grand abstraction called "Love". There are different kinds of love, and different ways of loving, and the different characters represent those different kinds of loving directly."False Dawn: The Sun Also Rises Manuscript" - Michael S. Reynolds. Reynolds presents a short history of the text of The Sun Also Rises. He presents some of the alternate titles Hemingway toyed with, and analyzes some of the early drafts, and the later changes that Hemingway made. This is all quite interesting and helpful in teasing out Hemingway's intentions."What's Funny in The Sun Also Rises" - James Hinkle. This is the other essay I did not read but I gather than Hinkle is attempting to highlight the jokes in The Sun Also Rises that he thinks most readers often miss."Toreo: The Moral Axis of The Sun Also Rises" - Allen Josephs. This is the other of my two favorite essays in the book. Josephs believes that bullfighting is the spiritual core of the novel. The Fiesta in Pamplona is a religious festival which represents a move from mundane to sacred time and bullfighting is a relic of ancient sacrifice which connects us with the universe in a quasi-mystical way. Hemingway himself describes bullfighting in these terms at times. There is an interesting mixture of the pagan (animal sacrifice) and the Christian (San Fermin) in the Pamplona festival. Barnes seems to have more of a connection to the pagan. He goes to the church but he does not really feel it. When he is at the bullfighting ring, however, he feels it. It is an emotional, and religious, experience for him. According to Josephs, Hemingway's "exaltation of the pristine savagery of the plaza de torso was tantamount to Hemingway's embracing an ancient mystery and iconoclastically rejecting much of what passed for modern Western values" (153). There is also an interesting quote from a letter that Hemingway wrote where Hemingway compares James Joyce to the bullfighter Maera "There is absolutely no comparison in art between Joyce and Maera - Maera by a mile" (153). Hemingway, apparently, thought that the bullfighter was more of an artist than Joyce. This probably goes a long way in explaining why I do not like the novel. I could not disagree more. Still, Josephs essay is very interesting, and quite enlightening.

It would be hard to imagine a more apt epigraph for Roberto Bolano's ambitious novel, 2666, than the one Bolano himself chose: "An oasis of horror in a desert of boredom".The line is from Charles Baudelaire and it manages to sum up the novel in a single sentence. The poet T.S. Eliot believed that Charles Baudelaire's depictions of ennui, and the horrors of modern life, were like the photographic negatives of a more positive, mystical, and beatific vision. In his essay on Baudelaire Eliot writes "the sense of Evil implies the sense of good" and "such suffering as Baudelaire's implies the possibility of a positive state of beatitude". In past ages the beatific vision was presented directly and in positive terms. Writers celebrated the signs of God's Providence in nature and history. The whole world seemed to sing the praises of God and provide evidence of His Glory. T.S. Eliot was as aware as anyone that the time for such positive visions was over. The modern world that Eliot himself depicts in his poems is a wasteland and the negative vision is all we have left of the mystical after the "death of God". We no longer see the providence of God in the indifference and violence of nature, and even if there is progress in history, something that is doubtful to say the least, the progress comes at the price of a great deal of waste and human suffering. Countless innocent lives are sacrificed to the march of history, some of them are sacrificed nobly on behalf of great causes, but many are simply the victims of the mundane realities of city life and mental illness.There are a number of modern writers who seem to me to present the reader with a negative vision of a God-forsaken world, a kind of modern day mystical vision, or substitute for the old visions of God's grandeur. What the writers I am thinking of have in common is not simply the unflinching portrayal of the darker side of life but the belief that an honest look at the darker side of life is capable of providing some metaphysical insight into the nature of reality. Blood Meridian: Or the Evening Redness in the West, by Cormac McCarthy, is a novel that presents such a vision and, it seems to me, 2666 is another. 2666 does not have a unified narrative structure, but the novel is centered around a series of rapes and murders that take place in the Mexican border town of Santa Teresa and, the narrator claims, even though "no one pays attention to these killings...the secret of the world is hidden in them". The brutal and senseless murders that are the focal point of Bolano's novel are the aperture through which the metaphysical nature of reality is revealed, just as, in previous ages, writer's believed they could read the secrets of God's Providence from the interlocking purposes of nature.The novel itself is long, at times frustrating, and composed of five separate, but interrelated, movements. 'The Part About the Critics' tells the story of four literary critics devoted to the work of an obscure German author named Benno von Archimboldi. After hearing a rumor that Archimboldi has been spotted in the Mexican border town of Santa Teresa three of the critics set off in pursuit. 'The Part About Amalfitano' follows the story of a philosophy professor, who lives in Santa Teresa with his daughter Rosa, and is slowly losing his mind. 'The Part About Fate' is about a newspaper reporter who is in Santa Teresa to cover a boxing match but winds up becoming interested in the murders taking place in the city. 'The Part About the Murders' interweaves the stories of a number of Santa Teresa detectives with endless newspaper like reports of the murders. 'The Part About Archimboldi' moves back in time to tell the life story of the German author Benno von Archimboldi, whose real name is Hans Reiter, including his experiences in World War II as a soldier for the German army.The five parts of the novel are related through what the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein would have called "family resemblances". Just as the facial resemblances between family members pass from a similar nose here, to a similar chin there, without there being a single facial feature that is common to all members of the same family, so too, the parts of this novel are related through a recurring character here, and a different recurring character or setting there, without there being a single unifying story to tie them all together into a whole. There is no Ur-story or meta-narrative operating in Bolano's world, perhaps another sign of our Godless post-modern condition. The first section is related to the second through the character of Amalfitano, who appears in both, and to the fifth through the character of Archimboldi. The second is related to the third through Rosa, and the fourth section is related to all of the others through the town of Santa Teresa. The fifth is connected to the first through Archimboldi, and the third and fourth through Klaus Haas. If beauty is the perception of form, or integral wholeness, then there is no beauty in Bolano's 2666, but, it seems to me to be another distinguishing characteristic of modern writing to try to find beauty in what is ugly, senseless, and disjointed, and, I think, Bolano is as successful as any other modern writer in doing so.Like a Mandlebrot set, the same fracture that is present in the novel as a whole is also present in the parts, though to a lesser degree. Each individual section is unified by the presence of a dominant story line and cast of characters but Bolano is fond of the digression. He spends pages introducing minor characters, giving their life histories, and then never returns to them again. Along the way we meet a painter who cuts off his own hand and includes it as part of one of his paintings, a mad poet who lives in an insane asylum, and a Romanian Jew who goes to fight for the Bolsheviks, and then, presumably, is killed by the Nazis. Those are just a few of the interesting characters that people Bolano's tome. When, late in the novel, a character says, referring to the writings of Archimboldi, "The writing was clear and sometimes even transparent, but the way that the stories followed one after another didn't lead anywhere", it is pretty clear that this is a self-conscious and self-referential literary gesture on Bolano's part. Bolano is a skilled writer, he is skilled at creating full blooded characters with the stroke of a pen, and skilled at creating interesting back stories that generally hold the reader's attention, but the digressions, after almost 900 pages, get a bit tedious.The murders that are the focal point of the story are narrated in a very matter of fact way. Facts are given about each killing including, the age and name of the victim, their occupation, the manner and approximate time of death. Sometimes Bolano fills in the back story a bit but, for the most part, we are given nothing but the bare facts of the case. By turning to the holocaust in the final section of the novel Bolano sets up a contrast that I think is important between the murders in Santa Teresa and the extermination of the Jews by the Nazis. They are both examples of senseless violence but the holocaust has become a part of our grand historical narrative in a way that more everyday murders like those in Santa Teresa have not. We have monuments honoring the victims of the holocaust, history museums to keep their memories alive, and there are first person accounts documenting the horrors of the concentration camps. The stories that Bolano chooses to tell in this novel are stories that are rarely told. We do not have any monuments honoring the dead of Ciudad-Juarez, or any museums keeping their memory alive (the fictional city of Santa Teresa is based on Ciudad-Juarez).Humans have a well documented affinity for narrative which seems to be rooted in our brains and nervous systems. Narrative seems to be one of the primary ways that we make sense of the world and, as senseless and horrific as the holocaust was, we seem to have succeeded in constructing a narrative about the holocaust that is capable of making some sense out of it. Even if the ultimate motivations driving the perpetrators of the holocaust remains a mystery as dark as any mystery in the universe, we at least know who to blame. The murders that Bolano's novel documents fall outside of history because they are deemed too unimportant and, therefore, they are never integrated into our sense making activities. They are also mostly unsolved which makes it difficult to assign blame. The murders remain genuinely senseless and unintegrated. We have no place for them in the stories we tell ourselves. In 2666 Bolano has attempted to make a novel, a form of writing that is tied essentially to narrative, out of something that resists our usual narrative activities. That fact, I think, goes a long way towards explaining the narrative fragmentation of the novel. It also explains why the murders are "the secret of the world" and are able to serve as an aperture, allowing us to see through the arbitrary nature of our standard, everyday cognitive constructs. The murders are just one more ignored hint that the meaning we impose on the world is secondary revision and rationalization through and through. Writers in past ages attempted to see through the seeming chaos of the world to perceive the divine order operating in it, while modern writers, Bolano included, attempt to see past the order that we impose on the world in order to perceive the senseless chaos underneath.Madness is another recurring theme in the novel and it fits with this theme nicely. In our modern Godless world madness is, perhaps, the closest we get to hearing the voice of the divine, or at least the voice of something other than our banal reason. Madness also reveals to us the arbitrary nature of our standard cognitive constructs. Madness breaks through our standard sense making activities and shows us the chaos rumbling beneath our feet. It is also possible that madness is the appropriate response in a mad world where hundreds of brutal murders are considered business as usual. The artists in Bolano's novel almost invariably go mad and they all seem to be conspicuously devoid of any redeeming vision for humanity. It has been a common place among intellectuals to look to artists for salvation from our self-inflicted miseries but, in Bolano's world, the cries of the artists are as senseless as the world that created them. They are poisonous flowers blooming in the desert.2666 is a well conceived artistic vision but, ultimately, it is equal parts fascinating and frustrating. There are at least three things that are responsible for the reader's frustration. First, the novel builds slowly to a climax in the fourth section. The murders are hinted at in the first three sections and then become the subject of the fourth. The reader is drawn into the mystery and is aching for some kind of resolution, preferably, one that would tie all the pieces of the novel together. The reader feels as if they are being led to a kind of climax for the first 600+ pages of the book, and then, suddenly, after the fourth section, the novel jumps back 70 years, and it never really gets back to where the story left off in the fourth section. The story of Hans Reiter is an interesting story, it would have made a fascinating stand alone novel, but it is marred by the fact that the reader is eager to get back to the killings in Santa Teresa, which take place in the 1990s, but is, instead, stuck back in the 1940s for most of the section. Second, the digressions get tedious for the same reason. All of the side stories that Bolano tells would be fascinating stories on their own, but the reader begins to feel like they are merely distractions from the central mystery. That makes reading the novel a chore at times. Third, there is, ultimately, no real resolution to the mystery. Bolano's novel, like life, leaves the reader face to face with the mystery of existence. That was the right choice on Bolano's part. Any "solution" to the mystery would seem puerile. Even if we were told who the perpetrators of the murders were would that make them any less mysterious? Would knowing who the perpetrators were silence our questions about the nature of evil or the senselessness of violence? Would assigning names to the murderers answer any of our questions about the meaning, or meaninglessness, of life and death? There is no "solution", each local solution merely hides a more general problem, but knowing that fact does not make it any less frustrating.If you can deal with the frustration, and you have time and emotional energy to devote to an ambitious novel, 2666 is worth a read.

After reading Stranger in a Strange Land (SSL) and Moon is a Harsh Mistress, I am done with Heinlein.  These are both his best-known works among the general population, and I found both too dated and preachy.  Summary of SSL:The Good:- The first part of the book is a fast-paced political & sci-fi thriller about the intrigues surrounding a human raised on Mars, who is heir to various valuable interests- Strong emphasis on mind over matter; the main character and later his disciples can will various things into happening, including healing themselves, telekinesis, etc- Emphasis on sexual liberation, esp. multiple partners and plural marriage, seems to have ignited or provided fuel to the 1960s sexual revolution; in fact, I came across references to this book in a biography of Playboy's Hugh Hefner, which is how I ended up reading SSLThe Bad:- The second part of the book, after the protagonist's political and financial matters are taken care of, turns into a slow-motion and slightly weird exploration of humanity and the creation of a sex-based cult -- apparently Heinlein wrote the book in two parts after years of hiatus- As others pointed out too, all the male characters are very smug and know full well how life should be lived - especially Jubal- The rare scenes in "heaven" are intended to be funny but are also completely illogical given the mockery of religion in the rest of the book- The pseudo-Christian ending is not logically connected to what comes right before it -- besides serving the need to end the book- What is Jubal's real lifestyle and background? Initially it looked like he might be a Hefner-style playboy living in a rural mansion. Yet later in the book he discusses women with Ben, and it becomes clear that his relations with his young and beautiful secretaries (who swim in the nude at all times of the day) are non-sexual, and yet it is not obvious why they are with him (not money, as he himself says) and are as intelligent and good-looking as they are. Sounds like Jubal is the author's own vision of how he wanted to live in his own old age.- If you want to read about plural marriage or other non-monogamous practices, this book is not a good source -- things in SSL happen because the protagonist wills them to be. To the extent that people in the past and today have practiced such lifestyles, it is best to refer to non-fiction to learn more.The Ugly:- Strange non-sequiturs like "9 out of 10 times a woman gets raped it is her fault".  Muslim scientist nicknamed "Stinky".- Patriarchal. Women are bossed around and second-class citizens like I guess they were in the 1950s. Watch Mad Men instead.For the record, I read the unabridged author's version.  Not the edited and shorter first printing.Not recommended.

I really wanted to like this book. The author's untimely end, as well as his childhood and early life, remind me of some of my relatives. So there were things I could identify with.However, I did not learn anything at the end, nor was the book entertaining. Yes, an early death could and does happen, seemingly without reason; that I knew even before opening this book. Yes, cancer is normally unforgiving. The author seems to have had a great life. Too much is left unsaid though, and he is not enough of a fascinating public figure. Just a baby boomer executive who was lucky enough to get rich.Overall it feels like this book was a vanity project, a long self-eulogy. If the author / protagonist really wanted to write it for his family, he could have used another medium and instilled in it more wisdom than this book contains.Not recommended.

I have worked at Google in the past, so a lot of what Laszlo describes is familiar to me (hiring, performance evaluations, benefits) and the way these things evolved over time look very plausible to me.  Google is a fantastic company and Laszlo Bock has done a great job describing the HR side of it.Depending on your own experience with hiring, management, and culture-building within modern tech companies, the book could come across as common-sense good practices or revolutionary.Insights from the book:- Invest HR budget first in recruiting- Don't let hiring managers make the hiring decisions; let an impartial committee review each candidate to enforce a high bar and have a meaningful discussion about the pros and cons of each candidate- Hire only the best, strive to find people better than you in some meaningful way- Find (source) your candidates; job boards are not a good source of talent- Do performance reviews using peer feedback and use committees to calibrate grades and promotions across teams- Split rewards conversations (say, annual performance bonuses) from development conversations (more frequent feedback on performance)- Research what your best people do well and how they do it, and try to extract their experience in the form of checklists and good practices- Have your best people teach others- Pay "unfairly" since the best performers (esp. in technology) deliver orders of magnitude more value than average workers- Run small experiments with various processes- Trust your people, be transparent- There are great perks which build good culture and they don't cost much (the author describes many that Google offers)- Be data driven in your HR decisions- Instead of traditional HR people, strive to also hire people with business operations (e.g. management consultants) and analytics (statistics etc) backgrounds in the HR teamThe downsides of the book :- It is aimed primarily at HR practitioners, in my opinion; so this is not a book on how to be a better manager per se- It is a little dry to read, and there aren't good examples; the author stays a little too abstract (I wonder if he did not want to share specific examples of "unfair" wide disparities in compensation, or examples of how a hiring committee operates with real candidates, etc, which would have been very interesting to see)- The author is a little too proud of Google (don't get me wrong, Google is awesome, but sometimes the tone gets too boastful)- Laszlo's pyramid of HR, akin to Maslow's pyramid of needs, is somewhat weird towards the end ("where are the fries I didn't order?")Overall I found Eric Schmidt's How Google Works to be a better and more relevant book if you are interested in general management and how to build a high-performance culture.  Eric Schmidt also talks about hiring, transparency, setting goals, and so on.  I find Laszlo Bock's book a little too HR-nerdy :)Recommended with some reservations.

It had been years since I bought a Swiss Army knife (SAK). I wanted to give one as a gift, and I thought which one would have all the essentials, including being able to open wine at home, open beer, adjust our eyebrows with tweezers, fix things up with an impromptu screwdriver, cut cheese for that wine we just opened, and trim things with the scissors?  Well, this one it is.I really like it. I am also a big fan of the Huntsman, which adds a saw, which makes it more of an outdoors survival tool than this Climber II. The more minimalist models in the lineup, Spartan and Tinker, do not have scissors, and in my opinion the scissors are among the more useful tools on a SAK. All in all, the Climber is a nice urban SAK in my book, and a good way to introduce friends to Victorinox without going overboard with the big and beefy models.Highly recommended.

I have been a big fan of the work of Apple and Jobs, and I have read other books and articles over the years about them.  So I was very much looking forward to this book and pre-ordered and read it as soon as I could.Overall I am not disappointed.  That said, it was speculated in the press that the goal of this book was to shed Job's old image as a genius and sociopath, and the book does try hard to do this at the expense of being comprehensive about Jobs.Good:- Overall narrative focused on Jobs's personal growth over the years- Shorter and easier to read and follow than the Bible-length bio by Isaacson- Focused on relationships rather than products or events- Includes plenty of quotes and anecdotes not seen before, especially from people close to Jobs during his second tenure at Apple- Sheds light on his final years with cancer and the work on the iPhone and iPad (something Isaacson did not do as well)- Good insights on Jobs's thinking about products and business decisions- Shows Jobs's human side;  I loved the stories about him helping someone jump start his car or being late for the Stanford commencement addressBad:- Very incomplete and not comprehensive.  This should not be your first or only book about Apple or Jobs.  Isaacson, although too long, is better overall.- Completely omits quotes and anecdotes from bad relationships.  Why nothing from Job's girlfriend and mother of his estranged first daughter?  Why nothing from Lisa, his first daughter?  Why so little from Woz, the cofounder of Apple?  Why nothing from Jobs's biological or adoptive parents?- If family was really so important to Jobs (and I believe it), why not tell us more about them and how he chose to relate to them?  Jobs was apparently very private and protective about his family during his life - why not shed more light now that he is gone?  How did he choose to raise his children?  Why not mention more about Mona Simpson, his biological sister, or include her eulogy of Jobs after his death (can be found in NYT)?Overall this book glosses over the negative and tries to explain Steve Jobs's personality.  Since this ultimately tries to get to Jobs's motivation and values, I found I learned something new and it gave me food for thought about my own relationships at work and at home.Ultimately, this feels like the book that Laurene (Job's widow), Jony Ive (Apple design chief) and Tim Cook (Apple CEO) wanted written about their Steve.  And this is the book's main failing.  It is history rewritten by the winners, as it were.Recommended with reservations.  Read Isaacson first.UPDATE 4/5/2015:I have been rereading Isaacson's bio of Jobs in bits and pieces after I finished this book.  I find Isaacson's book much better, chock full of anecdotes, and also funnier.  And unlike this book, it also presents Jobs as very flawed which it appears he was.

I use this tester regularly. We have all sorts of batteries around the house, and occasionally wonder if they are good or not. This device answers that question. For devices that use multiple batteries (remotes, mice, lights), often one of the batteries dies first and the rest are in good shape, so having a battery tester can save you money by allowing you to replace only the bad batteries, not all.I use this with AA and AAA batteries most of the time, and rarely with 9V. I have no experience with the other battery types it supports.This is not a volt-meter per se, and it is also much cheaper than a real volt-meter. To me, it only answers the question, should I throw away this battery or not? I do not rely on it to tell me level of charge of a battery etc.For the price, highly recommended.

We've used this chair for almost two years now, and I expect it to last us even longer. It is very stable and solidly put together - a German design. Our toddler by now is able to climb into it which is nice, and the chair stays stable. Funny thing, friends have a child about the same age who could not fit into the chair - so I guess you can get more mileage out of it if your kid is skinnier :)Highly recommended.

I won a Nike+ Fuelband SE of these after winning a minor fitness challenge. Since it was free, I had to try it out. Prior to it, I had used a Fitbit One, Fitbit Flex, and Misfit Shine for a total of a couple of years, so I am familiar with fitness trackers and their features.Pros:- Looks good and feels comfortable- Screen is great, very readable white digits, and the rainbow-colored LEDs are refreshing every time- Very useful as a watch, best watch among the fitness trackers I have used- Water resistant - I wore it in the shower without a problem- Nike Fuel points are fun! I used to think steps are the way to go based on Fitbit, but I realize that there are different activity levels and points actually make a lot of sense- iOS app is gorgeous- Charges straight off a USB port, no cables or adaptors needed- Battery lasts about a weekCons:- Step tracking is not very precise - could be 20% off from Fitbit One which sits at the waist and is very accurate- Nike disbanded the Fuel team and announced they are getting out of the trackers market = no future?- No sleep tracking - the sleep sessions feature needs to be manually started and stopped and it is basically a stopwatch for time spent in bed, no analysis or tracking- Sessions feature was not useful to me, besides the amusement of being able to create and name my own sessions- Not really waterproof for swimming- Cannot track anything else besides walking and running (although I suspect it does OK at running-based sports like basketball, tennis, etc)- Plenty of negative reviews about poor reliabilityI sold mine after a week or two of use because I had two more trackers already. I enjoyed it, and I miss its watch feature and the gorgeous app.To me it is the most enjoyable fitness tracker I've had. Fitbit One is more accurate but very dull. Misfit Shine tracks sleep but it is a very crappy watch. Fitbit Flex is duller and less accurate compared to the other trackers mentioned in this review.Recommended, as long as you don't run into reliability issues.

I enjoyed this book as part of the Kindle First offers.
