The author takes some old tales about Nazi experiments with time travel and ships with mysteriously disappearing passengers and weaves a horror fantasy tale out of it.The premise is a little unbelievable (aging mobster gathering top scientists?) and what happens on the ship is a bit like a cheap horror movie, but in a good way. I found it a page turner, and I was surprised time and again by the twists of the plot on the ship. The violence towards the end was a little over the top for my taste. That said, I can totally see it made into a movie one day - the pace if fast and the scenes are vivid.I liked the book. 3 stars because while I enjoyed it, it is not a big favorite or a book I would re-read.

After reading and following Starting Strength, I was inspired to read the same author's Practical Programming.It was in some ways a disappointment, even if it is a very valuable book. Let me explain:First of all, there is a lot of discussion of muscle physiology at a very detailed scientific level, which I found uninteresting and not directly applicable to my training. There is a lot of discussion of various training approaches and what a good or bad coach would do, making it clear the book is aimed at people who devise the training programs rather than the athletes or weightlifters themselves.Some slight annoyances are (1) repeating all the time how important overall strength via squats, deadlifts and presses is and (2) bias against bodybuilders in favor of strength training for Olympic lifting or other strength based sports. While I care about strength, I also care about looks, which is where bodybuilding approaches come in. In Arnold Schwarzenegger's Encyclopedia, there is a photo of Franco Columbu deadlifting 700 lbs, so bodybuilders are strong too. I found it annoying when the author made fun of them, which was thankfully not too often. Although the author dislikes bodybuilding, he describes what creates the "pump" and muscle hypertrophy and validates what Arnold Schwarzenegger wrote in his Encyclopedia of Bodybuilding, so that all squares away. Follow Arnold if you want to look like him, or Rippetoe if you want to build strength alone.As others have said, Chapter 6 about the novice program is in itself very valuable and perhaps the best part of this book. It adds detail about exercises, rest, and diet (including a sample daily meal plan) which are not found in Starting Strength. Chapters 7 and 8 provide similar details for intermediate and advanced training.If you are a novice, Starting Strength is sufficient and this follow up book is not needed; too little of it would be applicable, esp. if you are still making steady strength gains. Also, while Starting Strength is chock-full of useful information that's worth re-reading, Practical Programming is relatively dry, boring, and directly useful insights for the athlete himself are relatively rare.If you are a more advanced lifter or if you are a coach or fitness instructor, this book is for you. The author is very knowledgeable and a little overly thorough :)
It does the job, but it is hard to hear with it and I noticed some people had a hard time understanding me.

I like the size of the wipes, they are not super huge, so I don't feel I am wasting paper. I like the fact that they are 100% cellulose towel and chlorine-free, fragrance-free, and alcohol-free. The thing I don't like it is the fact that every time I pull a towel it takes forever to get it out and normally I get a bunch of them all together.

My lady has been using epilators for the longest time, over ten years. Granted,She's been lucky enough not to brake them, so she only used three or four different ones so she can't compare to all of them out there. She NEEDS an epilator. She has a lot of hair, and it grows really fast. If she shaves at night, the next day by noon she would have horrible black spots of hair. Also, after a couple of weeks, her hair would be so ingrown she would need to exfoliate for hours before she can do something with it.  So, shaving is not an option for her.As epilators go, the Philips Hp6520/70 Satin Soft Cordless Epilator is fine, it works as advertised. It removes hair. So far, we heard one brand after the other claiming that they are more effective or less painful. My lady has yet to try one that is significantly more effective or less painful than the others.So why 2 stars? Because it doesn't work while plugged, it needs to be charged to work and the battery doesn't last long enough for me to wax one whole leg. So here she was waxing, when on the middle of it, the thing stopped! With no way for her to use it while it was being charged.She likes the cordless feature, but I much rather be able to remove all the hair than having a cordless epilator. Not to mention, that there are other epilators that have batteries last much longer and they DO work while plugged.Hugely disappointed.

I got this book because it was recommended by Ben Horowitz in The Hard Thing About Hard Things, another solid management book.This book (High Output Management) dates from 1983 and it shows in the tone and subject matter. The book predates widespread email and talks a lot about manufacturing. However, these are not shortcomings. In fact, it is great that the author is not distracted by things like agile, lean, kanban, etc modern marvels. He makes an analogy between a fast food restaurant and other processes, including knowledge work and HR, and the analogy holds up. Of course, he also gives examples from his work at Intel.Key highlights:- what are high leverage activities and how to focus on them- how many direct reports are optimal- different types of meetings and how to run them, including 1:1s- task relevant maturity (TRM) of employees and how to manage them accordingly- how to give performance feedback- compensation and promotions- why and how you should invest in training programs- how to try to keep an employee who is quittingEverything is meat and potatoes of people and process management, and to the point. As I was reading this book, much of it resonated with my own experience, and at other times I was amazed at insights that showed me how Andy Grove truly was a top manager, after starting as a researcher and engineer.I wish I had a mentor or manager as wise as Andy Grove.Highly recommended.

If you are interested in flow, as defined by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, this book is absolutely worth the five bucks (Kindle edition).However, Csikszentmihalyi's groundbreaking book, Flow, is a better introduction to this topic, and a better one-stop shop on this topic. Dr. Cs was the scientist behind this concept, while Mr. Kotler is a journalist providing mostly human-interest stories about extreme athletes.The overall thesis of this book is that flow puts the brain in a state where pattern recognition and learning happen at much faster rate, giving rise to superhuman achievements over relatively short periods of time. So consistent flow is a shortcut to mastery, esp. compared to the popular 10,000 hours of conscious practice.Unfortunately, the author focuses entirely on extreme sports enthusiasts: big-wall rock climbers (free soloists), white-water kayakers, giant-wave surfers, BASE and bungee jumpers, freedivers, X-games-winning skaters, acrobatic skiers, etc. I say unfortunately because (a) I could not identify with people who dedicate their life to these pursuits and many of whom die as a result and (b) it is fairly obvious that these pursuits produce flow, while trying to achieve flow in a more productive daily-life activity is difficult and not addressed here.The author mentions a McKinsey study that executives who experienced flow were five times more productive. I would have loved to read more about that, rather than about how a ski bum tore his rectal muscles while trying to stop himself from terminal velocity by grabbing a rope with superhuman strength.Things I learned:- Montessori schools tend to engender flow in students, more so than other educational methods- Skill to difficulty ratio should be 96% to 104% for flow (assuming you can actually measure this)- Group flow, like in a jazz band, group of rock climbers, engrossing conversation, is a phenomenon separate from but similar to individual flowOverall: Recommended, only as a sequel to Flow by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi

Since this book is hailed as some sort of product development bible, I had to read it. I was very disappointed. If the ideas of rapid prototyping and A/B testing are new to you, there is plenty of value in this book, however.The "lean" method is different enough from traditional product development that unless you have practiced it, it is good to learn as much as possible about it by reading or otherwise since the methodology is non-obvious.The GOOD:Lean is very applicable to modern web software startups. The author makes it clear why the following are good practices:- validate business assumptions with real customers and working product or prototype- build the minimal viable product (MVP) which allows you to learn if a feature (set) is valuable- operate in small batches, ideally continuous deployment mode, so that the smallest changes are tested and effort is not spent unnecessarily on large features which may not be useful- A/B test everything to find the most valuable variant of a given featureA valuable concept is the Concierge MVP, which is basically a human-powered, high-touch early prototype that can be used to validate the usefulness of a product before you plunk down the effort to write code, build infrastructure, etc to scale.Random tidbit from the Japanese lean manufacturing lore: if you ask "why" five times in succession when investigating a production issue, you will unearth the true root cause. Who knew.Case studies from real companies (at least contemporary as of publication time) provide good examples of lean techniques.The BAD:The book is bloated and poorly organized. It is clear that the author did not use lean techniques and A/B testing to come up with the content :) The ideas are repeated as nauseam. Since I was reading this as an e-book, I would groan whenever another chapter started, waiting impatiently for the book to finally end.The author seems to think that Lean is applicable to *all* industries and human endeavors, and so set out to write a very generic book. If he had instead focused on web startups, this would have been a much more focused and shorter book. However, lean is known and practiced relatively widely, so perhaps this core audience is already converted.It is hopefully obvious why NASA did not use Lean Startup techniques to land a man on the Moon, and why Apple did not use it to design the first iPhone.Perhaps the biggest failure of the book is that it exposes (repetitively) the philosophical principles behind Lean but does not provide actionable examples / cookbooks for you to implement it.The UGLY:This book ultimately looks like promotion material for the author's consulting services for big companies that want to be innovative.There are also some aggrandizing statements here and there, like the proposal at the end to create a "Long Term Stock Exchange" as an alternative trading venue for company stocks, where value would be based on "innovation accounting" and of course the incessant references to his own company IMVU.VERDICT:Not recommended. Read blogs instead, and visit a company which practices continuous deployment and A/B testing -- you will learn a lot more that way.

I read this book over the past couple of days and loved it. It is among the best business books I have ever read (I know, the bar is low in this genre).The first chapter / read-before-you-buy sample is not representative of how good the book is. It starts with some autobiographical details that I personally did not find interesting. The first 2-3 chapters or 1/4 of the book is like that. And then it gets really to the point and turns into a kick-ass management guide.People management is mostly what the author covers. How to hire experienced executives. How to demote, reorg, and do layoffs. How to create a culture which is not political. How to communicate to avoid being misinterpreted. Different types of execs and CEOs. How to scale a company. How to integrate new employees and evaluate performance.The only topic which steers a bit away from people & process management is how to decide whether to sell your company, and that's a great chapter too.If you are a tech founder & CEO, this book is for you. If you are an executive, you will also find plenty of value. It is rare to find such unvarnished truth and stories from the trenches. Each chapter usually starts with a non-sequitur quote from a rap artist. I like rap too BTW. The quotes give some personality and flavor to the author's voice.Highly recommended.

I am sure it is very healthy. According to the ingredients, it packs a ton of different vitamins, and it probably helps avoiding a cold and getting over it faster. Still, I took it when my throat couldn't take the abuse of my coughing any longer and I can't say it helped with one or the other any more than any regular tea would have.The flavor is pleasant enough, though is not very strong so don't put too much water. I was expecting something a little more citrusy but it is actually very sweet. I actually think some citrus would have help cutting the dull sweetness, but that is personal taste, I guess. It is nice that is all natural.

The pad is nicely designed:- It looks pretty and sleek. Nice colors- It has two big magnets, one on the top of pad, which hold very well- It has three easily detachable sections on each page: "To do" "To Remember" " To Buy". Even if I won't use them for their specific functions it is nice to be able to detach a small part if I don't need the whole page.- Really good quality paper- It has a lot of pages- It has an elastic on the bottom, to keep the pages together, which I image would make the pad hold and continue to looking tidy for much longer.My only issue with the pad is that it doesn't come with any writing device nor a place to put one.

My current quest (around Christmas 2013) to find a camera which takes DSLR-quality photos but is small and convenient to carry has ended with finding the Sony NEX 3N. This review is specifically about the black NEX 3N model (I know that Amazon sometimes lumps several models together).This camera is great for casual photographers who want great image quality combined with convenience.By comparison, I have three old Canons which have served me for many years and I still use occasionally: a small PowerShot, a G-series, and a DSLR. A lot of the time these days I take photos with my Moto X due to its convenience and great image quality. I recently purchased, used, and ultimately got rid of the Nikon 1 J3, Samsung NX 2000, and Samsung Galaxy Camera superzoom, and I have played with a few more mirrorless cameras plus Sony RX100 etc. The Sony NEX 3N is the best camera of the bunch for my needs. Here is why:PROS:- Large APS-C sensor, same size as my DSLR. Helps with low light performance and allows you to easily blur the background for portraits. The latter is very hard with smaller sensor cameras, even with the 1-inch Nikon 1 series.- Very small and lightweight body with the kit 16-50mm lens. The lens is a folding design so it is smaller then not in use. Overall the NEX 3N is of comparable size to the Nikon 1 J and S-series, but the kit lens on the Nikon J protrudes more and makes it bulkier. The Sony is also lighter than the Nikon 1 and much lighter than the Samsung NX series.- Great ergonomics and one-handed use. You can easily hold the camera with your right hand (there is a nice grip for your finger tips), turn on the camera with your thumb, and operate the power zoom near the shutter / on-switch. Neither the Nikon 1 nor the Samsung NX allow you to do this - they are two-handed cameras. The ergonomics of the Nikon 1 are particularly bad in comparison.- Flip LCD screen for selfies (snapshots of yourself). This is amazing! In the first hour of owning this camera, we took our best family portrait while having fun with this feature. Very kid friendly too.- In camera HDR works very well. The images that come out have a balanced look and do not look like posterized caricatures (or the typical "HDR-y" look online)- 4 frames per second is great for capturing motion, especially kids- Taking video is easy and zoom and focus works well. Supports 1080i60 and 1080p24 as well as some lesser modes.- In-camera charging using micro USB, which is what most phones and tablets these days use. I can thus charge the camera in my car, for example.- Decent battery life. I have yet to run low on a family daytrip. That said, energy usage is high like on a point-and-shoot due to the extensive use of the LCD. DSLRs last a lot longer. When I can, I recharge at the end of the day.- "Superior Auto" is a great mode which I use most of the time. Besides automatic scene detection, it also gives you quick control over background blur, filter effects, saturation, etc.- As of this writing, this was the most affordable APS-C sensor camera. I bought mine used, and it was a screaming deal for a DSLR-sensor camera. Even priced as new, I think it is a bang for the buck. The other Sony NEX cameras are much pricier BTW.CONS:- HD video is in AVCHD format, which is not super PC-friendly and looks like Flickr does not support it directly. I have a way to transcode it to MP4, but it would be nice if the camera supported more mainstream formats.- No 720 HD video modes. Those are usually good for smaller video files or smoother motion tracking, but not available here.- No touch screen. This is not a big minus since the menu system is OK. The main plus of touch screens is control over focus.- No wifi. Although from what I have seen, only Samsung does a really good job with wifi and connectivity to Dropbox etc.- Phase detection autofocus would be nice to have. I am happy with AF as it is, but the Nikon 1 (and of course my DSLR) are snappier to focus. With moving subjects, this makes a difference.OVERALL:I think Sony has done a great job with the NEX series. The NEX 3N is the lower end of that series and it is already an awesome camera. The NEX 6 and 7 are even better, but also larger, heavier, and more suited for people who take their photography way more seriously than I do :) The battle in the mirrorless camera arena is between Sony NEX and Samsung NX at this point. Sony makes the better cameras overall and has more lenses, and Samsung has more in-camera features like touch screens, wifi sharing, etc. Both use APS-C sensors. Smaller sensors don't make much sense to me. I have not tried micro 4/3 due to the fact that they are not available in offline stores where I live; which indicates to me that those manufacturers are lagging behind in marketing. Nikon 1 looks like a toy compared to the NEX and the Nikon's sensor is too small for good portraits.Highly recommended.Regardless if you are coming down from an SLR or up from a point-and-shoot, you will like this take-anywhere camera.

I have had the older version of these panels, as well as smaller and larger brethren from the same brand, for more than two years now. They work.This particular product allows you to plug in anything that charges from a USB port, or anything that charges from a car cigarette lighter plug. The latter is handy if you are stranded in the middle of nowhere with your car and you have car chargers for your phone, walkie talkie, etc.Caveat: with the older model that I have, I have found charging via the car plug adaptor to be finicky. It requires really good sunlight and even then it is easy to drop on/off charging mode. Maybe something to do with the voltage. I have not tried this with this newer model, they may have improved things.Overall, this is a lightweight, rugged solar panel which does a good job charging things in an emergency. I would not rely on this however as a regular charging solution. If you live off-grid, you are probably better off with larger panels and bigger batteries than what Goal 0 offers. This is however ideal for having in the car and using during camping trips.Recommended.

I have had the older version of this device for about a couple of years, and now I got this latest version as well.Here is the intended use: open up the solar panels (two panels that together produce 7 watts in good sunlight), connect the AA battery charger gizmo, and charge the batteries. At a later point, use the AA batteries to power your flashlight, toy, or whatever it is, or use the charger itself (with the batteries in it) as a source of power via USB (connect it with a USB cable to your phone or tablet to charge). It works well in this role.More frequently, I use the Guide 10 battery charger indoors with USB only. I can charge batteries straight off my PC with a USB cable, without the solar panels. The charger also supports AAA batteries BTW. The charger also has a clear white LED so it can be used as a flashlight, which I have done occasionally when camping -- not as nice as a real flashlight, but plenty for lighting inside a tent or small room.The bad part: in the past I have had the battery charger melt on me (the area near the on/off/light switch). I do not even know why it happened since it took place inside my work bag when I was not looking. It appears that it may have been turned on somehow. Even so, it was a very disappointing experience which destroyed the charger and now I am more careful with these chargers. I have not had this happen again over the past couple of years.Pros:- easy to carry- handy solar and USB charging solution- supports rechargeable AA and AAA batteriesCons:- the batteries are not nearly the same quality as Sanyo Eneloop (do not last as long on a charge)- one charger melted on me in the past so keep an eye on them- more of a keep-alive than full-charge solution for smart phones (due to capacity of the batteries and speed of charging)Overall:Recommended, as long as you don't expect this to be a magical quick iPad charger :)

I recently bought this camera at half its retail price and I think in this case it is worth the money. After using this camera for a while, I am pretty sure that Android is the future of point-and-shoot cameras, if not all cameras. A big touch screen, wifi, and useful apps are much better than the clumsy old camera interfaces of the past.GOOD:- Superzoom lens. 21x zoom, starting at really wide angle. Not something a phone will be able to do any time soon.- Wifi connectivity + apps like Dropbox, Google Drive, Youtube, Flickr, etc means your photos can be backed up on the cloud immediately, or shared directly on Facebook, Twitter, and so on. I don't use a wire to download photos from this camera. By the time I get to my computer, the photos are already in the cloud.- Android and universal app support. Think of this as an Android phone which can't make calls. It can run all the apps you care about. Including Skype if you really want to make calls :) You can do all sorts of photo editing on the device using various apps. And you can check email, social networks, etc.- The whole interface is touchscreen driven and well designed. Usually a purely menu-driven UI sucks, but Samsung has pulled it off well here. I do wish there were a dedicated video button however.- You can pause and continue videos, creating a mini-movie with cuts between scenes. I had not seen this on other photo cameras before.- Relatively flat and compact. The huge 21x zoom lens folds neatly into the body and it is self-capping like any point-and-shoot. The camera fits in a back pocket or jacket pocket nicely.- Takes portrait oriented (vertical) videos, unlike other cameras. Video looks great, by the way.- Does not go overboard on high ISO in auto ISO mode (800 max) and it prefers to take lower exposures and still take the shot than go crazy on the ISO. Interesting idea, and I like it so far.- Standard micro USB charger like most Android devices. The battery charges inside the camera, like a phone.- Nice hand grip allows one-handed carry and use.- Decent built-in HDR (high dynamic range) and other useful modes.BAD:- Short battery life. This is probably the biggest shortcoming of this camera. I don't know if I can rely on it for a day trip or a weekend trip. I will try to put it to such a test before deciding whether to keep it. Android says 70% or more of the energy is used by the big touchscreen. Even dimming the screen and turning off GPS and Wifi have not helped much in my early testing.- Feels heavy. Definitely heavier than any other point-and-shoot I have played with lately. It is also a little thick for pants pockets. It fits, but not as easily as a phone.- HD video limited to 30fps.- Burst mode (multiple frames per second) does not seem to work well. It is slow, and after the first few frames, the rest come out dark, nearly black. As a result, this camera does not stop action well, esp. indoors.- I find myself using 1x - 2x zoom more than other settings. I wonder if this justifies keeping this camera compared to a zoom-less phone which would take nearly identical photos.- Small sensor has its limitations. It is hard to take really sharp, crisp, noise-free photos with this camera, especially indoors without flash. It takes nice photos on par with other point-and-shoots, but not on par with an SLR. You are paying here for a very flexible Android device rather than a fancy camera.- Auto white balance is a little off. It is a little warm indoors, and a little cool outdoors. Nikon 1 does a much better job. This Galaxy camera does a better job than the fancier Samsung NX series, however.VERDICT:- The jury is still out on this one. While it is probably the best point-and-shoot camera out there, I wonder if it is good enough to keep when compared with my phone.- If you want to own a futuristic camera, buy it. Every good camera in the future will have network connectivity, social networking, cloud storage, touch screen, and powerful in-camera photo editing. Like this Samsung Galaxy Camera.

Here is how I came to buy the Nikon 1 J3:During a recent trip, I discovered that my new Moto X phone took amazing photos and my old digital SLR was just too big & heavy for most occasions. So I started a mission to find something smaller and lighter which would partly or completely replace my SLR and take better photos than my phone. Note that most point-and-shoot cameras do not take better photos than the recent generation of phones, and in fact have the same sensors if not worse. Some sort of mirrorless large-sensor system seemed to be the answer, and I tried the Nikon 1 and others.In a nutshell, the Nikon 1 J3 is an outstanding camera with a terrible user interface.GOOD:- Takes good photos in all types of light. Press the shutter and it takes a photo right away, freezing the moment. No second guessing. Can't say that about most other cameras.- Super fast autofocus. It may well be quicker than most SLRs even. This camera is probably better suited for kids and sports photos than anything else you can buy.- Very high frame-per-second rate for full-sized photos. 15 fps with autofocus, 60 fps without! This is better than practically all other cameras on the market right now. I personally prefer the more sedate 5 fps which is still better than entry level SLRs :)- Good auto white balance. The photos come out looking natural, with good skin tones, etc.- Small and light. The kit lens has an interesting folding design to make itself more compact. This camera is smaller than all other interchangeable-lens mirrorless systems, as far as I can tell.- You can get some decent bokeh (blurry background for portraits etc) with the kit 10-30mm lens with big aperture plus remotebackground. Not as easy as APS-C or full frame sensors, but at least doable.- Clever "unlock the lens and turn the camera on" feature. No need to press the on/off button. Hard to describe but very handy. I wish other manufacturers did this too.- Even when noisy, the photos have an "optically fuzzy," instead of "digitally smeared" look when viewed 1:1, which is a better and more pleasing noise reduction than many other manufacturers and cameras offer.- Instant access to HD video. Press the smaller button with a red dot on it from any camera mode.BAD:- Although it is small and light, and fits in a jacket pocket, this camera is bulky. The kit lens protrudes enough to make it look like you are carrying a good old rock in your pocket. I wish it were flatter. Still, much smaller than any SLR.- The mode selector wheel on top is useless. Normally you expect to find Auto mode + PASM. Here you get Auto + 4 weird and semi-useless modes which were probably conceived for the Japanese market. PASM is hidden under the menus of one of them. The other ones are "automatic selection of the best photo", "take a slow motion 1 second clip before snapping a photo" (WTF?) and advanced movie mode (which is useless since you can record HD from any mode with a dedicated button).- The camera is too menu driven for what it is. See above - PASM and scene modes are buried under menus. I like changing between P, A, and S. (On this camera, S is the most useful mode in my opinion.) HDR is hard enough to get to that I never really use it.- You can't hold this thing one-handed. It is very smooth and there is no finger hold on the right. Why? Even basic point-and-shoots have some little ridge, and SLRs have a big bulge for your right hand to grab.- Auto ISO tends to pick the highest allowed ISO (in my case, 3200) too often when indoors. I wish it would instead try to take a lower-exposure photo instead and let you handle it in post-processing.- No automatic orientation for photos and videos. Are you kidding? I had to flip all my vertical (portrait) orientation photos by hand  in Picasa or Lightroom. Good luck flipping a video file. Any smart phone can do better. My 5+ year-old cameras can do better than this.- Lens cap. Annoying. I like using hoods on my SLR lenses so the lens is protected when open but this is not an option here. Given the puny zoom range, I wish this were a fixed lens self-capping design (like any point-and-shoot).- Noisy raw photos. I tried taking a few indoor shots in NEF, Nikon's raw format. The luminance and chroma noise were shocking. I will stick to JPEG since the image processor does a good job taming the noise in a visually pleasing way. I do not want to waste my time in Lightroom or some other software on this issue.- High frames per second are a bit of a waste of time and storage space. 15fps produces a flood of nearly identical photos that take a while to wade through, and can clog up your storage card. I find it impossible to take a single photo in 15fps mode, while it is doable in 5fps. In 15fps mode, the camera occasionally loses focus (it autofocuses in between frames) and then finds it again. I am sure 15fps and 60fps have their use, but they don't appeal to me yet.- Short battery life. 300 photos maybe? You may last a daytrip if you don't do bit multi-frame-per-second bursts or video.- Image quality is visibly below SLR level. My 5+ year-old APS-C sensor DSLR with the 50mm 1.4 Canon lens (and half the megapixels) utterly destroys this Nikon 1. Better sharpness, color, noise, bokeh, level of control over the camera, etc. That said, that lens alone costs more than what I paid for this Nikon package on sale. Still, it is good to keep things in perspective. The Samsung NX series has equal or worse image quality compared to Nikon 1 (with kit lenses), so it is not just the sensor at play here but every element in the imaging chain.VERDICT:- Great for kids, sports, and low light situations. Better than an ordinary point-and-shoot camera in terms of speed and image quality. The responsiveness, fast focus and frames per second are on par if not better than an SLR at a fraction of the weight and size.- If the camera were more compact, like the Sony RX100 (which has the same sized sensor and is very fast too), I would be in love with it. As it is, it is too bulky to be pocketable and my daily companion, and I am still not sure if I want to keep it.UPDATE JANUARY 2014:- I returned this camera to the store. Instead, I got a Sony NEX 3N and I love it. It is lighter and yet is has a larger sensor, flip screen, wider angle kit lens, and vastly better ergonomics (plus it costs less). Feel free to check that camera out. It also does 4 frames per second, which is not as fast as the Nikon but enough to capture sports or kids in motion.

I have been evaluating this camera for more than a week and comparing it against a Nikon 1 J3 plus my other older cameras. I have been a Canon guy over the years, and I currently have a P&S, a G series, and a DSLR from Canon, all of which are getting old so I was looking to get a large-sensor mirrorless camera.In many ways this camera points towards the future of non-phone cameras: it has a large sensor (bigger than a phone is ever likely to have), wifi connectivity for immediate upload and sharing, and large touch screen with smartphone like gestures (zoom, swipe, etc).GOOD:The best thing about this camera is the UI. With a couple of screen touches, you can change just about any setting. There is an awesome touch-focus-snap feature that allows you to focus where your finger is on the live image, and immediately take a shot. After using the touchscreen, any other camera without it looks primitive. The touch screen is great for taking photos as well as reviewing the results later.Wifi connectivity is also nice. It allows you to upload to Facebook, Picasa, Youtube, and Microsoft SkyDrive. I used the latter since it is like Dropbox - a good place to back up files for post-processing later on my PC. Wifi worked well.Lastly, because the sensor is APS-C size (like on most DSLRs), you get a nice shallow depth of field (bokeh blurry background) which is hard-to-impossible to obtain with smaller sensors.BAD:Image quality is closer to point-and-shoot than SLR. This shocked to me, given the large sensor. I attribute it to the image processor rather than sensor or lens. The images have a slightly pastel-blur quality to them (when viewed zoomed in) that I have last seen on an old Sony point-and-shoot I had 5 years ago. Looks like an image processing and compression artifact to me. Also, the level of noise at high ISO looks identical to that of the Nikon 1, whose sensor is 3x smaller.Auto white balance is also a bit off, at least on mine. It tends to produce slighly cooler tones, especially compared to the Nikon 1. Under indoor lights, when manually set to tungsten, the color matches the Nikon's auto white balance, but it is clear which company makes cameras and which one makes cell phones.Auto focus is slow and sometimes impossible under low light. This is very frustrating when trying to photograph kids - the moment will be gone by the time you are ready. Interestingly, if you use the touch-focus feature on the screen, the camera is much more likely to focus correctly, when the shutter button focus fails to focus. I guess there is difference between the shutter button focus trying to evaluate a larger area, while the touch-focus tries to find contrast in a smaller area and succeeds. Even so, focus is not as fast as I'd like (and slower than an SLR or the Nikon 1). BTW, focus is also likely to be lost during shooting video, especially at low light and longer zoom (50mm on the kit lens) and then there is a second or so of trying to lock on again, which is a bit annoying.Image stabilization is lacking. Most cameras in this class have it either in the body (sensor) or lens. Not here. The kit 20-50mm lens is not stabilized. This makes a difference in low light situations and when shooting video.Lastly, the physical buttons and controls on the camera suck. It would have been nice to have a normal PASM selector on top like most DSLRs have. Instead, there is a semi-useless selector on top (I avoid using it since it is hard to guess what it will do in what mode).OVERALL:Not recommended. Image and video quality are more important than UI and Wifi. The Nikon 1 has shown me that phase detect autofocus and image stabilization are necessary in a camera of this type. Samsung NX300 has phase detection, and if its autofocus is faster and better, I may give it a try. Another option is the Sony NEX series, which also has image stabilization and supposedly better image quality from the same size sensor (I have not yet tried it).

I used a Fitbit Flex for over a month because I had lost my Fitbit One. In a nutshell, Fitbit One is a better device.Pros (for the Flex):- always on your wrist, much harder to lose or forget at home etc- very water resistant -- I showered with it daily, and some moisture would get into the band but not affect the device itself- good battery life, lasts a week- sleep tracking easier than on Fitbit One because the device is with you when you go to bed (less likely to forget it)Cons:- Accuracy of step tracking is my biggest problem by far. First of all, because this is a wrist device unlike (Fitbit One and others that measure torso movements), I doubt Flex is able to detect activity when I am pushing a shopping cart, baby stroller, or simply carrying something in my hands. I use the device on my dominant hand (because the other has a watch), and although the device has a "non-dominant hand" setting, I do not believe it to be accurate. I noticed that my dominant hand moves less than the other because it is more likely to hold and carry things, or just move less based on how I carry my messenger bag, etc. Perhaps one way they get over the wrist vs torso and non-dominant wrist problem is by using some sort of multiplier compared to movements of the non-dominant wrist. Which leads to overestimating step count. For example, yesterday I mostly sat like a potato on very long international flight and yet I almost met my daily goal! On other days, I would go on long walks pushing a baby stroller, and barely make any progress. So Flex seems to overcount activity when you sway your hand like when walking, and undercount it when you are active but not moving your hands much. Fitbit One does not have this problem.- the five dots display is not very precise - you don't know whether you are 1999 steps short of your goal or 1, for example, and that frustrates me at times- entering and exiting sleep mode is too hard: you have to keep tapping the device like crazy, and sometimes it is more stubborn than usual; plus, it is still easy to forget to set it for sleep mode if you are too sleepy, or exit sleep mode in the morning if you are sleepy or in a hurry, which leads to missing or inaccurate sleep measurements- does not track or show climbing steps, distance, calories, etc which the Fitbit One doesI am returning the Flex and getting another Fitbit One. I can't wait to be able to see the exact number of steps I have made, pace myself during the day, and feel better about the accuracy of the measurements.Overall: Not Recommended.

I don't understand all the positive reviews. We have several of these wooden drag along animals (from different brands) and I must say this is probably my least favorite.Cons:1- The wheels and the fin are made of plastic. We got a wooden toy because we do not want our kid playing with plastic.2- The wheels do not work, the fish can't remain standing for more than 2 seconds when the toddler pulls it. So instead of having a cute little fish following him or her around, the toddler has this floppy thing that follows sideways. Fortunately, the toy is very light so it doesn't scratch hardwood floors.3- The plastic, not really functional: wheels get dented and scratched after the most minimal contact with a slightly rough floor (example if taken to the sidewalk).4- They toy is a little boring: most of the other toys like this we have make some sort of rattle noise or have something open and close when they are being dragged, this one doesn't.Pros:1 - My toddler seems to like it.2 - Since it is very light, the baby can carry it around.3 - The big eyes are a huge success.

We love green toys! We love that they are made in the US. We love that they are made out of recycled materials. Though we would like it even better if it weren't made out of plastic. Maybe out of the biodegradable cornstarch material? We also love the size of them, they are big, sturdy toys, not the regular flimsy made in China toys. There are no bells and whistles, no lights and sounds but just a great quality product that work simply, but nicely. We have several of them and I am sure they will be a favorite for years to come: Babies love them because they are light, colorful and easy to grab, older kids like them because they are big and play really nice, grown-ups like them because they are darn cool. It is nice to find a brand that does not sacrifice quality (specially of play) in order to call themselves "green" or "made in the USA".The spaceship is nice and big. The two doors are fun, though hard for our toddler to open and close, though the two little astronauts are big hit with the tiny hands.Recommended.

The reason why we ordered these is that we wanted to hold up a large rose bush which fell of our wall. This turned out not to be the task these plant clips were intended for. They are not large enough, and I worry that they are also not sturdy enough to support much weight.That said, we also have tomatoes, and these Garden Friends work well for those small plants. We have barely made a dent in the 20 count bag, so although they are not the cheapest, I think they work well if you only have a small number of plants like we do.A big plus for me is that the item is made in the US.Recommended.

Very happy with it so far. We are using it on our home theater PC with Windows Vista, and we may install it also on our Android mobile devices. The best thing about LiveSafe is that it runs unobtrusively and does not seem to slow down the PC that we use to watch movies, stream videos, etc.

I had heard and read about this book, so I finally made myself read it. Overall, it is a good resource, although a little too limited, especially given the sheer number of pages.What's good:- If you feel sudden fear in an unfamiliar situation, trust it. This is good advice and the author gives some examples where trusting or mistrusting this fear had good or bad consequences for the person involved. Human intuition has been honed over millennia and can pinpoint something weird much faster than conscious thought can. In fact, apparently if your dog barks at a person while you talk to him, the dog is reading your body cues (because your human intuition is richer) rather than judging the other person directly.- List of behaviors that strangers and con artists use to gain your trust, and how to reject them.- List of questions to ask at your child's school about their security measures, and what to ask potential babysitters.- How to deal with stalkers and abusive spouses (in a nutshell, remove yourself from the interaction ASAP).- How to fire problem employees.- Some insights into how various types of criminals think and how they are after all human and one can read their motivations.- Reinforces the importance of good parenting with some chilling examples of parental failure.- Spells out the difference between fear and anxiety and suggests ways to reduce anxiety.- Covers well the social engineering side of (unorganized) violent crime.What's bad:- Tons of self-promotion and name dropping. The author has a celebrity protection company and works with leading law enforcement agencies since his clients are high profile. He makes this clear on every page of the book.- Covers reasonably well only the cases where violence is most obvious and predictable, e.g. child abuse or spousal abuse.- Does not provide actionable advice on what to do when faced with danger, besides the obvious "trust your fear". Perhaps he means to say, get the hell out of there, but that is not spelled out.- Insists that violence is always predictable, and the opinion to the contrary (plus being extra aware or prepared) is wrong. Yes, in cases where once can observe the potentially violent person, such as inside families or at work, I would agree with the author. However, in the US there is a surprising number of public place shootings where most of the attendees would have no idea that violence would be coming until it is upon them.- Contradicts himself when describing a high profile manhunt for a serious criminal, which unexpectedly reveals the lairs of two other stalkers close to his customer's residence, even though de Becker and his firm are supposed to be routinely on top of these threats. So things are not as clear and predictable after all?Overall recommended. That said, there are other good books on this topic out there, and after reading this one, learn also about ways to protect yourself and loved ones.

After reading Suarez's first two books, I was really looking forward to this one, and overall I was not disappointed. I liked his first novel, Daemon, and wasn't too impressed with the second, Freedom. This third book is his second best, in my opinion better than Freedom and better than most action thriller books I have recently read.Suarez's first two novels were a lot more expansive in scope and thought provoking, trying to imagine the future through the lens of multiple technological trends. Kill Decision is a lot more focused on the near future and on military action and technology. This is why it reminded me of Tom Clancy - there is plenty of political conspiracy and intrigue, combined with special ops units and gallons of military jargon and abbreviations. This novel is thought provoking too, asking just how pervasive surveillance and drone attacks could be, and answering the question by introducing technologies currently believed to be cutting edge. In that sense, the style is also similar to Michael Crichton. There is also a good discussion of role of traditional and social media.So why only 3 stars? The plot and the ending were weak. Without giving away too much of a spoiler, it remains unclear who is behind the drone attacks. It is far from clear that the team of good guys has accomplished anything at the end besides giving us a fun and educational ride around the world (for which they get three stars). Also, there is bizarre emphasis on small "dumb" drones with ant-like swarming behavior (almost exclusively in the second half of the book) instead of the bigger and smarter (or human controlled) drones which appear at the beginning. In fact, this also signifies a disconnect between the research of the Stanford AI scientists early on in the book and the ant professor who occupies most of the rest, to the point that I wonder what the Stanford guys had to do with the plot at all, besides perhaps to tick off one more technology mention off the list. Another reviewer mentioned that in this book, the repetitive and annoying killer motorcycles of the earlier novels have been replaced by equally persistent killer drones, and I tend to agree. I wonder if this book was somehow rushed to print to capitalize on drones being a big topic du jour - it is clear that the plot lines and characters could have been a bit more elaborate like in the earlier novels. As it is, this book is more reminiscent of Ian Fleming's fun but relatively shallow action novels (which is also a compliment).Speaking of high tech gadgets, there are plenty. All sorts of brands and models of gear. Which brings me to two tiny annoyances. What's up with the special ops guys using Maglites? Who uses Maglites anymore? I would have expected them to at least have nice Surefire LED lights. And occasionally the good guys brandish a ".45 tactical pistol" or a "killing knife" - what is that? Everything else has a brand or model number or at least a description, except their most basic tool?All in all, a fun read. It may even make you want to go and build your own little drone :)

Pros:- short read (and inexpensive to buy)- well written and to the point- decent primer on the larger structural trends affecting unemployment, especially in the most recent recession/depression- optimistic view of how individuals will be empowered to become global entrepreneurs by rich technology like Amazon, Etsy, Google ads, and of course the artificial intelligence marvels of the future- smart quotations from Aristotle and Keynes :)Cons:- most of the points should be familiar and obvious if you read financial news and tech blogs, e.g. increasing income disparity, technology developing exponentially faster and obsoleting humans, globalization and digitalization creating winner-take-all market dynamics, etc.- no bold predictions of the future and recommendations on how to cope with the huge social dislocations (the authors admit that re-education of low-skilled obsoleted workers does not work, and government handouts don't do much for morale)- no mention how the ongoing centralization of income and power, combined with ever more powerful technology could result in oppressive dystopiaIf you have lived under a rock and did not know about Moore's law, Google's self-driving cars and natural language processing, or the jobless recession recovery and falling real median incomes in the US, this book is for you. I give it 3 stars because it is very well written and mercifully short.

This is one of the best books I have ever read, in terms of the effect it has had on my worldview. It is a pity that it took me decades to stumble upon it (its opinions are unpopular), so I heartily recommend that you read it, even if you only have a cursory interest in it :)The book completely lives up to its title. It traces the emergence of the industrial revolution, the "free market," and the social transformations (seismic upheavals would be a more appropriate description) that resulted from it. The author prophetically argues that a truly free market is a highly artificial construct with no parallel in earlier history, and if left to its own devices, it would lead (and has led) to ecological, economic, and cultural catastrophe. According to the author, the market should be subordinated to the needs of society instead of the other way around, and planning and intervention should be applied with that goal in mind.This books is a welcome antidote to all the political and economic dogmatism which has resulted from Adam Smith, Hayek, Mises, and even Marx. It is a pity that some reviewers here have given the book low marks. The level of free-market laissez-faire zombified indoctrination in the US is way over the top and most people simply cannot accept the fact that the truly unregulated market is a destructive force (in economic parlance, it produces huge negative externalities). It is sort of like nuclear energy, although the author does not make this analogy.There are of course issues with this book. The main one being its inaccessibility. It was written in the 1940s, so the language is a bit archaic (sentences too long for the Twitter generation). The author also assumes some familiarity with Europe of his time, especially the 1920s and 1930s; it would have been better if he had spelled out in a bit more detail what took place historically and why. Lastly, he dwells a bit too much on the English industrial revolution, and glosses over the continental one (Germany, France, others). Since he makes it clear that on the continent events took a different course, it would have been helpful to understand what happened and how it fits in his narrative.All this said, this book is very difficult to summarize since it is chock-full of thought-provoking insights. And the ending is beautiful and optimistic, very much worth the perseverance to read the whole tome :)Very highly recommended!

Granted, this is not a world changing device, but for the price, the convenience factor is definitely there. I love feeling like my baby's pacifiers are clean and sterilized any time I want and that it only takes a few seconds without me having to boil water or do other crazy things. I also like that I can put nipples from bottles in there. It is small, so it doesn't occupy a lot of space and it is ridiculously easy to use. It can be used anywhere where there is a microwave, so it is very handy for travel as well. This thing can also be used as a carrying box for pacifiers when traveling.There isn't enough info about the pacifiers themselves, however. Even after I researched, went to their website and tried to find everywhere about the type of pacifiers come with the device, I could not find any info. (Granted the package has a little dot that says BPA free, but does that mean that is all BPA free? That does mean only the device is BPA free? I don't know and I would like a little more info about it.)On the other hand, the company is European and usually Europe has tighter regulations about those things than the US, so that is comforting. The pacifier sterilizer is clever, compact and easy, and will probably get a lot of use from us.Recommended.

I have been cursed with Zimba's hair, my hair can be described as a Lion's mane. What do I mean by that? Thin, frizzy hair, not exactly curly, though not straight either and with a tendency to occupy three times its volume. It has the advantage of being super malleable, I can do whatever I want with it and the disadvantage of getting ruined by just whispering at it. That means, I have a love-hate relationship with hair straighteners since I was twelve. I love how my hair looks when I use them, shiny, tidy, easy to handle, but on the other hand, use it twice and my hair starts to show all the signs of destruction.This straightener has a few key features that help with that:- The Keratin Therapy Bath: Helps the hair look shiny and keeps it protected, though I think it gives the straightner an odd and a little nasty smell when heated.- The fact that one can control the temperature: Super easy to determine which temperature to use to straighten your hair, great for people like me that have hair that is thin and easy to straighten but also easy to damage. Granted, using it in the lowest setting can make the straightening process a little longer and a little less effective, but it is worth it for every day use if you don't want to ruin your hair.I must say I used it a  couple of times and so far, it doesn't look like it is damaging my hair too much, which is great.Another great feature, that it automatically shuts off after a while, just in case you forget and it also has a locking mechanism that makes burning yourself less likely.Overall I think it is a good product.

This is an example of blatant misrepresentation by the manufacturer. The box says organic cotton, which is a major selling point. When we opened it at home, we were in for a rude surprise. The canopy has a label which says "All New Materials Polyester Fiber" and the flowers have labels which say "Content 100% Polyester". So where is the organic cotton???To top it off, it does not fit our crib. They have made some strange assumptions about the size of the boards. By the way, this "masterpiece" is made in China, which does not make me confident in the materials used.NOT recommended! I am returning mine today.

The Good:- Very comfortable to use for extended periods of time- Good sound quality for music (I have not pitted it against mega expensive alternatives though)- Seals the ears pretty well for tuning out distractions and noise cancelling is goodThe Bad:- Separate mic and phones plugs won't work on an iPhone or even my laptop - you can only use them as headphones- No call control buttons like mute, on/off, volume, etcI use these for listening to music at work. I really wish that they had included an adaptor to make it work as a mic+headphone combo for newer devices. Otherwise I need to switch to iPhone style earbuds for Skype and so on.Overall impression: Recommended

I use these clips to hold USB cables for my mouse and keyboard and Ethernet and power cords for my laptop work station. These clips are great for this and keep cables in place. Attaching them was super easy. Because the clips are clear, they do not add to the clutter (visually). I have not yet tried to detach and move the clips, although supposedly that is possible. These clips are ideal for what I use them for, which is keeping cables in a specific place so they are easy to plug and unplug without the cables moving around. The clips are not generic cable organizers intended to keep similar cables bundled together, etc - for that, you need zip ties.

I bought this book based on the positive reviews here and my own curiosity about new angles on European history.The book's main purpose is to re-examine the forgotten theory put forth by the Belgian historian Henri Pirenne in the early 20th century that Islam killed Classical culture and caused the dark ages in Europe. Emmet Scott, the writer of this book, spends quite a lot of time and ink debunking the main critics of Pirenne while examining relatively recent archeological evidence.I definitely learned a lot from the book, especially about Islamic piracy, slave trade, disruptions in normal Mediterranean trade, the three-century archeological and cultural gap and the destruction of cultural artifacts in the Asian and Mediterranean centers of civilization.It is clear that the author definitely has an axe to grind with Islam and dislikes the cultural effects of Muslim conquest on the Euro-Mediterranean world. He makes persuasive arguments along these lines.However, the book is flawed in many ways:- It is not clear who the intended audience is. There is a lot of archeological discussion and minutia early on, but towards the end the author starts jumping to unsupported speculation. It is clearly not a scientific work, but neither is it good political commentary.- The book takes way too long to get to its core points about the cultural effects Islam. Of 16 chapters, the first 10 at least are a slow-motion slog though archeological sites, discussions of books and papers and so on, without actually clearly stating a thesis or conclusion. Only towards the end does the author start to show his true colors and make bolder points.- The author assumes some (unclear) amount of familiarity with Islam and the world of classical antiquity. It would have been better if he provided more of a background on Islam as a religion and its civilization. It would have been great to focus more on the interactions of the West with Islam, including crusades, Lepanto, the reconquista in Spain, etc. The author draws some parallels between the fervency of Spanish Catholicism and Islam, but this theme deserves deeper development. How about Byzantine iconoclasm and Islam's lack of religious images?- There are some mixed messages when it comes to Islam and higher learning. The author tries to deny the mainstream assumption that Islam kept, improved, and re-introduced classical knowledge to Europe. This is a Protestant cultural myth whose genesis is well exposed. However, the author does mention centers of learning and literature in the Islamic world (while making earlier points about Islam as the destroyer of classical culture). So which is it? He should have been more focused in his message.- At the end the author undermines some of his own assertions that Islam caused three centuries of dark ages. Apparently chronology around that time was not ironclad and it may well be that the whole period lasted a couple of decades (instead of centuries) according to some controversial theories. Hmm, so we still do not know that much about the dark ages, do we?- Scott at some point concedes that Pirenne did not have that much evidence to base his theory on back in the day, even if his theory seems sound in light of modern archeology. Well, in that case why spend most of this book on the narrow topic of discussing the academic merits of Pirenne and the disappearance of papyrus from Europe, when the larger topic of Islam and the dark ages is far more interesting?In sum, I wish the author had edited (rewritten) the book with more focus on the dark ages, nascent Islam, and the Mediterranean of that time. I am OK with his biases, and in fact I wish he had explored his thesis in full, without spending 2/3 of the book on obscure archeological discussions and critiques of narrowly focused papers. As it is, nearly 70% of this book is very dry and slow reading followed by some interesting but poorly developed themes at the end.

The “Mecca of Historic Preservation,” General George Washington’s Headquarters is the 1750 house built by Colonel Jonathan Hasbrouck and used by Washington during the Revolutionary War. It was scheduled to be torn down in 1850 but a group of preservations petitioned to keep the building intact and won. In addition to being the location where General Washington first issued the Purple Heart Medal, it was here “that Washington refused to become King.” Henry Hudson on “his historic voyage up the river that bears his name, anchored in the Newburgh Bay” and one of his fellow travelers told him “this is a very pleasant place to build a town on.” A hundred years later 54 Palatine refugees settled the area. The hardworking citizens turned the village into a manufacturing Mecca and their descendents built a thriving and modern city that was the second city in America to have it’s streets lighted by Thomas Edison. The city was noted for its architectural wonders. In nine chapters of photographs the book shows the growth of Newburgh from 1860 until the end of the 1960’s. The book is fascinating, but a little depressing when the government policy of Urban Renewal (Chapter 8) destroyed much of the town’s architecture and industry. Newburgh, NY is still a wonderful city although various levels of government have done their best to destroy this architectural jewel on the banks of the Hudson River. If the city can avoid becoming the main trash dump for NYC and stop other communities from sending bus loads of poor, largely uneducated people with no place to live to Newburgh, the city may still survive its problems just like it did Urban Renewal. Not mentioned in the book are some of the positive things happening in the city of Newburgh and the Town of Newburg on its border. There are now two colleges making their home in Newburgh City, the Stewart Air Force Base is now expanding to become an International Airport as well, and there are plans for building a casino near the airport. Hopefully Newburgh, which includes one of the largest historical districts in America will be able to prosper and retain its fantastic architectural and historical legacy. Other nearby towns such as New Paltz, NY have only been able to keep a few of their historic structures in the form of a one-street Village within the larger town, but Newburgh still retains 445 acres of its Historical District. Newburgh may survive simply because it’s one of the least expensive places to live within easy railroad commuter range of NYC. This book provides a nice peek at the town and its unique history.

It took me forever to finally get to the end of this silly, shallow novel. I'd read a couple of chapters and then get side tracked by another book and then another and then another. Try as I might I just could not enjoy this novel. The writing was okay, better than the plot, but much too wordy. It reminded me of the many attempts I'd made to read Thomas Hardy's "Return of the Native" where the author spends 30 pages describing a walk down a country road. I'm amazed anyone ever reached the end of that walk and finished that so-called "Great English Novel." I'm obviously too shallow for it.Reading it also reminded me of my phone conversations with my sister where she will spend an hour or more telling me every word and feeling she got from a 10 minute conversation about nothing with one of her friends.One of the first chapters of this novel set in L.A. involved the main female character waking up in bed  with a nude man that she could not remember ever meeting. She immediate starts trying to figure out if she had sex with this stranger. But there is no sign of used condoms or her diaphragm. Does any women in the college-aged, Millennial generation depicted in this novel even know what a diaphragm is?Anyway, the two strangers spend considerable time trying to find the woman's panties so she can getto her summer internship with an outfit called "Boomerang." The panties are gone until the couple accidentally finds them in the toaster oven. Okay, so that's supposed to be amusing. Maybe yes, maybe its just stupid?Frankly, the plot felt contrived and included lots of material (like the diaphragm) that would not likely be a part of the time frame of the story and it's characters.As somebody who lived in L.A. for several years, almost none of the residents we encountered (even in Hollywood) were as sex-crazed as the characters in this book. But having watched Jay Leno's "Jay Walkers" in utter dismay for several years since we lived there, I supposed Californians may have since dumbed down to a level described in this novel.Boring, boring, boring was my over-all reaction to this novel, even though the writer does know how to write. Maybe she managed to get farther along the country road in "Return of the Native?"

I bought and read this book because I'm very interested in the city of Newburgh, NY's history. I'm not really a railroad buff like some of my friends. The book was well written and satisfied my curiosity about the important part railroads played in the development of the historic city of Newburgh and the rest of the Hudson River Valley. The city is old enough that Gen. George Washington's headquarters was located there and is now a museum. The city was also the second city in America to have Thomas Edison provide the streets with electric lights. There is a lot railroad history attached to Newburgh and an equal amount, or even more, attached to the eastern side of the Hudson River across from Newburgh, but that's another subject (especially Croton-Harmon) for the Arcadia publishers.This book only devotes one chapter of pictures to the railroads running along the other side of the river. While this book provided me with what I wanted to learn, after a while I got tired of the ten chapters of photographs of classic trains, railroad bridges, ferry boats, active and abandoned railroad stations. However, I'm certain that when I loan my railroad buff friends this volume that they will find it infinitely more entertaining because with their educated eyes, they will see rare details and delights in the historic photographs that mean little to me. And if they also happen to know the geography around Newburgh well, then the train schedules and maps will also be of much more interest to them. This is a useful reference book for true lovers of railroad history. It was even educational for a non-railroad history buff like me.

It’s amazing how riveting a non-fiction book about modern day politics and power can really be. This is a 281-page turner in the purest sense of the term. It’s impossible to put the book aside once began. Readers of Edward Klein’s previous books won’t find this reading addiction surprising, but others should be prepared for a long night of blurry-eyed reading. Each chapter leaves the reader hanging over a cliff and ready to jump to the next exciting adventure in the political thriller. The book is nonpartisan in that the author doesn’t seem to favor either the Clintons or the Obamas. He just lays out the facts as best as he can based on interviews with many people who were present at the events and planning sessions. While many critics have claimed the book is a pack of lies, for those readers who have carefully followed the careers of the Clintons and the Obamas its difficult not to believe the contents of the books even if individuals might interpret them differently. The most interesting speculations, based on fact and common sense, are the secrets that Hillary and Bill are with-holding by omission that might make Hillary’s White House Run a flop. For those readers who believe what either the Clintons or Obamas say in public, be prepared for a shock to your system. It's unbelievable who really runs the nation because its really not the President.  It's amazing that every speech, decision, budget, law, executive order has to fulfill a political function whether or not it is good for the country. The political intrigues and lies that permeate Washington, DC, are truly Shakespearean. This book could easily be about the Roman Empire and its rulers and their political power struggles.

"Basil & Spice" was the name of a blog this same author ran for years. The blog's title caused most new viewers to think it was a food or cooking website. Not so. Ditto for this book of poetry that does indeed use food metaphors as well as actual foods to introduce the readers to the Christian Cultures that have existed in the Middle East for two thousand years.So skillfully done is the writing, that many of the meals that are an important part of every family and extended family celebrations that the reader can almost taste the distinct flavors. Some times the descriptions of the meal preparation seem like they could be used as actual receipts for making the yummy taste bud pleasers.Reading this book will probably make most readers long for the large extended families that exist in the Middle East. Many of the mothers included in this book had a dozen children. The culture is so different that it almost seems like is from an unreal world.This book will open the eyes of the Western readers through it's descriptions of important milestones in family life that hasn't changed much since Jesus walked the same areas described in this tome. The events are timeless. Birth, Baptism, learning, courting, weddings with the new bride moving out of her childhood home to the house of her Mother-in-law, Diaspora, endless war, loss, death, funerals, hope, all these events are conveyed in the poetry of this volume. As the author writes, "Music, dance, and poetry are in a sense the soul of the people of the Middle East. Poetry is often read aloud and is cherished, as it speaks to the heart in its native tongue."It's definitely worth the read. And the reader should take a look at the author's portrait on the book's last page. The image almost seems to levitate. That adds a certain amount of surrealism to the marvelous poems.

As one of those folks who are fascinated with reading and comparing listings and rankings of various people, companies, political trends. sports teams and sexual habits, I found this book interesting but my mind told me that it was probably not relevant to anything.First of all, probably some of the greatest leaders in history may be totally forgotten in the mists of time. As far as great inventors goes, who was it that first discovered how to make fire?Secondly, it makes perfect sense that recent events and personalities are well known enough to be listed on more than a couple of data banks and computers, but what about those famous or non-famous people from the past that no one even knows the names of?Naturally, in this world of 24/7 media, current events and personalities are going to garner the most Google and other types of hits from people searching for information. Movie and music celebrities may soon be the most researched folks in the history of the world. Based on search hits Barrack Obama will probably be the listed as the most important leader of the 21st Century even though he may well prove to be by far the worst U.S. President in American History.This reader reviewer will continue to enjoy reading the constant barrage of new lists--Top Film Stars, Richest People, Most Popular Dog Breed, etc., etc., but 99.9% of them are fad flashes.Fame, like beauty is fleeting.Statistics are the worst of the three main types of lies. Readers of this book should always bear that fact in mind. Statistics can be made to say anything.

For all those readers of the first Rush Revere story of the Pilgrims, this second book in the series won’t disappoint. As a Boston resident this reader loved the book because so much of it is set in and around Boston as well as the 13 colonies and England. Lavishly illustrated with both new paintings of Rush Revere and his time traveling horse “Liberty,” and historical documents and paintings of historical scenes. Ben Franklin is one of the main characters in this 242-page volume. The entire book could have been about Franklin because the Patriot was one of the most brilliant Americans to trod the country. He was an important force in the founding of the nation. Among his many inventions in addition to ‘Lightning Rods,” Franklin invented bi-focal eye glassed and even flippers to use for faster swimming. His flippers were shaped more like an artist’s palette than a frog’s webfoot. In addition to being a great inventor Franklin was also a good citizen. He founded the first Volunteer Fire Department in America as well as becoming one of the first famous newspaper men and book authors. Like in the first volume of this series, history comes alive for readers and listeners to the children’s-young adult history primer. Young readers will once again be transfixed by the time-traveling students and their part-time history teacher. Adults will also like this volume because of the presentation and the history that they’ve never heard before. This is a page-turner keeper.

This illustrated, 185-page book of practical geology is a page-turner by anyone's standards. No sooner had my copy arrived in the mail than I was curled up on the sofa eagerly turning the pages and studying the excellent photographs, charts and maps. When I took my teenage son to visit Italy the number one site we both wanted to see was Pompeii, even though it was on the opposite coast of most of Italy's most visited sites. Both Pompeii and the nearby city of Herculaneum were buried for centuries but Mount Vesuvius has and will erupt again. Both these ancient cities will once more be buried, but now more than three million people live in the nearby area and a sudden major eruption will seem like the end of the world for most of them. For those people who have visited Pompeii, another discovery that every tourist makes is that Mt. Vesuvius is only the volcano closest to Pompeii and Naples. As one stands on the upper seats of Pompeii's coliseum they will notice a long line of other volcanoes running along the coast. Some of them appear much larger than Vesuvius. This situation is also true for the Northwest United States. Mt. Rainer, Mt Hood and Mt. St. Helens are all part of the Pacific Rim of Volcanoes. It's interesting to read why people continue to live in the shadows of volcanoes even thought they know the danger. This book answers some of the questions about that living on the edge. Chapter 5 is called, "'It's part of the culture. Live with it! --cities in Japan.'" The book's other eight chapters also point to similar answers. This is a quick and brief book that wastes no time making its important points. It will answer many reader's questions about why people live on the edge of such proven dangerous neighbors.

For many years the National Geographic has maintained a special relationship with the White House and  every few years the NGS produces or updates a lavish full color update on the various U.S. Presidents life in the White House. This new edition of that continuing documentation is a 353 pages of large format, coffee table book.This book, with a foreword by Laura Bush continues to update the public on the building and traditions of "The People's House." Unlike some of the earlier small format paperback editions such as "The Living White House" this book is what most readers would expect a book about their leader's house to be like.National Geographic, unlike most publications, is located in Washington, D.C., not far from the White House and whenever some notable event takes place, NGS will send over a photographer or two to document it. Most photographic interns at the NGS spend some time providing photographic coverage of these White House events. When Lady Byrd Johnson was first lady, nearly every tree planting in her campaign to beautify Washington was covered by National Geographic photographers. This means that the National Geographic Society has an almost limitless collection of beautiful images with which to make it's selectionsfor these books.The NGS provides continuing coverage of the White House and other landmark buildings in or near Washington, D.C. This collection of White House history and photographs is exactly what most fans of the NGS would expect. It makes a nice coffee table illustrated history book. It's also the latest in a continuing series that will be updated to include interesting facts about the next President and his family.

I was surprised that this item wasn't larger, but that's okay because it's easier to store this way. I like the fact it stands up on its base so that the user doesn't have to be holding it while they are working. Also, because it stands upright, it works much better as a flashing emergency beacon that can be seen from all directions. It produces a good amount of light for its size. amount of batteries and the rubber covering looks like it would work well even when wet. It's a nice product whose flashing light looks like it could be seen from a good distance away.

As a Midwesterner I had no idea of the history behind the legendary New York Chelsea Hotel. I had thought it was just another one of those famous 100 year-old New York Hotels. What a delightful surprise I found when I started to read this wonderful history of the historic Chelsea Hotel. In 1884 "The Chelsea Association Building began its life as one of the city's first great apartment buildings--a cooperative club set in the middle of what was then the city's mass-transit crossroads and its center for the arts--and became residential hotel shortly after the turn of the century. Near the end of the Depression, when it succumbed to bankruptcy, the hotel was bought by a syndicate of arts-friendly Hungarian émigrés and managed by them for nearly seventy years. Over the decades, the genteel home for artists grew increasingly shabby as etched-glass panels were broken, murals painted over, and parquet floors pulled up so the buildings original eighty apartments could be partitioned into more than three hundred rooms and suites...In 1966, when the hotel was granted official city-landmark status--over strident objections by some neighboring business owners, who thought it would be better to raze the bohemian enclave some of the suites retained their late-Victorian grandeur."What non-New Yorkers such as this reviewer didn't know was that the Hotel was a commune for artists much like many others such as Massachusetts' Brook Farm that failed after only five years. Hotel Chelsea's commune for artists managed to survive for more than 125 years because it included a much larger number of fabulously wealthy residents and patrons. It is now in the hands of a NYC developer who plans to convert it back to a boutique hotel. Since there are still 80 households holding down their units, the proposed boutique hotel may be a while coming.The list of famous residents who at one time resided at the hotel commune would require several pages just to list.
