A few of them included writers Mark Twain, Thomas Wolfe, Allen Ginsberg, Arthur Miller, and Arthur C. Clark. Artists included John Sloan, Jackson Pollock, Dennis Hopper, and Larry Rivers. Musicians included Virgil Thomas, Bob Dylan, Janis Joplin and Pattie Smith.If the reader likes reading about some of the most famous artists and writers who ever lived, this book is filled with their adventures and creations at the Hotel Chelsea. Many of the hotels long-term residents came to spend a single night and never left. The ashes of several former residents were scattered around the rooftop garden. The readers will probably find it interesting to learn who they were?Other trivia answers readers can find out about are: Where was the Britney Spears Room? What famous writer did Jack Kerouac have a one-night stand with at the Chelsea? What play did Arthur Miller write while residing in the commune? Where did Andy Warhol shoot his film?  What album did Bob Dylan compose while living there?  When did film producer Stanley Kubrick visit Arthur Clark to work on "2001: A Space Odyssey?" Were Janice Joplin, Madonna and Marianne Faithful full-time residents there? How many famous authors wrote about the Chelsea Hotel based on their personal experiences living in the grand old place?The Chelsea Hotel was indeed a "Dream Palace" although many of it's neighors over the decades considered it more of a nightmare. The reason's for the latter opinions were probably the most interesting parts of this illustrated history.

It may just be coincidence, but lately this reviewer has read a lot of books that started out as page-turners but by the end had run out of energy. This was another one. Young “Winston was determined from an early age to make a name for himself and pursue a career in politics. “ He chose a military career in the 4th (Queens Own) Hussars, one of England’s elite cavalry regiments, “Churchill believed that a distinguished military career was, for someone of his background and class, the perfect preparation for entering politics Winning medals and decorations fighting for his country would enable him to ‘beat my sword into an iron Dispatch box’ For Churchill, this was the perfect ‘foundation for political life’, after which he intended to ‘devote my life to the preservation of this great Empire and to trying to maintain the progress of the English people.’” During Churchill’s six week participation in the Malakand campaign he also because a journalist by writing a series of articles for the Daily Telegraph. That series resulted in him receiving a deal to publish his first book in 1898 under the title “The Story of the Malakand Field Force: An Episode of Frontier War.” That book began Churchill’s life-long writing career. Young Winston later took part in the Boer War, ‘”where his dramatic escape from captivity made him a household name, helping him to win his first seat as an MP for Oldham in 1900.” Churchill had a plan and he turned it into reality. Along the way he was almost killed in several hard-fought battles. “The loss of so many of his fellow officers and comrades caused Churchill to reflect on the risks inherent to a military career. In other callings, such as politics, business or the arts, a person who conducted themselves properly and worked hard could look forward to advancement, while successful pursuit of a military career depended to a large extent on luck. It did not matter how many times a soldier had been under fire, each time he took to the field his chances of being killed were the same. He was saddened by the death of Colonel O’Bryen, a career officer with a record of distinguished service who had been destined for further promotion. But his career was cut short when he met, as Churchill remarked, ‘as fine an end as a soldier can desire’ fighting the Mohmands.” When the author sticks to the exploits of young Churchill the book moves right along. Unfortunately, depending of course on your viewpoint, the end of the book compares Churchill’s experience fighting in the Afghan campaign in the 1890’s with today’s American Military Campaign in Afghanistan. Most of the fighting took place in the same locations and involves descendents of the same fierce tribesmen Churchill fought as a young man in his first military adventure. That’s not the reason most people will read this book about what made Winston Churchill the great leader he was.

This 388-page history of F. Scott Fitzgerald and his classic novel is well written, full of interesting historical trivia and exhaustive. At first it was a page-turner but eventually it reached a point that for this reader there was more information than I really wished to know about the two subjects."'Careless People' is an histoire trouve about what was in the air as Fitzgerald wrote 'The Great Gatsby,' including the unfolding of a remarkable le tale of murder, adultery, class resentment, mistaken identity, and the invention of romantic pasts. In telling the story of the autumn of 1922, 'Careless People' also tells the story of an extended party, what Fitzgerald called their `Bacchic diversions, mild or fantastic.'"  "Jazz age parties reached their literary apotheosis with the publication of "The Great Gatsby," which predicted the party would come crashing to an end." The book, like "The Great Gatsby" is laid out in nine chapters so it is easier for the reader to associate the history and criticism with the novel. The writing and research that went into this book is impressive but for some reason the magic didn't last. It was like going into a world-class museum and after a short time the visitor is so saturated with great art that he is no longer able to fully appreciate the continuing experience.  It was interesting to learn that the book was not particularly well received at the time it was published. This is a terrific book for the hard-core F. Scott Fitzgerald fan even if they don't always agree with some of the book author's conclusions.

For serious readers of the Bible, this illustrated, and well-researched book should be added to their collection of concordances and other reference books to the Bible and Bible history. Because the National Geographic Society publishes it the reader is assured that every word in it has been checked and double-checked. The book includes "a continuous time line that places biblical events within a worldwide context." Maps of the Holy Land, biographies of 200 main characters of the Old and New Testament, illustrations of thousands of other people mentioned in the Bible are all included. National Geographic includes some of it's own illustrations of important Biblical events. Contemporary color photographs of how several of the cities and important locations mentioned in the historical text are also reproduced and it many cases show that the historical locations actually existed. The reference material, maps, color photographs and other material included in this high quality product are made available at a bargain price for interested readers. This is an excellent reference book for Sunday Schools as well. While not exactly a page-turner, this book provides current updates on what is known about the Bible and the people mentioned within its pages.

The first chapter of this excellent book that I read was  "Leonard Nimoy: The Interview." I didn't know that the legendary "Mr. Spock" had been an amateur photographer since he was a teenager  living in the West End of Boston. Like many beginning photographers he turned his family's bathroom into his part-time darkroom. Mr. NImoy takes a very intellectual approach to his fine art photography and the themes of his work. Readers of this volume will probably reach the same conclusion I did. This chapter alone is worth the modest cost of the book. But the book contains so, so much more valuable information. "A couple explained that they had never considered themselves collectors until they had run out of wall spaces and continued buying photographs." How many of us have made that discovery in the same manner? Anyone who has discovered he or she is a born collector will find valuable advice in this gold mine of practical information. "For those of you who are that hungry to be fine art photographers, you should know that as a gallery owner: "I'm looking for the ones who are in it to win it. "I want to surround myself with like-minded people. " I expect to see you at the portfolio review events. " I expect to see your marketing materials in my mailbox." The author of this entertaining and informative book has been a photographer, worked in the corporate world for years and owned a gallery for many years as well. This book is a curious, but fascinating mixture of common sense essays and interviews based on experience. "How will you connect yourself to the right people in the world--the ones that will help you in your career?" "Photography + Business + Peers + Mentors + Networking--it all plays a part in how and why I wanted to open and operate a fine art photography gallery and write this book. I want to be able to help artists and photographers gain the exposure that they deserve. It's a great feeling to live vicariously through their successes. I guess you can think of me as a glorified P.R. Agent." This book is a collection of examples of how some fine arts photographers made it and how many other talented wannabe fine arts photographers need to start building a network that will allow them to succeed with their desires, at least if they want to ever sell any of their work and receive some much deserved recognition. As a professional photojournalist for a brief time, an avid amateur photographer for almost 50 years who has also worked as a documentary film maker and even a movie critic, I found myself definitely lacking in the skills taught in this guide book. It's too bad Jason didn't publish this book decades ago when this reviewer was much younger. Like most artists, I preferred to concentrate all my efforts on making photographs, creating photographic books and films. I was pretty good at all those things and lousy at promoting and marketing.Like most readers of this book, I quickly learned how pitiful my efforts at networking have really been. There is much to be learned from this tome. In almost 50 short chapters Jason Landry shares some of his insights into the world of fine art photography and life in general. This reviewer lives in the same Back Bay Boston neighborhood and when Landry chooses to share some of the observations he has noted about his neighborhood, they are right on the mark and the truth of them becomes so obvious. If those observations are so accurate, it's a good bet that his other observations about collecting and selling fine arts photographs are also dead on.

After reading a terrific, illustrated two-page review of this book in the May 12, 2013 Sunday NYPOST I ordered a copy for myself. I started reading it the day it arrived. After finishing the first chapter I thought maybe I'd received the wrong book. I double-checked the review and confirmed that I indeed had received the same book I'd ordered.I read a little more and put the tome aside for a month to see if maybe I was just in a bad mood for reading this particular title. When I returned to it I read a couple of chapters in the middle of the book to see if it got more interesting. Frustrated, I put it aside for another month or so and once again returned to reading it.Nothing had changed and I began speed reading the rest of it before the book dissolved in my hands as it suffered from a strange case of boredom fever.Normally, I wouldn't even bother reviewing a book I disliked this much, but in this case I want to warn other readers that this may be the most boring book ever published on such a universally interesting topic. Maybe it was the illustrations in the NYPOST review that misled this reader?

This terrific telling of the true history of the Pilgrims is excellent, but for some reason it was a bit disappointing. As I was reading I had to constantly try and put myself in the mindset of a 10-year old child or young adult because there were things I was reading that struck me as holes in the story approach.The first problem was that the book reminded me too much of an advertisement for Rush Limbaugh's Tea Company. He really didn't over-do the commercialization, but it still hung over the entire narrative. However the Tea Company character of Rush Revere was probably the idea that started the whole book project as a narrative vehicle.Another of the little problems that may have only bothered me was that there was actual interaction between Rush Revere and his two student time travelers and the Pilgrims. Rather than actually communicating with them it seemed like the time travelers could have simply observed all the action from inside an invisible bubble where they could see and hear everything, but none of the Pilgrims would be aware of their presence. For instance, how does a flying horse with three riders land and take off from the May Flower several times without being observed by somebody on the small sailing ship? Also, after making friends with several of the Pilgrim leaders and ship's captain, how is it that those folks don't notice their absence during most of the trip and wonder if they fell overboard and go looking for them just to be sure? After three months on the storm-tossed May Flower, most of the crew and passengers must have smelled like a sewer, but Rush Revere and his companions arrive smelling fresh and wearing clean clothes? Rush Revere talks about not doing anything to change the future while visiting the Pilgrims but many of his young readers will realize just interacting with the Pilgrims in anyway would probably effect the future. Since this book will probably be followed by other time-travel visits to America's past, Rush might do well to consider the above-mentioned problems.The book does a wonderful job of telling the historical truth about the Pilgrims and their experiences and is based on diaries and journals of various Pilgrims. It has first-hand documentation of the events that differ greatly from what is taught in the schoolroom. But if these puzzling time travel paradoxes that seemed so obvious to this reader also distract the intended readers, then many of the important lessons of the narrative may be lost to them. Adults will also enjoy this book because what really occurred with the Pilgrims will be totally new and different from what 99% of Americans have been taught. Despite the minor problems mentioned this is a very important book. His correction of the current revised history taught in schools will probably be the first time the general public has learned these facts. Everyone who reads the book will have a much better idea of why the Pilgrims sailed to the Americas, the hardships they endured on the voyage and after their arrival in Massachusetts. The will learn about  the various political and economic systems that were developed and tested in order to assure the colonies survival in a harsh, unforgiving new world. The readers will know how the Pilgrims dressed, what weapons they used, how they trusted God for their very lives and their relations with the Native Americans. Although this reader read the hardback edition of the book, it's easy to see how the audio edition might be more interesting to younger readers. A good narrator like Rush Limbaugh could easily make the text come alive with different voices and pacing and maybe even use some minor sound effects to help make the story real. I don't know if the audio edition contains sound effects since I've not listened to it. This is an important step in telling the truth about American History and Capitalism. Reading the book reminded me of the old Walter Cronkite "You Are There" CBS television series that brought the audience to re-enactments of historical events. This book makes the reader feel that they too are there watching history in the making.

As a general rule I don't read the novel a movie is based on if I've seen the motion picture first.  In this case I made an exception because I was in need of something to read while riding an exercise bicycle to nowhere at the gym. The experience reminded me of why I don't see the movie before reading the book. It's almost impossible to get the image of the actor playing the individual parts out of the mind so that the reader can develop his own imagined image of the character. Since there are 500 reader reviews ahead of this one, about all I'll add to that vast selection is that the book is excellent. For readers like me who live in Boston and Cambridge it was an accurate description of the locale. For readers who have spent much time at gambling casinos and boats, it also had a feeling of realism. It's fun reading about the system of counting cards described in the book. It's fun seeing how the casinos treat the VIP Whales since most of us will never experience those wicked pleasures on such a grand scale. But no matter how many books are written about the casino gambling business and the people who inhabit it, it still puzzles me how folks can walk into one of those multistory, gleaming Oz-like Towers and think that they can actually beat the house. Common sense and plain eyesight says the house wins because that's what pays for building the house in the first place. The charm of this story is seeing how a bunch of geeky MIT students are able to beat the house at it's own game for at least a little while. This is an excellent escape to that Oz-like world of Casinos and the little guy against the system.

This is the second fine arts photograph by this photographer that I've purchased through Amazon's new Collectables and Fine Art Division. I bought this one because I was so enjoying the earlier one since I had it framed and hung on my office wall. While I'm not certain, I believe the models in both of my purchases are the same woman. There is a poised magic about her and the way the photographer has posed her within the individual environment of the overall scene. The photographer seems to be using the light and backgrounds for this and the earlier image in the manner of Paul Strand and/or Edward Weston. There is still some magic that comes from beautiful black and white photographs that is missing from most color work. My compliments to the skilled photographer and his selection of the right model for his pictures. Both the final product and model are superb.Readers of this review might also enjoy my earlier Amazon review of "Nude Standing In Rock Formation" by the same photographer.

I was totally unfamiliar with the work of this artist who seems to divide his time between woodcuts, graphics and photography. This particular mountain photo seemed to reach out and grab my full attention. It also seemed to tower over most of the other work by the same artist offered on the site, but that is probably just a matter of personal taste? I'm putting this beautiful scene between two of my classic mountain photos by Brad Washburn.One thing that has caused me to wonder about this work is how is the artist making any money from these limited editions. It would seem that by the time Amazon's sales commission and the commission charged bythe gallery Zatista Fine & Contemporary are deducted from the sales price the photographer/artist will be making a pittance. This photograph has an edition of 96, so I supposed that they may change the size of the print and make another edition. It's puzzling. Maybe Amazon doesn't take 55% of the commission on it's art like it does on its book sales?Whatever the business details, this is a beautiful image at a very modest sales price. It may be one of those cases where it costs more to custom frame it than it does for the art itself?

This is a book that I've had around the house for years and every time I come across it I can't resist delving into the mysteries it explains. The paperback copy I have was published in 1987. The fact it is still being published says much about its content. It's simply a fun, fun read. Learning the history behind common, everyday beliefs, activities and language is both entertaining and satisfying. It' also nice to be able to jump into the text anywhere. There is no need to start at the volume's beginning. The segments are relatively short and many are illustrated. It reminds this reader of Joe Friday's old saying, "Just the facts, nothing but the facts." The author is almost as interesting as the material in the book and the reader will find reading about him truly amusing.

For all those political junkies who follow Michael Barone's election analysis this book answers the question of how does he know so much about every voting district in the United States. He has been compiling 22 editions of "The Almanac of American Politics" since 1971. During that period he has answered the questions of why certain voting patterns occur in particular locales. Surprisingly, much of it has to do with the way various sections of the United States were originally settled by immigrants. In a fascinating Preface and six chapters Mr. Barone shares some of his observations about how immigration has shaped the nation. The six chapters are titled: "The Fighting Scots-Irish, Yankees and Grandees, The Irish and Germans, Incomplete Conquest, Promised Lands" and "Migrations of Choice" plus detailed notes, acknowledgements and an excellent index. What may surprise the readers is that the way early pioneers settled across the country was mostly governed by government politics and taxes. Even in the earliest days of the creation of what is now the USA, government regulations created by the earlier colonies caused certain immigrant groups to move in distinct directions in order to avoid the taxes and rules of those original thirteen colonies. The author is at this best in this book when he uses his detailed information on each and every geographical area to make his overall observations about how early immigration still influences the various geographic areas of America today. Not surprisingly, the reasons for immigration today is much the same as it was historically. In addition to the major immigrations by foreigners, the author makes some wonderful points of current immigrations patterns that most people don't think of as immigrations. Fleeing the poverty, crime and taxes of the cities beginning in the 1950s is one example. An earlier example was when the industrial revolution caused people to move from rural areas into the cities. Even air conditioning caused major population moves from the north to the south. While it's sometimes easy to get bogged down in the details and charts illustrating these immigrations patterns, the book is still well worth taking a look at. It's amazing that one of the chief motivations for moving to a different section of the USA is economic. People still follow the jobs. Both the employers and workers seek out the lowest cost of living and individual taxes that they can find. This is a very revealing book about the habits of the voters and why it has occurred like it has.

It only takes an hour to read all the text in this volume and to read the poetry that helps explain how Frida may have felt when she painted the works included in the volume. None of the artwork is unknown to anyone who is familiar with the work of Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo y Calderon who chose to call herself "Frida, German for `peace.'" Sometimes she hated it when the last name of her two-time (pun intended) husband Diego Rivera was added to make her Frida Rivera. Why she disliked that is explained in one of the author's poems. One of the statements included from Frida's letters and diary gives her opinion of the United States. "The most important thing for everyone in Gringolandia is to have ambition and becomes `somebody,' and frankly, I don't have the least ambition to become anybody." This is a very readable introduction to Frida and her work for students and young adults. The poems hit some of the main themes of her life without going into detail. For instance, she carried on "a brief affair with the exiled Soviet revolutionary, Leon Trotsky, whom Diego had brought to Mexico." Frida was lucky that she too didn't die from a hatchet to the brain, as did Trotsky when he was tracked down and assassinated. It's definitely  a worthwhile addition to any school reading list.

I almost didn't read this biography/memoir of "Silver City Millie" because the historic photos illustrating it were so blah. Finally, just before donating it to the Boston Public Library I read a few pages and was enthralled enough to save it long enough for me to read.  It was really well written. The pictures illustrating it were mostly taken decades after the reason for capturing them on film had passed. The photographs proved something else as well. The actual historical characters seldom look like the stereotypical Hollywood image of them. This is definitely true about this character because if you saw her in real life she was not very pretty, even considering the always changing standards of beauty. She had a grandmother's face even at age three according to the picture of her included in the book. However, she must have had a personality that really wowed every man she met. "Her mirth was an infectious as a happy plague." She was interesting enough as a businesswoman that she had many lifelong male friends who visited her simply to talk and socialize and plan political and business deals. Everyone fell under her spell."Millie's laugh was a softly rolling symphony, almost demanding in its resonant beauty to be mirthfully joined. People simply enjoyed looking into her enigmatic eyes and hearing the laughter that gave such a pleasing promise of joy." "It was difficult for many of the citizens of New Mexico and beyond to believe that Millie had scores of men who were just plain good friends. There were those who came to Millie's house just to visit and share confidences without any idea of going to bed with her or any of the other girls. Millie was puzzled all her life at society's failure to understand that the opposite sexes can have attractions for one another that have nothing to do with sexuality. She feels strongly that this is one of the major, but unacknowledged causes of worldwide conflict, not to mention the petty personal problems of everyday existence." Orphaned at a young age by the swine flu she and her three years older sister Florence were adopted.  But the stepparent's older son had stolen 13-year-old Millie's skates and she eventually got even and "whupped him, your honor, for stealin' my skate" As she told the juvenile judge in Kansas City. The judge was named Harry S. Truman and yes, it was the same one who would become President. "Judge Harry Truman" turned Millie over to the custody of the Papadakis, thereby helping add someone else to the list of people would become legends in their own time." Millie when she was just under 12 years old, she and a school chum started running errands on her way home from school  for the large number of women leaning out the windows and doors of the Twelfth Street Red Light District of Kansas City. Soon, the kids "were running errands of one sort or another, for practically every whore in the Kansas City red-light district." That was her first experience with ladies of the night. It certainly wouldn't be the last. "Eventually, she owned seven bordellos in three states and thirty-six big Chryslers (Most of those new Chryslers were gifts from her men friends) In 1945 she bought a bordello in Laramie, Wyoming." Millie lived to age 87 and died just before Christmas of 1993. Most of her whorehouses had been closed by 1968. During her long life of  excessive drinking and endless sex she met and befriended many of the most powerful men in the Southwest Dessert section of the United States. She was friends with cattle barons, oil, silver and copper barons, railroad owners and railroad workers, college students, movie stars and politicians from police officials to governors and first ladies of the US and thousands of other less famous admirers. She was very well connected. She was an important and much sought after character in the history of her time. She was a hard worker and excellent businesswoman. She owned cafes, beauty salons, bars, gambling joints, parking lots that she rented by the hour to taxi companies. She owned rental properties and jukeboxes where she raised the price of a song from a nickel to fifty cents. She was an unofficial liquor distributor. She even helped smuggle guns to the Mexican Rebels although she wasn't paid for that volunteer work to help one of her favorite male lovers who was a Mexican Air Force officer. That little adventure almost landed her in jail but her instincts and luck saved her from the wrath of the Treasury Agents. This is a page-turner that is difficult to put aside. Even the photographs are interesting both because most weren't taken at the actual time of their subject's notoriety, but after the famous bordellos had practically collapsed back into the dessert landscape. The women, for the most part, were not what would be considered pretty by today's standards, but in the boom town pioneer days, the isolation and heavy drinking probably made all the working girls of Millie's Brothels look like angels to their lonely, love starved, overworked clients.  Not only do the characters in this biography not look like Hollywood versions of themselves, but also they don't act like the Hollywood stories either. They are much more interesting and much more plain spoken. This is a fun read.

This is the first purchase I've made from the Amazon Collectibles & Fine Art Site. I felt the price of the limited edition photographs was very reasonable for many of the fine art photographs. It's obvious to me that I will be making many additional purchases of art on this Amazon site. The site makes it makes it much, much easier to locate little known works by both famous and lesser known photographers and artists.

Most people imagine empty mansions as abandoned, decaying, cobweb-filled derelict structures. This story is about vast private estates maintained for absent owners for decades by loyal property managers, gardeners, maids, butlers and other household staff, most of who had never seen or met their employers. The fabulous city apartments and palatial estates overlooking the Pacific, in NYC and in the N.E. Countryside  were always ready for a visit by their owners and everything was kept ready for such an unexpected visit. Most of these mansions included "panic rooms" for hiding from "bad guys." The NYC W.A. Clark home on Fifth Avenue included a special suite in the tower that was designed to hide in case of an epidemic hit the city. It was a "quarantine and panic room (suite)" combined.The costs of maintaining these properties cost millions of dollar a year. Who could afford such costs?  Few people have heard of an American named William A. Clark, who rivaled John D. Rockefeller as the richest man in the world. Residents or visitors to Las Vegas might notice the county in which the city is located is called Clark County, but even then they probably have no idea which Clark the name referred to. If they guessed it would probably be the Clark from the Lewis and Clark Mapping Expedition. Among other ventures, using his own fortune, W.A. Clark had the foresight to build a railroad from Salt Lake City on the Inter-Continental Line to a sleepy port town called Las Angeles. Along the way he built a railroad maintenance stop that was to become Las Vegas and sold plots of the railroad right of way to prospective developers of that land. His nickname was "The Copper King." He was also an infamous U.S. Senator, the political story of which is one of the more  interesting parts of this book. This book is about his family and what became of his huge fortune. Frankly, this reviewer finds the most interesting parts of this rags-to-riches story to be about the founder and how he created the great family fortune. How the heirs ran through their inheritance is always of secondary interest to me. But in this case, the daughter, Huguette Clark, who lived to be 105 years of age was more interesting than the usual tales of heirs who simply squander their inheritances at near light-speed. In this case daughter of W. A. Clark, Huguette Clark wanted privacy more than anything else and she found it hiding in a hospital room for decades as the hospital and staff systematically extorted money from her. She was perfectly healthy most of the years she spent in the hospital, she just liked it there. Paintings were being stolen, but not reported to police because she didn't want any publicity. The Bank Trust Company where her jewelry was stored for safe keeping forgot to pay the paltry fees on the safe deposit box where the bank kept it and it was all eventually sold at auction for pennies. It's fascinating to see how those institutions and people who are supposed look out for a person's wealth and health so utterly failed. This is the story of a woman of wealth who used the money more or less to provide privacy for herself and to make occasional donations from the vast fortune she had inherited. Once the story switched completely from "The Copper King" to his "copper heiress" the book is much less interesting. It is fascinating, however, to observe how the subject of this book seemed to feel she would live forever and what she did about it. This is a page-turner for the most part, but it definitely goes down hill once the main character is able to buy her privacy. It's really three major stories tied together and they are not all equally interesting to every reader. And as of this reviews publication date, the final estate hasn't been settled. It appears that the IRS and state tax departments of CT, NY and CA, etc., along with legions of lawyers will get most of the remaining fortune.

"Too exciting to put aside" best describes this detective action novel. It caused this reviewer to seriously neglect some of his other activities. Since college I've mostly read biographies and other non-fiction books for information. This book was a rare exception in that it was read entirely for entertainment and escapism. It may mark the beginning of a new interest in reading and reviewing fiction? Admittedly, this reviewer also loves everything Japanese so that fact may have colored the enjoyment that came from devouring this particular thriller. Half of it takes place in Japan and half in the USA. The book has lots of interesting characters and provides some real insights into Japanese business, politics, history and art. The general public's picture of the highly efficient government workings of Japan that is almost universally accepted as fact isn't as perfect as promoted. The exposes included in this novel will cause some Japanese to either cringe or silently nod in agreement. This is a 400-page page-turner with lots of cliffhangers. The book moves quickly because most chapters run from two to six pages. As the reader finishes one chapter he is drawn into the next because it's so short that it won't take long to read it. This could easily become the first of a series. It would also make a good movie because it appeals to both the Japanese and American audiences. In a film, there will be lots of opportunities for a large supporting cast to make their mark. This is the most exciting first novel that this reader has read in years. It very much reminds me of Michael Crichton's "Rising Sun, which was both an excellent book and terrific movie.

As one of the characters in "Late Early Man" says, "I'm more Drama than Documentary." As a reviewer I seldom read fiction and almost never read collections of short stories and that puts me squarely in the Documentary, nonfiction, non-drama part of the quote, so these tales by Ralph Lombreglia were a pleasant surprise for me. As an ex-documentary filmmaker from Boston I particularly enjoyed the "Late Early Man" because of the subject and the Boston locale that is so perfectly captured. The author has a unique way of summarizing feelings and events and seeing both the truth and humor in them.  After reading these stories the reader will never again forget the adventures in birthing that came while filming the "Great Power Sander Races." All of these stories had previously been published in magazines such as "The New Yorker" and "The Atlantic" which pretty much guarantees that the author had something useful to say in a highly professional and entertaining manner. This collection is nine fun reads. And the reader may see themselves as well as their friends, family and co-workers in some of the story portraits.

"Today's journalists make a mockery of the word. They are nave, even sometimes downright stupid. They are undisciplined, not just in the preparation but in the delivery of news. They cannot, or just will not distinguish between news and information. They are pawns for misinformation and practiced in disinformation. They are loud, condescending, arrogant, dishonest, foolish, incompetent, mean-spirited--and dangerous." "On Election Night, at our behest, the McLaughlin Associates polling firm asked some questions along these lines in their omnibus survey. "The first question we wanted answered was the degree to which the public believed the news media had helped to reelect Barack Obama versus those who believed they were helping elect Mitt Romney. Take out those who believed the press was neutral, or who had no opinion and you're left with Obama 84.8 percent, Romney 15.2 percent." This poll was taken when it was assumed that Romney would win the election. As I write this review there are 6 other supposed reviews of the book that consider the book absolute lies and fantasies? It's difficult to believe these people actually read the book because it's obviously so well researched and the conclusions are footnoted. Even if one doesn't agree with every conclusion in the book it's totally ridiculous to deny the obvious truths contained in it. In an introduction and 12 chapters plus an epilogue and detailed notes and an index. The general public knows that the so-called "mainstream media" is heavily biased to the liberal left. That's probably why the number of people who follow the mainstream media has been dropping like a piece of burning hot volcanic lava for the past 30 years. Even the media admits that they overwhelming vote (almost 9 to 1) for Democrats over Republicans. This is a good book to give a friend that doesn't really know that he or she is actually relatively conservative but automatically votes for the party that the media has been claiming represents the little guys over the rich. If the public schools provided even a little bit of economic education along with "individual thinking and questioning classes," voters might actually believe what their lying eyes are showing them over some of the nonsense the liberal media constantly pushes as fact. This book is definitely a page-turner and gushes with common sense. And the title of this review comes from a warning from the authors not to attempt to control the news media through the government. "It's a free country--at least, for now, mostly--and the national news media have the freedom to present Obama as the finest naked emperor that's ever lived. We must also salute that freedom, and defend it always." Then the author makes some suggestions for showing the media's untruthfulness in a manner that will actually reach people who don't even bother with following the news.

This title reminds me of "Dow 36,000" by James Glassman and Kevin Hassett that I read back in 1999 and we all know what happened not long after the book was published. In the case of "$10,000 Gold" and "Dow 36,000" the question the reader has to ask themselves is, "Sure, both events will happen someday, but when and will the dollar be worth anything at that time?" This is an excellent book for explaining the role gold has always played in history. It is also an excellent guide to investing in gold's various forms including jewelry (based on weight of gold, not artistic design), coins, ingots, bars, mining stocks, mutual funds, etc. Maybe the best point made by this tome is that owning gold is like insurance. It's a way of protecting wealth rather than making a quick buck buying and selling it although lots of speculators, hedge funds and option players do that as well.  It's a wealth protection for when money and other assets depreciate. This reviewer disagrees with the authors main point that uncompromised bullion is the best way to own gold. Bullion bars need to be assayed when sold to guarantee the gold is the quality stated because it's very easy to fake paperwork and serial numbers.  With numbered bars there has already been some reported problems by the pros. Recently several gold bars purchased by a big-time jewelry maker, turned out to be gold-plated tungsten bars. Scarier, there is still a rumor circulating that many of the gold bars held by the Federal Reserve Bank in NYC as well as some of the holdings at Fort Knox are gold plated Tungsten bars. This rumor has been hushed up to prevent a worldwide panic. The advantage with holding bullion gold coins is that like the silver dollars of the Wild West they can be cut into smaller sections. When silver dollars were cut into quarters the resulting piece was known as 25 bits or 25 cents. Even in the Wild West some of the gold coins were not actually what the mint claimed. Mormon Gold Coins were often only 90% of the claimed value. Now of course, those same coins are extremely valuable to coin collectors. But that wasn't so back when they were a regular form of payment. This is an excellent, generously illustrated with helpful charts and graphs, 298-page introduction to the history of gold and how to collect gold for the reader's personal portfolio.  It's definitely a page-turner.

This is indeed a wonderful, insightful, politically incorrect and fascinating peek into the mind of one of America's greatest Film Makers. Orson Wells was not just a child prodigy, he remained a genius throughout his life and continued to try and fulfill his dreams in film production. Unfortunately, his films cost a lot of money and he eventually reached a point that nobody would risk their hard-earned cash on one of his projects. He had a nasty reputation for not finishing the films he started before going off to another project. He knew his problem and even candidly commented that the studios would not back his projects because he'd never made them any money. Wells was lucky in that his two biggest successes--the radio broadcast of "War of the Worlds" and "Citizen Kane" occurred early in his career. They made him famous and because of that he was able to mix with the notables of the world as an equal. He knew everyone. In 27 chapters Orson Wells talks about the many people he has known. While there is lot of extraneous information about his other interests, opinions and politics, this book is largely about filmmaking and the film industry. From that stand point it was just a tad disappointing. Some times the general public forgets just how incestuous and petty show business can be. No matter how detailed Hollywood has been described by insiders, it is much worse--it really is a swamp of dangerous vipers. For folks who lived in Las Angeles in the 1970's and 1980's, Orson's unofficial office at a private table inside Ma Maison from the time it opened in 1973 until it shut down shortly after Wells died was well known. There were rumors that if he wasn't busy, outsiders could actually stop by and visit with him for the cost of a bottle of champagne, which they then shared. From reading this book, that rumor was probably false. Wells detested anyone, even acquaintances, who sat down at his table without being invited. My wife and I lived in Beverly Hills for a couple of years during that time period. We often talked about whether we should act like the out-of-towners we considered our selves and see if we could go by Ma Maison and meet the great Citizen Kane. We never followed through on that tourist tendency because we had three small kids; Ma Maison was very expensive and because we felt we really didn't have anything to say that would interest the great Orson Wells. We probably made the correct choice, but we will never know for certain. Who knows? We might have caught him at just the right moment? Also I happen to have a truly beautiful wife and perhaps her red hair would have reminded Orson of one of his ex-wives, actress Rita Hayworth? Wells and his movie-making friend Henry Jaglom shared enough experiences and goals that Wells could relax with him over long lunches even though he knew Jaglom was recording everything said during their meals together. Wells no doubt loved having that historic record made of his casual conversations. And being Orson Wells, he probably never really let down his guard for a moment. What he wanted history to know he would say in an entertaining way. His secrets would remain his secrets. But he was the great Orson Wells, and he made certain what he was saying was entertaining and never, never boring. This is a very good read. It flows along like the lyrics of the Stephen Foster song about the Swanee River. One can almost still hear the wonderful, deep voice of Orson Wells as he "just keeps rolling along."

It's difficult to imagine fighting hand-to-hand combat against Troy, Sparta, Babylonia, the Egyptians, or any other ancient nation state clad in armor made from Linen. But apparently the legendary warriors of ancient times conquered the known world and then ruled those lands for nearly a thousand years while wearing this homemade body armor. That is the obvious conclusion of this book. This cloth fabric body armor is called linothorax (also Type IV Armor) and this study of that ancient armor and it's use is called "'The Linothorax Project' and was an exercise in reconstructive archaeology that has attempted to illuminate some of the mystery surrounding this type of armor. This project, which began at the University of Wisconsin--Green By in 2005 had four main goals" all of which were answered by this scientific study. The main problem with the study of Linothorax armor in ancient times is that none of has survived although it possible that some will eventually be found in a glacier or tomb where it has not disintegrated? There are however, 913 images of this Type IV linothorax armor and the authors have comprised a database of all these images that date from the periods in question. The images include paintings from Pompeii, paintings on ancient pottery, base relief's, and freezes. The book's cover is a detail of Alexander the Great from the "Alexander Mosaic" from the House of the Faun, Pompeii and is thought to be a copy of a Hellenistic Greek painting. Working from the nearly a thousand images of warriors wearing Linothrox armor the authors recreated some of that armor using only the materials and tools available at the period when it was worn. They then took the materials and tested them in a variety of ways to see how many layers were needed to stop an arrow of the period from penetrating the linen armor. They also made armor using the various designs suggested by the contemporary illustrations of that armor. Among the conclusions the study reached were that linen armor was not only effective against the weapons of the era, but that the linen armor had lots of advantages over the heavier metal armor that came later in history. For one thing the armor was light and enabled the troops wearing it to travel farther and quicker. It was more flexible. It was very inexpensive to manufacture and easy to repair. It didn't rust. It didn't cook the soldier wearing it in the hot sun. It was actually superior to heavy, inflexible armor. The study didn't answer all the questions about linothorax armor; such as why in so many of the surviving images and illustrations of warriors wearing the armor was it so short. In many cases, it appears the armor didn't completely cover the genitals of the wearer. The most logical conclusion the authors came up with was that it was better that way for riding horses where the soldier wasn't so exposed to attack at the vital location.The book authors didn't explore the possibility that in ancient warfare that it wasn't considered fair to strike below the belt. They were wise to avoid any attempt at serious discussion of that theory. This is a very readable and short book for an academic study. It will make the reader keep an eye out for any archeology reports about an actual sample of the linen armor somehow being discovered in a sealed tomb or in of a "freak of nature" preserved environment like that of the Ice Man Discovered in an Alps glacier many years ago.

This biography depressed me. As one of the 90 million fans of Capp's satirical comic strips, it's sometimes depressing to find out about the real personality of a popular celebrity. That's one of the problems with biographies; the subjects usually die at the end of the book. Al Capp was an incredible success story of a boy who lost his leg trying to catch free rides on street cars, who grew up to become one of the most famous cartoonists of all time. Only Walt Disney and Robert Ripley had such shooting star careers to the top of their cartoon art fields. When Al Capp was at the height of his success he was a popular guest on television talk shows, had his own television show, and his face grace the covers of most major magazines including Time, Life, Newsweek and TV Guide to name just a few. He was making more than $500,000 per year. His Li'l Abner and Daisy Mae cartoons were eagerly followed by most of America's population. And Capp used that soapbox to satirize "the affectations and hypocrisy of the powerful." As the reader will learn by reading this biography, Capp was not the naive and loving Hill Billy of his fantasy world. He had a thing for beautiful young women but didn't like to take "no" for an answer in anything he did. Like many other rich and powerful celebrities, his fame protected him from his "out of control" sexual appetites. His predatory sexual habits finally caught up with him and ruined his popularity with the public. He simply couldn't keep his hands off young college coeds or aspiring actresses such as Goldie Hawn. Capp had a huge ego, but believed completely in the "casting couch." He was not the patient type and he preferred making his conquests by deceit instead of limiting himself to his many willing and available groupies. This true story is very readable and the audience will be familiar with much of the material, but it's still a bit of a downer for all of us who spent their youth and even young adulthood anxiously awaiting the next humorous and harmless adventure in Dog Patch. Hopefully his creations will outlive Capps own true story or at least the more depressing aspects of his fall from grace.Al Capp fans might be interested to know that there is a 1991, 127-page autobiography of All Capp with an introduction by John Updike that is a collection of Capps writings about himself and his creations. Some of it is really great and the book is titled "My Well Balanced Life on a Wooden Leg-Al Capp" and it's available on Amazon.

It's easy to see why this author has such a popular blog. What she says rings true to both men and women. Since I'm a male, I suspect her truths may seem much more on the mark for female readers. This may be the first economics, self-help book that is a true page-turner. The author's 258 pages of economic theory are separated into nine chapters and a brief summary of her final thoughts and her "final, final words" are a blast to read. The chapters have titles like "Love the One You're With, Hooking up in College, Love in Cyberspace, You Complete Me, Marriage is a Fine Institution, Bringing Home the Bacon, The Next Generation Comes of Age, Naughty by Nature" and "Love in the Sunset (Years)." This author has some really intriguing economic theories about how technology is changing the marriage market to such an extent that the educated are creating high-income couples to the extent that it is widening the poverty gap in every country. It used to be that highly educated and highly paid people were so busy it was difficult for them to find each other. Many marriages happened between one highly paid or rich individual and a much poorer, less educated mate. And in the case of the less educated and motivated classes, two poor people would produce more future poor and often no marriage at all. While the Internet is making it possible for high income and highly educated individuals to locate superior mates, the changes that contraception has brought to sexual relationships has also effected the economics of marriage and family. The highly educated and motivated don't have to give up sex while they pursue their ideal mate. They have time to keep looking and experimenting. Another change the author discusses in detail is that women now out number men at all levels of college and higher education. They are rapidly moving into the ranks of the highest paid and best-educated workers. This influx of females into the highest professional ranks has already changed the nature of society. It has made women totally independent and that's something new in the world. "But while educated women are becoming liberated to marry whomever they please, those same forces will essentially disenfranchise less-educated women from the marriage market and potentially, push more children into poverty." The author speculates "male income inequality encourages polygamy while female educational inequality encourages monogamy, so this suggestion that polygamy is the solution to growing female education inequality is counterintuitive. But the claim that female inequality encourages monogamy depends on the assumption that educated women are a relatively scare resource, which is no longer true. That suggests that, over time, having multiple educated wives will become `affordable' by wealthy men." She doesn't say so, but following her own "supply and demand" logic, many wealthy women may also decide to have more than one husband. The book is written with lots of study results, but also with lots of humor and sex is the subject being discussed in economic terms. For a happy ending the book discusses "the Big Mac Index that is produced annually by the `The Economist' magazine. The point of the index is to make exchange rate theory more palatable to readers by giving a real-world example of how well `purchasing power parity'--the theory that exchanged rates adjust to make the level of goods and services that can be purchased with a unit of currency equal between countries--holds around the world. `The Economist" does this by comparing the price of a uniform, tradable good--a Big Mac--in about 120 different countries. The idea is that by converting the foreign price of a Big Mac into U.S. dollars, we should be able to determine if a country's currency is either over-or undervalued relative to the U.S. dollar." "Okay, so here is the big idea: the BJ Index." That index is exactly what it says and the reader will be laughing as they follow the discussion of this new economic index to Dollars and Sex. This is a good read.

Not only is this Secret Bank exempt from the taxes and oversight of any nation in the world, but also has been that way since it was founded in 1930. This is the inside story of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) which is based in Basel Switzerland but does not answer to Swiss authorities or anyone else. It is the world's Central Bankers own bank. Learning about this super secret Super Bank will add much credence to the conspiracy theory of the bankers trying to create a New World Order. It's like a shadow world government that is so powerful and useful that no nation in the world is willing to try and control or shine the spot light into its dark recesses. The world's most exclusive and powerful club has only eighteen members most of whom are men. The power and influence they exercise is almost unbelievable. It is said the Nazi's didn't invade Switzerland because they didn't want to cut off their access to this institution, which is where they shipped much of the wealth they striped from the nations they invaded. The book contains an introduction and sixteen information packed chapters contained in three major sections. Those chapters are titled "The Bankers Know Best, A Cozy Club in Basel, Hitler's American Banker, An Arrangement with the Enemy, The German Phoenix Arises, The Rise of the Desk-Murders, The Tower Arises, The Second Tower, The All-Seeing Eye, (despite the familiar sounding names this is not "Lord of the Rings") and the Citadel Cracks." "The Tower of Basel reaches only eighteen stories above the city skyline, but the fate of the biblical tower-builders should give the bankers pause. For When God saw their work, he confounded their speech and introduced a multitude of tongues. The builders could no longer understand one another. The construction work stopped, they were dispersed and their town vanished into history." The bank is fighting for its survival by trying to evolve into a socially responsible institution. "Secrecy, opacity, and unaccountability--like gold--are embedded in the bank' DNA. The bank may find it can't continue as it has since its birth. This in a wonderful investigative report on one of the most secret and powerful institutions in world history. A reader doesn't have to like economics or banking to be mesmerized by this highly readable expose.

Although I seldom read and review fiction this story was surprisingly well written and also gave me nightmares. I couldn't believe it actually caused me to lose some much needed sleep.Obviously that's a sign of a powerful story well told.The story starts out relatively slowly and provides the reader with an education in the history of paper and ink making since the story's narrator is an expert in authenticating rare books and manuscripts. He has a gift for being able to know whether something is fake or real. That and other needed historical and geographical information is skillfully woven into the book's over-all plot. The information about Serbian-American Inventor Nikola Tesla and his work with A/C electricity and George Westinghouse is particularly interesting. That material actually fits seamlessly into the story when it taking place in Eastern Europe and at the Tesla Museum in Belgrade, Serbia.The book's story line very much reminds the reader of the 1999 Roman Polanski motion picture "The Ninth Gate" and because of that the reader may find him or herself visualizing Johnny Depp as the main character. That's not really a problem since the physical description of the main character resembles Johnny Depp.It won't take the reader long to realize this isn't one of the popular Twilight Vampire movie series. There are no lovesick werewolves wailing at the moon over the loss of their Vampire girl friend.The book is definitely a page-turner once the reader gets into it. It can easily be read in a single day and night, but this reader preferred to take his time and savor some of the interesting language the author's uses. He has a knack for summing feelings up in a way most people have not heard before.At this relaxed pace it took this reviewer three days to read the 338-page tale. That was probably the reason for two nights of fleeting nightmares. As the author wrote in one of his many understatements, "There is something unsettling about meeting a creature not human."Once the entire book was finished, there were no more nightmares because the story had been completed.  Some of the descriptions of the birthday parties in this book will chill your blood.This novel is so well written the reader won't be able to get enough. Fortunately for them, the possibility of at least one or two sequels is highly likely.

This book will make most hardworking Americans mad as hell.  In 51 brief chapters, Wayne Allyn Root translates the writings on the wall and shows the reader exactly how Obama plans to turn the United States into a Third-World Socialist basket case. This is not new information; it's just that its various parts are becoming more transparent now that Obama has been re-elected. "This is the Obama plan. He has to demonize, punish, and bankrupt the middle class, upper middle class, and small businesses (`the rich'), all in pursuit of `fairness'--in reality, misery for everyone. And it's all happening right in front of our eyes." "Get ready to celebrate Obama's new national holiday: DEPENDENCE DAY." This book is divided into three major parts with lots of brief, but to the point chapters. The First Part, "Obamagedon: The Disaster We Are Facing" helps explain what is happening right now in sixteen chapters. Part II is titled "How to Survive, Thrive, and Prosper during the next four years of the Obama Disaster." The fourteen chapters comprising that section has chapter titles such as "Learning to Use Y-PODS: Your Personal Defense Shield", "Your Precious Metals Defense System," "Rare Coins," "Diversify and Invest Outside the U.S.A.," " Guns for Protection and Profit," "Escape from High-Tax States," Back to Commonsense Advice" and many others that deal with those subjects. Part III, "Business Superstars Offer Their Advice" consists of nineteen chapters written by successful businessmen. Some of them use their own names, many prefer to remain unidentified, but they all relate personal experiences such as how much money and resources can be saved by leaving the high-tax states and even moving out of the U.S.A. One expert and his family retired to Panama for several good reasons and while they were happy there, they eventually returned to Texas. For most readers the information on how to protect yourself and your family will be the most interesting. While some advice may seem wrong now, like investing 35% of your net worth in precious metals, the advice is actually very sound. The markets go up and down, but some things maintain their value no matter what happens. The over-all advice is to not have all your eggs in one basket and what kind of eggs to collect. The readers are certain to pick up some valuable and useful advice for this book.And the readers must consider that once the government caused disaster happens, that the same people will still be in charge of solving the mess they created. The government will always survive, but the citizens aren't as vital as far as the government is concerned. The people will be little more than serfs.

This book, which is actually two books combined, consists of a fictional biography (actually a fake biography about a fictional character-not a fictional biography of an actual person) and a second book is the fictional Surgeon's lost magnum opus: "The Codex Extinct Animalia" a "Gray's Anatomy" for mythological beasts such as dragons, mermaids, centaurs, Pegasus and Cerberus to name only a few. The second the book arrived from Amazon Vine and when the package was opened, the book reeked of Gothic texture. The very volume itself seemed to give off dark vapors and scents of Edgar Allen Poe and H. P. Lovecraft. Normally I only review non-fiction, but this pure fantasy slipped by me when I was making my two Amazon Vine selections. It's one of those books that if I had actually examined in a bookstore that I probably wouldn't have bought. It was interesting to thumb through, but otherwise it wasn't my cup of tea, or my poison. The book uses some of the same techniques of writing fiction that was done so well by Michael Crichton. His fictional locations were so believable that at the end of the book the locations always had to be destroyed by burying them under miles thick lava or some other technique that would make them impossible to locate and visit. In the fictional biography of this combined set, The life and Writings of Dr. Spenser Black is described in seven short chapters each one being another chapter in the Doctor's life: "1851-1868: Childhood," "1871-1877 Marriage and Transformation," etc. etc. The doctor was believed to be a grave robber like his own surgeon father. In 1877, "Black speculated that perhaps the human being is not the best result of evolution; perhaps our ancestors shared traits with some of the ancient animals or, more accurately, ancient mythological animals. Black claimed that scientific evidence proving the existence of ancient mythological animals had been concealed by unnamed parties; taxonomy records were destroyed, constellation records were changed, fairy tales were altered and rewritten, all in an attempt to ignore our true history." The doctor felt that the fact human beings might not be the highest species on the planet had been concealed from the public and was forced to exist only in mythology and fairy tales. "The Codex Extinct Animalia" is the collection of Dr. Black's anatomy studies of mythological animals. Only a single copy has survived and is the source of the meticulous anatomical drawings in the volume. The real author and artist of these two fantasy books is E.B. Hudspeth who lives in New Jersey and he may well be on his way to becoming a cult figure himself. He has a good imagination, a way with words as well as a talent with pen and ink and anatomy drawings.

Like most people who choose to read this biography by Zev Chafets, I'd heard lots of rumors about Roger Ailes over the years. He'd built Fox News Channel from scratch after getting a billion dollars in start up funds from Rupert Murdock. Prior to that he was rumored, credited with being the campaign manager for Richard Nixon's successful Presidential race, for coaching Presidents George H. W. Bush and later Ronald Reagan. The man had come from nowhere, Warren Ohio, to be exact, and found his interest in media while attending Ohio University in Athens Ohio at the college radio station WOUB. He served as the WOUB Radio student station manager before moving on to a television career beginning in Cleveland and later Philadelphia where he became Executive Producer for "The Mike Douglas Show." It was a locally produced show when he arrived, but he helped turn it into a nationally syndicated program. For those readers looking for some "fresh meat" information about Roger Ailes, they won't find much of it in this biography. Roger's primary career has always been as a media, especially television, consultant. Since he began his professional career he has usually worked from 9 a.m. to 11 p.m. seven days a week.  That's how most successful businessmen make their marks--long, long hours of working and keeping their eyes on their long-term goals. Zev Chafets does a very professional job with his Ailes biography, but even he mentions that while Ailes, his friends and his employees were always forthcoming with the answers to his questions in this short 16 chapter book, he felt that Ailes was holding back some of the material that would be more interesting for a future autobiography that he wanted to write. Ailes also seems to follow that mid-western folk advice that "if you can't say anything nice about somebody, don't say anything at all." He doesn't reject any of the comments he's made in the past about various candidates, but he doesn't make a big deal about it. To him, his comments were his professional opinions as a media consultant about what happened and not any kind of personal or vengeful attack. The book is probably as interesting as Ailes let it be. There is lots of trivia about the people who he has hired and less about the people who he has had to  fire. Usually the firings were because the personality involved simply broke the company's published rules about loyalty and working with the team. It was interesting that several of those people who moved on to other media outlets such as "Mad Money" stock guru Jim Cramer were happy to contribute almost gushing praise for their former boss when interviewed by Chafets. Without exception they all felt that they had learned a great deal from their dealings with Ailes whom they considered not only a true professional, but almost a father figure. This is a very readable book and it probably paints as much of a biographical portrait of a high-powered political consultant as was possible under the circumstances. There simply isn't much in the way of scandal included in it. After Ailes finished his work with Richard Nixon he didn't get along with the new President's Staff so he cut all his ties with the new administration. Even when he was occasionally called in for some relatively short consulting, he refused to accept any payment or even Per Diem expenses for his advice. When the Watergate Plumbers Scandal Broke, Ailes was in Africa making a conservation documentary with Bobby Kennedy Jr.Maybe Ailes was just lucky but he is a person who believes that people make their own luck. The book did include some of his interesting observations about Nixon's character and method of working that hasn't been made public in the past.

Robert L. Ripley left his California high school planning to be a semi-pro baseball player or maybe a cartoonist? Fortunately for the world's amusement, he became a cartoonist. But even after getting the break of a lifetime for a brand new sports cartoonist for the NY Globe, he almost ended up on the N.Y. Giants.  While covering the team in its Marlin Texas winter camp he was invited to work out with the team. The coach told another reporter that Ripley was the "the best curve-ball I've seen in a long, long time. " Fortunately, for the world, Ripley broke his arm in a 90-degree fracture while pitching. All that remains of his baseball career is a picture of him wearing a Giants Uniform and swinging a bat. Before long the rest of the press remembered him more as a poker player than a pitcher. The young cartoonist's big break had occurred in 1910 shortly after he'd started working at the San Francisco Chronicle. His editor picked him "to be the lead cartoonist to cover the upcoming fight between retired champion Jim Jeffries and Jack Johnson, the first black heavyweight champ. The fight was billed as "'The Great White Hope' versus `the Big Black Menace.'" The fight had grown into one of the biggest sporting events in United States history. The fight was moved to Reno and the press went to Nevada several days early to watch the fighters prepare. Ripley "met two of his Bulletin predecessors, Rube Goldberg and Tad Dorgan. Also sitting at the table was the famous and famously troubled `Call of the Wild' author Jack London." For that fight, Ripley became a colleague with America's most famous western writer. He was greatly influenced by his exchanges with Jack London. Ripley became so `overawed' by this famous company that he almost missed "The Battle of the Century" because of a nervous stomach. He did get to his ringside seat to witness and record Johnson as he slowly ripped Jeffries apart in the 45 ROUND battle for the World Championship. 45 ROUNDS was apparently the norm for that boxing match. And anyone who can even last for 45 rounds has to automatically qualify as a superman. "When the old champion went down and out, there was not one cheer for the winner " was the caption on his cartoon of Jeffries lying on his side as the crowd looked on. Ripley became a success because he worked hard and had an incurable curiosity about everything he saw. Soon, his work expanded from sports coverage to covering the world. What he saw and was curious about he shared with his newspaper and their syndication partners. This is another of those fascinating, true rags-to-riches stories that is difficult to put aside until the final chapter is reached. And as the reader of this biography will quickly discover, Ripley was a bit of an odd ball himself. "LeRoy Ripley, it turns out, may have been the most unbelievable oddity of all." Definitely a very good read.

When I pulled it out of the package and wore it for the first time, it's definitely something you have to play around with, or it'll just kind of look a little flat on your head. The curls are definite, which I like how they spindle around each other.It's about 24 inches long (without straightening or pulling out the curls). The parting space is about 3 and a half inches. However, the parting space needs a little tweezer work done because it's very skinny. It has three combs and adjustable straps, and the cap is big enough for comfortable fit.It is curling iron safe becuase I curled it a bit to give it more body just over my eyes, and I ended up liking the wig more when I did that.The only thing I can't stand is the shine. Shine is like 'wig alert!'. It's just unnatural-looking, but the hair is very soft, and the hairline seems to work pretty well.I got mines from Divatress.com for around 35 bucks.Update 10/11/14I am DEFINITELY liking this wig. It's gorgeous! This is honestly one of the best wigs I've bought along with Vivica Fox Melrose wig. Those are pretty much the two realistic wigs I've ever bought. I will buy this unit again in the future. I love the body that it has, how I can flip the bangs over since the wig is in wonderful layers.

I just kind of stumbled upon these bags of Crunchmaster crackers. Curiosity got the best of me, and I picked up the Vegetable plus one other flavor I wasn't as excited about. Vegetable flavor won all the awards. I loved how the crackers were seasoned enough, becuase sometimes you pick up bags of chips or crackers that seem like they were forgotten to be seasoned.It doesn't really taste like vegetable, but at the same time, once your taste buds kick in, it's like I can ALMOST taste what specific vegetable it COULD be, but then it goes away. It's is very crunchy. Sometimes I wonder how loud I'm chewing around other people. I've gone into dipping the crackers into some Louisiana Creole dressing, which nearly sent me eating the whole bag in just a few minutes. This bag of crackers really does creep up on you if you don't count how many you're eating. Just  15 crackers are 130 calories. I especially like how there's fiber in these crackers.As far as the bag itself, it's about 8 inches tall. And of course as with nearly any product, it's almost halfway full. I measured 4 1/2 of free space left. Honestly, I would buy the individual bags at Wal-Mart for a cheaper price.

Although I'm not a fan of Justin Beiber, I had a 'sniff' sample of this perfume in a Teen Vogue magazine and liked it. A while later I bought it and it comes in this two-piece shell-like container, which measures about 7 1/2 tall. When it piece them together, it has this neat magnetic grip to protect the glass perfume bottle. I was able to lift it by the top container and it was still intact. The perfume bottle itself gives you like 5 inches in height. And and removing it from the containers is effortless.Once I had more experience with the perfume, my nose just lost interest for the fragrance. I appreciate that it's not one of those fragrances where it's so strong that it's hard to get rid of the smell unless you shower. I've had that happened before and it was terrible. I couldn't get rid of the smell in my room for about two days.I don't use it everyday. Sometimes I go a week and not use it. But when I get ready for college and if it's in my sight, I'll just spray some on for the sake of just smelling good in general.But given the price, it really does last you a good while. So, I guess the price is about right. I spray about two to three rounds on my body, but after that, I don't really smell it on me after at least 20 minutes go by.

I spent about $13 on these headphones. I don't used headphones everyday, but typically maybe 2 or 3 times a week. So, I was expecting them to last awhile, but I knew deep down, I'd soon be disappointed.Like one other reviewer said, the ear cushions do come off easily, at least just one of them. I nearly lost one and there were times I didn't realize it was off just when I was about to workout.One thing I truly love about the headphones was that it had just extra adjust volume feature along the cord. I liked that a lot becuase it just seemed like simpler way to control the volume. But that soon kind of turned into a bad feature because it eventually started working to wear the music would come out in one ear. So, I'd have to tap the volume adjuster here and there to return the the balance.I honestly would save your money. Only buy these headphones if you're not a heavy headphone user and just need it here and there.

There are a few things I really don't like about this wig. I had been looking at Melorse for a VERY long time because I like how the curls spiral back around the head. And YES, they really do look like that in person.First of all, the hair is incredibly soft. I don't know if that will ever change once it ages, but it's really soft. It doesn't feel like that typical synthetic wig where the strands are a little hard. It reminds me of the Vanessa wig by FreeTress Equal, which feels the same way. The only difference is that Melrose has a much longer parting space, which I LOVE. It might be 3 and a half to 4 inches long. However, the parting space is only a centralized space, meaning you're restricted to that one area of parting space.When I put the wig on and tried to move the hair around, it seemed a little lazy to me. If you think about holding a banana peel by the tip or top, that's what it looked like on my head. It's like it was just sitting on my head and had no body. One other thing I dislike about Vivica Fox wigs is that it has that dome or hump shape. The wig is way too shiny, which gives off the 'wiggy radar'. But I really do like that around the hairline it looks as if it's growing out of my scalp.One other thing about the parting space is that is unrealistic. It looks glittery. I'll have to put some concealer over it and give it a better texture and color.The wig can curl. In fact, I've curled it a few times, cut some down a bit to give it some layers, and once I did that, especially around my eyes, the wig looked way better than the factory style.But my main problem is the shine, the dome-head, and the glittery parting space. I bought mines from Divatress.com with a new-member 10% discount code. The price alone was around 30 bucks. So, I would NOT spend $70 for this wig. You'd get ripped off twice over!10-11-14 UPDATEThe wig is still going beautiful. I honestly, would buy this again as the wig grew on me favorably. I got rid of the dome shape by just adjusting the straps and making it a little tighter. The curls are starting to loosen just a bit, which makes the wig longer. So, i'll have to put in more curls. The ends in some places are starting to have that rough texture. But that's with any wig with age.

The smell kind of relates near to Vanilla or French Vanilla actually. But the more you sniff, the more it actually does remind you of vanilla cupcakes. Cupcakes are my heaviest guilty pleasure, which compelled me to pick it up when I had never seen it before. I've bought over seven of these since wearing chapstick seems more fun now. And even the exterior designing of it, seems eye-pleasing. This almost makes me hungry.But it's not overpowering or anything like that, and the smell is not very lasting as in you can smell it while it's on your lips. Other than that, it's a plus.
