For this reason I am returning it and am buying a leather holster pouch designed to hold this large phone with a case on it. If it had not been for this one problem I would have kept the holster because (at least out of the package) it functioned well. It also fit the phone with case perfectly and it looks pretty good. As to how it would have held up, I will never know.

Just received this dock and I really like it. Unlike some reviews I have read this dock appears to be an original Twelve South Dock. All parts including the back post align perfectly. I even received the Twelve South appliqué another reviewer said was missing from their box. This was an Amazon-Twelve South purchase, not from a third party vendor.As other reviewers have stated you must use the smaller 1 millimeter Apple cable. My iPhone 6 plus was shipped with the 2 millimeter cable so I used the cable I was using for my iPod Touch. The unit assembles pretty easily. I tested the dock plugs with my case on my phone before inserting into the post. I use the Speigen Tough Armor Case and the number 2 plug fits perfectly. The case is stable enough. I do use my second hand to hold the base when removing the phone. I have had to do that with other docks too. Under normal circumstances the phone is secure on the dock. Small children with prying fingers could topple it.I would like to mention to Twelve South that if they used a magnetized Allen wrench it would make inserting those four screws much easier. I mean this is a premium dock so it would be nice to have a premium experience assembling it. I also had to work with it to keep the wire cover snap out piece on the underside bottom of the base from coming loose even though the cable was firmly seated in the grooves. I removed the little cellophane type "pull" piece and then is snapped and stayed in place.Over all I am very pleased with the premium look and the functionality of this dock. My back support works perfectly and fully supports the back of the phone. And the absolute best thing I like about this dock is it should work with future iPhones. The design is ingenious. The one thing I hate is spending a lot of money for an iPhone accessory only to have it rendered useless when Apple redesigns their phone. This dock is so adjustable that I believe that problem will be eliminated with future phones unless Apple has a very radical design change such as curving the phones.  And the fact that this dock will work with a large variety of cases out there is the biggest plus of all.I decided to take a picture of the dock. Some previous reviews have stated that the back post is cut incorrectly rendering the back support useless. They obviously did not receive an actual "Twelve South" dock. As you can see my back support aligns perfectly. Again, I ordered this through Amazon Prime - Twelve South, not a third party vendor. I feel you are pretty safe by ordering the dock this way. And if something is wrong it is much easier returning to Amazon vs. a vendor.

I am extremely pleased with the look and quality of this stand. It fits my Beats Wireless Studio Headphones perfectly. I am including a picture of the unit with the headphones. It was packaged beautifully and professionally. You would think you were buying an Apple product. I have two sets of headphones but I only bought one stand because I had to see the quality first. Now I will be purchasing a second unit for my Bose Wireless Headphones. There is even a peel off plastic piece on the bottom of this unit that covers a sticky/tacky surface that makes the stand slightly adhere to the surface to avoid tipping over. Peeling off the plastic piece is optional. In many instances you may not need to remove it because the stand is solid built. But it is nice to have the option to remove it and reveal the sticky surface if needed.

I was skeptical when I ordered this cover. My plans were to protect the watch when I was at the gym. However after seeing this cover on the watch I plan to leave it on all the time. It fits like a glove and the cutouts for the digital crown, side button and band release buttons are superb. You can barely tell it is on the watch. I read a review from another reviewer concerning the dot pattern on the case. He is correct but to be honest I did not notice the dot pattern until I read his review. Upon close examination I saw the pattern. But the case is clear and let's the beauty of the watch shine through. It also protects the sides and edges of the crystal. Every portion of the metal part of the watch, top and bottom is protected with this cover. There is a cut out circle on the bottom so it does not interfere with the charge surface. If you want a cover that offers good protection under normal use and does not hide the beauty of the watch, this is your cover. It does not cover the crystal so if you are in to rock or mountain climbing you might want a hard case cover and a crystal protector. This unit is easy to install. It stretches over the watch and fits perfectly in place. I took the bands off first (very easy to do) then installed the cover and replaced the bands. Took about one minute. I am including a close up picture that actually shows the dot pattern. But keep in mind this is a closeup. Under normal circumstances you will find it hard to focus in on this pattern.

These shoes are very comfortable to wear and they are well made. For me they give just the right amount of support and cushioning. They are expensive but you get what you pay for. And when it comes to taking the best care I can of my feet or any other other limb for that part I am not going to skimp on quality.

This is a top quality aluminum wallet using the finest sturdy materials in its construction. It is sleek and easy to pull out of a front pocket. The large size should be able to hold most items carried in a traditional wallet unless you have it stuffed and bulging at the seams. It is a beautiful finish but it will scratch if dropped on a rough surface like a concrete driveway. That being said some sort of protective coating over the finish would be beneficial. This is a unisex wallet that depending on the color will work equally for men and women.

To be fair I know you are not going to get a lot of quality out of a queen size bed skirt that costs $15.00. So I am not going to be too critical of this manufacturer except for the way they advertise it. If you buy this you are getting $15.00 worth of quality, and that is not much. But that should be expected. I have seen bargain 150 count thread sheets that are luxurious compared to this. My beef is they make it sound as if you are getting luxurious quality by stating 1,500 thread count. I think someone does not know how to count. It does rip easily and it is very thin. The fit is ok for a 15 inch drop. If you are looking for a very inexpensive bed skirt with limited quality but does serve the purpose this is it. Just don't expect longevity out of it. Forget about the 1500 advertising and use your common sense if you are looking for quality.

Writing a review for underwear is difficult. Different body sizes and shapes plus individual likes and dislikes makes a review kind of useless. However, I can tell you what I like about them. The fabric is comfortable. I am average size, 6 feet & 170 lbs with a 34 inch waist. Even though the size chart says my measurement size for this underwear is a medium, I disagree. Large is perfect for me. Not loose and not too tight. I have been wearing this style for a long time. I find the pouch style to be comfortable and supportive. The horizontal fly is perfect. I find a vertical opening to be cumbersome and next to useless after using the horizontal opening. So to sum it up, this style is definitely worth a try.Update:  I have read from other reviewers stating the quality of this underwear is going down. I just noticed a hole in one pair of the briefs after 3 washings in a front loading washing machine. Front loaders are easy on clothes. I was surprised to find this and it could be that this pair is defective. The hole is at a seam. At this short time of wear there should be no deterioration of the fabric however unless as stated it was defective from the start.

Setup was super easy. Just go to the door opener motor, have the remote in hand and press the learn button on the motor. That's all there is to it. Remote functions perfectly. Hardest part, getting a step ladder to reach the motor.

This car seat gap fits my 2010 Camry well and looks very good. It totally closes the gap and almost looks like it came with the car. The beige shade does not totally match the seat but blends well. It is a very tight fit which is good. But because of the tight fit it squeals because of the faux leather rubbing the side of the console when moving the seats back or forward. This is not a big deal to me because the seats are hardly ever moved. But even if they were constantly moved I would still use them. It they were made of a cloth material they probably wouldn't squeal.

These are comfortable pants. The 34 inch waist is right on. No alteration needed for me. However the 32 inch length is off. With this pair it was closer to a 34 inch length. The alteration service had to take off an inch and a half. That being said I like the pants. They have a nice look and the corduroy style can be seen. The chords are not as deep as a $100.00 plus pair of pants but for the money this pair of pants is great.

I like these key finders. They function as advertised and I like the fact that they are color coded. I keep the key remote in a drawer with a note where I jotted down which color belongs to each key. It is imparitive that you keep the remote in a safe place where you will always know where it is located. The remote works well with each fob and works at a decent distance and is reasonably loud. You may have to walk around in search mode with the remote but if the key fob is anywhere in sight it will find it. I agree with another reviewer that an improvement would be an even slimmer (wafer thin) fob. This would be very useful for wallets. The current fob causes a slight amount of bulging. But all-in-all these are nice key finders and I am comfortable with them. They are great for items hiding in the house or in a coat pocket.  If your key is hidden in a couch or pocket you will need a quiet environment to hear them because the beeping will be muffled. So with that said maybe a sharper or higher pitch would be welcome too. But don't let that stop you. They have located keys for me two times since I purchased them. When it finds the item you are so glad you have them. Less searching on my part.UPDATE:  I have a great idea for an enhancement to this product due to a problem I encountered. This is not a defect with the product. Recently I was searching for one set of my keys that was missing. I thought "great" my handy dandy key finder will help me. But it didn't. And the reason was because the battery in the locater attached to the keys had gone dead. This happened several months after I purchased the key finder. I would like to hear a "low battery" chirp in each key finder. This way you would be warned when the battery was weak. To me this is very necessary because if the battery dies you are lost at sea. In the interim my suggestion would be to test each key finder every month. This will give you a better chance of not encountering a dead battery when you need it most. By the way, I found the keys. But it was the old fashioned way. I searched until I found them.

This band is much nicer than the band that comes with the Pebble due to the fact that the band is the same width as the watch. It makes the watch look more substantial and just has a nicer look to it. I am very pleased with the quality of the band and it is comfortable to wear. I am totally pleased with this band.UPDATE:  After wearing this band for 8 months (not every day) the metal buckle clasp fell apart. I tried everything to reinstall it into the band but it would not stay in place. I gave up and reinstalled the band that came with the Pebble. The only thing I can tell you is that the clasp did not break from rough usage. I can't say why it fell apart but it did. I'm dropping the rating to 3 stars. Maybe it was just this band, I don't know.
These bags are just as described. I like them. They are perfect for storing suits and mid length coats. The material is light weight but sturdy enough to protect your clothing. Very pleased.

I have several pairs of these shoes. They fit well and are a great casual/dressy casual shoe. Looks great with jeans or shorts. To keep them looking like new I clean the white band of the shoe frequently using a soft damp cloth. Do this after most wearings and they will be super easy to wipe any markings off and they will keep that out-of-the-box look.

You can totally change the look of your Pebble watch with this product. It adheres nicely and holds strong. That being said I wish the company could design them in a way where they could be taken off and reused if you want to change colors or styles. Technically you can but it is very difficult to remove without damaging the skin. At $9.00 a wrap it would be nice to reuse them when changing styles. They are fairly easy to install and easy to shift and adjust before you apply pressure to make them adhere to the watch. Once adhered they will stay in place. Making them easier to remove and reinstall would get a five star rating from me.

You just can't go wrong with Maui Jim. These are frameless which means they require a more gentle handling than lens with a full frame. However they are extremely lightweight and the optics are number 1. These are readers ( I use them with contacts). If you are rough with your glasses you might want a framed set. But if you want a really cool, lightweight pair of glasses and are reasonably careful when handling them, you will be totally pleased with them.

This watch is great for voice commands. I have an iPhone 5s and it excels with its interaction with Siri. The function is identical to using the phone. It is also not too bad with text messages. It will scroll the entire message across its small screen if you set it to do so. The message scrolls as soon as the phone receives it. It is HORRIBLE with email messages. It displays very limited information with email messages. And if you get more than one it only lets you know that you have email messages waiting which you will have to read on the phone.  If you were not wearing the watch at the time the texts or emails came through, the watch gives no indication of waiting notifications. Emails don't come across as soon as they hit the phone. The watch syncs with the phone in 3 minute intervals at the fastest setting. The leather band is not the best in quality. Going back to voice command, the watch speaks clear and loud. As stated previously it excels in this area. Siri functions perfectly and you can tell Siri to play music and it plays clearly through the watch. Here is the bottom line for me:  If you like voice command and talking through your watch, this is your smart watch for now. If you rely on text messages, this watch is good as long as you are with the watch when the text comes through. If you need good email notification, this watch doesn't make the cut. If it excelled at all three I would have kept the watch. But $300.00 is a lot to pay for a watch that has a poorly designed notification system for my needs.  I also own a Pebble Watch. It's text and email notification is very good to excellent and it also stores your notifications so you can call them back up. You cannot talk through it however. For now my suggestion would be to buy a Pebble if you want smart watch functionality. It works very good in all that it is designed to do. The technology is constantly improving in this market. Also as far as the watch reading your emails and texts through Siri - you can do this through the Martian Watch. But at no fault to the watch, Siri is sporadic with the way it reads emails. Sometimes you get the whole email and sometimes you only get the subject line. Texts are better. That being said I still in many instances have to pull out the phone to review many of the emails. If I have to do this then the watch is not as useful. I'm just saying for the price of the watch I should be able to completely rely on it. Sending emails and messages with the watch through Siri works much better. This watch needs a better system for visually reviewing emails and texts.

These lights perform perfectly and are a great value. You can pay double the price in a store, even discount stores. Nothing else needs to be said. I can't vouch for longevity because I have been using them for two weeks but I use them quite a bit and they are bright (they are dimmable) and they don't flicker. I purchased 7 of them and they all work perfectly.

I love this case. It fully protects all 4 sides and the back of the iPod Touch. There is no way you could damage the iPod on the sides or back by dropping it from any distance. It also has "lay on the table screen protection". The glass screen could be damaged by dropping if it hit an object in a certain way. To eliminate this issue I would suggest a "case friendly" screen protector. This case has a fantastic grip to it. It won't be slipping out of your hand. It is a tough built case but not bulky. It makes the iPod feel like a lighter iPhone. Because of the toughness the buttons are a little harder to press (they are covered by the case) but they press and operate fine. If you are looking for a case that has very good drop protection and easy to grip, this is your case especially when used with a screen protector. I should mention this case is not waterproof but would shield some rain. The bottom ports are not sealed. Overall I can highly recommend this case. The only time you would be in trouble is if you dropped it in a body of water. The case has a great feel.

I like this charger. It is cleverly made in that it tilts backward at the docking point so there is no stress on the connector. The tilting feature allows the back of the phone to rest on the resting plate eliminating the stress on the pin connector. It is compatible with some cases but not all. This will be hit or miss.

This is a solid built heavy duty cord. It is needed for higher amperage tools like electric pressure washers and high amp blowers, etc. Very well made and lighted plug is a nice bonus. It could be a bit to handle for some smaller ladies because the cord is heavy due to the fact of the thicker wire. Since it is so thick it may not fit many cord reels. But the idea is to protect your high amp appliances.

This is the best filter you can get. It is very tough and hard to wear it out. It is expensive but it lasts so long that it pays for itself. It also filters the air far better than those paper models.

These are without a doubt the finest rugs you will ever walk on. They are plush, and very well made. They do not slip or slide at all. If you are looking for the best, you found it. I wish you could carpet the whole bathroom with this product. You could almost sleep on them.UPDATE:  After using these rugs for several months it became time to clean them. They are very thick rugs due to the fact that they have memory foam in them. That being said they can be washed but they take FOREVER to become bone dry. Even placing them in the sun takes forever. Once washed and finally dry their appearance is not the same. They loose that new look and the fibers look matted. I tried to vacuum them but it doesn't help much. They have a matted down look. They are still very soft and comfortable to walk on but their good looks are gone. Most bathroom rugs/carpet will wash and look very fluffy after dried in a dryer. These rugs while very nice do not launder and keep their fresh appearance nearly as well as standard bathroom rugs. Because of this I am knocking my rating down to a three. When new and before washing they are a five.
This unit is custom made to fit your vehicle. It even has a lip that adds to the custom look. Installs easily. Looks like it came with the vehicle.

This unit would not work properly with my iPhone 5s. So why the 5 star rating?  The answer: because Olens Technology has the best customer service I have ever seen. The Renny would not stay connected to my phone. I contacted Olens Technology and they worked with me in every way imaginable to correct the issue including sending me a second unit. It too would not stay connected to this phone. Olens Technology paid to ship both units back to them and I was not out a penny. They are outstanding. Now to the unit. When it was connected it worked perfectly. It was loud and clear. For some reason it just did not like this phone, or the phone did not like it. The company tells me that there is a very small percentage of iOS devices (Apple) experiencing this issue and they are investigating the problem.  My recommendation:  Go ahead and try the unit. If it stays connected to your phone without disconnecting as mine did, you will have a valuable quality made Bluetooth ringer. If for some reason it doesn't function properly you will have no problem returning it. I might add that this is a finely crafted element looking device.

These are high quality made emblems. I ordered an extra set because I have the originals installed down low on the sides of the car where they are more subject to adverse conditions. They have been on for almost two years and holding up fine.
Shoe is well made and looks classy. You could almost wear them out. Very comfortable. I do recommend these bedroom shoes.

I did not purchase this case through Amazon. I purchased it directly through the Element Case website. It is a solid, well built case. It is a little bulky but that is to be expected of a case that is designed to highly protect a case from drops. This case has one design flaw at least in my experience with it. The flash cut out is very deep and it is white. When you take a flash picture the white cut out of the case causes the flash to reflect back into the lens. This results in a very cloudy/milky picture. It took me a while to figure this out because I thought I was not using the camera correctly. It finally hit me that the case may be causing the problem so I took it off. The result was crystal clear flash pictures. I reinstalled the case and had the same cloudy flash problem. I contacted Element and they are replacing the Rogue Case with a different case. I don't know if this problem exists with the black Rogue cases because the cutout is black, not white as on the gold model. I thought I should let people know of the problem I experienced with this case. Other than this one issue it is a very good case.

This is a beautiful crystal frog with nice faceted detail. I bought Frieda along with Freddy as a Christmas gift and it was very well received. The umbrella makes this frog very cute and she is the perfect mate for Freddy. Just pay attention to the stated dimensions because this is a small piece. If you are looking for a larger crystal frog then this will not be the one.

Bought Freddy along with Frieda as a Christmas gift. Needless to say it was very well liked. It is a beautiful crystal piece with nice faceted detail right down to the crystal green eyes. It is a small piece so pay attention to the stated dimensions. If you are looking for a larger frog this is not the one for you.

This phone system works flawlessly. I especially like the fact that Panasonic phones use triple A type replacement batteries and are very easy to find if needed. Some phones use those batteries with wire terminals attached to them. They are a pain when you need to find replacements. I have also found that the battery type in this phone (at least for me) has lasted much longer than the other type as mentioned above. The clarity of the phone is fine for listening and for talking. Sounds just like a corded phone. It has a solid build and every feature works including the cell phone feature. I have nothing negative to state about this phone system.

This is a nice basic cover for the iPod Touch 5th Generation. It fits perfectly and the clear model lets the color of the iPod through. It also  makes the iPod much easier (less slippery) to hold. It will provide protection from scratches on the back. It will offer drop protection if the drop hits the back of the iPod. However if you need moderate to serious drop protection, this is not the case, especially if the drop hits the front at the top or bottom of the iPod.  There is also no "lay on the table" protection for the screen. Still, if you are easy on your electronics you will like the simplicity of this case and the protection from scuffs and scratches on the back. A screen saver will help protect the screen from scratches if needed. All ports have easy accessibility. I have no use for the strap so the opening for attachment of the strap is a moot issue for me. However if you do plan to use the strap, as other reviewers have stated it could be difficult. I have not tried to attach it.

I purchased this cover to replace the original cover on the original Bose Soundlink. This bi fold design is superior to the older designed that just hanged down when you would pick the unit up. It actually stays attached to the unit upon picking it up until you physically pull it open to cover the speaker. It looks nicer too.

Before purchasing this shredder I read all of the reviews on Amazon. There is only one negative thing that I agree with other reviewers and that is the poor design for moving the shredder. There really are no handles on the machine to grasp to move it. You have to tilt the machine and hold on to the flat sides to move it. Why recesses weren't made on the sides for something to hold on to is beyond me. That being said it is still not that difficult to move if you need to. Just don't let it slip from your hands. Everything else about the machine is perfect. It is powerful and fairly quiet.  It has a large bin. The unit is very high tech looking with all of the blue led lights on the top of the unit. It makes it look very impressive and professional for a paper shredder. The only reason I gave if four stars is because the company overlooked such a simple solution by adding recesses to make moving the machine easier. If it weren't for that one issue it would be getting five stars. I do like the machine.

These are very nice and comfortable wearing headphones. The headphone paired with my iPhone 5 in a snap. They are very nice looking. I especially like the leather/vinyl ear pads. In fact that is why I chose them. I am using these specifically at the gym. The leather covering to me is much easier to clean than foam coverings found on other phones. They function properly except for when trying to place a call with them. During music playback they work perfectly with answering a call. However when placing a call (which is not that important to me) they activate Siri to initiate the call but she does not follow through with the voice command. Sometimes she will but most of the time she won't. Now on to the sound quality. You can't expect these headphones to perform like a $150.00 plus  set of phones. To me there is very little treble with these phones. Some music sounds muffled (depending on the recording). In fact I keep the sound setting on my iPhone to "Treble Booster" to be able to use these phones. That being said I like them, however I wish the company had tweaked them to give clearer voice and high notes. Any headphone in this price range is not for serious listening. However for casual listening during workouts or runs they are ok. The convenience of not dealing with dangling cords and earplugs is worth it for me to keep them. I can recommend them but don't expect outstanding sound quality.Update:In all fairness to the company that produces these headphones I feel compelled to give an updated review. After using these headphones for more days now they seem to be somewhat clearer than they were. This could be because they are breaking in, or, my ears are adjusting to them or a combination of both. That being said they are producing a cleaner sound in the treble range. It also made a call with Siri today. You have to speak loudly to the microphone and wait for all responses from Siri. I believe once you get the feel for making the call it will be ok. While these would never be my serious headphones for listening to music, they are perfect for the gym or any activity such as running, etc. I am upping the rating to 4 stars. I am happy with them.

This is a very powerful subwoofer. The build quality and finish is perfect. It produces very deep and powerful bass and does not sound muddy. I believe this subwoofer would please all but the most critical audiophile. This is not a small subwoofer.  If you attempt to place it in a cabinet or behind a piece of furniture you are probably going to have difficulty. But this subwoofer looks so nice you won't want to hide it. It has an impressive look and is furniture quality.

I purchased these speakers to use as surround speakers. In my opinion this function is what they were intended for. Used as surround speakers they are great. They reflect the background channels very well. They are also very easy to install them on a wall or ceiling. I have mine installed high on the back wall tilting down. In another room I have a second set installed on the ceiling tilting slightly downward. The ease in which they install is one of the reasons I purchased them. They also sound very good for surround purposes and they look good. I don't believe they would make a very good left and right front channel speaker. They just don't have the sound quality for main speakers in my opinion. That being said I am very happy with them as surround speakers. This is actually my second set because I have surround systems in two separate rooms. I was pleased with the first set. This is why I had no hesitation to purchase the second set for another room.

This crate is so much better looking than a wire crate. It has a very nice look. It works perfectly for my dog. That being said I have a very docile well behaved dog. He is 36 pounds and there is plenty of room for him to stretch out. If you have a very hyper dog or a dog who might struggle to get out I am not sure how this crate would hold up in the long run. While it is not especially flimsy, it is not heavy duty either.
This is a nice pet bed and fits his crate perfectly. The dog actually goes in his crate on his own and curls up in there.

I was pleasantly surprised when I received this pendant. It is designed very nicely and a very substantial piece for the price. I was hoping I would not be receiving a pendant that was as thin as a piece of tin.  It is not weightless and I am very pleased with the purchase.
These pajamas were a gift for my mother. She tells me they are very comfortable but the buttons will not stay closed. They pull loose too easily. Other than this one issue, they are fine.

This handset works just as stated. I have no issues with clarity and everyone on the other end of the call can hear me and they tell me the clarity is just fine. The volume control works great and the disconnect button works fine. No problems with this product.

This is a very quality product and fits the iPhone 5 perfectly. Looks awesome. The only issue I had with it was the peel off paper attached to the adhesive on the backside of the wrap pulled the entire adhesive strip off of the skin. This was due to the fact that I removed it improperly. I did not realize what was happening until after it was done. Be careful when removing the adhesive cover. I thought I had ruined it but the wrap was still tacky on the back side. I put it on the phone and it stayed in place and does not move or shift. That was months ago and I see no issues of it coming loose or peeling up. I get many compliments on this skin. Just be careful when removing the adhesive cover. Now I would know how to remove it without peeling the entire adhesive strip off. You can actually pull the whole thing off without realizing it until it is too late. Use your fingernail to carefully separate the adhesive strip. At least on my cover it was like the adhesive cover paper was fused to the adhesive strip.
They are true to size for me. Very light weight and comfortable. I have no issues with them. They seem to be well made.

These cushions are very comfortable, the same as the original cushions That being said I wish they were made of a more durable cushion cover. I babied the original cushions by never allowing any sweat or body oils to accumulate on them. I would actually clean my ears to prevent oils from getting on them before putting them on. Still after a few years the cover material cracked and disintegrated. I might also add that I also don't wear them that much. I am sure these replacement cushions will suffer the same fate because the material is the same. I can just imagine what would have happened to them had I not maintained them so well. You could NEVER use these at the gym. Bose needs to see that a more durable cushion cover is used. But as stated above, they are very comfortable and the sound from this headphone is awesome.

These are very nice valve stem covers. They project a high end look. They are also deep enough to cover the entire threads of the valve stem. I am very pleased with them and have no hesitation to recommend them. They are plastic but you would never know it and they are quality made.

This is a well made Karcher accessory. It is a must if you want to clean high eaves or even one or two story houses. I like the item because it allows you to stand farther back and not get sprayed down with as much water. If you are cleaning eaves you are back far enough as to not have water pouring down on you. Especially nice in winter months. It does make the trigger gun a little heavier and the spray force controller is farther away from you so you have to stop to adjust the spray pressure. But this is a small price to pay for getting less wet and not having to use a ladder.

I purchased this item from Brand Variety through Amazon. It works like a charm and pivots to any angle for ease of use. I was surprised at the power of the rotating brush. It takes a lot of pressure force to bog it down and stop it from rotating. That being said it cleans very well. The quality of the bristles are nice too. They are not stiff and abrasive. Perfect for cleaning windows. This Karcher brush is quality made. It is expensive, but in this case you get an above average accessory. There is another rotating Karcher rotating brush out there that does not pivot. I purchased it locally before purchasing the pivoting brush through Amazon. For my needs the non-pivoting brush is useless except for very basic cleaning due to the fact that you can't angle it. The brushes are also much stiffer. If you need this type of brush do yourself a favor and buy the pivoting brush. You won't be sorry.

These are great for quad copters and other little gadgets. The box end and open end are different sizes which is great for holding a bolt and a nut of the same size. There are no rough spots or sharp edges on the set I received.I think my 30 year old craftsman set is a finer set, but they don't seem to make tools that well anymore. These are good.

I'm using this to replace the elastic straps on my head lamps and the chest strap for a heart rate monitor. After enough time, those all lost their stretch. This elastic webbing will also wear out eventually and, at these prices, it'll be an inexpensively replaced.As for comfort and all that, this elastic strap seems to be as good as what came with my various devices. So, no problem.

This is an amazingly handy little device to have around because you never really know what that USB charger is putting out. I threw out about a dozen chargers after measuring them with this meter. Now I have a lot more confidence in the chargers I have left.

This is a little tape measure and looks like it'll work just fine for a long time. It's a big improvement over the crappy one it's replacing.I tend to keep a few of these little ten footers around because they are so handy. One in the kitchen, one in the office, one stashed in the truck, ... This is in addition to the larger ones in the tool boxes n' stuff. This is one of the good ones.

This review is for the Lenox Holiday Salt and Pepper shakers set that looks like a little Santa engine and a caboose. As I write this, the Amazon price for this set is $14.91. That is a smokin' hot deal.Firstly, this is a really cute little salt & pepper set. It is definitely for presentation, not so much for actually salting and peppering. The holes aren't numerous enough or placed well enough for dispensing salt & pepper. But, so what? It's cute an that's all it's supposed to be.Overall, quality is good. The detail is good and it looks like everything was painted in and at the right spots. The glaze is not perfect and I'd be annoyed if it was my Lenox bone china. But this isn't fine china. It's a little holiday nik-nak. And it is really cute.

This is a beautiful watch that comes in beautiful packaging. As I write this, the Amazon price is $83.50 - which makes this a five star purchase. On opening, the package that new leather smell wafts out. This would make a very nice gift because the whole presentation is just outstanding.The pearlescent-ish watch face has gold trimming and some black lettering, all of it flawless. The brushed gold colored case sets off the watch face nicely. The band is supple with excellent stitching. The stainless steel back plate is nicely patterned with Invicta branding. It all looks very... fancy.The watch case itself is 42mm diameter. What this means in practice is that it is kinda big and looks overly large on my wrist. BUT... that's the style of late with some smart watches being even bigger.The watch box is amazingly well executed too and appears to be made with real leather and nice stitching. Probably a keeper for storage and showing off.I think this watch is available at its current price because smart watches are becoming such a thing. This watch is just a watch. Pretty, but it's not going to show you your texts or anything. Also unlike a smart watch, this one doesn't stick way up on your wrist and doesn't need to be recharged every day.

This gadget asks questions until it -maybe- figures out what you're thinking about. I like it because it looks cool, has pretty blinking lights, and occasionally figures out something obscure. For example, it figured out those Naboo star fighters. Over all, I think this toy isn't supposed to be all that capable, just fun to mess with. It is fun to mess with.Something frustrating is that it doesn't rephrase questions at all and so many questions make no sense. The first question is always "being, location, or technology." It is frustrating when it's a location, such as the Varykino lake retreat (Padme & Anaken wedding pavilion) and the gadget asks: "Are they a pilot." So very many irrelevant questions. A little more software sophistication would have made this so much cooler. It is generally this way. That said, it kinda makes sense to ask if a technology is someone specific (R2D2).But - it is a fun gadget and it does attract curious hands.All in all, it is amazing that the Jedi holocron can guess some obscure beings, locations, and technologies. Well, maybe Darth Plagueis isn't that obscure. Galactic Senate Repulsorpod seems to have escaped the holocron's notice though.

I've tested a fair number of these FRS/GMRS radios, have an amateur radio license, and occasionally get designated "radio man" and end up handing out radios to groups of people. I settled on the MT350 (now out of production) a few years ago and bought a bunch of them. For the most part, the T480 is an upgraded version of my beloved MT350s.First off - performance. The T480 delivers well. The FRS channels are low power channels and the only reason I know of to use them is because someone brought a radio that can't operate on GMRS. Frown at such people. Confiscate their radio. No, you won't get 35 miles with this radio unless maybe both transmitter and receiver are on mountain tops in a remote place without other transmitters. This being very unlikely, don't expect more than 3 or 4 miles and even less if people are indoors. I've tried other brands in this price range and the "35 mile" Motorola talkabouts gave me the best useful range. Note: there are also "20 mile" talkabouts. Don't use them.Batteries - The most important thing here is that these radios accept standard AA batteries -and- come with rechargeable packs. The rechargeable packs make life easy close to civilization. The AA compatibility makes life easy when recharging isn't going to happen.  The T480 comes with a 800mAH hour battery. My old MT350s have 650 mAH batteries. They are interchangeable. Sweet!Recharging is via micro USB. Good. The world is full of micro USB chargers.Other stuff - I'd love it if the radio were smaller and came in much brighter colors. These things get dropped and misplaced a lot (Don't get the black ones - they vanish). The "whistle" is a joke. The belt clip doesn't have tension and should't be trusted -but- the lanyard attachments are great because they are on the radio center line. This means the radio hangs well from the lanyard. Use the lanyard, throw away the clip.The buttons are wonderfully functional. The T480 emergency button is easier to push by accident than the MT350 one. The MT350 had it between the antenna and volume knob. The T480 has it right below the push-to-talk button which is less than ideal placement.These units are fairly weatherproof. They can get rained on and getting wet but they can't handle staying wet.The directions are printed in too small a font. It may seem silly in the 2nd decade of this century, but printed directions that are easy to read in low light are really important.As discussed above, these are great radios for handing out to a group such as a tour group or hiking group. They are rugged and get the job done. Personally, I tend to use an Icom radio that costs a lot more but is waterproof (it floats), transmits more powerfully, and has a better and interchangeable antenna. Using it also requires passing tests to get the right license.These talkabouts really should be waterproof. Kind of like the Moto 360.

The Amazon curated collection has been a great deal. Good quality at a great price and I've never been disappointed.This particular pendant is very pretty. Very sparkly and eye catching. The product page doesn't show the pendants size. It's about the size of a nickel. I won't comment on the design because different people have different tastes and, mostly, because there's a picture right there for you to look at. Regarding that picture, the actual pendant is way more attractive. As for construction, it's good. It looks like it was assembled by some who cared about doing a good job.The chain is better than most. It's sturdy enough to do its job and is well built. It won't break without abuse.Another reviewer complained that the box wasn't all that. I agree. A bit of shrink wrap would do wonders for keeping sticky labels from making a mess.

This thing is amazing. Just plain amazing. The technology is eye popping. The cars can follow the track on their own and the driver basically selects speed and lane (and fires weapons). The cars are controlled through blue tooth from a phone or tablet. Speed is an on-screen slider, shift lanes by tipping the phone left and right. Each car is a bit different with different speed defense, firepower, and "special." Weapons are fired by tapping on screen buttons. It is all very intuitive and outrageously fun.I've only played against other adults. We all had a blast. I think kids would love it too. Especially devious kids with tactical awareness.The hardest thing about getting started is downloading the app, which took a minute. Maybe two. We all skipped the tutorial, so I can't comment on that. We just unpacked it, stuck the cars on the charger, set up the track, and got right to it. There are instructions somewhere. Someone should read them.The track is held together by magnets and it almost assembles itself. The cars charged pretty quickly, and it's off to the races (or battle). Recharge takes a little while, 8ish minutes.There is a tournament mode for battling AI drivers. I haven't tested the AIs much because we went straight to racing person against person. One guy hosts, the other joins. The host selects race, battle, time trial, or "king of the hill." The other players select join, and the host double clicks to select participants. It is just amazing watching the cars scan the track and then line up, perfectly line up, at the start line. and then you race, or battle, or whatever.Interesting tid bits... Unlike slot cars, these cars don't go fast enough to fly off the track. Their internal AI keeps them in their lane. Different cars have different top speeds. When a car is disabled, it spins around a bit and can flip itself off the track - neat touch! Sometimes, a car gets turned around and goes backward. The AI notices and spins the car to the right direction. Spins it fast too.The only problem I've had is that the android home button and stuff disappear when anki overdrive is run on cheapo tablet I'm using. It reappears when I go to settings-support though. Easy work around.Anyways... This is a fantastic toy and we're having a blast with it.

OK five stars for completely meeting expectations. How could it not? It is a pizza pan.I think this particular pizza pan is made of aluminum. It seems to weigh nothing. That also means that it distributes heat well and will stay shiny.In use, it doesn't bend like my other pizza pans because the ~1" lip keeps it nice and rigid. Some of my bargain pans twist as they get hot in the oven. This one stays flat.Over all, it's a pizza pan.

This is an oddly useful tent. First off, it isn't exactly a camping tent. It's more of a day shelter or stuff protector. For example, it's nice for getting coolers and gear out of direct sunlight. It's really nice for that. It's also a great little tent for getting yourself out of direct sunlight.As for sleeping in it overnight, maybe. The door doesn't zip shut. Bugs will enter if motivated to do so.Set up is very easy. It took a friend and I less than twp minutes or so to set it up without ever reading the instructions. It's pretty obvious where everything goes. It would have been even faster it the poles were formed a little different. I have other tents where you just toss the pole sections around a bit and the poles rapidly self assemble because of the shapes of the section ends and the elastic band running through the centers. These  poles took a little more jiggling.As a whole, this tent is very nice. The design is very well thought out. Every time you look for a little tie-off, there it is sewn into the tent in the perfect position. Things stay nice and neat because the door, windows, etc can all be gathered and tied so casually.The tent comes with some "sand bags" that can help weight down the corners. Nice concept, but those bags end up being used to hold stuff other than sand. Besides, a cooler or human inside the tent effectively weighs it down. Regardless, nice touch. This tent has lots of nice touches.Disassembly and repacking take 4-5 minutes because of the need to shake the crud out, because it's a but tougher to pull the tent poles out than to push them in (the poles run though sewn in channels), and because it takes a little attention to fold, roll up, and get the air out.Over all, this is a nice easy to set up shelter for car camping and tailgating.

Nitrile gloves are great to have around the house because there are so many times that you need a disposable glove. I constantly find new uses for them. For example, I now use them when polishing shoes because they rub in the wax as well as any rag -and- my hands stay clean. They are also great for any task involving oil. And for cleaning yuck from under the sink. and for handling that potting soil that smells like cow poo. and ...Nitrile is works better for me than latex because it doesn't shred and break as easily. Latex gloves seem almost eager to break. Another nice thing about Nitrile is that it doesn't age as poorly as latex. I once bulk bought latex gloves. A few years later and many of the latex gloves were either cracked or severely weakened. Very frustrating. I have years old Nitrile gloves that are still fine.The Ammex gloves compare well with the Nitrile gloves I get at Walgreens. The material thickness is about the same. The Ammex ones have more texture at the fingertips. Other than that, they seem equivalent.

Hey - this is good TP. It's pretty much exactly like the other Charmin in the closet. The other stuff is from a big box store. This TP is allegedly 308 squares while the others are 328. Hmmmmf. Anyways... It seems I've been using Charmin for decades. Odd to realize that.I use this stuff on my backside, as "gauze" for minor cuts, to wipe the goop from my dog's eyes, ... Basically, it is a quality soft tissue that has never clogged my drain - even when certain guests were going through at least a couple of rolls a week.The advantage here is that by ordering through prime I have one less reason to deal with the big box store.  People who really go through a lot of TP could do the subscription thing.

This apron fits my short n' wide man frame pretty well. Also, the black with white pinstripes works well for males. The material itself is much thicker than the restaurant kitchen aprons I wore back in the day. That makes the apron fairly sturdy. The colors didn't run in the wash machine but the apron did wrinkle up a bit. A few more washes should soften the fabric so that it doesn't hold wrinkles anymore. The apron strings are not long enough for me to -easily- tie the apron in front (34" waist). I suppose I could tie the apron strings in front if I really wanted to but its easy enough to tie a bow behind my back.As for using the thing. It's great. It is now hanging from a hook on the kitchen wall where it is easy to grab. This is really really important in the summer when I cook bacon shirtless.The two pockets are nice and large. They easily hold a timer and other stuff. Very good for reducing the number of trips between pantry and outdoor grill.All in all, this apron has improved my quality of life.

I got these at a great price. They were outright affordable. Price is a big issue for a device having a limited life span and far cheaper alternatives. After all, the amazingly log life that is quoted is for just a few hours per day of use. If you're like me, some lights stay on for way more hours (almost all hours) per day and the life will be shortened to a year or two.These bulbs linked right to my Wink hub without drama. Easy easy setup and install. It took all of a 1/2 hour to have voice controlled lights in my house (the Amazon Echo does the voice part).The bigger issue is if it is smarter to have smart bulbs or smart wall switches. The problem as of this writing is that the wall switches are flaky. Maybe GE can come out with a line of decent wall switches.What is really interesting is the option to not even have a wall switch. That's why I really like these smart bulbs. The remaining issue is how to be sure that the lights are controllable when the network goes down. That's a project for a different day.

These ear buds fit and sound great. They've taken a bit of abuse too and are still fine. Examples - sweat from running, being accidentally jerked out of my ear, and bouncing around on the ground.I've used ear buds and headphones that are way more expensive. These ones sound as good. These are now my go-to ear buds -except- for when I need noise cancellation. At this price I'll keep a spare or two. You never know when something weird is going to take out an ear bud.

This would be a five star product if I could keep it next to the wireless routers. It seems that this device's WiFi saturates or something if it is too close to a strong WiFi source. This was maddening for a few days as the device kept loosing all connection and refused to reconnect. Oddly, the Wink FAQs at their web site were no help at all for what is obviously a common problem. There are plenty of other places reporting this WiFi saturation problem.Now that the device is reliable, everything just works. It has been fun playing with the Wink Hub. I mostly control it by voice via an Amazon Echo. My next two projects are using ifttt and an android watch. This is just fun.The only problem so far is that this can be a budget breaker. There are so many toys to test.

I have built dozens of computers over the past few decades and it is amazing how much case design keeps improving. This case made for a supremely easy build. The sides, top and bottom come right off and makes installing components most casual. The position of power supply at the bottom with a nice space behind it helps contain the usual nightmare of power cables. A modular power supply helps too. The wires for hooking up the case switches, USB, and LEDs are all well labeled. The build took maybe 1/2 hour.Actually, the build was unintentional. I started checking how the components would fit and ended up just building the thing.There are ample fans of a good size which keeps everything cool and quiet. My build is almost silent with its solid state drive. Also, I selected a motherboard that can drive three monitors because my build is not a gaming PC and doesn't need a graphics card. I, however, need three monitors because I like to have lots of documents/web pages/text files open at once.So... if I could alter anything I'd consider maybe putting the case USB ports on the front instead of on the right hand side near the front.  That's just a maybe. The position of the case USB ports and power button work well for me.This case is kinda large for a mini ITX, but I still like it.

This is a well written and engaging book about catching one particular software pirate. What makes it special is that the story is told from the perspective of an assistant US attorney who is not a computer expert by any stretch of the imagination. This makes the book great for a much wider audience than say Tsutomo Shimomura's book, also partially titled "Takedown," who helped catch Kevin Mitnick.This book's author, David Hall, has to rely on experts like Shimomura to bring cyber criminals to justice. Hall is a remarkable author in that he displays very little ego. He is very frank about his thoughts, mistakes and miscues. I don't want to give spoilers, but Hall had a number of different theories about who did what and how. He investigates and -boom- dead theory. Then comes the part that's frightening. The man is relentless. He simply refines, adapts, and keeps learning about the pirate, the pirate's methods, and the pirate's victims.All of Hall's sleuthing has legal and political backdrops. The legal backdrop involves figuring out what the charges are, how to get the cuffs on a Chinese software pirate, and how to make sure he can prove those charges to his boss, different agencies, and eventually to a jury if required. As for the politics, Hall reveals that running a piracy investigation is full of political obstacles because there is only so much time and money available and the outcome is uncertain. It seems that US attorneys tend to shun risky investigations. Oh - risky doesn't mean getting shot at or anything, it means that there are easier to prove cases that are better for the office's performance metrics.Hall works largely with Homeland Security (HSI) officers. This is new(ish) because the FBI used to be the go-to guys. The book is a nice introduction to who and what HSI is.I could go on forever. I loved this book. I read it in a single long sitting over labor day weekend.

These are great for reaching into the bottom of jelly jars, instant coffee containers, and similar tasks. I doubt mine will ever touch ice cream but they are used multiple times every single day.Other than that - they are spoons. no rough edges, cleaning is typical. No surprises.

This helmet works well and at a great price point. Highly recommended.But... I often write how I would improve a product, here goes. Firstly, I'd  put in a button that makes the helmet dark regardless of what the sensors say. Second, I'd paint it white.As tested, I got little use out of the sensitivity setting setting. I just left it turned all the way up and indoors it never triggered offf of anything, other than an arc. At the highest sensitivity, it sometimes triggered off the sun. Yes, I did try looking directly at the sun but I had to keep my eyes closed most of the time and I could not predict when the lens would darken. I also experimented with it off my head and the sun didn't reliably trigger it.The black plastic get pretty dang hot in the August sun. That's why I'd paint it white.All that said, this is a great helmet. It does its job and there are lots of adjustments to make it fit perfect. I've only worn it a few hours but in that time had no hot spots. All the adjustments are obvious and easy - except the eyeball-to-glass distance that I didn't know was in there until I read the directions - and I still haven't messed with that adjustment, The distance is fine even with my eyeglasses.There's plenty of airflow too. No fogging. The forehead pad kinda buttons on three plastic posts and is easy to take out, ring out, and put back.

These are perfectly good medium duty trash bags. I compared them to kirkland kitchen bags, cheap 30ish gallon bags for outdoor bins, and my outdoor "contractor" bags.It isn't really fair to put these bags head-to-head against the contractor bags. Those bags are much thicker. The thicker bags are better at everything except expense. So, enough of that.Compared to the drawstring kitchen bags, the hefty steelsak is a bit thicker.First test - shoving in a finger until it pokes through. Both bags deformed about the same before bursting but the steelsak put up about twice the resistance. So, the steelsak will hold up better to sticks and stuff but will give way eventually.Second test - slashing with a knife. Surprisingly, both bags seemed the same. Similar slashing attempts either didn't cut through either or did cut through both. Once pierced, both bags had similar resistance to making the cut longer. I was impressed by both bags.Third test - knife slash against a cutting board. This test was mostly due to disbelief that the earlier slash test hadn't made long easy cuts. Similar results from both the kitchen bags and the steelsaks.Next came the cheap-sack. The cheap ones failed quickly. The didn't give much before getting finger-holed. The knife slashed through easily.Summary - the steelsaks and those kirkland kitchen bags are surprisingly good in comparison to those cheap bags I had sitting around. If I'm carrying trash in my car, I'm going to use those contractor bags -or- the steelsaks. I don't want a mess in my car. For yard waste, I'll compost. Also, if I were carrying bags of stuff any distance, like apartment dwellers would, I'd use a bag that probably won't burst or leak..

I'm an experienced multi-copter hobbyist and I'm impressed with this book. To be a bit more specific, I've owned numerous micro-quads, a Parrot AR drone 2.0, and have built a few 'copters too. I still learned a lot from this book. The only "constructive criticism" I can offer is that the book does not cover micro-copters like my favorites - the Blade Nano QX and its FPV (first person view) version, the Blade Nano QX FPV. These micro-copters are great for flying indoors and through the house. The book recommends against indoor flying. It's true that craft like the Parrot AR drone are hard to fly indoors - the prop wash makes for a very turbulent hallway, etc. But... micro-quads are great indoors and allow for quick flights every day without hassle.Over all, the book seems to suggest the Parrot AR Drone 2.0 or the DJI Phantom with GoPro. These are great choices for ready to fly quads. The book also covers care and fixing by pointing out that the devices should be inspected before and after each flight and even gives examples of pre-flight and post-flight checklists. Other kinds of flying craft are mentioned, such as fixed wing drones, but the book is really about multi-copters. The book does not really cover the repair budget. A new pilot should plan on spending at least half the price of the drone in first year repairs. In the case of a non-FPV micro-quad, they're cheap, plan to destroy a few. Also, the book doesn't mention that the manufacturers forums and online videos should be checked for "required" modifications. For example, the Parrot's landing gear really are fragile and that zip-tie modification is indispensable.There is a fair amount of text dedicated to not annoying others (being a "bonehead" - rhymes with drone head) and knowing and obeying the law. These are important issues. As for how current the book is, it discusses the FAA's proposed rules that issued in February 2015. So, that's great. Multi-copter technology has been evolving at an amazing pace over the past few years. It would appear that this book will become dated quickly, but there are big sections that will hold up well for at least a few years. For example, the proper ways to deal with batteries is unlikely to change. Nor will the parts on planning video shoots, taking care of the equipment, checklists, ...The parts that I found most eye opening and instructive had to do with cameras, video, and connecting socially with like minded pilots. Regarding cameras, the reasons for using a GoPro are well argued although I'm more of a mobius guy because my machines wreck gloriously and often. People more concerned with getting usable video and not crashing would probably prefer the GoPro. The book also covers way better cameras that can be used for taking great video but cost way more, weigh a lot more, and are for people with advanced budgets.On the subject of video, the tools for editing are listed and described. Most interestingly the book introduces some tools for removing camera jitter such as Youtube and Turbo Video Stabilizer for cheap and Adobe After Effects for not so cheap. The steps for getting that video out of a 'copter and into a computer are described, including getting video and images into a chromebook. Also, new to me, the Pixlr chromebook app can edit images. Interesting because the "Baseflight" chromebook app is a nice ground station and configuration tool for certain quad copter flight controllers.Another great section is the one covering using social media to meet other 'copter addicts. These are by far the most important resources for finding out how to deal with the problems that absolutely will crop up. Things like why your quad is flipping over instead of taking off. Also, the author mentions the glory of Youtube. I've spent untold hours watching 'copter how-to videos on Youtube. The book details using google groups, facebook, and manufacturers web sites to ask questions and connect with people - including observations that many of these forums are moderated and abusive/stupid posts won't stay online.To sum it up, this book is well done, timely, readable, and more informative than I could have ever dreamed of.

This is an economical nailer that is great for light work. It's construction quality is good, it's robust, and it does its job. This isn't the tool for laying flooring or putting in molding day after day. It's perfectly fine for remodeling the occasional room, assembling picture frames, hobby projects, that sort of thing.Notes: max PSI: 120 but I used 30-40 PSI to drive 5/8" - 1.5" brads.Oil: a drop into air connector, I used car engine oil because I had some at hand.Brads: 18 gauge, I used different lengths of the Hitachi ones from the big box store a mile away.First off - there's the issue of the manual and directions. They hardly exist and they aren't easy to find. I did not find them and I did google for them and did go to Arrow's the product page. This annoyed the heck out of me.The unit does require the occasional drop of oil and there will be an occasional very very light mist of oil that comes out with a nail. This is not a huge deal unless too much oil is put in. I put two drops of oil into the unit. This is where those instructions would be so useful for someone that's new to pneumatic nailers. How much oil (a drop now and then) and where to put it (right into the hole in the air connection).I tested this tool using Hitachi 18 gauge brads of various lengths and drove them into an old pine 2x6. The only way I found to adjust depth was by setting the pressure at the regulator. This can be a serious pain. It's easiest to start at low pressure and then move to higher pressures so that you don't have to bleed the air pressure out of the hose during between adjustments. It's almost impossible to set the depth to flush with the wood surface, but that really doesn't matter for most applications.You have to put the nailer into position and pull the trigger. You can't just pull the trigger and then bump along the work piece, driving a brad with each bump. Also, the cycle time is slow - probably because of the low pressure in the air hose.In summary, this tool will do the job but is best for small jobs. The better tools cost about three or four times as much, don't need oil, have depth adjustments, a faster cycle time, and can be bumped down the work piece.

Five stars because -other- people love it. I personally was shocked at how aromatic this body wash is. The entire bathroom was filled with a strong "mandarin and tiare flower" scent. It is not a manly scent and I was concerned that I would be carrying that scent for the rest of the day. I think the scent largely washed off because no one commented on it and I even asked a couple trusted advisers if I smelled perfumed.Other people, people without a Y chromosome, have review this body wash as follows: "It's nice <smile>".As for the body wash itself, it lathered up nicely, rinsed off, and definitely moisturized. It's not that big a deal for me in the summer (as I write this) but I do dry out during the winter. I'll see if dove has a less scented body wash.A note on body washes - I use them exclusively at home and keep the bathrooms stocked with them because bar soap builds up on the shower walls. My showers haven't had a soap scum in over five years since I switched to body washes.

This review is for the Belkin Conserve Insight Energy Use Monitor (F7C005). I gave five stars because it works well doing what it promises to do. It measures the power being consumed by a device, keeps a record, and will even calculate cost. Pretty simple stuff. There are lots of times that I've wanted this exact functionality.But... I ran into a problem because I'm adding brains to my house. What I really wanted is the Belkin WeMo F7C029fc because it can communicate with my Echo and because it lets me switch the power on and off. Note to Belkin folks - I'd really like a WeMo power monitor that absolutely can never switch off the power. I don't mean a selection or a checkbox "disable switch" option. I mean no dang switch at all. Just a power monitor and nothing more.Anyways, I tried this device out in a number of locations. It is currently monitoring my refrigerator because I do not want to be able to remotely turn off the fridge. The monitor is likely to remain there for a long time because it is a pain to get access to that outlet behind the fridge.To summarize, this is a great little monitor and it is really useful for checking out what kind of power is being pulled by different devices. But it doesn't have WiFi or bluetooth or anything like that.

Good stuff. It is faithfully mounting the control board on a quadcopter. The receiver is still unmoved after a few wrecks.This tape did peel off the quad and receiver while I was repositioning stuff to get it right. No damage from that.This two sided foam tape is better for this use than regular two sided tape because the foam gives way a little where surfaces aren't perfectly flat.I didn't use hook & loop, like velcro, because velcro lets the control board move around too much which confuses the gyros.

One of the ones that originally came wit my glasses broke. These were a drop-in replacement. They are more comfortable, my glasses feel lighter for some reason, and my glasses don't slip of my face as easily.Wish I'd bough these earlier.

This is an interesting gadget that I've been slowly using more and more. The key seems to be my own laziness.After the initial play time ("Alexa, what's phrenology?") Echo sat there ignored. Then I wanted to know the time without shifting my lazy butt. ("Alexa, what time is it?"). Later it was "alexa, how's the weather." Then it was "Alexa, set an alarm for...".Basically, I've been asking Alexa for stuff when I don't feel like reaching for a phone/tablet, lifting a finger, or even looking over at a clock.So, far, so good. The more I ask, the more it does. Maybe I'll even buy some devices for it to control.The phone app is pretty good. Also pretty amusing. When I was going through old voice queries the tablet played the recording and the echo responded to the recording.

It's an odd little device. It -does not- look like the fire tv remote in that the echo remote doesn't have buttons under the round thing.It does work. Lack of a speaker makes it weird because you talk to it and then hear the echo talking back from the other room.Other than that, it's like talking to the echo.On the fire remote is for moving around in menus and stuff. I have no idea what it does for the echo. Maybe if it did something it would be a nice addition. For now, I don't have a lot of use for the remote because the communication with the echo is one way, unless your close enough to hear the echo, in which case you don't need the remote.My opinion is subject to change as I keep messing around with the echo.

This is the brightest flashlight I, or anyone I know, has ever seen. A few years ago I started using a StreamLight tactical flashlight because it lights up the night way better than the normal LED flashlights I have sitting all over the place.This flashlight makes my tactical flashlight look like a candle. It lights up my hallway better than the ceiling lights. The dog absolutely can’t hide in the backyard at night because this flashlight is too good.The heart(s) of the flashlight are some Cree high brightness LEDs and two of the most amazing rechargeable batteries. I fly electric quadcopters and am careful to get great batteries. The flashlight batteries are lighter and with higher capacity than any of my quadcopter batteries.For testing, I filled a bin with water - about two feet deep. I turned on the flashlight, tossed it in the bin, and walked away when nothing exploded or shorted out. I monitored it with an action cam set to take a time lapse video. The flashlight stayed lit for 40 hours, 6 minutes. It was immersed the whole time. I’m not kidding. It was that long. Maybe the battery’s newness made some magic. Also, the flashlight has three continuous light settings and one strobe setting. The test was at the lowest continuous setting - which is still pretty darn bright.Next test was the same but with the flashlight at its brightest. It lasted 2 hours, 8 minutes after  full recharge. It was immersed the whole time.No I don’t have the recharge times. Also, no water ever made its way into the flashlight.If there’s anything negative about this flashlight, it’s that it takes some fussing to screw the end back on after the recharging/reinstalling the batteries. It takes a bit to get the threads lined up or something, but isn’t exactly a big deal. Maybe its all the O-rings. I think there are three O-rings sitting in three grooves. The flashlight comes with some spare O-rings that haven’t been needed yet.

I have a love hate relationship with the Cuisinart brand. Many of their products are outstanding but others are just sort of “meh” and not worth the extra paid for the label. This machine is astonishing. I like it almost as much as my Cuisinart immersion blender that has seen almost daily use for at least five years. This machine is so capable that it might see a similar level of use.First impression - this thing is huge and the base is heavy. It dwarfs my “normal” food processor. The first thing I tried was … hummus. Hummus is not a challenge to any food processor. The motor spun with authority and the chickpeas and stuff turned into hummus in the 4.5 cup work bowl. No surprises, normal clean-up.Regarding the accessory case - at first I was annoyed by the accessory case because I really like to keep my counters clear. The accessory case seemed like just more counter clutter. In like the accessory case now because it actually saves me some space and danger. It saves me some danger because my old food processor blades are loose in a drawer and they’re sharp and they’re oddly shaped. Now that I think about it, I’m lucky no house guest has been cut rummaging in that drawer. The accessory case now lives in a cupboard where the old food processor used to be.Next up was bread using a recipe from the booklet that came with the machine. Yes, this machine kneads bread. However… I also have a nice KitchenAid mixer with bread hooks. Based on the clean-up, I’ll probably use the mixer when only making bread and the food processor for more involved projects. Such as…Chicken pot pie, again using the recipe from the Cuisinart booklet. This is a fun recipe because the outcome is tasty and because it engages more aspects of the machine because it calls for the buttermilk biscuits in a different recipe. The machine simply worked. Cleanup was as expected. Food was great.The chopping blade is really cool because it is adjustable. This is really nice for fried zucchini because I’ve never been happy with the slice thicknesses the the old food processor could make with its non-adjustable blades. Very nice - one adjustable device replacing a few others.None of my tests had put any stress on this beastly machine so I decided to use it to make venison burger out of a “roast” that needed eaten. The ingredients were large chunks of mostly thawed venison and large chunks of mostly thawed pork fat (yes, I’m a dietary philistine). This is a tough task, but this Cuisinart machine did the job in a very workmanlike manner and in way less than a minute.The summary is that this is an amazing and beastly food processor. It is a vast improvement over any other food processor that I've ever used.

This thermometer meets expectations without drama. Most of all, it has the temperature guide printed inside the dial is great. Sure, I have a temperature guide stuck to the fridge, but this puts the information I need where I need it. The silicone dial backing is a thin piece of silicone that is surprisingly nice. This style of meat thermometer tends to get a hot dial because the housing is all metal. That little silicone covering probably saved me from grabbing hot metal.All that said, and as other reviewers have noted, it ain't perfect.No, it isn't super easy to read. It isn't hard to read either. I had to think for a few seconds because the dial could be more intuitive. Such is life.The description incorrectly says that this device gives quick readings. Could be quicker. If the meat chunk is big enough, I'll leave the thermometer stuck in it.As for build quality, who knows. I doubt Cuisinart built a factory for these devices and suspect that they went to one of the many manufacturers and asked "how much to get our branding inside that dial?"Then there's the sleeve. Actually, a tube with a metal clip. I guess it's for protecting the probe from other stuff in the drawer this thing lives in. I'm not sure why, but what the heck. Maybe it solves a problem other people have.  I'll try not to lose the tube.All in all, this is a meat thermometer that, functionally, is like just about every other meat thermometer. I like it because it has that temperature guide right there inside, a silicone thing that helps keep me from burning my fingers, and that sleeve. Hmmm, that sleeve. dunno about that sleeve yet.

There are no spoilers in this review because anything specific in the review happens within the first few chapters -or- is intentionally obfuscated. This is a really fun book to read. I read it in three sittings (I read slowly) and would have read it in one if I’d indulged myself.This is an odd story with the Jedi order flirting with edge of darkness and the human toll that they pay.The main characters are Asajj Ventress and Quinlan Vos. What’s great is that this book does so much to develop the characters. Vos is so very much a Jedi and he’s tasked with a very un-Jedi mission that has him twisting and turning to justify his actions. Ventress is … Ventress. Many of us are familiar with her from the “Clone Wars” series. We kind of know her back story, but we don’t know her. This book brings her into focus.There is plenty of action and the story has a very Star Wars feel. You can almost hear the voices and see the action with the blaster bolts flying and the narrow escapes. Actually, something that was a little … different was the battle droids saying “roger” instead of “roger roger.” For some reason, I always imagine them saying “roger roger.” As further credit to the author, even the battle droids come to life with their silly reactions and statements.All-in-all, this is a very good Star Wars story and would be very good on screen. But… there are things you can only get from a book and that’s what makes this book worth reading. Books are better at putting the reader in the characters’ heads. You get a better sense of what is bothering Obi-Wan about Vos’ mission and the way things are playing out. Heck, you even get a better understanding of how Dooku twists people around like he did with Ventress when she was his apprentice.After finishing this book I rewatched Dooku lose his head in Revenge of the Sith. Very satisfying. I also hope the Night Sisters have a come back. They seem not-so-bad now.

These little helping hands things have been a workshop staple for decades. That's because they work and are fairly cheap.This device is certainly not great. It annoys me in some way every time I use it because there are so many possible improvements. But this thing is inexpensive and is a little life saver.Most obvious improvements - wider base because this thing is tippy. The alligator clips should slide along the bar.One of my alligator clips falls off because of a crappy crimp connection. I still use these things all the time.

What's to say. It's an x-box one (xbone).It's louder than the xbox 360. That can be annoying when I let it annoy me. The Wifi works well - I am not using a wired connection.My main uses are netflix, youtube, and watching 3D movies. It does these things nicely and I'm pretty happy about that.As for the call of duty game. The single player mission is mostly fun. Lots of fun. No need to describe it here because, if you're curious, go look at the run-throughs on youtube. I do get annoyed with those parts of the story line where you just mash a button as fast as you can.
