Boring.Other than that, this is call of duty. Need I say more?I will be adding a kinect and stuff. Sometime. When the content makes me really want to add a kinect. has yet to happen...

It is busily danging a projector from my ceiling. I installed this thing about 6 months ago and then forgot it. That's a good thing because it means the mount has been doing its job and not giving me hassle.There are lots of pieces and it's a good idea to follow the instructions. This is especially so for the bottom part that attaches to the projector. All the pieces I needed for hanging a projector off the ceiling were included.There are lots of rotating and angling about adjustments that make it easy to aim the projector at whatever is being used as a screen. That said, you want to mount everything square anyway to avoid tombstoning the view. Sure, the projector can adjust for it but everything just works and looks better if the projector is square to the screen.As for the quality of the mount itself. It is a fine hunk of metal. Mu ceiling joist will break before this this mount gives way.

I bought this for the 3D - wanted to see how well a HD projector handled 3D.With this movie, 3D has finally come of age. In the past, the 3D aspects were kind of in your face and took you out of the action. In this movie, the 3D adds to the action and becomes a part of the story.As for the story - there are lots of reviews breathlessly recapping the story line. No need to waste my time typing in yet another plot review.The story is impressive though. The broad strokes being the time shifting alien race that is unstoppable and one man ending up as the counter. Normally, such a story would be told from a general's viewpoint with some grunt level action tossed in for excitement. Not here. It's all grunt level but this grunt has to win the war.

I bought this so I could get used to flying the nano qx before flying the nano qx FPV. This little quad is amazingly well engineered.Regarding the prop guards - those little bits of plastic that look like silly attempts at guarding the prop. They work. They work very well. The only issue with them is that they can snag things that the quad runs into. Really not a big deal.It was a little bit of a hassle to pair this with the transmitter that came with the nano qx fpv. It was even more of a hassle to pair that transmitter back with the nan qx fpv. I upgraded the transmitter to a Taranis X9D and all those problems are a thing of the past. Pairing is fast and easy. Also, the nano qx seems to fly a lot more smoothly and predictable with the Taranis X9D.As for flying this little quad. It is pure joy. It is very responsive while being easy to control. I fly it indoors a lot and try racing it under tables, through chairs, over ceiling fans, etc. Lots of wrecks because I am trying to go fast but it is amazing how easy it is to bring this thing back to a hover.It's hard to say what the range is because the range depends more on the transmitter and I have upgraded to a pretty good one. I regularly fly this quad 100 feet away. It's hard to see and control at that distance, being tiny, but is still under control.

Lots of functional connectors at a great price. What's not to love.The only odd thing is that the solder cups on the solder ends of the female connectors aren't as deep as you'd think. That little hole in the side does not go into the solder cup as expected.Regardless, the solder cups are deep enough and soldering really isn't an issue.  Especially once the connector and solder joint are shrink wrapped.Five stars for function without drama.

Great strap for its price. This is definitely an economy model.First off, it works exactly as it is supposed to. The pick pocket is OK while playing but doesn't retain picks when the guitar is being carried and the strap is just hanging. In other words - don't trust it to hold spare picks between sessions.The strap material is sturdy and the buckles seem rugged enough. The ends fit onto the guitar without drama and have stayed on reliably.Returning to that strap material, it is nylon webbing and it is some serious strong stuff. However... it being summer I'm often playing without a shirt. I have other straps that are a lot more comfortable for shirtless playing. Not that this one bothers me. I don't even notice it once I start playing. It just feels a bit rough at first.

Very light, good power. Corded is great because the battery powered ones run out of juice, batteries are heavy,  and that battery is going to give out in a year or two.My gas mower wouldn't start. I chose to buy this one instead of dealing with getting the gas one fixed. I may have saved money.I grew up using an electric mower, so it doesn't seem odd at all to trail a cord and avoid running over it. The mower itself is really light. I mow some areas with a one handed back and forth motion as if I were vacuuming a rug.The lawn had gotten rather long and ratty with the gas mower broken. This mower had to wade through grass that was 10" high in places. It did fine. There were a places where it bogged down and even stopped the mower blade. No problem. Back out and ease in and the blade did its job.If I were to change anything, I'd get rid of the the wheel height linkages. I'm capable of setting all four wheels individually. The linkages make it easier but are a pain to clean around. That's the other change - make it easier to sweep the mower clean with a bench brush. Not a big deal, but little improvements make for great products. As it is, this mower is already pretty great. Inexpensive, powerful enough, light, and gets the job done.

It arrived as a well set up and ready to play instrument. Just a bit of tuning required. It has held its tune for the month or so I've had it even though the weather (humidity and temp) have been all over the place. I did replace the strings, mostly to try out the other strings.Confession - I mostly bought this to play the bass tracks in rocksmith. Getting a five string was a mistake because everything bass in rocksmith is for a four string. Such is life. I held the B string at the fifth fret to tune using the rocksmith tuner. Since then, that string is all but ignored.As for quality - this thing is great. I think it is difficult to get a crappy instrument from a brand manufacturer these days. The build quality is good, the fit and finish are good, the fretboard is flat. There are no weird buzzes or thunks that aren't my fault.The stock strings are fine and would still be one the bass -except- that I had some Elixers that I wanted to try. The Elixers are smoother, a bit easier to play, and have less finger noise than the stock strings. I guess that the Elixer strings are an upgrade and I'm glad I put them on. That said, I'd be perfectly happy with the stock strings if they were still on there.The tuners are fine. I was worried at first that they would have backlash or something because this bass is so inexpensive. Nope. No backlash.I doubt I'll be upgrading this bass within the next few years. There are more expensive one out there, but this one does the job perfectly well.

I really enjoyed this book. I probably brought a lot of background to it though because I play eve online. As such, the ships and the way things happened made sense to me. That said, there have been a number of changes to eve game play that make aspects of this book somewhat nostalgic. Regardless, great story.What I most liked is how the different races were presented. The book starts with various Amarr but then moves through the other races. So many possible spoilers...Lets just say that most aspects of hi-sec game play get some attention. That and the Jove seem to be waiting in the wings. And the eve gate plays a role.No drifters though. or seekers.I did not actually read this book while playing eve. I just sat down and read it. Maybe I should have logged in my hi-sec mining alts. Next time.

Super versatile. This is a great pedal for anyone trying to figure out what pedals are for because it can do an amazing number of different things. Also, at its price, there really is little fear of messing it up. If you break it, get another. When I got it I spent hours playing with the settings and probably had a huge grin the whole time.At first, I was disappointed with the instructions. The fact is, this is a pedal. Plug in and play. Then play around some more. Then take a break and watch some of the videos online with guys playing with pedals. Most of all, just play around and see what you like. The thing about the instructions is that you can write books about setting up pedals and even then a book can't pick a string or finger a fret. Plugging in is the only way to really learn. Just keep in mind that this is an inexpensive little pedal and not an effects cabinet. Keep it simple, be happy.I bought this thing so that I could easily switch to e flat tuning from e standard. I think I had it worked out but didn't write it down and then messed it up and haven't tried again. I should have set it and the dripped on some wax or hot glue or something to lock the knobs in place. For now, it's easier to just tune the guitar. Maybe with practice it'll be easier to set up the pedal than tune the guitar. Maybe I'll use something else that specializes in pitch shifting. Someday.Other reviewer's have commented on the plastic body and said it seemed fragile. It survived the heel of a boot from a 180lb man.Other reviewers complained about noise. Mine seemed noisy at first but I think I was jacked into it weird. No problems after the first few minutes.That LED that says the pedal is on - it is bright as hell.Someone said the thing doesn't have true bypass. That isn't my experience. Maybe that reviewer had it set up different. Who knows.Someone complained about lag. I dunno. Maybe I'm just starting the phrases a little sooner. What I do know about lag comes from playing rocksmith. Rocksmith can have a weird lag when the audio is going through HDMI because some TVs are slow at decoding. There, the sounds goes guitar -> pedal -> rocksmith cable -> PS3 -> (HDMI) -> TV. The biggest lag seems to be at the HDMI step. That's probably why ubisoft suggests using the audio outs and staying analog.In summary, this is a great pedal because it can do so very many different things and gives you a feel for what you really want. Then, once you know what you want, keep a few of these around because they are so versatile. Frankly, I think I'll have at least one of these pedals sitting around or in use for the next few years.

This apron garnered a lot of compliments. It is rather cute and the extra long sash makes for a stupendously big bow. The colors are a really good match for the University of Washington and some U of W alums gave it full approval.As for quality, the fabric is good and the stitching is error free. The pocket is OK, somewhat useful and at least there is a pocket. Besides, this is a cute apron to where during a party (or tailgating U of W). If you want pure utility with big pockets, then this ain't for you.Usually, I'd end the review with how I'd change the product to improve it for my uses. The only things I can think of is that there are other materials that are more stain resistant. Those materials would make for a far more expensive garment though.

These are some nice bass strings. I used them to replace the original strings that came on a nearly new fender squire bass. The Elixir strings are certainly better. They are smoother and faster and a nice little upgrade.I recently reviewed the stainless steel Elixir bass strings. Here, repeated, is what I wrote about the nanoweb: The folks behind these strings are the same as those behind those gore-tex fabrics and that the slick PTFE dental floss (Glide?). The nanoweb is probably similar technology. That means that these strings will probably stay smooth a long time and shouldn't get crusty or anything as easily. They should also be easier to clean because of that coating.So, nickel or stainless? There is lots of discussion and disagreement about what is better – stainless or nickel plated. For me, the best strings are the ones I have on hand. I play what I have and am not that particular. When buying Elixir strings with nanoweb, I'll reach for the stainless ones because I rarely play straight into an amp and, even then, the amp has adjustable filters. It’s easier to mix the pluckier stainless to make it sound like the warmer nickel than it is to make nickel sound like stainless. Also, the nanoweb does a lot of what the nickel plating is for. The nanoweb makes the strings smooth and fast and also helps keep them from getting rusty and crusty. In other words, I think the nanoweb takes the place of the nickel plating without also smoothing out the sound as much.Regardless of all that, these are very good strings. They will probably stay on that bass for at least a year. They will probably get replaced with stainless Elixir strings.

Amazingly, this thing works. Who would’ve thunk that a hole in the bottom and a little stopper thing would work so well? This thing actually exceeds expectations.OK, wonderment aside, this makes sense. Chemists have used separation columns for centuries. Brewers have special vats with angled bottoms leading to a valve. This separator does the same thing but without the industrial niceties.Other than just working, the other niceties are the mesh at the top for catching the chunk and the baster. The baster brush is great because it works and is silicone and I love silicone kitchen gadgetry. The baster’s “shower” attachment is good because it provides good coverage, is faster to use than the baster brush, and doesn’t contact whatever is being basted.If I were to improve it… I’d make it easier to clean, I’d adapt the bottom to have at least a few degrees of slope toward the hole, and the hole plug would have a better plugging material (silicone?).Regardless, this thing works and gets five stars for doing its job without drama or weirdness.

Like the other vine reviewers, I received the “T4U” instead of the “T4UH’ – in other words, I got the USB stick instead of the version with the fold out antennas. Normally I’d be pis<dle><del><del> nonplussed, but I didn’t actually pay for this review sample. As such, I’ll just review what I got.So – why would anyone even buy a WiFi dongle these days when just about everything comes with internal WiFi?Firstly – there’s that desktop with a wire running to it. It would be nice to move that thing without running a new wire.Secondly – range. This dongle has pretty good range when coupled with some wariness. It comes with a USB 3 cable which is great because the dongle can be placed up high to get better signal and range. That said, this dongle is big enough that most people won’t want to plug it straight into their computer. My personal plan for this dongle it to stick it high on a boat mast to better reach lake shore WiFi access. Note: this involves shrink wrap to protect the connection between USB 3 cable and dongle.Third – speed. This thing is fast. It’s way faster than most internal WiFi, at least for now.Over all, this WiFi dongle does its job well and completely meets expectations. Five stars for that. However… if I had to buy such a device I’d get one that connects via a CAT6 network cable instead of USB 3. There are trade-offs. CAT6 means (most likely) a wall wart and power cords but should have setup via a browser. Setup via a browser is a big plus for me. Meanwhile, this USB 3 device doesn’t require external power. As for which is more secure – who knows.Finally, I’ve been really happy with TP-Link devices lately. They seem more engineering oriented whereas Linksys and Netgear seem to have become marketing centric. Hopefully TP-Link stays the course.

Review -Jungle of Snakes – James Arnold“Jungle of Snakes: A Century of Counterinsurgency Warfare from the Phllippines to Iraq” by James Arnold is a well written commentary on four insurgencies:  The Philippines by USA 1898-1904,  Algeria by the French 1950's, Malaysia by the British 1950's and Vietnam again by the USA 1960's.  The author states in the “Acknowledgments”  that his book grew out of discussions “about relevant military history about America's ongoing counterinsurgency operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.”  To this end the four insurrections are evaluated in terms of security, local conditions, preparations by the invading country, commitment, weapons, language, home support, capacity to recruit insurgents, pacification and country rebuilding techniques, goals of the conquerers, and information and communications, use of torture, and cohesion of the aims and methods of the conquerers.  It becomes obvious midway through the book, and frankly stated in the Vietnam section that the author comes down squarely with Gen Petraus and against Gen Westmoreland in the long standing disagreement about the roles of the army and other US military in any insurgency and counterinsurgency.In the Vietnam section and the conclusions section, the author makes frequent reference to the 1940 “Small Wars Manual” of the US Marine Corp and decries that its lessons had to be relearned from scratch as it had been forgotten.The book is well written, an entertaining read, informative as to neglected facts of the four insurgencies, and clear in its arguments as to why Gen Petraus was right.  There are few diagrams, and no pictures, but these would have been superfluous.I am left with the suspicion that the histories are told selectively to make the author's points.  Many points are made by focusing in on examples of pacification attempts and anecdotal evidence.I strongly recommend this book to students of counterinsurgency history as its points are well made and well taken.  But an eye needs to be kept out for prejudgements and selective history telling.  The arguments as to the tactics and strategy, i.e. the purpose and uses of the armies,  to achieve the goals of the conquering nations need to be understood and kept in mind as this book is read.FYI there are minimal references to Iraq and Afghanistan in spite of the reference made in the “Acknowledgments,” that this book is to prepare the reader to understand military history that applies to both.

Review – Learn to Play Go:  A Master's Guide to the Ultimate Game”This book is the first volume to a 5 volume set by Janice Kim and Jeong Soo-hyun, both masters of the game.  It is written as an introduction to the game and is intended to enable a player to play at the most basic levels of the game Go.  It succeeds very well.  I do not feel ready to go out and play tournaments, but I could play simple games.The Game of Go has very simple rules.  But the strategy and tactics are extremely complicated.  While computers can beat the world champion chess players, they can only play the very elementary levels of Go.The book has been carefully formatted with very many board examples of the game.  The writing is clear and easy to understand.  The levels of complexity have been kept to a minimum, with more to come in the remaining four volumes of the series.  And while deep study is needed to master the game, this book enables the English speaking American to at least start to play.After reviewing several other books on Go, I decided to try this series by Janice Kim.  I am glad I chose Kim's books.  This is an excellent introduction to the Game of Go.  I look forward to reading and working my way through the rest of the series.

Review The Phoenicians“The Phoenicians” from Charles River Editors is a good, but brief review of what little is know about the culture we know as Phoenicians.  They did not leave much in the way of writings or cities or other artifacts.  In spite of their basic first use of a phonetic alphabet, not much is known about them other than the writings in the Egyptian and Greek material.  Their precise origin is unknown.  They seem to be related to the Canaanites and the ancient Hebrews, at least by language.  They traveled and traded widely, establishing colonies cross the entire Mediterranean World.  Their colonies were especially on the west end of the Mediterranean Sea.  Carthage was one of their early colonies, but soon became more or less it's own city.They interacted with the Egyptians and the Babylonians and the Greeks.  In fact the name we use for them is Greek, and not their own.  The Sea People did not seem to bother them much, in spite of wreaking havoc  all around them.  The Phoenician Culture mostly disappeared after Alexander the Great defeated them.The book is brief, but well written.  It is easily read in under two hours.  Like most of the Charles River Editor books, it only claims to be a brief introduction to the culture. In that it succeeds very well.For some looking for a quick overview of the Phoenician History, this is quite good.  And I am not sure how much more is actually known.  More is known of Carthage, but even there our modern knowledge is sketchy.  Off one star for its brevity.

Review Metabolic Conditioning: Rapid Fat Loss and Enhanced Athletic Performance Using Metabolic Training Techniques (Metabolic Conditioning and Rapid Weight Loss Book 1) [Kindle Edition]Jason Rook (Author)“Metabolic Conditioning” by Jason Rook is a small book that well and competently explains the High Intensity Training technique.  Jason starts with the three basic energy production systems in the body.  With these Jason ventures into examples of the various exercises that challenge each.  Then Jason develops an approach to using these in exercise to both lose weight and to gain in athletic performance.  Ending with demonstrations of the tabata technique and basic instructions in how to apply tabata, Jason ends the book with sample workouts.  The intent of the book is for the reader to develop his/her own workouts based on the principles presented.  The book will make an individual able to develop workouts in line with the principles.The book is not technical, or medical, but very practical in its approach. Jargon is avoided. However,  this is not a book for the beginner exerciser, as one must know and understand the exercise repertoire to follow the book and to insert a variety of exercises into the principles.For an fitness buff, this is an easy approach to a very complicated topic all too often presented with all the details and jargon.

Review – Planet of the Bugs by Scott Richard Shaw“Planet of the Bugs” is the story of the evolution of insects from the first one celled creatures to the modern era.  The sweep is vast.  The story is excitingly told.  Scattered throughout are pictures of fossilized insects.The writing style is clear and easily read.  The Kindle version is well formatted.  The viewpoint is very pro-bug.  The actual text is only 60% of the book.  The remainder of the book is the notes.Dr. Shaw claims along with several other entomologists, who Dr.Shaw quotes, that this is really a planet on which the insects have been  far more successful in terms of number of species, genii, orders, in terms of sheer mass and sheer numbers, than any other living organism on Earth.  Dr. Shaw clearly shows us how the insects have survived through two of Earth's five major extinctions.  And he discusses that the insect will most likely survive the 6th Extinction as long as it is not too drastic.  Thus, if we were not so biased, we should call Earth, the Planet of the Bugs.Dr. Shaw freely and with familarity discusses the pressures that drive evolution.  It is Dr. Shaw's intent to demonstrate how the pressures of the climate and changes in the climate have driven the changes in the insects that have occurred over the last 250 million years.Dr. Shaw also chides us on ignoring the already underway 6th Extinction, the Extinction of Biodiversity.  He mentions global warming, but feels that the loss of life's multitudinous forms is the real 6th Extinction.The only drawback to this book is the necessary use of technical terms  They are all well explained in the text.  The thus named concepts are all necessary to understand the evolution of the insects.  And without dumbing down an excellent book, could not have been avoided.For anyone with  more than a passing interest in insects and the modes of evolution, this is an excellent book.

A two volume work on Emergency Medicine, well good enough for emergency medicine residents, and clearly enough worded for paramedics and their mentors and medical directors.  One volume is on clinical aspects and one volume is on administrative aspects of emergency medicine, including paramedic programs.  While this is called the first edition, NAEMS put out a similar book several years.  That book was unfocused.  David Cone of NAEMSP has resolved all the issues with the first book, and produced what will remain the standard in the field for many years.Highly recommended for all paramedic medical directors and mentors, and for all emergency room libraries.

Review – Seven Things You Must Know Before You Leave Your House With Your GunThis is an excellent little book.  It is not the definitive text on concealed carry, but an excellent refresher for the individual who is carrying a weapon concealed, legally.  It is from the people at Concealed Carry Magazine, including Patrick Kilchermann of the Concealed Carry Association.Covered in quite some detail are 1) the mindset of the individual who is carrying.  It is not “when can I shoot?”  but “When must I shoot?”  2)  Retention devices on the holster.  3)  The ten second rule of dying.  4)  live fire drills  5)  one hand out of commission shooting.  Not covered are gun choices and holster choices, although there are some recommendations and state by state law differences.  There is a whole chapter strongly recommending “Self-Defense Shield” insurance, which includes strong language on why it is needed.The book is a compilation of several outstanding authors in the field including Kilcherman, Don Stahlnecker, Kevin Michalowski, sArmando Basulto, Tim Schmidt, and Massad Ayoob.While not a textbook for the individual in the first concealed permit class, this is a useful little book expressing very well several important concepts in the concealed carry world.  I recommend it strongly for someone who does not regularly read Concealed Carry Magazine and is carrying, even if on a part time basis.

Review – Explosive Calisthenics by Paul Wade“Explosive Calisthenics” by Paul Wade is a tour de force.  This is the same design as Paul Wade's tremendous book, “Convict Conditioning I.”  Paul has chosen 6 calisthenic movements – jumps, power pushups, kip-ups, forward rotations, backward rotations, up and over the bar and lays out excellent progressions to master each of these.  He intends for these to be mastered one at a time, in sequence, each laying the strength, power, and skill to achieve the next.  And yes, these progressions include forward and backward flips and muscle ups.  Along the way through the progressions are many variations of each.Paul lays out the best breakdown of the differences between power and skill training I have ever seen.  Some would say Paul even belabors this point.  But the approach to skill learning (kips, flips, muscle ups) is so different from power learning (pushups, pullups, squats, bridges, leg raises) that this is critical to understand and practice.  Paul carefully explains in good, plain English the facts of skill learning and how it differs from power learning.  He makes the process of skill learning very, very clear.This is a book that any coach, or self teaching athlete, needs to sit down and read clear through, page for page before starting on any activities in the book.  Paul does not give numbers for accomplishing each level as he did in “Convict Conditioning I.”  He lays out the acronym PARC (see book) for recognizing when the athlete is ready for the next step.  This is much more subjective and difficult than getting numbers of reps and sets.  But both the coach and the lone athlete will be able to clearly know when it is time to move up.  Paul also makes suggestions for recognizing when more basic work is needed to move up.  This approach will minimize injury and burnout in the programs.  Paul repeats this concept over and over, and with good reason.  These are dangerous moves in which serious injuries and death have occurred.To begin the activities in this book, Paul states that an athlete should have mastered at least levels 5 or 6 (except handstand pushups) in “Convict Conditioning I.” He will need the power and strength of those levels to safely achieve anything beyond the jumps and the earlier power pushups in this book.  Even with this prerequisite, I suspect it will take most athletes a year or more to progress clear through the progressions in this book.  In my opinion, the athlete should have mastered levels 8 to 10 of the work in “Convict Conditioning I” before beginning the kips and rotational moves in this book.Also included are multiple small space drills for each of the progressions, and wonderful bonus sections that will enrich and improve any man's workouts.While the language is a bit on the rough side, it is nothing beyond what can be expected in a heavily male gym or used by 15+ year olds among themselves.  Gone are the name calling and extremely imaginative vulgarities that marred “C-Mass.”“Explosive Calisthenics” reads well.  The language is clear and explicit in its directions.  The pictures are well done, and illustrative of the skills.  The book is intended to be used.  While beautiful, very well designed and laid out, it is not the coffee table production of some other Dragon Door books.  This book is good enough to buy the paperback.  I feel it is well worth purchasing the actual paperback as opposed to the ebook.

Review – Kettlebell Long Cycle Training Douglas Seamans Jr.“Kettlebell Long Cycle Training:  A 6 week Progressive Training Program for Long Cycle Competition”  is almost exactly as advertised.  This is guide to doing well at kettlebell long cycle competitions  This is not a book for beginners in Kettlebells or strength conditioning.  Actually this is a 12 week program laid out in detail with lots of hints and suggestions for someone who is quite fit to do well in kettlebell long cycle competitions.  The program is 6 heavy days per week, with three days on the KB and 3 days on general physical preparation, and sport specific preparation and some long slow cardio.Douglas gives us lots of hints at focus, alignment, bounce, fixation, wobble, drift and fast drop.  Douglas outlines his personal warmup for both practice and competition.  Douglas has tips on handling the pre-competition week, the competition day.The instructions for the program are clear and well done.  Douglas has even attached a training schedule for you to print out and mark your progress.  But you are expected to know and be able to perform KB exercises and many other exercises.  Douglas even recommends having a personal coach/ trainer in KB.  Yes, there are many suggestions as to form in the book, but Douglas suggests a KB coach.The first day of the program is 10-15 decline pushups, 5-10 pullups (or reverse rows) finishing with 10 minute run or row OR combat spot such as bag work.  The program goes up appropriately from there for accomplishing as many reps as possible of long cycle kettlebell in ten minutes.  The program is intense as it needs to be.  There is some motivation material included, but also realism as to reality of training at this level.If KB long cycle competitions are your game, this is an excellent guide to preparing for them.Disclaimer:  While I have used KB's in conditioning, I personally have not competed in long cycle competitions.

Review – Average Joe's Guide to Old School Strength & Fat Loss“Average Joe's Guide to Old School Strength & Fat Loss” is a fascinating little book.  By admission of the author Gerry Magree, it contains nothing new.  But it contains a good old fashioned common sense approach to both eating and strength building. The mantra throughout the book is “Eat Clean, Lift Heavy.”The tone of the book is conversational and friendly.  Be warned, the humor is light British. My ebook  copy is well formatted and easily read.  Gerry Magree lays the onus of getting lean and strong on the reader / athlete.  He is giving you a good method to get both, but expects you to lay out effort and time to get lean and strong.About a third of the book is diet information and recipes.  This is not paleo, but common sense eating.  Lots of protein, Put your carbs into the evening.  Avoid beer and pizza and fast food and manufactured food.  Eat “natural.”  It makes sense.  Gerry repeatedly states that you can go off diet, but there will be consequences.The strength portions of the book are based on old principles – squats, pullup ladders, bench presses.  Gerry throws in some barbell curls and a few other exercises, saying “you are going to do these anyway.”  The instructions and pictures are well done, clear giving the reader an appreciation and knowledge for what is expected.Will the experienced athlete / strong man gain much from this book.  No.  But this book is for the “average Joe” off the street, who wanders into a strength gym and wants to get lean and strong.  For that person, this book is right on.

Review - Julio Bocca Birdy y otrosAgain, Julio presents a wonderfully danced, imaginative program of ballet.In "Birdy" Julio is both a bird and a person captivated by birds.  The dancing is very well done.  The settings and nearly bare stages are imaginative.  Having the "Eagle" fly out of a book that opens in the "fly" of the stage is amazing.Concertango is a dancing of a concerto with the Julio and a cast of 12.  Imaginative dancing well done, beautiful.The surprise piece is the "Llanto por la muerte de Ignacio Sanchez Mejias."  I am sorry that I do not understand Spanish to better understand and explain this piece.  An elder man gives a very dramatic recitative.  Julio dances grief, encouragement, motivation, defiance, appreciation and acceptance to just the human voice of the man reciting this poem.  It is a piece d'art, amazing in itself, even with not knowing what the man is saying.This is the merging of ballet and modern ballet by an imaginative and excellent dancer.  Tall, lanky Julio moves with ease and grace.  His ensemble likewise is talented and dances well.  The emphasis is on the dancing.  Well worth a watch.  Julio has run his dance group in Argentina and can be easily overlooked by those concentrating on the North America, Europe and Russian dancers.  Julio and his group are well worth a look.  Julio Bocca, now past 40 has semi retired but has left a legacy of good work worth picking up on the occasional DVD, several available on Amazon.

Review – The Natural Method: A Practical Guide of Physical Education Hebert trans Phillippe TilAs near as I can tell, this little book was first published in 1909 in French.  It is directions on establishing a physical education program for male youth 8 – 18.  The original author spent years in the field teaching physical education.  The Method comprises a “Basics” Program of “marching, running, jumping, swimming, climbing, lifting, throwing, and defense.”  A “Preparatory” program consisting of :simple and combined movements of the arms, legs and trunk and normal function of the joints.”  And a “Complementary” portion of “games and sports of all kinds and manual labor.”  There is not much more detail on the exact exercises, movements, games and contests included.The author strongly encourages “air baths” in which the male athlete/student – the primary target of the book – participates shirtless, even in as extreme weather as can be tolerated.  The  all but one or two of the few pictures in the book show large groups of young men without their shirts.There is a score card well described for maintaining records.There is a detailed layout for a small space workout space to include all of the above activities, except running which can be done on roads or trails.The program mentions that manliness also needs education in moral and virility, but leaves those areas to other books.This is a century plus old physical education program with many excellent aspects that could be incorporated into modern schools and teachings.  The goal is a strong, natural athlete and manly men.  As a piece of history this is fascinating.  As examples of practices that have gone the wayside, this is outstanding. The headmaster or teacher would have to spend time setting up the exact detailed programs to be included, and if not skilled in an area, find skilled instructors.The program is very valid, and if instituted intact in 2015 would 1) be a hard sell and 2) again produce manly, virile men.

Review – The Ultimate Yogi with Travis EliotThe Ultimate Yogi with Travis Eliot is a fascinating challenge.  Uday Entertainment gives us 12 yoga workouts, two cleansing challenges, and a final of 36, then 72 then 108 sun salutations to cap each of the three segments of the program.The Yoga workouts are good, basic and require strength, stamina and balance.  They are well video taped and the commentary to go along with them is good, and not condescending or fake golf course whispers.  Travis himself moves well, as an  experienced yoga instructor should.  The class of 16 men and women is well photographed doing the workouts.There is both a booklet and a day by day calendar to do the workouts in sequence.  The calender is well and clearly done, telling which workout do to on each of the 108 days.  The booklet is too brief.  Therein lies my problems with this program.The fine print on the back of the box states that this program is not for beginners.  That is fine, but should be much more obviously placed than it is.  If the practitioner is well versed in the poses, asanas, and vinyasas, and has basic strength, stamina, balance and flexibility before he/she starts, then this program will work.  The program is meant for individuals who already have the yoga experience to deal with the poses, asanas and vinyasas.  I did not find instruction in those basic principles in this program.  That is fine, if it is clearly made known in the instructions.Travis does state once - that I found - that the practitioner should do the various programs as far as they can, and work on improving his/her performance and completing each program as indicated over the 108 days.  This was not in a prominent spot in the program or the dvds and it should be.The program is self is good, and if the practitioner is ready with the knowledge and basic abilities in Yoga, then it will benefit the practitioner.  The capstone is the 108 sun salutations in one set.  Nowhere else have I seen this large number of sun salutations as a goal of Yoga practice.  And while it is a challenging goal for advanced Yoga practitioners, is realistic for most individuals?  I am not sure.  And does that accomplishment really mean anything in the Yoga world?  But yes The Ultimate Yoga will enhance a practitioner's strength, stamina, balance and flexibility

Review – Ashtanga yoga John Scott“Ashtanga Yoga:  The Definitive Step by Step Guide of Dynamic Yoga”  by John Scott is an excellent avenue for the novice to begin Ashtanga Yoga.  John covers Sun Salutations A and B, the Standing Sequence and the Sitting Sequence in good detail.  The instruction is good enough for intermediate students to gain practice form and correct their accumulated errors.The pictures and diagrams are excellent demonstrating the poses very well. The discussion is clear and simply put.  There is an introduction in which John tells of his introduction to Ashtanga Yoga by Derrick Ireland.  There is a discussion of the 8 arms of Ashtanga Yoga.  The Bundha are well described.This book is exactly as the subtitle describes.  Each step of the Sun Salutations A and B is explained and shown in excellent, easy to follow detail.  Each step of the standing series and the sitting series is explained and shown in excellent, easy – if the practitioner has the strength and balance and flexibility – to follow detail.  It is apparent that John believes that one starts with the body one has, and works one's way into the poses over time, i.e months to years,  as strength, balance and flexibility develop.John is obviously an accomplished practitioner of Ashtanga Yoga moving very well in the dvd and artfully in the images of the book.  There is no talking down, or hushed golf course type whispering going on.  This an excellent presentation of an all too often poorly done subject.  Other books of equal strength are those by David Swensen.There is a companion dvd of John Scott doing the Primary Series including the Sun Salutations that is also excellent.  I would recommend getting both the book and the dvd.

Review – Dynamic Strength Training for Athletes – Boyd Epley“Dynamic Strength Training” bears a 1985 copyright.  And it is a true classic of that era.  The author, Boyd Epley, is renown for initiating strength training for university and high school, for founding the National Strength and Conditioning Association, for his outstanding work in training athletes at the University of Nebraska including 10 Heisman Trophy, Outland Trophy and Lombardi Award winners and over 40 All Americans.Boyd wrote this book for the very young athletes (12 - 16 yo)and their families.  Boyd says right up front in the Preface that “This book was written to teach young athletes the correct principles of strength training so they can increase their strength to run faster, jump higher and improve their confidence.”  And with the principles of 1985 does an excellent job.  The pictures are of high school age individuals.  There notes to parents and suggestions for home equipment.  The exercises included are basic and within the reach of 12 – 18 yr olds, Boyd's target audience.  There is a brief, very brief history of strength development and several pages on Boyd's personal journey into strength training.  This material is organized to be both motivational and also to give some proper training tips.The book is well formatted and printed.  The writing is clear and probably about 7-8 grade reading level, again Boyd's target audience.  The programs in the book are excellent and still will work.My only issue is the age of the book.  It looks looks, feels like, reads like and informs like 1985.  The book begs for updating.  Boyd Epley is still alive, semi-retired I understand.  And while there are many books for young athletes these days,  few target this younger audience aiming more at the well developed 16 - 19 yo.  With Boyd's long experience and extensive knowledge he could update this book  into the foremost, most outstanding youth training book available in 2015.

Review - Body Weight Training Jason Scott"Body Weight Training" by Jason Scott is a simple little (44 pages) book with a big impact.  Jason takes three basic facts:  1)  To gain mass the lifter must lift more volume  2) when body weight lifting the only two ways to increase difficulty is by increasing reps or changing the angles of the body's levers.  And 3)  good weight lifting programs are very simple.  Jason does go through some other principles of body weight lifting, but these are mostly not related to the central themes of the book.Jason starts with 2 huge, respected body weight lifters,  Gama of India and Mike Tyson of boxing fame.  Jason states both used a very limited number of exercises in gaining their mass and their strength.  Tyson did include other exercises like dips, shrugs, and wrestlers bridges (no weights till after his stint in prison). Gama included lifting odd heavy objects like stones.  Both included some cardio work, and actually training for their sports (wrestling or boxing).Based on the two programs of Gama and Tyson, Jason lays out a challenging, extremely simple "mass" program of vertical pulls, vertical pushes and lots and lots of body weight squats.Then Jason wants to add a strength program of L-sits and bar hangsJason likes sprints for cardio and suggests 2 different approaches to sprints.Jason also suggests a brief pulse increasing warmup and a post workout deep stretch program.Thus with basically 5 exercises, Jason says you will add both mass and strength.Are there comparable programs?  When I was doing Wade's "Convict Conditioning 1," I hit 100 of both squats and pushups and was gaining in mass and strength.  I did not do as well on the other 4 of Wades's exercises.  Wade uses 6 exercises, so his program is somewhat similar.  Wade gives progressions for mastering the basic 6.  Jason just jumps in.  Jason's and Wade's programs are quite different.  For the beginner, I would suggest using parts of Wade's to get to the bottom of Jason's.Will it work? Based on Jason's pictures and his discussion of Gama and Tyson, and my brief experience with Wade, it will.  Be sure to take lots time to work up to the work loads.  Hurrying this beyond your own body's abilities will injury you.

Review – Master the Kettlebell by Max Shank“Master the Kettlebell” by Max Shank is a beautiful, well laid out, well planned, well written book to assist the athlete to use the kettlebell in conditioning.  Max himself is a Master RKC Instructor, and central to Dragon Door's revitalizing of that program.This book is written for the Personal Trainer.  Thus the first chapter is a “First Time Client Assessment.”  This is a simple, but complete assessment of the body of the new client which will give the Personal Trainer a good idea of the issues or lack thereof in the body of a new client.  It starts with the neck, and moves down through the shoulder, checks for impingement, thoracic rotation, checks out the squat and the lunge, looks at the glut bridge, ankle dorsiflexion,  before ending with trunk stability and upper body strength.  Then we got a discussion of the trigger points and their solution.Max includes a total body warmup.  In the warm up, Max includes the turkish getup, the goblet squat stretch and glute bridges.  Even with these the warmup is short enough to be practical.All that before getting to the exercises.  Max spends pages with instructions, pictures (himself and Beth Andrews, Senior RKC and Beast Tamer Challenger Master) warnings, miscues and mistakes and their corrections on the kettlebell swing, the KB get up, the goblet squat, the KB clean, KB presses including the bottom up KB press, KB snatch as the basics.  Then Max moves to the specific exercises,  the windmill, around the world, figure of 8, and juggling.  From here Max moves into the standard gym exercises using the KB.  These are presented in much shorter form.  The Personal Trainer should have a good grasp of these before applying the kettlebells.Max ends with suggestions on building programs and complexes for complete conditioning and athleticism utilizing the Kettlebell and general gym exercises.Max has put together an excellent introduction and advanced training book on using the Kettle bell.  This book is not recommended for the beginner to exercise as it assumes too much basic knowledge of the common gym exercises.  The instructions on the basic KB  moves and their teaching and error corrections are complete and well worth even the most advanced practitioner's and trainer's time.  The instructions on incorporating the kettlebell into general gym exercises are excellent, but requires the user to be familiar with these.Overall, this is an outstanding addition to the Kettlebell Literature and to the literature on general body conditioning and athleticism.The book itself is a piece of art.  If you want an exercise book for your front room coffee table, this is it.

I received this remote as a replacement for the original that went missing.Once my wife and I got the battery compartment open - initially difficult - placed in batteries, it worked.Initially I had difficulty determining how to switch input (HDMI 1, HDMI 2, HDMI 3, etc).  Now with that figured out, it will do what I want done.Perhaps those are just problems of not being remote literate, seldom having used a remote for more than turning the TV and the blue ray players on and off.

Review - Weeds of North America by Dickinson and Royer"Weeds of North America" by Dickinson and Royer is a beautiful color printed, photographic collection of over 500 weeds from the University of Chicago Press.  This is a general guide to the weeds.  If full identification down specie is desired, than the complete and current manuals such as Gray's, Kaul's  or the Great Plains Flora Association's should be consulted.  This book will get the user close.The images are beautiful photographs most often displaying the characteristics of the plants very well.The descriptions are modern, easily read and mostly in simple English.  The few technical terms are easily found in the glossary and diagrams of plant anatomy.  Each plant has scientific name and synonyms,  several common names, a quick id guide, origin, life cycle, where designated a weed, a generous description with bold headings of seed, seedling, leaves, flower, plant appearance and reasons for concern, What is missing is distribution maps.  There is no indication of the spread of the invasive plant other than North America.  This is a serious omission, hopefully to be corrected in future editions. A surprising addition is the listing of the destructive plant viruses that each plant harbors.Included is a key to the plants.  This is keyed to plant type, leaf arrangement, flower color with thumbnail color pictures to help guide for other characteristics.  This key is easily followed even by the amateur plant lover who has only basic knowledge of plant anatomy.  This key is vastly different than the technical keys in the complete manuals such as Gray's, Kaul's,  Rydberg's, The Great Plains Flora Association's, or Britton and Brown's.This book can be compared to the Dept. of Agriculture's "Common Weeds of the United States" which is very traditional and scientifically dense in its descriptions, (i.e. no paragraph breaks or headings and many more technical terms),  line drawings, no photographs, and 225 weeds listed.  Both are good in their own way.  Both have 2014 copyright.  Each has its target audience.  The color costs more, but not prohibitively.  Interestingly the sources listed by the books are totally different.

Review – Common Weeds of the United States – Dept of Ag“Common Weeds of the United States” is a traditional id guide to 224 weeds of the continental United States.  There are no control measures listed, just the id of the weeds.  Chosen for inclusion are weeds that are “prevalent weeds in croplands, grazing lands, noncroplands and aquatic sites.”  The introduction states that this set of weeds was selected by weed scientists largely from the composite list of 1,775 weeds published by the Weed Science Society of America in WEEDS 14: 347-386, 1966.  Thus, if the reader wants to identify down to the species, the reader should further id the weed in more complete manuals.  But this is a good guide to get close.The scientific nomenclature is that of the Weed Science Society of America.  The organization is the traditional evolutionary order of the plant families and then alphabetical by scientific name., genus then specie.  Common names, as listed by the Weed Science Society of America, are listed also.Each weed has two pages.  On one page is a scientific description of the weed.  The introduction states:  “The descriptions are semi technical, with the terminology simplified wherever possible.”  This is true, compared to say, Gray's Manuals.  But the reader will need basic knowledge of the scientific descriptive terms and style of descriptions of botany.  The drawings are drawings.  There are not photographs.  The drawings are good, but of the old botanical drawing school.  Once the reader adjusts to drawings instead of photographs, the drawings are clear and distinct.  The details of the seeds are very good.This is an excellent, traditional guide to common weeds.  Considering the cost of updating this to color photography and printing and the most likely audience of trained professionals, this is a good tradeoff.  For the layman, or common person who idly wants to know what that weed is, this is a little too scientific.Amazon lists another book by the same name and publisher from 1971, so this is an ongoing series of editions.

Review - Cline, Eric H. (2014-03-23). 1177 B.C.: The Year Civilization Collapsed (Turning Points in Ancient History) (p. 171). Princeton University Press. Kindle Edition."1176BC" The Year Civilization Collapsed" is a well written, very readable, detailed analysis of the Late Bronze Age and its collapse in the years 1250 - 1170 BC.  The book starts in approximately 1500B and examines the civilizations extant in the Eastern Mediterranean - Minoans, Mycenaeans, Hittites, Assyrians, Babylonians, Mitannians, Canaanites, Cypriots, and Egyptians - and their complex, active interchange with trade, royal marriages, diplomatic networks, commercial networks, transportation networks, and communication networks.  Many references to both the literature of the time on tablets and to archeological studies reinforce Eric Cline's opinion that Complex Theory and Complexity explain the collapse of the high cultures of the Late Bronze Age and their replacement over the next 300 years by smaller, less complex, but technically more advanced cultures of the Early Iron Age.Eric Cline summarizes the book saying:1177 BC, is a reasonable benchmark and allows us to put a finite date on a rather elusive pivotal moment and the end of an age. We can say with certainty that the far-reaching civilizations that were still flourishing in the Aegean and the ancient Near East in 1225 BC had begun to vanish by 1177 BC and were almost completely gone by 1130 BC. The mighty Bronze Age kingdoms and empires were gradually replaced by smaller city-states during the following Early Iron Age. Consequently, our picture of the Mediterranean and Near Eastern world of 1200 BC is quite different from that of 1100 BC and completely different from that of 1000 BC.Cline, Eric H. (2014-03-23). 1177 B.C.: The Year Civilization Collapsed (Turning Points in Ancient History) (pp. 172-173). Princeton University Press. Kindle Edition.Followed shortly afterward by saying:although we don't know how contemporaneous the final destructions actually were in Greece, it is clear that after the catastrophes were over , "there were no palaces, the use of writing as well as all administrative structures came to an end, and the concept of a supreme ruler, the wanax, disappeared from the range of political institutions of Ancient Greece." 3 In terms of literacy and writing, the same holds true for Ugarit and the other entities that had flourished in the Eastern Mediterranean during the Late Bronze Age, for with their end came also the end of cuneiform writing in the Levant, replaced by other, perhaps more useful or convenient, writing systems.Cline, Eric H. (2014-03-23). 1177 B.C.: The Year Civilization Collapsed (Turning Points in Ancient History) (p. 173). Princeton University Press. Kindle Edition.This book is not history made simple, but a very readable, complex analysis worthy of any person interested in ancient history.  Every aspect of the cultures of the Late Bronze Age and it's decline as listed above, and more are examined and evaluated with reference to the source of the knowledge.  Older references and viewpoints are referenced, and supported or refuted.  With the copyright of 2014, Cline has the book right up to date on discoveries made recently.A good read, A good summary of current knowledge, well worth the time to read.

Review - "The Sea Peoples:  The Mysterious Nomads who Ushered in the Iron Age"The Sea Peoples" is a short, little book running to a full 32 pages.  It summarizes our knowledge of a mysterious group of tribes who invaded the established Eastern Mediterranean World in the Bronze Age just at the time the Bronze Age was collapsing into a Dark Ages from which the Iron Age arose. There are many quotes from the Egyptian tablets and a few quotes and archeological references from the Egyptians and the ancient Greeks and other cultures of the Late Bronze Age.This book takes the slant that the Sea People were tribes that arose from Asia Minor and perhaps south east Europe (the Balkans).  They may have been Trojans  who migrated after being defeated at the destruction of the Troy of that age. Some may have come from Italy, or perhaps through Italy from Asia Minor.The book is well written.  It is easily read in under an hour.  The book does give the reader an understanding of the lack of knowledge of the Sea Peoples, and mentions the destruction wrought by them and in their time.  The language is not pedantic or heavily laden with scientific terms.  Unfortunately there is just not enough information in this book to locate in history or enough background given to teach people of the Late Bronze Age and its collapse.I would encourage reading this in conjunction with the book "1176 B.C."  The Year Civilization Collapsed." for a fuller appreciation of the Late Bronze Age and the destruction that accompanied the Sea People's invasions.

Review – Where the Negroes are Masters by Randy Sparks“Where the Negroes are Masters” is the story of the major British slave and gold trading port in West Africa, on the Gold Coast, Annamaboe.  Annamaboe is a city that thrived only during the slave trade.  This is the story of it's rise and fall.  It still exists, but only as a mere shadow of it's former glory.The intrigues, diplomacy successes and failures, the strong personalities, the strife between the Native Tribes (mostly Fante and Asante) and the British with extensions into the French and Spanish and Portuguese,  the battles and problems of governing such a place, the cultures and empires of the Fante and the Asante, the Native merchants and rulers and peoples, and much more are well described and their interactions discussed.Randy Sparks enables us to see the “Atlantic World” of trade between South America, North America, Europe and Africa.  In this book Randy focuses on the Gold Coast and its role.  The other legs of the “Black Atlantic” are in many other books.  This is a side of the story seldom told til recently.  We even get a chapter on slave trading in the African interior between the African Empires.The book is well and interestingly written.  The stories of power and greed and gore are well done.  The reader comes away from the book with a much better understanding of Africa and the Gold Coast slave trade.  The detail is amazing, gleaned from historical records and primary sources.  The notes and bibliography are nearly 25% of the book.For a more reading on the slave trade,  I recommend both Meredith Martin's “The Fortunes of Africa”  A 5000 Year History of Wealth Greed and Endeavor,”  and Paul Lovejoy's “Transformations in Slavery (African Studies).”  These two give a wide angle view of the slave trade where Sparks chose to concentrate on one major port.  For a modern, not Eurocentric view, both the wide angle and the sharp focus are recommended.

Review:  Pocket Guide to Choosing Woody Ornamentals by Michael Epp“Pocket Guide to Choosing Woody Ornamentals” is a very concise set of lists of woody decorative plants.  This book is devoid of pictures, but chunk full of valuable information for the garden planner.  There are lists of the color and season of flowering, short vs tall, city street, hedges, shade, foundation plantings, noise barriers, bird attractors, specific soil types, specimen selections, bark effect, poisonous twigs or flowers, or other parts of the plant,  pictures of shape and height at various ages, windbreaks, and yet many more.  Where useful growing zones (old version) are listed.Note: all lists are by scientific name without common names or scientific synonyms.  Also, the attributions are left off the scientific names.  The only common names used are in the lists of varieties of a species, where the scientific name would not be of use.This is a very handy book for professional garden planners or the very advanced amateur gardeners.  Unless you have need for this information on a frequent basis and the knowledge of the scientific names of plants, you don't need this book.The German version of this  book came out in 1970.  This english translation came out 1982, reprinted in 1990 and 1992.

Review – Invasive Plants:  Weeds of the Global GardenInvasive Plants is a fascinating little book.  It lists 80 plants brought from elsewhere than the USA that are known to be invasive.  Reasonable pictures,  good descriptions, brief analysis of which portion of the USA is bothered, tips on how to handle these 80 plants are all included.  Each plant gets its own page.  The amazing thing is that most of these plants are still being sold in the nurseries, at least in some portions of the US.The authors took two comprehensive plant directories and abstracted over 300 non native plants they consider to be problems with crowding out native species, damaging habitat for both domestic and wild animals and bird, endangering and overwhelming native bioms.  From these 300 they selected these 80 plants for being common and possibly wide spread and a serious problem in some portion of the US.A short list of the plants the authors included is:  Japanese Honeysuckle, ice plant, Amur maple, butterfly bush, tall fescue,  reed canary grass, pampas grass, Siberian Elm, Multifola Rose, bachelor's buttons, English holly, Japanese Barberry, black locust, paper mulberry, dames rocket and so on up to 80 plants.This book also contains some hints on management of these pests and hints on overall unwanted plant control.This book is useful for those planning gardens as to which plants to avoid.  The answer is often surprising.

Review – “Transformations in Slavery:  A History of Slavery in Africa” by Paul Lovejoy.  3d Edition 2012“Transformations in Slavery” is a detailed study of slavery in Africa.  Dr.Lovejoy states in his Preface to the first edition (1979) that the history of slavery in Africa, as opposed to the Atlantic and Mid Eastern diaspora of Africans via enslavement is extensive and poorly studied.  This 2012 edition is the third edition of this book; the first having been published in 1979.Dr. Lovejoy examines the numbers, utilization, process of enslavement, marketing, and development of slavery inside Africa, concentrating on the Fifteenth through the Nineteenth Centuries.  This is not a diatribe against slavery, nor an apologist essay.  This is a fact and number filled overview of  slavery in Africa as it existed from the fifteenth century through the nineteenth century.  The detail as to numbers and locations is astonishing.  The history is much more complete than I knew existed.  Dr. Lovejoy throws much light on the development of plantation farming over these years and on the role of the Muslim traders, and how their changes from warrior to reformist impacted the slave trade and slave utilization.  Dr Lovejoy gives us an understanding of the four major forms of slavery, Kin vs not Kin, plantation and other production, harem, and military.  Dr. Lovejoy gives us a view of the impact of the European abolishment movement and some details as to how that movement affected the interior slave trade in Africa.The book is well and clearly written.  The charts and maps are helpful.  The formatting on my ipad  and iphone was good.  This book is essential for anyone wanting to understand slavery as it existed in Africa and how that impacted both the Atlantic and the Muslim markets for slaves.

Review - The Fortunes of Africa:  A 5,000 Year History of Wealth, Greed and Endeavor by Martin Meredith"The Fortunes of Africa" is a rather large survey of the long, complicated history of Africa.  As such it picks out highlights of the history.  The book gives the reader a brief taste of the various parts of Africa in turn as it's focus shifts round and round the huge geography of the continent and through the 5000 years.  The huge amount of material this book surveys limits it's ability to do any location or era true justice.  Yet, Martin Meredith, who has written other books on Africa, succeeds in giving the reader a creditable taste of the huge table.The book is well written and enjoyable to read.  There are almost no pictures, only two or three maps in my Kindle edition.  The maps on my iphone were too small to be of use.  The selection of the material is by necessity eclectic.  The coverage of the various selections Martin Mededith choose is adequate to understand and appreciate  the breadth of the history and to come away better informed than before reading the book.I found the book enlightening and informative on a continent and a history of which I have seldom been exposed.  I would recommend "The Fortunes of Africa" to persons wanting to know more of an important part of human history that is all to often passed by.

Review – Talibanistan by Peter Bergen“Talibanistan” is an accounting of the peoples and places of the Taliban in Afghanistan as of 2011 with only necessary references into the Pakistani Taliban as of 2011.  The book is amazing in the detail and naming of names and locations of many of the Taliban leaders.  Peter Bergen does give a disclaimer that only those names and places known to the Western Allies and Afghanistan are listed.  Others may be referred to, but not with detail to identify them.  But the known list is very lengthy.The book is horrifying in its accounting of the civil right abuses and outright military overreach of both the Kasai Government and the western militaries.  These are presented in quoted interviews.  In fact the book point blank states that abuses and overreaching by the Kasai Government and the western military, such as home invasions, confiscation, and imprisonment are the reasons for many of the Taliban from their first Taliban Surge, returning in the Taliban Resurgence.Unless the reader has detailed knowledge of the geography and history of Afghanistan, the book is hard to read.  Otherwise the book is well written and quite readable.The histories, policies and strategies of the Taliban are only briefly discussed.  This is mostly an accounting of the people of the Taliban in 2011, how they came back into the movement, and who is talking with whom.  As such it is fascinating, but rapidly becoming dated.

Review – Dancing in the Glory of Monsters:  The Collapse of the Congo and the Great War of Africa by Jason Stearns“Dancing in the Glory of Monsters” is an overview of the Congolese Wars about 1996 – 2011.  The book covers history and current events from about 1990 to about 2011.  There is much positive acclaim for this book quoted in the front of the book from such as the New York Time Book Review, Wall Street Journal, the  Washington Post, The Economist, The Financial Times and many other reviewers of prominence. Most are calling Jason Stearn's efforts the most balanced and insightful look into the Congolese Wars available.Jason Stearns has spent considerable time in the Congo researching this book.  There are several fascinating personal interviews by Stearns himself reported on with various surviving main players in the story.The book is well written, and very readable.  The story is well told.  There are maps, a mite bit too small in my Kindle version that are very helpful.References are made to the brutality of the wars without subjecting the  reader unnecessarily to the gore and bloodshed.  Although Gore and Bloodshed cannot be totally avoided in reporting on these wars.  The personalities of the various leaders of all sides are well outlined and discussed, with their impact on the Wars and on The Congo.  The extreme corruption that made matters much worse is outlined.  The influence of Rwanda and Uganda are well displayed.  The effects of tribalism, especially the Hutu's and the Tutsi's and that of the Congolese leaders are discussed in some detail.  There are references to western nations such as United States, Canada, Cuba, Britain, and Belgium and the parts they played.  The affects of the diamond and mineral trade are discussed.For those with an interest in recent African History, “Dancing in the Glory of Monsters” is an absolute must to understand this era and locality.

Review - Conditioning to the Core  Brittenham and Taylor"Conditioning to the Core" by Greg Brittenham and Daniel Taylor is truly a epic work on the core, and the exercises needed to develop it.  At 371 pages it is the thickest and heaviest book on the core I have seen recently published.  But every page is packed with easy to understand information, or charts of exercises.  It is truly a textbook on the core worthy of a three hour college class.  But yet it is simple enough and use directed enough to be practical on any coaches desk.The authors insist that training must be done is three stages:  stabilization, strength and power.  They want us to advance through these stages, and then repeat them throughout life to maintain our cores.  The authors have set up easy to apply and understand and grade tests of the athlete to determine where in the progression above he/she should start and continue.  Their reasoning is that without a stable core, injuries, maldevelopment etc will occur.  And since power is the multiple of force (applied strength)  x speed, then strength must be developed before power.  I concur.The middle of the book is designed around the progression through three parts,  Part II Stabilization, Part III Strength and Part IV Power.  In each section is an clear explanation of that section.  Then each section has anti-extension, anti-rotation, lumbo-pelvic exercises.  Scapulothoracic exercises are in the stabilization section.The book starts with an excellent discussion, but not nerdy or pedantic, of the core.  Recent research on the core and exercise physiology is explained clearly and in easily understandable terms.  The book ends with a section on core testing, the complete core program, advanced core programs, and finally sport specific core programs.Each of the exercise sections has the excises well described, well pictured, and well placed in the ongoing core program.  Charts outline the basic exercises in each section and the progression of difficulty in each section.  These charts are large, clear, and well explained.  Note that Chapter 5 is a listing of 24 specific benefits of an exercise.  The charts refer back to this section to show us the purpose of each exercise.While at first glance, this book would seem to be a tome, it is actually an easy to use and apply outline of an excellent core development program, and a life time core maintenance program.  For a coach seeking a core program for his athlete's, imho, there is no better guide out there than this book.  For an athlete seeking to develop his core, this is an excellent guide.  To it's benefit, This is not a quickie book or catalog for core exercises, but the design of a complete core program.

Review:  “The hunt for Kimathi” by Ian Henderson with Philip Goodhart.“The Hunt for Kimathi” is the exciting story for the long, dangerous, exciting hunt to capture the last of the Mau Mau leaders, Dedan Kimathi, in Kenya.Ian Henderson was raised with the Kikuya Tribe's people in Kenya, and spoke their language fluently,  He also was nearly as much at home crawling through the forests of Kenya as they were.  Also Ian Henderson was at home in an English drawing room sipping tea.  Ian earned two “George Medals” for his exploits in the Mau Mau Emergency.  Ian Henderson knew how the Kikuya throught, and knew their customs.  These attributes made him unique and probably one of the very few men, if not the only man, who could lead a “pseudo-gang” of converted Mau Mau to capture their previous leader.The exciting story reads like a light English novel, and one to keep reminding oneself of the seriousness  of the  situation with ongoing raids and mayhem and massacres  by the Mau Mau.  These events actually came near the end of the Mau Mau Emergency and effectively ended the emergency.  There are letter drops worthy of the CIA.  There are treks through untrackable thick forest and thickets.  There are ambushes and attacks and battles.  There are jeep and land rover treks through jungle thickets and deep forests, over hill, dale and mountain. There are secret, bloody, gory, perverted sexual, oath taking rituals described factually as delicately as possible.  There are escapades to make your skin crawl.  There is plenty psychology for those curious about the Mau Mau.  There is plenty of history of the Mau Mau Emergency.The book reads well.  The story is well told.  The pictures are graphic, clear in detail, and fascinating.For those interested in the Mau Mau, this is an excellent resource.
This delivery toy truck is a wonderful toy.  It is well made, although my grandchildren have not yet used it.  It is attractive.  It is just the right size for a child's hand to carry or push.

Review Prochord Changes Vol I and II by Frank Mantoooth“Prochord Changes” Volumes I and II by Frank Mantooth are excellent sources for standard tunes, lyrics,  chord and alternate chord changes.  Each Volume contains 150 standards, giving us a good swath of the more commonly played tunes in the Great American Song Book.The books are very well formatted.  The staffs are large and clear.  The note notation is large and clear.  The chord notation is large and clear, with the standard chords in bold and alternate chords in lighter print.  As far as I can tell, the chord selections are standard and not overly complicated.  The entire book is single staffed.  Every tune starts at the top of a page.  Most tunes have two pages, a few tunes have three pages.  This makes for easy reading.  The tunes are positioned in each volume alphabetically.  The binding seems strong and the book lays flat.  In the front of each volume is an index so one can quickly find a tune.Quite a few of the tunes have playing tips and harmonic analysis.  A few tunes have historical annotations by Dr. David Baker.These volumes are outstanding work from an excellent pianist.

Each Volume contains 150 standards, giving us a good swath of the more commonly played tunes in the Great American Song Book.The books are very well formatted.  The staffs are large and clear.
