In all of the works recorded here, he evinces a singular tone of voice--firm in conviction but gentle of utterance, given to introspection without maundering, affectionate without descending too far into sentimentality, deliberate without dragging the music out.  His earlier EMI recordings with the Philharmonia (which have also recently been reissued to mark the anniversary) are reputedly brisker and more direct, without any diminution of sensitivity.  So I am eager to hear them; that will be my next listening project.  For now, however, I can give this set a strong endorsement, despite the bulky packaging (old-style 4-CD jewel boxes contained in a flimsy cardboard case) and skimpy annotations in Italian only.Postscript:  Since I wrote this review, DG/Universal has released a huge trove of Giulini recordings, including most (but not all) of those included in the "Art of Carlo Maria Giulini" set.  The advantages of the newer reissues are that they include more repertoire, are organized according to the ensembles/nationalities this great conductor worked with (VPO, Los Angeles/Chicago, etc.) and are housed in space-saving cardboard boxes. Cost is low for each volume.  For these reasons, I recommend that potential purchasers of the set reviewed above consider these newer reissues instead.  Also, fans of Giulini should be aware that Warner/EMI has released Giulini retrospective collections, also in space-saving boxes.  These include all of the recordings made with English orchestras, the Chicago/EMI recordings, and Concerto repertoire (with distinguished soloists such as Perlman, Rostropovich, Starker and others). Finally, Sony has released a huge "bargain box+ of Giulini's recordings from late in his career for that label.  An embarassment of riches here, as well as much duplication of repertoire.  If you don't fancy owning, say, three versions of Giulini conducting Dvorak's *New World* Symphony (albeit with three different orchestras), than exercise caution in ordering multiple Giulini boxes from different labels.  Also be aware that Giulini's interpretations became more personal, and slowed down considerably, as he aged.  For this reason I would recommend, particularly to the neophyte, the "London Years" volume from Warner/EMI as the best place to start in exploring this conductor's recorded legacy.  I would then go on to purchase one or more of the DG boxes (the America box is particularly fine, though I'm also partial to many of his VPO recordings, even if the tempos have begun to slow down markedly by the time he made them).  I wouldn't recommend the Sony recordings as a comprehensive collection, except to completists; rather, I would pick and choose among them,given that Sony has released most of them as economically priced single issues.

My personal quest to explore every known recording of this work--in search, perhaps, of the elusive ideal--has at last brought me to Giulini's late recording of the work for Sony.  Since its initial release, at full price, its critics have been numerous and its admirers few.  I can see why.  In an age dominated by period performance practice, whose protocols rightly demand rhythmic resilience, nonlegato phrasing, upbeat tempos, and a spirit of the dance, Giulini's languid, awestruck approach will seem not so much romanticized as just misguided.  Imagine Klemperer on valium.  Yet, should we always reject, a priori, an unorthodox, even idiosyncratic, approach to a familiar work, if that approach elicits musically satisfying results, even intermittently?  Do our categories sometimes need flexing and stretching?Nearly everyone will admit that Giulini was a great conductor, and that his proclivity for carefully sculpted phrases, super-refined textures, and, with advancing age, deliberate tempos could yield revelatory results in Bruckner, Brahms and Ravel (to cite three salient instances.  Add to this mix Giulini's further proclivity for introversion--some call it "spirituality"--and one might well ask whether this singular aesthetic might prove appropriate for getting to the heart of the musico-religious vision in what was apparently Bach's last will and testament as a composer of sacred music.My ears at very least, and more significantly my soul, tell me that this approach does uncover depths that other versions miss; while my intellect questions whether the results are musicologically appropriate and, more crucially, whether the obscuring of contrapuntal detail in Giulini's exquisitely blended textures could be anything other than just "bad" music-making.How can inappropriate musical exegesis be so deeply satisfying? So awe-inspiringly beautiful?  So attuned to one side of Bach's musical personality, while utterly oblivious to its other sides?I will leave it to adventurous listeners, who are urged to purchase and hear this wondrous recording, to ponder and perhaps resolve these paradoxes.  Let me add a few further incentives, however.  The solo singing in this recording is very good indeed.  Lovely voices, perfectly attuned--at least in this instance--to the value of what Giulini is asking of them (which involves, predictably, long-lined and beautifully sustained legato phrasing).  Keith Lewis's "Benedictus" is so gorgeously sung that it's worth the modest cost of this reissue just to hear.  The choral forces are large, and, as intimated above, textural clarity and precise diction yeild to vertical melding and long-range sculpting.  Yet the tone of the choir remains luminours, and the intonation steady, at all dynamic levels; moreover, they are capable of some of the most rapturously beautiful soft singing I have ever heard on record.  The instrumental ensemble plays with vigor and conviction throughout, despite some very slow tempos.  The wind and string obbligati are sensitively rendered: virtuosity in abundance, yet without a hint of showiness.But if I have described Giulini's interpretation as if it were a liability that one might endure for the fascination of the thing, then I have mislead my readers.  There are many positive virtues to Giulini's exposition of the work.  Not all of the tempos are inappropriately slow, and even where he takes a leisurely approach, the listener is afforded an opportunity to be borne up by the gentle ebb and swell of Giulini's effortlessly natural pulse.  Moreover, Giulini never lets the music just drift along; he always knows where he is going.  The end if each movement, and the place of each episode within the entire structure, is prefigured from the beginning.  Listen carefully, and you will find--to change the metaphor-- that Giulini's B-Minor Mass is a living, breathing organism bound together by tougher sinews than might be at first apparent from the sheer lovelines of its diaphanous surfaces.This is, then, a version to hear--but not for everyone.  Perhaps one could say that it is version of Bach's B-Minor Mass looking for certain listeners who might be attuned to Giulini's distinctive qualities as an interpreter of sacred music.  If the prospect of an unhurried and reverent musical contemplation of the Eternal appeals to you, then seek out this modestly priced recording.  The engineers have captured Giulini's distinctive vision with wide-ranging, exquisitely blended sound, despite the opacity of texture that occasionally obscures detail in the polyphonically dense choral movements.

I do not mean to derogate from Sir John Eliot Gardiner's status as one of the great luminaries of the podium in our age--to say nothing of his status as a pioneer and perfecter of period performance practice--but in the end the capstone of his career might well turn out to have been in the medium of prose rather than musical performance!  This is, quite simply, the most fascinating, engrossing, erudite and stunningly written work on the Leipzig Cantor available.  Too bad it focuses primarily on his sacred music (I would love to have Gardiner's obiter dicta on many of the keyboard, chamber and orchestral works treated only tangentially here); but within that  limited scope, Gardiner has achieved something quite remarkable:  a work of musical historiography that manages to combine rigorous scholarship with philosophical acumen and literary flair.  As a philosopher with a keen interest in the interface between aesthetics and religion, I particularly appreciated Gardiner's thorough understanding of the exigencies of church music within the Lutheran tradition, and his situating of tht tradition within the larger framework of Church history, scriptural exegesis and Christian spirituality.  His effort to discern Bach's character and aspirations from his church music rather than principally from the documentary evidence (which is relaitvely meager) fixes the reader's (and listener's) attention where it must always begin and end--namely, with the scores themselves, as performed and heard.  His charting of Bach's creative development, through the seasons and struggles of his career calls our attention anew to the status of the sacred music--particularly the Cantatas--as a kind of spiritual journal recounting the consolations and desolations of a fragile, fallible genius who also happened to be something of a mystic.  For Gardiner, in the end, Bach's sacred-musical testament amounts to the bravest and most brilliant of stands against the depredations of our human condition at its most terrifying--and *for* the transcendence to the rapture of creativity fitfully but effectually points.I cannot recommend this work highly enough.  Its pages will afford a fresh encounter with the composer, even if you have been studying his works and his commentators (as I have) for nearly a lifetime.  But even more tellingly perhaps, you will encounter John Eliot Gardiner in a new way--as an accomplished writer and winsomely humane scholar.

What more need be said?  This estimable series has gone from strength to strength, and the final volume transcends even the highest expectations.  All three cantatas are among Bach's most stunning creations (BWV 30 was singled out by Schweitzer in his study of Bach as a work of astonishing strength and originality), and the performances are nothing short of revelatory.  The four soloists are fully up to their tasks--and what demands Bach places upon them, particularly in BWV 30.  But everyone seems to be in a state of grace here--the vocal ensemble, instrumental soloists, and of course the director, Masaaki Suzuki. A sense of euphoria pervades all three Cantatas. Now that this project has reached its end, Suzuki must be acclaimed as one of the great Bach interpreters of his, or any, generation.  There are other superb Bachians--contemporary listeners are living a charmed existence in this regard--but on the evidence of the music-making in Vol. 55 (as in most of the previous volumes of the series), Suzuki has emerged as primus inter pares.  I also find it appropriate that Suzuki chose to conclude the final volume with the cantata that recapitulates music from the Gloria of the B-Minor Mass.  Yes, indeed: Gloria in excelsis Deo!  May Maasaki Suzuki be blessed--as who have been following the series have been  blessed.

As a great admirer of the Bethlehem Bach Choir--to whom all Bachians in the USA owe a huge debt of gratitude--I had high expectations for this recording of my personal favorite among Bach's large-scale sacred works (though it really is a cycle of six cantatas). Though I was impressed by many aspects of this production, overall my response was one of mild disappointment.  Among the virtues I would count the sprightly, expressive and stylistically aware playing from the ad hoc orchestra.  The wind and brass playing were particularly impressive; the strings (modern instruments playing with minimal vibrato) somewhat less so. Funfgeld has a solid grasp of Bach style and conveys an unusually cogent understanding of the score through his judicious pacing and insightful highlighting of detail. The arias, in particular, are vivacious, with dance rhythms well sprung. On the other hand, some of the big choruses could have benefited from more upbeat tempos, but the large choir would have made that impracticable. The soloists are fine, particularly the alto and soprano; both sing with expressive attention to textual detail and a decent knowledge of Baroque ornamentation and phrasing.  The tenor, Benjamin Butterfield, has a pleasing voice and  narrates effectively, though his negotiation of the difficult tenor arias is considerably less fluent, and his tone overall less pleasing, than his better-known recorded rivals.  The bass has a gorgeous voice but at times has problems with German pronunciation (as do all of the other soloists as well as the choir).  Speaking of the choir, their contribution was most of all responsible for my mild disappointment. They are simply too large a group to bring the requisite precision and lift to the articulation of rhythmic cells (so important in Bach). The more densely contrapuntal passages can also sound a but mushy, despite the conductor's efforts to clarify voice-leading.So, regrettably, I have to give this worthy release fainter praise than I would have liked.  Maybe I've been spoiled by the many truly great versions of this work on record--from Richter and Münchinger to Gardiner and Suzuki.  This work's discography has been particularly blessed over the decades, and better performances are available now at reduced prices. However, I will end on a positive note.  It is still worth hearing a choir and orchestra that continue to uphold the best traditions of Bach performance for well over a century; and it is important to acknowledge and appreciate the existence of such traditions on these shores.  Indeed, there's a point in purchasing a recording of the *Christmas Oratorio* that sports a "made in the USA" label.

Ormandy's recording of the Mahler First is certainly one to consider if you want to hear the composer's original five-movement conception, with "Blumine" occupying second place between the first movement and the Scherzo.In my estimation, however, that is not the main reason to purchase this inexpensive reissue ("Blumine," though charming, doesn't really add anything of substance to the symphony as we usually hear it); rather, it is for the terrific playing of the Philadelphians under their longime maestro, Euegene Ormandy.  Ormandy may not the the first conductor that comes to mind in relation to Mahler, but on the basis of this delightfully atmospheric and dramatically compelling rendition, Ormandy's traversal must rank with the finest of rival versions.  Though Horenstein/LSO still retains a unique place in nearly every Mahlerite's affections, Ormandy/Philadelphia is just as cogent as interpretation and superior in execution. The remastered recording is overwhelmingly clear and present, with plenty of "air" around the instruments.  Antiphonal passages come through enghantingly.I have to admit to being blown away by this recording, which I hadn't previously heard despite my decades-long obsession with this composer and his many interpreters.  The Von Stade/Davis rendition of the *Lieder eines fahrenden Gesellen* has been added as a substantial bonus.  Though von Stade is in fine voice, and Davis provides sensitive collaboration, this version cannot rival the classic ones--Ludwig, Baker, Fischer-Dieskau in my book--for depth of insight into the youthful Mahler's romantic preoccupations and existential crises; but it an effective accountm, well worth hearing.Strongly recommended to seasoned Mahlerites and first-time collectors alike.

This is the penultimate volume in Suzuki's magesterial series of Bach cantata recordings.  The final volume will contain three works--BWV 30, 69 and 191, all glorious.  I can hardly wait.  For now, we have this terrific volume to consider and enjoy. The three canonical Cantatas and one reconstructed work it presents make for a nicely contrasted program.  BWV 100 is arguably the jolliest among Bach's works in the genre.  It consists of a series of arias loosely based on a magnificent chorale tune; these are framed by a lavishly orchestrated chorale fantasia and a concluding harmonization of the hymn reinforced with winds, strings and continuo.  BWV 14, on the other hand, is a sober, introspective work sporting an opening chorale fantasia that rivals *Die Kunst der Fuge* in its contrapuntal intricacy.  BWV 197 is another one of those splendid wedding cantatas with lavish orchestration and expansive, well-developed arias.  It begins with a stunning fugal chorus, crowned with festive trumpets, that resembles the equally magnificent opening of BWV 195. Thereafter the listener is astonished ever anew by the fecundity of Bach's creative resources; all the more remarkable, then, that these resources are brought to bear on a one-off wedding ceremony.  The disc concludes with a reconstruction of BWV 197a, a sacred cantata based on the wedding cantata, but with significant alterations in orchestration and melodic detail.A real feast for earnest Bachians, then, and I am pleased to report that the performances are fully equal to these demanding works.  The choral singing, as with recent volumes in the series, sounds fuller, richer and riper than many of the earlier volumes in the series--yet with no diminution of clarity or focus.  Indeed, I have never heard more intensely satisfying accounts of the very different opening choruses of BWV 100, 14 and 197.  The latter approaches a grandeur that does full justice to Bach's sublime evocation of heavenly-earthly joy (Bach, a good Lutheran was never one to reinforce a sacred/secular dualism), in a way which we rarely encounter in "period" performances. The solo singing is splendid; once again, I must remark that Peter Kooij's ample voice sounds rejuvinated in these later volumes of Suzuki's catata series.  Blazkikova remains the very model of a Bach soprano.  Türk and Guillion are perhaps slightly less effective in their solos, but that may be just a subjective reaction on my part:  I have always found Türk's voice a bit thin in tone (despite his solid musicianship), and I must confess to a preference for female altos over countertenors (though Guillon is thankfully not too hooty).As always, the Bach-Collegium Japan covers itself in glory.  The ensemble and solo playing are splendidly incisive and articulate, yet without slighting expression.  Suzuki's pacing and shaping of the music are near-perfect.Strongly recommended, then, along with Suzuki's entire cantata cycle, now nearing its completion. Listeners new to the Bach cantatas or to Suzuki's readings of them might well start with this volume and work backwards.

This companion volume to Warner's newly-reissued set of Werner's Bach Cantata series is somewhat less recommendable than the latter.  To begin with, most collectors who incline toward or at least tolerate "traditional" approaches to Bach will already have multiple versions of the two Passions, the B-minor Mass, and the Christmas Oratorio by their favored artists.  Secondly, the deficiencies of interpretation and execution which were easier to ignore in the case of the Cantatas become more problematic in the case of these larger-scale works (and in comparison to versions by such figures as Richter, Münchinger, Klemperer, Jochum and many others).  On the other hand everything in this box is at least listenable, often very enjoyable, and at its best, quite edifying.  The finest performances here--such as the two Passions--are very good indeed, largely thanks to some terrific solo singing by such estimable Bachians as Helmut Krebs, Agnes Giebel, and Barry McDaniel (among others). On the other hand, there is also some less satisfying vocalism, mostly from Franz Kelch, whose wobbly tone and stentorian delivery undermine his efforts to portray a dignified Christus, but also from some alto soloists of a matronly Teutonic persuasion.  On the other hand, the choral singing in both Passions is nicely focused, mostly in tune, and effectively dramatic.  Werner's pacing of these works, though slower than we would expect today, is lively where it needs to be and contemplative where appropriate to text and affect. Werner's Christmas Oratorio enjoys a more intimate and lyrical conception than most other versions I have heard.  Listeners may be put off by a relative absence of exuberant celebration, though I find that Werner's thoughtful and somewhat introverted approach works well on its own terms.  The solo singing, once again, is outstanding, led by Krebs's elegant and engaging narration. The choral sound here is more diffuse, less articulate than in the two passions, but nicely balanced and more than acceptable overall.  The B-minor mass comes in a monaural concert recording from 1957. The performance has moments of majesty, though with slow overall pacing and a monumental conception realized unevenly by forces that sound amateurish and under-rehearsed, it may strain the endurance of even the most patient listeners.This box also includes gracious accounts of the Six Motets (plus the great funeral motet BWV 118), effectively paced and well sung, and sporting ample instrumental reinforcements.  A thoughtful, if rather sober account of Cantata BWV 147, in decent monaural sound, is thrown in for good measure; for some reason, this recording did not make it into Werner's cantata Box, presumably because a later and more lively stereo version was included therein.The recordings have come up well in the current remastering.  The St. Matthew Passion fares best, with an ample ecclesiastical acoustic adding helpful reverberation that does not, however, compromise focus.  The acoustic is a bit drier in the St. John and more diffuse in the Christmas Oratorio, though both sound reasonably clear and present if the volume is given a slight boost.  The monaural sound in the Mass is faded and rather strident at times; not pleasant to listen to for long stretches.  The recording of the Motets, on the other hand, conveys both clarity and presence.Should you purchase this set as a companion to Werner's Cantata collection?  That will depend on your tolerance for performances and engineering of more variable quality.  While you probably won't listen to Werner's B-Minor Mass more than once, I expect you may return in due season to the two Passions, which are quite involving and beautifully sung.  The Christmas Oratorio and Motets are certainly worth hearing from time to time, as alternatives to your favorite versionsd which they will not, probably, replace in your affections.

Fritz Werner belonged to a generation of "specialist" conductors that emerged after World War II in response to a renewed interest in Baroque music and stylistically aware performance practice.  Other distinguished members of that generation were Karl Richter, Karl Ristenpart and Felix Prohaska (to name just a few).  This movement was eventually overtaken by the turn toward what we know today as "historically-informed performance practice" that utilizes period instruments and the latest results of musicological research.  Listeners of an older generation, who lived through this momentous transition, will have retained a deep affection for those "specialists" of the early-LP era who devoted their musical careers to restoring to currency scores that had long-since lain mute on the shelves of dusty libraries--including, of course, the majority of Bach's cantatas.  Since then, of course, Bach lovers have been the beneficiaries of several more-or-less "complete" recorded editions of the Cantatas, by Rilling, Harnoncourt-Leonhardt, Koopman, Leusink, Suzuki and Gardiner.  May they all be blessed!  But the distinctive, if more selective, efforts of that earlier generation  deserve to be heard and enjoyed for their many virtues, even if by today's standards their limited notions of performance practice achieved, at best, mixed results.Fritz Werner's cycle of 60 Bach cantatas occupied that conductor from the late 1950's to 1972.  During this time he also recorded all four of Bach's large-scale sacred works as well as the Motets (and these, like the Cantatas, have been reissued several times by Erato and, latterly by Warner, during the CD era).  Despite vicissitudes of a largely amateur choir and (at limes) less than cohesive chamber orchestra, and regardless of the musicological limitations mentioned above, Werner's achievement as an exponent of Bach's sacred music was considerable, and has permanent value for listeners of every generation.  Werner's approach to this repertoire is, at its best, full of grace--by which I mean a certain graciousness, humility, generosity of spirit, and a plainspoken honesty that aims not to impress the listener with feats of virtuosity, but to serve the composer's intentions as he understood them.  Werner was a dedicated musician and Bachian who clearly enjoyed what he was doing, and that enjoyment by and large comes across in this venerable recordings.The qualifiers in the above paragraphs must be duly noted.  Werner did not achieve with the modern instruments of his Pforzheim Chamber Orchestra the degree of precision and cohesiveness evoked by Karl Richter from his Munich Bach Ensemble.  Werner's strings can sound seedy at times, and there are occasional lapses of ensemble and intonation.  On the other hand, the wind and brass playing are outstanding (the roster of soloists contains some very distinguished names, mostly from France).  The Heinrich Schütz choir, as indicated above, was not a super-professional ensemble.  Again, intonation and ensemble can sometimes be wayward.  However, their tone is characteristically light and transparent, and their diction is good (though not quite up to the awesome standards set by Richter's Munich Bach Choir).  It is the solo singing, in my estimation, that lifts this enterprise from the tolerably good to the memorable, and gives Werner's Cantata series its enduring value.  Nearly all of vocal soloists have light, attractive voices; they sing Bach's demanding arias expressively and idiomatically (within the limitations of stylistic understanding of that generation).  Agnes Giebel, Helmut Krebs, Barry McDaniel--to cite only three of Werner's distinguished roster of soloists--give some of the most memorable performances of their respective arias (and duets) ever recorded--and I am not excluding for comparison Richter's equally distinguished group, nor that host of vocalists that have graced the complete cycles of Rilling, Harnoncourt/Leonhardt, Koopman, Leusink, Suzuki and Gardiner.Werner's interpretive stance, as indicated above, emphasizes simplicity of utterance over searching out hidden theological meanings (a la Richter and Gardiner).  He avoids making music that is already polyphonically complex and melodically ornate into something imposing, garish or merely decorative.  He favors clean textures, moderate tempos (they will seem to slow to younger listeners brought up on today's early music ensembles), and lifted but not jerkily sprung rhythms.  The phrasing is generally smooth and legato, with a nicely inflected sense of line. Do not expect rhythmic cells to be articulated in the detached way we have come to take for granted in period performance practice. The expressive qualities of the music emerge effortlessly and naturally, without underlining or italicizing.  This approach can at times seem a bit dull, though if one will more often than not find it engaging as long as one is willing to appreciate a style of performance very different from what we have recently come to expect.  I have enjoyed Werner's Bach recordings for decades--through various incarnations on LP and CD--and I expect that unbiased listeners willing to follow Werner's Bach in the unglamorous "slow lane", so to speak, will be richly rewarded.  It is to be hoped that this latest, and relatively inexpensive, reissue of this material from Warner will inspire a new generation of listeners willing to revisit and retrieve the distinguished contributions of these early-music pioneers who did so much to revive great music that had hitherto remained obscure--such as the Bach Cantatas.Since I already own the previous Warner/Erato reissue of Werner's Bach recordings, I cannot comment on the sound quality of this new edition.  The sound, on LP and earlier CD incarnations, was always good, though with a hint of overload at higher dynamic levels (more noticeable in the arias than choral movements).  I strongly recommend this volume, and its companion (containing the Passions, Christmas Oratorio, B-Minor Mass and Motets), to collectors of all ages and persuasions; these recordings will afford much edification--and more than enough aesthetic food for thought.

If you are a Haydn enthusiat, then by all means consider purchasing  this superb collection of 79 Haydn symphonies performed by one of the premier period-instrument ensembles at the height of their collective powers under Chris Hogwood.  It is a shame that Universal/L'Oiseau-Lyre apparently abandoned this project to record all 108 Haydn Symphonies before it reached completion. To date there has been no integral recording of them on period instruments.  However, if the listener is willing to supplement Hogwood's incomplete cycle with other recordings of nos. 76-93, 95, 97-99 and 101-103, a complete collection of Haydn symphonies can be assembled.Hogwood's approach to Haydn is brisk but not breathless, bracing but not fierce, elegant but not mincing, scholarly but not pedantic.  The AAM plays splendidly throughout (the natural horns, for which Haydn often wrote excruciatingly difficult parts in his early-to-middle period deserve special commendation).  Hogwood and his band are always aware of the shifts in idiom and style that occur not only from one period of Haydn's career to the next, but often within a single work!  Was there a style that this astonishingly resourceful composer had not mastered--Baroque, Galant, "Sturm und Drang," High Classical and even proto-Romantic? Though not always a "period performance" enthusiast, I find the AAM's spare ensemble sonority (presumably what Haydn would have had at his disposal in Esterhaza) and resultant chamber-music textures delightful, particularly in slow movements. I also applaud Hogwood's decision not to employ a harpsichord (or other) continuo; it is not needed, and its incessant clatter would prove quite distracting over the long haul of this very expansive symphonic canon.  Textures emerge clearly, and often with fetching delicacy, without any reinforcement from a keyboard instrument.  Hogwood favors taking all repeats, even those in the recap of the Minuets; some listeners may find this too much of a good thing, but this was the scholarly protocol Hogwood adhered to.Despite occasional interpretive misfires, this is as consistently satisfying a HIP traversal of the bulk of Haydn's symphonic output as you will find.  Strongly recommended -- though I would search elsewhere for an affordable copy.ADDENDUM:  Only a few days after I wrote the above review, I noted that the price for this set had come down significantly--though it is still quite high for what is, ostensibly, a "bargain box."  If you have the means, however, this edition should prove either an invigorating introduction to these works or an invaluable supplement to whatever other Haydn recordings you have in your collection.  Dorati's complete cycle, on modern instruments, is still the most generally recommendable way of acquiring "Haydn in bulk," though compared with Hogwood's airy lightness, Dorati's direction can seem heavy-handed.

Despite his reputation as a martinet and as a cold, cerebral perfectionist, George Szell made a huge number of splendid recordings during his long career as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra.  In fact, an attentive audition of the contents of this massive, 49-CD mega-box reveals a musician that was not only in total control of his craft--and his ensemble--but also an unfailingly imaginative, insightful, and elegant interpreter of the standard repertoire.  Hearing these classic recordings, one is not only riveted by the intensity of Szell's music-making with the Clevlanders, one is also frequently surprised by how affectionate Szell's interpretations could be.  Indeed, if one is prepared to listen objectively, the stereotype of Szell as "all head and no heart" will be repeatedly dis-confirmed.There is far too much repertoire included in this massive box to give an exhastive commentary in in a brief review.  Other websites give specific information about content.  I will only mention a few specifics.  First, the megabox in question was produced under the auspices of Sony in South Korea.  There may be other incarnations of "Szell: the Edition," but this is the one to get: it is housed in a beautifully designed, and user-friendly, box.  Great care has gone into its production: each cardboard sleeve not only provides the usual information, but also has a plastic "inner sleeve" to protect the CD further from the rude shocks of mortal existence.  Perhaps this design was intended to evoke nostalgia--and boost sales--among LP-collecting baby-boomers. A fairly useful booklet is also provided, with track listings and an appreciation of Szell's artistry in Korean and (poorly translated) English.  Original recording dates are given, but no indication of when, where and how the digital remasterings were done.  The sound, however, is very good indeed--vivid, richly textured, with a warm Severance Hall ambiance to mitigate any chilliness in the interpretations (rare, in any case, as I have indicated above).  Are these the same remasterings Sony used for the Essential Classics and Masterworks Heritage series?  Perhaps, though some of the repertoire included in the box (Bartok's *Concerto for Orchestra*,Janacek's *Sinfonietta*, Rossini Overtures, etc.) have not previously appeared on CD--at least to the best of my knowledge. I didn't have any previous incarnations of this material on hand for comparison (having sold my entire Szell CD collection in order to obtain this box), but if my non-audiophile ears are any judge, the sound is mostly better than on any previous CBS or Sony reissue--indeed, often startlingly realistic.  But I may be imagining things--so take my remarks with a generous helping of skepticism.  It may also be that some of the "helpful" reverberation has been added electronically; if so, this listener regards the results as a distinct improvement over the slightly dry acoustics on many Szell/CBS LP's and earlier CD's.Some peculiarities are worth mentioning. This is, of course, not the complete Szell discography for CBS/Sony. I have no problems with that: a judicious representative collection may be what most Szell aficionados would want in any case.  However, it seems odd that such a massive retrospective of this great conductor's career would omit some of his best-known recordings.  Why, for instance was Szell's live recording of Mahler's Sixth included, but not his great studio account of the Fourth (one of his greatest efforts and universally commended by critics)?  Why include just one of Szell's numerous concerto recordings with Fleischer (Mozart's no. 25), and none of his collaborations with Serkin or Casadesus?  Yet the Mozart Clarinet Concerto and Strauss Horn Concerto no. 1 *are* included? Another oddity concerns the distribution of works per CD.  Some of the CD's are well filled (corresponding to previous reissues, or at least adding up to a respectable 60+ minutes of music); others, however, are astonishingly skimpy, such as the disc that contains only Beethoven's Eighth Symphony.  Why the Seventh and Eighth Symphonies couldn't have been combined on a single CD is a mystery to me.  There are many cases in which some of the well-known Szell recordings omitted in this collection could have been easily accommodated as a pairing with a given work.  There would have been plenty of room to accommodate at least some more Fleischer-Szell concerto recordings, or that great Mahler Fourth.  Granted, these recordings are readily available elsewhere, but it would seem ludicrous not to include them in this set given some of the skimpy playing times.Though I cannot comment in detail on the repertoire included in this box, suffice it to say that it is indeed representative of Szell at his best.  The Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven (including mono and stereo versions several Mozart symphonies) are all outstanding performances. I hadn't heard the Beethoven cycle for many years, but this time I was struck by the delicacy of certain phrasings and textures that Szell manages to evoke from his ensemble.  Though there is plenty of heaven-storming Toscaninian drama, Szell manages to convey a chamber-music intimacy to some of the more lyrical passages that I found both moving and surprising.  The Schumann and Brahms cycles (both complete) successfully combine classical clarity of structure with romantic warmth of expression.  His Dvorák Symphonies 7-9 are among the most exhilarating--and idiomatic--renderings of these  works available. Many listeners may be astonished at the sensitivity and luxuriant warmth of Szell's Richard Strauss tone poems; there are no finer versions than his of the four included in this box.  Szell's Mahler and Bruckner are also outstanding.  If the version of Mahler's Sixth included here doesn't quite evoke the terror of Bernstein or the searing intensity of Metropoulos--and one regrets the omission of the exposition repeat in the first movement--it nevertheless manages to communicate communicates a sense of tragic inevitability and (in the Andante) yearning for deliverance. I have a special fondness for Szell's Bruckner; he was one of the few conductors who could elicit an authentic Brucknerian sonority from an American orchestra. Some of his tempos might be considered controversial (the slow and rustic Scherzo in his account of the Eighth is a good example), as will his choice of Editions, but on the whole Szell probes more deeply into the dark corners of these works than Jochum, Haitink, Chailly, Barenboim, Böhm and any number of more renknowned Brucknerians.  The Twentieth-Century repertoire is also splendid: an incisive and classically-proportioned Bartok *Concerto for Orchestra*, robust and delightfully subversive Hindemith *Symphonic Metamorphoses*, and searingly intense Walton are among the highlights for me.Incidental caveats aside, this remains a highly desirable set for admirers of the conductor and collectors who would like to discover why Szell and the Clevlanders earned such a high reputation among concertgoers and critics during their long collaboration. Szell really did build the best symphony orchestra in the USA during his tenure, and his many recordings constitute a remarkable testament of music-making at the highest pitch of excellence--at times approaching as close to perfection as is humanly possible.  A strong endorsement, then, and an admonition to purchase this set while it is available; my guess is that its currency might be brief.

This box contains Brendel's first Mozart cycle, with Marriner and the Academy, expertly remastered and offered in the bargain-basement price range. As such it is excellent value, despite skimpy notes (in German).  Brendel's way with Mozart is well-known and often celebrated.  Not for him the expressive nuances of Perahia, Uchida or Barenboim.  Brendel's Mozart is vigorous, plainspoken and, at times, a bit prosaic.  In compensation, however, the listener gets a non-interventionist, but always stylish, reading of Mozart as near as possible to authentic performance practice as can be conveyed on a modern piano, with a modern-instrument chamber orchestra of appropriate size.  If that approach to these evergreen works appeals to you, then this set could function as a a fine "starter collection" of the Mozart Concertos (minus the four from KV 107 and those numbered 1-4, all of which derive from works of other composers, though they are arranged as concertos by Mozart himself). The set does include the two- and three-piano Concertos, nos. 10 & 7 respectively, though the latter is given in a very effective arrangement for two pianos.  Both are played with zest and imagination by Brendel and Imogen Cooper.Among the highlights of Brendel's cycle, I would cite the following:  6, 8, 9, 13, 14, 18, 19, 22, 23, 25, and 27. All of these remain free of the didacticism that could sometimes afflict Brendel's playing in the 1970's and 1980's. Few versions of no. 9 convey it's bold inventiveness as effectively as Brendel/Marriner, and I would cite that performance as the high-point of Brendel's cycle for this listener.  Nos. 20 and 24 are appropriately dramatic in a Beethovenian way, though occasionally the brittleness of Brendel's approach--and his tone--prove irksome.  That brittleness is also in evidence in no. 5, which is altogether too aggressive, and intermittently in nos. 15, 21 and 26 as well.  But I am not disposed to overemphasize these liabilities, for Brendel proves throughout this set to be a more than reliable guide to repertoire he obviously knows intimately and loves enthusiastically.  That enthusiasm ultimately wins the day, even in certain works where one might wish for a more gracious, lyrical approach.  For listeners who might find Perahia too delicate, Barenboim too personal, Ashkenazy too robust, and Uchida too introverted (among the complete cycles with which I am familiar), Brendel's collaboration with Marriner and the Academy at the heght of their collective powers might be your best bet.  Moreover, having a first-rate exponent of 18th-Century music at the helm assures that the orchestral contribution has the expert leadership it sometimes lacks in pianist-directed versions of these works.Altogether, a successful venture, strongly recommended, particularly in this price range.  Of course, every classical music lover and pianophile should at least consider obtaining certain Mozart concerto recordings that have deservedly acquired classic status--such as Edwin Fischer in many of the late concertos; Haskil in nos. 9, 13, 29 and 24; Serkin/Szell in 19 & 20; Casadesus/Szell in 21-24, 26-27; Curzon in 20, 23, 24, and 27; Gilels in 27; Kempff in 8, 22, 23, 24 and 27; and Bernstein (as soloist and conductor) in 15.  I would also strongly recommend Brendel's earlier recordings for Vox (particularly 25, 27 and the two-piano Concerto with Klien) and for Vanguard (9 & 14 with Janigro/Zagreb). Haebler's distinctive--if rather "dresden-china-ish" cycle with Rowiki for Phillips is regrettably long-gone, as is (I believe) Kraus's less consistently successful cycle with Simon and a pick-up Viennese Orchestra.  If some or all of those two cycles were reissued, that would be a benefaction for collectors.  Kraus's splendid versions of 12 & 18 with Monteux and the BSO is currently available for direct order from Haydn House, in good transfers (don't hesitate if you are an admirer of the pianist).

Suzuki's chronological survey of the complete Bach Cantatas nears its completion with this "antepenultimate" volume in the series.  Though Suzuki, the BCJ, and his appointed soloists have gone from strength to strength throughout this venture, their treatment of the "late" Cantatas has been extraordinarily satisfying.  Recent volumes have witnessed renewed vigor tempered with a suppleness and lyricism less consistently in evidence elsewhere in the series.  Add to this what seems to be a more forthright placement either by engineers, or by Suzuki, of the vocal ensemble--so that their important polyphonic contribution doesn't get swallowed up by the instrumental lines in full spate--and we have a recipe for success in all three of the works featured on this disc.All of them, too, are mature masterpieces not deserving of their relative neglect.  BWV 97, in particular, is a large-scaled work of remarkable ingenuity and expressiveness.  But BWV 177, with its haunting chorale fantasia on "Ich ruf' zu dir" and BWV 9 with its exuberantly joyful opening chorus and deeply expressive penitential aria for tenor are also works of outstanding invention.  Bach, as well as Suzuki, seems indeed to have saved the best for last.The performances, as indicated, are fully equal to the technical demands--as well as the consistently high invention--of these great works.  The instrumental obbligati are played with the utmost conviction and refinement (the demanding solo violin obbligato in BWV 97's tenor aria is a case in point); these musicians really dig in -- no hint of walking on eggshells (as there could be in some of the earliest volumes of this series).  The vocal ensemble likewise seems to relish the sheer pleasure of singing such remarkably complex music--as in the great French Ouverture, whose fugal section turns into a chorale fantasia, with which BWV 97 begins.  Nor is there a hint of routine anywhere in the vast contrapuntal landscapes that unfold before the listener in the opening movements of BWV 177 and BWV 9.  Far from it: the listener is completely drawn in to the theophany -- for theophanies they are.  The four soloists seem to have been given steroids, particularly the long-distance runners Blaze, Türk and Kooij, so tirelessly, even effortlessly, do they meet every challenge that Bach sends their way.  More to the point, they lift the dance-rhythms in the livelier arias, and evoke the pathos in the  meditative ones as if they were engaging in beatific play rather than coping with some of the most difficult vocal music ever written. The soprano, Hana Blazíková, though a fairly recent addition to Suzuki's roster of soloists, shows herself fully the equal of the three veterans in her deep understanding of the Bach idiom, and perhaps even surpasses them in the eager, youthful virtuosity of her singing.The SACD recording is as exemplary as are the performances.  Maximal clarity is married to ambient warmth in near-perfect proportion.As the reader can divine from my overuse of superlatives, this latest volume in Suzuki's Bach Cantata cycle is one to get.  Indeed, it may well be these artists' finest contribution to the series so far.

Listeners who have been following Suzuki's Bach Cantata series over the long haul (has it been 15 years or so -- it seems like an eternity) will know what to expect with this latest issue:  lean but not emaciated textures, snappy but not brusque rhythmic articulation, tempos that seem incontestably right, superb playing and singing, and of course sensitivity to Bach's religious vision without a hint of sanctimoniousness.The three works presented here are relatively "late" works; as with many of the sacred and secular works from the last 20 years of Bach's life they display an exquisitely subtle craftsmanship and an intellectual rigor that doesn't undermine, but further enlivens their spiritual depths.  BWV 140 is arguably the most popular of all Bach's cantatas, and it receives a first-rate performance here.  The opening chorale setting receives a brisk, confident and joyful account.  Suzuki balances the soprano cantus firmus (reinforced by a brass instrument) perfectly in relation to the dense contrapuntal activity in the lower three parts.  Suzuki preserves a sense of majesty here, amid the urgent call to spiritual awakening.  The two duets between Christ and the soul -- the Bridegroom and the bride -- retain this sense of joyous expectancy.  The erotic undercurrent is brought out (this is baroque opera at its most sublime!), yet without undue sentimentality (as was often the case in older recordings of this work). Blazikova and Kooij surpass all competition among HIP recordings with which I am familiar: theirs is glorious singing by any standard.  The famous tenor chorale, exquisitely sung by Gerd Türk swings ahead with unforced naturalness at just the right tempo.  BWV 112, though not as famous as "Wachet auf!" is no less inspired.  It is given a magnificent reading here.  The prominent corno da caccia parts in the opening chorale setting are given their head, with stunning results--despite one or two rough moments.  Robin Blaze is splendid in the alto aria, and in the bass arioso is appropriately spooky -- and expressively sung by Kooij. However, the high point of this peformance was, for me, the soprano-tenor duet, in which the two soloists manage to accommodate Bach's excruciatingly high tessitura, and rapid roulades, without so much as a hint of strain. I have always found this movement hard to listen to in most other recordings; the mood should be exuberantly joyful, but so often it is simply tense, due either to the evident discomfort of the singers, or to an overly brusque approach (or both).  Overall, this is the most satisfying version of BWV 112 I have heard; at least a version that is virtually flawless and that realizes the work's inherent nobility as well as its dramatic contrasts.  BWV 29 is well-known due its scintillating sinfonia, for which Bach transforms the opening movement of the E-major violin Partita into a concertante juggernaut for organ and festive ensemble (bedecked with trumpets).  This receives a thrilling account here; the ornate organ part going like the wind.  The opening chorus was later adapted for the "Gratias agimus"/"Dona nobis pacem" movements in the b-minor Mass.  It is given a splendid rendition by Suzuki's forces. I was delighted to note that Suzuki is not shy about building the piece inexorably to its climax, with the entrance of the trumpets and timpani.  Thereafter the elaborate arias and ariosi are sung with that combination passionate involvement and virtuosity that has been a hallmark of this installment in Suzuki's Cantata series.The SACD recording seems more immediate in its impact than some previous issues.  Moreover, the engineers have managed to give needed clarity and focus to the choral textures, thereby forestalling my longstanding complaint about the series (indeed, my one and only complaint)--namely, that the the vocal ensemble could sometimes sound emaciated in relation to the surrounding orchestral textures, with the result that important contrapuntal detail gets submerged.Given the quality of the music -- three of Bach's greatest works in the genre -- and of the performances, which deserve a "straight A" as we professorial types would say, this volume is one not to miss in Suzuki's near-complete traversal of the Cantatas.

I have only recently discovered the artistry of Simone Dinnerstein via her recent all-Bach album for Sony (the one with two keyboard concerti, an English Suite, and assorted transcriptions of organ chorale preludes). Her stunning playing on that CD prompted purchase of the recital under review here.  The unlikely pairing of Bach and Schubert amply displays her signal pianistic virtues: exquisite phrasing, astonishing control of tone, touch and texture, and an artistic sensibility that seems like a throwback to the very greatest pianists of yesteryear. One critic justly compared her to Dame Myra Hess, though I am reminded even more of Maria Tipo--another controversial artist--in the Bach partitas. The Schubert finds a depth of expression reminiscent of Radu Lupu, and no praise could be higher.  Her Bach is on a similarly exalted plane, though not every listener will approve of her pronounced rubato and agogic hesitations. These traits of her pianistic persona do not bother me, however; I grew up with the very personalized Bach of Glenn Gould.  I find that the Leipzig Cantor's creations not only survive, but positively thrive, when the recreative artist takes interpretive risks.This is indeed astonishingly beautiful playing.  I cannot recommend this recital highly enough, despite its baffling title and somewhat glitzy presentation (which make Dinnerstein seem like the latest crossover phenomenon).

Barenboim was at his best when he recorded for EMI early in his career.  His renditions of the Mozart and Beethoven Piano Concertos, as well as his chamber-music collaborations with du Pré and Zukerman, from that time (1965-1970) have always struck me as among the finest ever accounts of standard pianistic repertoire.  So, too, are his renditions of Beethoven's 32 Sonatas--the so-called "New Testament" of piano literature (the OT being Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier).  This is feisty, youthful Beethoven, and none the worse for that.  I appreciate this approach even in the more exalted, late works, which receive appropriately thoughtful, if somewhat romanticized accounts here, with plenty of *Sturm und Drang* to leaven the mysticism.  At times in the later works I was reminded of past masters such as Egon Petri or Myra Hess (to implicate two very unlikely suspects).  In the early and middle-period works, Barenboim's spontaneous combustion keeps the music from ever sounding routine; no phrase is taken for granted, and each is lovingly and creatively sculpted.  Throughout, Barenboim's rich tone and sparkling treble register  (beautifully captured by EMI's engineers) make this one of the most ear-pleasing, indeed sensuously beautiful Beethoven cycles of the stereo era.  The occasional smudged passagework or uneven trill reminds the listener not of any technical liabilities on Barenboim's part, but of the long takes -- perhaps even entire movements -- that afford a simulacrum of live performance throughout the cycle. Some listeners may resist some of Barenboim's controversial interpretive choices.some of which may well have been decided on the spur of the moment, such as the application of discernible rubato and other tempo modifications within a movement, or occasional extremes of tempo (at both ends of the spectrum).  Despite these minor caveats, however, this could conceivably be a first choice for neophyte collectors on the lookout for an inexpensive Beethoven cycle. One could  then go on to obtain more historically significant cycles by the likes of Schnabel, Kempff, Backhaus or Brendel (Vox is best) for comparison and contrast.  My only criticism of this latest reissue of Barenboim's first (and better) Beethoven cycle is that the booklet has omitted the superb and detailed annotations of the previous edition in favor of skimpy and generalized comments.  No matter; this one is a winner!

Ormandy's *Heldenleben* as been my preferred version for years. I find it more rewarding than more famous versions by Karajan, Reiner and Beecham.  Ormandy's account features rich, sumptuous orchestral playing, as we would expect, but also a very intelligent structuring of the whole, so that the work doesn't sound episodic (as it can in concert or on record).  Finer still are Szell's fizzing accounts of *Don Juan* and *Till Eulenspiegel*:  the playing of the Clevelanders, though less voluptuous than Ormandy's Philadelphians, is amazingly crisp, clear, and full of character.  The wind playing (including the all-important French Horns) is astonishingly virtuosic.  Szell's direction has the listener hanging on every note as these two musical narratives unfold.  All three recordings sound fine to my ears: fuller in Philadelphia; cleaner in Cleveland.This CD provides something like an ideal introduction to Richard Strauss for the neophyte.  For more extensive surveys of his tone poems, I can strongly recommend 2-CD sets by Haitink (on Phillips Duo) and Solti (Decca/London).  Then of course there are the larger surveys by Kempe (Warner/EMI and Brilliant), Reiner (Sony/RCA) and Karajan (DG)-- each one a classic, and all available now in affordable "bargain boxes."

I can only echo the views of my fellow reviewers (three to date):  Constantin Silvestri is indeed one of the top ten (I would say top half-dozen) most underappreciated conductors.  I, too, purchased the ten-CD set from Disky at an exorbitant price a few years ago.  I do not, however, regret that decision, for that set has given me enormous enjoyment.  Now the prospect of having the remainder of Silverstri's EMI recordings in my collection (minus his collaborations with Francois and Menuhin) is more than worth the nominal cost of the entire 15-CD collection.SIlverstri's Dvorák and Tchaikovsky are justly famous for their combination of visceral excitement with intelligent musicianship. But Silvestri's repertoire was huge; he does equally well with composers as diverse as Elgar, Shostakovitch, Rimsky-Korsakoff, and Ravel.  Much though I admire Silvestri's fellow-countryman, Celibidache (particularly in Bruckner), I have to say that the former is by far the more consistently satisfying conductor.  His interpretations never wear out their welcome with repeated hearing, as can those of Celibidache.  Among great conductors of which I am aware, Silvestri's interpretive priorities most resemble those of Cantelli in favoring swift (but not breathless) tempos, beautifully sustained cantabile phrasing, incisive rhythmic articulation without abruptness, carefully "etched" coloristic detail, and perfectly balanced orchestral textures. Why, then, is his artistry not better known?  Why has EMI waited so long to revive his recorded legacy?However one is inclined to answer these questions, we must be grateful for this massive retrospective edition of a conductor who deserves another chance at the limelight.P.S.:  And while you're at it, obtain the Carl Schuricht box from EMI/Icon.  Another sadly underappreciated conductor, somewhat less well served by EMI (though what he did record for that label is treasureable).

I have been purchasing Naxos discs for nigh on twenty years.  Frequently, they hold outstanding performances of standard and more esoteric repertoire; but just as frequently the performances are not quite competitive with the best the "major labels" have to offer (though the very concept of a "major label" could be called into question these days). In any case, this humble entry in the Naxos catalog is a jewel in the that label's crown.  These concertos for standard oboe and oboe d'amore are actually reconstructions of works that we usually hear in Bach's own adaptations for single or double harpsichord.  Bach's originals have been lost, though musicological research has determined that they were probably concertos for oboe.  In the case of BWV 1059--a stunning work in d-minor--the outer movements derive from the two sinfonias from Cantata BWV 35. The slow movement could have been some version of a cantata aria featuring obbligato oboe (the alto aria from BWV 42 has sometimes been motted as a possibility, as has the first aria from BWV 35).  In this recording Hommel and Müller-Bruhl give us a transcription of the slow movement from Alessandro Marcello's famous oboe concerto (the entirety of which Bach himself transcribed for keyboard, so its inclusion here is not as much of a speculative stretch as it might seem).The main reason to purchase this disc, however, is not only to hear skilful reconstructions of speculative original versions, but to enjoy Christian Hommel's exquisite playing and the ensemble's lively and gracious contribution under Müller-Bruhl's skilful direction.  Hommel clearly has the measure of the late-baroque idiom, though he and the members of the Cologne Chamber Orchestra are apparently playing modern instruments in historically-informed style (the pitch sounds like A-440 to my ears).  Hommel phrases with utter sensitivity not only in the expressive slow movements (where we would expect him to) but also in the outer movements, which are taken at quite a clip here. His virtuosity in negotiating the elaborate figuration, ornamentation and "editorial" cadenzas is quite formidable.  Müller-Bruhl, whose work in Bach I had not previously heard, is also on his mettle here -- as are his players.  He direction is incisive and highly charged, bringing out the dance-rhythms infectiously.  The harpsichord continuo player also deserves accolades for his or her imaginative and brilliantly executed realizations.  The recording is as vivid as the performances, though the soloist seems to be given a slight measure of artificial prominence.Listeners willing to engage speculative though entirely idiomatic reconstructions of familiar Bach will find much to enjoy here.  Very strongly recommended!

So many accolades have been given this recording already -- including the Gramophone "Record of the Year" Award from 2012 -- that yet another review would seem superfluous.  I will therefore add only a few brief comments:I begin by affirming that this is probably the finest Schütz recording to date (though Frieder Bernius's DHM recording of Symphoniae Sacrae III runs it a close second, in my estimation).  The singing is indeed "luminous" and beautifully blended, and the ensemble's understanding and projection of the words (all-important in this composer) is impeccable.  Rhythms are lively but never punched out.  Tempos are perfectly set to underscore the affect of the text; nothing is breezed over, and nothing is trudged through.  The four funeral motets that accompany the *Musicalische Exequien* are exquisite and rarely heard works; Meunier's renditions of these are equally exquisite.The recorded sound is eminently natural, with a pleasing reverberant "halo" around the voices, yet without blurring.  My only criticism would be that the solo voices in the concluding motet of the *Musicalische Exequien* ("Selig sind die Toten) are placed rather too distantly from the microphones for their contribution to make its make  intended effect.  They sound ethereal and seraphic--as they should--but the dynamic contrast between them and the ripieno ensemble is too steep.That minor quibble aside, this recording is one every Schütz devotee should own.  It clearly outstrips any previous recording of the Requiem (Gardiner's estimable version now sounds fussy and overemphatic by comparison).Laus Deo!

I just discovered the Richter *Messiah*, and it has been quite a revelation.  I have collected recorded versions of this work--always a favorite, and not just during high holy days--for nearly half a century. I am also quite familiar with Richter's numerous Bach recordings, as well as his superb rendition of Handel's *Samson.*  But for some reason I have never gotten around, until now, to auditioning his Messiah.  Perhaps I was deterred by the fact that Richter recorded this work not with his usual ensembles--the Munich Bach Orchestra and Choir--but with English forces (LPO/John Alldis Choir).  Or more likely, I felt an certain reluctance to purchase yet another version of a work that I know so well, and in so many editions, reconstructions, and performance practices.  In any case, I am delighted at having discovered what is, in my estimation, one of the most effective renditions of the work ever commited to disc.  No, that is not the mot juste:  "effective" is just too neutral an adjective.  Better to say stunning, sublime, elevating, indeed -- glorious!  I don't know what to praise most: Ricther's intensely dramatic, perfectly proportioned, lofty conception of the work; the John Alldis Choir's beautifully focused, nimbly exectued, and clearly articulated choral singing; the sumptuous but still idiomatic orchestral playing; the deeply expressive singing of the four soloists; or the brilliant continuo realizations by Hedwig Bilgram (imported from Munich along with Herr Richter).  Well, I shall praise all of these elements, since all contribute to something like a total realization of the work (mostly the Prout sequence, with one minor variant in the form of the tenor arioso version of "their sound has gone out").I will confine my detailed remarks to Richter's conception of the work and the solo singing.  As might have been anticipated from his recordings of the great choral works of Bach, Richter fully appreciates the spiritual dimensions of Handel's masterpiece.  *Messiah* is, for Richter, not just a musico-dramatic entertainment; nor is it simply a cultural icon, much less a museum piece to be contemplated in a state of historicist abstraction. Rather, it is nothing short of living communion, in sound, with the central mysteries of the Christian Faith. Of course, Richter is (mostly) aware of correct performance practice when it comes to tempo articulation and ornamentation, though he sees no reason to stint on the extra body of color provided by modern instruments and full-fledged solo and choral singers. He is also cognizant of the genuinely operatic qualities Handel brings even to a work which (along with *Israel In Egypt*) is among the least "operatic" of his oratorios.  And indeed he respects the work's iconic status as a mainstay of British culture and of that country's "choral festival" tradition (manifest in the grandeur of scale Richter maintains throughout, though minus the excessive stateliness of overinflated Victorian/Edwardian performances).  Finally, a word about the soloists.  Veteran collectors of *Messiah* recordings, myself included, will have distinct preferences on this score, and they may not coincide with any of the singers Richter (or DG) has enlisted for this recording.  To my ears, only Donald MacIntyre--who is genuinely awe-inspiring in most of his arias--could be thought to equal or surpass the best of the competition. Otherwise, I would give the nod to Alexander Young over Stuart Burrows, Janet Baker or Helen Watts over Anna Reynolds (haunting though her distinctive timbre is in "He was despised"), Pierette Alarie or Jennifer Vyvvian over Helen Donath (not ideally pure of voice).  But this is a impossibly competitive field--and Ricther's solo team is, overall, "as good as any and better than most."The remastered recording is rich, detailed, spacious and capable of considerable visceral impact in the grander numbers (the concluding "Amen" will lift you right out of your seat).In sum, this is a *Messiah* to cherish along with whatever other recordings you happen to favor; for me that will always be, among modern performance practice versions, Scherchen (mono and stereo), Beecham (mono and stereo), Sargent (1961 "Reader's Digest" recording), and Andrew Davis.  Each of these has its distinctive virtues and deficiencies, and Richter--the addition to my list of favorites--is no exception.  Whether over the long haul of numerous re-hearings it emerges as the one I would take, above all others, to the proverbial desert island, I cannot say.  But I predict that I will be returning to it regularly for spiritual edification as well as musical enrichment.  Don't miss it if you happen to resonate with my enthusiasms as articulated in this review.

The cantatas featured on the latest installment of Suzuki/BCJ's ongoing Bach Cantata series are among the most obscure in the Leipzig Cantor's output.  Nevertheless, all are delightful, edifying works.  I am particularly fond of BWV 195 (a wedding cantata) with its spectacular opening chorus -- rich with fugal textures and adorned with the most enlivening orchestral fireworks imaginable.  Those nuptials must have been quite an occasion!  BWV 192 is also a very engaging work; light, even galant in mood (as are the central movements of BWV 195), it provides an unexpectedly delicate setting for a hearty, and very well-known, Lutheran hymn (in English, "Now thank we all our God").  BWV 157 is also a light-textured work, in chamber style.  It's winsome charm is somewhat at odds with its funereal purpose, but who's complaining?  Finally, BWV 120a, which may be getting its first-ever airing here, is a reconstructed variant of the more familiar Town Council Election Cantata, BWV 120.  The Wedding version includes three recitatives, with choral interjections, that are not found in BWV 120.  The arias, too, are quite different in scoring and texture from their counterparts in the Election cantata.All of these rarely-heard works receive superb performances from these well-seasoned players and singers.  The vocal soloists include a tenor and countertenor who are, I believe, new to the series, and who, at least for the present recording, replace the "regulars" Gerd Türk and Robin Blaze.  All four cope well with the often hefty demands of their arias, though I don't quite care for the tenor soloist's nasal timbre (which acquires a whiny edge at the upper extremity of his range).  Bass Peter Kooij, as usual, delivers the goods--especially in the enchantingly whimsical central aria of BWV 195. As is Suzuki's regular practice, the soloists also sing in the larger vocal ensemble (three to a part); their nimble and finely nuanced singing is commendable, even if the balance of forces frequently favors the instruments over the voices (my one longstanding complaint against the Suzuki Cantata project).  This balance may be intentional on the part of the conductor; or it may be a function of the reverberant acoustic of the Kobe Shoin Chapel plus the engineering; but it sometimes obscures important fugal entrances and textural detail in the "choral" movements.But why quibble?  The music is glorious--and at times, in these works, quite unexpectedly forward-looking (the bass aria in BWV 195 almost sounds as if it could have been composed by one of Bach's sons; was this a gesture of acceptance of the ethos of a younger generation, presumably that of the nuptial pair, on the part of an aging composer?).  The performances convey a kind of joyful abandon and flexibility that we haven't always heard from this ensemble and conductor.  One of the best of a generally outstanding series, in my estimation.  Collectors of the series or neophytes need not hesitate.

Nicolai Lugansky was just a name in the music periodicals prior to my auditioning this set.  Now he has joined the ranks of great pianists in my estimation.  His teacher Tatiana Nicolayeva predicted that he would be successor to Richter and Gilels, and her estimation is by no means hyperbole.  This extrordinarily gifted pianist combines Richter's probing intellect and tensile strength with Gilels's sensitivity and exquisite touch.  He also brings to these recordings an distinctive exploratory quality, an inventiveness that takes nothing for granted.Among the highlights in this set, which surveys a decade's worth of recordings for the Erato/Warner label, is a coruscating traversal of the Chopin Etudes that exhibits jaw-dropping technical facility and sensitivity to nuance in equal measure.  This joins the select company of Pollini and Perahia at the top of the heap (and a huge heap it is -- a great many virtuosi have scaled this technical Everest on records).  Another highlight is a complete traversal of the Rachmaninov Piano Concertos with the Birmingham orchestra under the direction of Sakari Oramo.  His renditions of nos. 1 and 4 are among the very few I have heard that make an entirely convincing case for these works which have tended to hide in the shadow of the ever-popular c-minor and d-minor works.  Clarity and poise coupled with scintillating passagework and, throughout, a seriousness of purpose, make Lugansky's accounts of all four concertos uniquely memorable. The same can be said for the Paganini Rhapsody. I haven't been as swept away by these works since I first encountered the old Wild-Horenstein set three decades ago.  Oramo and his fine orchestra offer alert and incisive support.  We are also given a generous helping of solo works by Rachmaninov -- Preludes, Etudes-Tableaux, and two sets of Variations (Corelli and Chopin).  I was particularly impressed by the variation.  These works can seem diffuse in structure and uneven in inspiration; but under Lugansky's fluent and intelligent fingers, they sparkle and entice as I am sure the composer intended.There is more Chopin solo repertoire to enjoy as well; all of it technically astonishing and always thoughtful, if at times overly serious; one wishes he would lighten the mood where appropriate.  The same could be said for the Beethoven sonatas which greet the prospective listener enticingly on the first disc. Lugansky bears down on these works for all of the intensity they are worth; and while there is nothing trite or trivial about these performances, the doesn't quite convey Beethoven's variegation of moods and textures.  There is more unbuttoned humor in no. 22, elegence in no. 7 and tenderness in no. 23 than he allows us to hear. But then I was brought up on Kempff's Beethoven, and that may account for why I found Lugansky's interpretations a bit relentless.  They are, nevertheless, eminently musical and technically astonishing, as is everything else in this set.Two chamber works are included in this set:  the Chopin and Rachmaninov Cello Sonatas with Valdimir Knushev.  Cellist and pianist think and play as one here: this is a genuine partnership, in which both artists exploit every opportunity for conversational interaction.  Rarely have I heard these works performed so convincingly; they are masterpieces of their kind, yet in numerous recordings their full stature is eclipsed either by the performers' egos or by their failure to appreciate the subtle invention in each work.  Needless to say, both artists play at full stretch technically, and these are very demanding works for both cellist and pianist.Despite one or two reservations noted above, I cannot recommend this inexpensive and vividly recorded set strongly enough.  If you haven't heard Lugansky, or want to add some or all of this repertoire to your collection, don't hesitate to purchase thsi compilation while it is available.

Carl Schuricht was clearly one of the great masters of the podium, though his legacy remains underappreciated -- in part because he recorded less frequently than many of his contemporaries (e.g., Toscanini, Furtwängler, Böhm, Klemperer, Walter), and in part because his conductorial persona was more introverted than theirs.  Schuricht never courted or cultivated cult status; his podium manners were as gentlemanly and undemonstrative as his interpretations are direct and unfussy.  In general he favored brisk tempos, clearly articulated rhythmic patterns, finely shaped but never overinflected phrasing, and judicious orchestral balances (even in the biggest Brucknerian climaxes the brass are never allowed to blare).Speaking of Bruckner, Schuricht is generally acknowledged as one of the finest interpreters of that composer, and these EMI recordings of the third, eighth and ninth symphonies with the VPO (then as now one of the very greatest Bruckner orchestras) amply supports that assessment. Schuricht's commercial recording of the third has not been readily available since the LP era (though there was a CD reissue on a minor label a number of years ago).  It is a splendid interpretation: the opening conveys just the right atmosphere of mystery, of exalted expectation, and as the first movement proceeds, each climax is perfectly placed and graded.  The architecture emerges more clearly than in most other versions I have heard.  The raptures of the slow movement, on the other hand, are not overplayed; there is a discretion and a naturalness to Schuricht's exposition that completely avoids schmaltz (sometimes a risk when Brucknerian lyricism is overplayed); the relatively flowing tempo helps him in this regard. The scherzo is incisive, dramatic, but also playful as it should be.  Since this is the 1889-90 text, the finale is severely truncated; but Schuricht manages to make the movement seem unified, expansive and a satisfying culmination to the work, avoiding any abruptness.  And that great polka-chorale episode has never been so perfectly articulated or balanced (in my listening experience, anyway).  The Eighth and Ninth share similar virtues.  These are better-known recordings, having been reissued at least once before by EMI, and critics have usually responded favorably to them.  Some listeners may find Schuricht's Ninth somewhat wanting in fervor; the great dissonant climaxes (such as the one occurring just before the coda of the third movement) are not as shattering as they can be with other conductors (Schuricht will seem downright tame when compared with Furtwängler or even Jochum).  But this relative gentleness fits well within Schuricht's general conception of the work, which is more lyrical and open-hearted, even optimistic, than one usually hears.  There can be no such reservations about Schuricht's Eighth, however.  In this work the conductor gives a perfectly balanced exposition of the Nowak edition -- neither the agony nor the ecstasy allowed to dominate.  To be sure the first movement broods effectively, the scherzo sweeps along rambustiously, the adagio carries the listener forward on a tide -- but not a tsunami -- of exaltation, and the finale is a cogent symphonic argument, not just a relentless juggernaut.Altogether, a feast for Brucknerians, especially for those who are eager to hear a kinder, gentler approach to their favored composer.As if this were not sufficient, we are also given a remarkable Beethoven cycle with a vintage French orchestra, captured while its distinctive, francophone timbres were still in full cry.  Schuricht's approach to Beethoven is mobile, light-textured, sometimes hard-hitting, and rhythmically snappy at fairly brisk tempos.  One is reminded most of Leibowitz and Ansermet in this composer, and not at all of Schuricht's German compatriots.  If you resist ponderous Beethoven, but find Toscanini too harried and hectic, then Schuricht's cycle is for you.  Yes, those francophone horns do sound disconcertingly like saxophones, and the trio of the Eroica's third movement adds unintentional hilarity to its athleticism as a result.  But how often does one get to hear such characterful wind playing these days?  As with any Beethoven cycle, there are strengths and weaknesses:  the Ninth doesn't storm the heavens as much as I would like, and other conductors have given us more radiant accounts of no. 4 and the *Pastoral*.  However, I regard Schuricht's *Eroica* as one of the very greatest on record (despite those vibrato-laden horns); nos. 2, 5 and 8 are not far behind: strong, trenchant, yet beautifully nuanced performances that will recall Weingartner to some listeners.A Beethoven cycle to cherish, then.As indicated, EMI has handled the remasterings particularly well; I don't recall that previous incarnations of the Bruckner 8 and 9 or the Beethoven cycle sounded quite this good.  The packaging is what one has come to expect for EMI's Icon series -- a nice, sturdy slimline box, with a booklet, detailed track listings, and annotations that include a judicious appreciation of Schuricht's artistry.If you haven't yet discovered that distinctive artistry, then here is a golden opportunity at a very affordable price!

If you haven't yet discovered the genius of Wilhelm Stenhammar, Naxos has provided a golden opportunity to explore two of his finest orchestral works at minimal expense. The Second Symphony is an astonishing work--epic in scale, brilliantly scored, graced with beguiling melodic invention, haunting modal harmonies poignant dissonances, and seemingly effortless contrapuntal mastery.  One is reminded of Bruckner at his most expansive, Brahms at his most ardent, Mendelssohn at his most elfin, Elgar at his noblest, Sibelius at his most bardic.  Yet by the time he wrote the G=minor Symphony,Stenhammar was unquestionably his own man -- closest perhaps to Nielsen in spirit (he had introduced the latter's g-minor Symphony to Göteborg audiences in 1910), but otherwise utterly distinctive. The Symphony's great fugal finale rivals that of Bruckner's Fifth in scope and ingenuity (Brucknerians, I kid you not!)--though Stenhammar's polyphony is more playful than monumental.
