The *Excelsior!* Overture is an earlier work, and stylistically more derivative (I hear a lot of Schumann and Brahms, though the shape of the themes and the occasionally capricious turns of phrase bespeak the mature Stenhammar).Both works are given very fine performances by the Royal Scottish National Orchestra under Petter Sundkvist.  My first exposure to the Second Symphony was through Järvi's earlier BIS recording taken down at a live concert,followed by his DG studio recording from the early 1990's, also with the Göteborg Symphony Orchestra.  Both of those are terrifically exciting versions, with my nod going to the rougher-hewn, but more spontaneous live performance.  Sundkvist's reading sounds a bit sober in comparison, but it is also perhaps a more deeply considered interpretation.  Sundkvist brings out the majesty of the writing in the first and last movements better than Järvi, and in the latter he also draws the polyphonic threads together more effectively.  I marginally prefer Järvi's lighter touch in the Scherzo, but in the hauntingly beautiful Andante, Sundkvist once again surpasses Järvi in conveying the "nordic summer evening" atmosphere.  Yet despite these considerations, my loyalties overall remain with Järvi, who, though he may purchase visceral excitement at the expense of nobility, nevertheless proves more involving overall. But that is not to diminish Sundkvist's steadier version, either--each earns a distinguished place (along with Järvi's DG account and Stig Westerberg on Capricorn) in the Stenhammar discography.  Sundkvist's *Excelsior!* is everything it should be--passionately engaging, refulgent in lyricism.  In both works, Sundkvist elicits fine playing from every section the RSNO.  Though the strings, as recorded here, don't sound as full of tone or incisive of attack as Järvi's Gothenbergers, the Scottish brass provide beautifully robust and rounded tone--essential in both works--and the wind playing has suitably colorful.The Naxos recording provides nicely balanced textures and plenty of impact -- when played at a higher than normal volume setting. Otherwise, the rather distant placement of the microphones (more of an issue in the Symphony than in the Overture) makes the orchestral sonorities sound a bit washed-out.In the end, however, such reservations are of minor importance; for this is probably the best single-disc introduction to Stenhammar's symphonic music available; you will by no means regret owning it.  If you are sufficiently impressed by the two works on this CD, I strongly recommend adding at least two further CDs to your Stenhammar collection:  Andrew Davis's definitive account of the great Serenade op.31 (most recently reissued with delightful Grieg and Nielsen couplings on a very inexpensive Warner Apex CD) and a recent Chandos recording of the two piano concertos.  Then, if you are sufficiently intrigued by the prospect of Stenhammar chamber music, you might want to purchase a 2-CD set from CPO of String Quartets 3-6, stunningly played by the Oslo Quartet. Brilliant Classics has also reissued the bulk of Paavo and Neeme Järvi's BIS recordings of Stenhammar orchestral music (with a couple of vocal works thrown in, though minus the Serenade)in a reasonably priced 3-CD compendium.Whatever course you decide to take, do get to know the magnificent music of Wilhelm Stenhammar.

Wilhelm Stenhammar was arguably Sweden's greatest composer -- not excluding Alfven, Wiren and Berwald.  His music is skilfully crafted (prodigious gifts for counterpoint and orchestration), melodically distinctive (his themes are as sui generis as those of Grieg, Sibelius and Nielsen), and formally inventive. His early works betrayed the influences of Brahms, Dvorak, and Bruckner (among others), but as he matured he found his voice -- and what a distinctive voice it is!  Unfortunately, the canon of his mature works is relatively small, due to the strenuous demands on Stenhammar's time as a much-in-demand concert pianist and conservatory administrator.  But what we do have from him is almost uniformly magnificent.  I would not hesitate to compare his achievement, as a symphonist and composer of string quartets, with that of his better-known Scandinavian counterparts.  One you have heard his Second Symphony you will be convinced that here is a major voice in Late Romantic music.Brilliant Classics' inexpensive survey of his orchestral works(unfortunately, minus his great Serenade, Op.31) provides a golden opportunity to acquaint yourself with this remarkable composer.  Except for the aforementioned Serenade and a couple of overtures, all of his important symphonic and concertante works are here, plus a generous helping of shorter vocal works and some incidental music.  All are worth your attention, though I predict you will return most often to the Second Symphony (worthy of Bruckner and Sibelius) and the two Piano Concertos (the first a youthfully exuberant spin-off of the Brahms B-flat major concerto and the Second a concentrated and ingeniously crafted work foreshadowing Medtner).  All of these recordings derive from the BIS label.  The two Symphonies were taken down at live performances under Neeme Järvi; both are terrifically exciting under his direction and played with utter convictio by the fine Gothenburg orchestra.  For the remainder Neeme shares the honors with Paavo, his son, who does well by the shorter works played to the hilt by the Malmö symphony.  The two violin romances are fetchingly done and the two pianists (Derwinger in Concerto 2 and Ortiz in Concerto 1) dispatch their demanding parts with considerable elan and technical fluency.  The sound--enhanced by the lively and warm acoustics of the Göteborg  hall--is exceptionally fine throughout this set: clear and detailed with plenty of ambient warmth.There is a surprising amount of competition in the current catalog for most of these compositions.  Neeme Järvi went on to record a survey of the chief orchestral works for DG (the two Symphonies, plus the Serenade and an Overture not included in Brilliant's anthology, also with the Gothenberg Philharmonic}; those performances are more polished, and perhaps more deeply considered than the spontaneously-combusting live versions reviewed above.  Some critics have opined that Järvi's characteristic penchant for brisk, no-nonsense readings undermines the lyrical splendors of Stenhammar's music, though Jarvi's relatively hard-driving approach to the two Symphonies may well be an advantage for first-time listeners, insofar as it maximizes the dramatic urgency of the music and minimizes any impression of prolixity (the very fecundidty of Stenhammar's imagination can create that impression on first hearing). Many critics prefer Stieg Westerberg's EMI recordings of the Symphonies for their greater breadth and lyrical ardor, and for this reason some listeners may prefer that recording (still available, I believe). The two piano concertos have recently been revisited by Seta Tanyel in a well-received recording on Chandos (conducted by Andrew Manze).  On the other hand, the Brilliant box has the sdvantage of containing a number of shorter pieces, in fine performances, that are hard to find in alternative versions.In sum, then, this Brilliant collection is probably the best alternative at present for listeners seeking an introduction to this composer.  If you end up catching the "Stenhammar bug"--which is quite likely given the quality of his music--you can go on to explore alternative versions of the major works.  You may also find yourself encouraged to explore Stenhammar's equally remarmable cycle of String Quartets (excellent versions of these works are available).  In any case, don't miss out on acquainting yourself with the music of this unjustly neglected composer.

Sony's budget-priced reissue campaign proceeds apace.  A few months ago, they exhumed the Juilliard String Quartet's estimable traversals of Mozart's "Haydn" Quartets and String Quintets from the CBS vaults; now from the old RCA catalog comes an equally distinguished traversal of the same repertoire by the Guarneri Quartet.  Since both sets are quite inexpensive, chamber music enthusiasts might want to purchase both, for the approaches of these two distinguished American ensembles provide sharp and fascinating contrasts.  Whereas the Juilliard favor a lean collective tone, incisive attacks and strong rhythmic articulation, the Guarneri's favor a sweetly lyrical approach, more leisurely tempos, and an elegant, even suave manner.  They also strive to maintain the "long line" at all costs, thereby bringing out the "vocal" and operatic qualities in Mozart's chamber music.  Both approaches are valid--the Juilliards leaning more toward a Classical style, and the Guarneri's toward a proto-romantic interpretation that harks back to mid-Twentieth Century Viennese ensembles such as the Konzerthaus Quartet, the Baryllis and the Wellers.The results, in the case of the Guarneri's readings (no less than the Juilliard's) are simply splendid.  Mozart opined that operatic ensembles should "flow like oil," and that metaphor aptly describes the Guarneri's traversals of all twelve of these wonderful works.  The Six "Haydn" Quartets come from the early 1970's and find the ensemble in splendid form; slow movements, in particular, are deeply considered and ensemble throughout is near-perfect.  The engineers provide a warm ambience without sacrificing clarity; at all times the four instruments are clearly audible. The Quintets derive from the late 1980's, and were taken down at live concerts.  Three distinguished violists participate in two Quintets apiece. The interpretations are, in a word, magnificent.  These musicians clearly appreciate the intricacy of Mozart's craftsmanship no less than his profound, and profoundly unsettling, expression of the human condition with all its ambiguities and paradoxes.  The Guarneri and their distinguished guest violists also cultivate a fully conversational style, in which each performer responds to the others in dialogic fashion.  In other words, these are genuine chamber music performances, not occasions for five virtuosos to exhibit their talents (though there is no want of virtuosity when required; apart from one or two momentary intonational lapses, the playing is immaculate throughout).  The three greatest Quintets (the C-Major, G-Minor and D-major) are given performances that approach sublimity, and once again the slow movements are presented as the heart of each work.  The engineering is as fine here as with the studio recordings of the Haydn Quartets.  There is plenty of hall ambience, though not so much as to muddy the textures, and there are no distracting audience noises.In sum then, this distinguished set of Mozart chamber music that deserves to rank alongside the finest versions of the Haydn Quartets and Viola Quintets --including the Juilliard versions mentioned above, as well as those by the Amadeus, the Budapest, and the Pro Arte (the latter are classic performances from the 78-rpm era last seen in an early-1990's set from EMI).  As usual with this new series from Sony, there is minimal documentation.  But the music is the thing, and on that score listeners will not be disappointed.  Warmly recommended, then, both to veteran collectors and to those looking for a "basic library selection."

Warner's Handel Edition is an economical way of acquiring a substantial portion of Handel's orchestral and vocal output -- if one os prepared to do without much documentation (such as texts and, in the case of works in Latin or Italian, translations).  Both of the oratorios included in this volume are in English, though the choral diction and that of some soloists is not always sufficiently idiomatic or clear so that one can do without a libretto.That regret having been voiced, I heartily recommend this particular volume of the Handel Edition.  Both oratorios are splendid -- among Handel's supreme masterworks in the genre.  Belshazzar is a vividly dramatic piece on an epic scale; Jephtha is a more intimate, personal tragedy, filled with Handel's profoundest meditations on the human condition.  It was also the composer's final work in the genre (discounting the largely recycled "Triumph of Time and Truth"); his struggle with his oncoming blindness, and the fragility of his mortal frame, is manifest throughout his musical setting of the troubling story from the Hebrew Scriptures.There have been several fine recordings of *Jephtha* over the years--including Somary, Marriner, Gardiner and Creed (the ones I have heard), but fewer of *Belshazzar* (I wonder why the latter has never quite caught on with audiences or even with ardent Handelians).  Harnoncourt's version of the latter is, by a fair margin, the best of the available versions.  Pinnock's has some fine soloists and boasts a superb English choir that declaims the text far more idiomatically and clearly than Harnoncourt's Viennese group.  However, I find Pinnock's *Belshazzar* to be weighed down by a fatal dullness.  Neumann, on the other hand (on MDG), leads his forces with plenty of dramatic flair; unfortunately, his soloists by and large do not sound comfortable with their roles--or with singing in English--and his two countertenors are inexcusably shrill. Harnoncourt has by far the best cast of the three recordings (Tear, Palmer and Lehane are outstanding), as well as a choral ensemble able to sing with rhythmic incisiveness and supple phrasing (despite mushy diction on occasion).  The Concentus Musicus plays with their customary fervor, if not always with as much refinement as we would expect from period-instrument ensembles today (*Belshazzar* was recorded in 1975). Haroncourt manages to convey a cumulative dramatic tension throughout the work, but his flair for Handel's extraordinary musico-dramatic effects is heard to best advantage in the orgy scene from Act II, which culminates in Handel's fantastic and spooky setting of the "handwriting on the wall."  Overall, I would rank Harnoncourt's *Belshazzar* among the most effective and enjoyable period-performance versions of a Handel oratorio--though I suspect that if Gardiner had turned his attention to the piece, he would have produced an even finer realization (perhaps he will revisit Handel at some future date).I am not quite as enthusiastic about Harnoncourt's *Jephtha*. Its chief virtue, shared with this conductor's *Belshazzar*, is the vividly, indeed urgently dramatic rendering of a work that, in lesser hands, can seem overlong, weighed down by stretches of less than top-drawer invention.  A successful recording of *Jephtha* must convey a sense of fateful foreboding, even during the occasional dull patches.  Harnoncourt manages to communicate this sense of inexorable tragedy perhaps better than any conductor before or since.  The great choruses that comment on this tragic trajectory can have rarely been done more effectively, with Handel's text-painting played to the hilt.  The main problem with this performance, then, lies not so much in the interpretation as in the execution.  Both the instrumental playing and the singing could do with greater polish; the listener can be distracted at times by lapses of ensemble and intonation.  The chief problem, however, is the singing of Werner Hollweg in the role of Jepththa.  It's not only that his English diction is frequently unidiomatic; more importantly, his interpretation of the role is so over-the-top as to risk turning this character, with whom the listener should empathize, into a caricature. Histrionics are as unwelcome as blandness in the portrayal of a "tragic hero" of this sort.  If Anthony Rolfe Johnson errs on the side of blandness in his portrayal of Jephtha for Marriner, Hollweg is guilty of "tearing passion to tatters"==quite possibly at Harnoncourt's behest.  Vocally, too, Hollweg often sounds strained and out of his element.  The other soloists offer much compensation, though--especially Gale and Esswood.  Nor can it be said that Hollweg, for all his shortcomings, fails to rivet the listener's attention. Far from it. Too bad Robert Tear wasn't available for this recording!The remastered sound in both works is what we have come to expect from Teldec during this period: clear, robust, with plenty of visceral impact, though at times a little dry and wanting in ambient warmth.Despite flawed casting of the title role in *Jephtha*, these are two of Harnoncourt's most successful Handelian ventures. Yoked together in a slim-line bargain box, they make a tempting proposition for those who may be exploring this repertoire for the first time--or for those who would like to add two very distinctive interpretations to an already ample Handel collection.  In the case of *Belshazzar* there is no better version available; and in the case of *Jephtha* no more intensely dramatic recordings exists.

For years, I failed to take Friedrich Gulda seriously. His penchant for attention-grabbing antics (such as--reputedly-- giving a recital in the nude), and the easy commerce he favored between classical and jazz, pegged him in my thinking as a publicity-seeking crossover artist.That I couldn't have been more mistaken in my assessment was revealed to me a few years ago upon auditioning his altogether remarkable traversal of Bach's WTC for Phillips.  The studio-bound acoustic on that recording was claustrophobic, but the artistry was, in a word, sublime: as to dexterity, fluency and intellectual rigor rivaling Gould; as to depth of insight, surpassing Richter. Subsequently, I went on to acquire his scintillating stereo cycle of Beethoven Sonatas (recently reissued by Brilliant) and several volumes of DG's newer retrospective series (including the amazing, though sonically challenged, "Mozart Tapes").Gulda has latterly been exalted to a privileged position in my pantheon of great pianists.  His dalliances with self-promoting mischief notwithstanding, I now regard him as one of the most intellectually as well as technically formidable pianists of the Twentieth Century.His unique gifts--in both classical and jazz idioms--are well in evidence in this modestly-priced, though poorly documented, collection from Membran. By way of a brief review, I shall cut to che chase by prioritizing the items that impressed me most. The Debussy and Ravel pieces, for instance, are tremendously involving; in these works, Gulda always succeeds in finding a narrative thread, a plot-line (so to speak) that consistently enthralls.  This is by no means the light-textured, shimmering impressionistic approach to these French masters we associate with Gieseking.  This is Debussy and Ravel painted, as it were, in vivid primary colors.  The technical mastery is, in a word, stunning.The Mozart and Chopin are nearly as good, though the orchestral playing in the former's K. 449 concerto is poor (wind intonation excruciating), and the latter's e-minor concerto and various solo pieces, though pellucid in articulation are not always as effortlessly natural in rubato as Rubinstein.  Nevertheless, you will never be bored by Gulda's Mozart and Chopin; everything is deeply considered and boldly projected.  The Jazz riffs, "live from Birdland," are hugely enjoyable, and indeed probably in themselves worth the price of admission.The Richard Strauss items -- a delicious lieder recital in which the pianist accompanies Hilde Gueden, and a vigorous *Burleske* with Collins and the LSO -- afford pleasures of a more voluptuous nature. Gueden sings with ecstatic lyricism and coquettish seductiveness, and Gulda supports her with clarity and poise.  The *Burleske*--not a work I usually warm to--is given a rendition of both opulence and irony; just the right combination to convince doubters of this work's enduring value.If you know Gulda's Beethoven from any of his three complete sonata cycles (two in mono, one in stereo), the renditions included in this box will add nothing new to your estimation of Gulda--though they are all superb performances, combining complete technical mastery with extraordinary brio and deep understanding of structure.  Since I have not heard either of his monaural Beethoven cycles, I cannot say whether the performances included here derive from one of these sets, or rather from other sources (live broadcast tapes of particular recitals, for instance).  They do sound like studio recordings, however, even if the sound remains somewhat cloudy and constricted.  The one disappointment for me was the Beethoven C-Major Concerto with the Vienna Philharmonic under Böhm. In the outer movements, the tempos are very slow indeed, so that regardless of the occasional sparkle conveyed by Gulda's pianism, the overall impression is one of lethargy.  Usually Böhm is a reliable, and at times even exciting Beethoven interpreter, but not here.  The slow movement is lovely, but by then I had lost interestPerhaps the biggest surprise for me was the overall quality of the recordings and digital transfers.  Though many are boxy monaural, all are at least tolerable and the majority (particularly the Debussy) are pretty good.  This label has a spotty record when it comes to sonics (some of their "wallet-boxes" featuring famous conductors are almost unlistenable due to distorted digital remasterings). In the case of this Gulda box, however, I am happy to report that the remasterings have been undertaken with some care, so that the piano timbre usually sounds natural, without undue filtering making it sound as if recorded "under water."In sum, then, pianophiles who want to explore the artistry of Friedrich Gulda would do well to acquire this modestly-priced volume.

I concur with the Amazon reviewers above in their high estimation of the Budapest Quartet and their now-legendary Beethoven interpretations.  However, I much prefer their earlier, monaural Beethoven cycle from 1951-1952.  This earlier cycle was made well before the technical decline evident in many of this ensemble's stereo recordings, including their Beethoven from the 1960's.  In 1952 the Budapest still possessed a unanimity of ensemble and accuracy of intonation that they found increasingly difficult to manage as time went on..The good news is that The Budapest's monaural Beethoven cycle, which to my ears is superior in every respect to their stereo cycle, has been reissued in excellent transfers from United Archives.  Unlike many outfits specializing in archival reissues, this label's production values are outstanding, and their asking price falls within the upper bargain range.  Though recent United Archives releases are not available through Amazon (at least not yet), they are available in the UK via Presto Classical. I advise all prospective purchasers of the Budapest Quartet's Beethoven recordings to check out that website and to consider obtaining this ensemble's magnificent Beethoven cycle from the early LP era.  Their interpretations are even more  probing than in the stereo set, and their playing is far better from a technical standpoint.  The sound, too, is mellower and falls more easily on the ear as good mono often did.The choice is yours, thanks to the (relatively new) United Archives label.  You might also want to check out this label's other highly desirable bargain boxes, which include, to date, Michel Chapuis unsurpassed Bach organ cycle from the 1960's, Bruno Walters NYPO Beethoven cycle (excellently transferred) and Wanda Landowska's complete HMV recordings from the 1930's and early 1940's.  Amazon:  Why are you not carrying these wonderful recordings?

In Dvorák's splendid Opus 81 Quintet, Richter and the Borodins provide astonishing virtuosity and élan.  No other version I have heard, either on record or in concert, communicates such passionate involvement: the result is quite breathtaking. What I miss, however, is charm, and that folksy quality which is such an essential aspect of Dvorak's muse.  Many listeners will favor a more relaxed approach that gives the music room to breathe, to sparkle, and to laugh.In the seldom-heard Opus 5 Quintet, however, these artists give what must be regarded as a near definitive performance. If you have not heard the piece, you will be surprised at the eloquence, inventiveness, and vivacity that Richter and the Borodins discover in this youthful work.  The slow movement, in particular, is gorgeous, and gorgeously played here; it would be hugely popular if it were better known.These are live performances caught on the wing in 1982, and that may account both for the tendency to hyperactivity in Op. 81 and for the dryish acoustic throughout, which seldom flatters the strings (though Richter's contribution is well caught).In the end, I would hesitate to recommend this version of Op. 81 to listeners unfamiliar with the work, or those who are in the market for a "basic library selection."  If you already own, say, Curzon/Vienna or Firkusny/Ridge, then this unusual interpretation might make an ideal "second version" to add to your collection.  On the other hand, listeners interested in acquiring a recording of Opus 5 might well prefer this sizzling account to the competition (a fine, though more sober, rendition by Firkusny and the Ridge Quartet).  So there is some ambivalence on my part toward this release, even though it captures what must have been a memorable occasion.

I bought this set when it when it was first reissued on CD because I wanted to acquaint myself with the earlier Schubert quartets, and this was an inexpensive way to obtain recordings of this neglected repertoire.  All chamber music lovers know Schubert's great "final three"  (nos. 13-15)  and the fragment known as the *Quartettsatz* in c-minor (usually called "no. 12").  More adventurous listeners might also know the earlier g-minor and E-flat major works, as they sometimes turn up in concert programs and there have been several recordings over the years apart from complete cycles.  But few of us are familiar with the other early works, most of them apprentice pieces, through the composition of which Schubert was learning his craft--and doing so with a precociousness that rivals the young Mozart and the young Mendelssohn.The Melos Quartet made these recordings in the early 1970's when they were at their peak (they also did fine traversals of the Beethoven, Cherubini, Schumann, Brahms and Mozart "Haydn" Quartets).  They were (are still?) an illustrious ensemble with a distinctively sweet collective tone characterized by "tight" vibrato.  They favored clear textures (the inner parts are almost always audible), straightforward--even at times rather plain--phrasing, scrupulous adherence to the musical text, and a wide dynamic range that often resulted in sharp, even abrupt, dynamic contrasts. Their choice of tempo is usually sensible--neither too fast nor too slow. They don't always dig very deep beneath the surface of the music, but those surfaces emerge as carefully articulated and thoroughly polished.  With the Melos Quartet we encounter seemingly effortless artistry that never calls attention to itself.These qualities are particularly well suited to the "artless" lyricism of Schubert's early quartets.  In the apprentice works, the Melos don't fall into the trap of inflating what are frequently rather fragile structures, or trying to plumb depths that the young composer had not yet fathomed.  Early Scubert presents the listener with youthful zeal and uncomplicated lyricism, and what at times can only be called a gauche graciousness.As Schubert matured--and he did so with astonishing rapidity during his adolescent years--he succeeded in writing more idiomatically for the quartet medium, expanding and clarifying his understanding of musical form, and cultivating that instantly recognizable pathos which trades on harmonic ambiguities and sudden shifts of mood.  The Melos convey these trends particularly well in the attractive transitional works in E major, E-Flat major and g-minor.In the Quartettesatz and the final trilogy, other ensembles have savored the pathos more poignantly and conveyed the scope of Schubert's vastly expanded appropriation of form more cogently,  but the Melos' tight ensemble, incisive attack, and clarity of texture nevertheless succeed in bringing these works vividly to life. On the other hand,  one might wish for a more leisurely, gracious approach to these great works, such as certain Viennese ensembles cultivated during the middle decades of the 20th Century.  I am engaged by the Melos's traversal of the late Quartets, but rarely charmed (where Schubert intends to charm), terrified (where Schubert intends to terrify), or profoundly moved  (as Schubert can do when he is bringing the listener face-to-face with the human condition).So the Melos Schubert cycle has undoubted merit, even if one would not turn first to this ensemble in Schubert's fully mature quartets.  Another limitation is the remastered sound--at least to my ears.  The original LP's offered clean, nicely focused sound that was slightly "top-heavy" or treble-intensive as recordings on this label tended to be at the time.  The remastering has done nothing to redress this perceptible imbalance, but rather has exacerbated it by thinning out the violin tone and further emaciating the cello tone. As a result, there are occasional bouts of uncomfortably harsh sound in fortissimo passages.  This sonic limitation is not so severe as to preclude a general recommendation, however.  So let us call this four and one-half stars: a first-rate bargain featuring solid musicianship and clear-headed if at times overly studious renderings of Schubert's important contribution to the Quartet medium.

For once, there seems to be something like an emerging consensus among Amazon reviewers.  Haitink's early Bruckner cycle's greatest virtue is also its greatest liability--namely, a plainspoken approach that conveys the structural integrity of these awe-inspiring scores with a minimum of fuss.  Haitink resists manifold temptations to hype the drama or disrupt the flow by overmanipulation of tempo or agogic distortion.  In other words, this is the Bruckner cycle to purchase if you don't like interventionist conductors.  In some moods, but not all, this is exactly what I am after in Bruckner. Haitink's early efforts are particularly conducive to in-depth study whose aim is to discern the long-range structural logic behind the notes.  However, when I want to be edified, exalted, renewed in mind and spirit (all of which Bruckner's music can accomplish in his listeners), I will turn to other interpreters--and, yes, to those who favor a more interventionist approach  (Furtwängler, Karajan, Celibidache,Jochum  even Solti).  I might also add that there are non-interventionist Brucknerians who arguably succeed better at the "plain vanilla" approach than Hainink--such as van Beinum, Schurcht, Böhm and Stein.With these qualifications in mind, I can nevertheless recommend Haitink's set as a very good place to begin an encounter with this mind-boggling yet elusive music.  He rarely puts a foot wrong in setting forth the letter of the score, and succeeds surprisingly well in conveying the spirit, too, by focusing on, and scrupulously realizing, what Bruckner has written.  One can quibble about Hatink's choice of tempo here and there (the brisk romp through the first movements of 6 and 8, for instance), but rarely does he do anything that could excite controversy or distract one's attention from the music--and that is where one's attention should be focused when first encountering Bruckner.  Nor can Haitink's Bruckner  be considered dull, for everywhere he and his players approach these works with evident affection.And what players!  The Concertgebouw is, in my estimation, the ideal Bruckner orchestra.  They "paint" the music with bold, richly textured, primary colors. The Concertgebouw of this period, in Bruckner,  is the aural equivalent of Rembrandt.  In fact, I am disposed to recommend this set to neophytes and veterans alike just for the sake of reveling in this gorgeous panoply of orchestral color!  No other European ensemble--not even the VPO or the BPO--can quite match the Concertgebouw in this repertoire.There follows a brief run-down on each of the symphonies:No. "0":  One advantage of this set is its inclusion of the "Zeroica" as it is sometimes whimsically called.  A surprisingly mature work, considering its extra-canonical status.  Haitink does it some justice--I believe this was its first stereo recording--but others have discovered more depth and conveyed a greater dramatic urgency.  I would recommend Barenboim/DG, Solti or Skrowaczewski--all of which convey far greater character than Haitink.No. 1:  Hatink gives a lucid, refreshingly direct and energetic account which must be numbered among the best ever recorded.  This is the Linz version, which most Brucknerians prefer to his later redaction.  Not better than Karajan and Solti, but on a par perhaps.No. 2:  One of the handful of "perfect" Bruckner recordings.  Haitink coaxes absolutely glorious playing from the Concergebouworkest here.  The Haas edition is used.No. 3:  One of the earliest to be recorded in Haitink's cycle (1963), and one of the best, interpretively.  The somewhat rambling structure of the 1878 edition notwithstanding, Haitink manages to hold everything together with remarkable cogency.  He also conveys a fine sense of mystery in the appropriate places, such as the opening of the first movement.  The great passage in the finale where Bruckner combines solemn chorale with skittish polka is better realized elsewhere, but you can't have everything.  Overall, one of the better Thirds--though I prefer the 1889 edition under Böhm, Jochum, and Schuricht.No. 4:  Another lovely performance, worthy to set alongside Haitink's near-definitive account of the Second.  Beautifuly played, serene, yet with plenty of brio where that is required.  The finale is held together well (no easy task) and the hunting-horn scherzo is sufficiently robust without being over-driven.No. 5:  The nostalgia factor colors my judgment here:  this recording was this listener's first encounter with Bruckner, way back in the LP era.  When I first heard the magical passage in the first movement where Bruckner intertwines a serpentine thematic fragment within a hushed, pizzicato chorale, I knew that I had encountered the Transcendent via the art of music--and that Bruckner was the composer who would provide such encounters regularly.  Since that time I have heard virtually every recording of what remains my favorite Bruckner symphony, and Haitink's Concertgebouw version always comes out at or near the top.  This is one work which suffers from over-inflation or overemphasis.  Haitink knows that a reliable tourguide is all one needs in this vast cathedral of sound.  Much though I love Furtwängler's minatory account and Karajan's riveting exegesis, it is Haitink to which I return most often for renewal.No. 6:  An admirably sound and straightforward performance.  Too little majesty in the first movement, but Haitink achieves sublimity in the slow movement.  I prefer Klemperer, Stein and the under-appreciated Bongartz in this work.No. 7:  An uplifting account of Bruckner's most accessible symphony--until you hear Karajan/EMI and then it is hard to settle for what will sound, in comparison, like dogged literalism.  Haitink's Seventh is better than that, of course, but the best is, as they say, the enemy of the merely good.No. 8:  This was the first to be recorded in Haitink's Concertgebouw Bruckner cycle, and it reflects a certain immaturity on the part of a then very young conductor.  If this had been my first encounter with Bruckner, or with this, presumably greatest of his symphonies, I might not have understood what all the fuss is about.  Haitink is too brisk and too literal adequately to convey the agony and ecstasy of this remarkable music.  So everyone's advice to prospective purchasers of this set is that  you will need another version of the mightly Eighth. Karajan/Vienna is a perennial favorite (and rightly so), but for me Furtwängler owns this symphony. If you want to hear Haitink in just this symphony, I would recommend his later Concertgebouw recording which proceeds more slowly and meditatively throughout.  Haitink as usual, favors the Haas edition.No. 9:  Haitink is outstanding here.  I have not heard his later, Vienna recording, but this Concertgebouw version is as good as it gets.  The cumulative power of this sober, even at times introverted, reading is ultimately more devastating than many more overtly dramatic accounts, such as those by Karajan and Solti.  Haitink is surpassed, in my estimation, only by Furtwangler and Walter (two very different, and complementary, accounts).All told, then, this set provides a more than reliable introduction to the composer. Haitink is definitely on Bruckner's wave-length, even if he is only intermittently inspired.  His versions of 1, 2, and 5 are perennial favorites with this listener, and his Ninth must be reckoned among the best.  In the end, perhaps, it is the Concertgebouworkest that provides potential purchasers with an incentive to invest in this box, and the recording engineers have done justice to this ensemble's unique character.  The remastered sound is clearly focused and wide-ranging with plenty of ambient warmth.  Only the earliest recordings (nos. 3 & 8) betray their age with slightly thinner string and brass sonorities.  There is no other Bruckner cycle that surpasses this one for the sheer beauty of the orchestral playing.NOTE:  Universal will soon be releasing a new "Haitink Symphony Edition," which will comprise all of his complete symphony cycles by Beethoven, Brahms, Bruckner, Mahler, Schumann and Tchaikovsky.  It will be offered in a bargain box at a very affordable price.  Collectors interested in Haitink's Bruckner might well consider this new offering, if more extensive repertoire by this conductor is desired.  I have heard all of these symphony cycles except the Beethoven, and can testify that they are all superbly played and recorded, and the interpretations are consistently involving without ever getting in the way of the music.

Schuricht was a venerable figure among German conductors of the mid-20th Century, though his recorded legacy is relatively unknown today. That is unfortunate, since he was a remarkably perceptive conductor, worthy to be placed alongside the greatest of his generation.  He favored straightforward, clear-headed interpretations entirely without artifice or  glamor-mongering.  His conductorial manner was, in a word, gentlemanly. Whether the composer be Baroque, Classical, Romantic or Modern, Schuricht ensures that the music is set forth with utter naturalness.  Some critics have complained of a certain dourness, and I can see their point. If you're looking for visceral excitement or monumentality, these qualities are generally absent in a Schuricht performance.  Instead, you will find a certain intimacy of expression that makes it seem as if the music is speaking directly to you, the listener. This cherishable set  from Scribendum contains the bulk of the studio recordings Schuricht made in the early stereo era for the "Concert Hall" label, with several European orchestras which he led or guest-conducted during this period.Not every item in this set is equally well performed. The  SDR and SWR were hardly in the front rank among German ensembles at this time, and the same holds for the "Paris Opera Orchestra."  On the other hand, the Bavarian Radio Symphony and the Vienna State Opera Orchestra acquit themselves well for Schuricht.  The Schubert "Great C-Major" with the Süddeutsche Rundfunk orchestra sounds rather creaky in places, and the Brahms Fourth with the Bavarian forces will hardly replace Fürtwangler or Toscanini in anyone's affections.  However, the Bruckner and Mendelssohn (both specialties of the conductor) are splendid, with the Wagner, Strauss, Schumann, and Weber not far behind. The Paris orchestra gives fizzing renditions of three Mozart symphonies; these are wholly delightful (despite some slipshod ensemble and the absence of exposition repeats), not least because of the distinctive timbre of the Parisian winds,  Best of all, perhaps, are the Bach "Brandenburg Concertos" crisply and enthusiastically played by a fine Swiss chamber ensemble.  These are decidedly jolly readings, with robust but not inflated textures, snappy rhythmic articulation and incisive attack.  There is a fair amount of appropriately executed ornamentation, and the solo playing is first-rate.  The four concerti grossi by Handel (performed by a reduced BRSO) are also enjoyably light-hearted, even if the playing here is not quite as alert, nor the recording as vivid as in the Bach (the presumed harpsichord continuo is inaudible).The Bruckner Seventh deserves special mention, given Schuricht's strong reputation as an advocate of this composer.  Schuricht manages successfully to convey this symphony's lofty and expasnive qualities with a minimum of fuss at flowing tempos.  Though the tempo of the Adagio may well seem too brisk for some listeners, Schuricht's effortlessly natural phrasing and intuitive grasp of structure amply compensate for any loss of gravitas.  Though this is a very fine performance, it doesn't quite measure up to Schuricht's best Bruckner recordings (such as his EMI studio versions of the composer's Third, Eighth and Ninth symphonies with the VPO, or the live broadcast performances from Stuttgart of the Fifth, Eighth and Ninth recently released in Hänssler Classic's Schuricht edition).  The problem is that the Hague Philharmonic is not quite up to the exigent demands of this monumental score.  The string timbre tends to be on the pallid side;and the wind and brass playing are, in a word, undistinguished.  Too bad Schuricht never got around to recording this work with the VPO as part of his Bruckner series for EMI.  Fans of the conductor, however, will appreciate the opportunity of hearing the conductor's distinctive take on this work, and are urged to listen past the imperfections in orchestral execution.The recording quality throughout this set is reasonably good, though sometimes congested (as in the Schubert Ninth) and/or a bit cloudy (as in the Handel and Bruckner). Whatever the limitations, however, we must be grateful to Scribendum for resuscitating these historic recordings, long out of circulation. Overall, this gives the listener a splendid introduction to this "gentle giant" among Twentieth Century conductors.

No need to waste words:  this is simply the most beautiful Liszt recital I have ever heard.  No, it is not the last word on barnstorming virtuosity; Kempff was not a showman, though he possessed a technique sufficiently secure (even at relatively advanced age)  to surmount Liszt's more demanding passages.  But showmanship is utterly beside the point in these mostly introspective pieces anyway.  Kempff had exactly the right temperament to convey the sense of rapture--whether pastoral, sensuous-erotic, or spiritual--Liszt evokes.  Kempff's sensitivity to atmosphere, nuance and color in this remarkable music has never been surpassed (except perhaps by his own monaural recordings for Decca/London).  Suffice it to say that this recital is the perfect antidote for Lisztians who have overdosed on Cziffra--Kempff's antithesis in this repertoire (and I say this as one who admires the former's coruscating pianism no less that the latter's serene musicianship).The sound is as luminous and gentle on the ear as is the playing; DG's engineers have really done a splendid job in giving new digital life to an analogue original that was rather dry and top-heavy (as DG's recordings tended to be during the LP era.  There is now a rich, resonant (though not overpowering) bass, a superbly focused middle register, and a sparkling treble.If you have never heard Kempff's unique, and uniquely satisfying, Liszt, here is a golden opportunity not to be missed.

It may be a sign of the times -- and by no means a positive sign -- that top-rank classical recordings of recent provenance are being anthologized in huge omnibus collections of this type, and sold for a mere pittance. In any case, what might be an alarming cultural bell-weather constitutes a great boon for collectors--veterans and neophytes alike.For here we have all of Gardiner's Bach recordings for the DG/Archiv label (from which the distinguished conductor was subsequently, and inexplicably, dropped) amounting to something like a *Summa* of Bach's church music.  Included are the B-minor Mass, the St. John and St. Matthew Passions, the Christmas Oratorio, the Magnificat, and sundry Cantatas (some of which are studio recordings, others of which are live performances hailing from Gardiner's celebrated "Bach Pilgrimage" of 1999-2000).  Listeners in the market for the complete cantata cycle will not find it here, though three dozen works in that genre which are included constitute a splendid representative sampling (with a good balance between well-known and relatively obscure cantatas).What can be said about the performances, live or studio, which has not already been said?  Gardiner is one of our very finest early-music specialists; but more importantly he is a superlative musician, whose understanding of this composer is as deep as it is comprehensive.  Moreover, his choir, soloists,  and orchestral ensemble clearly partake of their leader's dedicated and enlivening musicianship.  The four large-scale works included in this package date from a period in which Gardiner was consolidating  his reputation as a Bachian and an early-music "superstar." Gardiner's Bach series for DG/Archiv began with the B-Minor Mass in 1982; that recording was considered near-definitive then, and it has not lost its luster in the intervening years. Except for some thin-toned and uncharacteristically tentative solo singing, this is as fine a traversal of this work as you will find on record; it still reigns supreme in the historically-informed category.  Perhaps if he had it to do over agian, Gardiner would not choose to alternate soloists and ripieno choir in many of the "choral" movements, but that practice makes this interpretation distinctive  (while favoring textural clarity in fugal expositions).  With the two Passions and the *Christmas Oratorio* Gardiner's series went from strength to strength, so that these recordings came to dominate the field during the remainder of the 1980's.  The solo singing in these latter three performances is particularly distinguished. and the late Anthony Rolfe-Johnson's sensitive rendition of the Evangelist should be singled out for special praise.  The choral singing, too, is tremendous, matching precision with expressive nuance.  I have a particular fondness for Gardiner's *Christmas Oratorio*, whose winning combination of vital energy and celebratory splendor has yet to be surpassed among historically-informed versions.The Cantatas, which followed in the 1990's and the Millennium Year, share similar virtues.  If at times one longs for greater simplicity of utterance--such as one finds in the old Fritz Werner or Felix Prohaska recordings from the LP era (despite their obvious lapses of musicological correctness)--Gardiner's rhythmic vitality and almost unfailingly intelligent pointing of detail generally silence any criticism.  If Gardiner comes dangerously close to "loving the music to death," better that than dry academicism.Twp recordings anthologized here--the Magnificat and the soprano-solo Cantata BWV 51-- were originally released on the Phillips label in 1983.  They make a welcome reappearance:  Emma Kirkby's soaring, if slender-voiced, account of BWV 51 set a new standard in this work, and few if any "early music" singers since have approached, much less surpassed, her achievement.  Gardiner's *Magnificat* is both as ebullient and dramatic as one would have expected; and, once again, few period=performance versions have rivaled it since it appeared.Despite the diversity of recording venues and the many improvements in digital technology over nearly three decades, the quality of the sound throughout this 22-CD set is of consistently high quality.  This time around, however (I have known most of these recordings for years in previous incarnations), I began to notice an excessive brightness,and perhaps a certain two-dimensional quality, in the early-digital recordings from the 1980's, which becomes more conspicuous when compared with the Cantata recordings from the later decade.  The later are altogether richer, mellower, with a more spacious "soundstage" (this is especially the case with the live recordings from 1999-2000).  But one shouldn't make too much of this; few listeners will have cause to complain of sonic limitations, given the immense spiritual uplift she or he will be enjoying!DG/Universal has informed us that this is a limited edition.  All the more incentive, then, to snap this up while it is available.  Seasoned collectors may well own many of these recordings already; if so, the price is so low as to justify purchase for the sake of those which you may not have heard.  Listeners new to Bach or to classical music will surely come to regard this remarkable bargain box as a cornerstone of their collection.  Those in the latter category may well experience an irresistible urge to acquire Gardiner's entire Cantata cycle (issued on the Soli Deo Gloria label).Call it Irresistible Grace...

I agree wholeheartedly with T. Beers's review, that Leinsdorf's Prokofiev was "nonpareil."  Leinsdorf remains an underappreciated conductor. Critics have often complained that his interpretations were cold, severe, intellectualized, even pedestrian, while giving him credit for evoking supremely disciplined playing from the ensembles he conducted.  As a veteran concertgoer from the Leinsdorf years in Boston, I can testify that, at his best, Leinsdorf was a tremendous interpreter of everything from Viennese classicism to the Second Viennese School.  Like Szell, Reiner and Solti, he preferred to exercise maximal control rather than opting for a more genial, laissez-faire style.  He learned quite a bit, I wager, from his experience as Toscanini's assistant.  However, like those conductors--who were also accused of being hard-nosed disciplinarians--he had an intuitive grasp of orchestral color and a great sense of dramatic timing.  His best recordings convey a heady exuberance and confident grasp of musical architecture that are always put in service of the composer and ensemble.Leinsdorf was particularly adept and making even the most difficult, "modernistic" scores tractable to the general public.  Prokofiev is a case in point.  The enduring fascination of this composer comes largely from his ability to combine, in creative tension, fury and tenderness, brutal primitivism and elegant neoclassicism, spiky dissonance and bittersweet lyricism.  Leinsdorf understands this tension fully, and conveys it more successfully than any other conductor of which I am aware.The four Symphonies Leinsdorf got to record--one wonders what corner-office executive nixed the prospect of a complete cycle--are simply outstanding.  The Second and Third are among Prokofiev's most difficult; in these works, the the composer fully lives up to his reputation as *enfant terrible* of modernism.  In both, Leinsdorf and the BSO take no prisoners in their vehement abandon to Prokofievian primitivism, while allowing the occasional hints of balletic playfulness and passages of soaring lyricism tell just as fully. Leinsdorf's recordings of the Fifth and Sixth have rightly been accorded "classic status." Leinsdorf's bracing and incisive Fifth emphasizes the work's neoclassical spirit, unlike the more romanticized interpretations of Karajan and Ormandy (fine though they are).  Leinsdorf's approach is closer to that of Ansermet, though he has a far finer orchestra to work worth. Leinsdorf's  Sixth, on the other hand, brings this troubled work in line with Shostakovich, even Mahler, by underscoring its unsettling combination of biting irony and tragic weight. A magnificent, and exhausting, rendition of what may well be Prokofiev's greatest symphony.As for the five Piano Concertos with Browning: I know of no finer versions on record.  Browning's virtuosity is as stunning as his perceptiveness is enlightening. Browning is not content merely to toss off the busy passagework as if it were a technical exercise--a temptation into which too many pianists fall in this repertoire--but rather, he takes pains to convey the musical meaning behind the notes.  Leinsdorf is with him all the way, delighted in the interplay--sometimes combative, sometimes seductive, frequently comic--between soloist and orchestra, and undoubtedly reveling in the brilliant colors of Prokofiev's scoring.  For me, this set of the piano concertos eclipses all of the competition--with the sole exception of Graffman/Szell in nos. 1 & 3 (performances with similar virtues), and perhaps Richter/Wisloki in 5.  The two Violin Concertos are also oustanding; the underrated Friedman (a student of Heifetz) dazzling in the D-Major; the young Perlman mellower, but no less assured, in the g-minor.Mr. Beers complained of the inexplicable omission of Leinsdorf's Scythian Suite and the Symphony-Concerto for Cello and Orchestra. Their loss is lamentable, but at least we are given a rousing Liutenant Kijé and a substantial selection from *Romeo and Juliet*.  The latter is beautifully performed, and has the considerable advantage of  closely following action of the play (unlike Prokofiev's suites from the complete ballet).Throughout these six CD's, the sound, to my ears, is extraordinarily vivid, well balanced, solidly focused, with a bass register that frequently causes seismic cataclysms (yet, miraculously, without distortion).  I did notice, along with Mr. Beers, a momentary clouding of the texture at the beginning of the First Piano Concerto.  I can also understand why the other reviewer found the sound too aggressive.  But better an excess of immediacy in Prokofiev than a distant wash of orchestral sonority.  In short, I found the engineering on the whole as outstanding as the performances.If you enjoy Prokofiev--and certainly there were few twentieth-century composers with such a distinctive, and immediately recognizable, tone of voice--you must have this set.  Even if you own recordings of some or all of these works, you should add this to your collection.  Given the modest cost (especially in comparison to previous reissues of the Symphonies and Piano  Concertos on Testament), I will not complain of the absence of documentation, apart from movement/track listings on the back of the cardboard slipcases in which individual CDs are housed.This set is irresistible; don't hesitate to acquire it.

Solti's Bruckner cycle from the early digital era has come in for some rather harsh criticism over the years.  Reviewers in the usual periodicals have denounced Solti's Bruckner as harsh, garish, vulgar, and superficial; the CSO has similarly been stereotyped as having exactly the wrong collective sonority for this composer--too cold, too brassy, to hard-edged.Of course, it's always possible to find recordings (or recall live performances) that fit the stereotypes (my first candidate would be Solti's digital account of  Debussy's *Nocturnes* from about the same period).  Here, however, is a Bruckner Seventh that will make you think twice about type-casting either Solti or the CSO.  It is an absolutely gorgeous account of the work: as atmospheric and contemplative as one would desire (the tempo surprisingly broad, but effective) in the first movement; as profoundly and nobly tragic as any on record in the Adagio (where Solti gives the music an appropriately Wagnerian cast--it is a threnody on the death of that composer, after all).  The Scherzo is delightfully rustic, and the finale exalted in its peroration.  Throughout, every section of the CSO play with devotion, nuance and the virtuosity for which they are justly celebrated.  The recording is a bit bass-heavy, but otherwise vivid, well focused, and sufficiently ample to accommodate Solti's apocalyptic climaxes (yes, I suppose, true to form!).If you are an avid Brucknerian, or are just interested in hearing a superb performance by one of the great American orchestras, you should seek out this recording--though not, perhaps, in preference to Karajan's EMI Seventh, which, at least for me, remains the benchmark in this work.

I have loved this recording of the *St. Matthew Passion* since I first heard it on LP during  my college days.  Gönnenwein strikes an ideal balance between the traditional "Kappellmeister" approach of Richter and Klemperer--which could be oppressively weighty in texture and rhythmically square--and the smaller-scaled, musicologically correct performances which are the norm today.  The conductor favors a lyrical rather than a dramatic interpretation of the work. Though the great moments are by no means slighted, inwardness predominates over monumentality and brilliance.  The modest choral forces sing with firm tone and reasonably crisp diction; contrapuntal textures remain clear, thanks to Gönnenwein's intelligent direction.  An outstanding roster of soloists is deployed for the arias, though I have some reservations about Altmeyer's Evangelist (he whines at higher dynamic levels and tends to bark when he reaches the top of his range) and Crass's Jesus (too stentorian, insufficiently  nuanced). The instrumental ensemble plays with accuracy, warmth and a good sense of style; all of the wind and string obbligati are well played, often beautifully shaped, if with too much legato phrasing.  The digitally remastered recording from the late Sixties is pleasing--well focused, with a lot of ambient warmth and only occasional hints of a metallic edge on the voices at higher dynamic levels.Before you invest in this reasonably economical 3-CD set, however, be aware that EMI has just released (as of April, 2011) a slim-line bargain box containing a treasure trove of "traditional" Bach recordings culled from that company's extensive back catalog (and ludicrously hyped as "timeless performances").  For just over twice the cost of EMI's previous reissue of Gönnenwein's  *St. Matthew Passion* you will also get that conductor's equally fine *St. John Passion* and *Easter Oratorio*, Ledger's oh-so-Anglican, but characterful *Christmas Oratorio* and *Ascension Oratorio* with Kings College choir, Jochum's superb digital *B-Minor Mass*, Barenboim's cherishable *Magnificat* from early in his conducting career, and a "historic" rendition of Cantata BWV 147 featuring the Geraint Jones Singers (sounding as if they'd rather be singing Purcell) and none other than Dame Joan Sutherland (sounding as if she'd rather be singing Alcina--or Norma).  I recently ordered this set from a distributor overseas (Amazon.com stateside does not yet carry it) and have been enjoying it immensely since its arrival.  Even if you own multiple versions of these works, it constitutes an irresistible bargain for which I'd opt in preference to the reissued St. Matthew on offer here.

Now that the Talich Quartet's survey of the Mozart Quartets is no longer available, this bargain box from DG is probably the best way to acquire the complete cycle at a modest cost.  The Amadeus Quartet recorded extensively over the four decades of their existence (1947-1987).  They gave us multiple versions of the best-known Mozart quartets, and many critics would argue that their earlier, monaural recordings of these works were fresher and more deeply considered than their later, stereo efforts (which is what we have in this DG Collectors Edition).  As a longstanding fan of the Amadeus Quartet, I have heard all of their Mozart recordings, and am of the opinion that their later recordings are by no means inferior. The versions of nos. 14-23 included in this Collectors Edition are altogether superb: invigorating, yet gracious readings that manage to convey both the playfulness and the pathos of the music without undue frivolousness or schmaltz.  The Amadeus' collective tone is robust, with a pronounced vibrato to which some listeners (particularly the historically-minded) might object.  I find their sweet-singing tone enchanting, though some might find it cloying.  The early quartets (among which there are a surprising number of near-masterpieces) are given no more or less than the weight they deserve; their rococo charms are undeniable in these light-hearted, but never condescending renditions.There is only one point on which I would caution prospective purchasers:  The Amadeus are not generous with repeats.  If it is important to you to hear the expositions of sonata-form movements twice, then you should probably pass up this set, fine though it is in other respects.The recordings have been effectively remastered; the sound is exceptionally vivid, with instruments closely observed.  The upper register is smooth, not too strident at higher dynamic levels (as some DG recordings of chamber music during this period could be).  In general the ten mature quartets, though recorded earlier (1960's), sound marginally more natural to my ears than the early quartets, which (if memory serves me correctly) are of 1970's vintage.  No grumbles, then, about the sonics--this is one of DG's better efforts from the LP era.So if you're in the market for a complete Mozart cycle, do consider this set, which is attractively presented (though notes are rather skimpy) and economically priced.  I prefer the Amadeus to the Hagens in this repertoire (the latter's Mozart recordings are also available in a bargain box from DG); I find the latter's interpretations superficial, though not everyone will agree with me on that point.  The Amadeus were one of the great ensembles of their era, and I'm delighted that their Mozart is still available.

The Amadeus Quartet's long and distinguished career has been well served during the CD era.  As far as I can tell, virtually all of their Westminster, EMI and DG recordings from roughly 1950-1987 have been reissued, repeatedly and in diverse configurations.  This is heartening, since it bespeaks an abiding appreciation among listeners for great chamber-music performances.The Haydn recordings anthologized in this inexpensive Collectors Edition are stereo recordings made during the 1970's.  Though their monaural versions of selected quartets from Haydn's ouvre convey a spirit, sparkle and affection less consistently caught in their later DG recordings of the complete quartets from opus 51 onward, the latter are by no means inferior.  Indeed, anyone coming to this music for the first time via these splendid Amadeus performances will be astonished at the fecundity of the composer's genius and the rich, glowing sonorities evoked by this magnificent ensemble.  Listeners who don't mind monaural recordings are well advised to check out the Amadeus's earlier recordings of Haydn, Schubert and Brahms, which have recently been reissued in an even more inexpensive bargain box from Brilliant (though the Haydn selection doesn't include nearly as many quartets as does DG's Collectors Edition).  However, if a more ample survey and more up-to-date sonics are required (and DG's remastered sound is as warm and vividly "present" as one could desire), the Collectors Edition is the one to go for.  Among the performances included herein are unsurpassed accounts of opus 54, 55, 71, 74, 77 and 103.  For some reason, the Amadeus are marginally less persuasive--at least to my ears--in Opus 51 (the "Seven Last Words of Christ"), and in the six best-known Quartets Opus 76--all of which seem somewhat "overheated," and at times slightly heavy handed as well.  But I wouldn't make too much of these shortcomings, given the refulgent tone and involving interpretations this estimable quartet provide.If you find the Amadeus's approach to Viennese classicism congenial, then you might also want to consider their complete Mozart quartet cycle (now also available in super-bargain range), their renditions of that composer's six String Quintets, as well as their Beethoven cycle (the latter of which was, in its day, a top recommendation for the Beethoven quartets, and which still wears well after nearly fifty years of continuous availability!).  DG have also reissued the Amadeus's earlier, and sprightlier, Mozart recordings from the monaural era in a more expensive, but cherishable, limited edition.No chamber-music lover should be without an ample representation of the Haydn quartets--the greatest of which are among that composers most sublime creations--and this inexpensive Amadeus collection is a perfect place to begin.  If subsequently you are interested in hearing the entire cycle (over eighty works--an amazing legacy), several fine complete editions are available--from the Kodály, Aeolian and Angeles Quartets, among others.

While complete editions of Schubert's piano sonatas are readily available (even in the bargain price range), surveys of his entire output for piano are quite rare. Indeed, this current offering from Brilliant may well be the only one.  For one who died so young, Schubert was an enormously prolific composer, and that holds for his piano works as well as for his lieder.  Many music lovers are familiar with all twenty-one of his sonatas, the Impromptus, Moments Musicaux and Wanderer Fantasie, but few of us know the blooming, buzzing confusion of Waltzes, Ecossaises, Scherzi, variation sets and other incidental pieces (not to mention fragments) which inhabit the less-frequented regions of Otto Deutsch's Catalog.But here they all are--minus a handful of waltzes (no great loss), one or two fragments, and the *Grazer* Fantasie (considered spurious perhaps)--in one 14-CD box, well played and recorded.  These recordings derive from a series originally issued on the now-defunct Denon label.  Though I haven't heard those CDs, I surmise that everything originally released by Denon has been included here, and that the sound has not been tampered with.How to sum up such a vast collection and such a remarkable achievement by one artist?  On the basis of my auditioning, suffice it to say that Dalberto is always a thoughtful, sensitive Schubertian, alive to this composer's unique sound-world, his chimerical shifts of mood, and to the darker currents that course beneath the surface of the music.  In the Sonatas, Dalberto takes all of the essential repeats, plays fragmentary movments *as* fragments, chooses sensible tempos (sometimes on the slowish side, but nothing like the distensions found in some of Richter's performances), employs agogics and rubato to telling effect, and keeps knotty textures reasonably clear.  He manages to convey the intimacy as well as the majesty of Schubert's writing for piano.  Nothing sounds forced, everything flows effortlessly and naturally.If in certain works (such as the Final Trilogy of Sonatas), other artists plumb greater depths (Lupu, Curzon, Richter, Brendel), Dalberto is by no means eclipsed by these more famous Schubertians.Much the same can be said concerning the shorter works.  The Impromptus and Moments Musicaux are quite lovely--worthy to be compared with Perahia, Brendel, Frankl (whose 3-CD Vox Box of Schubert piano pieces is a perennial favorite with me -- a real sleeper, worth searching out) among many others.  Though Dalberto's Wanderer-Fantasie is impeccably played, it does not quite efface memories of Rubinstein, Richter, Pollini and others who have brought an altogether higher order of mastery to this technically challenging work.  Dalberto caresses the many dances, variations, scherzi and other short pieces with just the right amount of affection, without weighing down what are frequently light-hearted trifles (the Ecossaises must hold some kind of record for brevity among classical compositions--some last for a mere twenty seconds!).Thus there is far more to praise than to criticize in this massive survey.  That having been said, however, I must note one potentially irritating feature of Dalberto's playing: his tone, so alluring in quieter passages, tends to harden at higher dynamic levels, acquiring an unpleasant steely edge.  Compare Dalberto with Lupu, for instance, and you'll hear a significant difference in tone and touch in the passages under consideration that can't be chalked up entirely to recording techniques, venues and instruments used (though they may have played a role in emphasizing the occasional edginess of Dalberto's playing).  On the other hand, this reservation--though not entirely a minor one for me--shouldn't deter collectors from obtaining this reasonably-priced set (even more reasonably priced if you purchase it from websites abroad).  In general, the many positive aspects of  Dalberto's playing, as well as the merit of his interpretations (which display a natural affinity for the composer), make this Brilliant Box something of a mandatory acquisition for avid Schubertians (of which I count myself one).  Overall, you won't be disappointed.  As for newcomers to this repertoire, I might suggest purchasing a complete or partial survey of Schubert's sonatas first (those by Kempff, Uchida, Brendel, and Lupu are particularly recommendable) plus single-CD editions of the Impromptus, Moments Musicaux and Wanderer-Fantasie (if the Sonata box in question doesn't include  these works).  Since many seasoned collectors will already have multiple editions of Schubert's best-known piano works, whatever drawbacks one may discern in Dalberto's survey will not be sufficient to deter one from investing in his complete survey.

I would like to add yet one more voice to the chorus of praise for Levine's (regrettably incomplete) Mahler cycle.  I have known and loved these recordings since they were first issued in the 1970's and early '80's.  I have heard a huge number of Mahler recordings over the years--since he is one of my favorite composers and one whose music reveals so many different facets in diverse interpretations--and I can confidently say that Levine's interpretations of  5, 6, 7 and 9 remain unsurpassed.  If I prefer Horenstein in 1 and 3,  Walter (not his commercial recording) in 4, and Ormandy in 10, that is only by the slimmest of margins. In any case, great Mahler interpreters are not in competition, they are in truth complementary; and for that reason, as an avid collector I could never be satisfied with a single rendition of a given symphony--even if it be among the very finest available, as is the case with Levine's outstanding Mahler cycle. What is distinctive about Levine's approach to Mahler is its cogency and balance. The sheer beauty of the music (that is, where Mahler is not being deliberately ugly or minatory) gets its full due, while the harrowing qualities, the biting irony, and the  toughness of Mahler's style fully registers (as it frequently doesn't in more anodyne interpretations such as those by Maazel, Bertini, Karajan, and on occasion Walter, Rattle, Chailly, and Abbado).  I would also call prospective listeners' attention to the fact that this was the first (projected) Mahler cycle to include a realization of the Tenth (the familiar Cooke revised version), and its presence is some compensation for omission of 2 and 8.The best news perhaps is that the magnificent playing and distinctive sonorities of the three orchestras represented here (Philadelphia, Chicago, LSO) have rarely if ever been captured in more vivid, yet warm, recorded sound.  I haven't heard previous digital remasterings, but I can attest that these are state-of-the art: virtually no digital glare or thinning-out of timbres, maximal impact (the trombone solo in the first movement of 3 will lift you out of your seat), and natural balance.  The sonic image is somewhat distanced, so as to give the illusion of being seated maybe two-thirds of the way toward the back of an acoustically live concert hall; yet there is no want of focus or impact.  I did notice some confusion of channels in this remastering of the Ninth--not exactly a left-right switch, but sometimes it's hard to tell where various orchestral groups (the first violins particularly) are positioned on the soundstage.The only real downside is that, given its rock-bottom bargain status, the presentation is very spartan indeed:  Discs are housed in space-saving cardboard folders (not too flimsy), with track listings and minimal data about performances listed on the back of each.  No notes, texts or translations, or links to a website where such might be obtained.  Moreover, several symphonies are split between discs.  No matter.  This is in truth a mandatory acquisition for all Mahlerites, and a plausible "basic library edition" for the works included.  For those symphonies Levine never got around to record commercially for this series (was expense an issue?) I would recommend the superbly remastered Solti/LSO for the "Resurrection" and Solti/Chicago for no. 8.  Both are available in relatively inexpensive single-disc reissues from Decca/Universal, with copious notes and texts included, and both are stunning performances.  For those allergic to Solti, I would also recommend Klemperer/Philharmonia for no. 2 (another single-disc issue) and Horenstein/BBC (a glorious live performance in decent broadcast sound) for no. 8. In this way,  could assemble an optimal "starter collection" of Mahler symphonies.  Counting *Das Lied von der Erde* as a part of Mahler's Symphonic canon (as the composer initially did), first-time collectors will need to obtain a version of that masterpiece as well.  There are many fine recordings of it, though I would particularly recommend Walter/Decca (with Ferrier and Patzak), and Bernstein/Decca (with King and Fischer-Dieskau, employing Malher's alternate version for Baritone rather than Mezzo/Contralto. Your game.

Australian Eloquence has already reissued Ansermet's superb set of the *Paris Symphonies", which could well stand as a basic library recommendation for those works.  Here we have an essential supplement to that set, which admirers of the composer and conductor should also consider.  Along with its neighbor in E-flat (no. 91), Haydn's Symphony no. 90 in C is one of his most neglected masterpieces.  It is a delightful work--celebratory, inventive, and full of sparkling good humor.  It is given a first-rate performance here.  Ansermet draws crisp and well-detailed playing from his Swiss ensemble, as he does in the much earlier E-flat Symphony nicknamed "Philosopher" (no. 22).  That work has always been among the more popular of the master's early symphonies, given its distinctive scoring (spice with pungent cor anglais solos) and serious demeanor (hence the sobriquet).  Ansermet keeps the solemn measures of the opening movement from dragging and throughout shapes the music with evident affection.  A lovely rendition.  I wish I could say the same for the two trumpet concertos with which these fine Haydn performances are coupled--or maybe I should say saddled--but the poorly balanced monaural recording, which sounds as if the microphone had been placed in the bell of the instrument, falls harshly on the ear.  Nor is the trumpet playing particularly nimble or elegant--as it has to be in both works.  The Hummel generally comes off better than the Haydn--the sound being slightly more tolerable, and the soloist's phrasing more supple.  The Haydn, however, is a disaster.  I applaud the systematic reissue of the entire Ansermet discography by Australian Eloquence, though in the case of these trumpet concerto recordings one might have wished that they had been allowed to remain in limbo.For the sake of the two Haydn Symphonies, however, this reissue is an essential acquisition for both Ansermet enthusiasts and Haydn aficionados. Thankfully, the engineers have provided vivid and well-balanced sound for these works.  Minus one star, then, for the inclusion of the inelegantly performed and poorly recorded trumpet concertos.

I agree wholeheartedly with the other reviewers as to the merits of Ansermet's Haydn.  Many years ago, when I was first exploring Haydn's symphonic output, Ansermet's trenchant and serious-minded interpretations of the *Paris* symphonies served to dispel the myth of a senile benevolence commonly referred to as "Papa Haydn."  There is nothing remotely quaint about this rustic "Bear" or frothily galant about this stately "Queen."  Ansermet's Hen may not cluck and peck as daintily as some--she's more interested in mocking the *Sturm und Drang* preoccupations of yesteryear.  Finest of all, perhaps is the great and underappreciated E-flat symphony, which aspires to a nobility and gravitas that anticipates Beethoven. Indeed, I find Ansermet's big-boned, but never flabby, approach to Haydn serves as a welcome reminder that Beethoven knew and admired his mentor's symphonic works for their humanitarian values as much as for their quicksilver wit.  Those values come to the fore with Ansermet as they rarely have with other conductors (Bernstein always excepted).  The SRO, often maligned, responds with crisp ensemble and (mostly) reliable intonation, even if the wind-players' phrasing is occasionally on the stiff side.  The remastered  recording sounds as fresh and wholesome as the performances.  Nothing artificial here--either sonically or musically.  Strongly recommended, especially at bargain price, though not in preference to Bernstein whose stunningly athletic *Paris* cycle conveys a remarkable affinity with the composer.

I am pleased that Newton Classics has reissued Marriner's superb set of the Schubert Symphonies.  This is the only Schubert cycle to include Brian Newbould's fascinating 'realizations" of the works and movements Schubert--for whatever reason--left incomplete.  So not only does Marriner offer us a finished Unfinished, but several large-scale works, including a vast, Brucknerian Symphony in E (notionally completed from a single line of score) and the altogether remarkable "Symphony no. 10" (realized from fairly complete sketches) whose pathos-laden slow movement anticipates Mahler and whose concluding movement boldly and whimsically combines elements of Scherzo and fugal Finale.Whatever versions of the standard Schubert symphonies you may own, if you are an avid Schubertian you must hear this set for these extra-canonical works.  However, this set would be recommendable even if it didn't include Newbould's speculative reconstructions, for Marriner and the Academy give us light-textured, fleet-footed and often ravishingly lyrical performances. Marriner avoids weighing down the early symphonies (1-4) with excess teutonic baggage (as Böhm can sometimes do, despite my abiding affection for his classic Schubert cycle).  In the transitional works (5, 6 plus a couple of Neubold "realizations"), Marriner charms the ear with playfully sprung rhythms and delicate pointing of texture.  The "Unfinished" and "Great C-Major" may not have the stature under Marriner they achieve with Furtwängler, Böhm, Walter, Krips and other past masters, but few listeners are likely to complain of insufficient scale, dramatic impetus or structural integrity.  Finest of all are Marriner's deeply considered and thoroughly enlivening accounts of the two grandest among the reconstructed works (the "Tenth" and the E-major).
