Amazing!The one change I'd make to this set, is to ditch the Chinese White and Cad Orange Pale (Watercolorists don't use white!) and replace them with Cerulean Blue and a magenta-ish red- which, in the Cotman line, looks like it would be Permanent Rose - and you'll be able to mix just about any color you'll ever need. Also, if you don't want the pans to go flying, a little rubber cement between the bottom of the pans and the box will do the trick- and yet still allow you to easily remove the pans when you want to.I wish I would have gotten a set of these years ago- I'm finding that being to able to just whip it out on the spur of the moment, when I just have some free time (as opposed to having to square away a big block of time for a formal painting session) has really enabled me to paint more, and is really freeing-up my creativity! In this respect, the 16 clams I paid for this set was the best money I ever spent on art supplies!And the beauty of it is, if you're a beginner, looking to try watercolor on the cheap, without having buy a bunch of expensive tube colors and brushes....just get this set, and a small block of watercolor paper (Don't skimp on the paper...it makes ALL the difference!) and that is all you really need to sample the real watercolor experience.Kudos to Winsor & Newton for a truly great product!

Back years ago, when my TV was still connected to the outside world, I used to watch the syndicated reruns of Cheers at 11PM, just as something to watch and wind-down by. It was never my favorite show- but it was always watchable; entertaining; and made ya laugh. In recent years, I'd been hearkening back to memories of watching Cheers, and wishing that I had the series on DVD- but alas! In the past, the price of the series on DVD was just too high to justify. Naturally, when I saw this complete series set offered for under 60 bananas on Amazon, I grabbed it- and I'm glad that I did!In my opinion, this show's appeal lies in the fact that it can make you laugh out loud quite often; and just transport you to a different world, apart from the current reality- which is what entertainment is supposed to do; but which most modern forms fail to achieve. And while I often don't like clichéd story arcs- I have to say that with Cheers, the Sam and Diane romantic story arc was very well done, and even keeps ME interested! And the beauty of it is, instead of concentrating on that one arc, the producers wisely just kept it as one aspect of the show, while giving equal weight to the other characters. Well-done!And, much like Three's Company, this is also one of those rare shows which is good right from the very beginning. It hits it's stride right off the bat in episode one; and the characters are already fully developed. A rare feat, successfully pulled off only by the real veterans of good TV comedy!I see some other reviewers complaining about the packaging. Personally, I have no problem with the packaging. It is more than adequate for storage and normal use; the DVDs are easy to access; and my mailman even dropped the box on the ground from his car, while trying to hand it to me while i was on my tractor- and it did it no harm.All in all, I am very glad that this series is now available in it's entirety for such a low price; and that the packaging is not bulky or gawdy, like some shows which come in novelty packaging!If you're looking for good old-fashioned entertainment to just sit and watch and relax to at night; which will take your mind off of reality and make you laugh...this is it! (I don't know what it is- even though in real-life i despise bars, and would never patronize one- there is something very comforting about this show!)

I remember watching Three's Company many years ago- and while it wasn't in the same league as All In The Family or The Odd Couple, it was just good light entertainment, which made you laugh and took your mind off of reality- which is exactly what entertainment is supposed to do (And what modern shows fail to do!)It has been a LONG time seen I've seen this show, as I do not have my TV connected to the outside world; I only watch DVDs; and i had been wanting this series for some time- but in the past, the price was too high to justify me purchasing it. Naturally, when I saw the complete series now available in one set for under 60 clams, I was ecstatic, and purchased it right away.I am completely satisfied with this set, for the price. The packaging is adequate, and doesn't take up too much space- and while the packaging and even the DVDs themselves seem to be of minimal quality, I'm sure they will last if treated with reasonable care. Picture and audio quality are good so far (I'm only on the first disc, mind you...).Some are complaing about lack of extras- but personally, I don't care. I'm just glad that the complete series is available in one package for this price. How often does one watch the extras, anyway? In my opinion, the producers did the right thing by making the series available at a price I am willing to pay. I mean, C'mon- this isn't Seinfeld; it's just a semi-slapstick light comedy, with the great Norman Fell as the butt of many sex jokes...and then later, the great Don Knotts. Fun to atch, and one of the best of it's genre...but really, how much can be said?If you enjoyed watching the show in the past, and are lookin for laughs and a break from reality; buy this- it is well worth the reasonable price, and will provide endless laughs. I tend to prefer intelligent humor, but this is one of the few sit-coms which can still make me laugh out loud. And unlike most shows, it is good right from the start! (Some shows take a while to hit their stride; and for the actors to fully get into their characters- but this one is right on the mark from the first episode!)

I've been a big fan of Celestial Seasoning's Lemon Zinger and Stash's Lemon Ginger for a while, so when I saw Lemon Lift by Bigelow in a store, I figgered[sic] I'd give it a whirl. My first reaction was "Where's the lemon?". Well, I really don't taste any lemon at all in this tea, BUT, it does have a wonderful blend of spices which remind me of pumpkin pie spice- as a result of that spice taste, I now buy this tea- not as a replacement for the other lemon teas, but for it's own uniqueness.If you're looking for lemon, this ain't it! But if you like pumpkin pie, give this a try. Also, do note that this has a black tea base- so it is caffeinated. (Lemon Zinger, by contrast, is hibiscus-based, and thus caffeine-free). Normally, I don't find Bigelow teas to be of the best quality- but this one shines because of the unique blend of spices/unique taste. It is a rather strong and robust tea, too- I really look forward to this in the morning!

So, you've won millions in the Powerball lottery; or have been elected to a position in local government on Long Island, and you're looking for a great gag gift so you can video the priceless look on your cycling-enthusiast friend's face when you present him with a "road racing bike" which, at 30 lbs. weighs more than any mountain bike made in the last 25 years; and comes with a mish-mash of the lowest-quality components available- then this is the bike for you!Be sure and leave the price-tag on it, because knowing that it costs 6 times as much as the equivalent-quality Walmart bike is half the fun!The bike is definitely ahead of it's time! You just watch; next year, all TDF riders will be mounting their brifters in the drops- Yes, I'm sure it'll be the hot new trend!In case your recipient is unobservant, call attention to the welds which look as if they were done by a drunken retarded chimpanzee.If Rube Goldberg were still alive, he would be riding one of these! In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if this bike was his idea!Truly, this is one of the best gag-gift items i have seen! It may cost a little more than the fake mustache/big nose and glasses....but the howls of laughter it will elicit as the cruddy Kenda tires blow-out the first time it is ridden around the block (assuming you can find some unsuspecting soul to actually ride it) will be more than worth it!No need for the additional expense of a whoopie-cushion; just keep a straight face and make like you actually, in all seriousness expect your recipient to actually ride this contraption, and he will soil his pants, as he turns pale in anticipation of actually having to be seen in public upon this monument to obsolete out-dated ode to shoddy quality, which no self-respecting 10 year-old would be caught dead on!I've heard that in at least one jurisdiction, judges were ordering DWI offenders to ride these "bikes" as an alternative to prison; but such practices were ruled unconstitutional, as cruel and unusual punishment.Hey! Is that a 1980's 7-speed drive-train?  This is truly the Harley-Davidson of bicycles![Gasp!] Is that A Shimano MF series cassette?! Well, I'm not surprised, as just about everything I see on this "bike" makes me want to exclaim "MF!".Now, if you do buy this "bike", you'll probably want to immediately exchange the included KMC chain- as it is the one quality component on this abomination, and you really wouldn't want to take away from the comedic effect by allowing your gag gift to actually brandish one quality component, would you? I can not believe that the manufacturer actually sprang for a KMC, as they do go for about $18 retail, and thus are worth more than pretty much anything else on this  (tee-hee) "bike".
No matter how good or bad your caliper brakes are....these will make them better! Best quality brake pads out there, bar none!

These things are just squishy-squashy plastic- they essentially are just there to hold your straps in place. They look cheesy; and they often get squished-down and stick to the bottom of your pedal, so that you have to reach down with your hand and open them up, to slide your foot in. Get metal ones instead (Like the MKS deep Steel Toe Clips), as they look and work much better. On the positive side, at least the straps were pretty good- I ended up using them with the metal MKS cages which I bought to repalce these before going to clipless.

Very nice quality cages for the pice! They stay shiny and look great, even on the nicest bikes; and they fit well and work great. Ironically, I switched to clipless shortly after getting these, but I'm saving these in case i ever want to switch back. Great product at a bargain price.

Although I'm not generally a big fan of eating off of plastic, I have to say that these plates are of a very quality; they look good (The colors are very saturated!); and they make taco night much easier and faster! Wish I would have had these years ago! The only downside is that you can't choose your colors when ordering here- thankfully, I got lucky and was sent a green and a purple! (Althopugh truthfully, all the colors look pretty darn good).If you make tacos...get these!!

When this arrived, I opened the box and thought someone had mailed a likeness of Hillary Clinton to me! After I calmed down, I realized it was only this enema bag I had ordered for my mother. Phewww! Suffice it to say, without going into graphic detail, my mother loves it- and it is of very good quality. If only these things didn't bear a resemblance to our politicians! But, I guess that is impossible, considering the quality of our "elected representatives" and the intended purpose of these products. In fact, if only our politicians would use these things, it would definitely help to relieve them of what they seem to be so full of.

These speakers produce the highest-quality bass that you will ever find anywhere even near this price point, hands down! Tight but full bass which will not disappoint.That being said, while the overall sound is definitely high-quality, it is not audiophile quality- but you were not eriously expecting that for this price, were you? Then again, these were obviously meant to be computer & A/V speakers (Although I use them for bedroom music speakers), so they were engineered to fill that niche, and they EXCEL at that purpose!I'm reviewing them more so from the perspective of music speakers- so plrease bear that in mind.My only real complaint, is that highs and certain mids can be rather recessed. That's it. If they had merely added a tweeter to each satellite, these speakers would be PERFECT. Even so, they still sound great- and the average user who listens to popular music probably wouldn't even notice. And that being said, they STILL sound better over-all than anything you can get anywhere near this price point which will retain powerful and quality bass.A few other niceties:The on/off button; Volume control; and bass level control are on one of the satellite speakers- so you can control everything conveniently and quickly, including the subwoofer. A headphone jack, and a 3.5mm input jack are also located on the same satellite- so you can plug your MP3 Player in easily. There is also a 3.5mm input on the sub, and R & L RCA input jacks on the sub.The actual components are very well-built and of nice quality. Heavy; not cheap and cheesy. And the sub is built sturdily and heavy enough to take the pounding of the bass that it is capable of producing, with no rattles or other annoying noises.The system works well at all volumes, from loud, to barely perceptible- including the sub, which still does it's thing, even at the lowest volume, and maintains the bass in proper proportion, even at very low volume- and thanks to the bass control knob, you can choose to have virtually no bass at all...or overwhelming bass- or anything in-between. You can tailor it just the way you like for your preferences and listening needs.The only slight caveats:The cables which connect the satellites to the sub are about 6' long. If you want to place the speakers further apart (Their placement in the room, and the orientation of the sub can make substantial differences in the sound) you'll have to get extensions. A standard RCA extension cable for the left satellite can be had for 6 bucks, but the special cable needed to extend the right cable (which contains all the controls) is rather expensive- ranging from 25 to 50 clams or more, depending on the length you need. Considering the qualityu of these speakers though, and the price for which you can get them here on Amazon, that doesn't bother me as much as it otherwise might- even if you spend 40 bananas on an extension, these speakers are still a great deal, and will still sound better than anything you can get for the combined price.Only other minor complaint: There are no keyholes or any other attachment points on the satellites for wall mounting. To be fair thopugh, most other systems designed primarily for computer use do not have such features either (Withj my old speakers, I drilled my own- without even taking the speakers apart- and I got lucky, and didn't hit anything inside...but I'm not willing to take that chance with these- so I made little shelves for the satellites, and velcroed them to the shelves!)That's it.Summary: If you're looking for great-sounding speakers for any purpose, with amazing bass, and are not prepared to spend several hundred bucks, get these! Period! Others aren't even close at anywhere near this price.  There's no competition- these are simply the best you can get at this price point- case closed; no regrets!

Only received one kit; not a pack of six. It took two calls to Amazon Customer Service to rectify the problem (And as usual, their customer service is excellent, and much appreciated)- but it was not worth the hassle, for such a generic cheap item. Other than that, these are decent run-of-the-mill generic patch kits. 5 stars for the product; 5 stars for Amazon customer service; 0 stars for the seller!

I bought this to keep coffee/tea warm on winter bicycle rides- and it does a great job of it. Seems a little expensive for what it is; and considering the fact that to use it for cycling or pretty much any sport, you need to purchase a Klean Kanteen Sport Cap 3.0Sport Cap 3.0 in order to be able to drink directly from it without removing the cap and letting the heat out.... But it's still the most inexpensive and best alternative for keeping drinks warm on a bicycle- as all the other decent double-insulated bottles which fit water-bottle holders, cost substantially more. [Klean Kanteens cost almost as much, but they're only single-wall- not double).It fits nicely in my bottle cage; and is not as heavy as I expected it to be [That's a GOOD thing!]A quality product- no complaints! (I'm sure it does a great job of keeping stuff cold, too- but for that I use insulated plastic bottles- but those were not keeping my drinks warm for more than half an hour! The Hydro-Flask keeps it warm for hours!]

I really wanted to like this mirror- it looks like a good design- but unfortunately, it is implemented poorly. The mirror simply does NOT stay put! It is more dangerous riding with this mirror, than no mirror at all, because you constantly need to re-adjust this mirror- as riding into even a modest wind; going over 15MPH; or even moderately-rough roads will endlessly keep knocking it out of adjustment. I even tried modifying it, by coating the pivot ball and socket weith rubber cement- but it only helped a little. One 34 mile ride with this piece of garbage was enough!The screw that tightens the mounting plug into the end of your handlebar, also controls the friction of the mirror's swivel- but no matter how tightly you crank down that screw (to the point where I was afraid i was going to crack my carbon bars!)...it just does not put enough resistance on that swivel to hold the mirror in place- unless you're only puttering along at 10MPH on a smooth road on a windless day!If they would merely add a small set screw to allow to lock the mirror's pivot in place, it would solve the problem.And while I wasn't expecting the world for ten bucks, I find it ironic, that I ended up finding a great mirror, which I love, for even less than this hunk-O-guano!! If youi want a great mirror for your drop-bar road bike, get this instead:  Pro Road Warrier Bar End MirrorOn the other hand, if you're a hipster, this mirror may be the next big trend! -Not as a safety device; but as a bicycle-fashion accessory! Picture it flapping uselessly in the breeze on a fixie with pink wheels and green tires, as the hipster-rider blows a red light on the way to the IPO-selling cafe in the regentrified neighborhood! Yes, this could be the next hipster trend! Remember where you heard it! In fact, if you already own one of these, instead of throwing it away, you may want to hold onto it, because if CatEye ever fixes the problem, these floppy useless ones will no-doubt be a hot commodity on that big auction website, and once they become scarce, will probably sell for six-hundred bucks, right up there with ancient horn-rimmed glasses and 1970's polyester disco shirts!

Bought these for my newly-acquired Venge (I do not use road pedals, as I want to be able to walk!) and was impressed, as these are noticeably lighter than the Ultegra PD-6500 pedals on my other bike- According to my scale, these weigh 5.1 ounces each. They seem just as sturdy as the beefier Ultegra pedals; and of course, they work great, and have adjustable tension. What's not to love?

I bought these to replace the expensive merino woll ones I use for winter cycling (The wool ones were not durable; nor were they very warm!) These Kenyons are VERY warm; they're comfortable; and they can't possibly any less durable than the wool ones they're replacing! (I'll never buy Minus33 products again!).I normally avoid synthetic fibers- but I needed something better than the Minus33 woolies for this winter; so I thought I'd give these a try...and I'm glad that I did! I have the bottoms, too- and between the two, I've been able to wear fewer layers, yet stay warmer this winter! (In fact, I've actually been riding my bike in colder weather than I ever have before!)Great product, for a reasonable price!

I had initially bought some expensive merino wool thingies to use for winter cycling- but they were a disappointment. By contrast, these Kenyons are actually warmer- much warmer- and less than half the price of the wool. Can't report on the durability yet, as I've only had them a few weeks, but they appear to be of good quality, and plenty sturdy enough for what I use them for (I'm very easy on clothes- even cheap garments last me forever).Riding my bike when it's barely above freezing; cloudy and windy, these alone, with just the requisite of cycling shorts over them [no insulative value!] kept me toasty!Great product! I have the tops, too- and between the both of them, I have been a very happy camper....errr, I mean cyclist, this winter!

I got a newer bike recently, and was stressing over the fact that my beloved Mirrycle STI-mounted mirrors do not fit 2010 and newer brifters; so I decided to try 4 different mirrors, hoping to find one that would be to my liking. The other three mirrors were garbage- but this simple bar-end mirror won the contest! In-fact, I now prefer it to the Mirrycle!*It stays put.(Even at 30+MPH/in the wind/on roughish roads)*It offers a good-sized viewing area (better than other bar-ends)*It couldn't be easier to install (Comes with two different "plugs" so will fit different sized bars)*It doesn't protrude out to the side- so it does not get in the way.*It looks good- doesn't "fred-up" your nice bike.*It's rather aero.*It offers a quick convenient view whether you're riding on the hoods or in the drops.*It's inexpensive!*Has largest viewing area compared to others of this style- i.e. much bigger than The Italian Mirror; bigger than Sprintech; etc.And surprisingly, I find it easier and quicker and more natural to take a glance at this mirror, than I did with the STI-mounted Mirrycle! You'd think with the STI-mounted Mirrycle, it would be quicker to use, not having to look down as far- especially when riding the hoods- but NO! -this baby is actually more natural to use, as instead of having to turn your gaze down a bit and to the side, with this, all you need do is a quick glance down (You don't have to turn your head at all). In the drops, it's even easier!Also, even though the mirror surface is smaller than the Mirrycle, I find I get a better view, because of the lower position. With this mirror, it's all road view, as opposed to my left arm.I had had reservations about getting this kind of mirror, because I'm blind in one eye, and a real Mr. Magoo with the other- but this mirror is still large enough that even I can get a good view- and if it works for me, it'll definitely work for you!Great product; I'm ordering another one for my older bike- I'm actually going to replace the Mirrycle on that bike with one of these, as I prefer it's view, and unobtrusiveness.UPDATE: Well, that was fast! These things DO BREAK EASILY! I was just fooling around with mine, in the house, and the stem of the mirror snapped-off right at the little ball on which it swivels. I like this mirror so much though, that I drilled-out both the stem and the little swivel-ball, and put put in an eighth-inch metal dowel (cut from a nail with a pair of Vise-Grips...) and JB Welded it all together- she's nice'N sturdy now! I also completely covered the swivel ball in a layer of JB Weld, to give it a little more diameter, so it stays in-position even better in it's socket when mounted on the bike- Now it's really rock solid! They really need to make these beefier though- I don't see them lasting long under normal useage, without the above modification. I'm planning on buying a few more of these, but I'm not even going to wait for the new ones to break- I'll just saw the stem off at the ball and modify them as I described above. Still a good deal though, considering all the other mirrors out there- 90% of which are useless. -And at least they're cheap.

I had bought one of the original (just plain) Clips years ago as my first MP3 player, and was pretty impressed by it (except for it's battery performance). I purchased this Clip Zip as a back-up/outdoor player, as I didn't feel it appropriate to use my big expensive Cowon player in those situations (and my Sony which used to do back-up/outdoor duty recently croaked).I was quite disappointed with the Clip Zip. I thought it was supposed to be an "upgrade" to the original Clip- and in a few ways it is (such as the MicroSD slot and full-color screen) but in most respects, it not only still fails to correct some of the problems of the original Clip, but is actually a downgrade!For instance: The Al-Gore-Rhythm (algorithm) of the shuffle feature still sucks! (It'll play some tracks over and over, while never playing others) -I mean, SHEESH! All these years since the first Clip, and they can't fix such a simple problem? Battery life is still abysmal (Regardless of what they claim- it's only around 10 hours, under light usage); and while the sound quality is decent (Better than iPod; not as good as Sony or Cowon) it did not seem to me to be as good as the original Clip- although everyone swears that these Zips are built from the exact same hardware....But the worst thing about the Zip, which is a definite downgrade, is the finish/type of plastic used for the actual body of the unit. The original clips were smooth and shiny and solid-feeling. These things feel like some kind of disposable one-use item- like a disposable razor or something; they now feel very cheap and flimsy- not even as good as some $10 Dollar Store player; like a cheap toy.It gets worse! O-K, there was no way I was going to pay full price for a new Zip- as you can buy a Sony for just a few bucks more- so I bought this refurb- as, even considering the flaws of these things, for <30 bananas, it would be O-K for a back-up/outside/lawn-mowing player- even though I didn't expect it to last more than a year (These teeny things with their teeny battery have always had battery issues- they just don't last) but the straw that broke the camel's back, was that this POS would brick EVERY time I disconnected it from my computer, after charging and/or file transfers. It was possible to get it functional again, by doing a "soft reset"by holding down the power button for a while....but each time, I'd have to hold the button longer and longer- and now, after a few weeks, it is getting to the point where it is almost impossible to get it to boot-up. Even for <30 clams, I expect the stupid thing to last more than a few weeks! Back it goes!It's a shame. Had Sansa truly worked at improving the original Clip just a little, by fixing it's issues, and keeping the price low, this could be a decent second/back-up player- but instead of working on the issues, it seems that they added a few new frills; raised the prices; and lowered the quality- transforming these things from decent "serious" players, to something that should be in the Dollar Store for 10 or 15 bucks.NOTE: They say if you Rockbox these things, it can improve performance/fix some of the issues- but of course, doing so will void the warranty- and considering how cheap and flimsy these things feel now, I just don't care....

I've been in love with the KJV for a good deal of my life- but somehow, it just never seemed right that the most important, most significant, most awesome book ever published in the history of the entire universe, should be reduced to some small volume printed on tissue paper. Enter this Greyden Press 1611 First Edition facsimile!THIS is more like it!It's the perfect size! It's not small, like the average Bible of today...but it's not as large as the original KJV- which would be unwieldy. It's somewhere between those two extremes- about the size of a concordance- and thus, it is just right for daily use. This is not a little book to be held in one hand while reading. Set it on your lap- you know it's there, but it doesn't crush you; or read it at a desk or table.The old Gothic typeface is a sight to behold! It adds beauty and elegance; and sets the Word of God apart from the average modern book. It takes a little getting used to, to read it well- but the font is a decent size (10pt) and clear and dark, so once you get used to the look of the letters, you will have no problem.I find that this  typeface causes me to read more slowly and deliberately...and that is a good thing, as it gives me time to absorb and contemplate what I read; without having to actually stop and ponder. Another added benefit is, that being forced to read more slowly, and not having to stop and ponder, seems to prevent the inevitable tiredness that seems to be quickly induced when I read! It seems that with any other book (even standard KJVs) I just read a few pages, I'm struggling to stay awake/get really tired. Not so with this Bible! I think the posture of keeping it perched on my lap, and the slower reading/no need to stop and contemplate/not being able to sit back and recline while this is on my lap; AND the extra attention necessary to decipher the Gothic typeface, is the key!This Bible really lets you EXPERIENCE the KJV- as opposed to just reading it. (Think of a simulator vs. an appliance). Having such a book which is large and substantial, with real book pages, instead of see-through tissue paper :D ; the beautiful and "different" font, and no extraneous BS (i.e. no "words of Christ in red" or anything like that) really adds a special atmosphere and reverence which sets the reading of this book apart- as should be the case for the Word of God; and for such a beautifully written and elegant text as the KJV. I feel like I'm in a different world when reading from this Bible; It's like going back in time.Do note that the price of this Bible varies WILDLY. A certain brick & mortar retailer (who sells Kenmore appliances and who used to use Winnie The Pooh as a logo on their clothes) sells this very Bible for over five-hundred bucks! I got mine for under a hundred, via a little internet searching and a large famous "auction" site.The only question that remains, is how the binding will hold up. It is a glued (as opposed to sewn) binding- which are generally not the best. It seems to be of good quality- as much so as a glued binding can be- but being a large and heavy book, I don't know how it will hold up. I've only had my Bible a few days as of this writing- but I see nothing to cause me any worry so far- i.e. when you open the book and lay it flat, there is no creasing of the spine or uneven shifting- so that is a good sign. My Young's concordance has a similar binding, and has held up for nearly 30 years.....so we shall see- But for such an awesome book, and considering that it is readily available for under $200 (and under $100 if you poke around), one can't have everything/can't complain.You have to wonder sometimes, with volumes of this nature, if the publisher intended it as a display piece, or as something to actually be read and used. This is now my daily reading Bible, so I will update this review as time goes on- but bottom line: If you love the KJV, and want to aesthetically enhance your Bible reading, buy this book! I like mine so well, and considering the low price one can get them for at the moment, I may just order another one to keep as a spare. I also foresee these appreciating in value as time goes on, as many of the better KJV facsimiles have in the past- as these are not produced in huge numbers- and considering what some places are even selling them for now (as mentioned above)- just get one while you can; while they are still cheap! You can never go back to a small tissue-paper Roman-typeface Bible after having one of these!

FINALLY- a nice pair of waterproof boots at a reasonable price! Many of the brands I used to buy and rely on, have reduced their quality in the last few years, to the point where I can no longer buy them [Think Timberland; Georgia Boot; Herman Survivors...]- I had never tried Wolverines in the past, but had always wanted to, so I thought I'd give them a shot.I've had these Wolverines for over a month now...and I am very impressed- so much so, that I am going to order a 2nd pair.They seem to wear well, and I think they will be durable (I'm not too hard on boots....but it seems that the finishing on many these days is so thin, that a new pair of boots will be all scuffed/scraped up in a few days- just from normal use- i.e. walking around; kneeling; etc. But these Wolverines are still looking good!They were comfortable from day-one! Required no breaking-in at all.Of course, they look great!The lacing system is fast and easy.The soles offer good traction and comfort, and yet are not the heavily-lugged variety, which trap mud and dirt. These soles stay clean, and are easy to clean when you do get crud on them.Of course, it will require more time to assess the durability of these boots- and whether or not they'll still be waterproof 6 months or a year from now- which seems to be an issue with a lot of other manufacturers these days; and I will update this review periodically- but so far, so good- and from what I've seen, I'm optimistic. I've been wearing workboots since I was a teenager (and I'm middle-aged now) and I can usually tell after a few weeks use if a pair will be durable or not. I have a feeling that these are going to be much like the ones I bought them to replace, which lasted me 10 years!In short: I love these boots! They already seem like old friends...but are still like-new! Hard to believe, for such a reasonable price!DURABILITY UPDATE 11-12-2014O-K, so I've been wearing these boots 90% of the time in the few months I've had them. I've done some building projects; got cement dust on them; am replacing the clutch on my tractor; etc. and you know what? These boots still look great! Unlike my Georgia boots, they haven't gotten all scuffed-up and scraped, even though I haven't been babying them! (The Georgia boots got horribly scuffed/scraped just wearing them a few times to town!)- I just ordered a second pair of these Wolverines to use for "good"! And they're SO comfortable, in every situation. One caveat: If you climb ladders a lot: These soles can be a little slippery on aluminum ladder rungs- but the soles are great in every other regard- and since I don't climb ladders too often, I can live with that- that be aware, and use extra caution if you should climb a ladder while wearing these (I would imagine the traction on metal roofs wouldn't be the greatest, either...)

I've been a tea-lover since I was a child. It used to be, you could buy a box of Lipton tea in the supermarket, and have perfectly fine tea. I don't know what has happened in recent years, but the major tea brands have all turned to crap. Twinings comes close to reproducing what normal tea once was. It is much more flavorful and rich than Lipton and such is these days.

I could only sit through about 20 minutes of this tripe! I thought this would be a fun movie; and having gone to high-school in NYC myself, albeit in the 70's, I figured I'd enjoy the nostalgia aspect.  This movie was just so stupid and boring, I couldn't stand it. You don't care about/have any interest in any of the characters.The one positive thing I can say: It does paint an accurate portrait of two aspects of the NYC school system, by illustrating what a babylon of confusion it is; how the staff are more interested in (and forced to) follow petty rules in regard to everything they ever do; and how the atmosphere in the schools is totally not conducive to learning (and it's much worse, today!)- but such things do not make for entertainment,  alone.

So, I ordered these just to add to my order to get free shipping- figuring I can always use spare cotter pins. It turns out, these will spoil you! Really nice pins, for use on the tractor; the truck; and whatnot. They look and feel good; and they seem to stay more secure than generic ones. Must. Get. More!

My elderly mother has always loved these little transistor radios- but for quite some time, it has been nigh impossible to find any of decent quality. I was really prepared to buy my mother a much more expensive Sangean or something, because we live in BFE (the boonies) and have metal roofs, so reception is tough. But after reading the reviews on this Sony, I couldn't resist giving it a try, before going with something that would cost over $50. My mother was very skeptical when I told her what it cost- she was basically ready to chuck it before it even arrived- but it arrived the other day, and my mother's scorn for it quickly turned into praise- now she wants me to order another one, so she'll have it in the future when this one wears out!I walked into my mother's place the other day while she had the radio on, and I couldn't the sound that this little thing was putting out! It was rich and deep- not tinny at all- and quite loud! Amazing! She had no trouble getting stations were problematic on every other radio.I'm impressed! All the good reviews on this radio are TRUE! Believe them! Very glad that I took a chance on this little radio! I'm going to order that spare right now!

I had initially given this a good review. I had bought two of these flashlights. At first they were great- I could light-up one of my out-buildings 300' away while standing on my porch! That didn't last long. The brightness quickly faded (Yes, I keep the batteries well-charged). Seems to be a problem in the circuitry in the switch. Both lights do the same thing. Now, these flashlights don't produce as much light as my $2 AA-battery-powered flashlight from Tractor Supply! I can't see worth a darn 10' in front of me, in my yard!Spend the money and buy the real thing, instead of these cheesy, worthless knock-offs. The good ones may cost quite a bit, but what good are these cheap-O's, if they don't even last a month? I'm throwing both of these out- they are worthless; good for nothing; garbage.

For such a cheap flashlight, this seemed pretty good at first- but after only a few uses, the brightness faded to the point where this piece of junk puts out much less light than my $2 AA-battery powered flashlight from TSC. I have two other cheap knock-off "CREE" flashlights which did the exact same thing- they worked great at first, but after just a few uses, are as dim as an NBA player on Wheel Of Fortune!This is going into the garbage- it is useless. And yes, I keep the batteries well charged. (At least the batteries that came with my other knock-off CREEs are half-way decent; The batteries that came with this are as worthless as the flashlight- they are significantly lighter than similar batteries- merely smaller batteries inside of a larger 18500 shell!After messing with this crap, I'll gladly spend significantly more for the real thing, so that I'll have a decent flashlight when needed. This stupid thing doesn't even provide usable illumination 10' in front of me, anymore (Whereas at first, it would light-up trees and out-buildings 300' feet away).Bottom line: Don't waste your money. Buy the real thing!

I'm not going to tell you that these are audiophile-quality cans. A real audiophile could tell you (and me) why they are not- but you're seriously not expecting audiophile-quality for fifteen bananas, right? What these are, are cans that sound GREAT, if you like bass. I don't know how they'd do with rap "music" or anything like that, but I listen to older stuff- everything from oldies to classical, and these babies give me the sound the way I like it: Warm; rich and bassy. For the kind of music I listen to, the bass is not distorted nor artificial-sounding. The mids and highs are there too. Not as prominent as the bass; not like they would be on a $200 pair of audiophile buds, but these sound GREAT to me (and my EQ is heavily tweaked to emphasize bass- even in music that was never bass-heavy- you may even get better performance with a flat or less heavily tweaked EQ).These are the second-cheapest pair of IEMs I have ever purchased, and yet they are my all-time favorites! They sound better than my JVCs, and they require substantially less volume to achieve the same level of loudness as the JVCs.The foam tips not only achieve a good seal in your ear (which really helps the sound quality), but they are very comfortable [I've always HATED earphones!] AND, the best part is: They don't come off in your ear when you take the phones out! [Unlike those stupid silicone tips, like the ones on my JVCs, which I had to dig out of my ear canal with a toothpick once!].I've read of other users having some problems with durability, which seem to be attributed to the built-in volume control. So, as a precautionary measure, I took a piece of clear packaging tape, and wrapped it around the volume control pod, with the volume slider set at max. I feel that this will stave off any problems, because it will keep the slider from moving [which is likely a point of failure] and, as the tape overhangs the volume pod at each end a little bit, it will act to relieve stress and movement on the wires, where they enter the pod- which is probably another major failure point. Hopefully these will last as long as my old Koss "Plugs", which I had for 7 years.I'm no audiophile- but all I know is that I like the sound of these phones better than any I've ever had [and I do use them with high-quality mp3 players- including a Sony E384 and a Cowon X9].  They're just perfect for the music I listen to, and the sound I like. Give them a try- for 15 clams, you'll likely be amazed. In my [biased] opinion, you could spend $100 on some "good" cans, and not get the sound that you can get from these!I'm actually going to buy a second pair, just to keep for the future, because I like these so much!

When I first got my first pair of these boots, I thought they were the greatest boots on earth. They were comfortable from day one; looked great; were easy to get on and off, with the zipper; and they were waterproof ["were" is the operative term, here!]. Who could ask for anything more? I even ordered a second pair, to keep for the future; and then a third pair, when I found a shoe-store's demonstrator pair being sold on that famous auction site for a greatly reduced price. So I actually own 3 pair of these.Well, I should have waited longer to make those extra purchases....because as it turns out, these boots go downhill quickly.The main problems are: They don't stay waterproof for long. And it's not that I don't know how to care for waterproof boots- I've been wearing workboots all of my life, since i was a teenager (and I'm a middle-aged coot, now). At first they are great- I wore them in the snow, and they were dry and warm- and yet they are light enough to wear in the hot summer too- perfect! Perfect, that is, until they are a few months old.... And it doesn't matter if you keep them up with silicone or what-have-you.My middle "back-up" pair, which I'd only worn a handful of times, I wore on a walk last night- on mowed paths through my pasture- and they leaked just from the short wet grass!!!!! That is pathetic! So, I can't even think of wearing these boots in the snow now...much less where  I might have to walk through shallow standing water, like puddles or anything! So if you're looking for a waterproof boot...look elsewhere, because these will let you down.I have a pair of Herman Survivors, which cost half as much as these Georgia Boots, and they are ten years oild, and only recently lost their waterproofness (and only because the upper started separating from the sole)Another major problem with these Georgias, is that the leather is of extremely poor quality. The finish is so thin, that these boots get scuffed literally from just walking through the grass. I've been gentle with these boots- wearing them for going to town or taking walks, or just knocking around, because they are comfortable- it's not as if I'm doing logging or steel-work or something- and yet, these boots end up looking like CRAP after literally just a few wearings. They look like they've been through a war...whereas in reality, they've only been through walks and shopping trips to town!  My 10 year-old Herman Survivors look better!It's a shame, because other than for those caveats, they would be great boots. The zipper is sturdy and will out-last the rest of the boot. They fit perfect and don't even need a breaking-in period; They look great [when new]; They don't have lugged soles, so they don't pick up mud; and yet they afford good traction....they could be the perfect boot if not for the above-mentioned major flaws. And I still love to wear them when it's dry; and when I feel like painting them up with that colored shoe "polish" [Because otherwise, as a relative once remarked to me "Your shoes look worse than a homeless guy's"!] -I swear, the finishing on this leather is tissue-paper thin!So here I am, stuck with 3 pair of non-waterproof boots.....which deteriorate faster than even cheap Walmart junk. And don't even THINK of wearing these for traditional workboot applications!I won't be buying any more Georgia Boots- I've learnt my lesson. From now on, I'll go with Herman Survivors- as they're cheaper; stay waterproof forever; and stay nice-looking.*****[EDIT: Forget Herman Survivors. Turns out, Walmart bought-out the Herman patents, and is now manufacturing Hermans as one of their cheap-o junk brands- and they are nothing like the quality that Hermans used to be. I've just ordered a pair of Wolverines here on Amazon...we'll see how they do...]****I do understand why there are so many positive reviews of these Georgias- because for the first few months, you'll think they are the greatest boots ever.  And then you'll even consider trying them again, because they were so good at first -"Maybe you just got a bad pair".."I just want to experience what it was like the first few times I wore these"- and then you'll end up with 3 pair...and wet feet...and bum's pitying you.

It is with great sadness that I pen this review. I hate to say anything bad about a show which for DECADES now, has provided so much joy; laughter; and entertainment- a lone treasure from the cesspool that is Hollywood.Of course, as with any show, some seasons are naturally better than others- but unfortunately, The Simpsons have hit rock-bottom with this season.Some might say that after so many years, that the crew of people responsible for making this show have finally run out of ideas- but I do not believe that that is the case. Rather (and they even allude to this fact in the commentaries) I believe the problem is that this is one of the years in which they were devoting so much time to the making of the [awful!] Simpsons Movie, that they neglected the actual show. Why they would do such to such a successful show (or why they were allowed to do it!) is beyond me- but such a course of action was disastrous for the show, and I'd wager that it was also a very poor business decision.Problem B: As had been the case in several preceding seasons, the producers seem to have fallen into a routine where they are more concerned with the plot of the episodes; and less concerned about the humor; wit; and amusing parody of/editorial on contemporary culture- which is a shame, because it was those things which once made the show so great.They devote so much effort to "telling a story" - and subsequently then have to devote more time to resolving the details of that story- thus relegating the humor and witticisms to a subordinate position. They even admit that oftentimes, due to time constraints, jokes and the little flourishes that once made the show so great, must be cut or passed-over entirely, in order to use the available run-time to tell the story demanded by the plot; and to resolve the details of that story.You would think that amongst such a cadre of intelligent people, as those who produce this show, that they could figure out that people do not watch cartoons for their plots/drama/meaningful stories!!! I'd imagine that I speak for many when I say that I personally watch The Simpsons for: A)The humor; B)The wit [The Simpsons was the ONE show which uniquely stood out as possessing intelligent and witty humor- as opposed to the vapid moronic nonsense which normally emanates from Hollywood] and C: All the little flourishes/observations/parodies which served as a commentary on/lampoon of/ridicule of contemporary American culture.Sadly, all of those great traits mentioned above are now gone. It's as if the producers have stopped seeing themselves as comedians/cartoonists/entertainers, and instead now seem to operate under the modus operandi that they are making half-hour animated dramas- with maybe an occasional joke or two thrown in here and there.Some people disparagingly refer to this season as one of the "Al Jean years"- which is unfair- as, in my opinion, Al Jean is brilliant, and has played a major role in the long success of the Simpsons- having been a driving force behind the show virtually since it's inception- and should be commended for all the GOOD seasons which he had a major role in producing, in one capacity or another.The Simpsons is clearly a big-team effort...but in this season, the "team" was obviously more concerned with making a movie; and relegated the series to a back burner- and it obviously shows. (And they really struck-out on that movie!)It was glaringly evident how they took many "shortcuts" with this season: Virtually every episode contains at least one music montage. -Now I can enjoy a well-placed music montage, when it is appropriate and relevant and well-done....but when one starts appearing in every episode, it is evident that it is just being used as a vehicle to fill time while requiring the least input.Also, the great touches which made earlier seasons so great, were noticeably absent here- i.e the little flashbacks/flash-forwards/thought balloons/non-sequiturs; etc. No, instead, we get little animated soap-operas now.I had high hopes for this season, as I read it's description and reviews, because I love it when they explore secondary characters- like Patty and Selma; Skinner; Flanders; etc. and even devote entire episodes to them- which they indeed do in this season- but unfortunately, even that couldn't save this season, as even those episodes were poorly done; and again, were centered around setting up a dramatic plot, and then resolving it- thus pushing out all the other traits which formerly made the show so great.After watching the episodes and commentaries of this season once, I sold my season 16 DVD set. Nothing worth keeping here. I never thought I'd have to do that to a Simpsons DVD set.Kudos for the commentaries on every episode, though. As usual, the commentaries were very enjoyable- only this time, they were much more enjoyable than the actual episodes.Bottom line: If you're looking the wit; humor; and observations/parodies/references that the masses don't "get"/etc. which once made this show so great...you're not going to find them in this season. :(

A thoroughly entertaining and informative great documentary about a great man!Myself, being originally from the north, it took me years to come to a true realization of the REAL facts surrounding the South and the Civil War and Lincoln, et al - and occurred only after I cultivated a keen interest in history. I wish I had seen this documentary (or something similar) when I was much younger, as it would have saved me much time, in overcoming the lies which we were fed in the public schools and by the media!Unlike many of the revisionist history books and fairy tales out there, this documentary is more realistic and accurate. It is not just another "Lincoln freed the slaves...the Civil War was about slavery" piece of clap-trap, This documentary presents a more honest and factual account of what was indeed happening during the life of Davis.Still, it is not perfect, and is somewhat lacking. It did not really show the cruelty and savageness of the Northern army (and not just to their enemies!); and while it did touch upon the real motivations for the Civil War, it still failed to substantially mention and explore the two major issues of the North's not wanting to lose the illicit taxes they were collecting from the South; and the role that the cotton trade played [The North being reliant upon the South's cotton for their industry]. Although these things may've received a one-sentence mention, they certainly deserved at least equal time with the aspects the show did choose to explain in a little greater depth. Also, the role that the New York bankers and shipping companies played.... But still, overall, this was a more faithful, honest and unbiased account than is generally seen.I find that many historical accounts about the time period of the Civil War are usually biased in favor of the North. It was refreshing to see that this was not the case with this one. Neither is it biased in favor of the South, contrary to what a few other reviewers seem to think. It is an unbiased, factual presentation. And while it may have some omissions, if anything, those omissions serve as damage control to the North. If some think that this is biased in favor of the South, perhaps they should re-evaluate the facts and their own values, and come to the realization that if they insist on justifying the criminal acts of the North, anything which presents the unbiased facts will seem to them to be "biased", if only because it accurately portrays who were the real victims, and who were the unlawful aggressors.Anyway, this DVD set was definitely one of the best-made historical documentaries i have ever seen, and it was a thorough pleasure to watch. If you're already well-versed in American history, you may not learn anything new....but you'll enjoy seeing that history well-presented; and find watching this a thoroughly enjoyable experience; and if this stuff is new to you, or if you're looking for something which will give your kids a more realistic understanding of the times, this will prove very enlightening, and also provide a platform from which to glean a smörgsbord of interesting ideas for future study.

Another great classic season of The Simpsons, from when the show was still at it's creative best!There is one thing I do not appreciate: I LOVE the commentaries that accompany EVERY episode- as you can imagine, the people who are responsible for making The Simpsons, are quite entertaining and informative. Having these commentaries is like getting double the value for your money, because the commentaries are as good as the actual show; and over the years, I've actually watched the commentaries multiple times. So what's my complaint, you may ask?My complaint is that Yeardley Smith is on more commentaries in this season than any other thus far! Don't get me wrong, I love what Yeardley does with the Lisa character- I think she is great as a voice actress.....BUT (and I'm sorry to say) the woman is a dolt! All she seems to do on the commentaries, is ask idiotic questions. It's as if one of the other commentators brought in their 5 year-old daughter!Sheesh! We listen to these commentaries to learn what goes on behind the scenes, and to be entertained by the witty people who make this show. Listening to a grown woman, who is actually involved in the show, ask the other crew members idiotic questions that even children know the answer to, is just a waste, and an embarrassment.I mean no disrespect, but it's the truth. For goodness' sake, if anyone connected with the show should happen to read this, PLEASE, for the love of Gawd,  DON'T have Mrs. Smith on future commentaries- if for no other reason than to preserve her dignity!I'm sure I can't be the only one who feels this way. If others reading this agree with me, please add a comment. Thanks.Everything else about this season is a "10"! Buy it! It's a classic that will endure for many years. (And from the days when they still packaged these DVDs in normal and sturdy DVD cases!)Enjoy!

I bought this for my elderly mother, after several Walmart toasters had proved to be of shoddy quality and short-lived for her. This is the nicest toaster I have seen in quite some time. It's sturdily made and works flawlessly. It does what it's supposed to do, and does it well! It toasts evenly, and I expect it will last a long time.Best thing is: It has a slide-out crumb tray, which makes cleaning it a breeze- i.e. you don't have to lift the toaster to clean out the crumbs...just slide the tray out- very nice feature- especially for the elderly. If I had use for a toaster, I'd buy this one! It even looks smart; and doesn't feel cheesy or tinny, like so many other toasters these days.Also, the bread slots are nice and wide, to accommodate thick bread and bagels and such. They are not especially long though, so if you have very large slices of bread, you'll have to cut them first.

I LOVE watching all of Ken (as well as Ric) Burns's stuff. There films are always visually-appealing, engrossing, entertaining masterpieces. The way they can make even still images come alive with sound and movement; and their balanced and thorough treatment of most subjects, makes their works a thorough delight to watch, regardless of your interest in the particular subject being covered.Watching their films truly brings history to life as no book or other documentaries can- and not only that, but they are just so aesthetically well-done, that they are the epitome of the art of entertainment- a veritable smörgåsbord for the senses.I've always been a big fan of Tommy Jefferson's, also- so this DVD seemed like a natural for me! While I would rate the entertainment value of this film as tops, I do feel that it's treatment of the subject matter was a little lacking, and not quite up to the standards I would expect from either of the Burns's.While it does serve as a very good primer and intro to TJ; and as a good basic timeline of his life; and it does a reasonably good job of conveying the context of the times in which he lived, I do feel that it is sorely lacking as far as illustrating the political and philosophical concepts which TJ stood for, and which made him such a genius and a great man.Also, I'm sorry to say, that having a black man narrate most of film [and one with not the greatest voice] did seem to be a blatant contrast to the mood of the period in which the historic events took place, and considering that this piece is about a man who did not see blacks as being quite "equal".Kudos to Mr. Burns though, for presenting both sides of issues, such as TJ's alleged diddling of one of his slaves, after his wife's death; and for pointing out that TJ was in-fact an advocate of abolition (and would have even succeeded in accomplishing it, but for one of his foes).One thing that really bugs me (and this is true of virtually all historical books and films) is the careless use of words and phrases which had quite different meanings in the past, than they do today. Words such as "humanist"; or "public education"[which, in the 18th and 19th centuries, meant: As contrasted with religious education- i.e. schools which were not started and operated by churches or religious institutions.  It did NOT mean a communal government school paid for through the taxation of all people, like we have today].Failing to make clear the true meaning of words which had vastly different meanings and connotations in the past, can be very misleading to a modern viewer- even if not meant to be so. Our revisionist text-books of today are blatantly guilty of that; only they do so on-purpose.All in all, this is a good intro to the life and times of TJ; as well as a thoroughly enjoyable form of entertainment. While it barely scratches the surface for even the mild history buff or aficionado of TJ, it is none-the-less a very enjoyable watch for all, even if you will not learn anything new from it.

I just picked up a package of these today at a local salvage store....had a few tonight with a cup of tea...and just ordered a whole case!These biscuits are not overly sweet; and not heavy at all. They are not heavily flavored, either....but yet, there is just something irresistible about them! They're kind of the consistency of graham crackers, but not as sweet or imposing- but they are not bland like shortbread biscuits. I usually tend to like things with very bold taste...but these crackers are the exception- not bold at all- quite the opposite- and yet, delicious and addictive! Even though they're "chocolate", you really don't even taste the chocolate- and yet it does something to contribute to the overall effect. They're quite unique; Perfect with tea or coffee- as they don't affect the taste of what you're drinking; and yet they taste GREAT! Minimal...but not bland. And fairly low-cal, too!!!! People who crave the typical American junk-food obnoxiously-sweet cookies and snack cakes, will likely not like these.I'm just so glad that I discovered these!

Wow! For a total price (item+shipping) that amounts to less than what a set of cheap sheets would cost you at Wallyworld, you get a really nice, soft, good-looking set of quality 100%-cotton sheets, here!The fitted bottom sheet is over-sized -it is big even on my pillow-top mattress- but that really isn't a problem- although i would prefer a little tighter fit (these are actually loose!)- so I am confident, that these will fit the thickest mattresses with ease. If you have a thin mattress, the fitted sheet may be too big.Other than that, they are just a great sert of sheets for the price- I'll be ordering more.

I had initially purchased a slightly cheaper grinder (A Sportsman MEG300) which worked O-K, but which I returned because replacement blades were unavailable for it (it used a non-standard blade). Bought this LEM as a replacement for that grinder...and I am IMPRESSED!This grinder is much more robust, and the parts which do the work are much heavier-duty than the other grinder. It's well-designed and easy to clean, and it works like a charm! I use it for grinding mainly top round and eye round into lean chopmeat, and it just does it so fast and effortlessly; makes me feel like a pro.The case is plastic and feels a little on the light side- but hey, this is meant for home use- and if you treat it well, I'm sure it'll be O-K. I mean, lets face it, for a grinder at this price point, there have to be compromises- and one is not going to get a stainless steel housing for a hundred bucks.The beauty is, that the "business" parts- i.e. the grinding tube and the plates, etc. are very well made, and feel very beefy. It is a size #8, and accepts standard #8-size parts- like blades and plates, so when/if you need replacements, you can purchase them readily, many places. (The slightly cheaper grinder was only a #5, and used some special proprietary parts which the manufacturer didn't even sell)One thing to note: This unit is not for grinding bone- as per the manufacturer's manual. If you need to do some heavy-duty grinding, you'll likely need a more expensive machine- but for grinding up just plain-old trimmed meat at home, this baby will get 'er done...and quickly and quietly! And I expect that it will last, as it seems built very well in all the places that matter. Very good quality for the low price.I thought my previous grinder was pretty nice- but now that I have this, the old one pales by comparison- this one is just so much better; more powerful; robust; faster (but not noisier) and feels so much more substantial/built heavier (but not heavy to carry).I am very pleased with it. It's like moving up to a Lincoln from a Chevy.  Oh, and a nice touch: When you press the regular (forward) power button, it stays on until you press it again- you don't have to hold it continuously- and thus both of your hands can stay free when grinding. The reverse button is a press-and-release (you hold it for as long as you want it to run in reverse) which is exactly the way it should be (I've never had to use the reverse though- as nothing ever gets stuck, thus far...)Well-done, LEM!

With it's amazing battery life; seemingly infinitely customizable sound; and a wealth of features, this is an AMAZING MP3 player if you [liker myself] are just looking for a dedicated music player. Yes, it's got video; and some other accessories, but this device is primarily made for playing audio- and it does that well. The other things are just gimmicks- and if you're into those other things, there are other devices which do them better.The only real problem I see with the user interface/touch screen, is scrolling. For everything else, once you've played with it for a day and learn how to navigate, it's a piece of cake. Scrolling remains tricky, though.  At least it has tactile buttons for the important things- and they work great.The bad news is: The manual for this player is WORTHLESS. It doesn't tell you how to use the majority of features...or even that they exist! (and it has some advanced features, like the ability to automatically replay just a part of one track)- However, you can look online at the manual for the Cowon J3, which has many of the same features, and uses a similar interface, and figure out the features that the two have in common)That's the good news.The bad news is: Cowon sucks!For one, they seem to have a quality control issue. I had to return my first X9 due to a battery issue. I'm now returning it's replacement due to it not connecting to the computer. I guess I'm a glutton for punishment, but I like this player so much, I'm going to try a third one. Ridiculous, I know- and it does not bode well for the longevity of the product, if I can't get one that even works right when it's brand-new! (If other companies made mp3 players with batteries of this size and capacity, I wouldn't even consider repurchasing this!)Cowon's technical support and customer service is a joke. The only way to contact them if you have an issue, is through email. They warn you that quite a few popular ISPs and webmail services don't make it through to them- and then tell you if you use one of those services, to get another email account from a service that does get through to them! (Absurd! Why don't they just resolve the problem that prevents their equipment from dealing with certain services and providers???)Then, when you contact them, they take days to get back to you. And of course, when they do get back to you, it's the standard "Reset your unit; upgrade the firmware..." script. (How can I upgrade the firmware if my X9 will not connect to my computer, which is the problem I contacted them about??!! DUHhhhh!!!!)Then they want you to submit a request for an RMA; and "if it is approved", you pay for postage to send it back, and at best can expect a refurbished X9 in trade for your 32 day-old X9!SKEW-REW THAT! I'm just returning mine to Amazon. (If you're going to chance buying one of these...only do so from Amazon- not from the manufacturer, or anyone else, or you'll be SOL if there's a problem!)I'll try one more time with a replacement unit....but I'd NEVER buy anything ever again from Cowon. It's a shame. This could be an awesome player- and is quite unique- but poor quality control and poor customer service kill it.I'll let you know what happens with my third and final one when I get it!UPDATE Oct. 1st, 2014. Third try seems to be a charm. I've been using my latest X9 for over a month, now....and it is working fine. AHhhh! It's a great music player when it works as it should- which it is thankfully now doing!

Initially, I found these gloves to be very uncomfortable, for some reason- even though they fit perfectly. After not having worn them for a year, I decided to try them again....and now they feel fine!Anywho....these are thin, light gloves which will keep your hands warm in moderate weather. I don't ride when it's much below 40*F, but they seem to do a fine job in the 40's, and they block the wind nicely, while not making my hands sweat. If you ride when it's colder than the upper 30's, I'd say you'd need a heavier glove, as I wore them once in the upper 30's with some wind, and my hands were on the verge of getting cold.They're made well, and designed well, so that no seams or other protuberances get in the way between your hands and the hoods/bars- and they're easy to get on and off.  All in all, a good product that does what it was designed to do.

I purchased this mainly to keep sweat out of my eyes when I ride my road bike. This is the only sweatband that has ever worked for me- even when it was 107* ! I quickly realized, that it would also be great to wear while doing work outside on hot days- so I've worn it while building a garage; fixing trucks and doing all sorts of things around the farm.....and I don't know how I ever lived without. It is SO NICE not to continually have to wipe my brow or have sweat dripping my eyes. And it keeps you dry for HOURS, even in hot, humid weather; even while doing strenuous activities. This is one GREAT product! I only wish I would have discovered it sooner! (Plain old sweatbands wouldn't work on me for more than 10 minutes!)

I bought this for a relative who was a fan of the show, who then lent it to me- and as I had never watched the show back in the day, I thought maybe it would be something to watch. How did this show ever stay on the air for YEARS? I really don't know how anybody can watch this crap! Funny thing is, the person for whom I bought it, who had been desiring to see the show again after not having seen it in many years, also wondered how she ever had liked it!This is silly, totally unrealistic, unbelievable nonsense, with no redeeming features. (I guess women just liked it for Tom Selleck...and perhaps boys liked it for the car? "Next week on Magnum P.U: Tom Selleck takes off his shirt, and then does a burn-out with the car"- Yes folks, there is a formula for a winning TV show! :D)I tried it, being an avid fan of old shows (I watch NO modern TV) but this show is just gawd-awful. I'm embarrassed for the producers who made this; and for the fact that enough of my fellow countrymen watched it, to keep it on the air! (And the scary thing is, that there were a whole genre of shows similar to this- such as The A-Team...and can we ever forget "Manimal"? LOL! Oh, how I wish I could forget that such shows ever existed. I may be a nostalgia buff, but sadly, the 80's seemed to be a dark decade for TV series- with shows like this prospering, and a few very good shows, such as It's Your Move falling by the wayside) Magnum P.I.? More like Magnum P.U.!

This has been one of my favorite movies of all time, for more than half of my life! This movie is NOTHING like your typical teenage underdog/bully story; and nothing like modern movies- i.e it is not just a bunch of clichés strung together; and the characters are unique and "real". It's a "feel good" movie, but with depth; and all the quality touches of a movie that was made to be enjoyed by adults. The acting and casting were superb; The sets; on-lopcation shooting and direction were perfect; the writing outstanding.DON'T write this one off as just another teenage/bully movie....it is far more.In my book, this is a very rare perfect movie!

I'm not an insomniac, but I do play something at night, on continuous loop, to mask outside noises, as I am very sensitive even to the slightest noise. I've noticed since doing this, that some of these products can actually help me fall-off quicker. Unfortunately, this is not one of those! In fact, I found this one annoying. I do realize that opinions on this subject are largely a matter of personal taste and preference, but I do feel that this recording has some major flaws, which many people will find fault with- as follows:First, the volume is NOT consistent. Some parts are loud; others are very soft. Some parts have a strong bass base [sorry...but I can't think of any better way to say to say that!) which I find to be very conducive for both masking noise, and inducing sleep- while in other sections, the bass goes almost flat. This not something you want when trying to sleep.Secondly: While it is not apparent in the sample track here on Amazon, a piano is used throughout this recording. In my opinion, although I do normally enjoy piano music; pianos are not conducive to sleep.Thirdly: There is a simple, repetitive melodic theme played by the piano, throughout. Having an identifiable melody- especially a constantly repeating one- is NOT a good thing when trying to sleep- it creates monotony; anticipation; expectation; and awareness of time.Three big fails, in my book- but hey, for the price, it was worth a shot!

I was hesitant to order season 15- not having previously seen any of these episodes, and in light of how bad the last few seasons had been- but desperate for a Simpsons fix, I gave it a shot. You can imagine my surprise, when I popped in the first DVD, and started watching the first ep- a Treehouse Of Horror ep, which are never among my favorites- and lo and behold it was a gem!Ditto for many more episodes.Watching the first half of this season, I saw that the crew at The Simpson's seems to have pulled themselves out of the years-long slump that they were in. Most of the magic of the early seasons is back! (The humor; the use of many favorite secondary characters, etc.)O-K, still, a lot of the intelligent wit is still missing....but hey, at least the show is vastly improved from recent years- well...at least that is true for the first half of this season. The second half of this season is where it appears that the crew started running out of steam again. Once again, they start to revert back to plot-centric episodes, where it appears that they put all their effort into the story line, and neglect the humor and the little touches that often make the show so great. (Not that I can blame them- seeing as it so much work to make these shows, and that many of them have been working on this show for so many years...I mean, they're only human.)But all in all, in my book, half of a good season is better than an entire bad season, so I can't complain (Though I might have, had I paid full price for this season! For half-price- which is what I paid- half a season of good eps seems about right:D)My biggest complaint about this season: TOO MANY MUSICAL numbers. And I'm not just talking about the one musical episode (Why-oh-why do they torture us by making Yeardley Smith sing??!! Please...PLEASE stop!). The use of popular-music cues over montages is done in just about every episode- to the point of being cliché. I mean, such can be effective when done when appropriate, to good effect, and with restraint- but it seems as though the Simpson's crew has started using such as a crutch to merely fill space. (It's showing, guys!)The BEST thing about this season, is [drum roll].....the COMMENTARIES! Yes! In past seasons, it had seemed like those doing the commentaries had lost interest- but this season, they back to their former glory. I normally enjoy listening to the commentaries as much as/or even more than watching the actual show- and this seasons commentaries were no disappointment. I was in my glory listening to the commentary on every episode. I think writer Tom Gammill was on just about every one...and he is one of my all-time favorites, so that also helped!Again, like earlier seasons, the commentaries were once again very enjoyable; informative and funny. Kudos to all those who participates, for taking the time to do these commentaries. Some of REALLY enjoy them! (I take back what I said earlier. The price of this season would be justified just for the commentaries, alone!).All-in-all...at least 10 very good episodes; and all good commentaries- makes this season add up to 75% good content. But I'm giving it 5 stars for the great commentaries! (I should deduct 4 stars for the continuation of the LOUSY packaging!).If you're a fan of the earlier Simpson's...this season is for you!

I purchased this to use as a natural anti-imflamatory for one of my elderly dogs. I am very impressed with the quality. It is very consistent and of the highest quality. Great for cooking; and I even eat some out-of-the-jar sometimes, when I'm putting it on my dog's food.

I loved the way this grinder worked, and it seemed well-made and like it was a bargain....but I quickly found out, when needing a new blade for it, that standard #5 blades do not fit (even though they are the correct diameter, this unit uses a proprietary blade, which is THINNER than standard blades, and thus will not allow you to assemble the plate and retainer when using any other blade!).I called the company which manufactures it (Buffalo tools) and they DO NOT sell a replacement blade for it!!!! I was told to "Try our competitors; they may have one that fits."!!!! (They don't!)What good is a grinder for which new blades are not available? I've scoured the interweb, and came up with NOTHING!This could be a great product, but without the ability to replace common external parts, it is worthless! Be aware.Back to Amazon it goes! I'll pay more, and get one that accepts standard parts- or at least one whose manufacturer offer such. Very disappointed. (And believe me, I tried everything, short of having a machine shop grind-down a standard #5 blade!):(

I wasn't expecting much for this price- but the other reviews were good....so I figured I'd give it a try (Didn't want to put a lot of money into an older computer....)- Well, I was very pleasantly surprised to see that this memory functions perfect-O-mundo!

UPDATE: 11/1/13: I continue to be amazed and impressed with this Hitachi! My place looks better than it ever has, because for the first time in my life, I actually enjoy weed-eating...so now I do it much more often; plus, even though it holds only half as much line as my old trimmer...the line lasts 6 times as long without me needing to reload (even when doing around fences, which used to chew up line on my old trimmer); and when it is time to reload...it is SO fast and easy with this baby! I just LOVE this thing! And get this: Even after sitting for a week or two, it will start on the very first pull, if I put the choke lever halfway between open and closed! Amazing! This is the best weed-whacker I've ever had, bar none! If you need more convincing, here's my original review:I JUST received this weed-eater not a few hours ago (From that blue home-improvement store.....as Amazon still hadn't shipped it after 9 days, even though it said "in-stock"...) and have just literally come in from using it for the last two-and-a-half hours. I am in LOVE with this thing!Surprise! It started on the 3rd pull of it's maiden run, after taking it out of the box (Would have started on the 2nd, if I had taken the choke off sooner!)- and ever since, it has started on the very first pull! The fact that it starts so easily takes 3/4's of the work out of weed-eating. After 2.5 hrs. of use, I feel as fresh as when I had started- something I sure could not say about my old trimmer- even though they weigh about the same.Surprise #2: This puppy is QUIET! First time in my life that I haven't needed to wear ear-muffs while trimming- and even after 2.5hrs, my ears aren't ringing; I'm not aurally stressed(I HATE noise!!!); and I believe that this quietness also contributes to the fact that I feel so fresh, even after the long use in 90* humid weather!SURPRISE NUMERO THREE: The line that came already installed on the spool, lasted for the entire job...and there's still plenty of it!
