Well done, poetic!! This is a really outstanding case. It looks far more expensive than it is, everything is where it should be, the device fits in snug enough to not risk falling out , but I have no trouble whatsoever getting my device out. I know that some reviews talked about a super tight fit. This might be something Poetic is working on because an hour after I bought my black case, the listings said that it was not available , with no time given for when it would be. I assume it will be again, however, because this is just a really outstanding case. The keyboard! I am absolutely in love with it. I have no idea how, because this is a small keyboard relative to a normal laptop keyboard, but I don't feel at all like I'm crowding my fingers when typing. As a matter-of-fact, I can whale away pretty much at full speed . The symbols are on the keys where they should be, not moved elsewhere as they are on another keyboard I looked at. The only thing I had any problem with was the backspace because it isn't quite where I expected to be … Probably just a couple of centimeters off , but that is something that you would get used to. The keys feel raised , they make the right noise, and there is sensory feedback letting you know if you might have struck a wrong key. That assumes you can feel it on your desktop or laptop. The case – enclosed keyboard itself fits into the main case extremely well. You just set it in place where it belongs and the magnets are strong enough to hold it there. It can be lifted out and put back in easily. The part that holds the device has perfect cutouts. You can easily feel and reach power, volume, etc. that includes charging hole. Also includes cameras. I do hope that the resume carrying this case because I want to recommended very highly. I have read that there is another case that APPEARS to be the exact same one , and it is cheaper. However I compared the reviews on both and felt that justified my spending $10 more for this one. Do be aware that this is not what I would call a minimalist case, meaning that it is going to take up a little more room in your briefcase than one that doesn't have a keyboard or the margin between edge of device and the edge of case which I'm sure was designed to protect your device if dropped. To me, though I also bought a minimalist case, this is protection that I will want at certain times. You might be wondering how the case operates if you leave the keyboard at home. Extremely well. You can have just the device and it and that works too. Though there is no loop for the attachment of the stylus, there are places you can clip it to. Last but not least, some reviews on other colors mention a chemical smell though I've seen very few if any of that mention with the black one. I do not notice any smell at all. It might be in the dyes used on the other colors.

Mine arrived yesterday and I was delighted with it. It was exactly what I wanted. Lightweight, as small as possible, as then as possible, properly placed cutouts for cameras, volume, power, speakers ; and last but not least, my HDX 8.9 turns off when I close it. It's inexpensive, and in terms of design, that's a steal deal . In terms of materials, it seems about right. So many of them are overpriced for what they are. My only complaint if I were to dig deep, is that it doesn't have any place to clip my stylus. But its description didn't say it did.  I have no idea what it would cost , hence add to our cost to have a stylus loop added to the design , but that would really make it perfect. It could also be maybe a quarter inch bigger on both directions to provide some margin just in case it is dropped, but the whole point of this case is minimalist. I do have a suggestion : when I first put my HDX in it my device did not seem to turn off when I close the case. I discovered that if I push the device as far as possible, creating as tight a fit as possible at the bottom end, when sliding it in, that makes a difference. And while at that , as for how the device fits in it , it's pretty perfect. It is tight enough so there is no possible way you could slide out of the case but it's not so tight that you have to struggle to get your device out. Nice-looking, lightweight, non-bulky, and inexpensive… That is what this case is about.

This is a good whisk, particularly for the price.  Stainless, comfortable handle.  The head came off my first one, but not fast enough for me to think it was badly made, it happens.  Bought another one, I use it for everything.  If you're a whisk aficionado, also do a search for "cocktail whisk" which is a small balloon whisk with a long handle, my other big fave.

Having done childhood in the 40s when "Lincoln Logs" were sold in big enough sets to do something with, fit together well and didn't come with a chemical smell that raised all your instincts to throw them out (let alone the worry about what the Chinese used to stain the wood for export to us), I found this set, made in Maine.  From their website, it sounds like the company was started by a couple who felt the same as I do, and it's mentioned these are stained with a food-safe coloring.  They look just like the ones I had, you can make way more than just the structure pictured on the box because they didn't skimp on pieces or sizes, and I'm not terrified they'll poison my grandchildren. If they do leave reddish stain traces on fingers or their storage bag or carpeting (mine didn't), I'd just put down a sheet.  The storage bag they come in is old fashioned burlap and I like that about them too. A real winner.

My email from Amazon asked "How many stars would you give this book?"  Lots!  The reason is, you can read it to the child or have it read by the App (nice male Brit voice) as each word lights up when he says it... OR child can read it.  Cute enough graphic illustrations.  It takes a while to read, not something you'd choose when the bread is almost fully risen.  If you read normally 2 books to your child before bed, you'd replace it with this one alone.  Maybe even three.

I'm not by any means new to technology, but I am new to tablets and had been flirting with an iPad Mini.  Amazon had a special for one day, whereupon I bought the 8.9HDX (3rd Gen) and IMHO, this thing dances swirls around the iPad Mini. Resolution, colors, crispness of images and sound, oh what a difference on sound.  A fair bit of research that day was telling me that Amazon's tablets are, dollar for dollar, superior in hardware and features--this made possible, I'm sure, mainly  because if you get a Fire, you're more likely to buy their apps, books, etc.  That's been true, and it's more than fair.  That said, I was worried that I would not be able to access competitors' websites (or at least it would be made difficult) because somewhere I'd read something along that line and that has not been the case, at all.  There ARE some PlayStore apps that you can't install, either direct from them OR via sideloading and I don't know the extent of that yet; I've only run into it on a game so far.  (Jury's out on that, in other words.)But regarding apps.  When I checked on Amazon's apps prior to ordering, I didn't see much!  However when I went to the same app store through my Fire, whammo!  There was a whole lot more there.  I've found a lot of apps in categories such as "Productivity" and I'm thinking maybe the Amazon App store is underrated.Apps aside, this Fire is doing far more than I ever thought it would. Especially great is the microphone on the virtual keyboard that I can use "speech-to-text" so I can dictate emails, website URLs, search terms -- anywhere you'd enter text, you can hit the microphone instead.  It has EXCELLENT voice recognition software, even picking up on terms unique to spinning and knitting, slang, purposely mispronounced words such as "gotta" and "whatcha gonna do?" if you pronounce them clearly.  It picks up on punctuation including "full caps yes exclamation point" will give you "YES!" In google searching for "Voice Recognition Commands" to see what else is there, I keep reading that Android Voice Recog. software seems lacking.  That might be a big plus for the Amazon products.  If so, it's an important feature to me because it saves soooo much time.Youtube videos on this thing are far better than they even are on my laptop, which is excellent.  I have yet to run into a buffer wait, and you can click on the full screen square on the video and that's another place where the very high resolution on the Fire wins the day.Rear camera takes outstanding photos and videos.  I mean, really good.  I exported them off the tablet and onto my laptop and they are crisp, clear, very accurate colors, really good.  The sound is beyond expectation.  I noticed that right away but I'm super aware of it in youtube tutorial videos I call in that are often created by women in other countries with heavy accents.  I was made particularly aware of the sound last night when I installed Netflix app and brought in an episode of Parenthood that I've seen on TV - I could hear background conversation more clearly than I could on TV.  The 4th Gen (2014) has even better sound (I compared the two in an electronics store side by side) but that's simply gravy on already outstanding potatoes and I didn't find myself envious of the difference, and I'm prone to that.And a word about Skype.  I'm crossing my fingers, arms, legs and eyes on this one, because the reviews on the Skype app are horrible.  I didn't expect to be able to Skype on it.  The first try, I did have delayed sound, but it cleared itself after a minute an it was in synch.  The second Skype call was to someone else and we had outstanding picture/sound quality and perfect synch.  So I may have gotten lucky, but my Skype is working really well from what I can tell so far.There is a bit of a learning curve, but Mayday is fast and convenient.  I cannot rave about the 3 Mayday experiences I've had, however, because they were not able to answer my questions without transferring me to someone more experienced; but they're good for basic stuff and quick answers and I may have gotten newbies to the job.  There's a minimalist, but adequate, tutorial and "owner's manual" (in quotes) if you hit the ? icon (help).  See those.  And why they don't make it more clear, I don't know, but a finger swipe from the left brings up that program's operating menu.  A finger swipe from the top brings down the Fire's operating menu.  Always.  That's the way it is on everything.  Just figuring out those two constants made everything else quicker to learn.All in all, I'd buy it again without a 2nd thought.  Definitely get into perspective the extra $50 or $100 for more storage because whatever you buy, you're gonna live with it.  Cloud does save the day on that, but I'd really rather not have to think about how much I'm loading onto my device.

Two stars because it's a pretty sturdy build so might make for a fun rake in granddaughter's sandbox.  However the teeth are sooo dull that it's absolutely useless as a back scratcher.  There's another one that I have three of already that works great!  Also telescoping, also purse-portable, it has 5 teeth instead of 7, looks like stainless steel (whether it is or not) and the slightly smaller head lacks nothing in being a far better back scratcher.  I recommend that one, hands down.

This crazy little wire coil works fantastically on electric coil burners.  Especially great when I'm dyeing yarns and roving in a thin (inexpensive) stainless kettle where I want temperature to get as close to boiling as possible but without any bubbling to felt the fiber.  In other words, that's quite a test.  It gives you temperature control.  Two come in the box.  It does not look like copper to me (dull metal silverish color) so I don't know what that's about, but it works great.  There's a heavier duty one in a zigzag design that I bought also for twice the cost and I don't like it as much.  Whatever you do, stay away from the solid plate diffusers with handle.  One of those bonded (as in melt!) to my red hot coil and I felt very lucky to be able to insert a spatula between them and that my very vintage stove top (no more parts available) wasn't ruined.  I use these a lot.

Having researched the heck out of electric teapots, I bought this specifically for fast boiling water for my low tech, inexpensive but extremely effective route to the best cup of coffee ever (Hario "Slim" Ceramic Burr coffee grinder + a "Ready Set Joe" single cup coffee filter holder).  My water comes to a rolling boil in 2 minutes, then the kettle snaps itself off with an audible click.  Not having to drag a cord attached to the pot lets me keep the corded base plate completely out of the way on my counter and if I wanted to store the pot separately I could store the base on its side against the wall without disturbing the cord's path between unit and wall. I specifically love that it's stainless interior.  Whole unit feels very solid and well-made. Good lid design lets you open the hinged top without steam burns.  This beats microwave or stovetop water heating hands down. (Instruction sheet says it is not meant for cooking eggs or any purpose other than boiling water, probably because it does snap itself off once water boils.) There are no negatives. If it died tomorrow, I would buy another one.

... they're just not shown first or even in bold print.  Instead, the Japanese/Chinese versions are given first and English follows in smaller print and it's easy to miss.  I think that might be a good sign because I was totally surprised at how good the quality is on this item.  (It's a Japanese product, but made in China.  That makes me wonder if many of the USA companies' outsourcing goes to the cheapest bidder because this Japanese company's product is not junk construction.)Things I love about it:*  Adjustable grind setting wheel does not require any disassembly and it has notched steps from the finest grind (almost powder) if set all the way clockwise until it stops, back to coarse, one click at a time, counterclockwise.  All settings that I tried (finest, at 5 clicks back from finest and at 11 clicks back from finest) were consistently ground without big chunks that fell through the cracks, and I got progressively coarser grounds, in other words, it works.*  Easy to grind!  Relatively.  I have "frozen shoulder" which is extremely painful, with limited mobility and I grind it with my bad arm as homeoopathic "physical therapy."  If it starts to hurt (no fault of the grinder) I can hold that arm still and swing the Hario instead, which means it's an easy grasp of the unit itself with a woman's hand.* Handle fits onto post with a solid click when it seats, no wobbling and it doesn't feel like its metal housing is made of cheap metal that would wear down and lose its grip over time, quite to the contrary.* Handle's groove lets you hang the whole handle off the top lip vertically for small footprint on the counter.* Base is not a cheap plastic either, but a good quality, see-through, perfectly clear, heavy-enough acrylic, with substance to it.  It looks like glass.  It has markers for 1-cup and 2-cups worth of ground coffee (each of which is a 2-Tbsp., standard coffee measure marker).  So it holds 4 Tbsp. (1/4C) of grounds total.  Maybe more.  Once you visually memorize how much coffee you like per cup, you can grind just that much, then stop.  It hurts nothing to keep additional beans in the hopper for next time, and unscrewing the base doesn't spill the beans because the clear acrylic lid snaps in solidly.  You can lie the top (grinding assembly) on its side while you place filters, etc. if you haven't already done that and the lid doesn't fall out.* The feed path from hopper to ceramic burr grinder mechanism is well designed so you don't have to keep giving the unit a shake or a tap to reposition them.  There are no hangups, they just feed through, and tilting it as you grind doesn't seem to matter either.Only Complaint:The black handle head is hollow, with an outer lip (probably for less weight when storing it on unit) which can be a tad uncomfortable if held against the flat of your palm, but this isn't a biggie at all.  I'm stretching to find a complaint at all.I love this little unit!  It takes me under a minute to grind 1 cup of coffee's worth but it's a smooth, easy operation that for some reason makes me appreciate the fresh coffee even more.  I expect I'll get years of use out of this unit and I'm really glad I bought it.One additional note:  Just in case I got lucky to have instructions that include English and yours doesn't, two important things, stated as such, are (1) don't rotate the handle counterclockwise; and (2) don't rotate it at all without beans going through the mechanism.  Otherwise, for taking it apart to clean, the little instruction sheet does have pictures so you could wing it without the text.  But do look closely because I had to in order to see the English instructions.

I can't believe a children's librarian would entitle a book "Me and..."  American grammar is under attack at best, and here we have a children's librarian just buying into it?  Next thing we'll be seeing is "John and I's relationship..." written by some English teacher.  Gaaa!

I'm converting to this percolator from the Presto 12-cup.  This one is also stainless (or appears to be) where it counts - on the inside, so it looks like it isn't going to be vulnerable to getting pitted from contact with the acidic nature of coffee.  The heating element's well is also covered with smooth stainless, therefore fully reachable for cleaning which is not the case with the Presto.I like the exterior water level indicator, but also just discovered that even the coffee basket has Tbsp. markers which could be convenient for some.  I have yet to see any coffee grounds in the coffee.  I buy beans in bulk and set grinder to "electric perk" but no filters seem to be needed, which I did use with the Presto.  Coffee stays at an ideal hot temperature and continues to remain non-bitter after several hours, and did remarkably well even with a small amount of coffee left in the pot (an unintended test).  I did taste a metallic tinge in the first 6 pots which was starting to become a deal breaker, but then I ran a stem brush through the inside of the stem with Dawn, which fixed it.  The only complaint I have which is minor and subjective is that the green "on" light indicator is ridiculously bright.  The good side of that, however, is that you're unlikely to leave it on when you shut off the lights to go to bed.  Exterior surface is brushed stainless and does not show fingerprints.  I've had it only a week, but by that time my Presto was already showing corrosion pitting on (and inside) the stem's well where the heating element is.I will come back and revise if anything changes, but I make multiple 6 or 8-cup pots of coffee all day long so a week for us is comparable to a lot longer time period for most households.  I've had a lot of coffee brewing/percolating machines, and this one is passing all my tests amazingly well.

I've been wearing Cuddl Duds for a long time and they've changed over the years.  Now they come in a zillion styles so you have to be very careful you're ordering what you think you are (e.g., "softwear" comes with stretch and a rayon/spandex based blend, and "with lace edging" comes in a blend of cotton (underside for warmth) and nylon (outerside for slide-y, non-bunching surface against your jeans or other pants).  The latter are what I'm writing about--the cotton/nylon blend.I recently bought a pair of these "Cuddl Duds Women's Softwear Lace Edge Legging" and just ordered a second through Amazon.  Here is info how to get the fit you want.1.  If the fit is right, out of the box, do not put them in your dryer.  Handwash and hang to dry.2.  If the fit is way bigger than you expected (they do now seem to run large), wear them to be sure you don't find you actually like them a little loose.  But if you don't, then machine wash and do put in the dryer.  They will shrink.  And I believe if you repeat, they might even shrink down more yet.  Now just be aware, if you machine dry them, when you first put them on, you might notice that the back (bum area) has snugged up along with the legs, but that the waist front comes up to your midriff.  (Awk???!)  Don't worry about it.  As soon as you wear them around and sit in them, the back stretches back out to accommodate your body and the front no longer seems long.  They do give, back toward (not necessarily fully to) their original size prior to what they were before machine drying them.  But I still think that repeated machine drying shrinks them down.I have a pair, same type, same fiber blend, same size, purchased 5 years ago that I repeatedly ran through the dryer.  They fit very snug.  That could be because of the dryer, or it could also be that in that 5 years the sizing has changed.  I suspect some of both because I don't recall them having been particularly loose, as these are, when I first got them.  I'm finding I actually prefer the looser fitting ones though.  They seem warmer to me when I'm outside, including in cold winds, and I like that they aren't cling'd right to my skin for all day wear.Regardless of how they fit, tight or loose, these are magical in that they definitely keep you enough warmer outside to earn their keep.  Yet at the same time, they're a thin fabric compared to any other leggings, e.g., "thermals".  Inside the house, however, you don't notice them at all, they are not hot feeling.  They don't show under clothing and they don't make your pants bunch up at the crotch like other thermals do because your pants slide right over them. Very highly recommended, specifically this style.  I don't know about the other fabric blends.

My planned use for context in comparison with your planned use:Two of 3 fans mounted near the ceiling, about 2-3 ft. to the left and right of my office wood stove, in hopes that the risen hot air could be urged (diagonally) across a 13'x15' room toward a doorway into the kitchen.  The 3rd would then be at the top corner of the office/kitchen doorway itself.  My fan mount placement has to be revised on the wood stove's side and I haven't yet mounted the doorway one.  Once I get it all tweaked, will revise review to include the effectiveness of this plan.  Meanwhile...Build:  Basically it's like a computer fan wrapped in a sturdy square black metal frame with a brown 11-ft. electrical cord that has an on-cord power switch about 2 ft. from the wall plug.  (If you don't like that placement, hardware stores do sell on/off switch pieces that you can pinch-clamp anywhere on a cord, which pierce little prongs through the cord for their contacts).  Sturdy housing, fan appears study also.  Note there is some weight to sturdy, so see "tilt" notes below.Mount:  Bracket screws onto wall w/provided screws.Tilt:  Fan bracket tilts up and down plus left to right.  No built in "stopper notches" in the tilt so that depending on your mounting plan, you may need to tinker via a well-positioned holding nail to keep the angle you want, but anything would be do-able, including mounting it onto a piece of 1x2 or 1x4 which, itself could be mounted to wall via a swing hinge.  In other words, its bi-directional tilt is handy alone or combined with what you fashion additionally.Noise:  Neither of the two that I have mounted are bothersome, they're steady white noise.  One is quieter than the other though, just so you know that noise can vary from unit to unit.Wind force:  Hard to describe, but here's my best shot:  If you wanted it to cool your face, you'd need to be (guessing) 3-4 ft. from it for a light breeze.  My thought for my heat displacing purpose was that, compared to the heat-driven fans that sit on top of wood stoves (that sell for over $110 and appear to reduce effectiveness over time), these would have significantly more air moving power and be able to be placed along ceiling where hot air gathers.  Once I tweak my placement better, will modify review to share what I find works.  I do think the one place I don't yet have one yet (doorway) might be key but we just haven't gotten to it yet.Conclusion:  Seeing them in person, I'm not disappointed in the quality at all.  Tilt angle stopper notches would have been helpful and a tad more power also, but given their small size I'm not sure they could be by much.

First, my broom isn't as pictured either - it's a black, square-headed broom and it works GREAT.  The handle screws into the broom head (not glued), by the way, just FYI.Meanwhile, these tools are fantastic for two things - cleaning out my wood stoves via their front door access and ash pans, and for tweaking along any fire you'd open your front doors to access.  Might also be great for side-door access but I can't speak to that.Details:  The broom head is only slightly wider than the shovel, which has a perfectly flat even floor so the shovel acts as a perfect dust pan for ashes you sweep up with the broom.  It's also an ideal width for getting around andirons for ash removal from stove interior.  The poker is a GEM.  A simple right angle turn without angles or curves, it gives you super control when tweaking the placement of kindling and beginning logs.  Also sturdy enough to lift big ones for readjustment.  The whole set is ideal for all tasks that are normally done without distance required, and I really appreciate not having to balance longer tools for that.  The handles are ergonomically comfortable with good grasp control, and all three tool handles loop readily over other fireplace tool holder stands which is what I do because I don't want 2 stands in the way, but the stand that comes with it is sturdy.  I do use my long poker for adjusting logs in fully established fires when loading through the top door, but anything I need to do through the front doors, I find these safer and way easier to handle.I ordered one set and liked it so much that I ordered a second for my other stove.

Okay, I ordered these before reading reviews, then did so after the fact.  So when they arrived I now expected them to be junk.  They barely had a chance to prove themselves because I already had it in for them -- I was going to hate them.Now I'm a woman so all fireplace gloves are one-size-fits all and these are as big as my Vermont Castings "serious" gloves, but at first these wanted to make my hands scoot out of them because after all, the lining side has a smooth surface instead of sheepskin.  And they're way lighter duty than my Vt. Castings ones.  So I was holding all that against them too.  At first.Well, I gotta say, I'm starting to really like these gloves!  No, you would not want to pick up a burning log with them, nor do I think you'd want to be dragged behind a car balancing the weight of your body on your hands. But with anywhere near normal wood stove/fireplace task use, I can't imagine how you'd get holes in them.  As for heat, one of my wood stoves has a steel damper control lever not brilliantly placed so the part you touch is super hot.  These work for that extremely well.  I've also pulled open my wood stove's left door with them (that's very hot).  No problem.  And I don't think I'd hesitate to remove a cast iron skillet out of the oven wearing them either, in fact I'm seeing pretty good kitchen glove potential because I do cook and bake with iron.  Just to test them though in that regard, my wood stove is currently at 450 degrees so I put my gloved hand on the top of it.  Sure enough, I was starting to feel heat after about 10 seconds.  But I just don't stand around leaning on my 450-degree wood stove.  I mean, why would you need longer than that to be holding your wood stove?What I'm really starting to like about them is what others don't.  They're not super thick.  Super thick means super stiff and no end clumbsy.  These are thick enough to be reasonably heat-protective but they're starting to conform to my hands and finger bend points even though they're typically big on me which I find terrific for handling firewood that has  splinters waiting to happen.If they started getting holes "from normal use" then I'll come back and update.  But I'm getting rather fond of these more flexible but still quite sturdy and plenty thick enough fireplace gloves.  (Do note I'm not calling them welding gloves.  That's because I don't see that word in their description, so for the people who are trying to bend them into welding glove expectations, I don't think it's a good idea.  And for those who say they picked up a piece of cast iron out of their ovens and could only hold it for 30-45 seconds... well, I can't speak to that.  I usually take mine out of the oven and set it on a cold burner or trivet.So conclusion?  I think they're really nice for handling splintery wood, for a reasonable length holding of pretty hot metal, and that the trade off of not getting to hold a 450-degree piece of iron for a fairly long time is that they quickly start conforming to your hands' bending points.  How thick?  They'd break any needle on my sewing machine and would not even come close to fitting under the feeder foot.

This is my first fabric shaver and I got it specifically for my own handknit sweaters, shawls, socks and other VERY "time-expensive" things that I knit. Now add that my yarns are far from cheap. In other words, I consider my hand knits to be a huge investment.The first time I used this shaver I had no problems but was cautious because of reviews that reported it creating holes.  I made a mental note to remain cautious but it seemed safe to me.  I just used it again on a sock (34,000 itty bitty stitches = 2+ weeks) and it felt a bit iffy, like it could snag and pull.  This is a harsher yarn with closer halo, so I barely touched the fabric, nervous the whole time.I stopped and took the thing apart.  Okay, do that so you can understand how this works (about the same as any shaver is going to work).  When you unscrew the cover with the holes, be VERY cautious because the blade wheel is right underneath it and it's meant to fall out.  Take it out, but put it on a towel, face down, out of the reach of people or animals. Handle carefully but examine it.  Those blades are mounted with flexibility, meaning they can rise closer to the holes or fall away from the holes.  Just note that.  Now slide off the lint door (dark one on the front of the unit - batteries are the other door).  See where and how the lint goes from blade area into that lint trap.  Mine had a TON of fuzz.  I removed it all, and blew it out with compressed air.  Also blew out the blade wheel.  Replaced door, replaced blade wheel and its cover, and shaved my fabric again.  Whoa!  Now it was a whole different world.  Whereas before I barely touched the fabric for fear it would snag, now I was able to press the face plate (holes) right onto the fabric.  And it did a GREAT job of shaving the halo and halo balls (a/k/a pilling).I'd still be careful with ANY fabric shaver, but I'm just saying the difference in my perceived danger of snagging with fuzz in the unit and no fuzz in the unit -- it was a dramatic difference.  If doing a whole sweater, I'd be cleaning it out, guessing 6 times or more, depending on the yarn's halo.  Being a spinner of yarns from raw fleeces also, I can tell you that wool fibers are strong AND fine.  Some have a staple length of several inches on up (longhair sheep = 7-8" fiber length).  The shaver cuts the fibers which is what you want.  But if those blades are forced outward (toward the guard plate with the holes) due to a wad of fuzz dust pushing it outward, those blades could pull rather than cut.I just love this little shaver, but having taken the thing apart completely and having seen how all this seems to work (key thing, that the blades are not frozen into their mount but can rise and sink), I just wanted to chime in with that info.

Disclaimer, I've only had it a day so will update if anything changes, but I bought this set for my second phone line, replacing a Uniden (whose proprietary and expensive handset batteries didn't last) so I'm familiar with Panasonic cordless.  These batteries are replaceable anywhere.This new set announces caller ID from the handset speakers, not the base, which is a HUGE advantage because the base can be in another room where you can't hear it anyway.  I haven't even cracked the manual but the answering machine and other functions are user friendly and intuitive.  Call blocking (which I have yet to read about) is a bonus.  The base itself has a surprisingly small footprint and can be hung on the wall.  Sound quality is excellent, volume control can be changed without interruptions or hassle (the up button on the center 4-way of each handset) and I couldn't be happier with it.My other Panasonic (same handsets except the new one has a sleek looking silver strip) gives me GREAT battery life between charges, and I expect this one will be the same -- can't ask for better than that.Another bigtime winner from Panasonic.  Not in love with their TVs' sound, but they make outstanding phones.I also bought their basic model headset (KX-TCA60). Never had a headset before.  OMG, died and gone to heaven?!  The other party can't tell you're using anything but the handset, its little mic can be offset below chin level so you can drink coffee without interference, walk around the house (handset in your pocket, cord attaching the two), make coffee, knit... completely hands free, great reception, fits comfortably and securely and doesn't hurt, in fact I forgot I had it on, and that little suckah will pay for itself in convenience.  It actually already has.  It has a clip on the cord if you want to secure it to your clothing or whatever.  Mine has to be pushed into the handset securely and not wiggled a lot or I get a blip of staticky "connect me better" sound, but that's not a big deal, I just see that it is.Very, very happy with this phone.  I'll update this if there's anything to pick apart on it as time goes on but it's just a little sweetheart at a really fair price.

I love the way it works, I love the way you can scrape out the garlic with no mess, I love the way it looks and particularly love the way it stores.  And it washes clean with minimal hassle.  And no garlic smell on my fingers.  Really an efficient way to go compared to a bulky garlic press.  Had I seen this little unit prior to getting my daughter a press, I'd have gotten this one instead for her too.  Somehow it didn't come up on search at the time, but I'd highly recommend this little rocker, it works great.

Great for hanging a recipe card off a cabinet knob to get it at eye level and not taking up counter space, also really good for intended purpose - clipping to pan edge.  I had no problem with round or flat spoons, it held all handle shapes that I tried.

Meh.  Okay, they're good for cookie sheets and would also seem ideal for when a cloth hot pad would flop into the sauce.  (Keyword "seem.")  The problem is that these are super slippery if even a drop of sauce or grease gets on the inside and it tends to, really easily.  The traction ridges on the inside just aren't enough to override how slippery the silicone material itself gets, and the material is stiff so there's not enough grip.  I really wanted to love these because of their size, but after using them a couple of times, I just kept feeling that they were a dropped casserole waiting to happen, with hot gooey contents clinging to my leg, foot, or ten times worse, atop a child passing by.  For that reason, interesting design intentions aside, I just don't see these as having secure enough grip potential.

Good for blending dry ingredients, mixing, stirring, blending AND lifting.  I do a lot of crockpot cooking and at the end, I often want to remove all but liquid so I can thicken sauce/gravy.  This one tool is what I reach for.  My original impression was that the tines were flexible, not so.  It's like a slotted spoon.  A second one is on my wish list for next order.

Just be aware that the three larger bottle brushes are made of very soft bristles.  Probably good for baby bottles that are washed before leaving a residue, but not up to any serious cleaning jobs.  They might be very good for something that's delicate or scratches easily as long as you could keep the metal stem out of the picture.  The smaller tube brushes are fine and one or two of them are the right size to fit inside the stem on a percolator coffee pot (one is too big and I almost got it stuck inside).

I LOVE this little cooker!  I've been using it daily since it arrived and I've even taken it for a car ride (that handy elasticized keeper is unbelievably handy if it tilts).  I can't say enough great things about it, including that it holds more than you'd think and that the oval shape on this size cooker is a HUGE advantage.  And in today's world of crappy quality and ill-conceived design, it's surprisingly excellent on both counts.First, info I couldn't find online anywhere (and if you have a camper or boat, this is particularly a good unit for you)...INTERIOR DIMENSIONS:Measured at the (oval) crock's floor, it's 6" long at longest point x 4.5" wide at widest point x 3.25" tall from floor to inside of rim (max useable cooking height).EXTERIOR (FOOTPRINT):At the widest/longest points, approx. 8.25" long x 7" wide x 7" tall.  This does not include handles or slightly domed lid.  ***FOR THOSE WITH A BOAT OR CAMPER***This shape fits into smaller, tighter spaces AND (mwaaa-hahaha) that little elasticized lid securing device which is included for travel?  It would be great for your kind of storage options because stuff gets wedged in and this is a glass lid and it isn't even possible to slide or get bumped off with that elastic thing in place.)OTHERWISE:- No power light (few this size have them) which is the ONLY thing I can criticize.- Knob dial feels solid and seats well onto the settings (warm, low and high) without floppy play, and not tinny feeling.- Cord is substantial in heft (does not scare you in other words) but short (24" from unit to prongs).- Plastic molded feet can slide on counter but most can and they're not particularly slippery.  You COULD add self-stick rubber feet, small ones.- Glass lid has stay-cool knob handle and it sits on a black rubber gasket around rim (the only one I've seen that has this), and creates a gap-free fit as it heats up.  But there are also 3 very thoughtfully designed groved indents in the crock's rim, and though condesation happens on any crockpot's lid, the gasket and groove combo prevents unexpected hot drips when you remove the lid.- Carry handles (on the base unit) are solid feeling and stick out farther than the crock insert's handles so you're less inclined to grab just the crock insert if moving it.  And you don't need mitts.- Elasticized keeper that's thoughtfully included for transport ALSO fits securely into a groove on the underside of the base's handles which keeps it off hot exterior and keeps it from slipping around (or off).  This thing was well designed.CAPACITY:Holds a solid 6 cups with a teense to spare before the rim.  In other words, pushing it, you do get a "useable" 6 cups cookable contents.  (My round 1.5-qt. holds less so "useable" volume is more like 5.5 cups, maybe a tad less, and the 2-qt. Rival that I'm returning has a full 1.5" of the crock that sticks up above the base unit, making it absolutely unuseable space, thereby a larger unit that STILL really only has 1.5-qt. useable cooking volume.)TEMPERATURES:Definitely seem right on target, as I've made these recipes before in another crockpot.  High WILL get you a simmering bubble but not an outright boil.  Low seems to be just a smidge below the simmering point, as it should be.OVAL SHAPE:This is my first oval crockpot and I did NOT expect to find oval on a little one.  I am now sold on oval shape.  You can fit a larger single item or 2 smaller ones side by side on the floor of it, there's more stirring and contents movement room.  As for storage, again I'll say, the oval shape is not only easier to fit into narrower places, but more ergonomically friendly to slide in and out of places.HINT:  If you want to peek but not lift the lid on any glass or clear plastic crockpot lid (which extends your cooking time by 15 min.), all crockpots form condensation on the lid, clouding it so you can't see much detail through the clouding.  Rather than lifting the lid, give it a firm, quick jiggle (in place).  Somewhere on the lid, the condensation will form into a droplet and slide down, making for a see-through place.  If not good lighting, use a little flashlight and you will get a really good view of the contents without letting any heat out.

I LOVE this little cooker!  I've been using it daily since it arrived and I've even taken it for a car ride (that handy elasticized keeper is unbelievably handy if it tilts).  I can't say enough great things about it, including that it holds more than you'd think and that the oval shape on this size cooker is a HUGE advantage.  And in today's world of crappy quality and ill-conceived design, it's surprisingly excellent on both counts.First, info I couldn't find online anywhere (and if you have a camper or boat, this is particularly a good unit for you)...INTERIOR DIMENSIONS:Measured at the (oval) crock's floor, it's 6" long at center x 4.5" wide at center x 3.25" tall from floor to inside of rim (max useable cooking height).  The top of the interior, measured there, is 7" long, 5.75" wide."USEABLE" CAPACITY:Holds a solid 6 cups of water which means on any foods that expand (hot cereals, legumes) you'd fill it less and it can expand to that.  On foods that shrink (e.g., green beans, most meats), you could fill it almost to the rim because as soon as it heats and begins cooking, it'll lower itself.  I also noted that on the 2-qt. Rival (which I'm returning), a whopping 1.25+ inch of the interior crock sticks completely above the base unit, making it useless for cooking capacity so nothing about that one is 2 qt. but it takes up more footprint space.  In my humble opinion, it's a good size for two people -- sometimes with leftovers, sometimes not depending on what you're cooking.  If you are 2 and want a fair bit of leftovers OR want the flexibility to make a main course for 3-4 people, the same unit comes in 3-qt. but I'm not sure if it includes the lid keeper band or not.EXTERIOR (FOOTPRINT):At the widest/longest points, approx. 8.25" long x 7" wide x 7" tall.  This does not include handles or slightly domed lid.  ***FOR THOSE WITH A BOAT OR CAMPER***This oval shape fits into smaller, tighter spaces AND (mwaaa-hahaha) that little elasticized lid securing band would be great for your kind of storage options where stuff gets wedged in, and ideally not always upright.  It holds the glass lid in place firmly, no slip-slide.OTHERWISE:- No power light (few this size have them) which is the ONLY thing I can criticize.- Knob dial feels solid and seats well onto the settings (warm, low and high) without floppy play, and not tinny feeling.- Cord is substantial in heft (does not scare you in other words) but short--24" from unit to prongs.- Plastic bubble-molded feet can slide on counter as most can but they're not particularly slippery.- Glass lid has stay-cool knob handle and it sits on a black rubber gasket around rim (the only one I've seen that has this), and creates a gap-free, snug fit as it heats up.  There are also 3 very thoughtfully designed groved indents in the crock's rim, and though condesation happens on any crockpot's lid, the gasket and groove combo prevents unexpected hot drips when you remove the lid.- Carry handles (on the base unit) are solid feeling and stick out farther than the crock insert's handles so you're less inclined to grab just the crock insert if moving it.  And you don't need mitts.- Elasticized keeper band that's thoughtfully included for transport ALSO fits securely into a groove on the underside of the base's handles which keeps band off hot exterior and keeps it from slipping around, or off.  This thing was well designed.TEMPERATURES:Definitely seem right on target, as I've made these recipes before in another crockpot.  High WILL get you a good simmering bubbling but not an outright boil.  Low seems to be at or just a smidge below the simmering point, as it should be.OVAL SHAPE:This is my first oval crockpot and I did NOT expect to find oval on a little one.  I am now sold on oval shape.  You can fit a larger single item or 2 smaller ones (e.g., stuffed peppers) side by side on the floor of it and with oval, there's more stirring room.  As for storage, again I'll say, the oval shape is not only easier to fit into narrower places, but more ergonomically friendly for sliding it in and out of storage places.HINT:  If you want to peek but not lift the lid on any glass or clear plastic crockpot lid (which extends your cooking time by 15-20 min.), all crockpots form condensation on the lid, clouding it so you can't see much detail through the clouding.  Rather than lifting the lid, give it a firm, quick jiggle (in place).  Somewhere on the lid, the condensation will form into a droplet and slide down, making for a see-through place.  If not good lighting, use a little flashlight and you will get a really good view of the contents without letting any heat out.

I'm an avid coffee drinker.  And after 15+ years of the highly-convenient drip Bunn (which I've sworn by specifically because it keeps a reservoir of water hot all the time so coffee's done in 3 minutes), I stumbled upon a thumbnail of the Presto Electric Percolator which I'd originally come to think of as old fashioned and outdated in convenience.  But it's what I grew up with.  LOTS of reviews.  And almost all of them, stellar.  The ones that got to me though were "full bodied" and especially "smell the coffee."  And then there were mentions that it keeps the coffee perfectly hot and a long, long time before it starts to taste burnt.I ordered one, and it truly feels like I've come back home.  The taste is a WORLD better.  The smell of coffee fills the house.  It's way more hassle than the Bunn (filter discussion follows) but it's just sooo worth it.  And it takes a lot less counterspace.  I am back in coffee lover's heaven.FILTERS:  I never used them when I had a percolator before (isn't the basket the filter?) but I've read a number of reasons why they're a good idea, and I made a pot without, and a pot with.  I liked with.  Taste and also cleanup, and then the nagging thing about whatever it filters out which I don't recall, but google it if you have concerns.The square filters (sample pack comes in the box) with the pre-punched holes are ridiculously expensive.  About 10 cents each which, in my case, would add up fast because I make 6-cup pots rather than 12's just because I like it freshly made.  But it so happens that the floor of the commonly-available unbleached, round basket filters fit PERFECTLY into the floor of the 12-cup basket.  And they go up the sides to right where this coffee pot's filter cover lands.  I mean, a perfect fit.  To cut the center hole, I take 5 or so filters at a time, and gently fold them in half, then in half again.  That gives you dead center.  (And if you fold carefully, you'll keep the convenient shape they come in.)  Just snip off the teensiest corner--like about 1/16th of an inch because it will quadruple in size when unfolded.  After a couple of times, you'll get the hang of curved snipping so it's a perfect fit over the basket's center post with no gaps.  (Yes, this is a TAD of extra hassle, but we've all gotten an awfully low threshold for what we consider hassle.)  These filters cost 01 cent vs. 10 cents each.The only claim Presto makes that I don't find true on mine is 1 minute per cup.  Mine took 8 minutes for 2 cups and it takes 8 minutes for 6 cups.  Pfffft.  Not an issue when the quality of the coffee is this outstanding, but I'm just mentioning it in case that's a biggie for someone reading this.So while Bunn has been a WONDERFUL company, with their 3-year warranty (whereupon they will totally replace your coffee pot at no charge if anything wears out), and they're one of the few companies where you can readily talk to a human, and one who speaks English, I have no choice but to convert.Now an Off Topic addition, and I don't work for Amazon - no affiliation, but this suggests you consider buying one accessory because I LOVE mine.  A long handled coffee scoop.  I bought the Norpro (there are others) but this little sucker is just wonderful.  2 Tbsp. exactly (one scooper per 2 cups) and I can get 1 tbsp. by tilting my coffee jar (contents level) and pushing this in halfway.  The edge comes out vertical, so it's pretty darned exact.  But I keep my coffee in a 1-qt. mason jar and the long handle goes all the way to the bottom (or if you buy your coffee in bags, same thing).  Solid stainless, really great feel with great heft and a hole at the end so you can hang it.  (Makes a great ladle also).  Just saying.  So here 'tis.  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000SSVGIY/ref=oh_details_o03_s01_i00.  Note that packaging MAY say 1 Tbsp. but it's two, and says so on the back of the handle.  Short handled coffee measure are a pain after using one of these.I give this Presto 12-cup percolator the highest of ratings.  It makes great coffee and it keeps it at a perfect temperature.  It has a small footprint, a substantial enough cord (though not as solid a connector as they used to be before China makes everything but that's replaceable if need be).  It's just a really good, good cup of coffee.  Me very happy camper.

First, what I bought says Rival but the company on the side of it says "Crockpot" so I think it's the same thing, because when I typed in my model number, this is what came up.  The photo also looks exactly like mine, down to the nth degree.  So I'm proceeding with that in mind.  And since I'm expanding my crop of crocks to buy a 2nd one in this size, I'm including the info that I couldn't find:CROCK'S INTERIOR dimensions:4-1/2" wide at the bottom, 5-1/2" wide at the top, 3-1/2" deep (which takes you to just a gnat's knee under where the lid sits, so figure 3.25" deep).Tradeoff with this unit:  You don't have high/low/keep warm but this one has THE smallest footprint of any 1.5-qt. crockpot out there, and the base unit goes all the way to the top of the crock (almost) so you do get full use of the available interior.  (They say not to fill a crockpot to the rim but some foods expand, others shrink, so just use forethought because ones that shrink are fine).CORD is substantial and thick enough not to be scary, and 36" long (good or bad depending on how you look at it).SURROUND HEATING ELEMENTS AND HOT SPOTS:  A hotter spot does exist on slow cookers, period.  A workaround is to put a tin foil "liner" section around the hot side which the food holds against the wall. (almost always it's the side opposite the controls but since this one has no controls, it's probably the side where plug is - has not been an issue for me, but just saying).  This hasn't been a problem for me, but if making oatmeal or whatever, you can also butter the sides of the crock which helps.ROCKING LID SYNDROME:  Yup, the lid (sometimes) will rock as it's cooking.  Not always.  It doesn't bother me.  Apparently some models have gaskets now, but they never have in the past and I've always thought that was on purpose.  (I'm still not sure a gasket for a tight fitting lid is a plus or a minus on a crockpot.)DESIGN:  Glass for the see through lid, plastic knob.  Straight sided, small footprint (7-1/2" base, 8-3/4" higher up because of crock's nobs).  Removeable crock (imperative!)COOKS FAST OR RUNS HOT??  Today's slow cookers ALL run a little hotter than the original 1970s pots, and for good reason.  Food safety.  Also many recipes (even on the older ones) overstate the cooking times.  Not all, but many.I have two little crockpots, this one and the Proctor Silex Oval 1.5-qt.  I prefer this one for smaller quantities (veggies, rice) simply because it has a smaller floor area and smaller footprint. Cute lil' thang.

At 18 years old, without motivation or direction, author Tania's highly adventuresome father gave her a choice upon her high school years drawing to a close - she could either go to college or take a 26-foot sailboat around the world.  By herself!  She had some writing talent so he thought the experience would give her no end of subject matter to launch a writing career, and though intimidated by the idea, she chose the boat.  And the commitment.  Tania is a really good writer.  There were so many times when these pages brought me right there with her, from the day she left New York filled with totally understandable fears until the end. We meet lots of people through her travels and get an idea of what such an experience would be like.  Though there are a lot of technical sailing/boat/navigation references as she runs into various scenarios, you don't need to know a thing about them to enjoy being taken along with her through storms, doldrums, mishaps and joys.  This was a really good book, I was sad to reach the last page because I enjoyed reading it so much.
Ended too soon for me. I can't wait until the Part 2 release.
Product works well after several weeks of use.

There are so many ideas on managing clients and staff available in this series. As an editor for a technical journal, I think I'll extract a few for my column.I especially liked the episode where Draper threw out Jansen, a client who wanted to sell bikinis but not show skin. Don called them prudes and idiots! I wish more engineering firms understood that the client-firm relationship is very delicate: it requires patience and honesty on both sides. Many a time, I have wanted to fire the client; instead, we build the process and it was either a nightmare of corrections or a product that limped out the door.As drama, the series is excellent. Draper and company could have been my father and grandfather. These were tough men who didn't talk about their feelings, at least not in public. It was nobody's business.Season 4 starts up where Season 3 left off. The only Season that is a little iffy is Season 1, in which the actors were still exploring their roles. We saw the same thing in Breaking Bad and House. By Season 2 Mad Men had a clear message and direction.You should stack Mad Men in the shelf with Breaking Bad and House, MD and entertain yourself and your family for decades to come.If this review was helpful, add your vote.

Does not come with screws.I went with four #10 1-1/2" (US standard) premium wood screws with washers for less rattling; #12 screws that would fit; I had #10s handy. If you mount on studs, then you will need a 1/4" drill bit in about 1" for the pilot. Use a stud finder you can trust and check the drill for sawdust. If it comes back with only drywall, then you're on to plan B.Plan B involves plastic anchors into dry wall. You will want the simple kind since they will support 67 lbs. each. Unless you're using the rack for mountain climbing, 67 lbs. will support all the pots and pans you can hang on the wall. Drill the hole size with 1/4" pilot drill bit; there are different types of bits so makes sure you have a set of pilot bits. Make the hole level, i.e., perpendicular to the wall (right angle). drill one of the top ones first, then swing the rack out of the way and set the next anchors: set by drilling the 1/4" pilot hole and gently pounding the anchor into the hole with a hammer. You have to set the anchors if its into dry wall before you set the screws! I used a level, a head lamp because the rack fits into a very tight space; the drill barely fit. Once you set the anchors, use an electric screw driver to drive the screws once you have the screws in a couple of turns.Check the level when you drill the holes for the anchors.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.
Worked as expected. I bought 2 clips because the pot rack comes with four. Six turns out to be the right number of clips for the rack.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.
Great movie! It introduces you to the smug world or wall street. The acting was superb.

This was a great clock until the battery fell out. I owned it for about 6 months. It survived one relocation and was ticking loudly in my bathroom. I was using it as my main alarm next to my bed.Pros: bright luminescent dial --- easy to read at night; loud alarm.Cons: poor time piece --- lost about a minute a week; battery fell out and the backing disappeared --- battery clip apparently was poorly made.Seiko should take their name off this clock or fix it's flaws>If this review was helpful please add your vote.

For the price, it is excellent. The kit is complete with combs and clipper attachments. It even comes with oil for cleaning the blades. I've only used it once and it did a first rate job. You can get some good advice from You Tube on how to cut properly. I followed the advice, used a no. 3 for the first cut and a number 2 for the final cut. It even does eyebrows --- use the comb without a clipper attachment. I left the top alone and only did the sides and back. I go back every other haircut to a professional so I can cover up my mistakes.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.
Charges much faster than other, older chargers with lower current flow.
A classic. Although the picture is a little grainy on a HD LCD this movie is worth having. I especially enjoyed the flying scenes.
Solid cup and will enjoy using it.

Best hub on the market. There are two 3 USB speed ports for high speed and five ordinary, 2 USB speed ports on the other side. I've used this hub for a month and it performs well. It is solidly built and the plugs are less prone to bending than competitor models.if this review was helpful, please add your vote.

I bought this Garmin to replace a faulty predecessor that reset itself constantly --- once or twice a trip in the beginning and finally a dozen times during a 15 mile trip.The performance is superior to its predecessor. The programming is easier but it has some gliches. For example, if you want to store a location in memory you have to use save home then change the name to suit. The Garmin still resets itself. It is unnerving to be driving down an unfamiliar highway and lose your map for a minute. I've missed several turns this way. I've learned to keep the Garmin charged initially to get me started. Another tip is to remember the details of the next turn so that I won't get lost if Garmin resets. I had the predecessor for almost 2 years.The reason I docked a star is because the nuvi 2597 frequently gets lost in the small town I work in: Marshfield, Wisconsin. It got me to the store I was headed for but not by the most efficient route. Then, when I found the route the Garmin decided we were lost: the infamous (?).On the trip here from Ohio the nuvi 2597 performed well. I think there were only two resets during the entire trip.Update: 8 30 15: the 2597 performs well except for a few flaws that have carried on from past models:1. The 2597 often misses the exit on highways because it is slow ---- if you listen to the advice a mile or two before you will get what your missing --- it's just unnerving to be told to turn when I can't because I'm passing the exit.2. Sometimes, it leads me to a place that doesn't exist. I update the GPS every few months.3. The voice actuation is awful. I have found it easiest to spell out the name but it still mis-interprets. This has been a flaw since 2012.Please add your vote if this review was helpful.

Right price, solidly built, and has the range. I used it to spray chemicals about 20 ft, at a 45 degree angle. The one shortcoming is the low capacity. I reloaded 3 times to cover a roof about 60 ft long by 25 ft.I used the sprayer to add wet and go to a roof to handle moss.I intend to use the sprayer again next spring.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.

Laptop performs well. The screen is adequate. The keyboard has good play, not as good as my old Pavilion dv7-6b55dx but close enough. The Pavilion is very fast. The Envy requires a little more concentration to move as fast. The Envy is compact and Win-8 is easy to learn and has a few advantages over Win-7 after a little practice. Win-7 was more cluttered.The CD player runs smoothly. I should note that the first version of this Envy did not come with a CD player but I replaced it easily with a $30 investment. You will need the CD for some software. The CD player is noisy in the Envy.The first version of this laptop that I received, died 10 days later. It could not communicate by wifi or wire to the modem. The seller sent a replacement very quickly and the replacement works well as my back-up laptop.This machine runs a little hot because of engineering limits that are becoming worse with each generation of faster air-cooled CPUs. I suggest buying a cooling pad; I bought a Xpad4Laptop, available on this site.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.Update, 10 12 15It would help if the touch pad could be completely neutralized. I tried uninstalling it from device manager (control panel) but was only partially successful. It comes back to life every time the computer starts up. I gave this book 5 stars because it is an excellent idea. However, to properly cover the world would take several volumes like the Durants did it with their epic series on history.  Will and Ariel Durant wrote a series on world history entitled “The Story of Civilization.” ''Rousseau and Revolution,'' a book in that series, won the Pulitzer Prize. “A People’s is not of this caliber.With that said, I will say that the book was enlightening. As with Zinn’s People’s History of the United States, Harman manages to unearth history not covered, or covered badly, by American textbooks on history. Harman pulls together certain facts on the fall of the Roman republic:“Slave labour led to the impoverishment of free labour ….”“Brunt relates how ‘the poor could not afford to marry and, if married, to raise children. Families were limited by abortion and infanticide, if not by contraception.’ Many children abandoned by poor parents would end up in the slave markets.’‘The leading families used their political control to increase their already substantial landholdings at the expense of the peasantry, pushing them into debt, taking their land and relying on the judges to find in favour of the Patricians.’Eventually, the Patricians, represented in the Senate, were forced to allow nomination of Tribunes to protect the Plebeians from the magistrates (judges) (who were in the hands of the Patricians.Two such tribunes, Tiberius Gracchus and his brother Gaius, who were too troublesome for the Senate ---- because they were active in their support of the poor --- were murdered by the Patricians. Eventually, this class warfare resolved itself by nomination of the Czar. The role of the Czar was to assure the power of Patricians who had begun to fight among themselves.In American history text books, the Gracchus brothers are described as transferrers of wealth. Definitely a capitalist perspective. I’m surprised they didn’t smear them in red by confusing communism with socialism.A good read, if you poke through a chapter at random, as I did. I will keep this book on my shelf with hopes that the author writes an improved second edition.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.

The argument Robert Reich puts forward is well-founded. French economist, Thomas Piketty, recently all but proved it based on French tax records dating back 150 years: economics melt down when the rich lock away money in capital gains. However, this book fails, as so many do, to deliver solid, workable ideas for dealing with the problems.One of Reich's ideas, "higher marginal tax rates on the wealthy," is an excellent idea but ignores the barb wire, i.e., all the defensive protections banks and governments have conspired to create to help the rich hide there money. Let's start there, instead of introducing another tired plan of taxing the rich. I would suggest employing an NSA-type spy agency solely for collecting taxes from the rich.Another idea is the "re-employment system rather than an unemployment system." This is a grand idea but like so many ideas there is no detail on how this could work in a modern society.Another vague dream is the old re-training idea. I have a relative who worked in an automotive plant. He was trained to repair robots until even that job went away a few years later. Have you ever looked at what jobs are hot? The high school councilors nearly always get their information wrong or too late. For this to work, you need companies training people to do real jobs. That's how it works in Europe, especially in Germany.As I said, a good read until Reich gets to the nuts and bolts.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.

Sometimes a two-man job.First, the tools. It helps if you have metric sockets and a wrench, though you can substitute imperial sockets.Second, you will need spanners as well as sockets. These are required for a tight fit.Third, you will need to bore out some of the holes.Fourth, and most important: plan a trip to the store for some spare parts. During the assembly a nut and a carriage bolt were not tapped correctly and took significant effort to disassemble.Fifth, some components were faulty. The front strut, item G, was not bent correctly. I couldn’t get both G struts to fit with the 13 mm wrenches. Instead, I built one as shown in the instructions, anchored the second strut with a 13 mm bolt and nut and went to the hardware store for a -inch replacement: ¼-in. bolt, washer and lock nut (AKA stop nut) and 0.375-in. washer to mate up to the ¼-in. washer for support. The 1/4"-in. washer allowed me to attach the G strut and even bend it into place at the yoke (H part).Sixth, the C components are a little tricky. The drawing was deceptive: the orientation is opposite of as shown in the drawings. The flat side should face towards the rear axial so that the bolt hole above lines up correctly.Word to the wise, don’t tighten anything down until they tell you to in the instructions: every nut is a lock nut in project. If you get it wrong you will have to apply great force to disassemble. My approach is to put everything together in my hands to see how it fits, then test the tools to make sure I have the right sockets and such, then inspect the bolts and then finally do the assembly.Assembly consists of three challenging sections: 1) assembly of the front section of the chassis; 2) assembly of the rear section of the chassis; and 3) attachment of the bucket (called the tray) to the rear section of the chassis. The third section is the most challenging.This third section in the assembly requires two people. Worst still, you will want to duct-tape the rear axial assembly (E) to the rear frame (D) during the assembly of the rear section; the instructions seem overly concerned that you will misalign the rear frame and put it together backwards when its already stamped “Front” and “Back.” This third section, attachment of the bucket with 6-13 mm carriage bolts, requires that the bolts go through the tray to the rear frame. I had some hold the bucket up, put in the center bolt and I quickly screwed it down with a socket wrench while they held the carriage bolt in place with a screwdriver: do the middle front one first to hold the rear chassis to the bucket (tray). Then do the other two. During this part of the operation, one of the nuts failed; another trip to the hardware store provided sufficient spares, though I could only get hex head bolts. I chose 5/16-in. hex heads 1-1/2-in. long to substitute because the ones provided were a little shorter than I liked. After getting the first bolt in it was possible to do the work myself, alone.After this step, the assembly was all downhill.The cart is a little heavy for my mother, a 78-year old but it will carry the weight. Altogether, I spent 5-hours to assemble the cart.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.

Remember that PBS show from the 70’s, “Connections,” that is modus operandi for this book. Gavin Weightman writes about the real inventors, and often the real inventor(s) --- plural.Did you know that Robert Fulton did not invent the steamboat, nor did he invent a functional torpedo for the British navy or anything else? Robert Fulton is an example of a great idea man and promoter, which many of the inventors are who you will find in the history books.Did you know that Orville and Wilbur Wright, the inventors of the first workable air plane, were terrible businessmen? Their first airplane had a number of mechanical faults, which others like Glenn Curtiss eliminated. One such flaw was an aileron that was operated by twisting the wing the way a bird flies. Ailerons are the flaps at the back edge of an airplane. Glenn Curtiss invented the modern flap as a lever as seen in today’s aircraft. The Wright brothers sued Curtiss for patent infringement. In fact, rather than spending their time inventing better aircraft as Curtiss did, the brothers literally spent their last dime defending the patents on their old, faulty design.Getting back to the title about the inventor of the cotton gin, I’ll start in the beginning. Nathanael Greene invited Phineas Miller from Connecticut to teach his children in South Carolina. Phineas Miller helped Eli Whitney come south to tutor as well. Whitney and Miller worked in secret with others in New Haven. Somehow, the word got out, the planters found a way to copy their design and then set about to destroy their reputations. One such story spread by planters was that “Whitney’s deseeding gin tore the cotton. Needless to say Whitney wins only a historical reference; Miller got nothing.Difficult to follow at times for its twists and turns, this book is worth the time.If this review was helpful, please add your vote.

Summary review:Pros:1. Goes where no vacuum has gone before.2. Extremely good HEPA filtration, far superior to most conventional vacuums on pet fur,dust, etc..3. Will untangle itself from most wiring and even traps under furniture.4. Will, with some difficulty, clean moderately thick shag rugs and carpet.Cons:1. Does not like loose throw rugs.2. Will still chew up tassles on rugs.3. Can find its way under furniture and become trapped: this happened twice ---- once with a couch and a second time with a lazy boy.I noticed no reluctance with dark carpeting and an ability to figure out how to unstick itself. It is best to de-Roomba the area first after running and watching the robot vacuum an area for 3-4 times. I used duct tape to put wires together so the Roomba could only push the bundle around without getting trapped in it. I stuck a board in under the lazy boy to keep it out of there. I also moved a chair away to allow the Roomba clear access to vacuum under a kitchen table while I am away. I have my mother running the Roomba once a week.Descriptive reviewI ran the Roomba through the downstairs and then took it upstairs where things are more challenging. Downstairs I have tile floor, thin carpet, a thick Persian rug in three rooms and a hallway. Right of the box, the Roomba darted for my office, which I thought was pecular. I let it work in there and then five minutes later it was in the hallway and then it zipped across to the kitchen/laundry room area. I was skeptical, at first, until I opened the dust bin. It was packed. Shortly after that it went back to the charger because it was operating with only partial charge: run time about an hour. I let it rest all night in its bat cave, i.e., a corner next to my futon/bed. The next morning, I let it run through its paces first thing in the morning; this time I used the virtual walls to focus only on the den where the futon is; otherwise, known as man-cave. After about a half hour I took it upstairs after emptying the bin. Previously, the night before I locked the Roomba in the office where it did a good job and avoided all the loose wires.I moved it upstairs; robots don't climb stair yet. It did the kitchen (tile + another Persian rug) and it seemed to need guidance. I used the remote control to drive it to one side of the kitchen that my mother wanted done more effectively and then I set the Roomba on "spot" so it cleaned more effectively. You can use the remote or the buttons on top of the Roomba. I had the virtual walls set up to block it into the kitchen.I wanted to see it run on shag so I directed the Roomba through my mother's office. It did fine but I could tell I was pushing it a bit. Through the office to the hard floors in the bedroom/bath hallway. I turned it loose in my mother's bedroom where it searched under the bed, just like my sisters would -- oh, looking for dust. It cleaned the whole room but tried to pull out the tassles in her rug.Next, we moved on to the living room with wood floors and a thin area rug. The Roomba did well until it got stuck under a couch and had to be pulled free. That's the only time it got stuck. It went straight back in and this time avoided getting stuck but did thoroughly clean under the couch. The living room was thoroughly clean of dust and cat hair in about an hour; the kitchen about 40 minutes. I took it downstairs to recharge. This house has about 1,000 feet upstairs --- the Roomba did about 75% of it, excluding most of the office and the second bedroom. It cleaned one narrow bathroom in about 5 minutes.Now, the bad news; the Roomba won't completely replace your vacuum: not enough power. Like the vacuum though, it also won't pick up pebble-sized clumps, anything wet, or oddly paper punch holes. These are impervious to vacuums everywhere.The Roomba, though it has many escape algorithms and figures out how to get away from small throw rugs, even those with tassles, don't expect these to get clean from a Roomba or even an ordinary vacuum. The Roomba also has trouble cleaning transitions say between a tile floor and carpeting. I found stuff behind that it couldn't get. It does transition well between the two, changing the vacuum mode but it's as though the debris an inch or so away from the transition is in a protective shadow.The Roomba is a great supplement to a vacuum and compliment. I've never had a vacuum go straight under a bed and clean every corner --- that's mechanically impossible. If you buy one of these, you will get more pet hair and dust out of your life but you will still have to vacuum periodically to get the big stuff. I am happy with it and plan to use it to supplement vacuuming every week or so.

Excellent burner! I cooked a spaghetti meal on this burner in an hour. A stove would have taken a little less time but I have no room for one in my apartment. The only complaint is a burnt plastic smell from a coating on the burner. Hopefully, this will disappear after a few more days.I use the burner periodically when I am home from business trips. So far, after using the burner approximately 20 times over the past 8 months, I have found that the burner performs well. The plastic smell went away after about half a dozen uses. Seldom do I use the 5 setting. For eggs, 1 is sufficient. For preparation of a casserole a 2-3 is sufficient.This burner sits on an insulated thermal sheet (SS cover with insulation sandwiched between.) on top of my microwave, which is on a cart. This is a very compact kitchen arrangement that works well for me.

Best all-in-one I ever owned!As a long-term HP fan I’ve lived with the idea that printers and scanners are only supposed to last a year or so: I was wrong. I bought an Epson 3540 to replace an HP all-in-one that lasted less than a year and simply wasn’t up to the task at hand. I was scanning pages of my library to reduce it to accessible PDFs. I am a consulting engineer so knowledge at my fingertips is appealing. The Epson cut through thousands of old articles, engineering notes, memos, brochures, calculations. I literally filled two carefully-packed leaf bags five feet high. The Epson is a little worn out but still functional.Pros:*  Fast printing;*  Clear scanned images --- PDF, JPG --- better than HP;*  Easy set-up;*  Easy, flexible software;Cons:*  Works better wired than wireless --- HP has the same problem (last 3 all-in-ones)*  Scanned images through feeder are often not straight --- take care to align side guides or use the document table for hand feeding;*  Scanner won’t feed heavy card stock --- don’t use the feeder for the HP at all.All-in-all, the Epson 8540 is the best choice in its category.Please add your vote if this was helpful.
