This is a great looking dinosaur but that is the only positive thing that I can say about it. It is not something that children can open themselves and even for an adult, the packaging is cumbersome, requiring strong hands and a wire cutter to extricate the beast.  There is no on-off switch so you can never quiet the him (the UPS person said that something was growling in the box) and (maybe blessedly) the batteries will drain quickly.  Battery replacement involves a Philips screw driver which is a nice safety feature and honestly, I would not bother replacing the batteries.  Labeling leads you to think that T-Rex actually stomps his foot, but that it not the case.  The dinosaur is articulated but minimally pose-able and there is a lot less movement than expected.  As for age appropriateness, 4-6 is about right.  The sound effects are initially interesting but by the end of the afternoon, the kids were pretty much done with it.  Hasbro could have skipped the batteries and stuck with a decent Jurassic Park inhabitant with voice overs by the children.  Not particularly engaging or creative and definitely not worth the price tag.

These are very, very thin, fragile shingles.  Many were broken when they arrived and working with them requires significant care to avoid more from following suit.  Fortunately there are a lot in the bag so I was able to complete the projects.  I finished one with enamel and another with acrylic paint ~ both worked well.  Not sure if better packaging would help keep them intact....

I love the concept of naturally infusing flavors into my water and was happy to try this bottle out.The lid and flip top opening fit snugly with no leaking problems thus far.  There are textured indented grip areas on the sides which help prevent the bottle from slipping out of the hand.  This bottle is made of hard, clear plastic which hopefully will be durable over time.  The infuser basket is well designed, fits well and is easy to assemble.  The basket is in proportion to the 22 oz. container but the bottle is a bit  too compact for a good infusion.  Whatever little amount of fruit you stick in there has to be cut into tiny pieces and unless the fruit has a pretty noticeable flavor, it does not hold quite enough for my taste.  A handy recipe download is included which was helpful and I have had the greatest success adding leafy things like mint and fresh herbs.  One advantage of its size however is that it is great for kids even if you choose to go with straight water.  All in all it is a product that you can work with and adapt to a variety of needs.  I have had other products from this company and find them to be very responsive to customer needs and feedback.  This infuser came to me from them with an invitation to use and provide an honest review.

If you do not mind  working with wool that is full of debris, this is a great product.  It was less expensive than from other outlets but required a great deal of time picking out all of the detritus.  Would not purchase again or recommend it.

This combo apple slicer and corer is not a must have but does make preparing fruit a lot easier and safer for the fingers.  The rubber grips are comfortable and provide a little more protection from slippage than my all metal slicer.  It works well on any size of apple as long as it is not larger in diameter than the slicer itself but know that the smaller the apple, the larger the core you will get.  Neither this or my Pampered Chef slicer (which creates 10 smaller vs 8 larger pieces)  completely cuts the skin at the bottom but the pieces pop out with minimal nudging.  The bright color keeps it from getting completely lost in the hodgepodge of my utensil drawer.  I received the Dynamic Chef slicer at a discount for my review and even had I paid full price, I would recommend it.

The Dynamic Chef fish spatula is a versatile tool that should be in every kitchen even if you never prepare fish.  I have used it with salmon, perch and tilapia.  Narrower than other spatulas in my collection, it slides under the delicate fillet and lifts it without breaking up.  It is sturdy, flexible without being floppy and the slots allow any cooking liquid (great for poaching fish) to drain away.  It works equally well with fried eggs and my grandmother’s recipe for paper thin sugar cookies.  Because it is metal you cannot use it with non-stick cookware.  We do not have a dishwasher so I cannot comment on its suitability, but it does clean up easily using the Armstrong method.  I received this product at a discount for my honest review and honestly would recommend it.
Easy to install, this is a perfect size for mounting a small flag on our iron porch  railing.  We have had several high wind and rain storms but not twisting or tangling of the flag.

I love hemp in any form and the hemp seed oil does a great job of softening and hydrating without being greasy.  The scent is tart, not overly sweet and lingers just enough.  This was given to me as a gift and I am savoring every drop because despite my fondness for it, I would never spend this much money on body lotion regardless of its benefits.

I am a long term consumer of Coconut oil but have never purchased this brand.  I am using it for both cooking and skin care and have not been disappointed.  It has a distinct but not overwhelming coconut smell and adds a subtle overtone of sweetness to whatever I fry or saute. I have yet to try it in baked goods.  The label indicates that it becomes a solid below 77* but I have found that it needs to be significantly colder for this to happen.  To avoid spills and for ease of measurement, I keep it in the fridge and warm it up in the microwave till it is the consistency that I an looking for.  It is a little more expensive than the Viva lab brand  and lots more expensive that Natures Way, both of which seem to have comparable characteristics and are just as good.  That being said, this is a fine  product that performs well so depending on personal preference and availability, this would serve anyone well.

The GoodNites are far more absorbent than than the Night Time Huggies that we have been using which is a good thing. They are easy to put on and take off and the Iron Man image is appealing.  The problem with them, as with any product that is advertised as fitting a wide weight range, the top and bottom ends of the spectrum do not always fare well.  My nephew weighs in at 40#, wears a 4T but the legs do not fit as snugly as they should.  As a result, he  has had issues with down the leg leakage on those nights when he was particularly wet.

This may be a great theoretical concept but it has little to offer in practice.  The most positive thing that I can say is that it is packed in a compact manner and is easy to assemble.  Our 3 cats range in age from 3 -12 years and weigh between 8-14# and only the smallest was able to squeeze through the tube.  The structure is far from sturdy regardless of configuration but worked best with both sections on the ground, joined by the connector.  Our cats were not particularly intrigued by it and actually had more fun with the carton that it came in.  I would suggest sticking with freebies like apple crates that have nice round peek holes and cylindrical oatmeal boxes.

An all in one box offering (except for the meat and cheese, and fresh vegetables), the kit included 6 soft shells, 6 hard shells, a package of seasoning and a package of sauce.  The edges of 2 of the shells were broken off but otherwise everything was intact.  The preparation is quick and easy and we were ready to go in under 30 minutes.  The sauce was adequate in amount and flavor as long as you did not expect it to be anything other than "mild" as advertised.  The shells are on the small side and three adults managed to consume the entire batch. This product makes no claims to be particularly memorable Mexican cuisine and it would be silly to expect it to be on par with a non-commercial meal.  It is however a good item to keep on hand for those nights when you are short on time or ideas and is simple enough for anyone with basic kitchen skills to put together.

If you are looking for convenience, easy packing, simplicity of preparation and clean up, this may be the product for you.  The cook in bag is lightweight and opens with minimal effort.  I would definitely suggest stirring or shaking the bag half way through the reconstitution and found that we got better results if we added an extra minute to the process.  The meal was flavorful enough but tasted better with a hit of hot sauce.  Texture wise, the meat was inoffensive but did have the consistency that I would associate with thickish, wet particle board; it would never be confused for freshly cooked meat.  On the really down side, it is an expensive ($10/Bag) convenience.  The portions are small in terms of satiety and it would be reasonable to use two bags to feed 2-3 people  rather than the 5 that the bag advertises.  As with everything, it all depends on who is on the trail and what sort of physical, time or financial cost they are interested in.

I thought that plastic would be better in terms of keeping the blade sharp but this item was not worth getting.  It is very difficult for me to keep the blade in the openings and a sharp blade too easily cuts into the plastic.  My previous mini miter was fiberboard and it served its purpose well for years vs. a few weeks.  Definitely not recommended.

This is not a scripture journal that appeals to me; possibly I am just not the right audience.  My experience is primarily with the NAB, Jerusalem and Message Bible translations, all of which seem to touch the soul of the contemporary reader more deeply than the CEB.  For people new to the practice of daily pondering and journaling, it seems a bit dry.  The passages are thematically related, followed by prompts that stop short of really engaging this user.  The book is nicely bound with a sturdy cover and is small enough to tuck into a a purse or book bag.  The downside to its small size is that the print is very very small and could prove difficult for older eyes to read and does not offer much in the way of writing space.  Our faith, spirituality and life experience are all very different so it is a good thing that there are many options for exploring our relationship to God.  This may work well for many but it did not do it for me.

We have tried quite a variety of coffee makers over the years and always return to the Mr. Coffee.  Their longevity varies (5 months- 5 years), but on a whole, they last proportionately as long as the more expensive models.  The difference between 10 and 12 cup capacity may appear insignificant but the ability to brew a larger pot is helpful in terms of time and efficiency.  The large opening on  reservoir is easy to fill and having the water level visible on the side is helpful.  We were using a Proctor Silex that requires filling the pot for  water measurement and then pouring it into the coffee maker and though it did not seem like an inconvenience at first, it was.  This is not a fancy coffee maker ~ no clock, timer or pre-set options ~ but honestly, all you really need is an on/off switch.  Because it does not have an automatic shut off mechanism, you do need to be attentive.  It is easy to clean and the black plastic does a pretty good job of hiding any coffee splashes. My biggest complaint is that despite years of practice, I have not mastered the technique of pouring the first cup from a Mr. Coffee carafe without spilling....

This soap has a distinct lavender scent that unfortunately does not linger.  It removes the dirt and I appreciate having a single product/container for multiple uses.  It is very low on the suds scale and while I understand that more bubbles do not equate with greater efficiency, you do need to use a several squirts to produce reasonable coverage.  My hair is very short yet it takes 3 pumps of soap to do the job so I am not sure it is as cost effective as hoped.  Not a bad product but I would find it more satisfying if the lather was more plentiful.

The snip off corner package design was convenient and facilitated getting all of the contents out.  Too bad the contents were not better.This BBQ sauce has a good enough flavor ~ a spicy bite and the overtones of smoke.  The problem is that there is not enough of the flavor.  I used the crock pot option which was quick and easy to prepare and the chicken turned out very moist and tender.  It was just too mild to be termed "BBQ" though. Next time I will use Open Pit.

I appreciate the whole food/non-GMO ingredients and the satiety quotient is good but on a whole, this was not one of my favorite bars. Unlike other reviewers, I find this product very lacking in sweetness and if I did not see "Peanut Butter" on the label would be hard pressed to discern its presence.  After eating several of them, I have decided that  to some extent, Vega One bars may be an acquired taste although I am not sure that it will ever be a taste that I enjoy.  This product is not made in a dedicated factory so may contain traces of milk, rendering it legally but not "ethically" vegan.  Vega is in full compliance with the labeling requirements and for many Vegans, the potential trace is not enough to deter them from supporting a product that is in other ways free of animal product ingredients.  For someone with a significant milk allergy though, it is a factor to keep in mind.  All in all, it is a rather costly, nutritionally functional product that does not have an offensive flavor but is not one that I would go out of my way to purchase.

These bars pack 120 calories that could be used in a far better way.  They lack any coconut flavor (or any flavor at all) although the texture suggests that coconut is present.  It feels dry in the mouth and offers little in the way of satiety.  Eat an apple or an orange, fix up smack sized bags of raisins and nuts...it will be far healthier and satisfying in all respects.

One of our cats is a very mature female, the other a younger, strong and very energetic male.  Neither have ever been picky about their food, happy to devour whatever dry bits are set in front of them.  They have been eating this food exclusively for 10 days, like it and are doing well.  Both have episodic problems with vomiting and while I cannot say that this has significantly diminished with the Gentle Digestive Formula, the incidence is a little less frequent. Because of the lighter color and the absence of any artificial coloring, the clean up when it does happen is pretty easy. The pieces are small and not overly hard which the older cat prefers.  It does not have quite a strong a smell as some other brands which is a plus in my books.  Nutritionally sound, reasonably priced, appreciated by all the eaters....its a good choice for us.

Cetaphil products have always worked well for our family and so far, this lotion is following suit. It is not-greasy, absorbing quickly and well, leaving baby skin soft.  To me, the scent is barely there and what lingers is inoffensive.  The color is a bit peculiar though and while it does not detract from the product, it seems like an unnecessary and poorly thought through addition.  Eczema has been a problem for us and while I cannot say this lotion is more effective than less expensive options such as Johnson and Johnson or Aveeno, it has not exacerbated the condition.  If organic is important to you, this would be a good choice.  If cost is a factor, there are other choices.

Gund plush toys are long term favorites of mine because they are so incredibly soft and squishy.  This is my first experience with one that "does" something and it is not overly impressive.  The mechanism is overly sensitive so that the music starts with the least movement anywhere in its vicinity and the single song quickly becomes annoying even for children.  The on-off switch and battery pack were a bit awkward to access which is a good safety feature.  It did not hold the interest of the 1 and 3 year old children to whom it was given for very long and had even less appeal for the 4 year old.  You will get your money worth in terms of irritation but aside from that, children will do just as well with a cute cuddly plush animal or guitar that leaves the sound effects to them.

If parents are told to have no pillows, bumper pads or other potential suffocation causing items in the crib, it does not seem reasonable that this would be something that a baby would take to bed either.  My year  old niece holds it while being rocked before bed and seems to relax with the music.  She has learned the trick to making it play and loves the light.  As other reviewers have noted, this is not what I would call a soft and cuddly toy but it is durable and so far has held up to the inevitable banging that babies and toddlers are so gifted at dealing out.  The battery pack is adult accessible and there is an on-off switch that is particularly appreciated during trips in the car.

This is a lovely Pintrest type book with creative ideas but it despite the claim that these art projects are for kids, the skill and patience involved exceeds that of most children and many of their parents.  The author herself extends the caveat "Many of the projects in this book can be made by kids but most will require careful adult supervision"  which puts these projects right smack in the world of what grown-ups want and need.  Old envelopes, empty boxes, calendar pages and newspaper along with card stock and construction paper are commonly found in most homes but for an outcome that remotely resembles the photograph, you also need a full complement of craft tools and the "experience and disposition" to use them.  If you and your children have the time, inclination and dexterity you might end up with a finished product that bears some resemblance to the pictures but you are running the risk of significant disappointment.  On a positive note, the book does suggest activities that will draw upon the child's own creativity and lived experience (cards, crowns, houses)  that can be done with minimal adult interference .  I am a firm believer in creative play and have found that left to their own devices children often have more fun with the box than anything it ever contained.  Skip the book, stock  up on markers, glue, scissors and duct tape, be there to to support their creative efforts.  They will be awed by what they are able to make and so will you.

I am a big fan of bamboo because of its nearly endless potential for use and renewal so was excited to be able to try out this product.  They fit a round 30#  toddler  well and the come apart at the sides feature means less mess from a soiled diaper. They are thin with a fabric like feel to the lining that is gentle on the bottom. They are a pricier than the competition but they are absorbent without feeling sodden, have not caused any rash and I appreciate the manufacturer's efforts at  environmental responsibility.

Well acted but not particularly well written or directed.  I also overly distracted by Apple/Agnes' teeth which were far too white, straight and well preserved for a young woman who has been living in foster homes and  dumpster diving on the street.  For a "based on a true story" movie, it struck me as a bit too Hollywood for my tastes.

I have tried  to convince my family that whole wheat pasta is worth eating with little success over the years and although they were less turned off by the Barilla brand, they did not embrace it.  The shells are thinner than the competition but were not completely cooked at 7 minutes and had crossed the line to a pasty/mushy  consistency  by 9 minutes..  Whole grains have the benefit of being more complete nutritionally, but there are more palatable ways to incorporate them into the diet  without wasting a pot of good sauce on pasta that sticks to your teeth rather than to your ribs.  If you like the whole wheat option, Barilla beats the competition.  If you are not a fan, you will not be converted.

Barilla Veggie pasta is a bit more hype than substance since the nutritional content will never measure up to eating actual vegetables.  If however you view it as a supplemental source, particularly for people who refuse to eat anything that resembles a carrot or spinach leaf, this is a nice addition to the meal. If you have vegetable suspicious eaters, there is a slight greenish cast to the pasta but covered up with sauce, they will not notice it.  It cooks up nicely within the time suggested on the box and holds up well with whatever topping you put on it.  Even when made into a baked casserole, the rotini held its shape without drying out.  As with most other pasta manufacturers, this is a 12 oz box instead of the 16 oz. packages of a few years ago so be sure to double check your recipe ahead of time.

For a quick and flavorful enough meal prep aid, this is a good product but not something that I would use often.  As with any processed ingredient, it is high in sodium and relatively high in calories.  We used the Sweet Onion version in the recipe that was on the package and people thought it was good but unexceptional.  My guess is that this flavor would best compliment ground beef but it might do well with chicken or pork depending on additional ingredients.  Cooking sauce is the latest darling of the marketing industry but to me, it is not a significant improvement over generic soup with some added spices.  Purchased in packages of 8 containers, it is reasonably priced and cheaper than some of the competition, though still more expensive than a can of soup.  The pourable package is easier to use than a can but less convenient to store.

My car is 14 months old and because we are pretty tidy and have avoided spilling, I have not been very proactive about  cleaning the black leather seats.  After using Chemical Guys Leather cleaner, I was humbled at the amount of dirt that had accumulated.  The cleaned leather is soft, moderately shiny and smooth to the touch.  The smell is a bit strong but not offensive and even with the windows closed, dissipates.  It also did a credible job on my winter boots as well as  leather and faux leather purses.,  We have always been an ArmorAll family but this is a nice alternative.

This is a fast paced police procedural about the ups and downs in the personal and professional life of Janice Itwaru, a NYPD undercover  narcotics officer.  Reminiscent of Joseph Wambaugh, Matt Burgess takes on the drug dealers as well as the people and the system entrusted with the job of rounding them up.  I am not sure that it lives up to the descriptor of being “uproariously funny” but it is a clever, amusing and  engaging read, particularly if you are in the mood for a reverently irreverent book that shows a good understanding of both sides of the street.

a few months ago our cats got into a bit of a tussle, with one sustaining a significant corneal scratch.  It did not heal and did not heal, eventually being diagnosed as ophthalmic herpes.  It has healed well but to prevent future problems, theses chews have been prescribed as part of the ongoing treatment.  The cost to purchase on Amazon is quite a bit less than through the Vet, he eats them eagerly and so far, his immune system seems terrific. If only all medications could be administered this way.... I cannot speak to the benefit of giving these chews to a cat that has not been diagnosed with specific problem but they have certainly been helpful in the treatment and prevention of a known infection.

Wool socks have always sounded more appealing than they turn out to be in real life because regardless of their claims to the contrary, they always make me itch.  With winter off to such a cold start, I decided to give them one more try and it was a risk worth taking.  These are thick, soft and warm and they have not caused one bit of negative reaction on my skin.  I line dry most of my clothes so am not sure how they would do in the dryer but machine wash without problem.  Sold as men's socks, they are advertised to fit women shoe sizes 8+ but I suspect that for women in the lower end of the size range, they would be too large. (they are a bit too generous for my size 11 feet)  That is a minor flaw in an otherwise good, made in America product that is keeping my feet comfortably warm and dry.

This is a cute book with bright illustrations and a story with feelings and situations involving friends, projects and self-expectation that many school age girls could relate to.  Keeping a journal is a valuable tool for organization, planning and reflecting on feelings and choices.  Following Eva's project is not only entertaining but it will encourage the reader to consider a similar process for themselves.  The appeal of this book will vary with the age of the reader.  Animal characters are of greater interest to the publisher's  suggested age range of 5-7, but to read this independently at that point may be a bit ambitions.  I gave it to a 4th grader with average skills who did well with the vocabulary and comprehension but found the owls a bit too juvenile for her taste.

This is a cute novelty, not a toy so if you are expecting a sturdy item suitable for children to play with, keep on looking.  The plastic is thin and cheap but adequate for its intended purpose which is to hang on the wall, light up and give voice to phrases from the movie.  My niece is a huge fan of this movie and was thrilled to have Olaf in the bedroom.  Her mom was thrilled to have it there too because it does not take long for it to be pretty nerve grating for adults.  As far as serving as a night light, it really depends on how much brightness your child can tolerate and regardless of their devotion, may find it more of a distraction.  The greatest negative for me is the cost (big price tag, batteries not included)  which is way more than it is worth in terms of durability, duration of interest and life enhancement value.  To spend $30 on something like this seems silly.

...this is a fine product.  The cubes are small, the serving size not huge but they are intended to add a bit of crunch and flavor to a meal rather than being the meal itself.  Comparing this product to bags of commercial salad croutons, the nutritional value is better and tossing a few on top of low fat yogurt adds interest without too much damage.  For a vegan diet, this is a nice option since there are few comparable alternatives available.  While you could produce the same effect by crushing a granola bar, it is probably easier and neater to offer these toppers to your dinner guests and ounce for ounce, not significantly different in terms of cost.

Despite being overly wordy and slow,  Lee Child's writing style is rhythmic and skillfully draws the reader into a predictably escalating tension between the hunter and the hunted. Intrigue, bloody violence and clever dialog are plentiful while our hero's personal habits remain familiarly spartan.  The cult of Jack Reacher will undoubtedly love "Personal" but for readers who are not blindly devoted to his barely plausible exploits, this  is pretty much the same story that they have read 18 times before.

I have been working with this product for several days and am ambivalent about it at best.  This is my first experience with a touch screen and with Windows 8 and I found that it is not quite as intuitive as I would like.  The manual relatively unimpressive and is completely picture driven, always referring the user to on line explanations.  The screen images are clear and bright and it is nicely sized.  The camera will handle both video and photos and this comes with a year subscription to Office Online which is a really nice feature. My problems started the second day.  Turning it on produced a time/date page only with no ability to sweep from any side or corner and no amount of tapping the Windows button brought up the start screen.  It would not turn off despite holding the on-off button down.  Despite the invitation to call or email ready and willing support staff, the phone call got me to an unidentified VM box and after 24 hours I have yet to receive a return email or hear anything from the on-line chat other than they would get back to me soon. The tablet comes with a keyboard case which you can plug into if you prefer a more traditional manner of use so I tried this approach to unfreeze the screen.  There is no explanation of keyboard usage in the manual and I could not navigate the screen.  Still searching for the "mouse wheel".  After hours of fussing with it, I shut it down by holding the off button for nearly 3 minutes.  Later I tentatively restarted it, the Windows start page came up and the touch screen works..  All in all, I have no sense of confidence in this tablet.  It takes an eternity to charge and does not hold it for the advertised 10 hours.  I am not a techno wizard but can manage a laptop, iPod, phone and Kindle relatively well and do not view this tablet as the kind of thing that should require  vast expertise to use.  I would not recommend it.

I have taken Glucosamine with Chondriton for 25 years and independently of any hard science for or against its efficacy, am a strong advocate.  This product is Glucosamine only but a slightly higher dose than my combination pill.  Thus far, it is serving me well during this leaf raking season.  It is large but not nearly as bulky as some others and the coating helps it to slide down easily.  So many of the glucosamine products include MSM and/or Vitamin D which is not necessarily desirable and I appreciate this option.  Well recommended and a product that I will purchase again.

This is another engaging installment in the Captain Underpants series that will tickle the fancy of both children and adults.  The dialog is quick, clever and will challenge the reader to expand their vocabulary in a fun and entertaining way.  Chapter titles such as "Its my Potty and I'll fly if I want to", "Alls well that ends poorly",  "Hello its nice to Beat you" and "Spank you very Much" are worth the price of admission and pretty much guaranteed to become part of the family lexicon.  George and Harold pursue the Carniverous Commode with vigor and creativity, inspiring the reader to equivalent mastery of their own world.  The only mildly disappointing feature of the book were the Flip-o-Rama pages but they are not integral enough to the totality to warrant more than a mention. Well illustrated, this book is another good choice for new or seasoned readers ages 6-7 and up.

I am not really sure about the intended purpose of this item.  It is pretty large for lunch and though it would hold 6 beverage cans, the handles are not sturdy enough to support the weight.  Putting this product to the lunch test this week has had disappointing results.  Despite its stated purpose as an insulated bag, the food was room temperature by noon. Including a small ice pack helps keep the food cool but likely will not enhance the longevity of the carrying straps.  Objectively inexpensive, it is way over-priced for the benefits it offers, is not particularly attractive and has little to recommend it.

Well written, balanced, theologically sound and thought provoking book that challenges the reader to move beyond stock answers and discover who Jesus is for them.  Like Jesus, Martin Copenhaver recognizes that we spend our life moving more deeply into the Mystery, accepting that clarity and certitude are neither possible nor desirable.  The chapters are relatively short on words but long on thought, addressing topics of faith, worry, compassion and living from a sense of abundance.  He includes reflection questions for each chapter as well as a well balanced list of additional suggested readings.  Well suited to personal use or or group conversation and well recommended.

There are not a lot of gluten free options on the market so I was happy to discover this one. Sadly it is not vegan.  The texture is reminiscent of a LARA bar and is a nice alternative to the  crunchy or chewy products that seem to fill the shelves. The chocolate flavor is subtle with just enough texture to the bar.  Despite the high sugar content, ZonePerfect did not taste overly sweet, is reasonable in  terms of calories and there was no strange lingering aftertaste or chemical overtones.  Because it is fairly soft, the biggest drawback is that is will flatten out at the bottom of a purse of book bag.

Aprons are not a fashion accessory for me because I am genetically incapable of cooking without one.  Not only is this one pretty, it is well made and functional.  The fabric is heavy enough without being stiff and the contrasting pocket/ties add interest to the printed body.  It washes beautifully and so far does not hang onto the stains.  Unlike some mass produced aprons, this is generously sized and well proportioned to fit most people well.  The ties are formed by a single long strip that slides through the facings creating the neck loop.  The only small draw back is that even though it is quite long,  there is the potential for one end to come all the way out, requiring that you thread it through again.  This costs more than if I were to make it myself, but considering the cost of fabric these days, it is reasonably priced and frees up more time for cooking.

This is a quick paced rhyming story about Farmer Brown and his crew of dressed up animals.  The illustrations are excellent and convey visually the  energy and movement of the words.  Included with familiar animals are lesser known beasts such as the caribou and turtle doves.  It is a book that adults can stand to read, it catches the imagination of children and quickly invites them to sing (and shout) along with the story.  Fun any time of the day, the characters in the book can be particularly helpful in getting reluctant children (or their parents) up and going in the morning.

This project comes with sturdy cardboard pieces, it assembles easily and creates an equally sturdy dog house that stands up to the pressures of coloring and play.  Washable, double tipped markers  are included which is good since they work better than crayons for this purpose and are easy for small hands to manage.  Nicely sized, the dog house does not take up an inordinate amount of room but offers enough opportunity for several children to participate at the same time.  We used it to keep the kids busy while the adults finished dinner and a fine time was had by all.  Once completed, it makes a good home for the many stuffed animals that live here.  Simple, non-mechanical, not batteries, ready to go and totally able to be recycled once you are done with it.

I had some problems building it with the wings folded so ended up with them extended.  Not my plan but the parts did not cooperate.  Other than that, it went together well.  Clear directions, decent quality.

Laser Pegs projects give you building with a boost.  Interchangeable with Legos, these have the added features of sound and light.  The suggested age range is 5-8 years but it is best suited to the upper edge or older. Depending on the coordination, patience and experience of the child it is within the realm of possibility for a younger child but we found that the assembly frustration level was significantly higher for the 5 year old who worked with it than for his 9 year old brother.  The multiple option feature is nice but again, a bit intimidating for many unassisted children. Plus the more that it is taken apart, the greater the potential for something breaking since this appears to be predominately a display item  that does not hold up well to regular play.

I have tried these seeds twice and had very limited success.  Very low percentage sprouted and the few that did were not very hardy.I would place the blame of low yield on myself and my gardening skills.  But the low percentage of sprouting I put on the seeds.

I have had these for years outside in every weather.  One was even frozen solid filled with water and never cracked.People will not think they are real clay or terracotta, but they also don't look like garbage either. The color does hold up through the seasons and you will not be replacing them every year.I don't use the optional tray because of my needs.

Overall I like miracle grow, but for potting mix I really would not expect large pieces of wood. Yet I have had some bags that must have missed quality control and arrive with large chunks of wood and very lean on the soil.I do have good results with this and early planting.

I do like the coffee, but as a French roast it has a weak flavor.My daily brand is Millstone or Dunkin Donuts.  This is no where near Millstone's French or Columbian roasts in flavor. And it is cheaper than Dunkin Donuts, and is better than Dunkin Donuts whole bean..For the price if you subscribe, it is a good value.  I would buy it again.

Yes it is inexpensive, but spend more and get a little better than this.And it does work.  The sockets are too close together to use for than two or so adapters. And the reset switch is cheap and poorly placed on the end
Heavy duty does not have to mean stiff, and that is my only issue with this cord.  It is well made, but for the price you can get a flexible cord that can handle the same power threshold.

This ink has a real nice flow. It dries fairly quick and does well in some of my more stubborn pens. So there is very little bleeding with the right pen/ink combination. Which for every day writing on paper it actually performs well. ( I don't use broad nibs so can't talk to the issue ).The only issue I have is with the hue, which tends to be more of a flat pale blue that shows a hint of violet.So with finer point nibs like a Pilot or Pelikan it tends to look washed out when dry.There are much better blue inks for the price.  But few inks will write as well as this on regular paper.

There is always the issue with drafting tape:  it either does not stick well enough to hold the paper down, or it is too sticky and really should not be called drafting tape.Scotch leans more towards the sticky side of the range, which is where I prefer to be since I use drafting vellum.  If you are using more of watercolor paper, then this will still work, but you have to take some care when peeling it off.The only real issue I have with the Scotch is the thickness of the tape. it does tend to get caught on your straight edge.But since it tends toward the stickier side of the range you don't have to go wild with taping down the entire edge of the paper, you can just block the corners.This will hold the paper down.. so no movement in the middle of drawing or moving your tools.

Today this storyline is cliché, though 20 years ago this would have been edgy material.There is a very strong cast with great performances. Turner is brilliant.  If you are older and have been a fan of Turner throughout her great career, then you will love this movie. If you don't like Turner, then don't bother with this movie. it really is that simple.Overall though it is leaps and bounds above than most movies cranked out by Hollywood.The director told the story well. So kudos to a first time director, and a woman.Even though I believe the story is cliché in Hollywood, it is also still relevant. which is probably the saddest truth to the movie.The plot is predictable and yes it is the story of hypocrisy in religion. well specifically the Catholic church and their faithful masses.

Setup was not too bad.  and the instructions are good.  But the reward is that it automatically senses who is being weighed once the profiles are setup.it is very accurate.There is nothing bad to say about this, unless you really don't like the cool styling.

Aside from the price, this is the perfect notebook.It is very thin, and the dimensions are perfect for stuffing inside a book and carrying it around.The paper is the synthetic velium, so you have to choose your ink wisely since it will smear easily.If you are a student and want even thinner, Kokuyo makes a campus notebook that is a little less expensive.

With the right tinting or transitions ( drivewear is perfect ) they are perfect.Well constructed solid frame. The spring hinges allow wide angle of expansion to fit any face or head.The placement of the bridge piece can create issues for some noses, and considering the weight, you could be pushing them back up your nose.( I have a bump where they should rest on my nose, so that is why I mention this..)But there are more than a few considerations.First.. they are heavy and large eyes.  Check with whoever does your lenses before you pass the point of not being able to return this frame.Depending on your prescription, you may or may not be able to get higher index lenses.. which you should have to eliminate the weight factor. Also make sure you have your Pupillary Distance perfectly correct.  The large lense size created alot of issues with my lab and the various lense coatings.  They had to be sent back several times.Higher index lenses will be less of an issue for the lab.They are worth trying on. You will either like the size and weight, or you won't.They are made in china.. which for the price is irritating, but it is the rule anymore, not the exception

This is an nice midsized frame. Smaller than wayfarer but still an nice sized eye area.The bridge is wide so if you have an unusual nose it will still rest up high comfortably.Also this is a very thich frame, which gives a some wieght and stability.The hinges are spring loaded so they will adapt to your face.The color of the frame will depend on the light available.  The light blue will only be that clear in bright daylight. I have transistions and it has a very cool effect on the light blue part of the frame.

Two important points:  1- They are very light and made for large faces.  So if you want light but don't want half rims or rimless then you should consider this frame.  2 - The lenses do not cover the entire eye hole of the frame.. at the temple there is a slot where the lense ends.. the image is not clear about this in the style..  so if you are going to use tinted or transistion lenses, then this is probably not your frame.Overall I loved the frame. nice styling and made for large faces.

Yes a true story, well based on a true story.  So what, that is no excuse for a boring movie.First, it won't take you long to wonder why anyone would fall for this, even though people have.Next you will wonder why the writer could not write a more interesting movie.. that honestly is the bigger mystery.Law and Order SVU did this story, and they did a brilliant job with it..

Seriously, this is one of the best Bond movies in a very long time.It is not  a predictable Bond movie.I realize there are those who will not like this movie, becuase it is not one of the canned stories.The whole movie meshes the action with the plot very well.Finally, the movies have caught up with Craig's rough edges. And honestly the Bond franchise needed it.

This is very poor quality.  I returned the one I bought ( it broke during shipping ).I would have returned it either way.  It is very small and not sturdy enough to sit on a table fire anything more than a few inches.Interesting concept, just poorly executed.

I got this on a lightening deal for basically the price of replacement heads.. So my review is biased by the low price.  Would I pay full retail for this?  nope.I have had other norelco's in my life, and was never impressed with them.However.  I do like this one.The ergonomics and form factor enables this easy to get a close shave no matter how odd shaped your face is.. my head is a pumpkin with odd surfaces, and this thing really gets all the angles.Also this does not make a mess of the sink.The rubberized gripping is a big improvement over my Dad's norelco.If only the heads were cheaper I would be alot happier with it.

Okay these are made in Vietnam and the paper is lousy.  (Moleskine paper quality varies widely depending on the country of origin )The paper is very thin and asborbs liquid, so ink will feather and bleed.  It is also poor for artwork, except for maybe sketching.It is useful as a notebook using pencil or a limited selection of regular pens..  any pen that writes wet will just be problematic.If you want watercolor or an art book, then get a Moleskine made for that purpose.For fountain pens use the other Cahier journals..The only positive is the price, but there are better Cahier's made in Turkey that have alot better paper quality.. though not blank.. Ruled or graph is what you will have to buy.

This movie you have to actually watch and give it your full attention.The overall plot is okay, but is disconnected a bit too much.The lines are what makes this movie.  Great actors given great lines,, or opportunities to make up great dialog.Sam Rockwell really brings this movie together.. he really shines. He is better than Walken in his prime..There is not a bad performance among this great cast.Yeah the plot is a bit lagging, but you have to let that go and enjoy the performances.

I have alot of pen cases and this is one of my favorite because of its size. It will fit both large, small, and any combination of size pens.It has excellent padding and the pens will fit snug.The other option is the pen cases with the elastic bands, while they are functional, they lack being able to expand or contract to save space.

My kid is an EE major and needed boards this size for a project real quick, so got these overnighted.  The boards in all of them were fine, and worked no problems.The jumper wires she didn't even bother using.. the insulation was shoddy and bare wire was exposed.  Not all of them were that way, but they were not worth using.  P

I love this line of pen cases and have had every style and size and one point.This is made from thicker leather and is stiff.. it is not padded on the inside.. The divider inside is stiff leather, but it is not fully connected and will move to accommodate the various thicknesses of pens.So it does not have padded compartments, but the stiff leather will pretty much limit the impact if dropped.This is bulky, but it will fit in a jacket pocket.. though it is bulkier than some of the other pen cases which you will never notice in a jacket pocket.They do make this in a three pen version, which is probably a better choice for the suit jacket.

Fits perfectly on your bookshelf, will travel as well but it will take alot of space in a laptop bag. . If you don't like the orange this is available in a nice black.Also the color is a richer and brighter orange than in the photo. the tone is almost right.The outside leather is a softer padded sytle, inside it is a stiff leather. The combination makes for a sturdy case that will protect your pens from dropping and even some compression on the case.. There is sturdy divider to protect the pens on the opposing cover.This will hold larger pens, and the stylish italian pens look great.Some considerations - This has some thickness but looks nice on a bookshelf.Also, there is only one band to hold each pen, there is nothing to hold the bottoms of the pens, just where they slide in at the top. It can be irritating because the pens will angle and can touch at the bottoms...

This is overall my favorite case for size,protection, and style.  If you don't like the orange this is available in a nice black.Also the color is a richer and brighter orange than in the photo. the tone is almost right.The outside leather is a softer padded sytle, inside it is a stiff leather.  The combination makes for a sturdy case that will protect your pens from dropping and even some compression on the case..  There is sturdy divider to protect the pens on the opposing cover.This will hold larger pens, and the stylish italian pens look great.Some considerations -  This has some thickness and if you have a very thin laptop case you will have issues.  For the average briefcase, large purse, or average thickness laptop back this is perfect.Also, there is only one band to hold each pen, there is nothing to hold the bottoms of the pens, just where they slide in at the top.  It can be irritating because the pens will angle and can touch at the bottoms...They also make a lerger 40 pen case, which fits well in a bookshelf.

I love this line of pen cases and have had every style and size and one point.This is made from thicker leather and is stiff.. it is not padded on the inside.. The dividers inside are stiff leather, but they are not fully connected and will move to accommodate the various thicknesses of pens.  So if you have 2 large pens, of course two of the dividers will push into the middle compartment. Like my nettuino trident is a very large pen, and this probably would not hold three pens that large.. it might but it would be a very tight fit.So it does not have padded compartments, but the stiff leather will pretty much limit the impact if dropped.This is bulky, so it would probably fit in a suit jacket pocket, it would be very bulky.They do make this in a two pen version, which is probably a better choice for the suit jacket.

This is not a high end item in the realm of cufflink boxes, but for the price it is nicer than the image.  This was purchased as a gift for my brother who collects cufflinks but will not buy a storage box.  While he has very expensive tastes in cufflinks, his storage method was terrible.He would never buy an expensive box, and this fit his needs.. I would not recommend buying this for someone who does not compromise on their taste. SInce it is obviously not in the same class as other cufflink boxes.This is geared more someone who wants functional, but does not want to pay for the higher priced boxes..  I actually like the style and finish of it, and so did my brother

First, this is the material that is missing from undergraduate stats textbooks: a critical analysis of the applications of statistics. While you do not need to know statistics to read this book, you should if you really want to walk away with new knowledge.The real point of this book is Silver contrasts Bayesian ideology with Frequentists approaches to forecasting. Bayes is not very well covered in undergrad stats texts. I remember the textbook I used in stats basically stuffed it in the conditional probability section as a few pages with little fanfare. And most books on Bayes seem targeted for the graduate level and don't offer a novice disscussion.The issues I have with this book are mostly directed at style of writing.  I found Silver's style hard to read at times. It read more like an academic paper translated afterward to be a mass market book for general readership.  Also the structure did not really work for me. Each concept goes from overview to specific to more specific to detailed.  well that is how it read to me personally, and it seemed redundant. Again this is my personal view on it, you may find the flow intuitive and easy to read.Overall a well researched book written by a brilliant person.

First, this unit is very easy to use and setup, so there is no excuse for anyone not to integrate CO protection in their home or office.It can be simply plugged into an electic outlet, or it can be wall mounted ( probably the more effective use ) out of the box. The electric plug is removable and there is an extension cord that stores inside the unit so it can be mounted away from the electric outlet.The digital display is easy to read for people like me who are older and need glasses.This unit is recommended by the volunteer fire company near me.

This case fits the bamboo perfect and the front pocket is a nice bonus to fit other small accessories. ( As noted by the other review ).A few additional points to consider. This is impact-resistant material, but it is not the stiff thick material that makes it too bulky. It is actually softer than other cases like this I have for other devices. The benefit to this is that it will not take any more room than it has too in  your laptop bag.

First, this is designed to be a course text, so the structure of the book is lesson based.The fact that it is a textbook format actually works for the total beginner. What do I mean by beginner: people like me who have zero background in creating or editing digital media like photos or bitmaps. And have zero background with the industry standard products like Adobe.So the books which are targeted for users who are transitioning to Paint Shop and know the standard Adobe methods for doing x or y just confuses me.If you know what layers are and how they are used, then this book is not for you.The pro's of this book are that it will take you lesson by lesson and show you how to use the product, and teach you techniques. You will learn both the why and how.Also all of the files needed for the lessons are online at the publishers website.This is not a reference. And yes it is not in color.. ( not sure why ).

this is about as simple as they make them.  At first I thought it would be a little bulky, but the design is perfect to hold dvd's/cd's with sleeves or the jewel cases.The sleeves that come with it are messy sinces the pieces fall out of the punched holes by just touching them. I would recommend buying better sleeves or the paper ones.

The other reviewer did a great job outlining the features of this item. So I am not going to repeat any of the information, though I do want to add a few things.  This item deserves more than one review.A few considerations for those buying this item. Not really cons, but some minor issues.First, the elastic strap is not adjustable, so this will not simply fit on a cover of any notebook as suggested in the product description. I use moleskine notebooks, the cardboard covered and this just bends the cover. So if might work on spiral notebooks that have strong covers, or it might work if you slip this over the entire notebook. This is not a con, and it is common sense.The upside is that the elastic band is snug.. everything about this is snug.  The pencil holders really hold your pens or pencils in this as you carry it around.The canvas material and the design do not allow for the compartments to hold very much.. the zipper pocket does have a nice size, but it does not have alot of depth. This is true of the outside pouches. If I were to make one change to this, it would be to allow for the zipper pouch to expand a little bit more.This is perfect for taking to class with just your book and the minimum of what you need. Or as a sketchbook caddie as it is designed.It is a well made clever item and the price makes it a great value.

The feel of the leather is nice and it gives it a professional look and feel. Usually pencil cases are designed for school kids or the crafting market so you really would not want to pull one out during a meeting. Or in the case of the craft/artist type they are typically too bulky to be convienent.So this pencil case fits the need for someone who wants to organize the pens and paperclips rolling around their briefcase or purse.  The slim profile makes it easy to stuff anywhere in your bag.

I have several booklights and this one wins for the thought put into the design and the features.The issues I have with most book lights is that they might work well clipped to a book or they have an awkward size..This booklight will sit on a flat surface or you can clip it to a book. Okay so other booklights can do that.  But this also folds up to a perfect size to put into your pocket or leave clipped to a book.The arm and the light itself can be adjusted and will hold position. Since it uses AAA batteries and not those camera/hearing aid style you can quickly buy batteries while on the move.The range of light and the fact that it has adjustable brightness make this perfect for travel or in bed.For the price you really can't complain about any shortcomings..

This is a great blue color tends more to the violet hue when it dries, which does not really come through in the color drop in the image on Amazon.The only word of caution with the Aurora inks is the drying time. So if your pen tends to be a wet writer, then you will have alot of smearing and bleeding.Personally I use this in my extra fine and fine point pens, so for me it works best in my Lamy pens and my older Dupont nibs. ( very old dupont's).

The four stars are because this is a great book on the Intel Parallel Studio and how to utilize the tools in your workflow.As a book to learn Parallel Programming; it is lacking. Considering the target audience is experienced programmers, I expected better coverage of both design and implementation considerations related to parallel programming. Everything is addressed from an application and algorithm level and completely ignores any coverage of system issues. ( IPC and Shared Memory are only covered at a superficial level ).So if you are going to use this as a tutorial on parallel programming alone, it is seriously lacking. You will not understand enough to know you have serious gaps in your learning. That is probably my biggest issue.As a book on the Intel Parallel Studio, this book is well worth the price.  This has some great labs and walks you through the tools and various parallel technologies provided with the Intel suite. The Intel documentation is hard to navigate and this book is a great jumping off point.  The author's provide code to test in the tools with bugs so you will understand the how and the why.This is the first printing, so there are alot of editing issues.

This is our first inverter microwave oven. We had to replace a small cheapo disposable microwave we got at a big discount retail chain.This is a nice midsized oven. It does not dominate  your counter space like the larger counter top ovens, and it also large enough to do more than pop popcorn.We eat alot of the low calorie diet tv dinners.. this oven heats them evenly and to perfection. The microwave panini meals even end up with toasted crisp bread.In 30 years this is probably the best microwave oven we have owned, and you cannot beat the price.

This classic Algebra book is perfect for the middle school student who wants to seriously master algebra. For older students I would recommend Webster Wells, though the language in that book is a bit rough compared to modern english.There are alot of exercises and the answers in the back. The benefit to these old texts is that they actually teach algebra and a ton of useful techniques that are simply missing in today's texts. From Binomial Expansion to Evolution and Factoring this will prep your student to really hit Calculus running.This is as the title suggests "Elementary", and the authors do have a follow-up and more advanced book, though I would probably hit Webster after this.

This is terrible reprinting of a classic book. I assume they tried to scan this and reformat it, but they lost most of the book.Pay the extra and get the one of the other offerings of this great classic textbook.

Montegrappa makes great pens.  This is not my first Montegrappa and they all perform flawlessly. The ink flow is perfect and the nib glides across the paper.This is a heavier pen and has great balance. Though the pen has a very wide barrel and the taper at the end is not comfortable for gripping. The image really does not impress a person that this is a wide pen. But it is.The colors are somewhat marbled and the light really makes it pop when you are writing with it as the various tones of blue move.For the price this is a steal.  If you are looking for a Montegrappa that is a little slimmer, check out the Parola ( great price and is a pleasure to write with as well ).

This is my favorite blue ink. It has great saturation and is a very pleasing tone of blue. It dries very nice and pops out on the page.I have never had any issue with lamy ink in any of my pens. And the blotter dipsenser is a bonus.And the best part is the price. can't beat it and I am happy with this and black lamy inks.

This has a nice depression era look to it and looks great on a desk.  It looks like a vintage piece. top notch quality.  Nothing beats light through crystal.  And the right color ink really makes it glow.Functionally it does the job, though I overfilled it by not accounting for the lip of the lid that sits down into the well to keep in on.

I really want to like this pen, and in some ways I do.First, nice color and size.  The magnetic cap is actually a great feature, and so is the ability to unscrew the nib from the body for cleaning. ( though this also seems to be the core of the ink flow issues as well ).The ergonomics really make fun to write with.  Though there are issues with inkflow, and don't slow down when the ink does flow or you will have wet spots. I don't consider this a fine nib. Though I generally prefer a pen which can produce crisp lines..  so it might be my own bias working against the pen.I use fountain pens for everything, and I would not use this as a daily writer. Though the nib is smooth even though it is a bit wet for my liking, but is an effortless pen.Here is where I put this pen.. I think there are better pens for the price.. Lamy studio is alot cheaper a 100% reliable, or the Lamy 2000 for around the same price is an outstanding pen.This is not a great starter pen, because the ink issues will turn you away from fountain pens. Also, if you were buying a business gift for someone you knew was into fountain pens, they would be unimpressed with this and you.  For your spouse or a friend, it would be a nice gift.This pen really turned me off of visconti. Though I do enjoy writing with it and the smoothness of my writing when using it.

This was the best price I found on a pen case small enough for carrying around.  The quality and construction are excellent.The business card slots on the cover are a little out of place on a product like this.The interior is a fine black velvet, and it does not look cheap.  One feature which is hard to see in the photo is the inside pocket opposite the pen holders. You can actually clip the pens to this pocket and fit more than the three pen slots on the other side.It does fit in a suit coat inside pocket, though it a little bulkly.Overall this was a great value.

First, this bag is worth the price.. It is light,but can carry some weight.This bag is designed to be fashionable and functional.  The strap is comfortable and has a wide range of adjustment.  The design of the top of the bag has the staps mounted at an offset from the top of the bag.. this was a really smart feature since it allows the bag to form fit your body and distribute the weight more evenly. Also the straps adjustment buckle looks cool.  The strap padding and width of the strap really make it a comfortable bag.The material has that water resistant nylon type feel, and feels strong.The back magazine pocket is roomy, plus it does fight for space with the inside compartments of the bag.. So you can stuff the magazine pocket without making the flap impossible to close ( eventually there is a limit to this, but I put a textbook in it.A 15 inch laptop will fit, but this is really designed for the slim mac's and such.. my Dell 15inch xps was a snug fit.. ( but it actually made me feel like it was actually secure. ).The main compartment is roomy. There are several felt stacked pockets inside.. the felt is a brillant design. it acutally makes them all usable.. most laptop bags make these stacked pockets with firm nylon and they are impossbile to use for anything other than business cards..Okay here are a few issues I have with the bag.. first it is a very compact bag in height.. I wish it were another inch or so higher..The outside pockets are too small.  my laptop charger won't fit, and even my glasses case won't fit. And it is the height of the pockets that is the issue.. since they have magnetic closures there is very little tolerance for having secure pockets.The magnetic closure is also an issue for the main flap.. there is very little tolerance, and you really have to shuffle the load to ensure that it stays secured.Other than that it is a great bag..  though it is expensive.

I have 2 lamy pens:  the 2000 extra fine and this one extra fine.I like them both, but for the price, the studio is a much better value.  First, it has a nice weight and balance. The construction of the pen is a smooth metal gripping surface and a brushed metal body.This pen has alot more weight than the 2000.  The major difference is the nib.. the studio is not a great quality nib, and ink flow can be inconsistent at times. Though it has improved as I use it more and break it in and I have gotten used to it.It comes with a piston converter so you can use either an inkwell or cartridge ink.The one irritation I have with the pen is the clip.. it is twisted to give it an artistic look, but it also makes it very thick.. so clipping the pen to a journal or notebook is not practical.For the price it is a great value.

This is a nice pen, the nib is perfect.  There are a few considerations before buying this pen. Unlike the tornado ballpoints, this pen is very lightwieght in construction.  For me it is an issue since it the balance is off due to the feather-like weight.  The other issue is the "capping" as the other reviewer defined.  If you don't cap the pen when in use, it is very small.. and when capping you really have to press it on for it to stay. and it almost seems like you are going to strip the threads doing it.. ( not sure if this concern is valid )..I am going to look at the Retro lava fountain pens which advertise a more solid balance and feel.
This is a great classic text, and it really is worthwhile. However this reprint is just a few chapters, so it is worthless.

These are very nice refills.  The color is like the uni-ball onyx rollerball pens.The ink flow in the blue refills seems to be more controlled than the black. I noticed less bleeding when I write. Also it seems to be a finer point than the black. ( it might be me, but I noticed a sharper point on these ).

This is probably the most recommended book by the historians I know in the 82nd Airborne Association. Marshall's unique position allowed him to write an authoritative account of the Paratroopers operations in Normandy.This reads like it was taken from his offical military records, so there is detail. The first part of the book is the 82nd, and the second part is the 101st.his drawings and maps are very specific to the local actions of specific units. And they are not great, since they are basically hand sketches. ( again probably taken from his orginal reports, though this is just a guess on my part ).  So you will get the detail, but you really need to have a basic understanding of the entire operation to really appreciate and follow his accounts. (this is not a con, just an fyi ).The other major point with this book is that it is not taken from veteran accounts decades after the war. So this is 100% fact from his work during the war.All The Way!

The only real issue I have with the seeds is that the color mix is not as bountiful as suggested on the picture.I grow this all year, in window sill planters and outdoors.  My region has a very generous climate and I get two good outdoor plantings a year.  ( though the humidity in the summer does impact the leaves. ).  So june and july are tough months for me with this.We just trim what we want every day for eating, and it continually grows in our window planters.  We had a very mild winter and I have this growing outside right now.It has a great flavor.Even if you are a terrible gardener ( like me ) this will grow.

Just reaffirming the other reviews..  This came up quick, but the yeild was terrible. Less than half developed to full ears.If you grow this, if you see ears not developing as quick as others, just weed them out.  Most of the plants for me ended up being plowed over.However, what you do get is great corn.

I am active in the 82nd Airborne Association and socialize alot with my fellow Troopers.This is the story you hear from paratroopers when we sit around talking and drinking. No matter what era, the raw stories told by veteran paratroopers is never dull and not the bravado you would expect.It is stories like this is how you hear it. This book is one you will not want to put down, and is one of the best.All The Way,

This is a great textbook, but the publisher is pulling a fast one on students. The university my wife attends started using their "own" version of this textbook and she was told it was impossible to use the 12th edition.  Their own verision was just half of this textbook, and you had to buy the other half for the higher level course.Turns out the instructor lied, not only could the students use the 12th edition, the instructor used the 12th edition.Before putting out the money for this, get the 12th edition used for about 5.00 and wait and see if there is a need for this verison. ( honestly we have both now ,and the 12th is actually laid out better ).( you can pay for my finance lab directly).

I had a slightly larger samsill backpack which I had to replace due to the width. My usage for backpacks is with my walker and the bicycle type basket, and for wheelchair when I am in the hospital. The width limitations of the basket make this perfect.The reason I mention the above is because I will not use the straps, which I have to wonder if will stay together if a person filled this backpack to full capacity. It does expand, and the support panel reinforces the bottom  well. But the weak point of this is where the straps are sewn into the backback. It is not an issue for me, but from other reviews it has been an issue for others.The material has a weather resistant quality. I don't think it will be water proof. I have been stuck in the rain with this when waiting for paratransit and this did a better job than my other samsill backpack of not absorbing water through the backpack.The front pocket has a zipper compartment which will easily hold a nook or the smaller kindle. (not sure about the older kindle which I know is wider ).My only other issue with this is the 15.6 laptop size. Yes it will fit, and the laptop protection will take care of everything except one weakspot at the top of the backpack. Since it just fits, the laptop pushes out the top of the backpack, and there is little protection provided by the bag. Normally I use a laptop sleeve with a backpack, but this is too snug.

The issue with this set of book is simply that the website is free, and updated constantly.And with Wolfram Alpha you get interactive access to the content.Otherwise if you really need the print version, it is a great resource and structed as an Encyclopedia. Personally I favor Tim Gowers book, because is part Encyclopedia and part Text which covers the fields of mathematics from the top down.The issue I have with this, which is not an issue with interactive web content, is the endless references back and forth on each topic. Yes traditional encyclopedias do this, but in this case is really is irritating.

This series is great, but when these were written the resources available to Mathematica users was limited.Also, before I became disabled I was a software engineer since,, well more than 10 years. ( yeah I am really old now ).  So I understand what progammers and everyone has come to expected from a guidebook titled "Programming".  And this is not a "hello world" kind of book, nor is Mathematica really fit that paradigm.And of course the obvious point is that when these were written the documentation for Mathematica was not as evolved as it is today. Today we also have a nice selection of books available for Mathematica which cover it well. ( the Navigator is probably one of the best, and for programming The cookbook is actually good. and anything with Paul Wellin's name is a better fit for the programmer ).Now to this book. This is actually a great book and series if you want to understand everything about Mathematica. Trott explains every fine point about mathematics and using Mathematica for mathematics. It is not an easy read, as others have noted in their reviews because there seems to be alot of examples which are not concise nor do they illustrate concepts very well. Yet the book is full of them.  ( though Trott has taught me alot about various fields of mathematics. From modeling earthquakes to forest fires ).I have run into aspects of Mathematica, the finer points of patterns and manipulating very complex lists.  This book has illustrated not only how, but why you should choose one construct over another.  Trott does a great job of presenting the various programming elements of Mathematica, and stresses a process in which you simply do not translate from "C" to Mathematica. From page one he stresses that you should not focus simply on the result, but the entire process of deriving the result.So as a Mathematica user and programmer this is a great book, however, it is a better reference than it is a primary source of learning the basics. But as you advance with Mathematica this book is a great resource. Even the Mathematica documentation can be frustrating if you are not sure what question you need to ask if the first place, and the circular references and links don't help either.The CD as mentioned contains all of the books, so no need to buy all the books.

Every parent should have this book and pull from it some projects to do with their kids. It will be very instructive and fun.As a art hobbyist, I can see where any art student will acquire new skills and a better understanding of space.

Everyone knows who Einstein is and E=MC^2, and newton and his basic contribution to physics. But the average person has no idea who Maxwell is or how prolific his contributions to physics and modern society.This is a classic book and a great read. I don't have the math background for a good part of it, but it is still worthwhile reading the theorems and his commentary and discussion.As a reprint this is clean, though I wish someone would typeset this to a less cluttered font and presentation.Worthwhile in anyone's library.

One problem was with my protective rubber boots. Trying to enlarge the hole to one inch was not a DIY job. I wasted money and destroyed the boots. It you have rubber boots that protect the lamp fixture from road dirt, take the boots to a machine shop. It is impossible to enlarge the socket access hole with any home tools.Other than that problem Kensun gets a 5 star rating. There are some suggestions for solving some common problems. Skim this for anything helpful.This concerns installation and adjusting the beams. Note that when adjusting your light, low beam shouldalways have a sharp cutoff: Bright light below and dark above. It they don’t,  you have an installation problem.Installation is straight forward except there is no mounting hardware to secure the ballasts to the car. I assume from the low cost charges by professionals that wire ties were used. I drilled and mounted the ballasts to the framework, using silicone and washers to prevent loosening. A secure wire tie mounting (tight to the car), is OK. You will need your own ties.Connecting the wires is bullet proof as the connectors don’t allow mistakes. The short part of the wiring harness will be closest to the battery with the long wires leading to the opposite side headlight. The harness is quality. Don't understand the negative comment.My big problem was enlarging my rubber boots as mentioned earlier. I still need to resolve the problem.The HID beams have a very sharp cutoff that makes beam adjustment easy. The cutoff is much sharper that my old Halogen lights. Although the lights are bright to on coming cars, they are not blinding. I do not get flashed by on coming cars.The included instructions are minimal. For beam adjustment, I recommend going to U tube. A good site there is ChrisFix – adjust headlight beams. There are others. It’s your choice.I encountered a “nut behind the wheel” problem. An easy call to tech support and they sent me a set of bulbs that helped discover the problem.I bought another HID set from eBay several years ago. The experience turned me off as I was cheated by the supplier so never installed them. I bought a complete set from Kensun, thus could compare the two systems.I am very happy with Kensun. They are superior to the cheaper set. If you review HID systems, Kensun comes out tops.I recommend the 5000K bulbs. The light approximates daylight where as 4300K is on the orange side and 6000K begins to have a blue/green tinge. I want to see in the dark. The 5000K gives the brightest light. Either side of 5000K begins to reduce the strength of the beam.WHICH IS BRIGHTEST? Someone tested all the Kensun varieties. The standard ballast, 35 watt 5000K system was significantly brighter than even the 55 watt system. That was a surprise. light meters can be subjected to different light frequencies but the 35 & 55 watt systems emit the same frequency.There are folks who are like some young kids. They confuse being different and being better. Just remember the two are not the same. Blue or Purkile lights may look cool but their light output sucks.Note about the headlight lens.Most cars have clear plastic headlight covers. These will cloud due to dust and dirt attacking the plastic. I restored them with 1500 grit wet/dry sand paper – used wet. (Do not use a more coarse paper. It will seriously increase your time with the polishing end.).Work the sandpaper in small circular patterns. Be careful, be CLEAN, do not allow foreign grit to get in your sanding. Just a single stroke will create significant damage. Continue sanding until close examination shows there are no scratches, fogging or pits on the plastic ( there are fine scratches from sanding). You may have a few really deep pits or scratches. Ignore them.If the damage is extensive you may need to buy replacements at $100 plus each. It’s your call.Follow your sanding with “White” polishing compound. It takes a lot of time depending on the destruction. Polish until all the fine sand paper scratches are removed. Wash with water adding a few drops of detergent. NOTE: If you try to stop short on the sanding, no amount of polishing will work. do each part properly.HID lights do not solve the problem of messed up plastic headlight covers. You can buy restoration kits but they are no better than my system and much more expensive. Some kits use a clear solution to fill in scratches after a thorough cleaning. They look good but the solution is softer than the original plastic and will not last like the original. Faster ain't always better.

If you are stuck on a busy hi-way, a jump starter is a god send.Just know your trade-offs.The high current will shock the plates on your battery and probably shorten its life. I used one on my worn out battery. Killed it dead but it was dying anyway. It did allow me to trip down to Advance Auto and get a new one. It is better to use a 2/10 amp charger if you have the time to wait an hour or two. Very high charging currents and jump staters are not good for the battery plates.

A laid back delightful movie. But note that this is formatted for the European market (PAL).A smart but disillusioned, semi-inebriated, professor who is teaching college grad students is forced to tutor uneducated people the finer arts of the English language. "A waste of my intellect."Enter a brash sexy-cheap, young girl who wants more from life than being saddled with an ordinary husband.
