He wants nothing more than babies a'coupla of beers and a soft couch positioned so the "Telly"  can watch him.Rita is one of those people who are very different than their appearance presents. She gradually begins to impress this professor with his jaded outlook on life.She has a raging curiousity with the ability to "think outside the box." It makes her dangerous to the established way of thinking as the "prof" warns her.Rita knows who she is and where she wants to go. It gives her an honest security that few of us know."RITA" is not a movie for everyone. But if you like people and want to understand what lies beneath, it's for you. If not, pass it by.

It's a gimmick product. Punch a hole in the shell; insert probe; fire it up and whipped egg.Sounds great but just not worth it. The old fashioned way is still best. Really what do you save? Time? Money? It's just not for me and I like gadgets.

If you want details, read other reviews to discover exactly why this product is worth the price. It solves a problem that Armorall and the others create.But if not...BUY IT!It does what the others don't do. No protector lasts forever but this does last longer than others without creating problems.

Encountered a minor problem when trying to insert a SD memoery card. It would not go in. In ollking for the sourde of the problem you could see that the outer covering was misaligned, making the opening too small. Disconnecting the hub from the computer and using a small screw driver, you could realign the cover with the SD slot.Otherwise the product does what it is supposed to. Shipping was a "China-fast."

KENSUN gets ``an A+ for customer service. I do not yet have enough experience but for this one comment.IMPORTANTMy Isuzu Rodeo has a rubber boot that protects the inside of the headlight from dirt. I destroyed it trying to enlarge to one inch for the Kensun HID bulb. Learn from my experience.by using the following procedure.Using a one inch hole punch, place the rubber boot on a wood board. Carefully center the punch around the boot hole. Firmly holding the punch, begin hammering the punch (I recommend a dead blow hammer or a rubber mallet).. A better solution would be to use a hole punch and a hydraulic press. Or best, pay a MACHINE SHOP to make the hole for you.Do not try to cut through in one whack or give two dozen "love taps" either. The rubber boot distorts when impacted. Examine your cut after each "whack." Replace the punch exactly where your cut is and repeat until you have the required one inch hole.Trying to drill the rubber causes the boot to be voilently ripped from your grasp, resulting in tearing the boot apart. A rotary file may work if you are willing to commit a month or so of your time.I do not know anything about the various types of boots, so if you have a solid boot like plastic, ignore this. You won't have my problem.The 4 stars is an attempt to balance their excellent service with their totally inadequate instructions. I have a mess that costs me time and considerable expense.

As a believer in Netzari theology, the author does not believe in 1 Thes 4:17, where the church is "caught up" by Y'shua in the clouds [this is a significant part of End Times prophesy]. The purpose in buying the AENT is to discover Biblical truth. Why buy a Bible that the translator does not believe it himself? [added 4/5/15]To begin, the AENT has some good points but some serious flaws. Sister Hannah has an analysis of the AENT with so much detail it is difficult for me to assimilate it. Her scholarly criticism of the AENT reminds me of, “I can’t see the forest for the trees.” Translation: There is so much detail that I can’t see the big picture.Since the big picture includes the End Times and is a major part of Protestant Theology, It is necessary that we pursue it. I do not fault her criticism, only that it does not adequately show us the real problem with the AENT.I admire Mr. Roth’s scholarship and his clarity but he allows his personal bias to cloud his analysis. For example in his objection to the Rapture he attacks the Catholic Church’s position on the Rapture rather than the Biblical foundation for it. That is a good debating strategy. But it only works if you fail to see its misdirection. The real basis for the Rapture is found in 1 Thessalonians 4:14-18 and it is quite clear.What we see in Thessalonians is the first reappearance of Jesus but notably He does not actually return. He stops short, in the clouds. The second coming occurs following the Tribulation. Roth’s philosophy denies the Rapture. This analysis seriously distorts the entire End Times events.More on this later.HERE IS MY TRY AT THE BIG PICTUREMr. Roth’s theology is founded on the Messianic Jewish philosophy called Netzari. They are Messianic Jews. They believe in the risen Messiah so they are similar to Christians. But there are significant differences. To me the most important are the Apostle Paul’s ministry and the Christian Rapture.For brevity this comment only touches on these two. Reference pages 933-938 in the ANET for Roth’s analysis of both the Rapture and the Apostle Paul. His revealed philosophy underlies the reasoning behind his footnotes.Will you agree that God is logical? He always has a purpose for everything and everything is motivated by love. Matthew 25, the Parable of the 10 Virgins is telling believers about the Rapture. But we must understand the ancient Jewish wedding if we are to see its meaning fully revealed. [There are a few websites that explain it fully. For brevity, I don’t do that here].Understand that in that wedding there is no sexual love or motivation. What motivates it is a call to duty. There is a deep respect for each other. It goes beyond our modern understanding of a wedding but we sure could use some of it today.To understand the big picture for the Rapture and Tribulation, we must know their purpose. The Trib is for the Jews who God has always loved.  Don’t believers usually come to Christ during a crisis?  Is not the Trib a big time crisis? God wants all His children with Him. But remember, He gives us free will. They are free to choose but must choose on their own.Its purpose is to bring His children Home so He can regain the fellowship lost in the Garden of Eden. The 144,000 must be His witnesses during the Trib. Didn’t God tell the prophet He always has a witness?Since both the Rapture and the Trib can’t be for the Jews, the Rapture must be for the Bride of Christ, the Church. The reason is found in the ancient Jewish wedding. God’s purpose for the Rapture is to keep the Church safe.The wedding ceremony is founded on the groom’s  promise to the Bride that she will always have security and safety. The parallel for the Rapture is in the 7 day sequestering when the now official union is consummated. Read about the wedding for a complete understanding.Sorry, I planned to include the AENT translation of Matthew 25:1-13 because it really adds clarity to its purpose. The differences are positive, minor but significant. That would make this too long. Hopefully this adequately describes the big picture that Roth’s footnotes hide.NOTE: I am a Christian. I believe the Bible is written by God to His children, the Jews. To really understand it requires that we understand Jewish history, tradition and culture. Did you know that God's calendar [Exodus12] states the year begins on Nisan one. That is our March 20 and its the first day of Spring.Isn't it just like God to begin our year at the true beginning of the year when nature springs to life, rather than in the dead of winter? That's our God!

The authors are clear and to the point. IF you accept their Baptist theology, you will like it.My problem is they fail to understand that God wrote His instructions to His children, the Jews. To understand the Bible requires an intimate relationship with the Jews, their history and culture. The authors fail miserably. Thus in many places, particularly in Jesus' parables their analysis is less than worthless because it not only misses the mark but seriously miss directs the reader. The problem may stem from [once saved, always saved.] Wrongly interpreted, it is a tool of satan.If you can find a copy of this commentary, check out how totally wrong their analysis of the ten virgins is. Much of the commentary is OK. But when an author's foundation is flawed, I have difficulty trusting anything they wrote. There are other good commentaries. Check out the analysis of the ten virgins before buying one.This example details my difficulty with their commentary.  Let me use Matthew 25, Jesus' parable of the ten virgins. To understand this, requires that the reader sees the comparison to the ancient Jewish wedding [an Internet search reveals one or two sites that nail it. I like the church - based in WV] The comparison is between the wedding and Jesus' meeting His bride [the church] in the sky. His purpose is to honor His commitment to protect His bride from harm [the Tribulation].I will leave the discovery to you, the reader, when you research the ancient Jewish wedding. It is beautiful once you have an understanding of Jewish culture. I would like to hear from anyone who does this. I  was blown away and had to totally revise my understanding of many precious Christian beliefs.As to 'once saved, always saved' -- Personally I believe our salvation is secure as long as we hunger for a personal relationship with God. Example -- Do you read a few verses in His book everyday, trying to really understand Him? Don't read a couple of chapters in a "through the Bible in  a year plan.." All God asks is for our heart to be right. It's easy, simple and straightforward. He is a loving God, not mean or cruel.We just can't be self centered and insist on doing things our own way. When we said our salvation prayer, did we leave out the "repent" part? If we did not promise to turn away from our old life AND DO IT, we cannot say we follow Jesus and make Him Lord.Continue to do right and we are secure in 'once saved, always saved' foundation. It is no accident that the parable of the Talents immediately follows the ten virgins. We have responsibilities and we receive the consequences -- good and bad.If you do not accept that God wrote the Bible to the Jews, I feel sorry for you. Maybe you believe in Replacement theology [that Christians have replaced the Jews in God's plan.] All negatives on this comment will come from that group. Remember, I did not write the Bible, God did.

I gave this to a teenage friend after skimming over it. It uses the NKJV translation solving a readability problem inherent with the King James that uses antiquated words and sentence structure. Please don't misunderstand. I like the KJV. It was my first Bible and is one of my Bibles I use. It is definitely NOT a Bible for new Christians or teenagers.A Bible is only effective when read. Why intimidate new Christians with a difficult book that is even difficult when written in plain English? The NKJV is not as easy to follow as the "thought 4 thought" translations like the NLT. But it is friendlier to the Holy Spirit. It works for me and is the Bible that goes to church with me.My friend found the NKJV readable so hope she learns to read it for understanding. The study part is designed to appeal to teenagers and is a helpful guide in receiving what God is telling us.Every new Christian should be given a study Bible, not just  any old Bible. It is a complex book with many hidden messages. Would you give a mathematics book written in Hebrew, to a student and expect them to get a passing grade?I found the publisher (Thomas Nelson) is on friendlier terms with the Holy Spirit than most mainstream  publishing houses. I believe in the Trinity and Jesus' promise that we receive the Holy Spirit as comforter and a source for God's power. It is with this power that Jesus won the lost. He promised that we could do the same. This is how God's desire to win the lost to Christ is best achieved.Although not as popular as the "Life Application" study Bible by Tyndale House, which is not Holy Spirit friendly, The Extreme Teen is a solid Bible. I recommend it, particularly for teens. It may be the best out there but I have only a few "studies" for comparison. Also it is out of print and may only be available used.

The Bible is written, by God  to the Jewish people, using their culture, customs, calendar and feast days. If a Christian fails to understand this, they lose the ability to receive much of its message. It is complex, with messages inside messages.One important understanding is learning about the relationship of Christ (the Bridegroom) with the Christian Church (the Bride of Christ). It follows a direct pattern mirrored in the ancient Jewish wedding. It is not only the ceremony but involves the entire procedure from the selection of the bride by the father, building the new home by the son, the feast, the ceremony and the 7 day consummation of  the union. This can enlighten you about the Rapture and the Tribulation.Look it up on the Internet; it is not explicitly explained Biblically but Mesianic Rabbis' understand it. Although not a Jew, I've discovered that Messianic Rabbis, like Cahn are better equipped to pass on Biblical wisdom, partly because their knowledge Marries the O.T.  with the N.T.It has been said that people who fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it. Please tell me how Biblical history and current history differ? If you  believe God is the author of the Bible, this makes sense to you. Believing, gives you an immoveable anchor on which to rest your faith. Without that you have a constantly moving anchor at best. Every sailor knows how to "set" an anchor. Is a moveable anchor what you would use to anchor YOUR boat?Another analogy is a child's relationship with a loving parent. A child, when either hurt or afraid, knows he can run to her parent for comfort, protection and support. Do I serve a loving God, who even more than a loving parent, is my Father in heaven? Or is he a distant god who asks and rewards in ways a loving parent finds abhorrent? Having the security of knowing your loving God is why the Bible is so important in a Christian's walk. It is that relationship in which the Harbinger was written.All that said, there are several other prophesies coming together that offer validity to Cahn's book.On the Harbinger's readability, it is an interesting read that intertwines fact with fiction. Cahn takes several events that followed 911, compares those to ancient Biblical history and shows a pattern between them and events unfolding in America today.  Whether one believes the message does not detract from it making a good story. Novels must be based on a believable story that flows easily from beginning to end. The Harbinger does that. By the way, a harbinger is a warning of things to come, so it is an appropriate title.Read the book, you won't be disappointed.

From several reviews I expected a chair that only fits light-weight, small frame folks. Never to see 70 again, I am an average 5' 8" and an overweight 175lb guy that can slide into a 40/42 suit.The #17 indicates that the inside span between the arms is17" (and it is a true 17"). The cloth is strong canvas. There are individual, locking brakes on the rear wheels, accessible by the caregiver's foot but not the user. All 4 wheels are 8." The two front wheels rotate; the rear are fixed. The wheels are a composition plastic with hubs that have well designed, metal bearings. I see no shortcuts in the quality of the transporter.Update: Forgot one thing. There are rubber foot pads on the frame, next to the rear wheels. By putting your foot on one, it gives added leverage when tipping the chair back to negotiate obstacles; a nice touch that overcomes the smaller wheel size.I sit comfortably, with more than ample room. A 19 would be excessively large and uncomfortable for me. Personally, I don't care for foot rests but a taller person would want to use the footrests. For me, they always seem to be in the way and hinder me when trying to motivate under my own power. I walk short distances with a cane and my wife pushes me on longer ones - when I just stick out my legs. Even at Costco or the mall, I make do without rests. Thank goodness tho, they all have floors whenever we pause. Nice, needed exercise!Several other transporters weigh 15lb, so the extra 4 lb (this is 19lb, less w/o the foot rests) increases its strength - a good thing. If you can pick up 15lb, you surely can handle 19lb. Like all transporters, it picks up with one hand by cloth handles sewn into the seat  (here, one on each side), making it a breeze to jerk up and toss into your back seat or trunk. Unless you drive one of those super-tiny gas sippers, you don't even need to collapse the handles and footrests but they will accommodate.It lacks some unnecessary bells and whistles, available for a couple 'a Benjamin's more. When you get this, you pay a couple 'a saw bucks extra for a stronger frame. For my money buy this as a #17 unless you are 200lb plus and need a 44/46 suit. If  you have a 17" chair at home (measure it between the handles or arms), that will tell you how you fit.If I designed a transporter, it would be like this. All wheels are 8". Larger 12" wheels (offered on the more expensive transporters), make traveling on rough outdoor terrain (like a family picnic) or possibly manhandling someone backwards up brief stairways a bit easier. For normal interior buildings with moderate floor level changes this is super. Any problems are usually solved by pulling the transporter backwards. With the #17, a stronger caregiver can tip and lift the patient to negotiate minor obstacles easily (but done easier with a standard chair).If your caregiver is strong, they can tip a standard wheelchair back, balancing it on the large rear wheels to navigate difficult obstacles. I don't feel this is as practical with the 8" wheels, but works for transitions of 2/3" high. I hope this gives you an idea of its capabilities and limitations.Although I got mine from a friend, Amazon has great prices. From my experience on my many other purchases, they stand behind what they sell.

Not sure what you get that makes this worth a couple of Benjemins when our stripped Glory was a single Grant but here is the info we can offer. I’m no cell expert but have some info on the service providers that may be helpful.First a note about the Huawei Glory. I use Amazon extensively but like the easy return options at Wally’s (a last resort, love hate relationship). They have it at half price, making it a super value.Good customer support and a good phoneBiggest problem is the on-screen keyboard. Even laid “landscape” my small size 8 fingers hit wrong keys about 1 of 4 entries. A stylus is a must for me. A 32GB SD is less than ten bucks from our Asian friends, making the total package unbeatable unless you are a hi-dollar, gadget freak.. This is my 6th cell and am happy with the technology strides over the years.Our experience with service providers: Although Tracfone is new to us, I am impressed, with their support, the phone and with their flexible system of refill cards. Not a major cell phone user, we wanted a cost effective, flexible “no contract” phone. In our opinion Tracfone is the best available and here is why.We have used US Cellular, T-Mobile and Tracone as no contract and Verizon, AT&T and Sprint as contract. But this only concerns our experience with the three no-contract folks.First US Celular: as their dealer they cost me almost $200 and it was a bitter learning experience in dealing with a company that does not give a toot about people. I cannot recommend them in any way.T-Mobile has poor reception in our area of N.C. but our main problems are their incredibly poor customer support and refill plan. When they changed their refill system it wound up costing us almost $300 in lost minutes. There was no sympathy and no recourse. We cannot recommend thenTracfone has a plan that eliminates all of the problems we had with T-Mobile. Their support folks have been great. The contract companies are easy to deal with but we are retired and cannot afford their high monthly cost.Last is Magic Jack. Although not a cell phone provider, their broadband Internet phone service is an objectionable, alternative for some folks. Their auto renewal system gives dishonest information and should be reported to the government Do we recommend them or is there a better alternstive? The answer is NO and YES. We used MJ for three years before learning of VoIP. If you have hi speed Internet, VoIP is a cost effective way to get good low-cost phone service.We found that the lowest cost system is to buy an OBI HAI VoIP interface device (Amazon has great prices). Get the cheapest one for simple home use. Obihai has several service providers that discount to ObiHai owners. Their service is cheaper and better than MJ. Also our provider, PhonePower, has very nice, Calif based support. NOTE We recommend at least a 5mip Internet broadband.

I must begin with an explanation of the two different schools of thought mirrored in EVERY study Bible. This is critical to choosing a study Bible that agrees with YOUR personal theology. This is almost never explained to prospective readers.Study Bibles fall into two basic categories: liberal and conservative. The liberal school believes the Bible was “God’s word” as written and understood by men. Thus it is open to interpretation.Conservatives believe God is the author and it was penned by “scribes.” As a conservative, I can’t believe an all powerful God, creator of the universe would not write His OWN book to His children – you and me.Does it makes sense that a God for who we lay down our very life in His service, that He would trust men to NEVER make a mistake in interpreting His intent? Believe that and you have to buy one of my tickets on the next Mars shuttle. Only one left. How about it?That said “The Word in Life Study Bible” is conservative and it is one of the best choices of the conservative study Bibles. I won’t go into its details; they are covered elsewhere.There is one important point not covered and that is, “What are really the main differences in the two schools?They are important.” It is important if you want the fullness of God as promised by Jesus in John 14. Jesus promised we would receive the comforter (the Holy Spirit). Jesus received the Holy Spirit, described in John 1:28-34. It follows that Jesus performed His miracles with the power of the Holy Spirit and that is mirrored in John 14 when we are promised the power to do Jesus’ works. Liberals deny this interpretation.Don't misunderstand; Jesus is God and all powerful but here He was man and capable of dying for us. In heaven, we don't die, do we? Does it make sense that God's laws apply differently here and in heaven? Jesus received the Holy Spirit for a reason; otherwise why does the Bible make a point of it? God is logical. He has a reason for everything. God structured our whole world on order and logiic - right down to how atoms function and are the building blocks for everything - everything..Further, in the interpretation of Genesis 1:26-27, liberals deny, exclude or offer alternate versions of the implied Trinity. This is key to watering down the importance of the Holy Spirit. When the Holy Spirit’s role in a Christian’s life is removed, it destroys our power. And that was Jesus’ key to winning the lost.In Africa today, many thousands are coming to Jesus by way of Reinhard Bonnke. He is a man of God who uses the promised power of the Holy Spirit to win the lost, just as Jesus promised. So don’t tell me I’m wrong.The Bible is a complex book with many messages about life and God. Think about what is important to your Christian life and how you want to grow closer to Him. Then decide what is a good choice for your personal study Bible,A study Bible helps understand difficult or hidden meanings. It should not be a substitute for your own understanding. Go with God.

First off, I like their approach.Head first books offer a unique approach  your traditional “text book” style. Type A people may not like it as they relate more to the quick and brutal approach to learning.Because its style is unique let me try to explain it. Picture yourself in a small class where your teacher presents ideas together with practice sessions, then follows each new concept with a Q&A period. This is the best word picture I can think of. At the end of chapters there is a review. “Did you get it?”On each page the book uses pictures with short groups of traditional text together with “cartoon” like text.. It is a very open presentation.If you are learning disabled, their open format is well suited to your way of learning. As a teacher, I discovered that learning is easiest when a teacher can build on a student’s existing knowledge. HTML AND CSS have little for most people to build on. This book does the best job of bridging that I have seen.As a beginners book, it is first class. On completion, you will be ready to tackle advanced concepts. You then have that necessary foundation to build on.

UPDATE (Feb 2013) Do NOT let the bulb dry out. There is a piece of gauze resting against the bulb that needs to be kept wet. Let it dry our and you will be buying a replacement bulb.(Original comment) Have had the HM-200 for several years and it does a good job (repeatable readings, ease of use). I give it a 5 because of quality and customer support. Based on quality/price, the PH-200 is about the cheapest available, including units on ebay.Suddenly my HP-200 stopped working yesterday (readings going wildly wrong mostly reading a 10.0 no matter the water tested). I called the company HM DIGITAL to find out why I could not calibrate it. The answer was that the sensor should be replaced every two years or so. He said there is a gel that gradually drys out. This is a wakeup because all ph meters use similar technology. Why this is important is that some ph meters do not have replaceable sensors. You can buy cheap meters but you take your chances on accuracy, mickey mouse calibration etc.If you are considering this or have one, I found a supplier that sells a replacement sensor at a reasonable price. the supplier is allwatercare com. in Atlanta. They also sell many different water testers and discount. I paid $38 for my replacement sensor while all other suppliers I checked wanted around $75 to $80. The company also has buffer solutions, cheap batteries etc. I think other companies just want to sell new units. Hope this helps.NOTE: My wife said she had dropped the meter a while ago but there was no apparent damaged. The sensor is a glass bulb and although the unit continued to work but it may have damaged a seal allowing a leak, accelerating the gel loss.

UPDATE 4/17Discovered it is necessary to close the slide with the full force of the spring. (So my initial comment on the slide is wrong.) This locates the laser beam correctly and is repeatable. What is not known yet is the accuracy of the beam. The beam is CLOSE to true but there appears to be a slight change in beam position when the bore sighter is rotated in the chamber. Without a access to a good calibration setup, this is the best I can do for now.  SUMMARY: The sighter is in close agreement with the gun sights. This is a positive report and am impressed with its performance so far. My position on the two devices covered in the first comment has not changed.This bore sighter has none of the chamber insertion problems I hear about with other cheap pistol bore sighters.1) The sighter fits easily in the chamber and is identical to a 9mm round. It is well made and brass.2) It has no adjustment screws. But without a precision calibration setup, I can only say it seems to be fairly accurate.3) Battery life is short, as expected but the supplied alkaline's hold up for at least 2-3 minutes. That is more than enough time to install the batteries, chamber the sighter and check out how it compares to the pistol sights. I used the same batteries four times before they began to wink out.4) There is NO caution of "don't close the slide." Which is an idiotic requirement, as a pistol's barrel does not lock into firing position until the slide closes. So this passes this test with flying colors.5) The kit includes 4 batteries; two are needed for one operation. So you can get two battery loads without resorting to buying more. I still have the second set. The laser lights as soon as you begin to screw the two parts of the sighter together so be quick. Closing the slide slowly or letting it snap on spring action made no difference in the beam position so I close it firmly by letting the slide snap the last inch or so of travel while pointing the gun down to hold the sighter in the chamber.6) Shipping was very fast (from AZ). This is a very good vendor. There are several vendors offering the same sighter. He is cheapest and the service is first class.7) It is well made and has excellent value for the small investment.That covers the pro.The con is that the bore sighter indicates that my Taurus 24/7 9mm 4" barrel, shoots about 3" high at 15 yards. This conflicts with my pistol bench testing, which shows that my pistol sights are accurate to less than a half inch at 15 yards.This means the bore sighter has a problem. I cannot explain that at this writing. Once able to do exact testing, I will update this comment. The rating will either increase or decrease depending on the results.To be clear, the bore sighter seems to be accurate in my jury rigged calibration setup yet in testing with my pistol it is considerably off. I cannot explain this so I will not give this a bad evaluation.I do have another comment that has to do with a pistol laser beam, NOT with this bore sighter. I favor the pistol laser beam as explained here.Being retired, the strength in my arms and hands ain't what it used to be. Since I've not used a pistol for decades, I needed to get up to speed if this is to serve its purpose (home and carry defense).I purchased hand and arm weight and exercisers, knowing that accurate shooting requires more than average strength. This is an oft overlooked problem.I knew I needed solid feedback to tell me what was needed to improve my accuracy. The pistol laser provides that perfectly and it has proven to be a much better investment on my way to becoming an accurate shooter. My optimistic goal is to have a 2" group at 10 yards.I use the laser beam when dry firing (no bullets). Dry firing exercises train my muscles to overcome our normal tendencies. These are the root cause for inaccurate shooting. I probably dry fire 3 to 5 hundred times for every live round fired. The laser beam on the target exaggerates the very small movements in my pistol, showing where and how to improve. I can't see this without the laser beam. It is particularly useful when dry firing (for obvious reasons) and is why I dry fire so often. Hey, dry firing is FREE.No need to bore you with how to be a better shooter; Youtube is an excellent resource. The many Youtube videos are like hiring your personal NRA expert that is on your beck and call 24/7. They cover stance, trigger, hand hold - all aspects of pistol control. I like Hickok but many have great points too.After two months, I'm slowly gaining accuracy. The biggest problem has been developing sufficient strength to hold the pistol steady and to be able to control my trigger pull without even a slight waver. Watching the experts on youtube, there is a long road ahead for this old codger. Patience and persistence.SUMMARYFor my circumstance, a cheap pistol laser has been a better investment than a bore sighter. The reasoning is that modern hand guns are delivered, shooting with excellent accuracy. Manufacturing tolerances give computer accuracy and factory testing on every weapon. This precludes having any "turkeys" in the market place.That said, any problems that surface on the range will be with the "whatever" that is firing the pistol. The solution is to find the exact problem and fix it quickly. This is where the pistol laser and expert training comes into play. Once the basic steps are known so old habits are erased, it is a matter of watching the laser on the target to identify any small problems remaining.Good luck, have fun. For me, developing accuracy requires diligence but is fun with the right training aids. NOTE: I like my Taurus 9mm but it is about 10 oz heavier than a comparable  Glock 19. In my novice opinion, the extra weight adds some stability but requires more muscle control for accuracy (my take after firing both for an afternoon.)

Most reviewers miss the purpose Mel Gibson had in making this film. This will explain it from a Christian perspective. The crucifixion of Christ is central to all believing Christians. It is their beginning, their end and their rock. Love or hate them, if you expect to understand them read this without developing opinions until the end.Bear with me as I have to lay some groundwork for you to understand my comment. I don't ask you to believe the Bible, only to understand the purpose of the film.The movie is meant for Christians. It is meant to show what Christ did for them and for everyone (whether they understand or not). The Bible was written over a period of 1400 years by 44 different people. It is complicated because it has a number of different messages or themes, of which I will not attempt to cover.For the purpose of this comment, what is central to the Bible are four basic threads. 1) It is a book of prophesy, mostly prophesy about the coming Christ (there are over 100 of these, all of which were fulfilled by Christ). 2) There is the story of his 3 year evangelism, in which He proved by miracles that He was the Christ (prophesied 100's of years earlier). 3) It describes Christ's sacrifice, death and resurrection (proving that Christ has power over death). 4) It describes what a Christian is to exhibit in their life (How they are to live).You may believe the Bible is a total fake, I am not defending it. But that does not change what I state above. Those four threads exist in the Bible. That is fact. I need to say that in order to explain the reason for the film.The Bible states that God sent Christ, His Son, to be a sacrifice for all. Before Christ, Jews had to sacrifice animals to absolve them of sins but animals were not perfect sacrifices. Christ had to be a PERFECT sacrifice. He was (Proven by Jewish history and their losing their homeland). Also to fulfill the prophesy given 700 years before His arrival (see Isaiah chapter 53), that He had to suffer the terrible punishment you see in Gibson's film.Let me pause. Non-Christians will find it implausible, inexcusable and abhorrent that any god would be part of the acts seen in the film or in my statements. To make it even more confusing, God is a loving God. He wants only good for everyone. Talk about something inexplainable!It is a waste of time for me to try and explain or defend this. You can discard the Bible as fiction but it is what is written on its pages. In that, there can be no dispute.The Bible is unique in history. There is no book that is a compilation of different authors where they all agree and present a cohesive message, let alone doing it over a period of more than a thousand years.So what was the purpose behind such a violent, unpleasant film?Christians understand that Christ was a sacrifice for their sin, allowing them to enter the Kingdom of God. But before seeing the film, I did not really comprehend it on a visceral level. If I am an example, the film is a success; "It was important that I experience His sacrifice". If you feel that you, your church or group will benefit from a better understanding of Christ's sacrifice, get the film. It has no equal in its scope or purpose.That was the purpose of "The Passion of Christ." It shows the price that God and Christ really paid so that Christians could enter the kingdom.I can hear someone saying, "Whoop Eee Doo." See! That proves my point that most reviewers do not understand the film. Some will feel my comment is crazy, stupid or worse. That does not change the truth presented here. Remember that I only present what the Bible states, not asking you to believe it.If you question me and want to investigate on your own, go to the Internet. There is a free Biblical resource that will help you look into it. In your search engine, type "eSword" to find the site. I've always believed that the truth is revealed when you understand all sides of an issue.If you want to look into the existence of Christ, investigate the "Shroud of Turin" on the Internet. It is believed by many that this is the shroud that covered Christ when His body was laid in the tomb. It is a controversial but a fascinating story.If you want to look into whether history and archeology back up the Bible, look up "Ron Wyatt" on the Internet. He was an amateur student of Biblical history and discovered some interesting facts. As with all things relating to the Bible, everything has its naysayers so you can come to your own conclusions.

This is a Chinese made legally licensed Meyerco product. Meyerco makes a quality line of knives and also sells their US made line (for a lot more $$$). This 3 inch (closed) knife generally shows good workmanship and has a quality 440C stainless steel blade (holds an edge and sharpens easily). For the price it is a really good buy. That is the plus side.The Negative is in how it opens. It is an A/O or assisted open. It does that but not well. First, a 4 inch knife is easier to open one handed than a 3 inch (this one). That means the assist really has to work well. I took it apart to determine the problem and see if it could be improved. The answer is yes (to some extent) but I do not recommend it unless you have some skill in knife design.The design of the spring is unique, giving the blade opening force a "double kick." It should open fully after the initial push from the thumb. Instead it hangs at about 130 degrees (0 degrees being closed and 180 degrees full open). This forces you to push the blade full open. Doing than brings your thumb into contact with the very sharp blade (uh huh). Maybe a better solution is to use arm and wrist action so centrifugal force gives additional momentum to the blade. I don't like that because everyone within 50 feet will know you opened your "quick open" knife - It's like shouting hey I got this deadly knife and I'm a bad a**." Now this takes a little practice as you can easily lose your grip and the knife goes flying. Hopefully you don't have to retrieve it from that blond's dress with the plunging neckline. Anyway, you get the idea.Note: At this writing, the picture does not show the serrated blade, which is about 75% serrated with a straight blade section at the tip and again at the heel.Summary: It is a really nice little knife with a design problem. I do not believe Blackie Collins designed his knife to have this problem, so I blame the Chinese execution of his design. I hope the heat treating of the blade was better as that is more important than the quality of the blade steel (Properly heat treated, 440C should have a hardness in the range of 58RC). Sorry, I can't test that.

"Atlas Shrugged" was written to voice a possible future political climate as Ayn Rand foresaw it. It is similar to George Orwell's "1984" in that their main theme includes a controlling  government. But Atlas Shrugged's purpose, government and its scope are very different. The tongue-in-cheek humor and allusion in 1984 is missing from Atlas Shrugged.  1984 was written in 1948; Atlas Shrugged in 1957. Both are well written. Both, in order to make their story work, weave in a little science fiction.Atlas Shrugged is also available in audio book form, for those intimidated by its 1000 pages.Atlas Shrugged is far more complex -- and long than 1984. The government's purpose in both is similar but Atlas Shrugged begins with a normal country similar to that of 1950 America (sans the influence and control of the Constitution). Powerful politicians, business leaders and scientists are the policy makers. These "behind the scene insiders" sell their form of "government" to a gullible, ignorant and self serving public, using two tried and true political ploys: (1) to each according to their ability and to each according to their need (translation: class warfare); (2) for the good of the people.The protagonists are also powerful business leaders except they oppose the idea of government control over the individual. They fight for individual freedom for all as outlined in the original Constitution.A note to younger readers: Rand's style uses lengthy character development and conversational interaction. Although a real "page turner," it is not the fast paced modern style of writing. It is important to the story (especially to her conservative views) but at times seems a bit wordyAs a novel, it is a great read and I do not want to spoil it. I only give you the essence of the book so you can decide if it is a book for you. I leave the details for your exploration and discovery. To accept an abbreviated summation of Atlas Shrugged is like looking at a picture of the Grand Canyon and believing that you done "been 'dere, done 'dat."Atlas Shrugged's real purpose unveils the weaknesses and consequences of liberal thinking. It is an accelerated picture of the politics from the 1930's, through to a fairly accurate mirror of what Ms Rand foresaw would exist in today's politics - and beyond. Happily, it does not have a sad end.In a sentence, Atlas Shrugged is an epic novel of romance, mystery, conspiracy and intrigue. It is well written and gripping despite its technical and political weaknesses, which are easily overlooked. (Remember, it was written in the 1950's.) It is heavily influenced by its conservative author. This is so evident that a person steeped in liberal philosophy will find it most objectionable. Conservatives, independents and libertarians will find it thought provoking, controversial and enjoyable.In keeping with the liberal agenda of today's universities, 1984 was on my required reading list. Most people have heard of, if not read 1984 but few have heard of Atlas Shrugged.I mention the following to exemplify the political climate in the media and publishing world. There are two "top 100 lists" of America's greatest novels, both published in the late 1990's. Atlas Shrugged heads one list but deserves no mention in the other. One list was authored by the editorial board of Modern Library (associated with the publisher Random House) consisting of 11 authors (who graciously included a number of their own novels). The second is a poll of 200,000 selected readers. I leave it to your wisdom to select the one listing Atlas Shrugged #1.Ayn Rand was an influential conservative, ahead of her time. Today, there is a conservative "Think Tank" named after her. [...]

I replaced my type 'G' card with this 'N' card. Had a slower data flow than expected. A call to the router tech support suggested that a change to a 'N' card, matching the 'N' router, would probably solve the problem. It did and the speed doubled.Instalation was smooth, easy and quick.The card was the lowest price for a 'N' card and it has performed flawesly during the month it's installed. I recommend it.

INTROSorry for the length but the XXL550M is a complex device with many features and options. If you know a lot about GPS's, just read the PROS, CONS & SUMMARY. If you want details, this is organized by headings so you can easily skip to what interests you. Because of the misinformation, this turned into a review instead of a comment.Many of the other comments are misleading or plain wrong. I tried to correct the errors by including factual information. I have no axe to grind. I just like the XXL550M and feel it is a great value in a GPS. I hope this helps you save money and decide on a GPS.PROSIt does EVERYTHING well that others complain about! I can't think of a use this will not accomplish. Are they rating a different GPS? Mine is the XXL550M (free maps) - Hey, could it be that even tho I'm a hi-tech freak, maybe I've just mellowed into an easily satisfied old pansy.The XXL550M has an easy to read 5" screen, which is not too big - not too small; easy to program (improved software over the XXL540); easy to change the display for individual preference, including voice options and volume; screen display has many readout options to choose from including a compass; fast and accurate map display; the XXL550 has a large 2GB of non-replaceable memory (memory can't be added); automatically adjusts for day/night viewing; easy to move from car to car; good TomTom website support; comes with a nice plastic screen protector; updates with the latest software and maps FREE.NOTE: It comes with a "stick on" dash mounting disk. This is important for those in Calif and states that do not allow windshield mounted GPS. (For those just driving through, get or make a large bean bag for a temporary GPS mounting.) It also is good for those who want the GPS closer than a windshield mounting. The disk mounts permanently but the XXL550M can still be moved from car to car. There is a well written, abbreviated manual that gets you going and a complete manual on the Internet. Also included are two cables, one for the car and one for the computer. Best of all, it keeps me from getting lost.CONSNo cons. But you must have (or have a friend, or local library?) with HI SPEED Internet in order to download the software options that make this GPS really usable.My first GPS so can't compare to others but it far exceeds my expectations. It gives me features I did not even think about.SCREEN, FEATURES & OPTIONSExcellent graphics (you can read really tiny 8 point type - but you have toget close to the screen); screen changes automatically for day/night viewing; brightness sets to your preference; Street names given well ahead of arrival; many voice options including manual and automatic volume with auto speed.TomTom encourages users to give feedback on map errors. If my experience is an indication, software updates are frequent (after 3 days TomTom had new free updates when I connected the XXL550 to their website again. The battery must be replaced by TomTom. I expect its life to be about 5 years with proper use. Most battery powered devices will operate on external power even when the battery is worn out. See use and care for Li-Ion batteries. One thing do not keep the GPS on constant charge. Let it fully charge and discharge regularly.I deliberately went way off course and it shows you the way out of any hole you can dig. But it does have a compass too, for those with "tracker blood" in their veins. The XXL550 gets warm (not hot) while in use so it must use a lot of power. The battery is rated for 2-3 hours but use the usb cable connected to the cigarette lighter (all necessary cables are included)Too many options to list here, optional screen colors, voices, displays, many  more. There are extra cost options for finding the cheapest gas and other perks you might find useful.It does anything you should need, except to avoid traffic jams. This is covered with an extra cost device and a software package but I know nothing about it.One thought: It seems that an ability to report on traffic jams is time sensitive, very complex and difficult to accomplish quickly, so think about that before you buy. The XXL550 has a usb port, so be careful. DON'T buy this traffic device if it has a pin connection.5" hi-resolution screen (320 X 240 pix) - good enough for my ancient eyes. I like the 3D view but 2D available.Definitely buy the "M" model 4 the free maps. Maps give a GPS its style and usability. New maps don't just give more accuracy and add data.SATELLITE SIGNAL & WEBSITE SUPPORTThe antenna worked well inside my house. Anytime you connect the XXL550M to your computer the TomTom website lets you update with their latest free software. TomTom also offers you the extra cost options. I got a $10 coupon to encourage me to buy, buy, buy.Getting on the TomTom website (the XXL550 connects automatically when hooked to an Internet enabled computer). It may present some problems for anyone not used to how the Internet works. Read the download manual carefully, follow the website instructions and you will be OK. Some things on the TomTom website took a little "figuring" but using the download manual was able to do everything without needing Tech Support. (Thus I have no idea about Tech's abilities.)Other Thoughts: To access all features, register and download the TomTom HOME software (must connect to HI SPEED Internet). Nice free features there. This model has 2GB memory, large enough to load most but not all options.PROGRAMMINGSuper easy to program for trips. (My wife programmed our trip - even before we set up the GPS on the Internet) The well thought out design makes it very user friendly. The included manual is short but you can download a complete manual for the "XL" GPS (It's the same as the XXL550M except for screen size.) Didn't check if it will program a complex trip with multiple stops but with the ease in programming, I don't see that to be a problem. It does offer an automatic choice to reverse your trip and send you home with no programming needed.MOUNTINGThe window suction mounting device and GPS makes a secure mounting duo when you are sure to lock the GPS into its mount (It does take two hands). The XXL550M has metal spring clips for a secure mount, not cheap plastic that wears out; a well made device. Mounting design makes it easy to remove the GPS, hiding it when leaving the car. The battery lets you take it on a hike but it still thinks you are a car (sorry hiking trails are not on the map). The window mount is easily removed so you can take it on another car.It goes without saying that the windshield should be cleaned before mounting the suction cup (moisten the plastic cup for better adhesion).COMPETITIONI looked at other GPS's and when this is on sale it is by far the best value for the money (Garmin look out). The map is a no-frills but extremely complete and super accurate map. Having used computer maps for years, it is not possible to have a map that is free from errors, so am sure there are some. Hey, it's is not a perfect world.SUMMARYThe GPS also gives an option for driving speed ('course my speedo works too & it's lots bigger). Speed is updated about every 2-3 seconds. This means the GPS updates street names, car position in that same time frame. When streets are close and driving fast, you can "over drive" the map data but it did surprisingly well in our 500mi test trip. There may be options other GPS's have but this has more than I need.Considering the distance to and from GPS satellites (a couple thousand miles give or take a city block), and the calculations required of the tiny XXL550M computer, I am surprised at its speed.NOTE: Be sure to download the TomTom free, "speed" package. It improves the ability of the XXL550M to access satellite signals and gives it a faster reporting time.Map detail amazes me - it locates me within a few feet. A GPS can only give longitude/latitude; the XXL550M's computer has to take that raw info, map it and show an actual map location - within several feet. All in 2 seconds! WOW

My first ML-2855ND printer was DOA because the interface circuits on the board were bad. This made it impossible to set up.  I called Samsung tech support because this problem is very unusual (in 25 years working with computers it was a first to have something that seemed to function but would not set up). The printer comes with both usb and network ports and I tried both.They did a quick phone analysis and determined that they would "fix" it for the paltry sum of $169. I said that I just bought the printer and wasn't there a guarantee? The response was $169 please. Mine was "I don't think so."Samsung states that there is a warranty but this may be some of the new definition for "transparency" being floated by some of our leaders. If not, it sure is good old double speak.I contacted the retailer and they exchanged it, even paying for return shipping. This is one of the largest Internet suppliers and I give them "Egg"cellent feedback for their support.To be fair, I have several Samsung products, including the ML-2855ND printer. All have given me good service but I have become VERY leary of buying Samsung products because of this experience. With this printer, I decided to pay extra for a one year warranty with my replacement printer.It has given me good service for the month I have had it. It installed easily, is quiet and I have no complaints. Will I buy another Samsung product? I honestly don't know. If I do, it will be with great caution and I have to figure in the extra cost for extra warranty.It is a replacement for a very similar "Brother" duplex laser printer (main board circuit failure). It should not have died after only 2 years of service. NOTE: Electronic circuits usually fail within 3 to 6 months and then tend to last forever. (The Brother printer was the exception.)[Since I had just bought a new toner cartridge for the Brother, I tried to get it fixed (over $400 and then to buy a new Brother over $300).] This printer was under $160 with the warranty and shipping.Unfortunately, I must give the printer a bad rating because of Samsung. I have never had this kind of experience dealing with computer manufacturer's since I started in this business in the early 1980's.Evaluate this as you deem fit. I have tried to be fair with the printer.

This review addresses three areas of a Dake Bible: (1) style and format; (2) size and quality of the versions and (3) what to expect from a Dake Bible (per your Christian growth).As you will see from other reviewers, it is a controversial Bible and we do NOT recommend it as a first study Bible. Right up front, it is impossible for you to determine its worth unless you compare a Dake to other resources. Bibles are very personal choices. Please understand that we believe you can find value in most everything but that also requires enough knowledge to separate truth from fiction.We also mention other resources for comparison, which seem to be absent in other reviews here.FIRST, what to expect from a Dake Bible.You may know that the author, a southern Pentecostal preacher (1902-1987) Finis Dake, devoted his life to creating it. Dake felt guided and inspired by the Holy Spirit to write this Bible. He only wrote comments when he believed he was directed by the Holy Spirit. This is more like a commentary, married to a Bible, than a study Bible. The Dake Bible is the exclusive property of the Dake organization.It is only available as the original King James. The notes are usually on the same page (referenced by verse) as the text, making it an easy reference. The Dake has many insightful comments that you will find informative. Although worthwhile, it is definitely not an "end all" resource.Dake also comes in a computer version (my wife uses this exclusively at home, only taking her Dake to church). Other computer Bibles are eSword (free, my preference); The Thompson Chain Reference DVD, Quick verse and others. Look for one than incorporates a STEP reader.Bibles with the Apocrypha include the Jerusalem Bible, which is similar to the NIV in literary style (our preference); the New Revised Standard Version with the Apocrypha by Henderson among others. Henderson publishes some wonderful Christian resources at affordable prices.If you are a student of the King James, also examine a Thompson Chain Reference Bible. Both this and the Dake are unique in that they represent a lifetime work. The Thompson is possibly the most comprehensive Bible as an all-in-one resource, with more depth than the Dake but lacking in Dake's personal and sometimes controversial touch. They are so different, they cannot be compared. The Chain Reference's disadvantage is that it is difficult to learn and effectively use - but worth the effort. Note, there are study courses (link [...]) and a DVD computer program is available.DO NOT buy the NIV version of Thompson's. It is a remarkably poor attempt to marry Thompson's references to the radically different NIV translation.If you are inclined to more English language friendly, translations - consider a Life Application Study Bible or an Open Bible, (New King James). We stop here not because there are no other good study Bibles but because this is not a book about Bibles. We own over a dozen different Bibles and have had three Dake Bibles.Because Dake's notes are extensive (they are longer than the Bible text), we suggest getting the expanded or large print version, unless you have the eyes of an eagle (even in the large version, the print of the notes is small). NOTE: None of the Dake users we know accept ALL of Dake's Biblical interpretations.For these reasons, we strongly suggest that you borrow or at least peruse a book store copy before buying one. Also, read our section on "size and quality" before coming to a decision. We are very UNHAPPY with our latest Dake. Some, who buy a Dake Bible on impulse, wind up putting it on a shelf.The bottom line is that (with reservation) this can expand your Christian faith, providing you are a serious student of the Bible. If you want to really understand God's Word, you will find a Dake useful but for more "eye opening" revelations, read or hear from books and tapes by Messianic Rabbis.A knowledgeable Messianic Jew can put together the Old and New Testaments in ways not possible with almost all Christian authors, including Dake.Some examples: The life of Jesus met all of the rules Jews required for a betrothal and marriage (if you aren't sure of its significance, please look it up). The crucifixion of Jesus met all the requirements for a ceremonial sacrifice. There are many, many more, few are even on a Christian's radar. The value here is that it will strengthen your understanding of Jesus, His love for us all and the special place Jesus has for Jews and how integrated He was in Jewish life and culture. Jesus did not turn His back on Jews, rather He offered God to all men.SIZE AND QUALITYFor size, we much prefer the larger versions (we are getting old). For type, we buy genuine leather (money available) because they last for decades. That is until we bought our latest Dake. Their genuine leather version was made it China. China makes some of the world's finest harmonicas; we don't generally trash Chinese products. They are more than capable, when they put their mind to producing quality.DO NOT BUY THE DAKE, GENUINE LEATHER BIBLE.Save your money and get imitation leather, vinyl, hardback or the DVD computer version. We hope the other Bibles are not made in China. You may want to check on this before making your purchase.It is sub-standard. The leather is not top grain but a sorry cut of leather. The gold, "edge page" guilding is rapidly wearing off our new Dake. In comparison, we have no problem with any of our US made Bibles; some are more than 30 years old. The leather of this cheap Dake's remains stiff, with a plastic feel not characteristic of any but the cheapest cuts of leather. This is despite our repeated treating the leather with the best leather softening products available. A top grain leather is soft and supple. With occasional treating, good leather improves with age and does not deteriorate. My first Bible, a Scofield Study Bible, with a genuine leather cover is in marvelous condition after almost four decades. Also, all of our other leather Bibles have a facing leather inside cover. The cheap, Dake Bible even messes up on this standard feature.We wrote the Dake organization asking for a comment but were ignored.STYLE AND FORMATThe large print version necessarily expands the comments (large print takes up more space than small). This means that more of the comments must be shifted to other pages. We mention this because one of the nice features of a Dake is that much of the commentary is on the same page as the referenced Bible text. Look both over as this becomes a personal decision.

I'm using the Marantz SR6009 as the centerpiece of my audio system. To cut to the chase, it is a fine sounding, well provisioned, and fully featured receiver for playing recorded music. Once you complete the initial setup, the SR6009 is a joy to listen to. Do keep in mind, though, that this receiver does not have Tape Monitor inputs and outputs, as used to be the standard for stereo equipment.Now then, on to the details for those interested...My Reviewing Perspective*Prior to obtaining the SR6009, I was using a Harman/Kardon receiver with a pair of 2-way Paradigm 3se speakers, a turntable, a cassette tape deck, a 10-band per channel equalizer, and two CD players.*I mostly listen to non-music radio broadcasts, both AM and FM, rock, jazz, and classical. I don't like a lot of low end and set the midrange as the lowest part of my equalization curve. For music, CDs are my primary source, followed by vinyl, self-recorded cassettes, and digital files.*Most of my digital music has been self-ripped in a lossy format for mobile listening. I don't own many commercially produced MP3, AAC, or other digital music files.Setup*It is easiest to first setup the SR6009 with a TV/monitor, a Wi-Fi network, and, if you own one, an Apple iOS device available. When the receiver is powered up for the first time, a few screens take you through the steps required to establish a wireless connection and do some basic configuration.*Using Apple Airplay on iOS makes joining your wireless network especially simple.*Once the SR6009 is capable of joining your Wi-Fi network, all the setup, configuration, and maintenance settings are accessible via a web browser. Anybody who has administered a Wi-Fi router through a web browser will find working with the Marantz browser function to be familiar and straightforward.*Something I was not accustomed to from my old system was having to manually associate specific input jacks with each output setting. That is, I had to, for example, set the SR6009 to use "Analog Audio In #5" when "CD" is selected on the front of the receiver. I don't view this as a flaw, of course, because it increases setup flexibility. But it's something to keep in mind, especially if you are upgrading from older equipment as I was.Operation*Since I'm using the SR6009 as an audio receiver only, my setup differs from home theatre setups because I do not have a TV or monitor permanently connected to the receiver.*The combination of the remote control, the front display, and the browser-based management function are sufficient for full control of the receiver (note that the Marantz app for smartphones does not provide full access to settings, so you cannot rely on the app for tweaking and adjusting).*Even though the front panel and display are minimalist, using and controlling the SR6009 in day-to-day use is intuitive and uncomplicated.What I Like*There is an extensive set of input and output jacks, which provides lots of possibilities for expansion and reconfiguration.*Phono inputs and a grounding terminal are built in. Viva vinyl!*Streaming music from my iMac (running OS X Yosemite) and iDevices (iOS 8) is extremely easy and seamless using AirPlay.*I have my primary CD player connected through one of the Coaxial Digital inputs, and I've been rediscovering my CD collection. Most of my discs now sound richer and more detailed. To my ears, Marantz has put an excellent digital-to-analog converter into the receiver.*Most importantly, the SR6009 produces clear and pure sound, with an amplifier that handles highly dynamic music with aplomb. It performs very well with the kinds of music I listen to, at the (often loud) volumes I enjoy.Caveats*There is no Tape Monitor functionality, so I've retired my standalone equalizer. This was a conscious tradeoff: I now have slightly less granular control over the output tone but have gained a direct digital connection from CD player to receiver (the built-in equalizer function has nine bands at 63 Hz, 125 Hz, 250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1 kHz, 2 kHz, 4 kHz, 8 kHz, and 16 kHz).*The lack of Tape Monitor also means owners of three-head tape decks lose the ability to monitor recording quality in real time.*There is only one set of Pre Out jacks. Again, this can affect people with tape decks because another, more frequently used component might need the connection.*While special equalization for compressed digital files is available ("M-DAX"), lossy formats still do not sound very good at higher volumes. They're somewhat improved at the high and low ends, but the midrange remains fuzzy, distorted, and indistinct. Don't expect miracles...*If you do not keep your Wi-Fi network running 24/7 and the SR6009 is set to maintain wireless access in Standby mode, the SR6009 must be manually rejoined to the network after your router powers-up (this seems to happen because the receiver cannot change its IP address when set this way).The Bottom Line*The Marantz SR6009 is a well-designed, fine sounding audio receiver. It is a great choice for bringing older sound systems into the present day, unless you are strongly attached to making recordings on a tape deck or love playing with your graphic equalizer. Four stars.----------Update (April 2015): No problems to report after two months of daily use and two firmware updates over Wi-Fi.Update (July 2015): No problems to report after several months of daily use.Update (November 2015): No problems to report (still using daily). No firmware updates have been needed since the first half of this year.

Icebreaker's Drifter Hood is a very comfortable, pared down midlayer or light outer layer. It's great for times when you might think about throwing on a fleece pullover but don't want all the zips, cords, pockets, loud colors, and other features that scream OUTDOORS GEAR!!!I do have a couple of caveats. First, Icebreaker has decreased the wool content of the fabric for this season (Fall 2014). I own both an older and the current version; the newer material feels less wooly and more slippery-synthetic. I think the fabric is equally comfortable but it doesn't drape as nicely as before. Second, the Drifter Hood has a slimmer cut than other Icebreaker garments. I usually take a Medium with Icebreaker but I found I like the fit of a Large size Drifter better.Four stars, for a wool-blend top that is great for lounging, breezy evenings on a patio, or hanging out at a brewpub.

I'm using the Speck StyleFolio with a first generation iPad Mini. The case is a fine solution for when you don't want to drag around a heavy, super-rugged case (like a Pelican or OtterBox) but need more protection than a simple screen protector/stand (such as the Apple Smart Cover).Things I like*Not heavy or bulky*A plastic shell fully encompasses the back of the iPad and holds the case on very securely*Many landscape oriented tilt positions, including for typing*Snapping closure both keeps the case closed and locks the cover out of the way when holding tablet in portrait positions*Full access to all ports and buttons maintainedCaveats*The case doesn't support portrait oriented tilt positions. You have to hold the iPad in your hands.*Using the rear camera is awkward because the front flap of the case covers the lens when the case is open. In order to take pictures or shoot video, you need to partially fold the flap and hold it away from the camera opening.*My case arrived with sloppy or frayed stitching in a few places. Speck provides a 1-year warranty so if the cover does begin to self-destruct, I hope it's within the next twelve months.Bottom line: 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 because I don't use the rear camera on my iPad much and the poor stitching, while somewhat disappointing, does not make the case unusable out of the box.

I am using the TP-LINK UH700 USB hub with my PS4. Since Sony only provides two USB ports on the console, a hub is a must-buy for anybody who wants to do more than just plug in game controllers. I've got a couple of DualShocks, a Turtle Bay audio transmitter, Turtle Bay headphones, and a Microsoft keyboard hooked up to the hub.Things I like*Slim, compact footprint. The hub is about half the size of a game disc case in length, width, and thickness.*Independently powered. This means less wear and tear on the PS4's power supply and less heat to disperse from the console. I would rather replace a USB hub than send in the PS4 for an inconvenient and expensive repair job.*On-off switch. Unlike many powered USB hubs, the UH700 has a power switch that lets you turn off the hub when it's not being used.One minor thing that would make the UH700 better would be a slimmer adapter. The supplied adapter is rather bulky and takes up a lot of space on a plug strip. This is just a quibble and doesn't affect the hub's functionality at all.Four stars.

Anybody who goes to see live music that is pumped through a PA system, even in bars and small clubs, is familiar with the GIG DILEMMA: I know it's incredibly flippin' loud in here but these foam cylinders make it sound like we're 50 feet underwater! So a lot of the time, you end up taking out your earplugs and dealing with ringing ears for a couple of days or, worse, long-term hearing damage.The DUBS Acoustic Filters are a great solution to this problem. They are designed to provide both less overall noise reduction (foam plugs typically claim around 30 dB while the DUBS are rated at 12 dB) and better musical fidelity than cheap roll-and-insert plugs.  Now you can "turn the volume down" a bit at a show but still be able to hear high and middle range sounds. Ride cymbal fans, rejoice!Wearing the DUBS feels similar to wearing earbuds or a Bluetooth earpiece. A spherical soft-rubber gasket holds the DUBS in your ear canal. Unfortunately only one size of gasket is included, so you're stuck if the plugs feel uncomfortable or don't fit well. Further, a lanyard or neck cord attachment points would be a significant improvement. If you drop a plug or one falls out of your ear, it's going to hit the ground. That's not a good thing at a crowded, sticky-floored joint or in a muddy, trampled festival field.Now for the most important thing: how do the DUBS sound? To my ears, they are biased towards the low end, with slightly boomy bass. If you already own Beats headphones or think subwoofers are one of the greatest inventions ever, you'll like wearing DUBS.Bottom line: DUBS Acoustic Filters are a vast improvement over foam earplugs...but could use a couple of minor design changes. Four stars, particularly if you always hang out near the bass bins or love kick drum.----------Note:If you prefer a more even and balanced sound, take a look at Etymotic Research ER20 earplugs--I've owned a pair for several years and like them as well.

What is this disc? Is it an album? Is it a jam session? Or is it a document of an ephemeral work of art that cannot ever be exactly duplicated? Or, as some would have it, is this an elaborate joke at the expense of Savages and Bo Ningen fans?Well, if you agree that a signed urinal or an image of a dusty piece of glass can belong in a gallery, Words to the Blind might be to your liking. As a live, Dada-influenced event performed in an art space, this 37-minute work is deliberately meant to challenge and provoke listeners. It's about as far from a fist-pumping, lighter-waving, sing-along gig as you can get. The sleeve even includes a manifesto and artistic statement of purpose for the record.Musically the piece owes more to Sonny Sharrock and electric Miles Davis than it does to rock. It's simultaneously driving and complex, with overlapping, sometimes oppositional playing. Things never devolve into total cacophony or chaos though; both bands keep to a fairly linear, accesible path throughout. Listeners don't have to worry about keeping up or possibly getting lost as they do with, say, Ornette Coleman or Sun Ra.So, yes, I do like Words to the Blind. But keep in mind I also like free jazz and Surrealist art and literature...

The Woods was the sound of (three) radioactive elements kept in close proximity imploding and the resulting catastrophic explosion that destroyed everything around it.  Turbulent, manic, and distorted, raging with the heat and light of a thousand suns, Sleater-Kinney's last album was, above all, UNHINGED and seemingly the apocalyptic end of a rrritous era.But somehow, somehow, they're back! And on this album, No Cities to Love, S-K has managed to hang on to all the power and energy that elevated The Woods over their previous work. The difference is now it's used to build instead of to destroy. Gone is the obscuring veil of fuzz and over-compression, leaving a walloping yet incredibly precise sound.The time apart allowed all three band members to add even more to their formidable chops. Carrie Brownstein's voice remains passionate but is now much more controlled, Janet Weiss' drumming is even more agile and inventive, and Corin Tucker can now swing it on her vocals like an indie rock Ella Fitzgerald (check out Gimme Love, it's almost like she's scatting with the drums and guitars, yow!).Intricate arrangements and amazing musicianship don't have to lead to self-indulgence, though. This record is much more concise and pared down than The Woods. None of the songs meander or contain anything superfluous. Every element fits into the whole and serves a purpose...at 32 minutes in total length, there just isn't time for wanking, noodling around, or tangents.Don't believe any of this? Check out the samples. Then pick up a copy of the album. Longtime fans will love the chance to hear fresh material from a band that seemed like it had called it quits. New listeners will be rewarded by a set with crystalline sonics, great hooks, and impassioned playing and singing that is a fine entry point to Sleater-Kinney.Four stars.

Ibex, for anybody unfamiliar with it, is a Vermont company that specializes in wool garments and accessories. Almost its entire product line is manufactured in the USA.Ramble pants are made from heavy weight wool. While both the raw wool and the twill fabric are sourced from outside the US, according to the Ibex website, the garment itself is made in Northern California. The grey color is not a pure grey; in strong light it  takes on a slight brown/orange cast (you can see this effect for yourself in the Ramble's product pictures on the REI website).The construction is very sturdy. The waist fastens using a rubber-rimmed snap, which is more robust and reliable than a sewn-on button. The high-stress areas at the top and bottom of the pockets are reinforced with rivets, as on Levi's jeans. All the stitching and sewing is high quality. The Ramble, with proper care, should last for years and years.In actual use, these pants are very comfortable to wear. They are cut like rock climbing pants, with plenty of room for a base layer underneath and a loose, mobile fit in the upper legs. The upper inseam/crotch is gusseted for even more freedom of movement. Overall, the look is clean and tailored enough for informal workplaces but retains enough of an outdoorsy feel for travel and active uses. And even though they're unlined, the pants don't ever feel itchy because they're made of merino wool.The only things I would change would be to add two more belt loops, have the factory do a better job of clipping loose threads after sewing is completed (at this price point I expect a cleaner finished garment), and offer short, regular, and long inseam options. These are quibbles, in any case, and don't take much away from a very comfortable, functional, and warm pair of pants.Four stars.

I tried the Oxo Good Grips Shower/Tub Drain Protector as a replacement for a drain cover with a different, flatter design. The Protector was placed in a shower/tub combo.I've returned to using my older cover because the Oxo Protector does not stay in place over the drain as well, especially when water is flowing from the faucet spigot directly onto the Protector. Even though the Oxo has a weight on the top, its bottom lip is not wide enough to keep it from frequently shifting out of position.A wider lip would make the Drain Protector a very good product. The current design, however, does not work well in my bathroom. If I had a stall shower or a tub where the drain was offset from the taps, I think I would like it a lot better.Three stars--it does work nicely once in its proper place over the drain.

I liked the Edge Thumb Grips for PS4 controllers until I discovered a huge design flaw. They do improve the feel of the thumb sticks and add a nice non-slip surface. The problem is that the Thumb Grips come off too easily while playing. When you're doing something intense, like boss battles or melee combat, that involves pushing a stick hard in one direction or rapidly moving the stick between extremes, a Grip pops off way too often. That's not a good thing.Two stars, for an accessory that is nice to use during normal game play but too often becomes a distraction at critical moments.

I'm using the Belkin MiXiT UP Charge/Sync cable in purple with an Apple 12W charger, an iPhone 5c, an iPhone 5s, and a first-generation iPad Mini. It does exactly what it's supposed to: charge these devices without any hassles or problems.An excellent feature of this cable, unlike with some other third-party Lightning cables, is that both the USB and Lightning plugs are slim and low profile, just like they are on Apple cables. This means the plugs work with all cases and folios nicely.I am satisfied with the both the build quality and functionality of the MiXiT UP Charge/Sync cable. I also like having a cable that isn't a boring white color for a change.Four stars.----------NoteAll devices are running iOS 8.1.1 at the time of the writing of this review.

This thick all-wool coat is a great piece for anybody who wants a comfortable and subtly styled outer layer...and is a little nostalgic for that high school classic, the letterman jacket.The Europa has a generous, boxy cut with plenty of room to spare, especially in the sleeves (sound familiar, former varsity athletes?). Details are sparse; this garment is unlined and has only two exterior handwarmer pockets. All the zippers (one main, two pocket) are high quality YKK chain zippers that slide easily. The main attraction, of course, is the loden wool. It is a sturdy, dense fabric that is very effective at holding in warmth. It's a little rough to the touch but a cool thing is that you can feel the lanolin in the wool fibers.Overall, the Ibex Europa is a nice casual jacket for around town use. It is understated and mellow and cozy. I do think it's too bulky and too minimally featured for demanding outdoors or non-cushy travel use though.Four stars. (And it's made in the USA!)

I tested the Netgear Nighthawk X4 router on this setup:iMac i7, Snow Leopard (wired, administrator)iMac G4, Leopard (wired)"Fat" PlayStation 3 (wired)PlayStation 4 (wired)DSL broadband---iPod Touch, fourth generationiPhone 5siPhone 5cKindle Fire HDXKindleiPad MiniMy Review Perspective*I upgraded from a 2 1/2 year old Linksys DSL/WiFi router. All the devices I connect to the Nighthawk X4 were previously configured for the Linksys router's wired/wireless network.*The i7 iMac is my primary machine and the one I use to administrate the wired and wireless networks provided by the router.*I'm not an engineer or a tech geek.
