As such, I won't be discussing bandwidth, throughput, error rates, or other quantitative measurements in this review.Setup:*Setup and configuration on my administrator iMac was very simple. I used the "Genie" automated setup. It was able to automatically configure both WAN and LAN settings on its own. Total time: about 5 minutes.*During setup, the application asked for the DSL login information I use with my ISP.*Genie downloads a router management application to your computer that must be installed before setup is 100% complete. The app is about 50 MB. Unfortunately, it doesn't run on Snow Leopard but it doesn't seem to be necessary for operating and accessing the router.*My G4 iMac and PS3 were able to access the network over Ethernet immediately after plugging them into the router.Pros:*The power adapter has a narrow, rectangular profile. Anybody using a plug strip will appreciate the adapter's skinny footprint.*According to the Shields Up firewall checking website (grc,com), the built-in firewall is set to complete stealth mode by default.*In addition to using Genie, the router can be configured via web browser. Browser-based configuration also provides access to advanced settings.*The browser-based management screens are easy to read, understand, and navigate.*The router offers a secure (WPA2) guest wireless signal that is hived off from the rest of the network.Cons:*This router is pretty big, about the size of a ream of letter-sized paper, and has four antennas that stick up from it. It ain't pretty and you can't really hide it from view. *There isn't a way to change the login name used to configure the router (it is easy to change the password, though).*There are a lot of lights on top of the router. When the router has a lot going on, all the flashing and brightness can be distracting. There is a switch on the back panel, though, that turns off all the lights except for a power indicator.Operation:*The router takes a lot longer than my old router to start up from a powered down state. This won't bother anybody who leaves their router on 24/7.*No problems with the wired connections to my DSL modem, desktop computers, and PS3.*No problems with the connections to my wireless devices.*I live in a densely populated area--both people and WiFi networks--and the router seems to be effective at both avoiding interference and maintaining contact with whatever is connected to it.*The signal quality is stronger and more stable than with my old router. Rooms that used to need a WiFi repeater for good connectivity now receive a decent signal.*Both high bandwidth activities, such as streaming video, and general `Net surfing are handled well by the router.*Multiple connections, wired and wireless, are handled well by the router. Lower priority devices will experience slowdowns when the network has multiple users but that's by design! The important thing is that the person watching a movie or playing an online game won't be affected much when someone else just wants to do a quick email check or sync a Kindle bookmark.Bottom line: The Netgear Nighthawk X4 is a fine router for Mac users. It is just as easy to setup as an Apple product. It provides a robust signal in both the 2.4 and 5 GHz bands, even in an environment full of other WiFi networks and devices. Four stars.----------Update (February 2015): Now running OS X Yosemite 10.10.2. No problems to report.Update (May 2015): Also using with a MacBook Pro now. Both iMac and MacBook running OS 10.10.3. No problems to report.Update (July 2015): Now running 10.10.4. No problems to report.Update (September 2015): Now running 10.10.5. No problems to report.

I'm using this APLWL USB 2 cable, in the bright orange and soft plastic variation, with several Kindle devices for syncing and charging. It works as expected and has some nice features:*The orange cladding stands out from other cables, especially all those boring white-colored cables that come with Apple products*6 feet is a good length that provides a lot of flexibility when connecting to chargers, hubs, and computers*Soft rubbery plastic makes coiling and transporting the cable quick and easyFour stars for a sturdily built, highly functional cable.

I'm using the Sennheiser PX 685i headphones with an iPhone 5c.I like them. I think they produce nicely balanced, clear sound, are more comfortable to wear than earbuds (especially for long periods), and work well with Siri, phone functions, and voice-enabled apps.However, it is worthwhile looking at the negative reviews here too. These 'phones clearly don't fit every ear shape comfortably. And if you are somebody who loves lots of bass, likes the extremely tight fit of earbuds or sound isolating earphones, or wants a blingy accessory that screams how expensive it is, these Senns aren't for you. But if you want a pair of headphones that let your music stretch out and breathe while also giving you full hands-free access to your iPhone--at a moderate price to boot!--give the PX 685i a try.Four stars.----------One more thing...Sennheiser should redesign the plug. If you use an iPhone case that does not leave a lot of open space around the headphone jack, the plug cannot be fully inserted into the jack. I had to switch from a case with a thick rim to a more minimalistic case. But I wasn't terribly bothered by that.

Ibex, for anybody unfamiliar with it, is a Vermont company that specializes in wool garments and accessories. Almost its entire product line is made in the USA.The Recycled Felted Wool Commuter Bag is a minimalist, cleanly designed and constructed messenger-style bag. The fabric is a felt made from a blend of recycled wool and artificial fibers. It is extremely lightweight and has a very visually interesting finish, with spots of various colors popping out from a grey background. It looks cool and is nice to touch.If you like lots of pockets, slots, zippers, and closures on your bags, the Commuter is not for you. It has two places to hold stuff: a slash pocket underneath the main flap and a roomy main compartment that has a soft cloth divider to create a laptop/tablet holder. That's pretty much it. The strap has an unmovable wool pad but can be adjusted on either end using the twin buckles. Closing the bag is simple yet effective. Just pull the two metal toggles (they're attached with elastic to the inside of the bag) through their respective metal-reinforced holes.Overall size and capacity fall in between Timbuk2 Small and Medium messenger bags. A laptop, some papers, and a small water bottle will fit nicely. Bulky or puffy items, however, don't work too well because the bag is fairly narrow and doesn't expand much.I think there are two important things to know before buying the Commuter. First, the felt is not waterproof or water resistant and the bag does not have any kind of waterproof liner. Second, the combination of the simple shoulder strap suspension and the lack of a cross-body strap make the Commuter unsuitable for serious bike riding. It's more of a public transit or car bag than a bike messenger bag, despite its styling.Other than that, I like carrying the Commuter Bag and it has a very unique look to it. Four stars, keeping its limitations in mind.

Simply put, the Irwin Vise-Grip High-Leverage pliers will make a worthy addition to your toolbox. They are sturdily made, have a pleasing heft that makes working with them extremely productive, and incorporate comfortable, non-slip grips on the handles.The lifetime guarantee is the icing on the cake. Buy once, use forever. Why waste time with cheaply made tools? Make the upfront investment and you (and your heirs) will be well served by these pliers for a long time to come.----------Note: the lanyard mentioned in some other reviews is NOT included with the pliers. It is an additional purchase.

Let's cut to the chase. The two big questions about this new, massively hyped jacket are:1. What is FullRange insulation?2. Why do I need the Nano-Air after Patagonia has been pushing its Capilene base layer-Regulator fleece midlayer-hard/soft shell outer layer system for so long?The first answer is simple. FullRange is Patagonia's proprietary version of Polartec Alpha insulation. Both FullRange and Alpha are extremely lightweight and breathable and remain warm when wet. FullRange, according to Patagonia, is stretchier than Alpha.Now, then, whether you need a Nano-Air depends mostly on if you often use an insulation layer between your fleece and shell layers. The Nano-Air is a big improvement over down or older synthetics if you do because the Nano-Air is just as light and thin as the others, the Nano-Air's insulation AND materials are fully breathable, and the Nano-Air's outer shell has a soft, cotton-like hand.What the Nano-Air is not good at is acting as an outer layer in windy, damp, or wet conditions. Its shell material is not waterproof and, by design, air moves very easily through all parts of the garment.In actual use, the Nano-Air is very comfortable and well designed. It has a fit similar to most insulation pieces, where it is roomier than most midlayers but still slim enough to go easily under a hard or soft shell jacket. There are three outer pockets, one chest and two waist (if you want two chest pockets, get the Nano-Air Hoody). Each pocket is welted so that the entire outside of the jacket is flat and free of obstructions. Another good feature is the drawstrings at the hem for cinching down the bottom part of the jacket. The cuffs, though, are not adjustable in any way.A welcome change from many other Patagonia jackets is that the main zipper is a chain zipper, not a coil zipper. Yes, it's a gear geek point but chain zippers are stronger than coil, require less force to slide, and are easy to repair out in the field.Cleaning the Nano-Air is easy, since you don't have to deal with down or worry about maintaining a pristine DWR finish. When it gets dirty or funky, you can just toss it into the washing machine. It air-dries fairly quickly but can also handle some time in a coolish dryer. Nice!Bottom line: the Nano-Air is a great improvement over Patagonia's older insulation layers, such as the Down Sweater and the Nano Puff Hoody. The one thing to keep in mind is that its outer shell is not the usual shiny, slippery, water resistant material found in similar garments. As such, the Nano-Air is not much of a defense against wind and water on its own. Don't leave home without a robust outer layer if you're not assured of fair weather!----------NoteComparison shoppers should take a look at the Marmot Isotherm Jacket. It uses Polartec Alpha and has a more traditional slick nylon outer material.

Let's cut to the chase. The two big questions about this new, massively hyped jacket are:1. What is FullRange insulation?2. Why do I need the Nano-Air after Patagonia has been pushing its Capilene base layer-Regulator fleece midlayer-hard/soft shell outer layer system for so long?The first answer is simple. FullRange is Patagonia's proprietary version of Polartec Alpha insulation. Both FullRange and Alpha are extremely lightweight and breathable and remain warm when wet. FullRange, according to Patagonia, is stretchier than Alpha.Now, then, whether you need a Nano-Air depends mostly on if you often use an insulation layer between your fleece and shell layers. The Nano-Air is a big improvement over down or older synthetics if you do because the Nano-Air is just as light and thin as the others, the Nano-Air's insulation AND materials are fully breathable, and the Nano-Air's outer shell has a soft, cotton-like hand.What the Nano-Air is not good at is acting as an outer layer in windy, damp, or wet conditions. Its shell material is not waterproof and, by design, air moves very easily through all parts of the garment.In actual use, the Nano-Air is very comfortable and well designed. It has a fit similar to most insulation pieces, where it is roomier than most midlayers but still slim enough to go easily under a hard or soft shell jacket. I've worn it under Marmot Alpinist, Nabu and Super Mica jackets and it has worked quite nicely. There are numerous outer pockets, two chest and two waist (no inner pockets, though). Each pocket is welted so that the entire outside of the jacket is flat and free of obstructions. Another good feature is the drawstrings at the hem for cinching down the bottom part of the jacket. The hood is soft and close fitting; it is meant to be worn under a helmet or hard shell hood. Both cuffs and hood have elastic around their openings but no Velcro, drawstrings, or cords for making adjustments.A welcome change from many other Patagonia jackets is that the main zipper is a chain zipper, not a coil zipper. Yes, it's a gear geek point but chain zippers are stronger than coil, require less force to slide, and are easy to repair out in the field.Cleaning the Nano-Air is easy, since you don't have to deal with down or worry about maintaining a pristine DWR finish. When it gets dirty or funky, you can just toss it into the washing machine. It air-dries fairly quickly but can also handle some time in a coolish dryer. Nice!Bottom line: the Nano-Air is a great improvement over Patagonia's older insulation layers, such as the Down Sweater and the Nano Puff Hoody. The one thing to keep in mind is that its outer shell is not the usual shiny, slippery, water resistant material found in similar garments. As such, the Nano-Air is not much of a defense against wind and water on its own. Don't leave home without a robust outer layer if you're not assured of fair weather!----------NoteComparison shoppers should take a look at the Marmot Isotherm Hoody. It uses Polartec Alpha and has a more traditional slick nylon outer material.

Yep, I'm going 5 stars on the Contigo Cortland Water Bottle. Why? I've been searching for something like this for a long time: a lightweight yet sturdy water bottle that is slightly smaller than a standard Nalgene, has a self-attached cap, and has a robust leakproof closure.I have the 24 oz. model of the Cortland. It has all the features I was looking for plus a built-in carabiner-style clip. It is now my go-to bottle whenever I don't want to carry a full-on quart sized bottle. The only time I would not recommend the Cortland is when you're somewhere that requires you to purify your own water. The interior of the cap has a lot of crevices and tight spaces, due to the sealing mechanism, and is difficult to keep sanitary without ready access to hot, clean water.Overall, Contigo has made an excellent bottle that is well suited for commuting, work, school, and most travel and outdoors use. The Cortland is now part of my core gear kit.

First, here's something important to know: if the product photo is accurate, the Nano Puff Hybrid on offer here is the first generation version from Fall 2012. That's actually a good thing because the current version has a much smaller fleece zone and has waist pockets instead of chest pockets. For active use, the earlier design is a lot more functional and this is an opportunity to get one.I own the original version in the blue/green color combo and, to be truthful, I love the way it looks but it hasn't become one of my favorite pieces. Why? Mainly because the Hybrid is stuck in the middle--it's not a full-on soft and toasty R2 fleece jacket but it's also not an all-over abrasion resistant, windproof Nano Puff jacket. I can't quite decide if it's best as an outer layer or a midlayer. It is incredibly lightweight and compressible, though, and is comfortable to wear. I mostly use it around town and for carry on-only airplane travel now. It does get a lot of comments due to its unique look!Three stars (unless you've spent the last few years lusting for a jacket that is mostly a Nano Puff in the front and a R2 in the back and lower torso...then it's a five star dream come true). Do keep in mind that the Hybrid has a slim, midlayer-like fit and isn't roomy enough to wear thick layers underneath.

I like using the Nano Puff Vest as an outer layer, either in 50˚F and above temperatures or as backup insulation during non-sweaty activities. The PrimaLoft fill is extremely lightweight and compressible, but the polyester shell and lining do not breathe very well. So, the vest holds heat in nicely but can quickly become clammy if you're working hard.The fit is fairly slim but not as tight as some of Patagonia's other technical garments, such as the R1 Hoody and Pullover or the Piton Hybrid Vest. It's actually pretty close to how classic Synchilla vests are cut, now that I'm thinking about it.Overall, the Nano Puff is well designed with the exception of the zippers. It is very easy to get the vest's fabric caught up in the zipper sliders, especially the pocket linings. You have to remember to be careful when opening and closing the pockets!Four stars for a good alternative to down-fill vests, particularly in rainy conditions.

If you're familiar with Patagonia's classic fleece vests, the best way to think of the Piton Hybrid Vest is what happens when a Synchilla Vest goes on a diet and gets serious about staying active.The two Polartec fleeces used in the Piton, Wind Pro and Power Dry, are thinner, lighter, stretchier, and a lot more compressible than Synchilla. Both fabrics have a smooth outer finish to make donning a shell over the vest easier. The overall design of the Piton is geared to people who want a very close fitting garment with a long hem (the extra length helps the vest stay put under a harness or backpack waist belt) for climbing or backpacking.In actual use, the Wind Pro does block more wind than regular fleece, including technical fleeces such as Patagonia's R1 or the material used in Marmot's Alpinist Tech Jacket, but definitely isn't windproof. The Power Dry sections wick and breathe effectively while providing some heat retention. As you would expect, though, the Piton doesn't insulate as much as the similarly light and thin Nano Puff Vest.So think carefully about what you want out of your vest before picking up a Piton Hybrid. The Piton is not soft and cozy like Synchilla. It won't store as much heat as a down or Nano Puff vest. It has a slim and clingy fit. But the Piton is extremely lightweight, has lots of stretch, works well with packs and harnesses, and layers easily.Four stars, keeping in mind the Piton's intended users and uses.

I'm using the Turtle Beach Ear Force PX4 wireless headphones with my "fat" 60Gb PS3. Overall, I am very satisfied, although I have a few quibbles.What I like*Setup was easy. All you have to do is connect the PX4's base station to the PS3's Optical jack and to one of the USB ports. Then set the PS3 to send audio to the Optical jack, if it wasn't already configured to do so. If you have another A/V component that needs an optical audio signal, the base station passes the signal through, even when the headphones aren't being used.*The headset is reasonably well made and comfortable to wear for long periods. No, the build quality and materials are not up to the standard of those AKG or Denon studio cans you've had your eye on but the PX4 does the job well enough in my opinion.*There are lots of configuration options, including the placement of the virtual speakers in the soundfield, a volume limiter, peak sound limiting, and mic sensitivity.*I also have a home theater audio system hooked up to the PS3 and the PX4 works seamlessly alongside it. When I'm not using the headphones, the base station automatically turns itself off and doesn't interfere with anything.*Most importantly, the PX4 system generates a soundfield with good separation and presence for the virtual speakers and the headphones sound more than good enough for gaming.Caveats*The base station does not support DTS sound. This can be a pain if a game does not allow configuring its sound output within the game because you then have to fiddle with the PS3's Optical output settings to force Dolby output. You also have to remember to return the settings to their original configuration.*For the most part, the wireless connectivity is clear and trouble-free. However, I live in an area where there are lots of Wi-Fi networks overlapping each other. When there is a lot of Wi-Fi activity going on, the sound can suffer from dropouts and static.*An extremely minimalistic Quick Start guide is the only documentation provided in the box. Turtle Bay should pack in at least a stripped-down manual so that quickly checking how a feature works or how to change a setting doesn't require firing up another device.Bottom line: all you need to know, really, is that once you start playing with the headphones on, you forget you're wearing them and quickly become immersed in the game. Four stars, keeping in mind that people living in places with a lot of Wi-Fi traffic might find wired headphones to be a better choice.

The 2013 redesign of the R1 Pullover made it the best midlayer fleece for active use today. It goes well beyond everything else currently available in both form and function.Patagonia shifted from a single fabric design to a zonal, dual fabric construction. The main body of the pullover uses a fleece that is very light weight and compressible yet warm, while areas that often get damp (underarms, underarm gussets, collar, cuffs) use an even lighter and faster drying fleece. Both fabrics have a smooth, shiny finish to make layering over the garment easier.The key to the high performance of the fleece fabrics is how they are made. Small squares of fleece are woven in a grid pattern on the inner face of a stretchy, translucent backing. This gives the fabrics the ability to be both warm and breathable. The fleece squares hold warm air while the thin backing allows moisture and vapor to pass between each square, unimpeded. Much better than earlier generation fleece!Other details which set the R1 apart are thumbholes on the sleeves, cuffs that stay put when pushed up, an extra long main zipper that makes it easy to dump lots of heat quickly, and a chest pocket that doubles as a second heat vent.My only caveats are that the cut and fit are fairly slim since the R1 needs to fit under a shell or other outer layer and, yes, it costs a lot more than those boxy, heavy el-cheapo fleeces that are a common sight at discount and fast-fashion stores. But if you want your fleece to be more than just a glorified baby's blanket, the R1 Pullover is well worth its price. And let's face it, if you don't lead a reasonably active lifestyle, you don't need this kind of technical garment.Five stars.

First, here's something important to know: if the product photo is accurate, the Nano Puff Hybrid on offer here is the first generation version from Fall 2012. That's actually a good thing because the current version has a much smaller fleece zone and has waist pockets instead of chest pockets. For active use, the earlier design is a lot more functional and this is an opportunity to get one.I own the original version in the blue/green color combo and, to be truthful, I love the way it looks but it hasn't become one of my favorite pieces. Why? Mainly because the Hybrid is stuck in the middle--it's not a full-on soft and toasty R2 fleece jacket but it's also not an all-over abrasion resistant, windproof Nano Puff jacket. I can't quite decide if it's best as an outer layer or a midlayer. It is incredibly lightweight and compressible, though, and is comfortable to wear. I mostly use it around town and for carry on-only airplane travel now. It does get a lot of comments due to its unique look!Three stars (unless you've spent the last few years lusting for a jacket that is mostly a Nano Puff in the front and a R2 in the back and lower torso...then it's a five star dream come true). Do keep in mind that the Hybrid has a slim, midlayer-like fit and isn't roomy enough to wear thick layers underneath.

I have been trying out various types of eco-bulbs over the last few years, both fluorescent and LED. The Kobi Electric K8L6 LED bulb is one of the best I've used. I have it installed in an eight-bulb chandelier fixture alongside several other makers' eco-bulbs. It currently gets 3-4 hours of daily use, which will increase to 5-7 hours per day as we move into late autumn and winter.What I like*The bulb generates bright light evenly over the entire surface of its globe. A lot of LED bulbs have dark zones.*Instant-on. Unlike CFL bulbs, LED bulbs reach their full brightness immediately after turning them on and, even better, are not harmed by frequent on-off cycles.*Opaque globe. This bulb is bright enough to use an opaque material for the globe, which helps to make the light warmer. Another benefit is that the bulb's appearance is unobtrusive. Some LED bulbs, due to clear globes or by design, have a high tech look that is not always desirable.*No mercury, so no haz-mat handling is required when the bulb "burns out" (many years from now).Four stars, subject to revision in a few months.----------Update (February 2015): no problems to report.Update (September 2015): no problems to report.

The OXO Easy Press Soap Dispenser does exactly what it's designed to do without any gimmicks or superfluous features.Three things I appreciate about the design are:*A wide base makes the dispenser very stable.*The clear insert at the bottom allows you to see when a refill is needed easily.*When the top is removed, the soap bottle has a wide mouth, making cleaning and filling the bottle simple and quick.A quibble is that it's difficult to vary the force and flow of the stream of soap that comes out of the nozzle. It's pretty much an all-or-nothing action. In any case, I don't think it's a big deal and I quickly got used to it.Four stars.

Yes, the OXO Good Grips 8-inch Chef Knife is very comfortable to hold, due to its well-designed handle, and won't stress your bank account much. But the blade is too lightweight for extended use or for easily cutting through anything that is thick or dense.Even though it may seem counterintuitive, a heavier blade actually is less fatiguing and more precise than the thin, light blades found on most budget knives.  So anybody who does a lot of prep work or cooks daily probably should step up to a professional (or at least "pro-sumer") quality knife. Such a knife will last for years and years and make working in the kitchen easier and more satisfying.The Good Grips knife would be a good choice, though, in a vacation house, for furnishing a rental property, and anywhere else you want a serviceable but inexpensive chef's knife. Or for university students kitting out their first off-campus apartment.Three stars.

The best thing about the OXO Good Grips 5-Inch Utility Knife is that it has a very good handle. The handle is comfortable to hold, has been designed to give you a lot of leverage over the blade, and cleans up easily.Obviously, given the price(!), this knife is not a heavy-duty or professional caliber knife. The blade does OK with soft ingredients and breads but its thin metal construction makes it too flexible for general use. Plus sharpening will cost more than buying another knife (it's best to have serrated knives professionally sharpened). That's not a good way to operate in my book...So, I think the Utility Knife could be an acceptable choice for casual or occasional cooks but anybody who works in the kitchen regularly will want a knife with a heavier, more robust blade. Three stars.

Why am I giving the OXO Good Grips Silicone Jar Spatula five stars? Simple. It's a well-designed kitchen tool that is truly useful.Now getting that last bit of marmalade out of the jar or making sure ALL the mustard is used up before opening a new package is a snap. The Jar Spatula also works very well for making sure a blender container is scraped completely clean after blending something thick or sticky.Add in the thoughtful and comfortable design OXO gives to pretty much the entire Good Grips line, and you've got a five-star product.

The Victorinox Santoku and Steak Knife Set is a good way to try out a santoku style knife without breaking the bank and also get a set of everyday-quality steak knives in the bargain.First, let's talk about the santoku. It feels very lightweight in the hand and when sharp, is easy to maneuver. No special cleaning or care is necessary since the blade is stainless steel and the handle is made from Fibrox, a tough material derived from silica, calcium, alumina, and a few other minerals (see the comments to this review for a link to more info on Fibrox). Ordinary chopping and dicing of vegetables and other soft ingredients is no problem; however, for working with meat and carcasses, I think a heavier knife is more effective and easier to work with.The steak knives are fine for general use but, in my opinion, feel and look a bit too insubstantial and informal for entertaining.Bottom line: I think the Victorinox Santoku is a knife that can either serve as a decent general purpose knife for casual or infrequent cooks or as a way for serious home cooks to see if a santoku fits into their workflow before committing to a professional quality version. The steak knives are functional but not particularly special in any way. 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 since you get five Swiss-made knives at a value price.

The De'Longhi Dolce Gusto Circolo is a nicely designed and well-constructed coffee maker. It is easy to operate and clean. What comes out of it varies greatly in intensity, flavor, and aroma. I think it works best for straight espresso and for hot chocolate.|My Reviewing Perspective|I drink a lot of coffee. At home I make it using either a drip machine or a French press and drink it black. When I want an espresso or anything involving steamed milk, I go to a coffee house or coffee bar. I stick to the basics and very rarely add syrups, sweeteners, or flavorings.|Why the Circolo Interested Me|Sometimes I'm in the mood for an espresso but can't be bothered to go out. I also sometimes get a craving for coffee at night but not often enough to keep a supply of decaffeinated beans around the house. So the Circolo seemed like a good way to be able to make the occasional espresso or cup of decaf without a lot of fuss and without having to store several varieties of beans.|General Thoughts|*The Circolo has an interesting, oval design. It looks much more graceful than most small kitchen electrics.*All the parts fit well and are sturdily made. With proper care, this machine should last for a long time.*The major disadvantage of the Circolo is that it only accepts Nescafé Dolce Gusto capsules. Owners are currently locked into using only the coffees sold by Nestlé.*There are no single country-source coffees (there is no way to get my favorite coffee, Kenya AA, for example) nor any specialized blends (say, Fair Trade) available. Further, Dolce Gusto capsules do not seem to be widely distributed in the US. I live in a major, hugely coffee-centric city and I cannot find a convenient place to buy them locally. Online ordering is my only option right now.|Capsule Tasting Notes|A starter variety pack of capsules comes with the Circolo. I also ordered a box of decaffeinated Lungo capsules from the Dolce Gusto website, using a coupon that came with the machine.I've graded each type of capsule on a A (best)-B-C-D-F (worst) scale.ESPRESSO: B+*caramelized flavor, thin crema, aroma OK not great, starts slightly bitter with pleasant finish and aftertasteAMERICANO: F or C*F: weak, over extracted, no flavor, poor aroma (suggested water amount)*C: barely acceptable flavor, similar to cheap diner coffee (half suggested water amount)DECAF LUNGO: D or C or B*D: very little flavor (suggested water amount)*C: slightly bitter (half suggested water amount)*B: strong, full flavor, slightly reminiscent of instant coffee (minimum water amount allowed by machine)CAPPUCCINO: C*slightly sweet, neutral aroma, mouth feel of full fat whole milk, more like a caffè latte, lots of milk with a touch of coffee (8 oz total volume from 6 oz. milk & 2 oz. coffee)LATTE MACCHIATO: B*foamy, milky, sweet, faint coffee flavorLUNGO: C*slight coffee flavor, like an espresso bar Americano with lots of waterCHOCOCINO: A*rich, foamy, strong chocolate flavor, nicely balanced between milk and chocolate|The Bottom Line|For my tastes, the Circolo makes an acceptable espresso shot and a fine hot chocolate. The other drinks are just OK at best and aren't satisfying.And while it's possible to make passable decaf coffee by severely cutting back on the water used, the resulting yield from each capsule is extremely small. It will get expensive really quickly making full mugs of coffee this way.So if you're somebody who has similar coffee habits to mine, the Circolo is limited to use as an espresso and hot cocoa maker. When coupled with the small selection and restricted availability of coffee capsules, the Dolce Gusto system is unlikely to get heavy use in my kitchen. Three stars.

I'm using the Belkin MIXIT 30-pin ChargeSync Cable with a 4th generation iPod Touch. I have the blue colored version. The cable works as it should for both charging and syncing.Build quality is fine. A nice feature is a raised tab on the 30-pin connector that makes it easier to grasp when inserting or removing it from a device. I also like the pleasant blue color of the cable itself--now that I have both Lightning and 30-pin devices, it's easier to grab the right cable with just a brief glance. Blue is also a nice change from the relentlessly bland white color Apple uses for all its accessories.Four stars.

If you are trying to break away from the subdued, but aren't yet ready for full-on bling, this may be the watch for you. It's large, rose tone gold colored, and has faux diamonds surrounding the watch face--it is not for the faint of heart. After you get over the shock of the mere idea of faux diamonds and commit to wearing the watch for a few days, however, you realize that the faux diamonds actually blend into the design as a whole quite well. If you aren't used to wearing large watches, you can think of it as a functional piece of costume jewelry rather than as a day-to-day watch.While I do intend to wear the watch when I don't want to wear a bracelet but still want to add a little pop to my look, I do have two reservations that will likely prevent me from making this my everyday watch. Not surprisingly given its size, the watch is rather heavy, so much so that you really can't forget you're wearing it. Also, if your wrist is bony, you may find that the dial digs in to your wrist.The manual (or lack thereof) is another source of complaint. A booklet does come with the watch, and while it describes some ancillary features such as the degree to which the watch is waterproof, it misses critical points. The watch has three inset dials; however, there is no information on the purpose of these dials or on how to reset them if needed. The insert also does not address how to resize the watchband. I took it to a watch shop to have it resized, but if I had wanted to do it myself, I would have been on my own.Overall, this watch is a nice addition to my wardrobe, but due to its weight and size, it is not likely to become my everyday watch.

When I first laid eyes on the House of Marley Liberate BT sound system, I was impressed. It's a nice looking wireless speaker that fits well into pretty much any environment, including offices (no, it's not shaped like a giant spliff or sporting Jamaican flag colors!). So I was excited to pair it with my iPod Touch.Unfortunately, there are some important things I've discovered I don't like. First, the Liberate only puts out decent sound at low to moderate volume levels. Once you start cranking up the power, the midrange becomes really prominent and everything sounds muddy and blaring. A related problem is that whenever the Liberate is first turned on, the volume resets to a high level. It does not remember any previous settings.Another thing I don't like is that there is no way to replace the battery. The Liberate's enclosure is completely sealed up, except for a mini-USB port and a 3.5mm plug jack. When the battery no longer is rechargeable, you'll either have to keep the Liberate connected to a power source all the time, losing the portability, or get rid of the entire system. That's a big waste, especially since Marley does not seem to provide any way to recycle or otherwise properly dispose of the Liberate. If you listen to music for several hours each day, it would be easy to put the battery through a few hundred charge cycles and  wear it out in about a year. That's not a very long lifespan.Bottom line: if you only occasionally listen to music at work and don't want the ability to make things loud, the Liberate could be a good choice. However, the inaccessible battery and mediocre sound quality at higher volumes limit the Liberate's usefulness for me.-------NoteOn my iPod I mostly listen to rock and jazz in MP3 and AAC formats. I tested both wireless and wired connections between the iPod and the Liberate. I had no problems getting either type of connection to work. I also tried out all the sound equalization options offered in the iPod's Settings menu in an effort to get better sound from the Liberate.

This iPhone 5c case has a major design flaw: the sides are slippery! Even with a super-protective, shock absorbing case (which this case is not), it's never good to drop your phone. The slick and glossy edges on this thing make it all too easy for your phone to slip out of your hand.The case is quite light and fits well, though. If you are extremely careful with your phone and are mainly looking to protect the back from scratches with a bit of (depending on your personal style, choose one) Kardashian-style bling or 1950's Formica sparkle, it might be OK. But I think most people will do better with a case that has grippier sides.Two stars.

After receiving the MarBlue Slim case several weeks ago, it has become my official go-to case. The easy snap on, snap off design makes the case ideal if you want protection on the go, but prefer to use your device without a case at home.  The device fits snugly, which is a plus if you carry your Kindle in your bag and might otherwise worry about it falling out and being damaged, but at the same time, it doesn’t share the downside of some cases you feel you need to pry rather than pop out of the case.The kickstand design is also an advantage of this case. I am able to prop up the case at the angle that best suits my needs in any situation without bothering about the Kindle sliding down the rubberized stand. The inability to prop up the device both horizontally and vertically is the only significant downside I have experienced with this case.Overall, a winner for those interested in design flexibility without adding significant weight or size to your device.

Icebreaker has made a great mid or light-duty outer layer here. Merino wool with a soft, fuzzy finish inside is a lot nicer to wear than polyester fleece. And it's machine washable to boot!There are some things to keep in mind though:1. Icebreaker cuts its clothing slim. If you are unsure about which size to get, it's probably best to size up.2. However, the current version of the Sierra doesn't fit as narrowly as in previous seasons. It's looser all over. No, Icebreaker hasn't suddenly become a "Big and Tall" brand but its pieces are now more forgiving for people who aren't built like marathoners.3. For some reason Icebreaker uses left-handed main zippers on all its products, not just its women's line. In other words, men's items have the zipper pull on the left side. This is the opposite of the standard practice in the US and takes a little while to get used to.Overall, the Sierra Full Zip is a comfortable, well-made jacket. It's fine for any use where you're not counting ounces and aren't that concerned about how quickly the piece dries. And if you already have a Sierra in one of the solid colors, have a look at the Break-Up Infinity style. It has a state-of-the-art camouflage pattern, licensed from Mossy Oak. I got it because it reminds me of the hunting themed lining of a rectangular Coleman sleeping bag I had as a kid. Four stars.

Have you ever worn your Patagonia R1 fleece layers around town (since R1/Polartec PowerDry fleece really is the best available) but felt a bit sheepish (ha ha) because you looked like you were getting ready to camp out for a month or strap on a climbing harness?Well, the Upslope jacket is a nicely tamed version of Patagonia's highly technical R1 Full-Zip jacket. The Upslope, while not a baggy garment by any means, has a more generous, forgiving cut. The cuffs, collar, and waist are made from a knit, ribbed material that is stretchy and gives the Upslope a more tailored look than a Full-Zip. Best of all, the Upslope is great for layering because the R1 fleece has a smooth and shiny finish. Shells and overcoats glide right over it.I think the Upslope is best for in-town and soft-adventure travel wear. It is a bit heavy compared to more technical fleeces, such as Patagonia's R1 and R2 lines and the Marmot Alpinist Tech Jacket, doesn't have ultra flat pocket and zipper construction, and the zipper pulls are bits of knotted rope without rubber grasps. As I said before, this thing wants to be *civilized*! But you still get high performance and comfort that blows away those big-box store and fast fashion chain cheap-o fleeces.All in all, a cozy, warm jacket that fits into daily living well.

I own lots of Bugsaway stuff--shirts, hats, socks, neckerchiefs, you name it! When the permethrin fabric treatment (Insect Shield) is near its peak strength, the insect repellent function of Bugsaway clothing works quite well. I've worn Bugsaway in both dry and humid areas and I recommend the line to anybody who wants to reduce the amount of DEET they put on their skin.The downside of Insect Shield is that it eventually washes out of fabrics. Early generations of Insect Shield were rated for only 25-30 wash cycles, while the current version is rated for 70 washes. If you're travelling fast and light and only carrying a couple of shirts, it's pretty obvious that the constant washing will get you to 70 washes quickly...especially if you're on a multi-week trip or getting heated up and sweaty a lot.So, I was instantly interested in the Sandfly jacket when I came across it recently. An outer layer does not have to be washed nearly as often as a shirt. Plus a jacket offers more flexibility if you're in an area where you don't need constant insect protection. My only worry was that the Sandfly might be too heavy or bulky to wear in hot conditions.The Sandfly, I was pleased to discover, is very well suited to wearing a thin, wicking base layer underneath because the majority of the jacket is made out of mesh. It is extremely light weight, breathable, and compressible. It has a slimmer cut than many ExOfficio garments, but still fits more generously than Patagonia's slim fit or anything made by Icebreaker. It may be more accurate to call the Sandfly an overshirt rather than a jacket; it has no insulation and offers no protection from cold or wet.ExOfficio could improve a few minor things, though. First, the chest pocket doubles as a stuff sack for the jacket but there isn't any kind of attachment point (like a fabric loop) to use when the jacket is packed and stuffed into the pocket. This means you can't tie it to a pack or clip it on your belt. Second, the chest pocket's inner zipper slider doesn't come with a zipper pull. Finally, the main zipper is a thin coil zipper that is quite stiff and a little difficult to get started. Slightly larger teeth and a larger slider would make the jacket easier to open and close quickly. None of these are showstoppers in any case.Bottom line: I wish the Sandfly had been around years ago. Then I wouldn't be the owner of several Bugsaway shirts that are near the end of their insect repellent lifespan but aren't that suitable for around-town wear. Four stars.

What's the deal with all the open-world sandbox games with "dogs" in the title lately? Sleeping Dogs, Watch Dogs, what's gonna be next? Eating Dogs, Walking Dogs, Lap Dogs, Hot Dogs?Anyway, Watch Dogs is fun if you like sandbox games. Don't look for a lot of innovative gameplay or a radically new take on the genre. With the exception of invasive multi-player (more about that below), it's a mashup of a lot of stuff that has come before it.In video game math, we can say:Watch Dogs = Grand Theft Auto + Deus Ex + Max Payne(free roaming, multiple ways to beat missions, a super slo-mo powerup, lots of guns)Watch Dogs = Grand Theft Auto + Heavy Rain + Lisbeth Salander + Edward Snowden(gang warfare, a dark, disturbing, voyeuristic tone, hacking, conspiracies, NSA-type surveillance)Watch Dogs = Grand Theft Auto + Clockwork Orange + the Untouchables(carjacking, ultraviolence, Chicago)So if any of that turns your head, you'll probably dig Watch Dogs. Or if experiencing a deviant dystopia that is influenced by Orwell, Kafka, and Gaitskill sounds cool, you'll like Watch Dogs.The feature that seems to have received the most hype is the persistent and invasive multi-player. You don't have to launch a special multi-player mode to have other, REAL people enter into your game. Unless you're involved in a mission, another player can try to hack you or tail you at any time. I've never been big into multi-player gaming so I can't say this makes or breaks Watch Dogs for me...but I do think it's an interesting way to keep the game constantly changing and challenging for everybody. The online car racing, on the other hand, is exactly like it is in other driving games. As usual, knowing the courses and their shortcuts thoroughly is the key to succeeding.Ubisoft could have done a few things better. First, the load times are atrocious on PlayStation3. Every time you die or fail a mission, it's a long wait for the game to reset itself. This takes you out of the game and breaks up the flow. The only game that was worse for this is Stuntman. Perhaps it is no coincidence that the same studio, Reflections, was involved in developing both games! Second, again possibly related to Reflections, driving is kind of a pain. Pretty much every vehicle is hard to control because of floaty, super squirrely, or unresponsive handling. Finally, the story and character development doesn't rise above typical videogame level. While the writing in Watch Dogs is no better or worse than in most games, Ubisoft could have taken more care with such a highly promoted, Triple-A release. None of these are showstoppers, though.Bottom line: Watch Dogs is a fun and, thanks to current events, highly topical game. It might make you paranoid as well. Four stars.----------Oh yeah, if you've ever had a hankering to hang out with Al Jourgensen or see the Survival Research Laboratories (SRL) workshops there are a few things in the game that will make you laugh. Or if you're sick of Abstergo Industries messing with your head.

My household is chock full o' Timbuk2 stuff. Messenger bags, totes, camera inserts, mobile phone pouches, and more. While we all appreciate Timbuk2's burly construction and lifetime warranty on its products, pretty much every item has something that could have been done better. Usually it's a small detail, such as Velcro hooks on a flap facing towards clothing (better to have the pile side that way to avoid knit fabrics getting caught up) but sometimes it's a major problem like a rucksack that won't close properly unless it's fully loaded.This time it's different, as the saying goes. The Command Laptop Backpack has been thoughtfully designed all the way through. It is truly a joy to wear and use. Every pocket, slot, buckle, and strap has been well thought out and elegantly blends form and function.I have the Carbon Full-Cycle Twill color/fabric choice. This grey colored woven fabric gives the Command a soft, pleasant hand with a professional looking texture. And grey, of course, is a color that works well in pretty much all office, school, and travel situations. Overall, the Command has a nicely understated and minimalist look to it.The most amazing thing about the design to my mind is that even though the Command is a 32-liter volume pack, it looks and feels like a much smaller pack. When it's not fully loaded and the bottom compression straps are pulled in, it feels, in both size and weight, almost like carrying a 20-liter daypack. Very nice. The other great feature is the TSA-compliant laptop compartment. When you're at an airport security checkpoint, all you have to do is flip the shoulder straps over to the front of the pack and open a zippered flap to expose your computer to TSA screeners. Helpfully, the straps are anchored to the top of the bag such that they lie flat and stay put no matter which way they're facing. There's even a handle on the long edge of the pack that allows you to carry the bag like a briefcase when the shoulder straps have been rotated. Again, very nice.Do keep two things in mind, though. First, while the suspension is very comfortable and highly adjustable, the Command isn't suitable for outdoor activity use because it doesn't have a waist strap. Second, anybody who is hard on bags might want to look at one of the nylon fabric color options. The Full-Cycle Twill will not stand up to abrasion, moisture, and abuse as well as the regular nylon fabric.Bottom line: five stars, for an incredibly well designed and constructed technology backpack.----------AddendumTimbuk2 takes its warranty program seriously. I recently sent them a pack with fabric and stitching that was beginning to tear. They repaired my bag and returned it to me at no charge, even though I had been using the bag for over a year. That's unbeatable service!Addendum 2The laptop compartment really isn't a hassle to access quickly. As I said above, the shoulder straps easily rotate out of the way when necessary, lie flat, and don't require unhooking or removing any straps or buckles to flip them over. I've posted some photos in the Customer Images area to show how it works.

If you are looking for a travel case for your Kindle Fire HDX 7", consider the Incipio zipper case. It's especially well-suited for business travel, with a professional looking folio design and a smooth, leather-like finish.The case offers sturdy construction that should protect your Kindle even when you put it in soft luggage stuffed under your seat. It's hard to imagine using the credit card holders, but the penholder comes in handy for carrying a stylus. Once you arrive at your destination, it's easy to snap your Kindle out of the case. The back and sides of your device remain protected by a thin, light plastic cover that's designed to allow quick removal and reattachment. The button covers are well placed, allowing you to use your Kindle without removing the case for use during your flight.Overall, the case has served me well on a couple of work trips and I intend to use it in the future when I travel. There are, however, a couple of downsides to the case. First, the zipper is a little stiff. The main shortcoming, though, is the lack of a kickstand. iI you watch movies on your flight or later at your hotel you will be limited to holding your Kindle by hand. If it were equipped with a kickstand, I would be likely to leave my Kindle in this case even when I'm not traveling, but without that feature, I find myself switching between cases. Luckily, the hard back snaps off easily, so if your at-home case is easy to attach, this shouldn't be a major issue.Four stars.

I know what you're thinking. I'll pick up the FastFit Keyboard case for my iPad Mini and I can stop lugging my laptop around. Less weight, less space, no more trying to type on a virtual keyboard, everybody's happy, right?Well, it doesn't quite work out that way. The compact size of the iPad Mini has forced Belkin to make several design decisions that reduce the usability of the FastFit keyboard. The keys are small so it's easy to make "fat finger" mistakes even if you have slender hands. A lot of the keys have three functions. Some of the keys deviate from the standard QWERTY configuration. For touch-typists in particular, it is very jarring to have an Enter key where the semicolon/colon key is usually located.Aside from the physical layout of the keyboard, the FastFit does have many positive aspects. It is very lightweight, has an aluminum back that exactly matches Apple's iPad shell, and acts as a stand as well as a screen cover. It also supports the iPad's close-cover-to-sleep function, although that's not that useful when you're using the keyboard as a stand.Something Belkin should improve is to either provide more comprehensive setup and usage instructions in the box or post detailed information on its website. The printed sheet that comes with the keyboard is very minimal and leaves users to discover a lot of things on their own. Belkin's website currently isn't much help either, even in the Support section.Bottom line: the FastFit Keyboard is an improvement over the iPad's on-screen keyboard. However, I think hunt-and-peck typists benefit more from the FastFit because its physical design limitations make it difficult for touch-typists to work quickly and accurately. I do like the overall construction and features of the FastFit though; the problem is that the iPad Mini just isn't well suited for this type of accessory. 3.5 stars, then, rounded up to 4 because the FastFit's weaknesses are rooted in Apple's design, not Belkin's.

The Circulon Genesis series is a lightweight line of pots and pans that is well made and has a nonstick coating that is safe to use with metal utensils. These two features alone put this Genesis set ahead of most value priced sets. However, the light and thin aluminum construction means that accomplished home cooks or those who can afford the increased initial cost might want to look at higher-end cookware.I do think, though, Circulon Genesis is nicely suited for uses such as:*A quick start for college students moving off campus*In a vacation house that is rented out*For people who don't cook often or mainly boil liquids and heat up prepared products*Anybody who wants robustly made, non-stick cookware that doesn't cost a lot, with the tradeoff of middling heat absorption and retention performanceCooking with the Genesis set is as expected. Each piece heats up and cools down very quickly. That's OK for dishes that are cooked hot-and-fast in a single step, such as fried eggs, but not ideal for searing thick cuts of meat or for anything that goes low 'n' slow, like braises. Also, the distribution of heat across each pan depends heavily on the shape and size of the stove burner you're using, due to the thinness of the metal.Bottom line: since Circulon offers a lifetime warranty on its products, durability concerns raised by the light materials aren't a big factor. So within the uses discussed above, I feel comfortable giving this set four stars. Committed cooks and those who can afford to spend more will, I believe, be happier by stepping up to a "better" or "best" product line.

My reviewing perspective*I'm using the Shure SE112 Earphones with a 4th generation iPod Touch and an iPad Mini that are loaded with music in MP3 and AAC formats.*On my iDevices I mostly listen to rock and jazz. I don't like to hear a lot of bottom end, especially over headphones and earbuds.*I'm not an especially demanding mobile listener because when I want to hear great sound or listen to classical music, I rely on my home stereo (yes, that's incredibly old school, I know).What I like*These earphones generate good sound. The high end, midrange, and low end are well balanced and clear, to my ears.*The ear tips help ensure a good seal for blocking outside noise. Three sets of tips are included: large, medium, and small.*The combination of a light weight and the soft tips make the SE112s very comfortable to wear for long periods.*The Left and Right markings on the buds are large and easy to read.*A velvet carrying pouch and cleaning tool are provided.There is something important to keep in mind, though. As with anything that tightly seals up the ear canal, any movement in the earphones or cord translates into a distracting noise. Loud, busy songs can mask the movement sounds but they can be heard over most music.Bottom line: The Shure SE112 Earphones are a fine way to listen to music. The big caveat, in my opinion, is that the movement noise makes these earphones unsuitable for workout or any other use that makes the cord swing around.  If you can keep the cord still, though, the SE112s are a good replacement for cheap, stock earbuds. Four stars.

The Contigo Tranquil Bottle has a great feature not commonly found on water bottles: a two-piece cap that allows you to choose between a wide mouth and a narrow mouth. I really like the ability to use the wide opening when filling and cleaning the bottle and the narrow opening when taking a drink.However, I don't think the Tranquil is a good choice for serious outdoors use (trekking, camping, climbing, skiing, etc.) because the cap is not self-attached to the bottle and, according to Contigo's website, the bottle cannot be used with hot liquids. But for times when losing hold of the cap would not be catastrophic and you don't care about not being able to pour boiling water or a stew or soup into the bottle, the Tranquil is a very functional, well-designed water bottle.Four stars, keeping the Tranquil's limitations in mind.----------NoteSee the comments section of this review for a link to Contigo's instruction sheet for the Tranquil. Contigo really should include this sheet with the bottle because it contains very important usage information.

I've been using the Samsung 16GB microSDHC UHS-I memory card to transfer files between an i7 iMac, a HP Slate 7 Extreme tablet, and a first-generation ("fat") PS3, using the built-in card readers.I have not had any problems with data-transfer rates or writing and deleting files.  However, it is a little disappointing that Samsung did not include a card case. All you get is the micro-card and an adapter for using the card in SD-sized slots. This is just a quibble, though, and only is an issue if you plan on carrying the card outside of a device (say, in a camera bag).Four stars, keeping in mind that I am not making the kind of performance demands a DSLR camera or streaming video box would put on the card.

The Hive Response case offers the standard features you'd expect in a Kindle Fire case, including a stand to prop up the device for movie watching or surfing, but with the added benefit of an eye-catching design. I'm not sure the honeycomb design offers the ergonomic benefits cited in the product description, but the hive design together with the soft blue color make this one of the most visually appealing cases on the market.The case slips on easily and fits snugly once in place, offering solid protection without the annoyance that sometimes comes with inserting or removing a device from its case. The case does not include a screen protector or front panel, so if you tend to be rough on your devices, you may want to consider another option. That said, the relatively thick rubber inner case along with the plastic hard shell should offer all the protection you'll need.I only have one suggestion for improvement. While the horizontal kickstand works well for watching movies, having a vertical kickstand option would make it easier to read hands free. The ease with which you can add and remove the outer shell would make this the ideal solution for those looking for a protective, but not necessarily super-rugged case.Four stars.

The 2013 redesign of the R1 Pullover made it the best midlayer fleece for active use today. It goes well beyond everything else currently available in both form and function.Patagonia shifted from a single fabric design to a zonal, dual fabric construction. The main body of the pullover uses a fleece that is very light weight and compressible yet warm, while areas that often get damp (underarms, underarm gussets, collar, cuffs) use an even lighter and faster drying fleece. Both fabrics have a smooth, shiny finish to make layering over the garment easier.The key to the high performance of the fleece fabrics is how they are made. Small squares of fleece are woven in a grid pattern on the inner face of a stretchy, translucent backing. This gives the fabrics the ability to be both warm and breathable. The fleece squares hold warm air while the thin backing allows moisture and vapor to pass between each square, unimpeded. Much better than earlier generation fleece!Other details which set the R1 apart are thumbholes on the sleeves, cuffs that stay put when pushed up, an extra long main zipper that makes it easy to dump lots of heat quickly, and a chest pocket that doubles as a second heat vent.My only caveats are that the cut and fit are fairly slim since the R1 needs to fit under a shell or other outer layer and, yes, it costs a lot more than those boxy, heavy el-cheapo fleeces that are a common sight at discount and fast-fashion stores. But if you want your fleece to be more than just a glorified baby's blanket, the R1 Pullover is well worth its price. And let's face it, if you don't lead a reasonably active lifestyle, you don't need this kind of technical garment.Five stars.----------Note:At the time of the writing of this review, the seller's product descriptions are for the R1 Hoody, NOT the R1 Pullover. The main differences between the two are that the Pullover does NOT have a hood (!) and the main zipper is not offset. Also, potential purchasers may want to ask the seller if the product being offered is the Fall 2013 or Spring 2014 model of the R1 Pullover. The pre-2013 versions, in my opinion, are not as well-designed as the later ones.

First, let's answer the big question: does NeoShell really do what Polartec says it does? Based on my experience with the Nabu jacket, the answer is yes...at least as long as the durable water repellant (DWR) finish on the outer fabric is working well. As anybody who already has waterproof-breathable rainwear knows, keeping the DWR in good condition is just as important as the membrane material when it comes to real-life breathability.The Nabu, then, offers something that didn't really exist before: a mix of hardshell waterproofness and softshell comfort and breathability. Before NeoShell, the closest thing to the Nabu was hybrid jackets that put hardshell panels in critical areas and used softshell fabric everywhere else. These garments, unfortunately, were a compromise and in actual use never really lived up to their promise.I find the Nabu to be a very comfortable and functional jacket. It is soft and stretchy, like softshells should be, stays quiet when you're in motion, has a flexible, lightweight lining, and is cut slightly long in the sleeves and hem to give lots of freedom of movement. I've worn it in some pretty heavy downpours, both with and without a pack on, and did not experience any leaks or discomfort. The Nabu is not that great for going fast and light, however, because it is somewhat heavy and not very compressible. Also, the breathability works so well that the Nabu may not be the best choice for extremely windy or cold conditions.A few small improvements Marmot could make would be to give the hood a wire reinforced brim (at this price point the laminated brim seems a little chintzy), make the Velcro wrist adjusters wider and longer, and change the design of the pleated gussets on the sleeves so that gathered fabric from adjusting the cuffs lies more flat. I don't think any of these are showstoppers, though.So, if you're tired of the crispy and stiff feeling of hardshells and aren't worried about the usual weaknesses of softshells (heavy, low abrasion resistance, not windproof, bulky), the Nabu is a great way to get waterproof-breathable performance more comfortably. Do keep in mind that if you already own a softshell, buying an ultralight hardshell, such as the Patagonia M10 or Marmot Super Mica, may be a better way to go, especially if you are counting ounces. You'll gain more layering flexibility and benefit from a having more robust outer layer in the rain. Travellers, on the other hand, should find the Nabu to be extremely useful and I think it will quickly become a favorite.Four stars.

I like the Northwall, even though it's not really an essential piece. In other words, if you don't already own a hardshell, an uninsulated softshell, and a fleece midlayer, buy those three items first. They will form the core of your gear kit and provide maximum layering flexibility. The Northwall, on the other hand, is great for times when you KNOW you wouldn't want to take off your fleece, aren't expecting really wet conditions, and don't want to wear two separate garments. Plus all of Patagonia's state-of-the-art technical features are present: welded seams, a unique drawcord system for adjusting the hood and waist, and the best fleece available today.It's important to realize that Patagonia gave the Northwall a minimalist design intended for active outdoors use. It is water resistant, not waterproof, does not have hand warmer or internal pockets, has a rather snug fit, and is cut long in the sleeves and back hem. Anybody who is looking at the Northwall for around-town wear only might end up disappointed because it is not particularly warm when you're not moving and doesn't have a lot of room for carrying stuff.But if you like the extremely light yet highly functional softshell material used in Patagonia's Knifeblade series (Polartec Power Shield Pro) and also like R2 fleece (the middle weight of Patagonia's technical fleeces), the Northwall is a fine way to get the best of both in one jacket.Four stars, keeping in mind the Northwall is best as an addition to your core gear.

I bought the Rapid because I wanted a bag that was truly waterproof and also usable as a comfortable hiking daypack. During my search, I narrowed my choices to two packs: the Rapid and the Patagonia Stormfront Rolltop Pack 30L.The major differences are:*The Rapid is sewn together, with sealed seams, while the Stormfront has welded seams.*Both packs have a similar strap and suspension design that utilizes an external, permanently attached framesheet to provide structure and stiffness, but the Rapid's framesheet is full length. The Stormfront's framesheet has a mid-back gap.*The Stormfront is made with a denser, stiffer material than the Rapid (800 denier nylon with waterproof coating on both sides of the fabric vs. 420 denier nylon with a waterproof liner laminated to the inner face)While both packs are about the same price, I went with the Rapid because it has many hiker-friendly features, such as exterior mesh pockets, hydration bladder support, and a Hypalon lash loop, and its flexible fabric is more comfortable for all-day walking. I wish the Rapid had welded seams since sewn and sealed seams are not as robust as those that are welded, but Sea to Summit has a lifetime guarantee so (hopefully) I'll be covered if any of the seams begin to leak. I also wish that the bottom of the pack was made from a higher denier material or had a double layer of fabric for durability in a part of the pack that receives a lot of abuse.Overall, the Rapid has performed well for me. I've worn it in heavy downpours and everything I had in the pack stayed completely dry. The shoulder straps do absorb some water, though, and require a few hours to fully dry out. The suspension is easy to adjust and comparable to those on alpine packs, with the exception of the sternum strap, which goes into slots and only has four possible positions, and the waist strap, which is a bit minimalistic for a 26L bag. Also, the rolltop works best when the pack is at least half full. When the pack is empty or only has a few items inside, the folds of the rolltop can loosen up slightly after closing the pack.Bottom line: the Rapid combines comfort with performance well. No more messing around with raincovers and trash bags when doing stuff in the wet! Four stars.

I've been using these Belkin styli with several Apple products, including an iPad and an iPhone. Each stylus is lightweight and comfortable to hold. The feel is very similar to the sort of giveaway ballpoint pens found in hotel rooms and not-so-fine dining establishments.While using a stylus is more precise than using your fingers on a touchscreen, something to keep in mind with this particular stylus is that it works best when held perpendicular to the screen. As such, its most effective use is as a pointer. Anybody who needs a stylus that behaves more like a brush or felt-tip pen should consider a different model of stylus.Overall, though, the Belkin Economy Capacitive Stylus combines form and function well. Four stars.

I'm testing these Amazon Basics rechargeable batteries in three devices: a 3-battery LED flashlight, a pair of Sennheiser noise cancelling headphones and a LG LCD television remote control.When the batteries arrived, they were pre-charged, as promised, but did accept some topping off. I did not experience any problems putting them in a basic Energizer AA/AAA charger (model CHP42US).After approximately a month of use in both devices, the batteries have not revealed any drawbacks and have been working well. Even so, it may be prudent to wait until these batteries have established more of a track record before using them in mission-critical or failure intolerant applications since they are a new product as of the writing of this review (according to the product description above, they were introduced in April 2014).Four stars.

I like the Kensington BlackBelt 1st Degree Rugged Case for the iPad Air because it is very comfortable to hold and carry. Instead of using hard and unyielding plastic as the main material, Kensington made the BlackBelt out of a flexible, rubbery material. The BlackBelt, as a result, feels both grippy and soft in your hand.Don't worry--your iPad is still well protected. The case is very shock absorbent and has a beveled edge surrounding the screen, so that you can set your iPad face down without worrying, and thicker padding in the corners for additional impact protection.There are two things to keep in mind, though. First, the BlackBelt does not have any kind of membrane, covering, or lid for direct screen protection. Second, the BlackBelt has a two-piece design, with a transparent hard plastic insert that goes between the back of your iPad and the interior of the case. If you don't want your iPad's screen to be exposed at all times or if you like to switch cases often and you're a forgetful person, you may want to consider a different case.Four stars.

Yep, the Belkin Lego Builder Case for the 5th generation iPod Touch is, in a word, FUN!!! It has bright, happy colors. It adds a Lego Building Plate to the back of your iPod. And best of all, it turns Apple's severe and minimalist design aesthetic on its head.Anybody who follows Apple knows that its lead designer, Jony Ive, has been in love with metal and glass for the last few years. Shiny, bright plastic has not been part of Apple's design vocabulary for quite some time (with the exception of the unpopular iPhone 5c). But now you can make your Touch look like the fun-machine it truly is!Don't worry, the Builder Case *does* work well amongst all this folly. It protects the back of the iPod Touch from dirt, scratches, and small bumps, doesn't interfere with wireless activity, and all the ports and buttons remain easily accessible.Five stars--the Lego Builder is a fun AND functional case.

A Spy Among Friends is both a unique and thought provoking read.Unique because unlike many books about spies and spying, A Spy Among Friends is focused on the interpersonal facets of intelligence work. There is little discussion of spycraft or operational details. Instead, Ben Macintyre explores the psyches of three men whose careers and lives were mightily intertwined: Kim Philby, Nicholas Elliott, another elite member of MI6, and James Angleton, the legendary CIA officer. All three, over a period from the Second World War through the Cold War, were simultaneously helping each other and betraying one another. The consequences of their actions are well known; from Guy Burgess' defection to the USSR right before British intelligence was going to arrest him to the destruction of files to cover up the CIA's enabling role in Philby's activities, these three men were at the center of it all. Juggling and obfuscating professional ambition, personal life, and ideology was unavoidable and inescapable for them. Nobody, not even their own families and closest friends, knew the complete picture.Thought provoking because the Kim Philby case is simultaneously archaic and immediately relevant in today's world. The resurgence of tension and competition between Russia, the major European Union countries, and the United States is bringing back many of the political, economic, and human rights conflicts that arose during the Cold War era. It is a sure bet that the intelligence rivalry between "East" and "West" has intensified as well, with the new twist that low-level workers who are not social elites have the ability to do as much, if not more, intelligence damage to a country as Philby did. Present day informants such as Bradley/Chelsea Manning and Edward Snowden would have found it extremely difficult or impossible in Philby's era to access the quantity and quality of documents they stole. Further, somebody like Snowden probably would not even have been allowed into the clubby and incestuous intelligence world of the 1940's, 50's, and 60's due to his lack of educational pedigree and social connections. These changes have significant implications for counterintelligence work that still have not been fully recognized, as shown by the failure of the NSA to contain or even perceive Snowden's activities until after he went public.Macintyre, in any case, is a fine writer, as readers of any of his previous books already know. He writes in a clean, clear, accessible style and has quite an eye for eccentric details of people and organizations. Macintyre liberally peppers his books with these drolleries and consequently keeps his narratives from becoming dry recitations of dates and historical facts.Bottom line: anybody with an interest in the Cold War, international relations, or the personal aspects of espionage should like this book. Four stars.

I like the Northwall, even though it's not really an essential piece. In other words, if you don't already own a hardshell, an uninsulated softshell, and a fleece midlayer, buy those three items first. They will form the core of your gear kit and provide maximum layering flexibility. The Northwall, on the other hand, is great for times when you KNOW you wouldn't want to take off your fleece, aren't expecting really wet conditions, and don't want to wear two separate garments. Plus all of Patagonia's state-of-the-art technical features are present: welded seams, a unique drawcord system for adjusting the hood and waist, and the best fleece available today.It's important to realize that Patagonia gave the Northwall a minimalist design intended for active outdoors use. First, let's answer the big question: does NeoShell really do what Polartec says it does? Based on my experience with the Nabu jacket, the answer is yes...at least as long as the durable water repellant (DWR) finish on the outer fabric is working well. As anybody who already has waterproof-breathable rainwear knows, keeping the DWR in good condition is just as important as the membrane material when it comes to real-life breathability.The Nabu, then, offers something that didn't really exist before: a mix of hardshell waterproofness and softshell comfort and breathability. Before NeoShell, the closest thing to the Nabu was hybrid jackets that put hardshell panels in critical areas and used softshell fabric everywhere else. These garments, unfortunately, were a compromise and in actual use never really lived up to their promise.I find the Nabu to be a very comfortable and functional jacket. It is soft and stretchy, like softshells should be, stays quiet when you're in motion, has a flexible, lightweight lining, and is cut slightly long in the sleeves and hem to give lots of freedom of movement. I've worn it in some pretty heavy downpours, both with and without a pack on, and did not experience any leaks or discomfort. The Nabu is not that great for going fast and light, however, because it is somewhat heavy and not very compressible. Also, the breathability works so well that the Nabu may not be the best choice for extremely windy or cold conditions.A few small improvements Marmot could make would be to give the hood a wire reinforced brim (at this price point the laminated brim seems a little chintzy), make the Velcro wrist adjusters wider and longer, and change the design of the pleated gussets on the sleeves so that gathered fabric from adjusting the cuffs lies more flat. I don't think any of these are showstoppers, though.So, if you're tired of the crispy and stiff feeling of hardshells and aren't worried about the usual weaknesses of softshells (heavy, low abrasion resistance, not windproof, bulky), the Nabu is a great way to get waterproof-breathable performance more comfortably. Do keep in mind that if you already own a softshell, buying an ultralight hardshell, such as the Patagonia M10 or Marmot Super Mica, may be a better way to go, especially if you are counting ounces. You'll gain more layering flexibility and benefit from a having more robust outer layer in the rain. Travellers, on the other hand, should find the Nabu to be extremely useful and I think it will quickly become a favorite.Four stars.

...you use the rear camera on your iPad Mini a lot.For the most part, the modulR iPad Mini Mobility Pack is a fine protective case with a nicely designed system of interchangeable components. The Pack contains a back plate that holds your iPad, a separate, shock absorbing front plate with raised posts at each corner for attaching accessories, and three carrying straps (shoulder, wrist, hand).A very odd design decision, though, makes the modulR case a poor choice for anybody who uses the rear camera frequently. In order to use your iPad, you have to snap the front plate over the rear of the back plate. The front plate does not have an opening for the camera. This means that when the case is open, the front plate blocks the camera. But when the case is closed, the camera lens is left unprotected because the back plate *does* have a camera opening.For non-Retina Mini owners, there is another problem: whenever the front plate is attached to the back plate, in any orientation, the microphone is covered up. The back plate does have a port that matches the placement of the rear panel mic on Retina Minis. But as above, the front plate will block both mic ports when a Retina iPad is in use.The only workaround for these problems is to carry the front plate separately when you want to use the camera or mic. Doing this, however, creates other problems because the front plate provides the shock protection and is where all the accessories attach. Plus it's a pain to keep track of yet another item when you're on the go.Bottom line: if you do not use your iPad regularly for photos, video, or Facetime, the modulR Mobility Pack works well.
