It is much lighter in weight, less bulky, and easier to put on and take off than most "armored" cases, such as OtterBox and Pelican, at the cost of providing less protection. The accessory attachment system adds a lot of flexibility to how you can carry and use your iPad. So, since I don't take pictures with my iPad much (I prefer a dedicated camera) and rarely use iPad Facetime or Siri (I do that stuff on my iPhone), I feel comfortable giving the Pack four stars. But constant users of the camera and/or microphone really should look at other cases. The same goes for anybody who needs truly robust impact and shock protection.----------AddendumI was also given a modulR Storage Stand, an accessory not included in the Mobility Pack, to review. The Stand attaches to the front plate posts and holds the iPad in landscape orientation (with the long edges horizontal). It has a hollow interior with cut-outs for storing a Lightning cable and an Apple 5W power adapter. It's functional and convenient for home or office use but I think it is too bulky to carry when commuting or travelling.Addendum 2modulR says this case meets "Mil Shock Std 516.6". This standard is a subsection of a broader United States Military standard, Environmental Engineering Considerations and Laboratory Tests (MIL-STD-810) and is essentially a drop test. It's worth noting that thicker and heavier cases such as the Pelican ProGear Vault, for example, are built to meet the same shock protection standard. However, manufacturers have a lot of leeway in carrying out the tests and there is no industry group or certification authority for consumer products making these claims. See the comments to this review for a link to a webpage that discusses MIL-STD-810 and how it can be applied to consumer electronics and accessories.

The Atmos X3 is a sturdy and well-made case for the iPhone 5c. It provides robust protection from minor drops and impacts yet does not add much weight or bulk to the phone. Cellular and Wi-Fi reception do not seem to be affected by the case. Access to all buttons, ports, and switches is unimpeded.A design feature I particularly like is how Thule has made holding an iPhone more secure by beveling the top and bottom edges around the entire case and adding a non-slip finish to the areas where you naturally grip the iPhone.I do have a quibble that is a matter of personal taste. A large, reflective silver Thule logo is prominently placed right by the rear camera cutout. While this does not affect the functionality at all, I feel it makes the case a little obnoxious.  Whenever you're holding the phone to your ear or taking a photo, the logo screams to the world you have a THULE CASE on your phone! Of course, the sort of person who flaunts, say, a Tumi carry-on or an Arc'teryx jacket won't be bothered at all. To each her/his own taste, right?Aesthetics aside, I like the Atmos X3 very much overall and have made it the main case for my phone...I just wish the Thule branding was more restrained. Four stars.

I never thought *this* would happen...Timbuk2 has, in effect, blown off the bike messenger gig, got a full-time job in an office and become kind of buttoned down. If you were good friends with an earlier version of the Classic Messenger, you might be wondering what's going on and if you'll be able to hang out with the new bag in the same way as before.Well, the Classic Messenger Bag 2014 is more or less the same on the inside as the previous Classic but has been scrubbed and cleaned up quite a bit on the outside. Now the squeeze clips are hidden away under the front flap, the main strap is softer and lighter, and the Timbuk2 logo patch has a more restrained look. Plus the new Cam buckle creates a sleeker, less-likely-to-get-caught-on-something profile by eliminating the gigantic loop of strap that used be created when the bag was hitched up high on your back.This new look seems a little odd at first since Timbuk2's style was fun and funky before. Crazy color combos, straps and reflectors hanging all over the place, and a cobbled together look was how Timbuk2 rolled before. But don't worry, the burly construction and comfortable feel have not changed. Things have just calmed down a bit and Timbuk2 is now set to move comfortably into middle age.So, if you're looking at your first messenger bag, Timbuk2 makes one of the best. They have a long history of quality workmanship and offer a lifetime warranty. If you're replacing a bag or adding to your collection, don't worry. The 2014 Classic may have become a bit boring on the surface but it's still a great messenger bag and won't let you down.----------AddendumTimbuk2 really does take its warranty program seriously. I recently sent them a bag with fabric and stitching that was beginning to tear. They are repairing my bag and returning it to me at no charge, even though I've been using the bag for over a year. Nice!

The FAVI Wireless Speaker for iPhone is interesting conceptually. It is a cradle that is able to amplify any sound generated by an iPhone without using a physical or Bluetooth connection. All you have to do is set your iPhone down on the Favi and it starts working. I tried it out with an iPhone 5c.Unfortunately, neither the wireless connection technology nor the cradle's amplifier and speaker are well suited for listening to music. Static and crackling is often introduced into the sound stream while the sound output quality itself is severely limited by a low-power amp and small speaker.Bottom line: for voice-only uses, such as conference calls, FaceTime, Siri, or non-musical audio and video streams, the Favi adds a bit of convenience if you're sitting at a desk or around a table. However, I view it as more of a toy than as a real aid to productivity.

If you're looking for a hard shell case for your iPad Mini (I have a non-Retina Mini), the Pelican ProGear Vault has an almost perfect design. It is well built with rugged materials, can act as a stand, and every port, jack, and switch is protected when the case is closed up.So what's not to like? Well, there are a few small flaws that are not showstoppers but could have been easily avoided with some minor design decisions:*The opening for the Lightning port will only accept cable plugs that are the exact same size as those on Apple-made cables. This means you cannot use any cables with plugs that are even slightly larger than Apple's design, as cables made by accessory manufacturers often have. The opening is also very deep, which makes it difficult to insert and remove a cable without pushing or pulling on the cable itself, rather than on the plug end. This stresses the cable in an area that isn't meant to withstand much pressure, torque, or force.*While a metal hinge is used to connect the top and bottom of the case, the latch used to close the case is made of rigid plastic. It seems likely that repeated use of the latch over time will weaken or break it. Pelican does have a lifetime guarantee, though, so it may be possible to get a replacement case if the latch does fail.*There isn't a really comfortable way to hold the iPad in portrait orientation. The case latch protrudes backwards when the case is fully opened, making it somewhat awkward to hold on the right hand side.*The case hinge is not stiff enough to allow a full range of positions when the case is acting as a stand in landscape orientation. When the stand is opened to more than a 30-40 degree angle, depending on the surface it's resting on, the stand no longer supports the iPad.These are all minor things, though, and take little away from an extremely protective and functional case. I like the Vault and have been very satisfied with its performance overall. Four stars.----------AddendumFor anybody trying to decide between the Pelican Vault and the OtterBox Defender (I have both), the choice mainly comes down to three things.First, do you want your iPad's camera to be protected by the case? The Vault's camera port has a transparent cover while the port on the Defender is just a hole in the case.Second, does having an integrated screen membrane matter to you? The Defender has a sheet of clear plastic that covers the iPad's screen at all times. On the Vault, the screen is uncovered when the case is open.Finally, are you forgetful or klutzy? The Defender has a two-piece design with its lid doubling as a stand. The lid and case are not connected in any way, so there is a larger potential for mishaps than with the Vault, where the lid and case are connected by a hinge.In any event, the Vault and Defender are very similar to one another; each is a burly, strongly constructed case with lots of protective features. You won't go wrong buying either one.Addendum 2See the comments to this review for additional information about Military Specification MIL-STD-810G and IP ratings.

I'm using the Belkin Dot Cover with a non-Retina iPad Mini. It is lightweight and provides basic protection to both the front and back of my iPad.Things I like:*Thin and light, with an easy-to-grip, soft matte finish.*The clasp is held in place magnetically both when the case is closed and when the case is used as a stand.*Easy to insert and remove iPad.*Understated, professional appearance.Overall, this a good case for undemanding environments, such as classrooms, offices, and cafes. Keep in mind, though, that it does not provide much shock protection and is not water resistant. It also does not automatically put the iPad to sleep when the cover is closed (an odd design decision). But if you appreciate minimalist design and are generally careful with your gadgets, the Dot Cover is a fine choice.

The OtterBox Clearly Protected screen cover does what it's supposed to: it provides scratch protection and makes it difficult to read the screen from certain angles.The big tradeoff, as you would expect, is that using the cover negates the benefits of having a Retina screen on your phone. Brightness, color intensity, and image clarity are all diminished by this cover, as with any privacy screen. It's like going back to the days when flat panel monitors and laptop screens had a vinyl anti-glare covering rather than a glossy, optically clear glass front.You can always crank up the screen's backlight to compensate for the cover's effect on brightness, of course, but then your phone's battery drains more quickly.In actual use, the effectiveness of the privacy function depends on what is being displayed on the screen and on an observer's viewing angle. Apps that use large typefaces or that have uncluttered designs, such as Apple's stock and weather apps, can still be read, even at a 45-degree angle from the phone. Busy, packed app interfaces are obscured pretty effectively, though, especially if they use a small or narrow font (the Bloomberg and BBC News apps are good examples of this).Bottom line: the Clearly Protected screen cover is simple to install and essentially does what it is designed to do, with some limitations. Even though I have stopped using it, I still think it is a four-star product because my issue is due to a personal preference--I like the sharpness and precision of Retina screens--and not to a design or manufacturing flaw.

...a flawed design and sloppy sewing keep me from giving the Lowepro Passport Sling II four or five stars.I like the concept of the Passport Sling. It doesn't scream CAMERA BAG! and is lightweight and comfortable to carry.So what's my problem? It comes down to a few design decisions and workmanship. Specifically,*The bag's shape is asymmetric, with one end coming up a lot higher than the other. Consequently, accessing the part of the bag that hangs closest to your body is awkward.*Lowepro should use a strap buckle that closes more securely and that allows persistent adjustments to the shoulder strap length. Many messenger-style bags have a cam buckle that maintains the same high and low positions every time you use the bag. The buckle on the Passport comes open too easily and cannot "store" your preferred strap lengths.*A problem common to most sling and messenger bags is compounded by the buckle: it is difficult and uncomfortable to put things in or take things out of the bag when it is worn in a high position. Since the buckle and shoulder strap have to be readjusted every time the bag is raised or lowered, it is a major hassle to go in and out of the bag frequently.*I'm disappointed by the quality of the sewing and finishing on the Passport. The stitching on the padded insert's Velcro is fraying after only a few uses. There are needle holes in several places on the main zipper tape. Finally, I had to trim hanging threads all over the strap, bag, and insert before using it. I have a couple of other Lowepro camera bags and haven't encountered these issues before.Despite these dislikes, I have found a use for the bag. If I'm going to a place on public transport and I'll only need to take my camera out of the bag once during a shoot, the Passport works well. But I cannot recommend the Passport as a primary camera bag.Three stars.

I've been using Amazon's version of Apple's USB A to Lightning cable with a variety of Apple mobile devices, including iPhones and an iPad Mini, for both charging and syncing.It works without any problems or warnings from iOS. Amazon has built its cable somewhat differently than Apple, though. First, both the USB and Lightning plugs are longer, wider, and thicker than on Apple's cable. This may be an advantage for people who have difficulty grasping and pulling small objects or have mobility problems with their hands. Second, the cable itself is slightly thicker and heavier than Apple's. Finally, the finish on the Amazon cable is somewhat slippery to the touch while Apple cables have a rubbery finish.The only (inconsequential) problem with Amazon's cable is related to the Frustration Free packaging certification. While the cable is packed in a box that is easy to open, the plug ends come tightly wrapped in sticky plastic. Removing this plastic wasn't as easy as "Frustration Free" implies.Bottom line: the AmazonBasics Lightning cable is a seamless, value priced alternative to Apple cables, as long as you don't mind having the Amazon logo on both plug ends. And keep in mind this cable may not fit into device cases with a narrow or deep Lightning opening. Four stars.

“There once was a little girl who had boundless imagination, and exploring was one of her favorite things to do. Every object in the house that caught her eye had a brilliant story of its own…” – Daria SongAs a child, I loved coloring. I wouldn’t say that I was the most artistically gifted of children, but picking up crayons and a coloring book was so freeing. While I secretly maintained a stash of markers and coloring pages throughout high school (and even college), I was absolutely thrilled when adult coloring books became “a thing.” The variety of coloring books is diverse, and some are clearly better than others, but The Time Garden is an absolute treat. Daria Song manages to blend stunning coloring pages on high quality paper with a charming story. The book is bound in a quality way making this a book that can be added to your shelf after you have colored the pictures of the story. The cover has delicate gold accents, and the book jacket gives the book a formal feeling (but can be removed when coloring, making it a practical touch as well). The Time Garden is a one-of-a-kind book that is both a timeless coloring book and a precious story book.  While the images are dainty and require precision to be colored in the most beautiful fashion, the story can be enjoyed by all ages. This book is truly a gem!

“Facebook might know that you’re one of M&M’s many fans and send you offers accordingly. they also know when you break up with your boyfriend, move to Texas, begin appearing in lots of pictures with your ex, and start dating him again. Google knows when you’re looking for a new car and can show the make and model preselected for just your psychographic. A thrill-seeking socially conscious Type B, M, 25-34? Here’s your Subaru. At the same time, Google also knows if you’re gay or angry or lonely or racist or worried that your mom has cancer. Twitter, Reddit, Tumblr, Instagram, all these companies are business first, but as a close second, they’re demographers of unprecedented reach, thoroughness, and importance. Practically as an accident, digital data can show us how we fight, how we love, how we age, who we are, and how we’re changing.” – Christian RudderDataclysm is, to put it simply, an eye-opening book that examines how digital data defines, changes, and informs us. Christian Rudder of the website OkCupid analyzes data for his career, so it is not surprising that he successfully compiled an engaging book that makes numbers and graphs fascinating. The topics examined through data are diverse and somewhat eclectic, but completely engaging. For example, topics like what makes relationships work, how individuals are likely to describe themselves, how writing has changed in the last decade, and even the most hated word in the world are examined. Numbers and algorithmic data have never been so fun or engaging.  Dataclysm is a great read – especially for those who realize that we may not be able to change the information that the internet collects on us, so we might as well embrace it.

I honestly wasn't expecting to love the Neutrogena Anti-Residue Shampoo as much as I did when I received a sample from Neutrogena! It was amazing. I have used different products to tame frizz and retain my curl (especially with the humidity of summer). Unfortunately, it builds up, and my hair can get a bit gunky and heavy. One was with this shampoo, though, and my hair was clean, soft, shiny, and gunk-free! I cannot celebrate this enough! So much better than I could have anticipated.

This is definitely not my normal review and post.  This is not a novel or a non-fiction memoir, but a creative, individually-driven journal that is simply amazing.  The Q&A A Day series has journals for all types, college students, couples, kids, etc., but this newest one is designed for creatives of all ages. With a simple prompt and a 4-square layout, this journal allows your imagination to run wild each day. Thoughtful prompts encourage out-of-the-box thinking and allow you to feel focused and refreshed each day. Plus, the four year style allows you to see four years of thoughts, progress, and reflections in a simple format…it is like a time capsule in book form.Prompts vary with each day having a new spin on creative thinking, but some of my favorites follow: How would you illustrate a smell that you love? What would best symbolize your life’s biggest challenge right now? Visualize the pros and cons of a decision you need to make. What if you had to wear a disguise today? Picture it here. And If you could change one thing about yourself today, what would it be?The response options are unlimited. Simply sketch, chart, write, or list your thoughts and begin a beautiful collection of ideas and inspirations.

The premise of Crooked Little Lies sounded great...a mysterious series of events, a missing young man, a former prescription pill addict.  All of these could have come together to allow for a suspenseful and engaging story. Instead, I found the characters to be shallow, predictable, and petulant. There was a lot of complaining, unnecessary whining, and a lack of depth (to both the characters and the plot). Character relationships begin and end suddenly, and while there are hints of suspenseful underpinnings, in reality, these are never fleshed out in a way that allows them to be engaging plot twists.  Despite the fact that I gave this book quite a bit of time, I couldn't get "into" it and found it to be a disappointment.

“Pope Francis insists on the dynamic element of the Church. In his homilies he is acting as a teacher of spiritual life, inciting us to move forward, to go to the existential peripheries, on mission. The way becomes the great metaphor of spiritual and ecclesiastical life. Only on the way is encounter possible. The way is, in this sense, the place of truth.” – Antonio SpadaroPope Francis has quickly become known for his approachable nature, his humility, and his relevant messages. His cheerful smile and undeniable warmth have made him a favorite among Catholics and non-Catholics alike. Encountering Truth captures these qualities in the most beautiful way with Pope Francis’ homilies from morning mass at Saint Martha’s chapel. Every morning, he observes mass with a devoted few; average people who are eager to join in the powerful celebration and gain inspiration from the pope. The simple homilies from these daily masses offer insight into Biblical passages as well as sound advice for those of us striving for faith in God in spite of the hectic pace of the modern world. Many of them have been collected in Encountering Truth so that devoted followers around the world can share in the wonders of the daily mass from a tiny Vatican chapel.Beginning with an engaging introduction by Antonio Spadaro, this book offers wisdom, insight, and most of all, reflections on scripture that are inspiring and comforting. With homilies focusing on grace, humility, courage, prayer, weakness, truth, and, hope, among others, this collection of 186 of Pope Francis’ brief homilies is an absolute gift. The brevity of each homily allows for a brief reading when there is time or a more in-depth study along with the provided Biblical passages. There is no need to rush through this book reading each homily; indeed, it is so much more beautiful when each passage is savored and fully appreciated.

This keychain is adorable!  I had to purchase it when on vacation because it is so darn cute. The combination of coral leather and navy/cream linen make for an adorable little accessory that is both fun and functional. The leather is a bit stiff still (my keychain is relatively new), but it is made of high quality materials. The one thing that makes this keychain a bit off is that the flat central ring is very wide. As a result, not all keys will fit on the keychain. Yes, there is a hook so that you can add a second ring or clip keys on easily, but if your goal is to have a cute and simple ring of keys, you may miss the mark. I was able to fit my essential keys on this, but my car key can't move from the small center section where the ring is thinnest, and my mailbox key doesn't fit on at all. I am willing to work with this for now, though. Hopefully it doesn't become too much of a problem. Overall, though, this is adorable.

I have tried a number of vegan protein powders. I have tried those with greens and without greens and all sorts of plant-based protein sources. This, however, was one of the worst that I have tried. It was chalky and had a really odd flavor. It was so bad that I could not continue to use it. It even had a bad aroma which was quite a deterrent when trying to eat something healthy. I would not recommend this.

Many books which examine the essential stories of the Bible fail to prove why these stories are significant. They provide a summary of the story, but don't elaborate on commentary.  As a teacher who has a Biblical Literacy unit in my class, this was less than ideal. I was thrilled to discover this book because it not only clarifies some of the most important stories in the Bible, but it also shows how these stories impacted literature, politics, and pop culture. It is a great read for anyone hoping to have a better understanding of the Bible (with or without any faith background). It is easy to read and accessible and offers a great explanation as to why it is so important for everyone to understand the Bible. Very useful resource; I highly recommend it!

I would rather do yoga at home than at the gym, so when I found Stratusphere Yoga, I was so excited. This DVD combines active yoga with strength training (through the weighted gloves that are recommended for each practice).  There are four different practices which target different parts of your body; you can do any or all of them. Trish Stratus is energetic and motivational, but not annoying or fake. There are modifications for yogis of all ability levels. I love that this DVD offers a yoga practice that is different than what most DVDs offer; it is energetic and I truly feel that it combines the best of both yoga (stretching, relaxation, refreshment) and an active workout (strength-training, increased heart rate, etc.).  I would recommend this to anyone trying to diversify their practice.

“My cooking changed when I became a vegetarian – all of a sudden I had to look at cooking in a completely different way. The building blocks that I had grown up with and the rules I had learned as a chef didn’t quite fit anymore. So the challenge to find new ways to add texture, interest, and flavor to my food have meant using a new palate of ingredients and some new techniques in the kitchen.” – Anna JonesWith a title like A Modern Way to Eat, Anna Jones’ vegetarian cookbook makes a bold claim: the healthiest, most exciting, way to eat in the modern world is a plant-based diet filled with delicious, exciting recipes. Jones, best known as Jamie Oliver’s UK food stylist, has created a lovely collection of complex vegetarian recipes that are sure to please all crowds. The pictures are a beautiful combination of scenery and recipe options, and Jones’ voice and advice throughout the book make for a book that is as enjoyable to read as it is to rely on for recipes in the kitchen.Jones’ signature style is a slightly elevated take on classics. Some of these are celebrated with specific recipes, but others offer readers the opportunity to get creative with flow charts that make for perfect meals (i.e. the ideal dinner salad). There are some delicious options for all times of day: Blueberry Pie Oatmeal, Butternut Squash and Kale Tart, Favorite Roasted Roots, Sweet Tomato and Black Bean Tortilla Bowls, Asparagus and Toasted Cashew Stir Fry, and Roasted Banana and Coconut Ice Cream. The recipes range from classics (like Banana, Blueberry, and Pecan Pancakes) to exotic new options (Raw Thai Citrus Crunch Salad). While some of the recipes are labor intensive, and some require hard-to-find ingredients, they are worth the effort. Jones celebrates the vegetarian lifestyle, but does not fully address other dietary preferences. This book is ideal for experienced chefs eager to expand their repertoire of delicious vegetarian options, but probably not well-suited for beginning chefs.

This deodorant is wonderful. I didn't expect much because the last time I used a clear gel, it was less than effective.  I decided to give this a shot, though after receiving it from BzzAgent. I am so glad that I did. I brought it with me to D.C. and Michigan when I went on a recent vacation. The humidity was unbearable and it was hot the whole time I was on vacation. Using Secret Outlast, though, I didn't worry once about feeling fresh. This deodorant works and was perfect for every outfit (I had to be dressed for a wedding and several family get togethers and didn't worry a bit about marks on my dark clothing).  Definitely a fan of this!

“I love to eat. A lot. I often joke that my current way of living evolved from needing to find a way to eat a lot and still be healthy. Therefore the diet I follow and encourage others to is not about sacrifice, deprivation, or labels. It is about enjoying delicious food to the fullest extent without counting calories or fat grams. it is about adding healthy, whole-food ingredients to what you are already cooking, taking things slowly, and approaching food with an open mind and a curious belly.” – Sarah BrittonMy New Roots: Inspired Plant-Based Recipes for Every Season is completely unexpected. It is a beautiful collection of creative, healthy recipes with stunning photos, but it is also a guide to having fun with healthy food. Sarah Britton, of the My New Roots blog, knows how to make delicious food that is filling, beautiful, and energizing. Britton has ingeniously arranged recipes according to season (even dividing summer into early and late in order to maximize the fresh ingredients that compliment each other in each season).  Some of my favorite options include Raspberry Breeze Smoothie, Pear Apple Crumble, Thai-Style Coconut Soup with Zucchini Noodles, Butternut Stacks with Kale Pesto and Butter Beans, Cleansing Grape Salsa, Carmelized Fennel on Herbed Polenta, and Grilled Zucchini and Green Onions with Baby Spinach and Hazelnuts.  All of the recipes are vibrant and packed with freshness!There are a few things to know before diving in, though. While the title of her book states plant-based (a term that is typically associated with a vegan diet), Britton focuses on a diverse diet that does in fact have some dairy (i.e. the ghee is made of butter, yet Britton’s tag suggests that it is vegan and optional cheese in some recipes) and eggs in it. This can be a bit confusing (and even frustrating at times), but the recipes are diverse enough to be appealing to a wide range of eaters. There are some recipes that require some exotic ingredients that may not be available to all readers (celeriac, trumpet mushrooms, garlic scapes, etc.), and some of the recipes require a substantial amount of effort.  Overall, though, this book is an excellent guide to healthy living with delicious recipes!Pina Colada Passion Fruit Popsicles8 medium passion fruit3 cups chopped fresh pineapple1 (14 ounce) can full-fat coconut milk2 tablespoons raw honey or pure maple syrup1. Scoop out the flesh from the passion fruit into a small bowl and set it aside. You will have about 1 cup total fruit pulp.2. Combine the pineapple, coconut milk, and honey in a blender, and blend on high speed until smooth.3. Into each Popsicle mold, pour a small amount of either the pineapple-coconut blend or the passion fruit pulp, and then alternate between the two until you’ve almost reached the top (leave a small amount of space at the top to allow the liquid to expand slightly in the freezer). Using a Popsicle stick or skewer, stir the liquids a little bit to create a marble effect.4. Insert a Popsicle stick in each mold, and freeze until completely frozen, about 4 hours.5. To serve, run each mold under warm water until the Popsicle slides out.

“When a school principal explains that your girl has thrown ink in someone’s face, there are probably certain things that you’re not supposed to do. You’re not supposed to break down in tears, divulging your personal problems. You shouldn’t act like the mother of a criminal, angrily insisting, “She could not have done this!” And you probably shouldn’t get so defensive that you ask what the other student did to provoke her. But when it happened to me, all my shoulds went right out the window…Callie and I shared a seven-hundred-square-foot apartment. We shared meals and gossip and jokes, and after her latest growth spurt, we’d even started sharing shoes…”But Callie’s so gentle,” I , and then I started giving examples. Spiders behind the toilet, beetles inside the screen door, half-dead flies drowsing on the windowsill.  Callie scooped each of them up and shuffled to the front door, where she released their bodies in the open air…“It’s our policy to met with parents before taking disciplinary action,” Mrs. Jameson told me.And that was when she said it. Bully. Bullying.”  – Lauren FrankelBullying is a topic that cannot be ignored in contemporary society. Bullies come in all shapes and sizes, and bullying takes all forms. Hyacinth Girls deftly addresses the complexity of bullying and its evolving nature with technology. Rebecca, a single dental hygenist is raising her best friend’s daughter, thirteen-year-old Callie.  Callie is sweet, pretty, and popular, and when Rebecca is notified by the middle school principal that Callie was bullying a classmate, Robyn, she is horrified.  She realizes that there must be some mistake, and after talking with Callie and her two best friends, she realizes that the whole situation is a misunderstanding.  After meeting with the principal, Rebecca shares all of this, then is informed that other students came forward and cleared Callie’s name.  Rebecca is still shaken, though, when Robyn’s mother calls and accuses Callie of ruining her daughter’s life.As Rebecca tries to put the pieces together and move on, she watches Callie change. Watching Callie suffer through the most difficult of adolescent times brings up her own memories of a childhood spent with Callie’s mother, and causes her to question what she knows about the girl she is raising.This book is creatively written, interspersing notes from Callie to Rebecca and flashbacks from Rebecca’s childhood.  Additionally, this book is set apart not only because of the powerful voice and the realistic plot, but because Callie also tells her story throughout.  Callie shares how events really unfolded and the secrets she kept from those who thought they knew her best.This book is compelling and engaging.  It is filled with twists and turns and unfolds naturally. Callie and Rebecca could be your next door neighbor or a close friend. Frankel is fantastic at creating a beautiful mystery out of things that could otherwise seem too ordinary to merit extraordinary story telling.  This is a must read for anyone who knows any adolescents or remembers the challenges of being one.

I was so disappointed by these olives.  The black olives were kalamata olives (not what I expected at all as they were not clearly labeled), and the green olives with garlic were extra spicy.  Some of the packages even tasted slightly rancid.  I was so disappointed and will certainly not be purchasing them again.

As an English teacher,  I teach The Odyssey to high school students. I have read multiple translations and have tried to use varied options to engage students in this classic text. This, however, is the first version that seems to really be relevant and engaging for my students.  Stephen Mitchell has done a fabulous job with it, making it both true to the original story and a wonderful contemporary read.  While I know that this is not necessarily the most authentic translation, it is well done and ideal for those who want to read this classic.

The title is quite deceiving, but the book offers some good advice.  The book offers some good insight into the whole dissertation process, but really is very similar to other quality dissertation books I have seen.  The advice is general and applicable to dissertations of all sorts, but I think that this could serve as a good introductory guide for those just beginning their work.

” Hey girl! It’s me – your old pal, Expensive Creams. Or should I say your NEW pal! We’re going to have so much fun together, you have no idea. It’s going to be wild. I have been waiting and waiting and waiting for this day You must have seen me, surely. On your mom’s shelves? In the windows of fancy department stores, wrapped up like precious gems from exotic lands? Ohhh, buddy. I’ve been watching since you were breaking into the medicine cabinet and slathering Pond’s all over your face till you were pasty white and crumbling like some kind of moon child. What you didn’t realize was that you were just practicing the extreme-y, creamy measures you would one day take in a futile attempt to stop the relentless pull of gravity.”- Monica HeiseyI Can’t Believe It’s Not Better is a smart, funny, and open guide to all that keeps gals up at night as they think about their careers, dating, food, and friends.  Monica, with cleverness and Canadian spunk navigates all of life’s mundane events with humor and a level of honesty that is most often found among true friends. Writing about burritos, how to handle a party, odes to cheese, and good/bad mistakes, Heisey is original and refreshing. At times the book can be a bit too goofy or honest for comfort, but overall, it is a thoroughly enjoyable read.  I Can’t Believe It’s Not Better is entertaining, and while ideally suited for twenty-somethings, this is a great read for any lady interested in getting a laugh and having a light read for summertime!

As someone who brings their lunch to work everyday, this is the one utensil that I have to bring to work. Packing a lunch is easy with this reliable tool.  I have used the plastic ones before, but after mine broke, I upgraded to this.  This is high quality and leaves no metal taste in my mouth. Great option for all kinds of dining on the go.

"What I saw there brought on a smile: backlit by the room behind her, Sister stood just barely over five feet tall, slightly hunched, wearing glasses, and attired in a full, traditional habit of long black veil, white coif, black tunic belted at the center, brown wooden rosary beads dangling from her waist, and sensible black shoes. There was just one deviation: she also wore a blue denim bib apron smeared with paint." - John SchlimmA seemingly lost soul forced to return to his hometown and await a permanent teaching position, John takes an unexpected trip with a friend - not a long trip, just a trip down the street, but a trip that will forever change his life.  John visits the ceramic shop at the local convent, a shop that he never knew existed despite its location beside his alma mater, the Catholic high school where he substitute teaches.  That one trip changed his life and forged his bond with Sister Augustine, a petite and compassionate nun who crafts ceramic statues at the convent's shop. Her calm nature, her dedication to her faith, and her joyful demeanor allow her to endear herself rather quickly to John. Soon, they forge a friendship, and the bond they share revolves around much more than ceramic statues of angels and the virgin Mary.Over five years, Sister Augustine teaches John life lesson and ceramic sculpting. John learns lessons of humility and thoughtfulness from a woman who continued to craft works of art well into her eighties. He has conversations about death, faith, and family, all the while learning about himself and his dreams.  This book is unexpectedly touching.  I expected a story about a nun and the lessons she shared with a young man, but I did not expect to love the story for its beauty and power. Schlimm writes with incredible voice, transporting readers to the small ceramic shop, through five years of conversations and changing perspectives. Needless to say, Five Years in Heaven: The Unlikely Friendship that Answered Life's Greatest Questions was absolutely lovely - a must read for anyone needing inspiration, joy or renewed faith.

“Most of us know that the way we eat is central to our well-being. But we may not always know exactly what ingredients to buy or meals to plan for the most satisfying, delicious and healthful results. This book will show you how easy it can be: Start with fresh produce, whole grains, and lean proteins; prepare them simply; and take the time to share and enjoy them.” - Martha StewartI love food. I love cooking food, eating food, and celebrating the way that healthy food makes me feel. In all honesty, though, there are times when too much of a good thing isn’t so good, and when I can’t seem to break out of a rut with the foods that I make.How refreshing it was to read Clean Slate, a beautiful book by the editors of Martha Stewart Living. The book is rich with information about the healthiest foods to integrate into your diet, the richest fruits and vegetables to make part of your daily routine, and the most delicious combination of antioxidant-packed foods in tempting recipes.  Rich photographs, a wealth of information, and a clearly organized collection of recipes identified as Vegan, Gluten-Free, Dairy-Free, and Nut-Free makes this book absolutely tempting. All of the recipes avoid butter, refined sugar, all-purpose flour and red meat, all in an effort to get readers the clean start they need to reexamine their eating and encourage new healthy habits.Options like Watercress and Potato Soup, Melon-Mint Smoothie, Squash Salad with Tomatoes, Zucchini Blossoms, and Ricotta, Warm Spinach White Bean Dip, Almond-Date Smoothie, Red Lentil Soup with Turnip and Parsley, and Lentil Burgers provide plenty of options for throughout the day.  The authors even include sweets that are healthy and delicious: Spiced Hot Dark Chocolate, Fig and Walnut Biscotti, and Coconut Water Ice Pops, among others. Overall, this book is an absolute treasure with options for anyone wishing to eat healthy and for all home chefs who are passionate about ingredients.A sample recipe featured at https://onceuponmyshelf.wordpress.com/2015/01/13/clean-slate-a-cookbook-and-guide/

As a vegan who works hard to incorporate protein and wholesome ingredients into my diet, I was so excited to see this book.  I had never heard of the author's blog, but looked at the book description and the reviews and felt confident with my purchase. When it arrived, though, I was so disappointed. The Amazon book preview stated that "All of the recipes are (or can be easily made): gluten-free, soy-free, nut-free, dairy-free, vegan." I am not sure how this is true as most of the recipes rely on a nut butter of some sort, and there are no specific suggestions for ingredient modifications. Additionally, despite the fact that I followed the recipes in every way (even using the specifically mentioned brands), the bars were mushy and runny (I had to freeze them just to get them to solidify).The flavors are great (German Chocolate Cake, Tiramisu, Caramel Macchiato, Peanut Butter Fudge, Chocolate Covered Strawberry, Orange Cranberry Quinoa, and Matcha Green Tea Almond Fudge, to name a few). Many, though, are covered in some sort of chocolate or caramel (making them a bit sweeter than I would like to see in my protein bars). Overall, this book is a disappointment and despite the promise of making my own protein bars at home, this book doesn't offer healthier solutions.

I was told by my doctor that I needed probiotics, and encouraged me to look for options that would be easily absorbable and enduring. When I found these, I thought for sure that I had a perfect solution.  Unfortunately, after switching from my previous brand to Probionix, I noticed few, if any, results. I added these to my water every day (sometimes multiple times a day) as directed, but there was no indication that they did anything. Most probiotics that I have tried have led to noticeable improvements in digestion, but I had no positive effects from this.  The only reason I gave this two stars was that it did not upset my stomach and was easy to use.

I had been looking for a suitable garbage bag that would be strong enough for standard garbage, but was more environmentally friendly.  After hearing the terrible reviews of so many of the 'green' bags on the market, I was excited to find these. They can be either white or black on the outside and have a sturdy drawstring; the bag is durable, but not extra thick.  They work perfectly in our kitchen garbage bins, and as a bonus, the cylindrical container saves space under our sink.  I will definitely purchase these again.

This set of drink flavorings is delicious, but it can be a bit easy to add to much to my water. I love the hint of sweetness and the yummy flavors, but it is important to figure out the right 'dosage' as it can be tricky to find the perfect level of sweetness.  These can be addictive and I love the variety of options in this kit - definitely a great way to get a bit of sweetness in my beverages without all of the yucky additives.

As a smoothie junkie, I have had loads of opportunities to integrate cacao nibs into dozens of smoothies, and I have tried so many different brands.  The Terrasoul brand, though, is so good that I am seeking out ways to make cacao nibs part of smoothies, overnight oats, baked goods, home-made protein bars, etc.  These are delicious with a rich chocolately aroma, and a delicious, slightly sweet taste. These are organic and have a number of other certifications, and well worth purchasing at this price.  This will certainly be the only brand of cacao nibs that I buy from now on; they are so good and so good for you!

I wanted to love these and indeed, the first time that I tried them, I thought that they were pretty tasty.  After about my third bar from the box, though, I found them to be dominated by the flavor of the dates and the texture of chia seeds.  These bars are made of loads of healthy ingredients, and it is always a plus when you can get goodies that are covered in chocolate, but I find these to have an odd aftertaste.  These bars are good, not great, and certainly have enough protein to tide you over mid-afternoon, but there is a slightly chalky-texture and if these bars get cold (whether by being put beside a cold refrigerated item or being left in a cold car), they become almost unbearably brick-like and overwhelmingly chewy.Overall, these aren't terrible, but they are not my favorites.  They have some great qualities, but there are others that I prefer.

Many people claim that lucuma is a sweetener, but I find that this delicious powder lends a hint of caramel flavor to smoothies, oatmeal, and even chocolate chip cookies.  This in no way would replace sugar for me, but a little goes a long way in giving treats a hint of caramel flavor. The light powder has a subtle flavor, and Terrasoul does the best job with lucuma.  It is delicious and has a slightly sweet aroma.  I do not eat this on its own, but when stirred into baked goods, smoothies, or overnight oats, it is a perfect touch!

While I saw other reviews that commented on the price of these tablets, I find that they are worth every penny.  These tablets are natural and easy to use for cleaning bottles of all sorts.  I take a glass water bottle and a glass tea bottle to work every day, and find that dish soap doesn't always do despite the fact that the tea bottle has a wider mouth.  With Bottle Bright, though, I am able to drop a tablet, let everything soak for a bit, and find clean, odor-free, residue-free bottles.  I have not tried this in plastic bottles because I do not drink from plastic bottles, but I love how this cleans and removes odors (of everything from tea to flavored water) from glass bottles and container lids.  Plus, the company donates to charity which makes me feel a bit better about my purchase.

As a gluten sensitive individual, I am always looking for healthy and hearty flours that I can use in home cooking.  I am thrilled with this Bob's Red Mill teff flour.  It is so delicious and is perfect for blending into other gluten-free flour mixes for a heartier baked good.  Plus, teff flour is filled with protein, iron and fiber, so it is tough to go wrong with this flour.  It is light and can make both sweet and savory baked goods absolutely delicious! While I was initially curious about whether I would be able to use all four packages in time, I am loving the diversity of this flour, and  I will definitely be purchasing this again.

“There’s a Japanese term I like to think of when it comes to many aspects of life – kaizen. It means ‘change for the better’ and consciously finessing, learning, and applying new ideas and experiences to shape a stronger, more successful daily process. Wellness is all about this type of continuous improvement.” – Heather CrosbyHeather Crosby, the visionary behind the YumUniverse blog, has compiled her wisdom and kitchen creativity into her cookbook.  YumUniverse is part memoir, part nutritional guide, and part tantalizing recipe collection.  With beautiful photos and approachable menu options, this cookbook is a wonderful addition to the collection of an experienced chef and a great introduction to vegan cooking for those trying to better understand a plant-based lifestyle.Crosby approaches the vegan lifestyle with wit and wisdom, honestly revealing her struggles with eating veggies and growing up loving junk food.  In an approachable manner, though, Crosby steps readers through a vegan pantry, transitioning to veganism, and eases readers into recipes that are both delicious, simple, and gluten-free.  With everything from how to  make a great egg substitute to how to create delicious non-dairy creams, this book is a compelling blend of resources and recipes. For example, Beautiful Breakfast Patties and Pear & Ginger Crepes are perfect complements to a weekend’s brunch. Toasted Superseed Power Bread and Chickpea Flatbread are just two of the tempting vegan gluten-free options here. Sweet Potato Sauce, Black Bean Soup, and Comforting Veggie Noodle Soup make for healthy and delicious dining.  Lentil Quinoa Kale Tacos, Asian Cabbage Salad and an entire chapter on sandwiches are a treat. Rainbow Veggie Ribbon Alfredo, Raspberry-Peach Fruit Leather, Salted Caramel Sauce, Mexican Unfried Ice Cream, and Maple Spiced Cream Sandwich Cookies are delicious! My only objection to this book is that there are only about a hundred (and not a million) menu items to choose from.Review and a recipe from onceuponmyshelf.wordpress.com

I have been a Chloe fan for a while and I was thrilled that she went back to a full menu for her third cookbook (while I loved her vegan desserts in her second book, it is nice to have diverse meal options here).  Chloe's Vegan Italian Kitchen is a true delight - it is jam packed with tantalizing recipes that are easy to make.  With options like White Wild Mushroom Pizza, Bowties in Garlic Cream Sauce, Eggplant Parmesan, and Wild Mushroom Farro with Lemon, Mint and Artichokes, there are a number of delicious dinner options There are great sides like Italian Chopped Salad, Cream of Mushroom Soup, and Broccoli Rabe with Garlicky Bread Bites.  There are even delicious desserts like Tiramisu and Italian Wedding Cake.  There are a number of gluten-, soy-, and nut-free recipes that are labeled clearly, and the food photos are completely tempting.  The one thing that is a bit goofy is the collection of Chloe-centered photos, but the food tastes so good that it is worth putting up with.  Overall, this is a book that I am thrilled to add to my collection - even my omnivore husband has been thrilled with the meals that I have made already.

“Vegan Holiday Cooking is for people who love to cook and who are constantly looking for innovative and delicious recipes. It’s for people who love to spend time in the kitchen, either alone or with friends, and create beautiful vegan food that is full of flavor and love.  It’s for cooks who love to bring everyone to the table to celebrate and savor the holidays.” – Vegan Holiday CookingAs a vegan home chef, I love the ease of making a quick meal at home.  When it comes to celebrations and making something extra special, though, finding the perfect recipe can be difficult.  Too many cookbooks focus on the everyday without emphasizing special occasions.  Vegan Holiday Cooking from Candle Cafe by Joy Pierson, Angel Ramos, and Jorge Pineda is the exception.  This book makes vegan dining a year round celebration.With menus for the Super Bowl, Easter, Thanksgiving, Cinco de Mayo, and other essential holidays, this book is a year round treasure trove of vegan recipes.  Plus, the photos and detailed descriptions associated with the recipes make for a visually stunning and absolutely informative cookbook.  Plus, options like Mini Muffins with Homemade Preserves, Crispy Black Bean Tacos, Big Barbecue Seitan Burgers, Vegan Cheese Plate, and Warm Apple Turnovers and Champagne Ice Cream are sure to become year round favorites.  Others, like Braised Cranberry Orange Tofu, Christmas Pomegranate Punch, and Joy’s Grandma’s Seitan Brisket with Roasted Carrots, Shallots and Turnips, you will be able to make any holiday more festive and exciting.This gem of a collection features recipes to suit every palate – vegans and omnivores alike.  While the recipes are not labeled as gluten free, there are a number that fit the bill.  Overall, though, this book is a winner and perfect for any holiday.

“The rhythms of life in Lebanon were unhurried, meaningful, and steeped in tradition. Food – both the preparation and the consumption – was a celebration of life, something to be savored and enjoyed. The ingredients were always fresh, the vegetables in season, and meat was eaten only once a week or on special occasions” – Joumana AccadI love eating international cuisines, but rarely do I feel confident with testing out exciting flavors in my own kitchen. Taste of Beirut by Joumana Accad, though, makes the delicious flavors of Lebanon a realistic option for any night of the week. With a wealth of insight regarding Lebanese cuisine (i.e. incorporate olives into every meal and lemons are used daily), and a diverse selection of delicious recipes, this book is an absolute treasure. The beautiful pictures and clear descriptions truly bring the flavors of Beirut to life.With recipes like Mint Pesto, Pine Nut Sauce, Turnip Pickles, and Walnut Sauce, there are delicious traditional sauces to enhance any recipe. Other options like Fava Bean Soup, Falafel Sandwich, Lentil Soup with Swiss Chard, Swiss Chard Stalks Dip, and Red Lentil and Pumpkin Dip are absolutely delicious. Red Pepper Hummus, and Baba Ghanouj are absolutely tempting!

“It can be scary to make new recipes for the first time, but you will be pleasantly surprised to discover how easy it is to make healthy safe pantry staples at home. Whether you are a novice in the kitchen or simply need new techniques and ingredients, you will find the guidance you need in this book.” -Colette Martin (p. xii)I love cooking, baking, and trying out new recipes, but nothing is worse than seeing a delicious recipe and realizing that it has all sorts of ingredients that I can’t tolerate (dairy, gluten, etc.). Fortunately, Colette Martin has solved all sorts of problems with The Allergy-Free Pantry: Make Your Own Staples, Snacks and More Without Wheat, Gluten, Dairy, Eggs, Soy or Nuts. This amazing collection of recipes avoids some of the most common allergens and each recipe is a breeze to make with all sorts of step-by-step instructions and an abundance of photos.Recipes like Brownie Bites, Potato Chips, Quinoa Bowl, Snickerdoodles, Cauliflower Cream and Creamed Vegetables, and Fried Polenta Sticks are sure to be hits (even for those who have no allergies or food intolerances).  There is a wealth of recipes for basics like Sunflower Seed Butter, Strawberry Jam, Dairy-Free Ranch Dressing, Homemade Buttery Spread, Nondairy Milks, and Sandwich Bread.  This book has you covered from breakast to dinner and has all sorts of recipes for in between, and with loads of detail and beautiful pictures, this book is a winner all around.

The water from the Mavea filter tastes delicious, but it has some odd flaws.  The filter is easy to install and the digital reader is easy to set.  The filter is set on a timer so that you must change it every 2 months regardless of how often you actually use it.  A bit of an odd setting.The water is added through the pitcher through a hole on the top that closes when the water reservoir is full.  Unfortunately, the hollow "bobble" closer does not close until there is no room left which actually leads to leaking from the handle and down the front of the pitcher (kind of frustrating as this mixes the tap water with the filtered water). The filtered water reservoir is pretty large, and the white color is neutral and subtle.  Overall, I really like this pitcher, but it takes some getting used to.

The Amazon picture does not do this bottle justice.  This bottle is a tall glass bottle that has a watermelon colored silicone wrapper with cute oblong cutouts. The silicone wrapper goes from the very bottom of the bottle to about an inch from the mouth opening.  The mouth of the bottle is about an inch in diameter and the glass is of a medium-thickness (I have another glass water bottle with a large opening and it is thick glass which makes for a heavy and clunky water bottle). The lid is a tear-shaped plastic piece that has a silicone stopper which is the only piece of the lid which actually touches the mouth of the bottle. The label says that this bottle is BPA free, phtalate free, lead free and responsibly produced. So far, it has proven to be durable for room temperature water (I don't like cold or icy water, so I am not sure how that would impact anything).

“When you do something over and over again, gradually increasing the difficulty, that’s how you get major brain change.” – Bend Your BrainI am a fan of puzzles, logic problems, word games, and brain benders. I love the challenge, and after reading Bend Your Brain: 151 Puzzles, Tips, and Tricks to Blow (and Grow) Your Mind, I love that I am working to improve my memory, spatial ability, coordination, critical thinking, and word skills. This book, full of challenging puzzles and exciting games makes building my memory an exciting activity. Options like Wordoku, Connect the (850) Dots, Visual Words, Recall the Logo Details, and Mazes make building your brain a blast.  There are dozens of different styles of puzzles in this collection, and because it is created by the geniuses behind Marbles: The Brain Store, these are designed to help your brain grow while having a good time.  The games target specific brain skills and are rated based upon difficulty, making this an approachable book for novice logicians and perfect for puzzle pros.  Plus, the clever infographics and bonus brain facts make this an engaging guide into the inner workings of the brain.  I loved the creativity of these puzzles and absolutely know what I will be buying some of my logic loving friends for Christmas! From onceuponmyshelf.wordpress.com

“Like many kids, I loved candy,  but less for eating it than for their colors and shapes and packaging.  I thought of it as another craft material possibility.” – Jodi LevineWhile I may not be the craftiest person around, I love cooking, baking and decorating, and when I feel particularly inspired, I will give crafting a whirl as long as the project is fun and enticing.  Things may be about to change, though.  Jodi Levine, a long-time staffer for Martha Stewart Living Magazine has perfected the art of creating decorations, candy, and even jewelry out of candy.  The themes are diverse – marshmallow polar bears, candy cane bowls, and clown cupcake toppers.  The steps are easy, and the results are adorable.  The projects are easy enough to get kids excited and promote creativity (many require little more than hard candy, marshmallows, or simple kitchen ingredients).  The options range from simple to sophisticated, but all are enjoyable.I may never look at hard candy in the same way! From onceuponmyshelf.wordpress.com

This B-12 spray is so easy to use (just spray once and you have your daily dose of B-12), and it is so tasty.  It tastes like raspberry juice and is delicious.  I love that it is vegan, gluten-free and organic; I don't want any fillers in my supplements.  I am so excited that Garden of Life has created this line as it is high quality and effective - I don't have to compromise at all.  The one thing that I did notice (which doesn't bother me) is that after spraying, sometimes there is a bit of red residue on the nozzle.  It is only a droplet, but it may bother some people.  Otherwise, this is a wonderful product!

Carol Roberts has written a wonderful guide that walks you through every step of the dissertation process. With in-depth detail and a personal voice, this is the book that has prove most helpful to me as I have begun the processes leading me toward my dissertation.  It is a great resource.

I love cooking and I love trying out new recipes.  While there are some flashy and bold cookbooks, some of the recipes lack flavor and originality.  Naturally, I was thrilled when I read Vegan Beans from Around the World by Kelsey Kinser.  This book is wonderful.  What is lacks in flashy photos and elaborately staged meals, it makes up for in originality and flavor. This book has quickly become a staple in my cooking routine and I cannot recommend it enough.Kinser has taken the time to create a vast repertoire of bean-based menu items that are simply amazing.  They are hearty and filling, but easy to make.  With options like African Peanut Soup, Dutch Split Pea Soup, Greek Lentil Salad, and Indonesian Raw Veggie Salad, there are a number of ways to create a light lunch. Main dishes like Falafel, Italian "Meat" Balls, Chana Masala, Chickpea Couscous, and Southwestern Chili are absolutely delicious (and are able to appeal to vegans and omnivores alike).  There are a number of kitchen staples like Cashew Sour Cream, Hummus and Soy Milk that are easily made with Kinser's guidance.  Additionally, dessert options like Sweet Red Bean Paste, Chickpea Cupcakes, and Navy Bean Pie are a wonderful way to incorporate the protein, fiber, and nutrients of beans into a wonderful treat.Vegan Beans from Around the World is a wonderful book - both for beginning and veteran vegans - and is a simple, straightforward guide to creating delicious bean-based menu items deliciously!

Worry Free Living is a faith-based guide to coping with anxiety and stress and is a great resource for all Christians who struggle with worry in general.  With scriptural messages, sound research, and powerful advice, this book is ideal for learning to deal with the debilitating effects of worry.  Anyone living in the 21st century recognizes that stress is an overwhelming emotion, but few have been able to write about it with the perfect balance of faith-based insight and practical medical advice that Cole and Ross have.  This is a wonderful guide overall.

The Whole Life Nutrition Cookbook is simply amazing.  With a wealth of information on nutrition related issues (like digestive woes, food allergies, and health concerns), this is more than a traditional cookbook.  This book has delicious recipes, but more importantly serves as a guide for whole life nutrition.  With the emphasis on being conscious of what you put into your body and its impact on your overall health, The Whole Life Nutrition Cookbook takes preparing healthy, delicious meals to the next level.  With options like the Green Grape Smoothie, Oatmeal-Blueberry-Banana Pancakes, Tofu Scramble, and Warming Miso Soup, it is easy to start the day off right.  The Spicy Black Bean Soup, Summer Vegetable Soup, Steamed Vegetables with Lemon-Garlic Dressing, and Oven Fries all make for delicious meal-time offerings.  Summer Vegetable Spaghetti, Artichoke and Almond Pate, and Lemon-Basil Pesto are delicious, as are the dessert offerings of Raspberry-Rhubarb Cobbler, Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies, and Grain-Free Chocolate Mini Cupcakes.  This book is absolutely a wonderful guide to all sorts of healthy meal options, but more importantly has so much sound information about cultivating healthy living habits that it is well worth diving into.

This video is a bit dated, but the footage is great. The video covers all of Turkey and goes in depth in a way that is hard to find in a relatively short documentary.  It is well done with lots of insight and information, but the film quality is fairly low.  I used this with my students and found that they liked the information, but many of them left with the notion that Turkish citizens eschew technology simply because of the age of this film. Well done as long as you realize it is a bit older.

I love the Sunwarrior Protein powder because it doesn't have soy and has only a handful of ingredients (versus so many powders which are packed with unpronounceable ingredients).  The flavor is great and the powder blends smoothly either on its own or in smoothies with no grit.  It is quite yummy and the price is wonderful.

I cannot say how much I love this book.  The fresh ingredients, simple recipes, and delicious flavors have forced me to relegate my other vegan cookbooks to the back of the cupboard.  This one is taking center stage, and for good reason.  It is packed with great recipes that are delicious for vegans and omnivores alike.  It also has a number of gluten-free recipes, meaning that everyone will be satisfied. With everything from delicious smoothies (the Gym Rat is my favorite) to Black Bean Sweet Potato Enchiladas, and from fruit crumbles to hearty dinner salads, this book covers it all.  With recipes for basics like hummus and salad dressings, and options like Tex-Mex casserole, this book is ideal for anyone who loves cooking.

Heroes of Kalevala was a game that quickly became addicting.  It has a wonderful story line, great art, and a fun puzzle game.  This is a pretty standard matching game, but it is fast paced and becomes increasingly challenging.  I love it!

Patrick Madrid has done it again.  With his personable approach and insightful writing, Madrid thoroughly examines the Catholic church and why it is so exciting to be a Catholic now.  With detailed examples, anecdotes, and a truthful examination of the good and bad of this faithful institution, Madrid celebrates the Catholic tradition.  By looking at the sacraments, mass, the Eucharist, Mary, the role of the pope, and the importance of Saints, this book not only is a great spiritual affirmation for anyone who is currently Catholic, but a great book for those who are interested in the Catholic church or are taking confirmation or RCIA courses.  Madrid's honesty is inspiring and his knowledge of the Catholic faith tradition is compelling.  This book is quite simply a one-stop guide for anyone who has ever asked "Why Be Catholic?"

The Whole Truth has the potential to be a great show - it is original in its scope and detail and has cleverly designed plot lines.  It quickly becomes predictable, though, and the acting (especially by Maura Tierney) is lackluster.  The characters frequently come across as flat and one-dimensional. They also seemingly fit all the stereotypes.  This series had a lot of potential, and it is entertaining, but don't look for depth or quality acting. Overall, it is enjoyable, though.

I purchased this book for a class and I am so glad that I had the chance to read it.  It is a captivating read that is absolutely eye-opening in its examination of the current American education system, the future of our nation's education system, and how we stack up against other nations.  Darling-Hammond, a Standford professor and an education advocate is very aware of the realities of testing, funding inequality, and teacher preparation and how each influences our current system.  The school to prison-pipeline, charter schools, and innovative teacher preparation programs are all taken into consideration as Darling-Hammond examines the current system. With strong data, dynamic cases, and eloquent voice, Darling-Hammond makes a clear case of what has gone wrong in education as it is currently employed, and makes compelling suggestions about what can be done to return America to its former glory as a strong educationally-minded nation.

Some books are spooky, some romantic, and some are a combination of the two.  The Vanishing by Wendy Web is a ghostly tale set in a mysterious, wooded mansion near the Canadian border and has just enough spookiness to keep you scared, and a hint of love to warm your heart.Julia is the widow of a Chicago investor who swindled millions from his clients.  Spiraling into a depression because her husband’s victims have been coming after her since he took his own life, Julia is thrilled when she gets the opportunity to escape it all and “vanish” with the help of a mysterious stranger.  Adrian Sinclair is the wealthy son of Amaris Sinclair, a famous writer who supposedly died decades ago.  In reality, though, Amaris has been hiding away from the public eye and Adrian offers to help Julia escape if she is willing to act as a friend to his aged mother.  When Julia meets Amaris, and the rest of the staff at the Havenwood Estate, she begins to suspect that there is more to the story.Dimly lit halls, ghostly apparitions, night time visitors, and footprints in the snow cause her to suspect that she may have been brought here for a very different reason.  Also, the fact that she so closely resembles a woman in a painting from a century ago makes her question the motives of the Sinclairs.This book has twists and turns and a unique plot; I came to like Julia and cheer her on as she tried to solve the mystery of Havenwood.  It is well worth a read!

Gabrielle Bernstein has gained a following for her common sense strategies focusing on calming, reflection, and spiritual growth.  Her new book, Miracles Now, emphasizes a number of simple strategies in the form of meditations to allow you to become more conscientious, less anxious, and live a more confident life.Although many of us are busy and rush about our daily lives, Miracles Now provides a wonderful starting point for beginning to calm down just a bit.  Each short reflection (no more than a few moments to read) emphasizes a way to connect to God, develop healthier habits, or help yourself and others.  Additionally, a brief Miracle Message follows the passage and is the perfect saying to ponder throughout the day (or tweet out as Bernstein suggests). For example, in the “Happiness is a Choice You Make” excerpt focusing on looking for happiness in God, not the external world, the Miracle Message is a simple statement: happiness is a choice I make.With over 100 reflections that range from powerful to commonsense, Bernstein has collected a set of advice to enhance your spiritual life, decrease anxiety, and celebrate life. Messages ranging from Stop Obsessing and Your Eyes Will See What You Desire to Lose the Stage fright and Pray Before You Pay are refreshing and motivating.

I have been listening to Relevant Radio for years.  I love the content and was thrilled to see that I can get it on my Kindle.  The player is easy to use and I am able to access live streaming content as well as recorded rosaries in various formats.  The one thing is that the player can get a bit glitchy and stop abruptly.  Overall this hasn't been a huge problem, just a minor annoyance, but I am hoping that it will be worked out soon.

I was a bit wary of purchasing these initially.  I wasn't sure if they would fit my Clarisonic Mia.  Fortunately, they were a perfect fit and work as well as the original ones at a fraction of the cost.  I had been overpaying for the Clarisonic ones for years; now I know to stick with these.  The one thing that is a bit different is that these come in a blank box with no directions, so a first-time user may be a bit confused.  Also, I noticed that these were a bit rougher than the Clarisonic brand for the first few uses, but either the bristles softened slightly or I grew used to the extra scrubbing.  Well worth the purchase overall, though.

Every now and again you come across a cookbook that is both inspiring and exciting.  The Blender Girl, of the eponymous blog, has created such a cookbook.  It is filled with vibrant color, brilliant flavors, and tantalizing combinations.  The recipes are packed with healthy ingredients, and each involves a high powered blender in the process of creating the masterpieces.Tess Masters takes the time to walk readers through the ingredients and how to make the most of your blender (on any budget).  It is in the recipes, however, that Masters (a.k.a. The Blender Girl) really shines.  The recipes highlight raw and superfoods and are all vegan with a number of gluten-free options. With creations like Raspberry-Lemon Cheesecake Smoothie, Apple Pie in a Glass Smoothie, Artichoke and White Bean Dip, and Awesome Almond Crackers, there are multiple ways to start off a snack session.  Amazing options like Basic Creamy Cheeze, Pine Nut “Parmesan:, and Macadamia “Feta” are great accompaniments to dozens of entrees, and recipes like Green Smoothie Fruit Leathers, Glowing Greek Salad, Mushroom Magic Soup, Savory, Sweet and Spicy Crepes, and Baked Caramel Apples round out a wonderful selection. The ingredients are readily available and the book is packed with diverse flavors, all of them getting a special touch with the help of the blender.The sauces, soups, dressings, and toppings made with the help of a blender and some great recipes are all consistently tasty and a great way to expand the range of your Vitamix beyond just smoothies. Mix on!

I purchased this book thinking that it would be a wonderful collection of short stories to better understand the events of Japan's triple disaster. The book is a set of short stories - both fiction and nonfiction - but some were so far out there and disconnected from the disaster that I had a hard time appreciating them.One story is about a bear who goes for a walk with a neighbor (human) after the disaster; another is about an imaginary dog who helps children recover from the disaster by taking on their ailments.  I recognize that these stories reflect a cultural element, but much of the book is creative fiction with little commentary on the disaster events - "Hiyoriyama", for example.There are a few gems within this book, but overall it is a bit of a disappointment.

As is the norm for Demi's books, the images are detailed and captivating.  The story is simple, yet thought provoking.  The moral at the end of the story is ideal for young children and older readers alike.Although this is a children's book, I am using it as a piece of a unit on Turkish culture with high school students.  They found the story charming and engaging; the visuals are intriguing enough to keep them interesting in a quick class read, but the story is clearly one which with they can relate.Great book overall!

This definitely is thick and kind of clunky, but it does do a good job of protecting the phone.  The screen protector is a bit off and is a bit short of the length of a Nokia Lumia 521.  It does cover the screen mostly, but leaves about 1/4" uncovered.  The stylus is pretty cheap and flimsy - definitely wouldn't buy it alone.  Overall, this is a good cheap phone case, but nothing fancy.

This app is wonderful - it offers loads of options for workouts at home or on the go. You get to select your workout length and type and have options like cardio, yoga, 7 minute workout, core workout and stretch.  There is a great narrative that moves you from one exercise to another, and if you don't know how to do a workout, just watch the video. This app makes it possible to get in a good 5 minute or 45 minute workout and is just great overall.

I recently moved my home-office into our second bedroom because it's much more conducive to working on my doctoral studies.  The only drawback is the Internet connection comes through the wall of the former office.  This means I have to connect via our home-Wi-Fi connection.  The old card I had was an 802.11g and reached less than half the bandwidth available.  So I decided to buy a new card.  The TP-LINK installed quickly and easily.  Just before I opened the case to install it, I went to their website and downloaded the driver.  This way I knew I'd have the latest and wouldn't have to deal with updating after the installation; plus I've done away with CD/DVD drives.  After installing the new card, I started up the system and ran the driver installation.  It immediately detected the card and installed drivers in less than 1 minute.  When I ran a broadband speed test I got the maximum upload and download speeds of my router!  It's blazing fast and I couldn't be more pleased with my purchase.  Also, it comes with both standard and low-profile brackets.

I decent Italian dressing without a lot of preservatives.  No maltodextrin, gluten or carrageenan!  I would have given 5 stars if it weren't for the poorly designed cap.  The inner spout piece kept getting stuck in the cap causing the dressing to gush out uncontrollably resulting in too much dressing.

These kitchen tongs are really attractive and great if you use color-code themes as I do.  They come in black and red.  I chose red for gluten-free cooking and grilling and have a set of black for regular use.  The silicone ends and grips work well and clean up nicely in the top drawer of the dishwasher.  I've been using them regularly for the past month and so far they're holding up well with no signs of wear or melting.FULL DISCLOSURE: I received these in exchange for my honest opinion.

This is my second food scraper.  The first one I bought is nice, but doesn't have a grip like the Sunsella.  It's also got an edge perfect for cutting into dough.  It's well constructed, goes through the dishwasher and makes a nice addition to my growing collection of stainless steel appliances and gadgets.FULL DISCLOSURE:  This product was provided for free in exchange for my unbiased opinion.
I love Suave products.  From their shampoo, to their conditioner and body wash.  The quality is great and the price can't be beat!

These measuring spoons are sturdy and go nicely with the rest of my stainless steel appliances and utensils.  I especially like that I can put them through the top-shelf of my dishwasher.FULL DISCLOSURE:  I received a set of these in exchange for my honest, unbiased opinion.

Does a nice job on the dishes and not on my hands.  Many harsh soaps tend to irritate and even blister my hands.  This product is gentle and does not give me dish-panned hands.  The fragrance is also pleasant.

The best topical product I've found so far.  I suffer from peripheral neuropathy and have for years.  Most pain relievers only diminish the pain for a few hours.  This stuff works all day!  It also works rather quickly.  The first time I applied it to my arm, which was throbbing from pain, it took about 10 minutes before the pain was completely gone and I'd forgotten all about my neuropathy until the next day when it reared its ugly head.  I've tried other topicals like this, but this is the only one with staying power!  Just be careful not to apply too much or to particularly sensitive areas, because it can burn.  I'd recommend trying out a small amount on the affected area and wait about 10 to 15 minutes.  If you don't feel burning by then, you're probably good to go.FULL DISCLOSURE:  I received this product in exchange for my honest, unbiased opinion.

Recently I upgraded my old computer system and needed a good backup solution.  I bought this device and a new SATA3 hard drive.  The Liztek device worked like a charm.  It was easy to install.  Windows detected it immediately and loaded the appropriate drivers.  I was able to successfully backup my entire hard drive to the new back disk in record time.  Now I use it on a weekly basis to create shadow copies of my system.  Very pleased with the performance!FULL DISCLOSURE:  I received this item in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

Better than your usual wine stopper, this one actually helps create a vacuum that preserves your unused bottle of wine for days.  Great for picnics!FULL DISCLOSURE:  I received this item to try in exchange for my unbiased opinion.

While I only have occasional back pain, I do like sitting on a thick cushion with good support.  This cushion provides good support and works great at home, in the car or in the office, but it's a bit large to be carrying around with you to a restaurant or on public transportation.  I use it primarily at the dinner table and in an older recliner for extra support.  It's especially helpful if you suffer from sacroiliitis.  Learn more: http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/what-is-sacroiliitis/Full Disclosure:  I received this product in exchange for my honest opinion.
