Very comfortable and highly effective at treating joint pain and peripheral neuropathy.  Read more here: http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/can-compression-gear-ease-the-pain-of-peripheral-neuropathy-and-joint-pain/Full Disclosure:  I received this product in exchange for my honest opinion.

Very comfortable and highly effective at treating joint pain and peripheral neuropathy.  Read more here: http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/can-compression-gear-ease-the-pain-of-peripheral-neuropathy-and-joint-pain/Full Disclosure:  I received this product in exchange for my honest opinion.

So far so good!  I bought this fan a week ago to help cool my system, especially the GPU, which was getting exceedingly hot after recent upgrades I'd performed on the system.  Now the system is purring like a kitten.  The blue light is a little bright but certainly not cornea-burning as some have suggested.  If your PC is in your bedroom, then this makes for a great nightlight.  The small amount of white noise emanating from it is barely noticeable and somewhat soothing.  Installation took a Phillips-head screwdriver and less than 5 minutes to complete.The one fact I overlooked when purchasing this fan is that it has just 3 pins instead of 4.  This simply means that while my system monitoring software can detect the fan and its speed, it cannot manipulate the speed automatically.  This isn't a big deal for me, but I thought it was important to point out.

I love this grow light! It fits lamps using a standard light bulb socket and provides ample light to grow healthy seedlings and nurse wilted plants.  I used it to nurse back to life a bamboo plant that was quickly fading due to neglect.  Within just a few days it was back on the road to recovery.  Now I've got it working on my newly planted seedlings which will be transplanted to the rooftop garden once they're big and healthy enough.  I'll update this review in a few weeks.Full Disclosure: I received this item in exchange for my honest opinion.

As someone who has constant struggles with low energy due to B-12 Deficiency Anemia brought on by multiple auto-immune diseases, it's nice to know there are choices to vitamin therapy beyond supplements and syringes.  With a gluten intolerance and the fact that many of the over-the-counter supplements contain gluten, I was thrilled to find this product.  I apply one patch each week and wear it for 24 hours.  That's it!  No side effects, no swallowing and no shots.  And my energy level has been relatively high and constant.  I highly recommend this product to anyone who suffers from fatigue due to a B-12 deficiency.  Read more here: http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/vitamin-b-12-super-energy-patch/Full Disclosure:  I received a coupon for a free sample of this product in exchange for my honest opinion.

This was a gift and I couldn't be more pleased.  By far the best coffee maker I've ever owned.  Keeps coffee hotter than traditional glass French presses; looks classy and has a filter plunger design that guides the filter to its target smoothly without skewing.  Thus, coffee grounds are kept out of your coffee!  Love this! See my Youtube review: http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/does-a-thermal-french-press-make-better-coffee/

We live in a circa 1920's brick 3-flat in Chicago.  Additionally, we live on a busy street with a school across from us and an alley beside us.  Due to the heavy traffic and dirt alley, we get a lot of dust in the house.  Even during the winter when all the windows are closed the dust builds up in just a day or two.  We decided to purchase two Whirlpool HEPA filtration units and positioned them at either ends of the house.  What a difference these units make.  The filters aren't cheap, but they last an entire year.  We've had both units going 24/7 for the past 3 years and they just keep going strong.  Dust is no longer a problem and the house can go a week or more before dust begins building up.  We're delighted with both the units, which we got from Abt, and the filters which we buy online because they're a bit cheaper.

Some of the best certified gluten-free oats I've found so far.  They're always fresh and make excellent oatmeal cookies.  I eat 1/2 cup of oatmeal each morning and it keep my digestive system going regularly.  Something greatly appreciated when you suffer from digestive issues like celiac disease and Crohn's disease.  Thank you Bob's Red Mill!  Here is an example of one of my favorite oatmeal cookie recipes made with this wonderful product: http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/gluten-free-oatmeal-chocolate-chip-cookies/

Excellent strength.  I use these in my large kitchen trash can which is actually 17 gallons.  Although I have to stretch these 13-gallon bags to fit the larger can, they take the stretching without compromising the bag.  I can pack these bags really full and then never tie.  Love 'em!

Beautiful, tough and the perfect sizes for all my chopping needs.  I treated them with mineral oil to help protect the surface and then started using them for all my chopping needs.  I've been using them for over a week now and they show no signs of wear.  They're simply beautiful and I couldn't be happier.Full disclosure: I received this set in exchange for an honest, unbiased opinion.

Glutino's has one of the most extensive and delicious product line of gluten-free snacks.  These bagel chips are delicious by themselves and even better in hot soup.  I recently made French onion soup and placed these bagel chips on top instead of a slice of bread.  Then I covered the soup bowls with a slice of Swiss cheese and baked them.  The result was wonderful!

The best all-purpose gluten-free flour I've come across.  As a person with a gluten-related disorder (celiac disease) I really appreciate companies like Pamela's adopting testing that falls well below the FDA-mandated threshold of 20 PPM.  This mix not only makes waffles and pancakes that rival wheat-based flours, it also makes wonderfully flavorful cupcakes, cookies and sweet breads like banana bread.  For some of the many recipes I've created using Pamela's Ultimate Baking and Pancake Mix, please visit my website at http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com and search the ARCHIVES menu for recipes.

Love this popcorn!  I just purchased three different flavors of this popcorn at HomeGoods and absolutely love that it is not only gluten-free, but certified gluten-free by GFS Labs -- One of the most prestigious testing facilities of its kind and with the most sensitive gluten-sensitivity testing available at 3 PPM.  This is important to people like me who suffer from celiac disease and cannot tolerate even the smallest traces of gluten.I also like that instead of sugar, they use corn syrup as a sweetener.  Not high fructose corn syrup, but just plain corn syrup, which makes it sweet, but not overly so.  And unlike similar products, it's NOT greasy.  Their products are also GMO-free if that's important to you.  It's also made right here in the good ole USA in Beverly Hills, California.

Goes on like regular body lotion with no unpleasant odor.  Took several applications to create an even tan without streaks, but the end result was a golden tan that lasted weeks.  Gloves are absolutely a must to prevent hands from staining.Full disclosure:  I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

I've always wanted a cake decorating kit.  After being diagnosed with a gluten-related disorder nearly a decade ago, I've had to learn to cook and bake at home.  I've gotten pretty good at the cooking part and have started to focus more on baking.  So when I got this kit I was delighted to finally begin to make fancy desserts.  My very first project was with a cocoa buttercream frosting.  It wasn't half-bad, but I definitely needed more practice.  This device is very intuitive and after just a couple of uses I began to become pretty proficient.  My biggest mistake so far was not allowing the cupcakes to cool long enough before topping them with the frosting.  There is a huge assortment of shapes I've not yet had the chance to try, but so far this has been a great addition to my baking arsenal.  Clean up is effort-free.  Just soak in soap and water for a few minutes and they clean up nicely.  I've provided a picture of my very first creation -- A raspberry cupcake with cocoa buttercream frosting with a splash of Patron XO Café tequila!FULL DISCLOSURE:  This product was a gift in exchange for my honest opinion.

As someone with a gluten-related disorder (celiac disease) who must avoid cross contact with other potentially-hazardous foods, it's comforting to know products like this exist and are readily available.  Even with the FDA's recent declaration the BPA plastic products are considered safe, I prefer to err on the safe side and know for certain I'm not getting them in my body.  This splatter guard has been a God-send.  It not only protects my food from falling splatter, but also protects my microwave oven from unnecessary splatter.  Making cleanup a breeze.  It's flat, so storage is no trouble at all.  It's also light weight and easy to take with you on the road.  I especially like the fact it fits small and large dishes.  The holes in the top work really well to vent steam and there's no risk of the lid flying off and exploding food everywhere.  I found it most useful for bowls of hot soup.  The only issue had experienced with the splatter guard was when heating food on a plate.  The guard has no sides, so it lays flat on top of your food.  If you happen to have cheese in the dish, it will tend to stick.  Also, if the dish does splatter, it will shoot out sideways onto the walls of the microwave.  Of course, that's easily remedied by using bowls instead of plates.  It's not a big issue, but definitely would have encouraged me to give it the full five stars.  The price is also reasonable, albeit, I think it went up since I got mine several weeks ago. You can see a picture of the product in use at my Instagram page: http://instagram.com/p/ycfE0YQwb3/FULL DISCLOSURE:  I received this as a gift in exchange for my honest opinion.

I love this stainless steel hip flask and use it almost everywhere I go.  I'll be taking it to Mexico with me next week to enjoy tequila on the beach!  This is the first flask I've ever owned and now I'm wondering why I didn't get one sooner.  It's light weight and stylish and holds up to 6 oz of liquid.  It cleans up easily with soap and water and looks as good as it did the day I got it.  I've heard that some flasks can leak, but so far this one's working like a charm.Full disclosure:  I received this product in exchange for my honest opinion.

Vitamin C serum is one of the hottest new products on the market.  And with good reason; there is strong evidence, including a 2002 study from the NIH, that concluded: “This formulation of vitamin C results in clinically visible and statistically significant improvement in wrinkling when used topically for 12 weeks.”  (See link below)I’ve tried a number of vitamin C serums, including New Radiance Naturals Vitamin C Serum, and so far I’ve have been very impressed with the results.  It’s designed to reduce fine lines, smooth the skin, clear up acne and make you look younger.  It even held diminish a scar I have on my face from surgery due to skin cancer.  I love the stuff!  Oh yes, and it’s gluten free for those with a gluten-related disorder like celiac disease.http://theglutenfreeprofessor.com/new-radiance-naturals-vitamin-c-serum/

I first saw these mats on a television commercial during the holidays.  I thought to myself "I've got to get one of these."  It turns out, they come in sets -- so I have two mats.  You lay them over your grill grates and voila!  A clean, safe Teflon-coated surface that's easy to clean.  They're flexible, so you can roll them up and put them in your luggage or in your beach bag for those times when you want to use a public-park grill without having to worry about scraping off all the sinister crusty black charcoal-like material clinging desperately to the grates.  And if like me you suffer from a food allergy or gluten-related disorder, this is a God-send!  You'll always have a surface you can trust no matter whose grill you end up using.Full Disclosure:  I received this item as a promotional gift in exchange for my honest opinion.

For me? This book is absolutely five stars (I'll explain why I deducted a star a bit later).Elizabeth Gilbert's TED Talk on creativity was a beautiful, honest, emotional piece about success and failure and what it means to be creative. Since then, I've been happy to listen to anything she has to say on creativity and writing.So this book is an absolute gift. It's a collection of very short essays on different topics, divided into six sections: Courage, Enchantment, Permission, Persistence, Trust, and Divinity.Within those, she has some solid, practical advice, and some more inspirational, theoretical ideas. She talks about how fear is just part of the package when you're doing something creative, so you need to recognize it's going to be there and learn not to let it make decisions for you. She talks about how sometimes ideas come to you but they're not actually for you (which is why you might struggle to create) - so we're not "stealing" ideas from each other, but they're floating around and hopefully you're aware enough to catch them. She talks about failure and regret and inspiration.I absolutely loved it.So why only 4 stars? Because while it's subtitled "Creative Living Beyond Fear," and she offers lip service a few times to non-writing creativity, she's really talking about writing. So for writers - 5 stars. For other artists - 4 stars.

The last activity monitor I had was the BodyBugg, which I really liked, except it had no display, so every time you wanted to see how you were doing, you had to check the app.Here there is an app, but you get most of the same information on the device, so you don't have to sync as frequently (or at all, frankly). There are apparently also an associated scale and "sleep system" (to control the temperature of your bed).This will definitely win no awards for style - the nuyu, frankly, looks cheap. It is a little square you can either snap into a rubbery plastic wristband, or put on a magnetic strap to wear on your belt. I thought for sure I would be popping the nuyu out of the band accidentally all the time, but that actually hasn't happened at all - it's very secure. So if you absolutely must have something attractive, this is not your activity tracker, but it's mostly unobtrusive and far cheaper than the alternative.The nuyu is also water-resistant. I wore it in the shower just to make sure it was as advertised, but I have to say I'm not entirely sure why that's a feature. So I don't miss out on the three steps I take turning around in the shower? Well, whatever. If that's important to you, note that it really is water-resistant.App: The app has a lower limit of 66 lbs and an upper limit of 331 lbs for your weight. I thought at first this might be a limitation of the nuyu scale, but that states no lower limit and an upper limit of 400 lbs. So if you're below or above those weights, you can still use it, but your calorie amounts won't be correct. Also, as other people have noted, the privacy policy you have to accept to use the app is ridiculous. Get it together, nuyu.Accuracy - well, here's where things fall apart. If you're comfortable knowing generally about how many calories you burn, steps you take, and sleep you get, this is fine. But if you're looking for precision statistics, I would doubt the nuyu.Sleep: It regularly overestimates my sleep, sometimes by an hour or more. Sometimes randomly it will add twenty minutes of sleep time during my day when I didn't sleep, and a couple of times I took naps and it didn't register it at all. Documentation on the nuyu is nil, so I'm not sure how it's judging sleep. By how much time I spend lying down? By pulse rate? If so, should I be wearing the wrist strap more tightly?Steps: The overall daily numbers are probably pretty close to right, but I usually sync it in the morning right when I wake up, and it tells me I've taken between 60-100 steps. I don't think I sleepwalk, and though I do often get up in the night to use the bathroom, that's a matter of ten steps, not 72. Anyway, overall I think it's probably generally close. Certainly if you're using it to monitor yourself and keep yourself motivated, it's fine.Calories: I have done my calories in an online calculator a few times and I come out within a few hundred. Again, documentation is lacking, so how are they calculating this? Off heart rate? Body temperature? Simple steps and weight algorithm?Battery life: The nuyu uses replaceable batteries (one of the reasons it's cheaper). The first battery I used that came with it failed in 3 days (syncing once a day - I keep the bluetooth on my phone off to preserve battery life). The second battery that I installed has been going steady for over a week.I like the nuyu, and for the price, it's fine. I wish it had better (read = any) documentation so I could understand how it works and use it better. But if you're looking for some general stats to challenge yourself to take better care of your health, this is a fine choice.

To me, this is a little bit of a solution in search of a problem - I've never really had a problem checking the temp of a shower with my hand, but I guess for the novelty value of knowing what temperature you like your shower at, this is a good thing. (Also, 92-degree water feels kind of cool - who knew?)I have not experienced the high-pitched whining at higher temperature, and though I wish the flow were a little more enthusiastic, it's fine to wash the shampoo out of my hair. (The highest setting is forceful, but narrow - feels a little "sharp," if that makes sense.)The light does flicker a little bit at the magenta setting, but I don't find it bothersome.It's a fine showerhead, but I wouldn't buy it unless you're interested in the temperature setting in particular.

We live in a dry climate and use a lot of lip balm.This goes on smoothly and holds together, even in warm environments.However, I have two problems with it: it's not incredibly moisturizing, and it has a number of questionable ingredients.If you live in a less dry climate, the level of moisture might not be as much of an issue. I find that unless I reapply constantly, my lips feel just as dry as before I used it.But the larger issue is that it contains a number of seed oils, including soybean oil, and we prefer something that's made of better ingredients, like coconut oil and beeswax (this includes these ingredients, but also a number of less healthy oils - even canola oil?!?!).If you are less picky about ingredients and don't live in a very arid climate, you may have better luck.

I have never been entirely happy with my Cuisinart, so I was curious about a replacement. I like Black & Decker's mini-choppers, despite their limitations, so I thought this one seemed worth a chance.And I'm really impressed!I love that it comes with numerous blades and disks (just a couple more than my Cuisinart) instead of having to buy extras. And the REAL bonus - there's a smartly designed storage unit for them. It's another thing you have to find space for in your kitchen, but it's so compact for all it holds I don't mind. We bought a stand-alone Cuisinart brand blade/disc storage container and it feels cheap and has never worked properly.Warning: as with my Black & Decker chopper, these blades are SHARP. Within minutes of opening this thing, I had sliced a finger pretty deep with the main chopping blade just by brushing my finger against it.It also comes with two bowls - an 11 cup and a 4-cup. Yes, the 11 cup is smaller than my 14-cup Cuisinart, BUT, here's the thing: one of the reasons I've never liked the Cuisinart is that the blade sits so low I have to process in batches. So what's the point of a 14-cup bowl if I can't fill it? It's also nice not to have to use the enormous bowl if I'm only making pesto, for instance.Another advantage is that the base of the Cuisinart's bowl has a hole so big I always fear spilling when I'm taking it off the base, and I have to hold the blade in place.This is set up differently, with a smaller shaft to hold the blades and discs and less risk of spilling.The motor is strong and the blades are sharp. We made an ice cream recipe that involves frozen bananas and ice cubes, and the Black & Decker handled both no problem. And even though the blade sits low in the bowl, I didn't have to constantly take off the lid and move the food around in order to have it get to everything.We've made pesto, marinades, ice cream, and mashed cauliflower. In addition, I've used the slicing and chopping disks, both of which worked just great. We don't keep it on the counter, but it does have a nice look if you want to.If I had to buy another food processor, I'd choose this one over my Cuisinart. Sorry, old friend.

I just loved Matthew Dicks' Memoirs of an Imaginary Friend, so I grabbed this one right away. However, it's not as strong.Caroline Jacobs is a wallflower, until she finds herself unexpectedly telling off one of the smug members of the PTA. This lets loose something inside her and she takes off on an unexpected road trip with her teenage daughter to tell off a childhood bully.Both stories are good, but I kind of wished they'd been two different books - a YA about this girl and the loss of her friend, and an adult novel about a woman finding her voice. It fell more towards a YA tone and theme for me, and I just didn't feel a real adult resonance. It's a short book and a quick read, but it wasn't my favorite of his.

This was my least favorite of the Schuyler sisters trilogy, but I do like Beatriz Williams' books.If you've never read one of her books before, do not pass Go, do not collect $200, but proceed directly to A Hundred Summers. Then you can work your way through the Schuyler trilogy, starting with The Secret Life of Violet Grant.This works better as part of the trilogy than as a stand-alone book. I thought Pepper was the most interesting part of Tiny Little Thing, but unfortunately in this story, she's not developed much further. Mostly she exists to listen to someone else's story - Annabelle Dommerich, who owns the historical storyline in this book. I find WWII narratives to be a big yawn, so this was a disappointment for me, as neither storyline grabbed me.However! Beatriz Williams writes a good, fast-paced story. Most of her characters are emotionally chilly, but they sure do lead interesting lives. It's a good read, if not my favorite of hers.

This book was interesting, but for me not life-changing. As someone who's fairly risk-averse but feels more risk would make my life better, I wanted to see what I could learn.Kreamer's central thesis is that people, work-wise, fall into one of five categories:Pioneers, who are "very decisive" and "the most entrepreneurial" of the categories, and the most willing to take risks.Thinkers (most common type), who are interested in "sensible risks", but don't take them because of "worry about finances and family stability."Defenders (second most common), who "like things to be predictable" and think about work more as a paycheck than "a calling."Intentional Drifters, who "intentionally choose a free-form, freewheeling" approach to their work.Unintentional Drifters, who "have ended up in less-than-satisfying jobs due to external forces" and are disappointed by this.Kreamer then devotes a section to each type, giving examples, explaining how the type works, and how the type can learn to embrace risk (and therefore reap rewards) in their own way. I guess I would be categorized as a Thinker, but the description didn't entirely resonate with me, and the strategies she offered (carefully thinking through career options, trying things out) felt fair, if unexciting. Maybe if you feel like a type really fits you, you will have a different experience.There are other useful tidbits in here, mostly about how to think about risk - not as a blip, but as the way of the future and the past - and how it benefits us in our working lives. It's a quick and easy read, and worth checking out if you are interested in the question of risk.

If I hadn't been reading this for review, I would have abandoned it with a three-star rating about a quarter of the way through. This is the problem with reading a book you're lukewarm on all the way to the end - what is a mild disappointment becomes irrational resentment by the end.So I'll try not to be irrational.The best part of this book, hands-down, is the description of the John Muir Trail, where the main character Liz is hiking. The author's acknowledgements state that she hiked the trail herself, so the descriptions are really detailed and loving. Sometimes they veer into travelogue rather than plot, but because I was ultimately more interested in the trail than the story, I was okay with that. If you want an intro to hiking but don't feel like reading a guidebook, this would do fine for that.The suspense at the beginning regarding the bad guys was good, but since most of the book they just show up and are menacing for a page and then disappear again - in both the story and the main character's emotions - it wasn't sustainable for me.Liz has a lot of secrets and issues she needs to work through, but the author can't really come up with any better way for her to divulge them than randomly blurting out words which lead to a confession to her partner, who has an incredibly inconsistent moral code and the personality of cardboard.A lot of how you feel about this book will depend on how you react to Liz and her choices in the past. I was put off by one of them in particular and it colored my view of her for the rest of the book, especially because her explanation for why she'd done it was pretty flimsy, and it seemed like an irresponsible choice for a fully-grown adult in a committed relationship. But maybe you're more forgiving and you'll like her more.If you want a story about hiking the John Muir Trail, this is fine, but I wouldn't recommend it for more than that.

This is the second Shannon Stacey book I have read, and the second in this series, after Taken with You (The Kowalskis). These are part of a series, but while Taken With You was fine on its own, this one was a little harder to fully appreciate without the benefit of having read the others. This is partly because Liz and Drew apparently hooked up at someone else's wedding in a previous book, but mostly because a large portion of the book involves the extended Kowalski family, and given that I had no previous attachments to them, they were just names here.But that's not necessarily a flaw, depending on how you feel about series, just fair warning.Anyway, I liked both Liz and Drew. He's your standard-issue sexy small-town sheriff, but his protectiveness didn't come off as creepy as it often does. He was just straightforward and earnest and interested in Liz. For a fun twist, she was the one who was reluctant to commit and creeped out by how everyone immediately goes from zero to babies (which is a nice point about romance novels in general). But, shocker, she comes around in the end. Given that this is a romance, I'm not going to call that a spoiler.But the obstacles keeping them apart were kind of meh. Mostly something about her brother not wanting them to be together is the major issue, which seemed flimsy to me. Maybe it would make more sense if I read his book, but that I do think is a flaw - it should have been clear here why a man not wanting his friend to date his sister just because was an issue for a bunch of grown-ass adults. And her reluctance to commit is overcome so suddenly, literally in the course of one conversation, that it clearly was never an issue to begin with.However, I'm still rating this three stars, because it was a sweet, diverting read, with a little spice. I preferred Taken With You, but this was still a nice way to spend an afternoon.

As someone who travels and makes presentations, I have to say these are lifesavers. Easier to carry than a big flip chart, reusable, and very flexible.They're not complex - it's just a plastic sheet that adheres to a surface using static cling. I've used them on whiteboards (so I can write and then move the notes to a wall instead of erasing) and walls. The only place they wouldn't adhere was a brick wall - not enough smooth surface.Fun side note - my students LOVE them. Grown-ups turn into kids when you give them dry erase markers and a surface to draw on, and all the places I've used them at people have just thought they were the coolest.Just like a whiteboard, you can erase and use them again. The Expo markers are slightly lighter than on a whiteboard, and much lighter than a regular marker on a flip chart, so if you've got folks with limited vision or a really large room, they're not ideal.I wish they were a little smaller to be able to get the box easily into the different kinds of luggage I use for carry-on, but that's pretty much my only complaint. Thank you, Quartet!

Apparently, I've been living under a rock, because I had never heard of this blog or the ensuing kerfuffle over it. In addition, I don't even eat sandwiches, and I hate books with recipes. I chose to read it because I like a good memoir and a good love story, and I was interested in what she had to say about the internet backlash she received.I have to say if you like sandwiches and recipes, you may dig this book. There are not recipes for all 300 sandwiches in here, but there are plenty, and lots of them sound tasty.But the narrative between them felt thin and disappointing. Smith is a journalist, so she's a competent writer, but it reads - surprise, surprise - like she took her blog entries and stuck a bunch of recipes between them. It all feels like a report, not an analysis, even when she talks about her father's cancer and her own lumpectomy.To me, the best part of the book was when she discusses the internet attacks on her, but she's strangely unemotional about that (again with the reporting), and it's only seriously dealt with for fewer than ten pages. And as for the love story - I didn't find that very captivating either.Solid meh from me, with the recognition that if you are a serious foodie who doesn't just glance at the recipes, you might enjoy it more.

2.5 stars rounded up.If you asked me to write a summary of this book without looking at the back, I'd start with something like, "Audrey narrates a story about her older brother Frank, and his conflict with his mother over how much he plays video games." For the first third to half of the book, Audrey feels like an afterthought.Sophie Kinsella's voice is fun and sharp and funny (I very, very rarely laugh aloud when reading and I did twice in this book), just like her Shopaholic series.Storywise, however, I felt this was really flawed. Audrey is suffering from a severe anxiety disorder and depression, and you can piece together that this condition is a result of some serious bullying at school - severe enough that multiple students were expelled and an administrator fired. However, anything of substance is only alluded to - both the initial incidents and her breakdown. Because those are so vague, her symptoms and recovery are also vague, and what heals her in the end is, basically, getting a boyfriend.It was okay for a while for the core issues to be avoided, because she's not ready to face them yet. But when she does start to recover, it would have been easier to sympathize with and cheer for her if she faced her demons instead of just darting around them.This was just a missed opportunity. Not every book has to be a Lesson, but if you're going to tackle subjects like bullying and depression, tackle them. Don't meander around them for a few hundred pages and call it good.

This is a fine eyelash curler, though I'm not sure what makes it "ultimate." It's the same size as my trusty Sephora eyelash curler, and the pads are interchangeable. The feel of it as far as tension is the same too.I suppose the distinguishing feature of this is the "conditioning" pads, which feels kind of gimmicky. The pad seem to be the same material as regular eyelash curler pads, so whatever chamomile is "infused" into them is likely staying inside and not getting on your lashes. And you're only holding the pad against your lashes for a few seconds, and then probably applying a bunch of chemicals on top of them, so I'm not sure what good it's supposed to do. In addition, as others have mentioned, Googling doesn't seem to turn up anywhere to buy replacement pads, so after you're done, you can't replace them anyway.I only mention that because that seems to be its distinguishing feature. Otherwise, it's just an eyelash curler, and it works just fine for that purpose.

This book can be read very quickly, but I'm not entirely sure it should be. It took me a few re-reads of the first pages to get into the style, which is elegant stream-of-consciousness. You're in the narrator's head quite intimately.I responded to a lot of these issues - the dream of being an Art Monster versus the reality of family and bills to pay, the push-pull of motherhood, the confusion of betrayal. She's unhappy, but unclear about what she wants. She thinks her husband is perfect which only makes her feel more imperfect.“My plan was to never get married. I was going to be an art monster instead. Women almost never become art monsters because art monsters only concern themselves with art, never mundane things. Nabokov didn't even fold his own umbrella. Vera licked his stamps for him.”It's often unexpectedly funny (my favorite: calling therapy 'The Little Theater of Hurt Feelings), and even more often thought-provoking. Another favorite: “But now it seems possible that the truth about getting older is that there are fewer and fewer things to make fun of until finally there is nothing you are sure you will never be.”This book is about marriage and identity and compromise and art and a million other things. I enjoyed the first read and would like to read it again, because despite its slender size, there is a lot to think about.

These are teeny tiny - about the size of my thumbnail, but in dim light, they sparkle very prettily.You can barely see the blue, which is a shame, but they are a nice touch when you're looking up close.They have an interesting sort of snap closure, which keeps them securely on my ears, but takes a little pressure to open and close. I am slightly concerned about breaking them after long-term use.They're nice for a little sparkle without being fancy or overwhelming. Presented nicely in a pair of boxes. Nice for gift-giving to someone with subtle tastes.

As a flat iron, I would give this four stars. As a curling device, I would give it one.Some advantages over a traditional flat iron - it's light and you can use the brush to add extra smoothness. I also like that the top of the iron doesn't heat up so you can hold it with both hands (well, one hand on the handle and fingertips on the other end). It doesn't get too hot and there is no burning hair smell.However, the bristles mean you can't get the iron close to the roots of your hair, so you can't straighten from end to end. In addition, I've ended up with many more broken flyaways at the roots - I wonder if this is due to the brush?There's a lock to use it as a hot brush so you don't have to hold it closed. However, and I had the same problem with the InStyler Wet To Dry Rotating Iron, Purple, 1-1/4 Inch, the brush means that I never got good curls out of it. Whatever the heat does, the bristles of the brush ruin. In order to have good curl, the hairs have to cling together, and I found it impossible to make that happen with the brush. That said, my hair is thick and it's hard to get it to hold a non-natural curl in general, so read other reviews and see what others think.Since this doesn't really perform either function (straightening or curling) perfectly, I can't say I'd recommend it, but it's okay.

I used to love Marian Keyes, but her last few books have left me cold, including this one.Keyes' gift has always been approaching really difficult subjects - alcoholism, eating disorders, depression, domestic violence - by wrapping them in seemingly lighthearted stories, blending in humor and often flat-out silliness. That's still present here, but it doesn't quite work.Problem #1 is that the book's structure is confusing. She leaps repeatedly between time periods over the past 4 years. Some of that is handled with a change in font (major pet peeve), but then in the 'present day' font, she often veers into a lengthy flashback that just left me confused as to when we were in the story.Problem #2 is that the narrator, Stella, is unengaging. She's depressed, which is important to write about, but mostly means she spends a lot of time remembering things and eating her feelings. She didn't have any believable active conflict. The past, even when she's bedridden and (unbelievably) communicating by blinking her eyelids (not a spoiler - this comes out quite early on), is more interesting than the fallout, points about karma aside.And problem #3 is related - the mystery of how she got to where she is in present-day is thin and dragged out. It's easy to figure out who she thinks is responsible early on, and then the story just meanders around for 450 pages. If I hadn't had to finish this for a review, I would have tossed it after 50 pages.I feel terrible giving this a negative review, because Marian Keyes has given us lots of great books, but this just felt sloppy. However, I have read some positive reviews (was released already in the UK), so other people might have more fun.

This was very much just an okay read for me, but that was personal preference. I can see people enjoying this much more than I did.There's a busy plot with lots of characters to remember and lots of complications, which make it feel busy instead of just waiting for Ty and Vicky to get together. There's a sense of humor and some pretty slapsticky moments, which keep it lighthearted.There's a high sensuality level, which I usually like, but too often veered into crassness for my taste (eg repeated use of the word 'tit,' which is just kind of juvenile to me). Ty's wound over his wife's death was (a) jarringly dark for such an often wacky book (b) inconsistent and (c) offputting as the reason Vicky and Ty were initially at odds. I just can't see him getting over her involvement with the case so quickly. There were also too many other potential and past partners of Ty - when the hero and heroine meet, I want that to be it for each other, while Ty is happily feeling up and considering more with another woman well after his connection to Vicky has been established.I could nitpick like that all day, but in the end, it was enjoyable, so I'll rate it three stars with the knowledge that if you aren't put off by the things I am, you might like it more.

I usually just let my hair air-dry, partly to keep the curl in it, but mostly because I'm lazy. But when I do blow it dry, it ends up so frizzy I end up having to flat-iron it to make it look normal. My hope was this would solve both problems at once.For the record, my hair is chin-length and wavy/curly, and very thick.And it kind of does. It takes almost as long to dry my hair as a blow-dryer, but less time than blow-drying and then flat-ironing it. THE TRICK: Read the directions! If you're using it on wet hair, you can't drag it down like you would a flat iron. You have to hold it in place for a few seconds as you make your way down the section. This feels weird, because if you do this with a flat iron on wet hair, it'll start to burn and smell and break. But this works. However, it's not a blow-dryer, nor is it a miracle, so I wouldn't expect either of those things!It does not leave my hair with stick-straight ends like a flat iron, which I liked - I prefer not looking like straw. It also doesn't get as straight as a flat iron, and the roots were still frizzy, as with a blow dryer.I didn't have luck using it as a curling iron, which I think is a design flaw. For the record, my hair doesn't hold artificial curl well, because it's so heavy, but I think the issue here is that you create a curl with the heat, and then the tines of the brush/comb part break the curl right back up. There might be a trick to this, but I won't use it as a curling iron so I didn't bother researching further.I'll be honest - for the price, I might have been disappointed. But if you're lazy like me and are looking for something that will get your hair mostly dry without frizz or the scary burning smell of a flat iron, this is a good choice.

Just a reminder: "Student" edition means limited in features, not any easier.I was a regular user of Photoshop and InDesign a few years ago. And while time has passed, I imagine I could still do some of the more basic tasks - create objects and fill them, import and place photos, maybe do some light editing.CorelDRAW is more analogous to Adobe Illustrator, which I have never used. However, I thought my skills would translate, but I still felt quite lost when I first started. It's taken me two weeks to get the basics down, and I still feel far from being to emulate the more complex tasks that make Ilustrator so attractive and are the reason I was interested in it.There are hints on the right side, and easily accessible videos (Corel is big on videos, which can be helpful, but I would always rather read instructions - the link in the software takes you to the searchable manual online).If you're looking for an Adobe alternative, this is certainly feature-rich, but I have found it more complex than I would need and not terribly user-friendly.

This was a firm 'meh' from our cats. The first few times we took it out, they were engaged. They batted at the feathers and occasionally captured them, dragging it away (very awkward with the heavy ball at the base) to groom or "kill" it.The ball spins, but doesn't really move on our wood floors. We have a similar toy that rolls across the room that they seem to enjoy more. The feathers are definitely very attractive to them, but now that they've seen what it does, they tend to watch it for a few moments and then walk away.Long term, I worry about the feathers - they aren't sturdily attached and they don't seem easily replacable (I guess you have to buy an entirely new wand).All this said, our cats tend to like things that act more like prey - moving erratically across an entire room, rather than just spinning in one place. If your cats just like to play, they may enjoy this more.

Your enjoyment of these as a sweet will depend on how much sugar you're used to. Our only sugar comes from fruit, so I find coconut pretty sweet, and there's sweetener added to these (tapioca syrup, inulin and monkfruit), so I found these perfectly sweet and coconutty.They're tiny (1 inch diameter, 1/2 inch high), so they're definitely a "treat" and not a snack. I guess I just wonder why anyone would pay a dollar each for them - you could make something similar easily and with even cleaner ingredients.

I gave up the Shopaholic series after Shopaholic & Sister, which I thought was not just unfunny, but offensive. But for some reason I felt like I light read, so I chose this, and it's good. Unsurprisingly, I haven't really missed any plot developments except for her having a baby, who's basically ignored in this book, so not a problem.Look, if you want high literature, look elsewhere. But if you want light, silly escapades that strain credibility and a book you can read in a few hours, here's the one. Becky is in LA here, and her new obsession is with celebrity. She's decided she wants to be a stylist to the stars, and spends the book getting into one ridiculous situation after another in pursuit of the dream. When she stumbles into her own celebrity, she finds she likes the limelight herself, and takes it a bit too far, in typical Becky Bloomwood fashion.The book's only flaw is that it's too long - over 400 pages, and though Becky has actually matured some, she still grates after about 300. There were too many subplots, some of which are not resolved by the end, so I can guarantee you another installment in the series. I don't think I'll be in a rush to read that one, or catch up on the books I missed, but this was a pleasant way to spend an evening.

Andie Mitchell is a food blogger, and a pretty good one. Unfortunately, that skill doesn't translate well into book-writing (which I thought we'd learned already?).This book is not terrible. The beginning is painfully overwritten, with endless description - Mitchell has never met an adjective or adverb she didn't love. If you like food porn more than I do, you might tolerate it better, but either way, she settles down eventually into the story.The problem is, there's not much of a story. She had a childhood marred by her father's alcoholism and early death. She has a great brother and endlessly devoted mother. She used food to mask her pain and was very overweight for most of her life, but she was also prom queen and had lots of friends. She tried some diets that didn't work, but eventually lost the weight and then she takes you through an exhaustive run-down of her jobs since college.Maybe a Cheryl Strayed-level memoirist could have wrung more out of this story, and it definitely could have been an interesting personal essay, but as a book it's just okay.

Somehow I had initially gotten the impression that this book was upmarket women's fiction, like The Weird Sisters, or The Paris Wife: A Novel (Random House Reader's Circle). On the first page, I figured out that this was really just chick lit, so I revised my expectations, but this book still failed to be interesting.Allison has just moved back to her hometown with her son to give him a fresh start. Her husband died eleven years ago, so she finally figured it was time, I guess? Allison doesn't really have any problems: she's gorgeous, her parents are ridiculously supportive, her kid is great, and she promptly attracts a successful, attractive guy. Ostensibly her movement from grief back into life is the issue, but the tone of the book is fairly emotionless, so I never believed her grief was an actual issue, especially because it wasn't fresh.She becomes friends with Charlotte, who's shallow and unsympathetic when she's not wildly inconsistent. There's a manufactured crisis between the two of them, but it all works out.A lot of the issues with this book fall in the lack of demonstrating, the lack of "showing." There are few actual scenes, mostly just narration, so the emotional impact of anything that does happen to the characters is missing. There's also a lack of conflict - we're told Charlotte and her husband are having issues, but we never really see it, and he's so nice when he's not with her I mostly just felt bad for him that he had married her. We're told Charlotte's daughter is a problem, but we only see some mildly bratty behavior once, so I wasn't sure what the problem is. Everything interesting in the book either happened years ago or happens offstage.So ultimately, disappointing and bland for me.

Reading other reviews on this makes me feel a little foolish, because I did not find this easy to use or assemble AT ALL, and I'm still fumbling with it as I go.Here's the core of it: if you want to make things like zucchini noodles to replace pasta, and are tired of dealing with a julienne peeler, buy this. It does what it says it will do, and cleverly.My first piece of advice: read the manual. The designers have set up an ingenious system that doesn't waste space - the blades are stored in a little compartment under the machine, the handle comes off and stores inside, the blade folds down and there's a little plastic cover for the whole thing (that I still haven't managed to put on right). Seriously, I have a thousand Cuisinart pieces rattling around the cabinet - those folks could learn from Paderno. But you will never figure out where all the little bits fold up and slide in and snap on by yourself, so read the manual.Side note on that: the manual said to put the vegetable on the round holder. Mine has a rectangular holder. The pictures at that step are useless.Which brings me to my second piece of advice: watch some videos. They made clear to me what the manual did not.My third piece of advice: experiment, and be prepared to waste some veggies in the process. I've been unable to get small vegetables (carrot, small squash) to work, but I have gotten larger-diameter veggies to work easily. However, I've found it works better if you cut the veggies in half (widthwise), otherwise keeping the pressure up is awkward. But this is good anyway, because otherwise you'd end up with too-long zoodles or curly fries.If you're more mechanically-minded than I am, maybe you'll find using this easier from the get-go. However, despite all my frustrations, I still far prefer it to my julienne peeler, so I'll keep wrestling and hope it continues to get easier over time.EDITED TO ADD: I just ran across this in my cabinet and realized I hadn't used it since about a week after I wrote this review. Clearly not a can't-live-without gadget.

We own the Omron wrist blood pressure monitor, but I found the readings I was getting with it were wildly different than the ones at the doctor's office. Was it just a case of white-coat hypertension, or was the wrist monitor really that off? I decided to give this one a try.For most folks, this monitor will be just fine. The arm band is large enough for 24", and is easy to get on and off by yourself. It's noisy and not super-speedy, so you won't be able to use it in bed in the early morning without waking your partner, but it's easy to use. The display is big and clear enough for folks with limited vision, and it's easy to use - one button.I've used this regularly with the wrist monitor to see how they compare, and I can't say I've figured out a pattern yet. Sometimes the wrist is higher, sometimes this one is. They always agree on the pulse to within one or two beats, but the blood pressure, particularly the systolic, can vary between the two (taken at the same time or one right after the other) by as much as 20 points.I guess if all you need to know is whether your bp stays around the same level, this would be fine, but I can't say I've gotten any answer as far as accuracy is concerned, and given that both of the numbers I get are so different from the doctor's office, I'm not sure which one to believe.

It's hard to give this toy a negative review, because the cats love it so much. For that, it's 5 stars.BUT.There are three big problems:The first is that the feathers are not attached securely into the plastic at all, and fly off if you do anything bird-like.The second (related) is that the plastic part at the end of the feathers is cheap (as is the entire thing), and one good chomp from a cat breaks it easily.Both of those problems yield the same results: buying a LOT of replacement feathers. It's like a printer...they get you on the ink. We've tried taping and gluing the feathers in with no luck. If anyone has a better solution, we'd love to hear it.The third is unrelated but still kind of a pain - the string is literally that: string. So if you fling the bird around (the whole point), it gets tangled and knotted and it's very difficult to un-knot.And yet, we keep buying replacements. Why? The cats love it SO much.

I'm going to go ahead and give this two stars because when I put my food in, it was raw, and when I took it out, it was cooked. But other than that, this is not a great product.The timer hasn't worked right yet. Twice it's used some kind of new math, where even though it had been cooking for four-plus hours, the timer had only counted down 30-60 minutes. The first time this happened, I missed it entirely and only noticed what was happening when it started to smell burned (it was). The second, I checked at four hours and was able to turn it off, but that kind of defeats the purpose of a 'programmable' slow cooker, right?My Hamilton Beach 33969A Set 'n Forget Programmable Slow Cooker, 6-Quart has a lid that locks on and has rubber on the edge. Not so with this one. The metal edge of the top sits directly on the stoneware with no lock, which means the steam generated during cooking makes it rattle the whole time. If you're in the kitchen or within earshot, that's super-annoying.It is a good-looking product and easy to use.You can get a much more reliable slow cooker for a little more money and save yourself some burned dinners.

Setup was a snap, and it seems to pair pretty well with my iPhone 5. Once the phone pairs with it — either if the unit is in range of your phone, or else if other local devices with Bluetooth “see” it and let your phone know — it will show up on a map.When my phone is the only nearby device the map isn’t too precise. It shows the phone and TrackR in the same general vicinity, but isn’t more accurate than, say, 20 feet or so. That makes sense; there really is no way to triangulate position with only two devices. It may be that you get a much more accurate map if there are other nearby devices helping your phone “look” for the TrackR. (So, if three people in a crowd all had Bluetooth on and set their devices to “discoverable”, it might be that you get a really accurate map that shows you exactly where the unit is relative to your device.)In any case, the accuracy of the map isn’t a huge deal because you can press a “sound alarm” button that makes the TrackR produce a loud-enough-to-hear-but-not-so-loud-that-you-want-to-smash-it chirp. If you lose your keys this alarm will definitely lead you to them.The catch is that this only works if the phone and TrackR are connected, and in my limited testing the unit seems to disconnect after a while. If I turn Bluetooth off, wait a few minutes, and then turn it back on my phone still finds the TrackR just fine; the same is true if I power down the phone and then turn it back on before too long. But if I keep the phone and the TrackR apart for a couple of days the devices “lose” each other. You have to reconnect, and you can’t do this without pressing the button on the TrackR. So it might help you find the car keys you misplaced a few hours ago, but not the camera bag you put somewhere last week.

Though I consider myself a Bohjalian fan, I haven't read his last few - didn't want to read about a plane crash, and not a big fan of historical novels (though I respect him as a writer for trying something different).The thing I loved about his early books was that I always felt I learned something new - midwifery, homeopathy, dowsing. He seems to have left that behind, but in this case it's not a disappointment.Emily, the narrator and main character, just has such a great voice. She's engaging from the beginning, even though the way she tells the story is somewhat disjointed, it's a slow burn, requiring you to put the pieces together, rather than confusing.The disadvantage of the strength of her voice is that the book is really, really dark, and Emily is not only caught in that darkness, but she is deeply broken and difficult to love. Topics the book deals with include: a nuclear disaster and multiple ensuing deaths, repeated and casual drug abuse, homelessness, cutting, rape, prostitution, child abandonment, crime, radiation sickness, mental illness, and alcoholism.It is so well written that it's very readable, but I also found it unrelentingly dark. If you're a sensitive reader, it might be too much. But if you can handle that darkness, it's so beautifully done it's almost worth it.

Though I've loved many of Sue Miller's books, I could hardly remember this one from day to day. I didn't have any problems putting it down and felt no particular urge to pick it back up, other than to write this review.The three main storylines - Frankie's readjustment to life after her aid work in Africa, the arsons, and Frankie's father's illness and dementia - never gelled into a smooth whole. The book's description makes much of the conflict between the year-round and summer residents, but that is overstating that quite a bit - the conflict doesn't really arise until fairly far into the book, and it's pretty toothless, despite its potential.I liked the romance between Bud and Frankie, but there weren't really any obstacles to it, so while it was the piece that kept me reading, it didn't really amp up the drama.I was about to say I'd keep reading Sue Miller, but then I remembered The Lake Shore Limited, which I couldn't even finish. I'm not sure. Her recent work isn't painful, but it's not fabulous either. This one was just okay.

From the outset, there's a very Secret History feel to this book, which is probably why I fell for it. The tone is dark and moody; though the setting is a charming Italian city, it's been overrun by students, and there's a sinister disconnectedness to the place immediately.Irish Taz has arrived for a prestigious study abroad program, though she's a mediocre student, and is swept quickly into a glamorous group of four girls: wealthy, sophisticated, attractive. Taz is described as somewhat bland, so she's flattered to be accepted by the group, and naive enough not to ask questions where she should. Taz's character is really the main flaw of the book - she's a weak person, but also not clearly drawn, so often it feels like she's acting out of character rather than going through an arc.The book is clearly inspired by the Amanda Knox case, but I far preferred it to Cartwheel, which I couldn't even finish. The fact that this is from the victim's perspective (not a spoiler - you learn she's dead in the first few pages) allows Crouch a lot of leeway.Speaking of the author, if you've read Crouch's other books, this is a huge departure, but it's more memorable than those were, too.I have some quibbles with the end, but I won't divulge them for fear of spoilers. And overall, I really enjoyed the book and didn't want to put it down when I had to.

Can't comment on the accuracy, as I'm not pregnant this month, but they definitely are easy to use. Rather than squinting at a screen trying to decide if that second line actually is there or not, you get a digital display with a blinking cursor as the test works, and then a clear printed phrase, "Pregnant" or "Not Pregnant." The instructions state that the "Not Pregnant" result stays on the screen for 24 hours, the "Pregnant" result for 6 months. Nice if like me you're using first morning urine and want to go back to sleep (hey, it's not my first rodeo).There's been a redesign since what's pictured on the box - it's larger with a much larger display and more square than rounded.Lots of reviews about false positives. Remember chemical pregnancies can give an early positive. Best to endure the 2ww and wait until your period is late.

We've got clay-ish soil, so I was a little worried about this tool, but I thought it was dead easy. Put it in straight down, put your foot on the bar to push it down, pull it back out. Our lawn is small, but it's not a difficult job. Took about half an hour.Some other reviews mentioned issues with the tines bending - not sure how that would happen if you use it on moist soil per the directions. It rained last night, we did the lawn this afternoon while the soil was still moist, but not wet. No problems with its pulling out clumps of grass or dirt.My only wish is that the tool were a little longer - we're tall and were doing a little more bending than I would like. But it was still easy and quick.

If you're a protein shake drinker, you've likely had the problem of thinking you've snapped the lid down only to shake it and end up with liquid all over your arm.This bottle offers an ingenious solution that made me very happy. You pull the lid down over the spout like a snap bottle, but then you have to turn it to close it entirely. It's just a nice little safety feature that made me realize how annoying I find the pure snap closures.I was doubtful of the propeller-looking mixer, but I actually think it works better than the metal spheres in my other bottles.Re: color. The bottle itself is kind of a smoky color that makes the shake look kind of unappetizing and hard to tell if you've blended fully. The purple is purple with pink accents. Pretty girly.I'm sold on this and when my other bottles wear out/get misplaced, I'll replace them with this style.

I usually use teabags, but this is a good teapot for loose tea. Removable infuser has fine mesh to keep tea leaves from sneaking through, goes all the way to the bottom of the pot for faster complete infusion. Tea is strong and rich (our preference) after steeping for 10 minutes.It is 4 cups, which given that our mugs are a little more than a cup, seemed small, but given that it doesn't keep tea warm effectively is probably for the best. Please note that - it's not designed to keep tea warm, just to infuse and pour.Other reviewers mentioned its weight, which I haven't seen as a problem. The pot we got is red (not lemon). The photo shows it as kind of a bright cherry red, but it's not that bright - somewhere in between that and a darker brick red. Pretty.Been happy going through the dishwasher a few times, so thumbs up if you're looking to replace your one-cup infuser!

We don't do much baking, but I do make some no-bake freezer treats, and I hated running out of paper liners (and the waste).These are, as pretty much everyone has mentioned, slightly smaller than you may be used to, but it's not as though they're the mini-cupcake size. They fit just fine in my muffin tin and held plenty.When I was removing the frozen product from the liners for the first time, it was a strange experience - you really have to pull, to the point where a paper liner would have torn. But once I got aggressive, they peeled off fine - no sticking, no scraps of paper sticking to the food, which was quite nice.They're a little awkward in the dishwasher, but durable and work well in the freezer.

On the one hand, I tend to believe that guidebooks are all fairly similar. On the other hand, once you get used to a certain label, it's hard to make changes.I like Rick Steves' advice, but the layout of his guidebooks bother me. The information is great, but the tall, thin format and the easy-to-tear paper, in addition to the lengthy explanations and descriptions can be a drag if you're on the go. (Ironically, I like to read those before I go, rather than having them with me on the ground.)This Lonely Plant Paris book is a more standard paperback size with heavier paper and lots of bright photos. Those are kind of a waste (who's going to be confused by whether or not they're looking at the Eiffel Tower?), but they look pretty.There's an introductory section with top sights, explanations of general cultural information in short, direct paragraphs, and pages in each section listing recommendations, so you can plan stops on the fly. The layout of the more detailed listings is by neighborhood, in standard guidebook format. Finally, there are a handful of less vital but often interesting chapters: day trips from the city, historical and cultural information, more cultural information (train stations! bike rental! public toilets!) and a short language primer.This is a good book for a brief visit with stops at the standard places (though they do have some fun recommendations that are not in every guidebook's top 10), with bonus points for the good and detailed cultural info. After slogging through Rick Steves' travelogues, this book just felt accessible and manageable, with just enough information to plan a pleasant journey.

I've been using a shipping freezer pack to tend to my tennis elbow. That stays cold for a long time, but it's not flexible, and there's no way to hold it on, so I end up tying it around my elbow with a bandanna.I jumped at this product because the picture on the box makes it look as though it has some way to attach the pack when it's wrapped around a "small" area (I don't know what child they wrapped it around for the picture, by the way - it barely meets around my wrist). This is not the case. It's just a cold pack, and I ended up tying it around my elbow with the same bandanna.It takes about 2 hours to freeze initially, and 30 minutes to re-freeze, as promised. The fabric is comfortable and the gel keeps it pliable.It stays cold for maybe 10 minutes, cool for quite a while longer.There's nothing wrong with it, per se, but there's not a whole lot right with it either. I think I'll stick with my freezer pack solution - it lasts longer, and since I have to tie it on anyway, there's no real advantage.

Our old speaker wire had degraded and we were continually losing audio from one speaker. This wire has solved the problem. It's very well-insulated, which means it's sending a strong and consistent sound signal. We'd never cut wire to length or stripped the insulation for installation before, but that was no problem, just standard household scissors did the trick. Twisting the wire into a connector-friendly shape also went fine.The product description makes a point of the box and the spool, so I'll just mention that the frustration-free packaging works as advertised.Good sound quality, seems like a bargain. Two thumbs up!

Salt Sugar Fat is an amazing and often depressing look at the food industry in America. The fact is, most of us aren't eating food, we're eating products. Michael Moss did extensive research, including visiting the laboratories where these companies (which seemed surprisingly open about their methods)create and design the products we call food, from Lunchables to soda to cereal.The authors of It Starts with Food: Discover the Whole30 and Change Your Life in Unexpected Ways talk about "food with no brakes", food products that are designed to appeal to our sense of taste and have no genuine ingredients that give us any signals of satiety, leading to overconsumption. Moss talks about how the food industry uses salt, sugar, and fat to create these foods without brakes, and how their marketing departments get them into our hands. I won't lie - reading it gave me some mouth cravings for sugary cereals, but when he talks about the number of scientists and the chemicals they use to make these products tasty and shelf-stable, it's hard to keep those cravings going.Though it was an interesting, often fascinating read, I'm giving it 3 stars for two reasons - first, it's too long. Salt, sugar, and fat each have their own section, but that's really unnecessary, as Moss is making the same points (and occasionally repeating the same anecdotes) about each one. Second, his nutrition science is behind the times - for instance, he talks in the fat section about the dangers of saturated fats, which is questionable, and ignores the real issue of the kinds of fats these companies use - highly processed, unnatural seed oils.If you're interested in nutrition, this book is totally worth a read, despite its flaws.

Living Paleo for Dummies won't give you all the information you need, but I guess that's not really the point of the For Dummies books. If you're already pretty familiar with the Paleo lifestyle, this would serve as a good refresher, but won't give you anything new. However, if you're unfamiliar or trying to find something good to share with someone who is, this is a good start. It covers the food, certainly, but also lifestyle ideas like Mark Sisson does for fitness in The Primal Blueprint: Reprogram your genes for effortless weight loss, vibrant health, and boundless energy (Primal Blueprint Series) or the Hartwigs do for sleep in It Starts with Food: Discover the Whole30 and Change Your Life in Unexpected Ways.I don't know Dr. Petrucci, but Melissa Joulwan is a well-known paleo blogger and author of Well Fed: Paleo Recipes for People Who Love to Eat. Her writing has lots of personality, which shows through, but not in the annoyingly cutesy way that Dummies books can have (this is actually why I'd recommend this book over The Complete Idiot's Guide to Eating Paleo).There are a handful of included recipes, and while some of them will feel "out there" to people used to a Standard American Diet (Sesame Kale), lots of them will be a good intro - Spaghetti Squash & Meatballs, Leafy Tacos - to people who might think paleo is all about Flintstone-sized hunks of meat. And while our kids adapted pretty quickly to paleo, there are lots of helpful hints for folks whose families might be more resistant. Good job!

This replaced our home office Epson WorkForce Pro WP-4530 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax, iOS/Tablet/Smartphone/AirPrint Compatible (C11CB33201), which we really loved.The major bonuses to this as compared to the other were faster printing speed and two drawers for paper (we own our own business and do a lot of shipping, so a separate drawer for labels was a bonus). I didn't expect to love the touch-screen interface so much, but it is really wonderful - the only disadvantage is the onerous arrow key selection on the keyboard, but after you set up your wireless network, you'll rarely have to use it, so it's worth gritting your teeth through.Setup was a little bumpy, but I have the suspicion that was more to do with our network than the printer. The Epson scanner software isn't pretty, but it does a great job. And indeed this printer is fast and efficient, and thus far, low on ink usage. It also jams far less frequently than the previous Epson, which is a relief. It's small and low-profile for the amount it does, copies and scans and prints well (we don't use it for fax). Printing from iPhones and iPod and wireless printing also successful. Another new feature is Epson Connect, where you can email documents to your printer and they'll be waiting, all printed out, for you when you get back to it. This is a need I didn't know I had, but it's come in handy more than once.Overall, we're really happy with our 2nd Epson  - if you're in need of something slightly more than a home printer but not up to a laser, this is a great choice.

We've never been to Hawaii and were feeling overwhelmed about which island(s) to visit and what to choose, so we picked up this Fodor's to help. Help it did: on flipping through the first time, there's a chart at the beginning laying out reasons to visit each island (Beaches, Nature, Sports) and then at the beginning of each island's section, a list of highlights.The book is divided by island, then by locations and activities. As with other Fodor's Guides, I'm always fond of the Fodor's Choice listings - starred listings that can take you to their recommended restaurant or hotel or activity. If you like to do lots of your own research, this fairly slender guide will really only be a beginning, but if, like me, you just want an overview, selections like that are great.I've never been big on photos in travel guides, but there are plenty here, and they're gorgeous (though, to be fair, they are photographs of some really gorgeous places), along with lots of maps and other illustrations (including charts of types of leis and fish you might see while snorkeling).The book's greatest strength for me was its breadth, as it showed us a little bit of everything (with a surprising amount of detail in certain places - the Big Island's restaurant listing is 16 pages long - 18, if you count the map). However, if you know which island you're going to, you'll want to get a guidebook specific to that island. Because our trip isn't until next year, I can't tell you yet how their listings measure up, but certainly for the overview we wanted, this was exactly right.

We've set this up as external backup drive for one of our laptops. Though others have complained about the native software, we used it with Time Capsule, and it was truly plug-and-play.Cords are good length, all included, and the size was fine - it's the size of a large paperback book, the same as our other drives, with a nice unobtrusive design.Of course, the question with all hard drives is...how long will it last? Our other backup drives are Western Digital and iOmega, and we've had good luck with those, so we're hoping for the same here. If it dies, we'll update the review. Until then, it's all good news.

We needed a longer HDMI cable, and this one fit the bill. Perfect for people like us with unique or challenging A/V setups, yet delivers crystal-clear video and audio. We were pleasantly surprised by the quality.

I've never had a bamboo cutting board before, and if you haven't either, I recommend doing some research on caring for them. They will require oiling, you shouldn't use them for meat unless you're (a) willing to do some heavy disinfecting afterwards and (b) marking which side you've used for meat, and they have to be hand-washed and dried.However, if you want a board that will spare your knives and is made from a more sustainable material than wood, bamboo will do it, and this is a fine starter set.I was surprised how small the boards were (especially the smallest one), but they've turned out to be just fine. The smallest one is surprisingly handy for tasks like mincing garlic or chopping parsley, and I find myself reaching for it repeatedly.Frankly, I'm just not likely to take care of these the way they're meant to be (and I use ceramic knives, so that's not an issue), so I can't say I'm crazy about them, but they're a nice exposure without spending an enormous amount of money for a huge, heavy bamboo board at a pricy kitchenware shop.Edited to add: The longer I've had these, the less I use them. The extra steps in caring for them mean I'd just rather use my dishwasher-safe ones. What can I say? We're lazy cooks.

Assembled this puzzle tonight with the 4-year old. This definitely requires adult assistance.It comes with a half-sphere to build the halves of the ball on. The pieces are a good large size for little fingers, and they are numbered, so the adult can help locate the piece and the child can figure out where it goes (that's really the only educational part - the spacial relations present in any puzzle). They snap together tightly and the ball, once assembled, is sturdy.Love that you can keep things in it. He's snuggling with it now - blanky in one hand, ball in the other.As a bonus, I also got an age-appropriate similar puzzle from the same company for the 8-year old. That one was much tougher - the numbers are hard to read, smaller pieces are difficult to snap together, overall just much more complex. We got about a quarter of that done in the time it took to complete this one. Honestly, I'd rather have gotten two of these - she could have done it more independently but it would have been quicker and less frustrating.However, this one is a thumbs-up.

Length: 186 pagesStyle: Erotica RomanceStory: GOODIntimacy level: D.R.I.P (Don't Read In Public)Enjoyment: GOODSeries: (Compulsions Book 2)The GoodExcellent series and excellent chemistry. Book 2 Compulsive Fascination lives up to the name and if I didn't know any better I would think the author is trying to get me addicted to this series. I can only say that this is my personal preference and how I like my books from time to time. Calum oozes sex, sex, sex, and more f***ing sex, he is that hot. His demeanor, the way he handled Livana, it was a turn on for me. Livana was not your typical weak female character but she does get weak around Calum. The author build a kind of hyped/ chemistry in book 1 Addictive Lunacy, that I had such a release in book 2. If you are a fan of this author I wouldn't only suggest reading this book but her other books because I have yet to be disappointed.The BadI really have nothing bad to say about this book apart from the end.OverallOverall, I and you will get lost in this book, story and Calum and Liv's story. I promise you will be entertained and tickled in all the right places can't wait to read more.

Length: 177 pagesStyle: Erotica RomanceStory: GOODIntimacy level: Sex-citingly GOODEnjoyment: FAIRSeries: (Breaking the Declan Brothers, #1)3.5 StarsThe GoodI love the plot to this story, not only Emmie and Jax's storyline but Jax's brothers and the women they are about to encounter. This is your typical formula of boy meets girl at high school, both had crushes on the other and both reconnect after a few years. Jax was your silent sexy type and was very inviting with his words. Emmie was likable when around her friends and off course Jax. Their physical chemistry and interaction towards the end was more appeal for me. Seeing their story unfold makes one hungry to read the other books in the series.The BadEmmie could come off annoying as though she was still in high school at times but she was still likable in some ways. The build up between Jax and Emmie came off a bit repetitive and seems slow at one point but quickly recovered.OverallOverall, still a good quick read with likable characters to build on. The brothers sounds yummy, sexy with a bit of mystery to them.

This is the 62nd book in Kagero's Monographs series and volume II (of 2) devoted to the Ar 234. It is an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", 120 page, square bound card cover. There are three unbound fold outs included so, as always, if buying second hand make sure these are included.The book breaks down similarly to volume I, the previous volume in this series. The first 30 pages are devoted to a brief service history of the aircraft supported by numerous but not always the best quality black and white photos. There follows 24 pages of drawings reproduced from contemporary factory documentation. These are certainly not without interest but the German captions are not translated forcing the non-German speaking reader to online translation services for enlightenment. One and a quarter of the unbound foldouts also feature factory drawings.There follows two pages of modern line drawings of the Ar 234C-3 in 1/72nd scale. There are seven views - the normal six and a profile with the wing removed to show the entire, unobscured fuselage. One and a half of the unbound foldouts feature the same drawings in the larger 1/48th and 1/32nd scales. The final quarter of a foldout shows some detailed drawings by Brian Hygate of the Ar 234B including inboard profiles and many details.The book concludes with 64 pages (including rear cover) of high quality computer graphics of both the Ar 234B and Ar 234C. Exterior features are extensively covered.As was the case for volume I everything *except* for the modern line drawings and the computer graphics appeared in the first (one volume) edition of this book, Monograph 33 from 2007, by the same author. The present book also reproduces the black and white photos at a somewhat larger size in many cases. The cover painting is new as well. The earlier (2007 edition) also included some "masking foil" that is not included here.In conclusion, the drawings and graphics represent a substantial upgrade in value for my money and completely justifies buying both volumes of the new edition even if one has the first one. Way too often Kagero tries to get readers to double dip, that is, buy the same material twice with little to no new material. This time around they did it the right way.

This is the 61st book in Kagero's simply named "Monographs" series. It is a 8-1/4" x 11-3/4" square bound, 128 page card cover.
