There are also 2 unbound foldouts so if buying second hand make sure to ask if these are included.The book has several distinct sections. The first 50 pages are a design and development history of the Ar 234 up to and including the Ar 234C series. It is supported by numerous black and white photos including many of several iterations of a wooden mock up of the aircraft. It is followed by two pages of 1/72nd line drawings of the Ar 234B-2 in seven views, the traditional six views and a seventh profile with wing and engines omitted to give an uninterrupted fuselage. These drawings are reproduced in 1/48th and 1/32nd scales on the unbound foldouts.Then we come to the major contribution of this book - the 66 pages of high quality computer graphics. The concentration is heavily on the cockpit and the landing gear and I doubt that any reader will not learn more about the aircraft after examining these pages.The book concludes with four pages of color photographs of a preserved aircraft and 5 pages (including rear cover) of color profiles.All is excellently done. It remains to compare the contents of the present book with a previous volume in the Monographs series devoted to this aircraft. This was Monograph 33 by the same author. Everything in the present book appears in the previous book *except* the computer graphics and the line drawings. The black and white photos are reproduced in a larger size than in the previous book as well. Thus the present book constitutes (along with volume 2) a considerable upgrade to the previous book. The cover painting is completely new and the masking foil included in the previous volume is not included here.All in all, highly recommended whether one owns the previous book or not.

This is the 100th title in publisher Steve Ginter's long running Naval Fighters series. It is an 8-1/2" x 11", 128 page, square bound card cover. Unusually, for a Ginter title there is a fair amount of color to be found between the covers. Also, unusually for a Ginter title this is not a very good book.The following is speculation but I'm trying to be as generous as I can to the authors and publisher. The book has the feel of a fragment of a book that was hastily padded out and published after the death of one of the authors (Riley). As other reviewers have noted precious little of the book seems to deal with the nominal subject of the book. A very large percentage is nothing more than padding. I think Ginter published the book as a favor to the authors but I'm not sure he did them much of a favor.The silver lining of the book is the color content in the form of a few pages of color photos and some specially commissioned color profiles (I suspect by the authors and not the publisher). The attractive cover painting is also on the credit side of the ledger.I think the more appropriate way to publish this material would have been a normal book on, say, the Vought Corsair biplanes with the the Blue Goose material incorporated and Riley listed as co-author.In short, I can't recommend the book to any but the most diehard Naval Fighters completist. I certainly would not have bought the book if it wasn't in the Naval Fighters series. Again, I'm speculating but if publisher Ginter was trying to be a nice guy I don't think he quite pulled it off.

Marvel has these omnibuses down to a science now. As products they are really quite impressive. Physically, the book is about 11-1/4" tall, 7-3/4" wide, and about 2-1/4" thick. It has1176 pages. It is hardbound with decorated boards. The dustjacket front and spine are identical to the corresponding covers but the rear jacket cover has a montage of individual issue covers while the back cover proper depicts the werewolf battling Moon Knight. The interior pages are of a thin coated stock. This makes such a large book more manageable at the price of some opacity. The see through is minimal and I'll take the thinner stock any day. The binding is sewn so the book will stay open on any page with little or no effort. The book is hefty; I would guess about 5 pounds. It is probably best read with it open on a desk or table although I did not have any problems reading it while lying on my side with the book beside me on the bed. Reading it while on your back is probably out of the question, though.The content is equally impressive. All comic books make some demands on the reader as far as the willing suspension of disbelief goes but this one more than most. I have no problem with accepting that a man can turn into a werewolf. I do have some issues with the way that condition is handled in the book, though. Russell constantly fears he will harm someone as a werewolf but acts in such a manner that makes that a virtual certainty. He is constantly taken by surprise that there is a full moon on a given night. One would think that a werewolf would be a virtual walking almanac who could quote the rising and setting of the moon for months in advance. His father seems to have dealt with the problem of lycanthropy for years in a very capable manner; Russell just seems helpless. The relative power of the werewolf is also dialed up and down as required by the plot as well. Sometimes one man is more than he can handle; at other times he holds his own against demigods.But once you accept that Jack Russell is only going to be as intelligent and powerful as the plot demands we have some excellent stories. Heroes are typically only as good as the villains they face and the werewolf has quite the rogues gallery built up by series end. The supporting cast is excellent as well. The werewolf had a fair amount of crossovers and guest appearances with the various Marvel characters. Spider-Man, Dracula, Morbius, the Monster of Frankenstein, Moon Knight (his first appearance), and Iron Man all make appearances.The book is entirely self contained; this was before the company wide crossover made that virtually impossible. There is an unresolved subplot at the very end. Typically these get resolved in other titles after a book is cancelled but I don't know whether this one ever was.The artwork is generally excellent throughout. Most people prefer Mike Ploog but I think Don Perlin is the definitive werewolf artist. Doug Moench is unquestionably the best writer but the others are fine as well.Extras are fairly generous but nothing really special. There is a letter page announcement of series cancellation, art from the Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe series (but not the text), unused covers, original art (four to a page unfortunately), and a series of cover art from various previous werewolf collections.All in all, outstanding value and great entertainment. Jack Russell is a very likable hero, if not too bright on occasion. The first person narrative style really works well and sucks the reader right in. Highly recommended.

This is the 100th Warpaint book in a series that goes back at least 25 years in its current incarnation (there were previous short lived Warpaint series). It's hard to be certain as Warpaint books have never carried ISBNs or copyright dates. The book is an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", 72 page, square bound card cover. In addition to the 72 numbered pages there is a bound foldout that is equivalent to 4 additional pages. The author is Charles Stafrace who has written a number of excellent Warpaints in the series' later years. This book is well up to Stafrace's normal high standards.The subject of the book is one of those aircraft that, despite being built in large numbers and having served with many operators, has been neglected by authors and publishers because it saw little or no combat. This book goes some ways in making up for that neglect.Despite the book's title coverage is fairly complete of all the Republic swept wing jets. The XF-91, XF-84H, XF-84J, and RF-84K models are all covered as well.The book is well organized. The background, design, and development history is covered in more detail than is normal in a Warpaint book. The problems encountered during development are discussed in some detail as well. The rather brief service history in the USAF is detailed as well as service in the Air National Guard and it's association the the Thunderbirds aerobatic team. Then, in alphabetical order, the service history of the aircraft with the various US allies is covered. Especially interesting are the activities of French F-84Fs and RF-84Fs during the Suez crisis (where they flew in Israeli markings). This was the only shooting war the aircraft managed to get into although we also learn that F-84Fs in Turkish service shot down Iraqi intruders and that Greece came close to ordering strikes during the war over Cyprus.The text is well supported as always by many photographs with a fair proportion being in color. There are 7-1/2 pages of color profiles including the inside front and rear covers, 4 pages of high quality line drawings on the bound foldout, 21 tables (the majority taken up with serial number matches with the various operators), and 4 pages of detailed close-up photos in the "In Detail" section.This book is highly recommended. It is a worthy 100th book in the series and I hope there is a straight wing F-84 Thunderjet follow-up in the works.

This is the 35th (No. 16035) book in Kagero's Super Drawings in 3D series. It is published in the familiar format of an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", stapled card cover with 68 interior pages although the page numbering includes the card covers which is standard for this series.The subject is a welcome one, a dreadnought type battleship built in a nation which would shortly no longer exist, Austria-Hungary. The computer graphics, as always, are superbly done and give the reader an excellent impression of the exterior of the ship. There are a few features present which I have not seen on the ships in other volumes in this series. The openings where the main armament emerges from the turrets are closed off by metal panels which have to be opened for the guns to elevate. These are unfortunately always shown opened. There are also vent doors in the interiors of the funnels. I would have liked more detail here as well. There are also extensive views of the ship with the torpedo nets deployed.But this book has more than a few weaknesses as well. The text has never been a great selling point of these books but this book was especially lacking in this area. There was no discussion at all of the design or technical details of the ship. There is a service history of sorts but it is padded out with exposition about the political problems of the country which ultimately led to its partition. The translation is more than a little dodgy as well. There is the sentence "The Szent Istvan survived almost unscathed" followed by an account of her sinking! I think the authors were going for "The Szent Istvan almost survived unscathed". The captions are generally informative but rather brief. The constant use of "headlights" when "searchlights" was meant was annoying. The torpedo battery also gets short shrift, being below the waterline. Only the stern tube is mentioned in the captions. The covers for the side tubes are visible but not mentioned; I couldn't make out the bow tube at all.The worst failing was the lack of the usual unbound foldout  with conventional line drawings. All the reader gets is a full page advertisement for the volume in Kagero's Top Drawings series for this ship. I hope that this does not become the norm for this series.In conclusion, the book can be highly recommended on the computer graphics alone but if the conventional line drawings are important to you you may have to buy another book.

This is the 60th book (No. 3060) in Kagero's Monographs series. The book is an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", square bound, 144 page card cover. The book is devoted to the Dornier Do 17/Do 215, one of three bombers the Luftwaffe started WWII with and the only one of the three that didn't serve to war's end.The book breaks down into three parts. The first 100 pages are devoted to the background, design, development, and service history of the aircraft. The next 32 pages feature very high quality line drawings primarily in 1/72nd scale but with some fittings drawn bigger. There are a few pages of drawings in 1/96th scale detailing external differences between models. Color profiles and a few plans take up the remainder of the book and the rear cover.All is excellent and well worth the asking price but I can only award three stars because of Kagero's occasional practice of double dipping (enticing the consumer to buy the same material twice) as in this case.Seven years ago Kagero published a Do17/Do 215 book in this same series (it was number 39) with the same author. Are there major differences, justifying a new volume in the series? Sadly, no.The differences are minor. There is a new cover painting. The current volume does not have the masking foil the original did. The text in the current volume is spread over 100 pages instead of the 92 of the original. This permits some additional photos to be added and in fact some photos have been reproduced at a smaller size to squeeze in some more. The drawings are identical but in the current book the Polish captions have been removed leaving only English. The are three additional pages of color profiles and as with the drawings the Polish captions have been removed.In conclusion, I can only recommend this book if one doesn't already own the original in which case I highly recommend it. If one does own the original there is little point beyond obsessive completism (which I succumb to more often than I would like) to get this newer edition.

The book is the 99th in Steve Ginter's long running (over 30 years) Naval Fighters series. This one, I believe, is the biggest yet, coming in at 272 interior pages in a square bound 8-1/2" x 11" card cover. It is part 2 in the AD/A-1 Skyraider sub-series with at least one more volume to come. Color, as nearly always in a Ginter publication, is restricted to the front and rear covers.Whenever you see the word "squadrons" in the title of a Ginter book you can be certain that Ginter himself wrote it. Squadron histories are a Ginter forte. He has a standard format which presents a lot of information with a minimum of text. He briefly describes the history of the unit prior to receiving Skyraiders. It is interesting to note how few squadrons in this book go back to the '20s or '30s. He follows with models and numbers of aircraft in inventory, commanding officers, parent group or wing, deployments, and if applicable, combat history in Korea and Vietnam. He lists losses with pilots and other crew identified and memorable actions are detailed often in first person accounts. There are black and white photos of aircraft in the squadron's markings in almost every case. Almost all the photos are of full aircraft but one does see a lot detail like dive brakes opened in in flight photos. Almost every unit has a photo of a patch or insignia again in black and white.The book's glaring weakness is the paucity of color. The '50s and '60s were periods of colorful markings for Navy aircraft and black and white photos just can't do them justice no matter how often were told that the fin tip was green or the stripe was yellow outlined in black. The front and rear covers are just not enough. Can't we get just one 16 page signature of color photos in the interior? Specially commissioned color profiles would also be great.There are also a few typos throughout the book. The most glaring is a confusing reference to a (non-existent) "EA-1B". From context it is fairly easy to tell that "E-1B" (a non-Skyraider) was meant.In summary, there is great value here but the retail price is great as well. We all know what we can expect from a Ginter book these days. This one delivered.

This book is the 99th in the long running Warpaint series. How long running is difficult to ascertain; Warpaint titles do not carry ISBNs or copyright dates. This book is typical of the breed. It's an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4" stapled card cover with 48 interior pages. The card covers, both interior and exterior, are also pressed into service.Not a great many books have been devoted to the F3H/F-3. The only other one I possess is the Ginter Naval Fighters title of some years ago although I am anxious to take a look at the new all digital Detail & Scale offering of this aircraft. The present book is very well written giving equal weight to the development and description on the one hand and service history on the other. The development was complicated by the problems plaguing the Westinghouse J40 engine but the Allison J71 replacement was by no means trouble free. The service history was in contrast fairly straightforward with only one operator, the US Navy, not even Marine Corps or Naval Reserve service. This gives plenty of room for some welcome pilots perspective.The text is supported by numerous photographs, a great many in color. The are also 7 pages of color profiles, 2 pages of detailed line drawings at 1/72nd scale, and 4 tables (specifications, production, units, and kits/decals/accessories).There is little to complain about. A fair number of photos are spread across the fold but this is not as bad for a stapled book as for a square bound book. The line drawings and color profiles are all devoted to the -2 version but this is understandable as the only version to see service.Highly recommended. If you liked previous volumes in this series you should like this one as well.

It's an amazing thing watching TV shows you haven't seen in a half century. You keep saying things like "This is the one where they use the minisub's canopy as a shield!" or "This is the episode where they point the cameras at each other so they can't be watched!" or "This is the one where this thing is growing out of control through the sub!" as memories from long ago bubble to the surface.This show had all the problems that shows of that era shared. Budgets were low. Scripts varied widely in quality. Nothing carries over from previous episodes; it's as if every episode is a standalone. Indeed, later shows contradicted earlier ones on key points. Character development was virtually nonexistent.But the show had one great strength; the actors, whether cast or guests, never phoned it in. They squeezed what they could out of the script. Richard Basehart is particularly impressive in this regard; the material may be weak but he gives it all he has. David Hedison is not in the same league as Basehart in the talent department but he's still quite good. The other cast members don't get a lot of chances to shine but they never drag the show down either.The guests in this first season were a particularly impressive lot. Many familiar names although some were not so familiar at the time like Carroll O'Conner and Robert Duvall. I also was surprised how effective Werner Klemperer was in a dramatic, villainous role. I think he could have made an effective Blofeld in a James Bond movie had he not become typecast in his later Colonel Klink role.I really enjoyed watching these shows again but I have to admit the attraction was mostly but by no means completely nostalgia. I couldn't really recommend it to others who don't have a particular fondness for 1960s television. Adults will find it too unsophisticated for the most part and children will find it too dated.

This book has a lot of the features of previous volumes of the series. It has high production values throughout. It has a wonderful biographical feature on artist John Prentice supported by a good selection of non-Kirby work and photographs. It also has some great Kirby story arcs in the first half of the book. The first story has Honey Dorian in a very critical undercover role. The second (although rather short) features Kirby's nemesis, the Mangler, whose appearances are always welcome. The next two, while not as memorable, are good as well.The last four, however, while not without interest, seem to be non-Kirbyish somehow. The fifth story, Between Haven and Hell, has a somewhat absurd plot that is more reminiscent of the Phantom than Rip Kirby. The next, For Lack of Elise, has no real villain. The worst of the lot, Living in Harmony, doesn't involve crime, has an absurd plot, and wouldn't be out of place on the Twilight Zone. There is some recovery in the last story, The Packer Expedition, but even here Kirby is more of an action hero than detective and does nothing to catch the villain.Recommended despite reservations. Let's hope in the next volume we get some more Mangler and some Pagan Lee.

The 21st book (No. 16021) in Kagero's "Super Drawings in 3D" series is a stapled card cover of European A4 size (8-1/4" x 11-3/4"). There are 68 internal pages but the page numbering includes the card covers for obscure reasons. There is an unbound foldout included which has conventional 5 view line drawings in both 1/350th and 1/700th scales on one side and a large perspective drawing and various fittings in various scales on the other. As always make sure this is included if buying secondhand.There is a brief development history as usual. This is fairly adequate and correctly credits developments in fire control as the reason for the type's appearance. However, I think it confuses the later development of director control with earlier developments. It also doesn't mention the reversal of accommodations from the standard of crew forward and officers aft that this ship pioneered (unsuccessfully).The bulk of the book is devoted to the outstanding CAD drawings of the ship. These drawings depict the external details of the ship as it appeared when entering service in 1907. I believe this is the first book in the series to depict torpedo nets. These are shown in both the deployed and stowed conditions. Also interesting is the fairly austere rig of ships of this era before various electronics started to dominate. The extensive number of boats is also shown to good advantage. There is also the lack of antiaircraft armament and the the interesting disposition of the large number of anti-torpedo boat 12-pounders. On the other hand the locations of the broadside torpedo tubes cannot be found on the drawings.The captions can only be considered barely adequate. Lots of interesting features go unremarked despite room for lengthier captions.Highly recommended despite these quibbles. This series is all about eye candy.

This is the 33rd book (No. 6133) in MMP's long running "Yellow Series". Uniform with others in the series, the book is a 6-1/2" x 9" (European B5) sized, square bound card cover of 128 pages. Unusually, there are no unbound foldouts but there is a bound foldout, equivalent to 8 additional pages. There is color throughout in addition to a colorized photo on the cover.The author this time is Robert Michulec who will be familiar to readers of books from AJ Press, but not perhaps to readers of books from MMP. He wrote a 6 volume work on the Bf 109 for AJ Press (in Polish, condensed to 3 volumes in a rather rough English translation). Interestingly, at AJ Press the aircraft was referred to the Me 109 and Michulec defended that usage. Here, it's back to the conventional usage of Bf 109.The book is divided into three parts. First, there is an excellent design and development history which is excellently supported by black and white photographs. This covers all aspects of the Bf 109F, including the various subtypes and Rustzatz and Rustzustand modifications, tropical and GM 1-boosted versions, research efforts, production details, and more. There are also plenty of line drawings but all in 1/48th scale (the cover blurb about 3 scales shown on the Amazon cover shot does not appear on the actual product). In addition, there are some computer generated CAD drawings of the various cowlings and the tropical modification. There is also a color cockpit drawing on the foldout which appeared in the author's AJ Press books. It is of high quality but lacks the key identifying the various features.The second part of the book contains the color profiles, some with plan views. This section is about 25 pages long. It is supplemented by a gigantic color profile that stretches across 4 pages on one side of the foldout. All appears to be of excellent quality.The third part consists of close up photographs of surviving examples. These are supplemented not only by drawings from the contemporary technical literature but by more CAD drawings. There are also some period black and white photographs.Highly recommended. You can't have too many books about the Bf 109. Indeed, the appetite for books about any German aircraft of this period seems to be insatiable. I hope there are plans for Michulec to produce books about other Bf 109 versions. The E and G models were covered in the earliest books in this series but could use a thorough makeover.

The plot of this short story is really basic; it has been featured in comic books for the better part of a century and shows little sign of losing its appeal. Two superheroes arrive to fight the same menace. Do to a misunderstanding they wind up fighting each other. They eventually make up and finally defeat the menace by working as a team. And Riordan pulls it off quite nicely.The two superheroes are Percy Jackson and Carter Kane from different Riordan series. The story is told in first person from Carter's point of view but to compensate Percy, being older, comes across as somewhat more powerful and wiser although not by much. Riordan is clearly using this tale to test the waters of a future book or series. The sequel hooks are sharp and in plain sight.Fans of either or both Jackson and Kane will want to read this and the flexibility of electronic publishing makes it a snap to get a short story like this into the hands of a lot of readers. Highly recommended.

A few years ago I read an omnibus volume collecting the first three Jacqueline Kirby mysteries. I enjoyed that volume so much that I made a mental note to pick up the fourth (and, unfortunately, last) Kirby novel when my reading schedule permitted. That time finally came and I am happy to report that the book does not disappoint.Like many of Peters' books this one can be enjoyed on a number of levels. As a well plotted mystery it has enough plot twists and red herrings to satisfy most mystery lovers and only in a few instances is plausibility ever  in question. It also works as humor; the author clearly was having a good time writing this. It's also an expose of sorts, exposing the unpleasant side of the publishing business. And given that it revolves around the sequel to a famous novel one wonders if there was a not a bit of autobiographical material mixed in. One also wonders how much the fuss surrounding the sequel to Gone with the Wind influenced the book? Was Peters ever in the running for that plum gig?In any event the book is highly recommended. One doesn't really need to read the previous Kirby books to enjoy this one. It is a sequel of sorts to the previous "Die for Love" but the connection is fairly tenuous.The Kindle edition is perfectly formatted. One annoyance that can't be blamed on Kindle formatting was the use, several times, of "shouldn't of". English teachers worldwide must have shaken their heads wearily.

This book was a strange read for me and not because of the subject material. Any well researched book about haunted places (and this book is well researched) is going to have to deal with two narrative threads - what is believed and what is fact. Author Stollznow does not distinguish between the two very effectively. Her approach is very strange. Each chapter begins as if this is a book pulled off the occult shelf of the bookstore. Supernatural and paranormal claims, legend, rumor, and gossip, along with some actual fact, are presented in a matter of fact manner with no hint that the author has the slightest doubt about what she is relating. Then, at some point in the chapter, with no change of tone, the author begins to dole out the results of her research which effectively demolishes what she had related previously.I found this approach very off-putting and confusing. If it was intentional I can only say that it didn't do much for me. If it was due to lack of writing skill I'm more sympathetic but the effect was still annoying.The book is redeemed by the impressive amount of research. Stollznow seems to have visited each place and read extensively. The book is well illustrated by photographs, many taken by the author. The references given are a good starting point for anyone wishing to follow up.The Kindle edition is excellent with one major flaw. The Table of Contents does not appear in the menu; one must go to the beginning and page back to it. The Kindle edition is also rather overpriced; this is a rather short book for the asking price.The book can be recommended for those who aren't put off by the rather strange presentation.

More and more frequently these days I come across books because their authors are guests on podcasts I listen to. That was the case for the present book, the authors appearing on the "Monstertalk" podcast.This is a skeptical book but it is not a dismissive one. The authors take their subject quite seriously not the least because one of them (Loxton) is a convert from the believer camp. Often, when someone goes from believer to skeptic or skeptic to believer, it is merely to employ their irrationality, personal convictions, and close-mindedness in a new cause. But sometimes, as here, it is because the weight of evidence (or lack thereof) is bearing down irresistibly. Thus, in this book the reader comes away with the distinct impression that the authors are being fair and not grinding an axe.Beyond this, I was impressed by the amount of scholarship that went into this book. It is meticulously documented and the notes and references make up over a quarter of the book. A fair amount of this scholarship was harnessed to the task of their original contributions to the subject. This is especially apparent in their chapter on the sea serpent.There are five "cryptids" covered, bigfoot, yeti, the Loch Ness monster, the sea serpent, and "Mokele Mbembe". The coverage of the first four is excellent. The last appears to have been included to highlight the creationist agenda in cryptozoology but is certainly not without interest. The podcast interview said that other cryptids were cut on space grounds; I hope they can appear in a follow up book.The book concludes with a chapter where each coauthor gives his opinion on how much harm there might be in cryptozoology. Predictably, Loxton says not much, while Prothero opines that there is a great deal. I think Loxton makes the better case. Prothero comes off as shrill and alarmist.The Kindle edition is almost perfect. Even the index has its references linked. Since there are nearly hundreds of notes I do recommend reading this book on a touchscreen device to make navigation easier.About the only flaw in this book is the lack of a proper bibliography; the references have to be extracted from the notes. I'm sure lack of space played its part in the decision to omit one.Highly recommended to skeptics and believers alike. This is a fascinating, hard to put down book.

I read this book as a result of two other interests converging. I am a fan of Peters' Amelia Peabody books and also a fan of Robert M. Price's books on religion and its influence on popular culture. One of the latter, "Secret Scrolls", is an overview of novels that have lost gospels as a plot point. Peters' "The Dead Sea Cipher" was one so I decided to give it a try.It's a fairly typical Peters' effort. It is more or less equal parts mystery, romance, humor, history lesson, and travelogue. The book is quite entertaining and absorbing although having been written in the late '60s somewhat dated. The characters are interesting and believable. The mystery is not exactly Christie-esque in complexity but serviceable enough. The action sequences are also well done. Pace is a little on the slow side because Peters likes to work in a lot of history and travelogue as the setting moves from Beirut to Damascus to Jerusalem to the Dead Sea but this is handled fairly efficiently.The books only flaw (as Price pointed out) is that the reader never actually does find out what all the fuss is about. One might argue that this is not what the book was ultimately about but still the reader is bound to be a little frustrated if he has any interest at all in biblical matters.I read the Kindle edition. The only flaw is that the chapters are not marked on the progress bar so the reader doesn't have an immediate indication how far he has to read to finish a chapter. Otherwise, no issues. I recommend that the reader bookmark the cipher when it appears so he can easily refer back to it as the characters puzzle it out over the subsequent chapters.Recommended. Fairly standard Peters fare but that is well above average.

The 15th Fantastic Four masterworks collects over a full year's worth of issues (151-163) and two Giant-Size (3 and 4) published originally in late '74 to late '75. This seems like a lot and sure enough it is; there are about 300 pages in this volume. But it must be remembered that the page count in Marvel comics was at its nadir during this period. Roy Thomas writes his usual detailed introduction. Despite his claims of continuity maintained while artists and writers were shuffled in and out I think only the artwork is of consistent high quality throughout.The first two story arcs in this volume are rather pedestrian. Both the "Four Horseman" story in Giant Size #3 and Thundra's origin in 151-153 start out interestingly enough but in both cases the resolution seems lame and contrived. The worst of the lot is 154 which is basically a frame for a reprint of an old Strange Tales Human Torch story (not included, mercifully). Fortunately, it only takes up a few pages.Then things begin to pick up. Giant Size #4 introduces Madrox the Multiple Menace with a guest appearance by Professor X of the X-Men. The X-Men were in publishing limbo at this time and were making guest appearances to maintain their presence in the Marvel world. Then there is a great three part Dr. Doom and Silver Surfer story in 155-157 with a great twist at the end. Next up is a two part story with the Inhumans that puts Sue back on the team and Medusa back with the Inhumans. Finally, a rather over plotted but entertaining four issue clash with Arkon.Extras are generous and comprehensive. We get covers for the all reprint Giant Size 5 and 6, an unused cover for Giant Size 5, and all the original material published in the Fantastic Four Marvel Treasury Edition.Not the best Fantastic Four masterwork but the production standards are as good as ever. Recommended.

This is the second of two volumes that cover the 25 year postwar history of the British Light Aircraft. The book is a laminated hardcover, 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", of 398 pages. The only color is the author's photo on the rear cover.This book covers the aircraft (and some projects) in alphabetical by manufacturer format. It is immensely entertaining and informative. It is also well illustrated by some well chosen black and white photographs and occasionally a reproduced contemporary advertisement or drawing. Some of the aircraft are illustrated with conventional three view drawings. These are on the crude side but do adequately convey the specifics of the aircraft in question.One strongly gets the impression that very little editing or production assistance was provided to the author by the publisher. He was very much left to fend for himself. The text is littered with typos like "as" instead of "was" and the like. There are also many misstatements like the Bristol Mercury being a sleeve valve engine or magnesium being an aluminum alloy that would never have slipped through had a professional editor gone over the manuscript. After warning us that the Auster designations are not a particularly useful way of sorting through the various Auster products the author does not exactly clear the matter up. A family tree would have been very helpful here and a more involved publisher could have provided one.Although the book can be read in its own right if one is primarily interested in aircraft details I strongly recommend reading Volume I first. Not only does it set the proper political, economic, and technical contexts in which these aircraft were developed it also contains many more photos of the aircraft covered. Only in Volume I does one get a peek inside the cockpit of the Chrislea Ace for a look at its unique control system. In Volume II the reader is merely told that John Taylor built his monoplane in his flat and had to pass the components through an upstairs window; in Volume I there are photos of this interesting process.Highly recommended despite the rather mediocre production values and sloppy editing. The author is not only an historian but a participant and this makes his two volume work an even greater value.

After 150 volumes in this long running series there can't really be too many WWI era aircraft yet to be covered, certainly not if we restrict ourselves to the western front. There are still aircraft to be covered although the folks at Albatros Production must be hoarding them like precious gems at this stage. The 150th volume in the Windsock Datafile series covers the Austro-Hungarian Phonix C.1 two-seater.The book is consistent with the others in the series. It's a 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", 32 page, stapled card cover. Like the more recent Datafiles the card covers are coated on both sides so color can be properly displayed on the inside and outside front and rear covers. The front cover has the normal full cover painting and the rear cover the normal 3 color profiles, though the aircraft didn't have too many distinct color schemes. The inside front has color photos of factory models of the aircraft and a museum exhibit of the observer's gun. The inside rear has color photos of propeller decals and a fabric fragment.The text is well written and meticulously researched if the comprehensive notes are anything to go by. The aircraft history not only covers the service in Austro-Hungarian colors but also service in the nations formed from the breakup of the Hapsburg empire and post war service and new production in Sweden. The text is supported by a great many black and white photos. There are also six pages of line drawings in 1/72nd and 1/48th scale.It's a rare Windsock Datafile that can't be highly recommended. This one is not one of those exceptions.

By now Windsock Datafile readers know that "at War" in the title means that the book is an update of a previous release. In this case, Windsock Datafile 35, authored by the late Peter M Grosz, devoted to the classic Rumpler C.IV, gets a facelift.The current book is still an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", stapled card cover. The page count is expanded to 40, up from the 36 pages of Windsock Datafile 35. The line drawings are more extensive in the current book with 7 pages of 1/72nd and 1/48th scale drawings compared to 3 pages in the earlier book. The color profiles are more numerous as well with the inside front and rear covers as well as the rear cover devoted to 7 new profiles including some plan views. Another feature of many "at War" titles is present here as well. There are 4 pages of color photographs of restored examples.The text relies heavily on the Grosz original but does reflect research done since its 1992 publication. There are many new black and white photographs to support the text, however.Highly recommended whether one has the Grosz original or not.

This is the 18th (No. 16018) book in Kagero's Super Drawings in 3D series. The series seems to be doing well for Kagero if the rate of releases is any indication. Like others in the series this is an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4" (European A4), stapled card cover with 88 interior pages. The "interior" is a necessary modifier because the page numbering includes the card covers in this series for some reason. The book also includes an unbound foldout and a pair of 3D glasses (sigh). If buying secondhand make sure these are included. The books in this series usually come in a sealed transparent sleeve when new.The book kicks off with an 8 page history of the ship with a primary focus on the Pearl Harbor attack and the circumstances of her loss. I understand that a lot of new research has been done in the last 10 years or so, mainly with computer simulation brought to bear, and the text seems to reflect this. However, it is also clear that the text and the graphics are at odds at some points. The text implies that 4 3" single guns were installed in place of the unavailable quad 1.1" guns but the graphics show (correctly, I believe) empty positions.The meat of the book, as always, is the CAD drawings of the ship from innumerable angles. The quality is outstanding; the captions are something of a letdown. Some captions are attached to the wrong drawing. Some are repeated word for word. And most are not nearly as informative as they could be. The exclusive use of metric measurements is not appropriate for a ship designed to English units. Gun calibers rendered as 356 mm or 127 mm are okay since the English equivalents are well known. But describing searchlights as 30 cm, 60 cm, and 90 cm and boats as 8 m, 10 m, and 12 m without the English units is just unacceptable.This is the first book (I think) that has a painting-like centerspread, similar to the title pages the series has had for a while. These are not paintings but "3D visualizations", that is, computer generated. However created, they look great.Unfortunately, this book features the return of 3D anaglyphs which require the 3D glasses to render the depth. I have a horrible time getting this feature to work since I have poor eyesight without my conventional glasses. I think this feature is little more than a gimmick in any case.The foldout depicts the ship in conventional line drawings with five views in 1/350th scale on one side and some perspective line drawings of the superstructure on the other side.The series is heavily into large ships of the WWII era but at least they featured one built much earlier. Surely an aircraft carrier, a destroyer, or even an MTB, S-boote, or PT boat is due for a book?Highly recommended.

This is the 14th book in publisher Jakab's unnamed series devoted to aircraft with a Czech connection. This is the second (and last) volume devoted to the French Morane-Saulnier MS.406. The book is in hardcovers this time; many earlier volumes were card covers. In any event it's 8-1/2" x 12" and has 96 pages. Like others in this series the text is bilingual with Czech (I'm guessing) in the left column and English in the right.The book picks up right where the first volume left off. It begins with the relative strengths of the French and German fighter arms before the German assault on May 10, 1940. Then we get a very detailed, almost sortie by sortie, history of the aircraft throughout the Battle of France up to the Armistice. The activities of Czech airmen serving with the French are highlighted. The story continues with the service of the MS.406 with the Vichy regime. This is more extensive than one might suppose with action ranging from North Africa to Syria to Indochina to Madagascar. The Free French service is covered. The service in Switzerland to enforce Swiss neutrality is related. Finnish service in the so-called "Continuation War" is quite detailed. There are brief notes describing the aircraft in German, Italian, and Croatian colors. The text concludes with a detailed technical description.The text is supported throughout by many black and white photographs. In addition, there are eight pages of color profiles and two pages of 1/72nd scale six view line drawings of the D3801 and the Morsko-Morane, respectively Swiss and Finnish MS.406 upgrades.The English translation is only fair but usually comprehensible. Another annoyance is the use of abbreviations for many French and Finnish ranks without explanation, for example, "Cne.". The internet saved some frustration here.Highly recommended for anyone with an interest in this aircraft.

This is the 6th book in Czech publisher Jakab's unnamed series devoted to aircraft with Czech connections. It's a square bound, 8-1/4" x 11-3/4" card cover. Color is restricted to the color profiles; the front cover has a colorized photo while the rear cover is devoted to other Jakab books. The text is in two columns; the left in Czech (I presume) and the right in English.The book is the first of two(?) devoted to the French Morane-Saulnier MS.406 C1. The text is somewhat more comprehensive than the title would suggest. The whole MS.406 family of aircraft including the MS.405, MS.407, MS.410, etc are covered. The text follows the background, design, and development of the aircraft and the service history up to the day of the German offensive in the West in May, 1940. The service history in Finland during the Winter War against the Soviets is also covered in some detail. The brief and uneventful service in Turkey is also covered. The text is supported by many black and white photographs. These are not of the highest quality but no doubt the best available. The Czech connection is through the service of Czech airmen in France flying the aircraft after the German annexation of Bohemia and Moravia.The book concludes with four pages reproducing drawings and photos from period technical literature, three pages of 1/72nd scale, six view line drawings of the MS.405 C1, MS.406 C1, and MS. 410 C1, and eight pages of color profiles of various aircraft.The next volume(s) will no doubt finish the story off. The book is highly recommended. The English translation is not perfect but is an improvement on previous volumes in this series.

The 94th book in the thirty year plus span of the Naval Fighters series is devoted to the F7U-1, Chance Vought's innovative but ultimately unsuccessful fighter. It is consistent with other books in the series, a square bound, 8-1/2" x 11", 128 page card cover, with color restricted to the front and rear covers.The contents are much different from most Naval Fighters titles, though. Where most Naval Fighters books devote a few pages at most to the background, design, and development this book is almost entirely devoted to these issues. This is virtually a cradle to grave, blow by blow account of the F7U-1 program from conception as the Navy's first swept wing, afterburning, transonic fighter to test aircraft for the redesigned F7U-3. It is important to note that this book does not cover the F7U-3 program except where it intersects the F7U-1. Other Vought proposals based on the F7U-1 and competitors are also covered.The book meticulously covers all aspects of F7U-1 development in the context of the times - shrinking budgets in the late 1940s and desperation to get a swept wing fighter into naval service once the MiG-15 appeared in Korea. The airframe and engine problems are gone into in fine detail. The text is supported throughout by many black and white photographs, contemporary drawings, and even some drawings that have been specially prepared for this book.The only reservation I have about the book is that it is aimed at a reader with considerable aeronautical knowledge. If phrases like "marginal lateral stability" and the like mean little to you the value of the book will be diminished. Other than that the book tends to be a little too "Navy centric"; other than pilots Vought personnel are rarely if ever named. I've read elsewhere that this was the last aircraft that longtime Vought designer Rex Beisel was involved with; no hint of that here.Also this should not be considered a replacement for the earlier Naval Fighters book covering the F7U series as a whole. The two are actually complementary.Highly recommended. There's no hint if a follow on book covering the F7U-3 is in the works. That would be great, of course, but the present book stands fine on its own.

Physically, the book is in the standard Ginter format. It's an 8-1/2" x 11", square bound card cover with 240 interior pages. Color (unfortunately) is restricted to the front and rear covers. It is also the first book in the Air Force Legends series in 6 years.I suspect that this book was originally intended for another publisher. This book would not have been out of place as a Specialty Press title when Specialty still issued new works. It is organized unlike any other Ginter title I've read.The book has a brief 6 page introduction (numbered A-F). Then there are 6 chapters dealing with the major B-50 subtypes.1. The B-50A2. The B-50B, RB-50B, YB-50C, B/RB-54A and XB-55 (includes the later RB-50E, F, and G models)3. B-50D and WB-50D4. The KB-50, KB-50J, and KB-50K Tankers5. B-50 Test and Research & Development Aircraft6. The TB-50A, TB-50D, and TB-50H TrainersThe book closes with 5 tables and a comprehensive list of sources. The inside rear cover reviews the Academy plastic kits.All is outstanding. The book is very well illustrated with black and white photos and drawings from contemporary technical literature. Everything is very well organized with each subtype getting a more or less uniform treatment so the reader comes away with a very comprehensive look at the aircraft. The illustrations are very well captioned.The text complements the graphical material perfectly. Outstanding are the modifications necessary to enable the aircraft to carry atomic bombs. There is also a fascinating look into how complex (and ponderous) the preparation for a nuclear attack was circa 1950. The early (pre-flying boom) refueling techniques, weather reconnaissance, photo-mapping, photo-reconnaissance, and training aircraft are also expertly placed into the context of their times.The only error I could find was the use of "procession" when "precession" was meant. That's really reaching, of course. Other than that, the only complaints are the shortcomings of the publisher. The overall lack of color is the biggest disappointment. It would have added a great deal to the book. A table of contents and an index would also have added to the value of the book as a standard reference.Very highly recommended. If for some reason the Ginter connection puts you off (and it really shouldn't; Ginter publishes many fine aircraft monographs) rest assured that this book doesn't suffer from most of the Ginter shortcomings.

...but otherwise fairly solid.The books collected in this volume tend to be not as highly regarded as they might otherwise have been. The reason is that the "Celestial Madonna" storyline immediately follows the issues in this collection and that the stories in this collection suffer by comparison. Be that as it may, taken on their own terms most of the stories in this volume hold up fairly well.The first five issues, 120-124, feature the Avengers vs. the Zodiac which segues into the origin of Mantis. Ongoing subplots include the mental breakdown of the Swordsman, Mantis' increasing attraction to the Vision, and the latter's estrangement from the Scarlet Witch. It's fairly action packed and entertaining with a few silly plot points like the Avengers being launched into space to kill them (just blowing them up wasn't good enough?) and the Stalker being sensitive to sunlight.We then get into the first crossover with Captain Marvel with the Avengers defeating Thanos' space fleet. Captain Marvel 33 is then reprinted for no discernible reason other than Mantis appearing in a few panels. This is a complete waste of space in an Avengers Masterwork as the reader has no hope of following that intricate plot.We then get a Giant Size Avengers which reintroduces the Golden Age Whizzer back into continuity as the father of Quicksilver and the Scarlet Witch and something else. The Whizzer's fatherhood doesn't last, however.There is a one issue spotlight on the Black Panther and then we get another crossover, this time with the Fantastic Four and the Inhumans for the wedding of Quicksilver and Crystal. It isn't too bad but having just read it in Marvel Masterworks Fantastic Four 15 lessened the impact.The book closes with an interesting development with Agatha Harkness and the Scarlet Witch. The issue (and the collection as a whole) ends on a cliffhanger which kicks off the aforementioned "Celestial Madonna" storyline.The primary creative weakness is the art. Lots of pencillers and inkers and some work better than others. The art in the first few issues in this volume looks horribly rushed.Steve Englehart contributes a very informative introduction. An interesting item is the practice at the time to draw one page of art and then blow it up to a two page spread to pad the page count.Recommended to fans of the Masterworks and/or the Avengers. Not great by any means but fun and entertaining.

The 148th book in the long running Windsock Datafile series is, like all the others, an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", stapled card cover. There are 32 interior pages and color is restricted to the card covers although in the case of the interior rear cover it is just a promotion for the other de Havilland titles in this series.The book covers an aircraft not previously dealt with in this series, a rarer and rarer event as the number of volumes mount. The AMC DH1 and DH1A was the first of a distinguished line of aircraft that extended over two companies and many decades. Unfortunately, the aircraft itself had few opportunities to distinguish itself being built in small numbers and not as highly thought of as the contemporary FE.2 series.The book is well up to the high standards of the series. There is an informative text supported by many black and white photographs, six pages of high quality line drawings in 1/72nd and 1/48th scales, and three color profiles on the rear cover. Much is made of the fact that the de Havilland designs of the WWI era are now complete in the Windsock series. Interestingly, the Aircraft Manufacturing Company, which built the WWI de Havilland designs, is now rendered "AMC" instead of the former "Airco". The text claims that the former was the practice during the war. If that was the case then where did "Airco", in widespread use for many decades even in the early Windsocks, come from?In any event the book is highly recommended.

This is number 60 in the long running Naval Fighters series by publisher (and for this volume, author) Steve Ginter. It is a stapled card cover, 8-1/2" x 11", of 56 pages. Color, as usual, is restricted to the front and rear covers.The book is a unit by unit history of the F9F Panther in USMC service and service with the Reserves, Blue Angels aerobatic team, and Argentine Navy also included. This sort of thing is Ginter's bread and butter (though not usually mine). Since several units served in the Korean War with this aircraft the histories are more interesting than they might otherwise have been. It seems well detailed with pilots who lost their lives either in combat or accidents properly memorialized.The histories as always are complemented by many black and white photographs so modelers will have no shortage of schemes to depict. A book aimed at modelers really demands more color but the series apparently does not command that kind of budget.Recommend for those familiar with the strengths and weaknesses of the series. You know what you're in for.

This is the 15th book in Kagero's excellent and groundbreaking Super Drawings in 3D series (No. 16015). It is an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4" stapled card cover with 80 pages of interior text and color throughout. I say interior pages because the page numbering includes the card covers for reasons that escape me as the interior covers are blank.The book has all the strengths of the other books in this series, namely the many pages of impressive CAD (computer aided design) drawings of near photographic quality. The views are spectacular. The captions do the best they can but there is so much detail in these drawings that one sometimes wishes that labels could be placed on the drawings proper so one is never unclear about which level is the battle bridge or compass bridge or anti-aircraft platform or whatever. What one really wants is access to the computer model itself so the reader can peel back and replace drawing levels to suit or pick any view he wishes. I think that will happen eventually; in the meantime I'm grateful for these books.There is also an unbound foldout with large scale conventional line drawings of the ship. If buying secondhand be sure that this is included.The text in these books is always somewhat basic but in this case I feel the text is fairly misleading. The text describes the ship essentially as built but the ship is depicted as it appeared very late in her career. The ship went through a very thorough rebuilding in between but there is little hint of this in the text. The title, Battlecruiser - fast battleship Haruna, is probably the best indication the book provides. The horsepower doubled, the ship acquired blisters, the armor (especially the deck armor) was improved dramatically but the text gives little indication and no details of all this. I think the problem was that text from author Skwiot's book on Japanese battleships might have been reused here without adequate editing.Some readers might have a problem with the subject of the book being a sister ship of the subject of an earlier book in this series (Kongo was covered in 16005). I don't have a big problem with this (the books on the Scharnhorst and Gneisenau also depict sister ships) but would have preferred a ship of another class.The book, despite these flaws, can be heartily recommended. The vast majority of readers are probably very familiar with the ship's design history.

This is one of AJ Press' "middle period" releases. It has an expanded page count that takes it out of the stapled bound format that was used early on but the unbound foldouts (sometimes two or three or more) that are ubiquitous today haven't yet made an appearance. The captions are also still exclusively in Polish and not Polish and English like their current releases. Also the title of the series has just changed form the original "Monografie Morskie" to the current "Encyklopedia Okretow Wojennych". The current book carries a 1999 copyright date.Physically, the book is an 8-1/4" x 11-3/4" (European A4), square bound, 100 page card cover. Color is restricted to the cover painting and the nine color profiles distributed equally among the front and rear inside covers and rear cover. The text is entirely and exclusively Polish.The book is the third volume (of four) covering the German U-boat arm in World War II. The book appears to cover the U-boat types from IX to XIV. The Type IX is given the bulk of coverage, naturally. The graphical content will be the primary to the English speaker. There are lots of black and white photographs, many of indifferent quality, but many of interest also. There are also some body lines and line drawings of the various (including unbuilt types). The Type IXC and C/40 subtypes also have a couple of pages devoted to the specific conning tower and ballast tank ventilation holes of the individual U-boats which will be of interest to the modeller.There are also 4 pages (with drawings and photographs) detailing various attempts to launch rockets from U-boats. Finally, the last 9 pages (again, with drawings and photographs) detail the history of accommodating aircraft aboard U-boats.Although not entirely without interest to those of us with no Polish skills the book might be worthwhile if the price is right. AJ Press will no doubt eventually be giving each U-boat type expanded coverage as they have for the Type VII but that can take a long time given their current rate of release for new titles.

In many respects this book is excellent. It has a lot of interesting information about the discovery and composition of exoplanets. The discovery techniques are gone into in commendable detail, especially the transit method. There is also a fair bit of historical background as well. The composition relies more on computer models but the breadth of possible planets (sort of like a planetary "main sequence") is also gone into in some detail. The astronomy end of the book is great.The biology part is a very different matter. Things start off well enough as the details of the origins of terrestrial life are reviewed. Then the author makes the plausible enough claim that a certain amount of geological activity is necessary for the development of life and earth's is just barely adequate. Super-earths, he asserts, with their greater geological activity would be more hospitable to the development of life.By this point we have arrived at the last chapter. The book has built up to and has been pointing to the climax promised in the the book's title, "The Life of Super-Earths". I was expecting the author to tie up the biology and astronomy and show how life on super-earths would differ from life on earth. Naturally this would be somewhat speculative but that doesn't matter.What we receive instead is a rather lame chapter on synthetic biology. Super-earths disappear from the narrative and we get a description of what biologists are hoping to do in the laboratory. All in all, I felt cheated. The promised punch line never came.The book can be recommended nonetheless as a relative recent recapitulation of events surrounding exoplanets, both discovery and theory.The Kindle edition was quite serviceable with a few flaws. There was an amusing glitch where exponents were linked to chapter notes. The print index was printed without the page numbers and was unlinked making it completely useless except as suggestions of terms to search for. Finally, the book was organized into two parts of six chapters each but only the parts are marked on the progress bar. Sparse progress bars are a particular annoyance as it doesn't give the reader enough indication about how much further he has to read before reaching a convenient stopping point.

I decided to buy this book after the author's appearance on the Monstertalk podcast.The book gives every appearance of being comprehensive and definitive. The entire history of the lake monster phenomena is gone into in meticulous detail, possibly a little too meticulous. The first part of the book does drag a little as we are treated to sighting after sighting with little or no analysis. However, the author does have method to all this as he later contrasts the way the sightings have evolved over the centuries, specifically the "head like a horse's" meme that takes off after appearing in a popular regional magazine.The book then gets into high gear once the sightings get elevated to the level of an ongoing controversy. The parts about the Mansi photograph, the often eccentric monster proponents, and various possibilities floated to explain the sightings are expertly and very entertainingly done. The book is also very comprehensively documented. The author appears to have read everything ever committed to print about Champ.Also adding to the authority of the book is the author's acquaintance with most of the major figures surrounding Champ, both proponents and skeptics. It is clear that the author has no particular ax to grind.Complaints are minor. The author used a few words which baffled me and my Kindle dictionary such as "shonky". The online urban dictionary cleared that one up. The author also deviates from a strict chronological story at a few points which caused some confusion. There is also some repetition, especially with respect to the problems with the Mansi photograph which are gone into several times at different places.The Kindle edition is first rate with only one complaint that I have had with a lot of Kindle books. The book only has a few items in the table of contents which makes for a sparse progress bar. The sub-chapters needed to be marked on the progress bar as well.Highly recommended and I am encouraged to check out this author's other works.

The is was the 7th Goldsborough Nero Wolfe novel written with the permission of Rex Stout's estate. Like the rest of Goldsborough's efforts I thought the characterization was more or less spot on with a few minor reservations. Firstly, his Archie Goodwin is just a bit much; the wise cracks and sarcasm are overemphasized. Secondly, the whole broken elevator episode seemed gratuitous like Goldsborough was showing off how he can write Wolfe out of his element.The biggest gripes I have are with the plot. There is a certain "Alice in Wonderland" feel to it as Wolfe is asked to investigate the death of a writer who has taken over writing novels about a popular detective created by a recently deceased writer. And this writer, while adequately capturing the atmosphere and character nuances of his predecessor's fictional world, has trouble constructing interesting plots. These kind of life imitating art plot devices can be made to work but I think this particular device was more annoying than clever.Worse, I think the plot has a huge hole in it. While Wolfe's deductions are perfectly reasonable I couldn't for the life of me understand why the murderer would then confess. There didn't seem to be any proof whatsoever.The Kindle edition of this book has a few flaws but nothing major. The worst is that the table of contents, though linked, does not appear in the Kindle menu. It can be reached by going to the beginning and going back a page. There are a couple of footnotes to previous (Stout) novels that are not linked so one has to go to the end of the chapter to see them. The book also seems to have been scanned from the print edition so there are quite a few OCR glitches like stray periods and apostrophes.The book can be recommended but it is not up to vintage Stout levels or even the best Goldsborough. Nevertheless, it has its charms.

This Queen mystery is in a transitional period between the plot driven early books and the "psychological" period that began with Calamity Town. Queen the author has by this time streamlined his books by jettisoning the clumsy frames of the early ones supposedly written by "J. J. McC." The mid-story "Challenge to the Reader" has also disappeared. Queen the detective is no longer a stuffed shirt but has not completely morphed into the likeable, sensitive, and vulnerable character to come.The mystery is fairly deep with a lot of complexity and easily a half dozen plausible suspects. Queen mixes it up somewhat by making a lot of the suspects quite sympathetic which impaired this reader's efforts to be objective. The murder itself was quite plausible with few strains on the credulity of the reader. On the other hand, I had just read The American Gun Mystery so maybe it looked better by comparison.Besides the mystery itself Queen spends much time lampooning Hollywood culture in particular and California in general. There is no doubt much real life experience being put to use here.The Kindle version of the book has a few flaws but nothing major. The Table of Contents is present and linked but does not appear in the menu. It can be reached easily enough however by going to the beginning and going back a page. The progress bar is sparsely populated with only the 5 "Parts" marked instead of the more numerous 21 "Chapters". Annoying, but not a deal breaker.All in all, fairly entertaining and perplexing. Recommended.

I came across this book by accident. I read the first six Goldsborough Nero Wolfe novels in the late '80s and early '90s and then when no more appeared I assumed the series had run its course. Actually, there was one more in the mid '90s and then this one much later. A title like "Archie Meets Nero Wolfe" is irresistible so I bought and downloaded the Kindle version.The book was good but lacked a certain inventiveness (just like the title). My main disappointment is that the entire puzzle that Rex Stout had assembled is already complete with the exception of one piece, Archie Goodwin. Wolfe lives in his brownstone with Fritz and Theodore and the orchids with the office with the large globe and one red and many yellow chairs. He makes his living as a private detective hiring legmen like Saul Panzer, Fred Durkin, and Orrie Cather. He butts heads with the police represented by Cramer, Rowcliffe, and Stebbins. Etc, etc, etc. Archie is merely fitted into position. One wished that Goldsborough had backed up somewhat to a point where the puzzle was missing a few more pieces.Despite this the book does have some interesting scenes. The book is set in the early 1930s at the depths of the great depression. Archie is a 19 year old kid, worldly for his age, trying to make it in the big city. After getting fired from a night watchman job he tries to carve out a niche as a private detective working for Del Bascom. These pre-Wolfe preliminaries are the best part of the book in my opinion. Other interesting parts are Archie's first impressions of the people he will be spending a lifetime among.Like I said, Goldsborough, as in his previous novels, plays it pretty conservative, not straying too far from what Stout established. In his previous novels which were continuations of the Stout canon that was probably a wise course. In this prequel I think a little more inventiveness was indicated. Despite this, I recommend the book.The Kindle edition is perfectly formatted and a joy to read. Absolutely no issues. Indeed, Wolfe's large vocabulary probably makes the Kindle the preferred format.

This is an early Ellery Queen mystery written and set in the early 1930s. These early Queen mysteries are somewhat of a mixed bag. On the one hand the stories are usually fairly cleverly plotted and the murders ingenuous. On the other hand Ellery Queen is depicted as an upper class stuffed shirt with extremely annoying speech patterns. Think of Philo Vance on a particularly bad day. The reader is usually prepared to put up with the latter to enjoy the former but fortunately Queen the author humanizes Queen the detective as the series of books approached the 1940s.To my mind The American Gun Mystery is one of the weaker early Queen novels. The plot involves murder during a rodeo in a crowded 20,000 seat arena. Trying to plot a baffling mystery given such circumstances is a very ambitious task which Queen does not quite pull off. Granted, in any "classic" murder mystery the reader grants the author a certain literary license in the way of plausibility. In real life complex murder plans are impossible to pull off because no murderer can possibly control the large number of real life variables. All we ask of an author is not to stretch our credulity too far. At several points in Queen's plot he asks way too much of the reader. Without going into details it is beyond reason that with 20,000 potential witnesses that the murderer and the subsequent hiding of the gun will not be witnessed by scores of people in the act. Certainly no rational murderer would risk this.Other annoyances are the completely unnecessary framing sequence and introduction by "J.J.McC." This serves no real purpose and Queen thankfully jettisoned it as he moved away from strictly "whodunits" to "whydunits".Still, the book is not a waste of time but I would not recommend it as one's first Ellery Queen book. I am reviewing the Kindle edition of the book and everything is properly formatted. There are a few "OCR" gremlins where "along" becomes "alone" for example but these are few and far between.

This is the second novel from Elizabeth Dean featuring Emma Marsh, the first being Murder is a Collector's Item and the last being Murder a Mile High. The book was an entertaining read but was more enjoyable for the humorous elements, the well drawn characters, and the glimpse into the world of 1940 Boston than the mystery proper.The mystery was fairly lightweight but not without interest. This is the sort of murder where any number of people could have done it; the difficulty is all in narrowing the field down. Dean is no Christie or Carr but the details of the murders do show some planning.I think the plot might have been easier to follow had there been a floor plan or two included. The details of the manor do not seem to have been adequately described and in any event a picture is worth a thousand words. There are also some unfamiliar rooms like "buttery". These situations are where e-books shine. I hope the Dean books eventually have Kindle editions.Recommended. Rue Morgue Press made no mistake bringing this book back into print.

This is the 90th volume in the long running Warpaint series. It is a 64 page, 8-1/4" x 11-3/4", stapled card cover with color throughout. Besides the numbered 64 pages there is an 8 page equivalent bound foldout with 1/72nd line drawings so make sure this is included if buying second hand.In common with other titles in the series there are six pages of color profiles, six to a page, and one page with a four view color drawing. There are four tables covering production, performance, available kits/decals, and operational units. There is a wide selection of photographs, many of which are in color. The usual "In Detail" section of close-up photos is a generous 5 pages in this volume. There is also 4 pages of nose art close-up photographs.It is the text that lets this book down so badly. It is either poorly written or very poorly edited. The text meanders all over the place and gets repetitive. Some sections begin in chronological order and then back up and repeat the same events. There are numerous typos that range from the merely annoying ("Curtiss LeMay" instead of the correct "Curtis LeMay") to the incomprehensible ("...while an arrestor hook was fitted with an arrestor hook").This is a shame because there is a fair amount of material here that was completely new to me such as the "Reed Project" and the British B-17C (Fortress I) operations. The author seems to have done a fair amount of original research and not just cribbed from the many published sources available on this famous aircraft but his presentation leaves much to be desired.The book can be recommended to the modeler who has been satisfied with the Warpaint titles in the past. The general enthusiast has much better books to choose from; this one is not hopeless, merely exasperating.

As always, Avery provides an excellent product - as well as a wide range of online templates to create ones own business cards!PROS:1) Can be used with most Ink Jet printers. (I have a Canon Pixma, and the card stock worked beautifully.)2) Can be used with MS Word -- both Mac and PC.3) Can be used with Avery's online selection of  templates. And the templates work with both Mac and PC, too!4) Stock works well with both black-and-white and designs.5) These Clean Edge Business cards are two-side printable!6) End result looks well and professionally done.CONS:NoneI really like Avery's Business Cards, because they're designed to be "plug and play."  Because I've always used MS Word to create business cards, I decided to try one of Avery's online templates.  I just typed in my info and out came printed business cards! Then, I opened the MS Word route made two-sided cards.  Both sets of cards came out beautifully.  And I did a happy dance, because, well, I'm Old and I remember the days when online templates didn't work with my Macs.If you need to make business cards on the quick, try  Avery's Two-Sided Printable Clean Edge Business Cards.  You'll be happy you did.

Because I'm Vegan, I'm always in the market for good quality stainless cookware.  This Tri-Ply OXO is the real deal. It's just heavy *enough* and beautifully designed.  So far, I've used to stir-fry veggies, pan-fry veggie patties and make pancakes -- all on medium to lower heat.PROS1) It cooks evenly and well on low heat, medium and medium high heat.  Whether you're using olive oil or nut butter or water, it really does cook veggies beautifully.  And the pancakes it produced were light brown and lovely... Once you cook with this pan, you'll NEVER go back to so-called "non-stick."2) It's a mid-weight skillet, so it's easy to take over to the sink to clean after use. Grin.3) It's a good size for one person or for a small family.  And it would make a nice house-warming present for cooks new or old.  One doesn't need to be a professional chef to enjoy cooking with this Tri-Ply wonder.4) I did find that it seemed to cook things at a slightly lower temp that I used with my old skillet.CONSNone.If you're a cook who adds a dash of "love" to every organic dish you make,  this pan belongs in your collection.PS-- I accidentally used a *stainless* spoon to stir my Kayla's Four Alarm Rice yesterday -- and I didn't ruin the pan! Oh, I love my OXO!

I really love this wee, rubbery stapler! I have severe Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy in both hands. When I'm having a flare, hard metal staplers are difficult for me to use. This funky, wee Bostich Dynamo is a game changer.PROS:1) Great for Home, School, and  Office. It's small enough for older elementary school kids to use -- and it's comfortable for adults, too.2) The rubbery bottom is a compartment that holds extra staples. Who doesn't need extra staples???3) Light-weight and easy to use.  Even with with edaema, I was able to staple six papers together without an issue!4) It's blue. It stands out amid all my other steel brown staplers from 1982.5) It's rubbery top grip is ergonomic.CONSNone that I could find.Because of my RSD, I fell in mad goofy love with this little, blue stapler that makes it possible for me to staple documents without causing me pain.  My "blue sweetie" now has a place of honor on my computer desk.

Speaking as a both True Crime junkie and a Lapsed Catholic, I liked this book.  A lot.  I cut my baby teeth on stories of visions of Mary and the saints who had with them. I was also raised to understand that power within the Church comes to women *only* through mysticism and death.  The fact that the nuns of  Sant'Ambrogio lifted one of their own into "sainthood" in total defiance of the Vatican doesn't surprise me, as having a saint in the family brings attention-- and wealth -- to a convent. I'm not shocked that a young novice mistress wanted a cut of the local “saint’s” power and attention, nor am I shocked that she'd poison a fellow religious in order to keep said power and attention.  (Sex with the mysterious “American” was icing on the cake.) The fact is that the scandal of the Nuns of Sant'Ambrigio was to be *expected* in a world where feminine power remains exceedingly rare.Wolf's thorough, scholarly study is one of power, sexual intrigue, and poison wrapped in a cult of sainthood. Although, I had to concentrate in order to digest the formal language used in some of the quoted documents,  I enjoyed the way the story unfolded.  The author made the world and people that created the scandal understandable and very real.  Take away the period “clothing” and the events of the scandal could happen within any sheltered or closed community today.I spent a stormy weekend curled up with a cup of tea and The Nuns of Sant'Ambrogio. I’m happy I did.

On A Clear Day is NOT my cup of words. At all.  Speaking as a woman with Learning Differences, I couldn't wrap my brain around its meandering, babbling style.  I was lost and bored both at the same time!  Unfortunately for me,  On A Clear Day is quite simply an "off day."  After my fourth try at reading it, I just couldn't give it any more time nor energy.

I tried to like this book.
