I really did.PROS:1) It's written for younger middle school children.2)There's no bad language, sex, or violence.3) It's easy to read.CONS1) It's boring.2)The author switches between TWO First Person points of view - a personal pet peeve of mine. This plot device is Not Good Writing and needs to Stop.Now That You're Here is a science fiction romance that desperately wants to be the next Big Thing.  Maybe book two will be better...

The Frangipani Hotel is one of the most delightfully strange novels I've read in a long, long time. Its ghosts are fully-formed and sometimes horrifying, sometimes *haunting.*  (And not all of them are *ghosts*, either,  but other familial monsters lurking in Phi's murky personal history.)  I don't want to give away the secrets hidden within the rooms of the Frangipani.  I want you to be drawn into its universe as I was -- lulled and then jolted by what lurks inside.Ms. Kuppersmith's writing is full and rich.  And speaking as a writer, reading The Frangipani Hotel was a delight -- a haunted delight, but a delight just the same -- because I didn't find myself wanting to change a single word.  The author's ghosts belong to another world entirely... I loved this book.  I really, really did.And I'm still pondering a question that Grandma raised in the first chapter: "Do we ever really escape?"

I love these YogaAddict Yoga Socks and Gloves.PROS1) They fit snugly/well.  This is *very* important to me, because I prefer a snug fit with NO wiggle room.2) They're truly non-slip and work well with my yoga mat.3) They're hand wash or machine wash delicate and dry flat/drip dry.  I lived on the wild side and washed them on delicate in a lingerie bag and plopped 'em on my sweater dryer-- and they washed up beautifully.4) For folks with RSDS, the YogaAddict gloves are so *comfortable,* I've worn them for warmth when my joints are flared.  Awesome.5) The toes of the socks aren't constricting and have a natural fit.  Love them!6) The gloves are actually mitts.YogaAddict makes a really nice non-slip product.  I went from practicing yoga with bare feet and hands to wearing the gloves and socks almost every session. I'm getting so much use out of the gloves.

This series just gets better and better.  Having gotten his feet wet documenting monumental weird history in season one, Don Wildman just keeps on giving us the strange and wonderful in season 2.Delights of Monumental Mysteries Season 2:1) Mike the Headless Chicken, Fruita Colorado's chicken of the paradise -- honored yearly at Fruita's Mike The Headless Chicken Day. I've been a devoted fan of Mike's ever since I saw an old postcard of the Headless One, when I was five.2) "Superman Vs the KKK. " I knew this story but still learned a thing or two. Everybody should know the power of the man in blue!3) Lucy the Elephant. Y'all know I'm a sucker for Elephant Tales.4)" The Kidnapping of the Sacred Cod." Oh, yes.  It's all true, peeps!6) Blind Tom, the musical prodigy who went from being a slave to freedom. Finally. (Raises interesting questions about what *really* happened to slaves with disabilities.)7)"Newsboys Vs The World."  The true story of the newsboys' war against the papers of NYC.8) WASPS and how we weren't supposed to know about the women pilots of World War II.9) And lastly, that "camp" in California that was supposed to be a hub for the Nazis.  Creepy and very scary. (Don WIldman is so obsessed with it, he's visited its ruins several times in several different shows.)Monumental Mysteries is goofy, witty and wise.  It educates us as it delights us.  I can't get enough of it!

I love Monumental Mysteries.  It's brain candy for the historically inclined.  Goofy and wonderful and sometimes wise, this is a show I'll stay home to watch.  Even my Toy Poodle Service Dog is entranced by it.Series Delights in No Particular Order:1) Smoky the Yorkie - yet another "taxidermied" hero dog. (Don Wildman says "taxidermied" and makes me laugh.)2) The Teen Vampire from Maine. See it, know it, love it!3) The Sad Demise of the First Circus Elephant -- another sad elephant tale.4) Ellis Island and The Sailing Stones.5) Grand Central Station & The Occult.6) Eureka Springs' Crescent Hotal AKA "The Cancer Hotel" -- I love and miss the Crescent.  My family stayed there when she was being restored.  I miss its haunted self.7) Buffalo Wings Monument and the sadly beautiful Audrey Munson, who modeled for statuary all over NYC.8) Heddy Lamar, film icon and inventor of secret tech. Who knew?This series is totally worth owning.  Watch it again and again and amaze your friends with your knowledge of weird history and the monuments devoted to it.

I like this book.  A lot.  It encourages folks to realize that animals "talk" with each other just as we do.PROS:1) Short chapters are easy to understand and digest-- and leave one wanting to know even more.2) Would be an excellent book for older children and teens who are interested in animals.  (I think it would be great for parents who home school. It's a good "read together book.")3) Every chapter is heavily illustrated.4) This book encourages the appreciation of animals and their rich worlds.5) It's a great gift for those who think you're crazy for thinking your pet has his/her own language. Grin.CONS:Not a one.I wish that I'd had this book growing up.  I love language and everything about the *way* we communicate.  Reading this book reminded me over and over that human beings aren't the only species that communicates. Nor are we the only beings with emotional lives.  The Secret Language of Animals is a gem.

I'm digging the Jouer Cosmetics line.  I love creme eye crayons, because they are versatile as all get out.  This Jouer Creme Eye Crayon is a beautiful coppery color.PROS:1) Made in the USA2) No Animal Testing3) Can be used as an eyeliner or as an eyeshadow.4) I'm not sensitive to it -- and I'm very sensitive.5) Goes on smooth and neat -- and looks great with powder shadows.6) It lasted all day long.7) Comes in a tube about the width of a "laddie" pencil, making it easier to hold. Score!If you like coppery colors, greens and gold tones, this lovely creme eyeshadow crayon will work for you.  I'm fair olive, and Baroque goes with my golden eyes.  Frankly, I'm using it to replace my brown eye pencil, because Baroque really POPS with my gold shadows.

I don't know about you, but I'm always looking for fun lip gloss. Not only does this  Jouer lip gloss come in a cool square tube, it's a nifty shade of pink.  I loved it immediately, as I'm a very fair olive.PROS1) No flavor.2) No animal testing.3) No lip-poofing additives.4) Goes on lovely and smooth -- and it really does moisturize.5) Comes in a stunning array of colors.6) "Jouer" means To Play in French. And who doesn't love to play with make-up?

I'm not exaggerating when I say that *Nurses and Midwives in Nazi Germany: The "Euthanasia Programs" is the last, *best* book about Aktion T4.  Not only do the editors provide an excellent over-view of how nurses and midwives participated in killing the disabled and mentally ill, but also Susan Benedict gives us new, detailed information on the nurses of Meseritz. For the first time ever, I read excerpts from the nurses' trial testimonies.  And I read the testimony of Elly Buchenschuss, the caregiver who said NO.( Because of German law, we cannot know the last names of the perpetrators, but I can honor Elly Buchenschuss the caregiver who refused to kill.) Ms. Benedict writes about the so-called consequences and the nurses' acquittals.  I cannot over-emphasize the importance of the chapter on Meseritz-Obrawalde. It alone would be worth the price of the book, but the other chapters are just as informative and every bit as important.This book shows how healthcare professionals were drawn into the machine of medicalized murder.  Doctors were given a choice whether or not  to participate in T-4, but nurses, in general, weren't.  Doctors gave orders, nurses followed those orders.  As Sister points out, many doctors and nurses of the day truly believed in the "euthanasia" of so-called "useless eaters." When an entire system is in place to kill, it's not easy to say No -- especially, when people were sent to concentration camps for distributing Von Galen's sermon.  But there were people like Elly who said No -- and none that we know of were sent away to concentration camps. Think about that.Nurses and Midwives in Nazi Germany: The "Euthanasia Programs" belongs on the shelf beside the works of Friedlander and Burleigh.  It's one of the top three books written about Aktion T-4 *in any language.* Buy this book for your archive, for your library, for your own use.  It's more than scholarly -- it's inherently readable.  When you read it, you'll learn so very much. I know I did.Speaking as both a T-4 Scholar and as a woman with multiple disabilities, I implore you to learn about the history written in this book. Forewarned is forearmed; and history has a way of repeating itself.

I love to walk early in the morning, before it gets hot outside.  This headlamp makes it possible for me to walk before sunrise without having to worry about tripping on rocks and such.  I *really* like this headlamp.PROS:1) It comes complete and ready to go out of the box2) The headband is wide enough to be comfortable and easy to adjust. I'm a Headache Person, and I can wear this!3) The headlamp itself is adjustable both in aim and in brightness.4) Great for biking and walking and running -- and for wearing to the bathroom in the dark, when you're camping.5) I used this headlamp to go through CDs in a dark part of my house. SCORE!6) The on/off and brightness buttons are easy to use -- even while you're wearing it.7) The headlamp is removable, so that the band can be cleaned.NOTE: LED lights are *bright.*  Please be aware of this when setting aim.  Also, this headlamp is designed for use by adults.

This little scarf hanger is the real deal!  It holds 10-20 scarves, depending upon thickness. ( If you're storing silk scarves that are thin, you can easily store two in one holder.)PROS1) The smooth holders won't snag your delicate silk scarves.  Keeps your knit scarves from stretching out if you hang them folded in half.2) No more fold marks on your silk and cotton scares, because the hangers are smooth and won't leave marks3) If you're storing scares or silk ties that are thin width, you can easily store two in one holder4) Stores a lot of scarves in a little space.5) Protects all of your scarves from wrinkling and snagging.6) It's "Green."CON - and it's not really a con at all1) This design isn't for thick knitted or crocheted winter scarves.This is a great little hanger/organizer.  It's well-designed and will last you a lifetime.

I took my time reading Under Magnolia: A Southern Memoir. You see, one of my dearest, best Sister Friends died, and I needed a good, slow read.  I needed something *real.* And that's what I got with this book.For those of you familiar with Mayes' *Under The Tuscan Sun*, you're in for something different. Good and different.  The author delivers a memoir that is rich in the good and the bad and the dysfunctional.  Real life is touching and messy and a whole lot of learning.  I think I loved this book, because I needed to read someone else's life.  I needed to read about *her* world and not think about the depths of mine.  But Mayes gave me a Good Read instead of a place for escape.Under Magnolia is not Southern Gothic.  It's Southern Real. And that's a whole lot of good right there. This book touched me unlike any other in a long, long time. That says it all.Thank you, Ms. Mayes.  You enriched my world when I really needed it.

I chose this vacuum, because it's a "lightweight" -- and for its Swivel-Steering.  I am *more* than pleased with its performance and delighted that it's designed to brush dirt off of walls and other borders into the path of the vacuum. I really worked this Oreck before I wrote my review.  I've been able to vacuum my entire 900 foot house TWICE and have yet to fill its bag!  I mean, it sucked up Poodle hair poofies and dust from when my wall was sanded with equal ease. Score!PROS1) For being a "light weight," it's certainly not a light-weight when it comes to design.2) Really does flatten out to get underneath tables, etc.3) Has brushes on the sides that guide dust and dirt off of walls and other borders and into the vacuum's path. I love those wee brushes!4) The Swivel-Steering makes vacuuming more of a pleasure than a chore.5) It's a bagged vacuum BUT its Oreck bags are HEPA filter in make.6) It's the *perfect* basic vacuum. Period. Great for your dorm, home or apartment!7) It's backed by the Oreck Warranty, which is one of the best in the biz.CONS1) It's a bagged vacuum. If you live in a small town or in an area without an Oreck store, you will have to order your bags online. I speak from experience.(This is the Perfect Basic Vacuum, so I'm not counting its lack of attachments has a Con.)Because I live in constant chronic pain, vacuuming is NOT a joy for me.  However, the Oreck Magnesium RS is the one upright I've owned that I can actually *use* with ease. It's now my official Downstairs Vacuum.  Love it!

Coffee is my secret pleasure.  I drink a cup once every six weeks or so -- and, as a result, I'm Demanding.  This SterlingPro French Press elevates the process of making coffee into a *pleasure* PLUS it makes a great cup of coffee.PROS1) It's a French Press, which in my world just makes smoother coffee.2) It's well-designed. If one follows the directions precisely, there's no muss or fuss.3) The glass pot is dishwasher safe. (I put it on the upper rack and it came out fine.)4) The double-screens mean no grounds in your coffee. I MEAN it! No Grounds.5) Comes with a set of extra screens.6) Ideal for making your morning cuppa plus your thermos cuppa for on the go!7) Can be used for making less than 1 Liter without affecting the process. (I made a half carafe full, and the coffee was still smooth.)This is my experience with a well-made French Press. It's a dream! It really is.  If one follows the instructions, it's nearly impossible to make a bad cup of coffee with this thing.

If there'd been Rock Stars back in 1919, Sgt. Stubby would've been one. As it was, Stubby posed for pictures and led parades with equal aplomb.  His grin was beloved of the nation -- the United States. And he was a Pit Bull mix. I've loved Sergeant Stubby since I was a little girl.  In my Spent Youth, there wasn't Breed Specific Legislation - there was just the story about a Bully Dog  named Stubby, his Man Bob Conroy and the War to End All Wars.I loved this book.  I loved it, because Ms. Bausum brought the *dog* Stubby back into our lives. This book is really a love letter to what the relationship between humans and their dogs *can* and *should* be.  Even in the worst of times, Stubby loved and protected his Man, Bob Conroy. And Conroy returned the favor.I believe that Stubby's story has been ignored for two reasons over the years:  the years post WWI have been wiped clean by the horrors of the Spanish 'Flu, and Stubby was a Bully Breed. This wonderful book wipes the slate clean and starts at the Beginning of Conroy's and Stubby's relationship. From there, it's all about Love.While, this isn't a children's book, it could be read by and discussed with children of ages 10 and up who are interested in Sgt Stubby and in non-demonizing images of the Bully Breeds. (It would make a GREAT book report after a trip to the Smithsonian!) *Sergeant Stubby* should be required reading in *all* police departments, because officers need the chance to see Pit Bulls in ways other than Mean. (Read a book, save a dog's life!)  Stubby's story can and has opened hearts and minds to the Love of a dog.PROS:1) It's all about Sgt Stubby.2) But it's really about Love.3) And... Drum roll, please.... Sgt Stubby was a Pit Bull mix! And he had The Smile. Yes, he did! Y'all know I love me a Pittie Smile.SORT OF A CON1) Stubby was "stuffed" after his death.  His "taxidermied body" now resides in the Smithsonian and has appeared on the TV Series *Mysteries at the Museum.*  I first saw Stubby at the Smithsonian and heard his story as a child.  I wasn't upset, but many of the adults in my world were.*Sergeant Stubby: How a Stray Dog And His Best Friend Helped Win World War I and Stole the Heart of a Nation* belongs in every War Dog lover's library, and every dog owner's library. But mostly, give it to your friends and relatives who think you're crazy because you Love YOUR dog so much. Dollars to donuts, wee Sgt Stubby will melt their hearts -- just as he did the author's.

I used to think this stuff was too greasy for me...until I needed something to help heal a couple of shave biopsy sites incurred during a routine skin cancer screening. My doctor and others said that Vaseline was just as good as Aquaphor as the point of using either was to keep the sites moist enough not to ever completely dry out. Once they dry out, the skin doesn't "fill in" anymore and you will end up with a bad scar. So...I used the Vaseline to start, then I tried Polysporin.Well, after a week, I really wasn't seeing any improvement, so I decided to give Aquaphor a try instead. It's NOT just "glorified petroleum jelly" as the derm office said. It has panthenol in it, for one thing, and is less than half petrolatum. It has a stickier, less oily feel to it as well, so it stays where you put it unlike pet.jelly which melts and runs. No scent, of course, so that's great. From the maker: "Unlike petroleum jelly, it creates a semi-occlusive barrier on skin, which creates an ideal healing environment that enables the flow of water and oxygen. It also absorbs the recovering skin’s own natural wound exudates, keeping the wound moist to help promote healing."Well, it must be the reason, because within a couple of days of using the Aquaphor (and bandaids to keep the wounds protected), I noticed a marked reduction in the redness of the sites as well as a noticable calming of the skin. Another few days and the deep depression or "divet" quality of the sites started to fill in with new skin. Yay.It's been three weeks now and both sites are fairly healed, no bandaids necessary, both filled in significantly. I know they will continue to heal over the coming months, and that this will be aided by using the Aquaphor.Bottom line: Far superior to Vaseline or Polysporin for biopsy sites. I think it may be the different, thicker consistency and the panthenol (protein) that helps rebuild the tissue. I am going to use it exclusively from now on, plus try it for cuts, burns, and even just dry skin.

When you have combination skin AND you are becoming "wiser" every passing year, ahem...finding a scrub that isn't too harsh yet still works is a challenge.Some scrubs are way too sharp or the grit size is too large and can feel like they are meant to take off more than just the dull, dead skin. (I'll leave the walnut shells for the walnuts). Others are too small and delicate, made of synthetic, or disintegrate too fast and you end up with more like just cream on your skin, which does nothing except leave a film.This scrub is natural chia seed, so no super sharp edges or plasticky damaging beads. The scent is much like their apricot cleansing milk...very light and of course, natural. I use this scrub in the shower on my face and sometimes on my elbows, shoulders, and neck. Yes, neck. It's that gentle.So, my trifecta for soft skin is as follows: Andalou Naturals Apricot Probiotic Cleansing Milk, 6 Ounce, Andalou Naturals Chia Plus Omega Radiant Skin Polish, 2 Ounce, and Andalou Naturals Super Goji Peptide Perfecting Cream, 1.7 Ounce. If I'm going out in the sun for any length of time for day time, I love their combo sun screen/moisturizer, too, Age Defying Ultra Sheer Daily Defense 2.7 fl oz Lotion. They make a lot of other goodies, but these are my core go-to products.I also like the fact that I can get them for a lot less on Amazon and they are always available (unlike Whole Foods lately!)Hope my review helps someone!

Picked this beauty up at DSW for a great price and in a color that apparently is not made anymore...ruby. This explorer style is substantial and the zipper fobs look to be real brass. Wow. But mostly, the leather quality if superb. Butter soft and smells great, too.The zippers run smoothly and easily, the credit card slots are just right in tightness and width. And unlike some leather wallets, the INSIDE of it is 100% leather, too.Another great product from Fossil. I'm going to go look for the Explorer bag that goes with this. Hope it's as beautiful!

There are only two brands of bar soap I can/will use now: Vanicream bar and this Dove Sensitive. I do have to say, though, that the Dove bar (though both are fragrance free) has less of a scent of any kind than the Vanicream. Both lather very well, both are non-irritating, but I find that the Dove Sensitive is more moisturizing than the Vanicream. I don't know about the folks saying the Dove Sensitive smells weird (if you want weird, try Cetaphil bar...yikes!). I don't smell anything on this bar.Very enjoyable lather, creamy, and you can use it on your face. Super softening and great as a shaving cream for legs, too. It's a keeper.

There are only two brands of bar soap I can/will use now: Vanicream bar and this Dove Sensitive. I do have to say, though, that the Dove bar (though both are fragrance free) has less of a scent of any kind than the Vanicream. I don't smell anything on this bar.Very enjoyable lather, creamy, and you can use it on your face. Super softening and great as a shaving cream for legs, too. It's a keeper.

What this shampoo does for my hair is amazing. I've noticed that when I use my Andalou sulfate-free shampoo, I have to use a lot of conditioner. No prob. But when I use the Therappe, one shampoo and I get a really conditioned, silky feel even when I'm still in the shower. Sometimes I think I could get away with no conditioner at all...but I still go ahead and use my Andalou Brilliant Shine conditioner or Shikai Intensive conditioner just for protecting my ends. (My hair is fine, thick, almost straight, tangles easily, and is just past my shoulders).And that scent....wow. Nothing smells like it. It's like coconut, but not annoyingly so. Such a nice experience lathering this up! It's like a little trip to the islands.When I go to comb my hair, the comb slides right through easily. And when I blow dry it out straight, I've noticed that it is smoother, healthier feeling, has fewer fly-aways, and looks good longer...even into the second day. I normally have to wash my hair every day to get it to feel right, but I can go two with this shampoo.

Got this product along with the Thera Tears eye drops (single vial form) on the advice of my ophthalmologist to take organic flax oil of some kind for blepharitis and dry eye. It's an interesting product; you've got a generous amount of vitamin e (natural version) to preserve the oils, and also to keep you from depleting your own vitamin E as you process the omega-3s. The fish oil is molecularly distilled, so it's likely clean, yet they leave it in the natural triglyceride form. However, there is no listing on the label for what country the fish and flax oil comes from or from what kind of fish. That info is pretty standard for most companies. You might write to them to find out.Also, minus one star because they use soy bean oil (not sure how much as the label does not state) as a carrier for the vitamin E. Also, plant omega-3s in flax oil are only absorbed at a rate of about 4% in humans, as opposed to 100% for the omega-3s in fish oil. So when it says on the label that you are getting 1,200mg of omega-3, that's fish and flax combined, so not all usable omega-3. Something to think about.And keep in mind, this product is not registered on the IFOS website which is the best third-party testing lab for fish oils. But perhaps that's because of mixing in flax oil, making it impossible to test it this way. Not sure.The vitamin E is a problem for me as there is a LOT in this product, over 600% of your daily value. It, as well as other high-dose Es I have tried, causes me great alertness in the daytime and enhanced memory....but the massive vivid dreams won't let me sleep long enough. I keep waking up! I thought about cutting the dose down to one or two softgels, but then the omega-3 would be too low.The serving size is 3 softgels, each a small 850mg in size, with Amazon pricing about 36 a day, equaling:1,600mg of fish oil (triglyceride form)1,000mg organic flax oil, yielding totals of:EPA 450 (from fish omega-3)DHA 300 (from fish omega-3)ALA 450 (plant omega-3)Vitamin E as natural d-alpha tocopherol acetate:183IU (over 600% of your daily value!)Mixed tocopherals including gamma:20So, all in all, Thera Tears is a pretty good deal. Good quality, great price, very convenient.

The front of the triquetra is 3/8 of an inch wide, so they will take up a bit of space on the average ear lobe. Very nice knots, shiny, but still antique looking. I took off one start due to lots of tarnish that had to be cleaned off. But no biggee. They are a nice weight, pretty design, great price.

As I get older, and though I have no serious eye issues now (other than astigmatic presbyopia), I have noticed that my vision isn't what it used to be. I get my regular exams (just went yesterday and all is good), but I do have floaters and I've noticed that my night vision isn't quite as sharp as it used to be. So, in reading about the research into eye supplements (what works, what doesn't), of course I came across the AREDS1 and 2 studies, and discussions on omega-3, lutein, and zeaxanthin. From the American Optometric Association site on the subject:"Beyond reducing the risk of developing eye disease, separate studies have shown that lutein and zeaxanthin improve visual performance in AMD patients, cataract patients and individuals with good health. Although there is no set recommended daily intake for lutein and zeaxanthin, most recent studies show a health benefit for lutein supplementation at 10 mg/day and zeaxanthin supplementation at 2 mg/day." And although omega-3 is important, it wasn't as powerful as the lutein/zea combo. You can read the total outcome of the AREDS2 study at www.areds2.org.So, when I saw this product from Nordic, I was intrigued. Nordic has included a generous amount of DHA, at 788mg and EPA at 158mg, and 20mg of lutein and 4mg of zeaxanthin in two softgels--the perfect lutein/zea ratio. So, following the AOA and AREDS2 guidelines, you really only need to take one of these to get your 10mg of lutein and 2mg of zeaxanthin. Even at one softgel, you are still getting plenty of DHA at 394mg plus 95mg of EPA. Plus, in one softgel, you get 15IU of natural vitamin E, half the day's total. And since these are supplements...you will be adding to these totals with your great diet of lutein/zea-rich foods, like kale, spinach, and broccoli. Most people should have more than enough at day's end.All in all, a brilliant product and adjustable to boot. Oh, and FYI; their Omega Vision is the EXACT same product, it's just marketed to the consumer instead of optometric professionals like the ProDHA Eye is. There is no difference in the two...but the price of this one is a bit nicer on Amazon. :)

I wondered why the borage oil from NOW Foods was so much cheaper than that of say, Nature's Way or Barlean's or Health from the Sun...I finally got an answer from the company about where they source their oil from. It could have been Canada, New Zealand, or perhaps England, since most of the world's quality borage oil comes from these countries.It's from China. I'm seeing a trend in their choices now: This borage oil is sourced from China; they use hexane to extract their black currant oil, but don't say so on the label; and their "pure" NKO Krill oil, at least for a while, was really a cheaper blend of krill oils, but they never said so on the label.So, I went with Nature's Way Borage Oil 1300mg, 60 Softgels instead. It's sourced from Canada.But that's why we do these reviews, double check with the manufacturers on ingredients and sourcing, etc.

I wondered why the borage oil from NOW Foods was so much cheaper than that of say, Nature's Way or Barlean's or Health from the Sun...I finally got an answer from the company about where they source their oil from. It could have been Canada, New Zealand, or perhaps England, since most of the world's quality borage oil comes from these countries.It's from China. I'm seeing a trend in their choices now: This borage oil is sourced from China; they use hexane to extract their black currant oil, but don't say so on the label; and their "pure" NKO Krill oil, at least for a while, was really a cheaper blend of krill oils, but they never said so on the label.So, I went with Nature's Way Borage Oil 1300mg, 60 Softgels instead. It's sourced from Canada. If you don't mind a liquid, you might also check out Nordic Naturals - Nordic GLA (Unflavored) - 4oz. This one is sourced from New Zealand.But that's why we do these reviews, double check with the manufacturers on ingredients and sourcing, etc.

As we age, our ability to make gamma linolenic acid (GLA) starts to wane. Our skin can get dryer and thinner along with other lovely side effects. I decided to try a GLA oil to see if I could see any skin improvement in texture or moisture. I checked out borage oil and evening primrose oil (EPO) as well. While borage oil has the highest yield of GLA per milligram, there is no omega-3 as in black currant, and there is always the possibility of left over pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs) that may contribute to liver damage. EPO is the weakest of the GLA oils, plus it can have undesirable estrogenic effects. Black currant oil is right in the middle; good yield of GLA and no known side effects, PLUS you get omega-3.It's important to know that this black currant oil is NOT hexane-extracted, like NOW Foods and many others. It is cold-pressed, much like olive oil, so you are left with clean, pure BCO.This 1,000mg size is decent and easy to get down. If it is too big for some, this also comes in a half-size 500mg version. Health From The Sun Black Currant Oil Softgels,  500 mg, 180 Count. It allows you to take one in the morning and one at night, if you wish. Either way, you're still getting a good amount of GLA. (Their sister company, Solaray, also makes a compact 600mg size, also cold-pressed, here Solaray Hexane Free Black Currant Seed Oil Gla, 90 mg, 90 Count.)My only "beef" with this product is that the gelatin source is porcine (pork) as it says on the label. I give them credit for at least telling us (probably for those who cannot eat pork products) as most manufacturers just say "gelatin" and leave it at that. Usually, unless otherwise stated "gelatin" means beef. For those who can't use pork products, they do make these in a veggie gelatin in the 1,000mg size. Check them out at:Health From The Sun 100% Vegetarian Black Currant Oil Softgels, 60-Count.I will report back if my skin dryness improves!

There was another review about this product and the hexane issue, so I chose to investigate for myself.This product may have hexane in it because that is their extraction process. I just called NOW Foods today and reconfirmed that they do indeed use hexane for extraction. I asked them why they don't put that on the label, and the rep said that "it's a very negative thing to put on a label." lol No kidding. I asked them if there was any residual hexane solvent in the oil, and they said "no, none that is detectable, but we don't want to put that on the label either to draw attention to the fact that we use hexane at all." So, there you go. She also said that "black currant oil CANNOT be cold-pressed." Not true. It's just cheaper to use hexane because the company can get more out of each seed.There may well be no hexane residual in this product, but we as consumers have no way of knowing. What bothers me most is the fact that NOW chose not to tell us anything. This reminds me of their "krill oil blend" issues with NKO...but that's another story. Makes me wonder about their other products as well if this is their way of doing things. They always have the lowest prices...I'm beginning to see why.On the opposite side, I called Health from the Sun about Health from the Sun Black Currant Oil 1000mg, 60-Count and they do cold-pressed, much like the process for olive oil, so what you are left with is pure, clean BCO. Solaray uses the same method, so they're good too. They are a sister company of Health from the Sun, and they make a compact 600mg version softgel that is great: Solaray Hexane Free Black Currant Seed Oil Gla, 90 mg, 90 Count.Hope this helps someone make a more intelligent decision.

The first thing I noticed that was different about these softgels is the size....they are a much more manageable 800mg size instead of the average 1,000mg or even the larger 1,200mg. You take three per serving, so a total of about 2,400mg of wild salmon oil. Pretty normal amount from brand to brand. For those who care, the gelatin is made up of a 80/20 split of bovine/porcine (beef/pork). Therefore, these are not Kosher or Halal.The other thing is the color; a much deeper orangey-red than say, Wholemega or Solgar's, or even Vital Choice's sockeye salmon oil. But that's because Barlean's adds a LOT of additional astaxanthin to this oil, so you are getting substantially more of this antioxident (a whopping 500mcg per serving) than you would naturally get in straight wild salmon oil (normally about 20mcg). This helps to preserve the oil itself, but it is not natural in this case.They also add 1,000IU of vitamin D3, another bonus. But D3 is very inexpensive, and many people take that separately. Also, you get a smidge of Lutein at 6mcg. Not sure why they added this, no one else does, but it doesn't hurt anyone, to be sure.These are 100% pure, whole wild Alaskan salmon, but I don't know what types. I'm trying to find that out, too. It matters because sockeye is the most prized of the salmons for astaxanthin and for stronger omega profiles. (That's why it can get costly).One more thing that matters a great deal is that this oil, unlike most wild salmon oils, is tested by batch with the IFOS (International Fish Oil Standards Program). This is a very well-known and reliable third-party lab (a real lab, not like Consumerlabs.com). You can take any batch number off a bottle of Barlean's Wild and Whole and see exactly what's in it and what's not. Very important.One reason I'm giving it one star off is partly because they feel the need to add ascorbic acid (vitamin c) and citric acid to the oil. According to Barlean's, they are a part of the antioxidant package to support the oil freshness. Yet none of the other leading salmon oils add either of these ingredients. Interesting.Which brings me to the cost of this product. Ouch. I only use retail prices for comparisons because Amazon prices, as we all know, can fluxuate wildly. I bought the 90-count of these today at Whole Foods for a hefty $33. At three a day, that's a month's supply. I also bought New Chapter's Wholemega, 60-count for $22, a month's supply at two a day. I also bought Solgar's wild salmon oil, 120-count for $30, a TWO month's supply at two a day. So, $33, $22, or $15 a month. But then, only Barlean's is IFOS tested...So, if you want substantial extra astaxanthin, a more pleasant size, IFOS testing, and don't mind paying top dollar, these may be just perfect.

What this shampoo does for my hair is amazing. I've noticed that when I use my Andalou sulfate-free shampoo, I have to use a lot of conditioner. No prob. But when I use the Therappe, one shampoo and I get a really conditioned, silky feel even when I'm still in the shower. Sometimes I think I could get away with no conditioner at all...but I still go ahead and use my Andalou Brilliant Shine conditioner or Shikai Intensive conditioner just for protecting my ends. (My hair is fine, thick, almost straight, tangles easily, and is just past my shoulders).And that scent....wow. Nothing smells like it. It's like coconut, but not annoyingly so. Such a nice experience lathering this up! It's like a little trip to the islands.When I go to comb my hair, the comb slides right through easily. And when I blow dry it out straight, I've noticed that it is smoother, healthier feeling, has fewer fly-aways, and looks good longer...even into the second day. I normally have to wash my hair every day to get it to feel right, but I can go two with this shampoo.Now they have just come out with a new version with Caviar Complex. They took out the nettle, rosemary, and added three new proteins and some quats...which to me equals possibly crunchy hair. So, I scoured my neighborhood stores to buy up what I could find of the old formula. Others must have been doing the same as I didn't find much! lol I have no interest in the new formula. It doesn't even smell the same, and that is one of the HUGE selling points of this shampoo. Bummer for all of us.

With two softgels, using molecularly distilled yet not concentrated anchovy/mackerel/sardine oils, you get:With two, 1,000mg size softgel, providing:Total Omega-3 600 mg which consists ofEPA (eicosapentaenoic acid) 320mgDHA(docosahexaenoic acid) 200mgWith two, 1,200mg softgels of their Solgar Wild Alaskan Full Spectrum Omega Supplement, 120 Count, which is not molecularly distilled (different process), you get:Vitamin D3 (as cholecalciferol) 200 IUTotal Omega 3 Fatty Acids 500mg providing:EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid 202 mgDHA (docosahexaenoic acid 180 mgDPA (docosapentaenoic acid) 41 mgOther Omega 3 Fatty Acids 77 mgTotal Omega 5 Fatty Acids 1.9 mgTotal Omega 6 Fatty Acids 48 mgTotal Omega 7 Fatty Acids 192 mgTotal Omega 9 Fatty Acids 384 mgAstaxanthin  20mcgSo, you can see that the total omega-3s and the amount of EPA and DHA in each two-softgel serving of the anchovy/mackerel/sardine product is slightly higher than the wild salmon oil, even though the size of the softgels is smaller. Yet with the salmon oil, you are getting the full natural complement of all the omegas, including the important 7 and 9. And both products are the natural triglyceride form, closest to actually eating fish.I can see using both of these oils together to get the higher omega-3 of the anchovy/sardine and yet the full-spectrum of the salmon oil. Two of each would give you 1,100mg of omega-3 a day, which is perfect for most people. I took one star off because, as a natural product, they are a bit stinky, IMHO.

When I smelled this at my hairdresser's place, I fell in love. Grassy, clean, crisp. Mmm. That's what the two stars are for...But as for the performance of this shampoo, nope. Sadly, like so many "volumizing" products out there, it is very harsh and stripping. This is one way to get volume, I guess, but not the kind you want. There are some very harsh sulfates in this stuff. When I told my hairdresser what I was using, she said "stop." Yes, it was making my thick, fine, wavy hair a dry frizzy mess.Bummer. I still steal a sniff every once in a while in the store...if only it worked for me.

When I first opened the box, I thought that it would be too small of a sign to be seen from the sidewalk by the dog owners. The size is about 9X7 inches. But looking at it after I put it in the lawn, it works just fine. If it were any larger, I think it would look odd for a residence. It would look more like a park sign, and that's not what we want.The sign is made of fairly heavy aluminum, nice quality of enamel paint, good contrast from greenery of the landscaping, so it can be seen well from a distance. The stake is very thick and sturdy and will stand up to a lot of pushing and pulling and hammering, it seems. We have VERY hard soil here in AZ, so I had to smack it with a hammer many times to get it to go in. Just don't hit the sign itself!I chose the wording on this version because we have a problem with off-leash dogs as well as lazy owners not cleaning up after their dogs. The wording is direct, and firm, but still polite. We will see if it works as far as the dog owners paying attention to it. But that isn't really the sign's job....it's the owners'. :)

Got this little "starter kit" very quickly. The vials are glass with little pumps built in (they do not open), just FYI. They were all full and in good shape. Arrived via USPS in a little ziplocked container with bubble wrap securely around them.What I received was slightly different from what was listed as far as names of fragrances. But they listed 11 not 10 (10 is the right number). Here's what I received in my collection:Nectarine Blossom and Honey--First favorite. Sensual and the most natural, like "hey, let's curl up on the couch and snuggle."Wild Bluebell--Second favorite. An unusual flower scent, very "pretty."English Pear and Freesia--Third favorite. Crisp like "hey, let's go for a hike."Blackberry and Bay--Fourth favorite. I really didn't expect to like this one. I mean, bay? Cooking bay? It works somehow. But I smell a little like a holiday dinner.Red Roses--VERY realistic, but not the kind of roses I grow. These are more tea rosey.Orange Blossom--Exactly like an orange blossom, right down to the sort of bitter under tone.Grapefruit--Not what you might expect. Surprisingly manly.Lime Basil and Mandarin--Great, but like many of her scents that are marketed to both men and women...smells a bit too unisex for me.Earl Grey and Cucumber--Tart, tangy and kind of "shouts" out at me. Nope.Pomegranate Noir--Fruity, tangy, earthy, loud. Has a bit of patchouli in it. Not for me. Might be good for a swingin' night club...on someone else.The two scents listed in the product description, Amber and Lavender, and Vanilla and Anise were not in my order. I think those two must be rotated in and out, because I got Red Roses instead. And I'm good with that because I don't like Anise at all anyway and am not a fan of lavender. :)As far as the scents themselves go, wow. I've never smelled Jo Malone scents before, but always heard they were "real." They are. They fade quickly, but that's good. No scent headaches here, no overpowering odors, nothing synthetic. They are the real deal.

IT WORKS! We tried every other humane way to keep off-leash dogs from crapping all over our lawn. We tried the Havahart Critter Ridder (spray and granules), but the dogs couldn't have cared less. We tried a sprinkle of curry powder on "favorite" spots. Nothing.But this, well, this baby works perfectly. Took some time to get adjusted perfectly so only the offenders would be sprayed (not our good dog neighbors), but it is really sensitive and has a great range. You can adjust distance, duration, night, day, all the time, or off, plus how high or low the spray shoots. To get it even lower to the ground, just tilt the device forward a bit. I would advise actually reading all the directions. Really simple and yet helpful.The only issue was some dripping at the hose connector, but I solved this with a dab of Plumber's Putty. No biggee. The unit is FAR superior to the Scarecrow and worth the extra $$ as this one is mostly metal with a brass hose bib and metal foot push. The Scarecrow is ALL plastic. There really is no comparison.We only have it on at night (turn the unit and the hose off during the day) as that's when the offenders come out. The dogs hear the unit click on and so you get the spray and the sound of the water AND the element of surprise. Should start to train the dogs not to come on our lawn. Now if we could only train the off-leash owners.Word of caution: I have accidentally sprayed myself a few times as I forget it's on after a while. haha Just make sure you turn it off before you go running outside! Also, make sure not to turn it on for the night if you are expecting any deliveries....we tagged the Ontrac guy the other day and it was really embarrassing. He was nice about it, but be careful. On the other side of that, it would seem to work to keep solicitors away from your door at night! :)

As we age, our ability to make gamma linoleic acid (GLA) starts to wane. Our skin can get dryer and thinner along with other lovely side effects. I decided to try a GLA oil to see if I could see any skin improvement in texture or moisture. I checked out borage oil and evening primrose oil (EPO) as well. While borage oil has the highest yield of GLA per milligram, there is no omega-3 as in black currant, and there is always the possibility of left over pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs) that may contribute to liver damage. EPO is the weakest of the GLA oils, plus it can have undesirable estrogenic effects. Black currant oil is right in the middle; good yield of GLA plus omega-3 and no known side effects.It's important to know that this black currant oil is NOT hexane-extracted, like NOW Foods and many others. It is cold-pressed, much like olive oil, so you are left with clean, pure BCO.The 500mg size is a great for folks who have problems swallowing larger softgels.It allows you to take one in the morning and one at night, if you wish. I like being able to split the dose. For those who want the "one and done" experience, they come in a 1,000mg version too: Health from the Sun Black Currant Oil 1000mg, 60-Count. (Solaray, a sister company of Health from the Sun, also makes a great compact 600mg size softgel using the same pure cold-pressed method. You can find it here: Solaray Hexane Free Black Currant Seed Oil Gla, 90 mg, 90 Count.)My only "beef" with this product is that the gelatin source is porcine (pork) as it says on the label. I give them credit for at least telling us (probably for those who cannot eat pork products) as most manufacturers just say "gelatin" and leave it at that. Usually, unless otherwise stated "gelatin" means beef. For those who can't use pork products, they do make these in a veggie gelatin in the 1,000mg size. Check them out at:Health From The Sun 100% Vegetarian Black Currant Oil Softgels, 60-Count.I will report back if my skin dryness improves!

Got this to keep neighbor dogs from using our beautiful lawn as a public toilet....with the owners never picking up after them. The dogs couldn't have cared less. Used the oil as well for a double whammy, but they trotted around on it like there was nothing there.On a happy note, though, we are going for the motion-activated sprinkler instead. That should do it!

Got this to keep neighbor dogs from using our beautiful lawn as a public toilet....with the owners never picking up after them. The dogs couldn't have cared less. Used the oil and the granules as well for a double whammy, but they trotted around on it like there was nothing there.On a happy note, though, we are going for the motion-activated sprinkler instead. That should do it!

I would only recommend this type of product for those treating actual conditions such as high triglycerides or heart disease as they are in the concentrated ethyl ester (EE) form, just FYI, not natural triglyceride (TG) like their "Very Finest Fish Oil" softgels and liquid. So, you are getting a bit more EPA and DHA than in the natural oil version in fewer softgels.As with all Carlson's products, these softgels are clean and third-party tested (verifiable on IFOS's website). The size is ok; not a tiny 500mg like some, but not a huge 1,200mg size like so many other high-powered concentrates. These are a do-able 1,000mg and slide down pretty easy.The softgels are, like all of Carlson's softgels, made of beef gelatin (for those of you who prefer not to eat pork gelatin). I like how they include a smidge of vitamin E (10IU) to not only preserve the oil better, but to help you keep from being slightly depleted as you process the omega-3s.The EPA and DHA amounts in this product are almost identical to what's in Nordic Naturals Ultimate Omega, but Carlson doesn't use lemon oil. You get about 80mg more omega-3 in NN than Carlson, so the difference is negligible in that way. Personally, I'd rather have clean, clear gems of EE fish oil than cloudy lemon-flavored torpedoes. Plus, Carlson's is a better value. As for NN's claim to "superior triglyceride form," it's not quite the same as natural triglyceride (TG) form. It's rTG, which is basically converted EE, which is close, but not exact. I do love the Nordic Naturals - Prenatal DHA - Unflavored - 500 mg 180 - Softgel, and take that every day as well for a little brain/eye boost. Tiny softgels and no lemon oil.If you need something even more powerful to treat a particular condition, Carlson The Very Finest Fish Oil Liquid Omega-3 Lemon, 500ml is always a great choice. One little teaspoonful will net you a whopping 1,600mg of omega-3 and it is in the original natural triglyceride form.Compared to their competitors (like Nordic Naturals) the prices cannot be beat. Carlson's tends to keep the prices of their items down to a realistic level, which, to me, speaks to their dedication to help as many people as possible with their oils.Good health and good choices to you.

I give Deep Steep points for trying such a unique combination of grapefruit and bergamot, but it did not work for me at all. The lotion itself is a very nice consistency and soaks in well, but the fragrance for me was rather stifling.I'm still giving it three stars for originality and because the creme itself is very smooth and nice, AND they don't use fake ingredients. Kudos for that.No kudos on this scent.

I give Deep Steep points for trying such a unique combination of grapefruit and bergamot, but it did not work for me at all. It's only saving grace was that it "ran away" quickly. I'm still giving it three stars for originality and because Deep Steep has some other great products, AND they don't use fake ingredients. Kudos for that.No kudos on this scent.

So, there you go. She also said that "black currant oil CANNOT be cold-pressed." Not true. It's just cheaper to use hexane because the company can get more out of each seed.There may well be no hexane residual in this product, but we as consumers have no way of knowing. What bothers me most is the fact that NOW chose not to tell us anything. This reminds me of their "krill oil blend" issues with NKO...but that's another story. Makes me wonder about their other products as well if this is their way of doing things. They always have the lowest prices...I'm beginning to see why.On the opposite side, I called Health from the Sun about Health from the Sun Black Currant Oil 1000mg, 60-Count and they do cold-pressed, much like the process for olive oil, so what you are left with is pure, clean BCO. Solaray uses the same method, so they're good too. They are a sister company of Health from the Sun, and they make a compact 600mg version softgel that is great: Solaray Hexane Free Black Currant Seed Oil Gla, 90 mg, 90 Count.Hope this helps someone make a more intelligent decision.

Because of all the great reviews, I took a chance on these larger earrings. I normally prefer things dime or nickel-sized, but have to say that these larger earrings are just lovely. They are somehow not too heavy even at about the size of a half-dollar at their widest. Gorgeous knotting and shiny, but not garish.Great value, beautiful earrings.
These beauties are about the size of a nickel, but not quite. Perfect weight, and the unique design is spot-on for the Chalice Well's look. Silver Insanity does it again.

Got these to go with the beautiful matching necklace and was not disappointed. Silver Insanity does it again. Substantial weight, yet just right. Gorgeous design, and you can see through the hearts. They do look like butterflies in hearts, as one reviewer pointed out. Lovely!
Nice weight, great definition and you can see through the heart. Beautiful delicate chain as well. A real winner!

I have a beautiful citrine ring in sterling that I received as a gift, and wanted some petite citrine studs to go with it. These seemed like a good deal and lovely.I normally love every single thing I've gotten from Silver Insanity...but these are the first item I've ever received that I can't and don't want to wear. The stones are a bit cloudy, but that I could over look. It's the stems that are the big problem. They seem to have some kind of coating on them and the ends are very rough and sharp. It's like the coating in peeling off in spots and making the surface of the posts uneven, thus causing the roughness. Not good for something that you are not only going to put in your skin, but that will be getting lots of wear from the pushing and pulling on of the backing.As a minor thing, one of the posts is rather crooked as well. Not the greatest construction.I wouldn't give these to anyone, or wear them myself. I may send them back or just chuck them. Not a good buy. Next time, I'll pay more.

I've tried a LOT of fish oils, liquid and gelcaps, and these are actually quite good, though lesser-known. Here are the stats as I see them:Size: These are quite large at 1,250mg size, which is 50mg more than Norwegian Gold Critical Omega, and 250mg more than Nordic Naturals, just for comparison. I took one star off for size as that might put some people off. You might just have to pop these and drink the oil.Potency: 1,000mg of EPA/DHA, PLUS 60mg more of other omega-3, which is great. Most brands use ALL of the omega-3s when they add up the potency, so it can be misleading. These are accurate. You only need one to get a full gram of omega-3 a day.Form: Molecularly distilled for purity and potency, and ethyl ester form. Take before meal with a bit of fat in it for best absorption.Third-Party Certs: IFOS and MSC-certified. Don't usually find either one of those, and usually not both together. Impressive.Color: Almost clear, no enteric coating.Taste and smell of gelcaps: Made of fish gelatin, NOT beef, so no "beefy" scent. This is a plus for me and a lot of other people. They say they are orange flavored (natural), but as has been said, I really don't detect any orange scent or taste. They are just very mild.Freshness: I always break one of the caps from a new bottle open to check the freshness, and these are lovely. They barely smell like anything. The Norwegian Gold caps were really stinky, for instance, as many other fish oils can be even when fresh. Perhaps because these are made in the U.S. from Alaskan pollock and hake, not herring, mackerel, or sardines (caught in Peru and Norway), which are decidedly smellier.Burp-back: None so far, but I still take it before a meal with fat to enhance absorption.Price: Some have said they are expensive, but considering that you are getting a full gram of omega-3 per gelcap, they are really not anymore expensive than other premium ultra-concentrates. Using retail prices, and only looking at omega-3 content, to get about the same omega-3 per serving, you have to pay $30 for a month's supply of Norwegian Gold Super Critical Omega, or $28 for a month's supply of Nordic Naturals Ultimate Omega (and you have to take two gelcaps). Barlean's is $20 per month.Do they work for joint and mental agility improvement? You'll have to test that for yourself!

I received these as a gift a few years ago and have worn them often. They are very versatile as they can be rather dressy or casual, depending on what you are wearing them with. I recently was updating my sterling jewelry, tossing some things that I've grown tired of, debating on others that aren't aging well, but these beauties were a no brainer....keepers. They look as nice as the day I got them!They are shiny, but not overly so as to look fake. They are a nice length and weight, kind of medium. The knotting is very clear and a lovely pattern. Substantial, yet feminine.Silver Insanity is becoming my "go-to" company for good silver; reliable quality, great designs, fast shipping, nice velvet pouches, and no, they aren't on "prime," but it doesn't really matter.

I received this little beauty years ago as a gift and have worn it often. The moon is almost exactly the size of a dime. The loop is sturdy and goes well with the moon. The choice of chain is subtle and works well, too. This is a quality weight item, yet it is not excessively heavy. Perfect for me.I was thrilled to find that Silver Insanity also makes matching earrings Sterling Silver Celtic Knot Crescent Moon Earrings available here on Amazon (also dime-sized), so I scooped those up last week. Just got them today and they are just as lovely as the necklace. I highly recommend them as well.Great quality, prompt shipping, nifty velvet pouch for gift giving, and beautiful designs.

I was really excited about this product, but when I got it, I was bummed to see how much yeast it is brewed from, and that it also has yeast-type probiotics. Doesn't work for me at all.If you don't mind yeast, go for it! For myself, I ended up settling on just pure enzymes, no "extras," and got Renew Life Digestmore Ultra, 90 Count. These are working VERY well and are just the straight stuff (and more affordable, too).

Well, score another one for Renew Life, though they didn't "create" chia seeds...and that's what these are. However, nice packaging, good quality seeds, fresh, and clean of rocks and such. The only thing they might change is to make them organic. (No where on the label does it say this, so I have to think they are not.)I love to just put a tablespoon in a glass, swirl them around and watch them start to gel up. Or, I put them in my morning Greek yogurt mixture and voilá, more nutritional yogurt!Good product. They get extra points for their ever-lovely art work as well. Whoever does the package design these days for their lines gets an A+.
